Author's Preface
I wrote this book because I wanted to give readers real access into every word of Sun Tzu's The Art of War. This book is my attempt to present it in a new, easy-to-read version.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In this book, you will find real examples from military history illustrating every military principle from Sun Tzu' s The Art of War. To help readers fully understand the nuances of how certain military campaigns were fought, some of these examples make multiple appearances in different chapters, each time providing the reader with a different angle.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: As readers make their way through the book, they will learn about the various concepts, strategies, tactics and ways of thinking that make up the art of war. The reading experience is designed to be like a personal helicopter ride, transporting you to the skies above ancient battlefields, with Sun Tzu himself sitting in the seat next to you, explaining in real time how each side is maneuvering their way through the battle, blow by blow. My personal background is in entrepreneurship, so some chapters contain brief discussions of lessons for corporate management and entrepreneurial competitiveness mixed in with the primary content.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But, these are side-notes to the main historical narrative, and a part of my writing process of following where my thoughts take me. This book is not about looking at 'corporate warfare' through the lens of The Art of War. Rather, it is about really getting to the heart of Sun Tzu's masterwork as an ancient text, and understanding what it means in its original context. This book has been built on the shoulders of generations of Chinese scholars who have continued Sun Tzu's life's work by writing their own commentaries about The Art of War. Specifically, this book is based on the writings of 11 commentators who have forged a place in history, and whose work was first compiled in a Song dynasty (960-1279 CE) book, Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu's The Art of War. Each chapter in my book begins with a brief review of their work, before swiftly delving into a deeper analysis and discussion2.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, who are 'The Eleven Commentators?' If you want their names, they are Cao Cao, Meng Shi, Li Quan, Gu Lin, Du You, Du Mu, Chen Hao, Wang Xi, Mei Yaochen, He Shi and Zhang Yu. But who were they, really?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The first to write a commentary on Sun Tzu's work was Cao Cao, who jotted the following musings about his contribution: ¡§I have read many books about war and heard of many military strategies, and of all of these Sun Tzu's writings are the most profound. But it would be impossible for ordinary people to grasp the lessons within, and there is much that is superfluous, and so this text is unable to fulfill its purpose in the world.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
For this reason, I have written a commentary to elucidate its meaning."
Cao Cao spent a lifetime on the campaign trail during the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE). He is a giant figure in the annals of Chinese history, not only for his peerless military mind but also as a rare talent in the art of governance.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Because of his towering historical stature, his commentary has received the most serious attention, and I would assert that his is also the most accurate of all the commentaries. Large parts of this book follow Cao Cao's lead.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Sadly, Cao Cao was very sparing with his words, and what he did write is succinct to a fault. He even said that Sun Tzu was too wordy! After all, Cao Cao was a professional ¡V a powerful warlord and a poet ¡V and he was not writing for the benefit of ordinary people.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: As much as we might wish otherwise, he has left us even fewer words than Sun Tzu himself. About our second commentator, Meng Shi, not much is known regarding his real name, his place of birth, and most other details about his life. We don't even know for sure during which dynasty he lived, although it's possible he lived during the Liang dynasty of the Southern dynasties (420-589 CE) period.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Not much of his commentary is still with us today, but he did leave us some useful material to work with. Next up, Li Quan lived during the Tang dynasty, probably during the reign of Emperor Xuanzong (846-859 CE). He spent part of his life living as a religious hermit, practicing the Dao on Shaoshi Mountain near the Shaolin monastery.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He later was plucked from his humble mountain life, appointed as an administrative assistant to the military commissioner of Jingnan, and later rose to the rank of Censor. He had a lot of opinions and wasn't afraid to speak his mind.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: For instance, he said that Cao Cao's commentary was riddled with mistakes, and so he took it upon himself to write a new interpretation. Though I haven't managed to find any errors in Cao Cao's work, Li Quan's commentary is nonetheless very well written. The commentator Gu Lin lived during the Tang dynasty.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: During the reign of Emperor Dezong (779-805 CE) he served as an advisor to the military governor of Zhaoyi, a man named Li Baozhen. Li sent Gu Lin to bring a rebellious general, Wang Wujun, back in line, which he successfully did.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: As a result, he also managed to destroy Zhu Ci, another general who had rebelled and attempted to establish his own dynasty. Gu Lin was rewarded with noble titles: King of Wuwei Commandery, and Commander-General of the Shence Army. So, this commentator was himself a real military man, and perhaps because he was constantly busy fighting, his observations are short and succinct.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: We can only guess he didn't have much time for writing. Du You is a particularly special character. He served as prime minister of the Imperial court during the middle part of the Tang dynasty, and he lived through the catastrophic An-Shi rebellion that tore China apart.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: His experiences during this hugely destabilizing conflict inspired him to take up the mission of 'devising methods to enrich the country and bring peace to the people'" He spent 36 years of his life painstakingly reviewing ancient texts, and the works of generations of respected scholars.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He traced the origins of contemporary government institutions, decrees and administrative frameworks, all with the aim of learning the lessons of the past to hold up as a mirror to the problems of his own day.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He compiled his research into an encyclopedic tome, known as The Tongdian. Unsurprisingly, Du You's commentary is hugely respected and is an authoritative source. Our next commentator, Du Mu, was Du You's grandson, and after Cao he was the most successful and influential of the reviewers. His output contains a large body of writings, many of which reference examples from various historical battles.

The line, 'We are a house of two hundred volumes,' is a reference to the 200 scrolls of his grandfather Du You's monumental work of scholarship, the Tongdian.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It's hard not to be a little arrogant when you're the scion of a wealthy noble house, and blessed with an outsized amount of talent on top of that. No matter how brilliantly Du Mu lectures on military theory, his manner can be overbearing.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: For example, a phrase that features regularly in his commentary is, 'Cao is mistaken!' This is invariably followed by Du Mu's own explanation of what he believe was actually happening. In any head-to-head comparison between Cao Cao and Du Mu, it would only be natural to trust Cao Cao more. He was, after all, the only one of the two who had actual experience leading troops into battle. But, this doesn't mean that Du Mu's different interpretations of things were entirely wrong.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Generally, when Du Mu says that Cao Cao's wrong about something, the two commentators were talking about different things. Du Mu was a better poet than Cao Cao, who also happened to be a famous poet in his own right.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He was certainly very talented, but he couldn't necessarily understand what Cao Cao was talking about, since he had no battlefield experience and wasn't quite on the same level as Cao Cao academically. There is a Confucius quotation: 'Be always respectful, and you will never face humiliation.' This idea is also in the Confucian text, The Great Learning: ¡§The ruler's words going forth contrary to right, will come back to him in the same way3." The idea is that if you bad-mouth someone, someone else will inevitably bad-mouth you.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Because Du Mu made a habit of saying that Cao Cao was wrong, another writer naturally went out of his way to tell the world that actually it was Du Mu who was wrong. That writer was Chen Hao, the next of our 11 commentators. Chen Hao thought that Du Mu had muddied the waters by discrediting Cao Cao at almost every turn, and so he felt compelled to set the account straight. The words 'Du Mu is wrong, Cao Cao is right' appear often in his commentary, part of his attempt to restore order to academic discussion of Sun Tzu's The Art of War. Chen Hao lived towards the end of the Tang dynasty, and his views about earlier commentators are summarized in historical records: ¡§Chen Hao considered Lord Cao's commentary profound and cryptic, while he considered Du Mu's commentary broad and sweeping. Chen Hao wrote his commentary in order to moderate the gap between Cao and Du." Chen also respected the commentators who came before him as men of great wisdom, and made it his mission to carry their work forward. His thinking was: Sun Tzu has left us this remarkable book, but it's difficult for people to understand it through Cao Cao's commentary because it's just as brief and technical as the main text itself. On the other hand, he ventured, people might be misled by Du Mu's commentary, which although detailed and comprehensive is also undermined by sloppiness and even inaccuracies in some areas.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, Chen Hao decided to build on the foundation left by Cao Cao and Du Mu, and wrote a new commentary. Chinese historians have grouped together these three commentaries - by Cao Cao, Du Mu and Chen Hao - and given them a name: Commentaries of the Three Masters. By studying them together, students stand to gain deeper insight.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Five of the 11 commentators lived during the Tang dynasty: Li Quan, Gu Lin, Du You, Du Mu and Chen Hao. This high concentration is because China became very unstable during the second half of the Tang dynasty, after the An-Shi rebellion.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There was war almost every year, and so scholars were preoccupied with studying military theory much more than usual. This explains why Du Mu, whose grandfather had been a prime minister, became interested in military issues even while he was making a name for himself as a great poet. In this sense, he was very much a product of his times.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: After the Tang dynasty, the dynasty most preoccupied with military matters was the Song dynasty. It started with a period of relative peace, but then a series of events put the country under constant military pressure. There was constant tumult, from the Tangut rebellion, started by Li Yuanhao's declaration of a rival 'Western Xia' dynasty in the northwest, to conflicts with minority ethnic groups in the north. As problems piled up, the Song court was short on both competent generals and experienced troops.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: What was to be done? Desperate, the dynasty's leaders turned to books in search of answers. The country devoted itself to studying the art of war, culminating in the government-compiled primer for military studies, called Seven Military Classics. The first of the seven classics was Sun Tzu's The Art of War, which is how it first became established as a classic text - thanks to the Song government. Against the backdrop of the Song dynasty's military problems, Wang Xi wrote a new commentary.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: However, details of his life cannot be verified in any detail due to a lack of sources. Mei Yaochen was another commentator who's also known as a great poet, and he was a good friend of Ouyang Xiu, one of China's greatest-ever poets. I have used his work often in this book, because his commentary is of a high quality; it is quite succinct and exacting.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Not much is known for sure about the commentator He Shi, not even what his real name is or during which dynasty he lived. We don't have much commentary from him either, but what we do have is worth keeping.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Our final commentator is Zhang Yu, who lived during the Southern Song dynasty. His other writings include a book titled, Biographies of One Hundred Generals. He put a great deal of work into his writings, producing a high-quality commentary that I have used a fair amount throughout this book.

content:

That concludes my introduction of the wise and esteemed 11 commentators of the ancient world. Although they were definitely wise, they and their writings belong to antiquity in many ways. I still had questions that I couldn't find a proper explanation for, so I began to search for commentaries by modern writers. There is no shortage of specialist commentaries about Sun Tzu's The Art of War, but most of them are concerned more with academic research than actual military studies. They are first and foremost works of scholarship, and they aren't concerned with war per se. When a writer writes about war, but is not motivated primarily by actual war, he ends up writing in a certain way, and about certain things - sometimes in a way that seems to actually move the discussion further away from the inherent subject matter. Eventually, I found a book titled, A Translation and Commentary of Sun Tzu's The Art of War4, written by Guo Huaruo and published by the Shanghai Ancient Books Publishing House. This writer, Guo Huaruo, was a Lieutenant General in the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He graduated from the Whampoa Military Academy and was involved in the Northern Expedition military campaign (1926-1928 CE). He also served as second-in-command of the Nanjing military district, and as the vice-director of the Chinese Academy of Military Science.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
His commentary on Sun Tzu's The Art of War is extremely insightful, and I have used it as a reference guide whenever I've been unsure about something, or when different ancient commentators' accounts give contradictory information. The highest pursuit in Chinese scholarship is, in the words of Song dynasty Confucian scholar Zhang Zai, ¡§To establish one's heart for heaven and earth, to establish one's life for the people, to uphold the works of past sages, and to bring a peace that lasts for ten thousand generations."
I hope that this little book may help you, the reader, and that it may honor and carry forward Sun Tzu's work and tradition. Hua Shan
