chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The value system of Sun Tzu's The Art of War

The very first word of Sun Tzu's The Art of War is so often misread. The unwitting reader then veers far off course and away from the actual meaning - and it's all because of differences in value systems.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The word in question is the first word in the title of the first chapter, 'Ji' (?), which is translated as 'plan,' in the chapter title: Calculations. The Chinese word 'ji' has another meaning - 'stratagem'- and also forms part of the title of another ancient Chinese military text, The Thirty-Six Stratagems. Readers often lump Sun Tzu's The Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems in the same category.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
In fact, the two texts have been combined in a single book: Sun Tzu's Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems. And yet, they are not at all the same. Both feature this word ji, but in The Thirty-Six Stratagems, it means something like, 'ingenious strategies,' or 'wily maneuvering.' In The Art of War, ji has nothing to do with ingenious strategies; what he meant by ji is 'making careful calculations.'
So, what does the word ji being interpreted to mean 'ingenious strategies' have to do with value systems? Well, this question touches upon a very human weakness - the desire to come up with some brilliantly clever strategy that can deliver rapid, definitive results.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But this mentality is exactly what Sun Tzu was speaking out against. The Art of War is a book that teaches victory by means of actual, solid strength, not by sneaky stratagems. To Sun Tzu, ji (planning) is a fundamental principle, not a specific strategy that a commander can deploy in battle.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It is obvious and inelegant rather than ingenious and subtle. It's about calculating the balance of power in concrete terms - 'the five factors and seven considerations.'
The 'five factors' are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline. The 'seven considerations' are: (1) Which of the two kings is imbued with the Moral Law?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: (2) Which of the two generals has the most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: (7) In which army is there the greater consistency both in reward and punishment? Basically, it's about comparing the two sides' political situation, timing, geographical conditions, personnel talent, discipline and institutional frameworks. Actually, what Sun Tzu means by ji is the equivalent of the modern-day management studies concept of SWOT, which is used to compare both sides' Strength, Weakness, Opportunity and Threat. But then, what is the objective of 'Calculations?' It's all about knowing which side will win.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
By comparing each side's 'five factors and seven considerations,' you can determine before the war has even begun who will win and who will lose, and thus whether or not your side has the formula for success. The writer Du Mu, in his commentary on The Art of War, offers a clear explanation of the original text:
¡§'Plan' - that is, to 'calculate.' Someone asks: 'What does it mean to calculate?' Someone else responds: 'At its core, it refers to the five factors, which are called: The Moral Law; Heaven; Earth; The Commander; Method; and Discipline.' The first thing to do is to go to the temple and calculate the five factors of your own forces and those of your adversary. After having done this, one can determine who will be the victor and who will be the vanquished.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
When victor and vanquished are determined, then shall you summon the generals and mobilize the people. In the art of war, nothing precedes these five factors. That is why they appear in the first chapter."
What we call the 'formula for success' means first calculating who will win and who will lose, and only going to war once victory is already yours. This is the very core of Sun Tzu's way of thinking - 'First obtain victory, then go to war.' Or, as I like to put it, 'Win first, fight later.'
In all of Chinese history, who was the most brilliant and effective strategist? When Chinese people hear the word ji, the first historical figure who comes to mind is Zhuge Liang.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When the word ji is used to talk about him, it is in the sense of 'ingenious strategies,' and not referring to the five factors and seven considerations. He would never pass muster if judged by these standards - Sun Tzu's standards.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He held not a single advantage over his enemy, the state of Wei, in terms of either SWOT analysis or the Moral Law, Heaven, Earth, Commanders, Method or Discipline. But, he had a dream, and so he summoned his generals, mobilized his people, marched out from the mountains of Qi and rapidly stormed onto the central plains.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: His war brought ruin on the country and the people, and left the fields strewn with corpses. He took huge risks, and the fact that he won involved a generous helping of luck. Yet, despite this, he also had a reputation as the most cautious person alive, someone who never engaged in a battle that he didn't have complete control over, and who retreated at the first sign of a problem.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This begs the question: why did he feel the need to mobilize his troops and start a war in the first place? Zhuge Liang's 'strategy' was a muddled, sloppy version of the concept ji. So, then, why is Zhuge Liang so famous and beloved by the people of China? The answer is that people love a good story, and he is at the center of a truly great one.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Good stories are a common by-product of 'ingenious strategies.'
True strategy, and true victory, do not make for good stories. In fact, they usually seem quite dull. This point actually comes up in Sun Tzu's The Art of War: ¡§Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage." Zhuge Liang became more renowned for his wisdom than anyone else throughout 5,000 years of Chinese history. Yet, 700 years before Zhuge Liang was born, Sun Tzu said: ¡§Good fighters have no reputation for wisdom." In other words, if a man is renowned for his wisdom, he is not a good fighter. When a good fighter does go to war, it's a dull event - not at all story-worthy.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
This is one of the key lessons we have to learn from Sun Tzu's The Art of War. Where the layman sees only what is dull and unremarkable, that is where we will find the great way of the masters. That is where we must go to learn the true skills of the greats. Sun Tzu's 'Reverent Wariness'
For Sun Tzu, 'the art of war' is not the art of fighting battles, but the art of not fighting battles. It is not the art of winning by fighting battles, but the art of winning without fighting battles.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It is not the art of fighting battles first and winning later, but the art of winning first and then fighting battles later. Extract from the original text:
¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected."

Analysis:
Sun Tzu made it quite clear that military affairs are of huge national importance - literally a matter of survival and ruin, life and death. Military affairs must be carefully scrutinized, and never taken lightly.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Sun Tzu considered this point so fundamental to war that he made sure to address it before anything else, at the start of the first chapter of The Art of War. Like Sun Tzu, Confucius also attached great importance to wariness. In the major Confucian text, The Doctrine of the Mean, while expounding its version of the Dao, heavy emphasis is laid on the idea of 'caution and fear.' This is the idea that one should be cautious and not take risks; that one should be scared of the unknown, and always be alert and constantly scrutinizing not only yourself but also anything you may have overlooked or don't know about. At this point, I think we've made it pretty clear that the idea of not fighting battles is a major motif in The Art of War.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If a leader puts into practice all of Sun Tzu's teachings, they will successfully bend their enemy's troops into submission, all while never having to fight a battle. It would be perfectly correct to say that The Art of War is more a study of how not to fight wars than how to fight wars. This partly explains why the only biographical information we have about Sun Tzu's life is very vague, while other generals of the same time period, like Wu Zixu, left many a fabulous tale behind. Consider these words: ¡§Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage, but excel in winning easy battles." When Sun Tzu wrote about 'victory,' he meant the kind of victory that is sealed in the temple while plans are being drawn, not the kind that's snatched from the enemy on the battlefield. This ideal of victory is, from the start, contemptuous of the kind of stirring war stories that become inspiration for poems and songs.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Sun Tzu seeks victory long before battle erupts, a victory in which his troops need never dirty their blades with enemy blood. Do Sun Tzu's warnings about war being 'a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin' only apply to military leaders with armies behind them? Not at all; these words hold meaning for each and every one of us.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For example, behind every move in a company's business operations, behind every pen-stroke, fortunes hang in the balance, lives could be changed, and reputations made or broken. The pen can be straight or crooked, wielded with truth or falsehood.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: One false move, and you can be sure it will come back to bite you, even if in the short term there seems to be no ill effect. How much life and money could be saved if we all embraced this 'reverent wariness,' and this sense of responsibility, and recognized that every move we make could mean either a new lease on life or abject ruin for ourselves, our families, our companies and clients, and indeed for other people and society at large? If I have a job, my workplace is an arena.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It's a place where life and death face off. The way I carry myself through life affects the balance of life and death. This is the wariness and sense of responsibility that I hope every one of us can take into our hearts. Sun Tzu's analytic method for strengths and weaknesses: 'The Five Factors'

Extract from the original text:
¡§The art of war, then, is governed by five constant factors, to be taken into account in one's deliberations, when seeking to determine the conditions obtaining in the field. These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline."

Analysis:
I have already mentioned that the concept of ji (plans) in Sun Tzu's The Art of War is the way of calculating the balance of strengths and weakness between one's own forces and the enemy. As noted, it's in fact very similar to the SWOT analytic model used today in corporate strategy to calculate strengths, weakness, opportunities and threats.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Now, let's talk about how the balance of the five factors is calculated: The Moral Law, Heaven, Earth, the Commander, and Method and Discipline. The 'Moral Law' (the Dao) is about the ruler's ability to obtain the compliance of the people, which is achieved by winning their trust through demonstrating grace.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Basically, it's about whether the people do what you tell them to do. It's about whether your ruler is an enlightened lord who possesses the Moral Law, or a crass despot to whom such a thing is a foreign concept. The Moral Law is about comparing each side's political situation, and the leadership ability of each side's ruler. 'Heaven' and 'Earth' form a pair.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Heaven is about following the timing of nature ('heaven'), and Earth is about having knowledge of the lay of the land. Even if the way you carry out a mission is the same regardless of when you do it, you still have to consider the timing.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If the timing is right, success will follow. But if the timing is wrong, nothing you can do will make it work. Once you have compared the idiosyncrasies of each side's ruler, the natural timing, and the advantageousness of the terrain, it is time to compare 'the Commander.' Whose general is more skillful? This is about appointing someone who is wise, competent and even-handed: a sage.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This is why moles are often used during war - agents who are sent to bribe the enemy ruler's most trusted advisors and ministers. This is the 'stratagem of sowing discord.' Your agent infiltrates the enemy court and feeds the ruler incriminating information about his most capable generals. The aim is for him to call these generals back to court and away from the front lines, and then send out some moron in their place.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's then that you strike. Finally, we compare 'Method and Discipline' (discipline is normally translated as 'law'). This has nothing to do with a country's politics, which is about the Moral Law, or the Dao, more than anything else.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: 'Method and Discipline' are about military law. The commentator Wang Xi wrote, ¡§The art of war is governed by five factors. The Dao of using military force is about harmonious inter-personal relations (this is the most fundamental) and natural timing and favourable terrain (this is auxiliary)." One should only raise an army when all three of these factors have been achieved. Once you've decided to raise an army, you have to choose your generals and your commander-in-chief.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Once the commander-in-chief has been selected, it's time to drill method and discipline. The commander-in-chief must have strong abilities in leadership, formulating clear and strict rules and orders, and ensuring strict obedience. That wraps up our explanation of the order of the five factors: first the 'Moral Law,' then 'Heaven,' followed by 'Earth,' 'the Commander,' and finally 'Method and Discipline.'
The commentator Zhang Yu also makes a point of explaining the order of the five factors. He said the reason 'the Commander' and 'Method and Discipline' are put in last place is that whenever a ruler decides to raise an army to attack some neighboring despot, the first thing to be done, when you're planning in the temple, is to analyze how much loyalty each side's ruler inspires in their people.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Are they are willing to die for him? The next step is to gauge the natural timing: whether going to war would be in keeping with the timing or in conflict with it. Then, the terrain must be analyzed - is it easy or treacherous?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When these three factors are in place, it's time to send your general out into the field. Once your troops have crossed the border and left your country, 'Method and Discipline' are entirely in the hands of your commander. That is why the five factors are put in this order.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
They are used in sequence to calculate and compare each side's strengths and weaknesses, and to form a picture of the prospects of victory or defeat. Victory belongs to the side that is united in desire, from the highest general to the lowest soldier
 
Extract from the original text:
¡§The Moral Law (Dao) causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger."

Analysis:
Sun Tzu's interpretation of the Dao is very clear. It is the 'Moral Law' - the ability to make the people of one mind with their ruler, and the soldiers of one mind with their general.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The winning side will be the one that can achieve this. When the people and the leaders are united, share common moral values and have the same desires, the country has the internal foundation for waging war. This boils down to whether or not the people support the war effort.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: You should only fight if the whole country supports you. If you don't have unanimous support, you shouldn't make any rash moves. This should not be confused with the righteousness of any given war; that is not what Sun Tzu is talking about.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He is concerned with a different question: do the people support the war? Japan's pre-Second World War invasion of China is a good example. If the Dao was about having a righteous cause, then of course Japan did not have the Dao. However, that's not the answer you get if you look at it in terms of whether 'the people are in complete accord with their ruler.' Japanese militaristic propaganda had already whipped the country into wild enthusiasm for war.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The conditions existed where 'they will follow their ruler regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.' For the Japanese people, whether they lived or died did not even enter into the equation, with the most extreme example being the suicidal kamikaze fighter pilots. If you look at China during the Japanese invasion and occupation (1937-1945 CE), it was not a unified state.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
There was constant fighting between regional warlords, on top of which, the Nationalist Party and the Communist Party were engaged in a civil war. The common people yearned for peace. They had no appetite for war, nor did they have a unifying Emperor who could inspire universal loyalty. China was on the losing side of the Japanese invasion for eight years, and lost at the very first of the five factors - Moral Law, which compels people to be 'in complete accord with their ruler.'
The Dao, as it is interpreted by military men, is not about cosmic truths. To them, it's a simple question of whether the people support your war or not.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Are they loyal to the ruler, or aren't they? Are they willing to lay down their life for their country? It's irrelevant whether the war is 'just' or not. Anyone who goes to war will claim that they are on the right side.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: So, how do we know who is on the side of good? We can only even begin to see who 'the good guys' were several years, or perhaps a decade or more, after the war has ended. After that, it takes many decades, or a century, before there is any kind of unanimous verdict. If you want to use the Dao to win a war, the key is to get three things right: policy, publicity (propaganda) and the mind-set of your troops. If you can do that, people will willingly fight by your side. If you make the Dao your first priority, you understand that in war, the state's propaganda machine is just as important as its war machine.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: One could argue that's it's even more important. The Mao-era army leader, Lin Biao, realized the truth of this when he said that anyone attempting to seize power must rely on two barrels: the barrel of the gun, and the barrel of the pen.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: These same two barrels also are vital tools for solidifying power. Some historians in the field of communications studies consider Sun Tzu the first thinker to write about propaganda, and indeed the origins of communications studies lie in military propaganda.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Propaganda Technique in the World War, a book written after the First World War by American political scientist Harold Lasswell, became one of the seminal works of communications studies, and many of its ideas are identical to those of Sun Tzu. Heavenly Timing: Military uses of meteorology
 
Extract from the original text:
¡§Heaven signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons."

Analysis:
Cao Cao commented on this passage: ¡§When launching an attack, conform with Heaven on the basis of Yin and Yang and the four seasons. Hence, it is written in The Methods of the Sima (another of the Seven Military Classics, written by Sima Rangju): 'One does not mobilize troops in winter or summer; this is how one extends love toward the people.'"
But, did Cao Cao stick to his own rules?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Not at all. In fact, he suffered a famous defeat precisely because he didn't heed his own words - the Battle of Redcliff. Before the battle, his adversaries Zhou Yu and Sun Quan had essentially carried out a SWOT analysis. They wrote: ¡§Now is a time of great cold; the horses have no grass to eat, and Cao's troops have travelled far from the Chinese heartland; they are unfamiliar with the conditions in the south and are not yet acclimatized, so they are vulnerable to infectious illnesses; this is not the way one should handle one's army."
Yin and Yang, cold and heat, and the four seasons are a progressive series of concepts. Heaven is made up of two kinds of qi, Yin and Yang.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
When one expands, the other contracts, and it is this fluctuating dynamic that gives rise to cold and heat. The changing balance of cold and heat is marked by the four seasons. In fact, in military discussions there are three layers of meaning within 'Heaven':
1) The grand scheme of things in the world at large ('all under heaven').

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This is about conducting one's worldly business in a way that conforms with Heaven. 2) Observing the stars, the clouds, and qi; burning turtle shells and divining the meaning in the cracks that form. 3) The four seasons; weather forecasting and using weather conditions to one's advantage in war.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The first point is about the macro-level situation and grand strategies. Questions relating to this point are worked out long before raising an army. In discussions of the third point, strategists such as Wu Qi in his Warring States-era (475-221 BCE) book, The Wuzi, analyze weather conditions using a standard set of terms. These include 'strong winds,' 'time of great cold,' 'midsummer' and 'blistering heat.' Different decisions are made depending on the benefits or dangers of the conditions at hand.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Weather can even be used as a weapon. For example, if you plan to use fire against your enemy, you'll need to rely upon the wind, which essentially means relying on 'Heaven.'
Of all three of the aspects of 'Heaven,' the second one is the most talked about: divination. However, talking about it is precisely the key; it is about making sure everyone hears what you are saying.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Basically, it's a kind of propaganda - a useful kind of nonsense that's used to fool one's enemies - but which one should never actually believe in. The famous military leader, Lord Jiang, who advised the first king of the Zhou dynasty, expressed it like this: ¡§A wise man does not personally follow such things, though fools preoccupy themselves with them."
When Zhou Wu, who was to become the first King of Zhou, launched his attack on the tyrant king of the Shang dynasty, his troops were deployed for battle at Gongtou Mountain in Sishui. The weather that day was foul, with wild winds, torrential downpours, and thunder and lightning.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The wind ripped the troops' battle flags and drums to shreds, and as Zhou Wu stood on his war chariot, his bodyguards were scared stupid. Faced with this situation, Lord Jiang said: ¡§In war, it is not necessarily always auspicious to conform with Heaven and the Dao, and likewise it is not always inauspicious to turn against them. However, if you lose control of events and of people, your whole army will be destroyed and you will be lost.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: As for ghosts and gods, Heaven and the Dao, these are things that cannot be seen, cannot be heard. Therefore, a wise man does not concern himself with such things, while fools allow themselves to be constrained by them.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Here, today, you have capable and worthy men. The time to make your move and gain victory is not determined by the auspiciousness of the date, but by the favourableness of events; not by readings of yarrow stalks, but by the auspiciousness of the actual situation. Do not wait and pray, and blessings will follow."
Imediately after Lord Jiang said this, he gave the order to attack. Zhou Wu, the king-to-be, protested: ¡§If we attack now we will be going against the god Taisui! The turtle shell readings are not propitious, the readings from the yarrow stalks are inauspicious, and the stars spell disaster! Please withdraw the troops."
Lord Jiang was infuriated, and said to Zhou Wu: ¡§In our time, the Shang king has executed the sage Bi Gan, imprisoned the sage Qizi, and rules the land with the evil minister Fei Lian. Why should we not overthrow him?"
Lord Jiang then said that the yarrow stalks and turtle shells used in divination were nothing but ¡§dead, dry grass and moldy old bones." He ordered one of his men to bring the stalks and shells to him, and had them burned. Then, he personally led his men into battle.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Zhou Wu followed his lead, and on that day, their enemy - the Shang king - was destroyed. In another example, Liu Yu, founder of the Song of the Southern dynasties, was advancing upon the city of Guanggu, having managed to surround the forces of the non-Chinese Murong people. He was about to give the order to attack when his generals decided to consult a calendar.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They realized that it was an inauspicious day: 'The day of moving toward destruction.' Each of the generals in turn insisted in no uncertain terms that they could not make any moves. But, Liu Yu said to them: ¡§Huh!

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Moving toward destruction... this is very auspicious! I will be moving towards their destruction!" Liu Yu did indeed take the city of Guanggu on that day. There is a popular Chinese saying to express the idea of 'when the time is right.' It translates as: 'When the Heavenly timing is good, when the land is favourable, and when the people are in harmony.' Here, we have seen that 'Heavenly timing' is actually about people being in harmony - all people under heaven being in harmony, not just one's own people.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For military men, the concept of 'Heaven' is just military meteorology. It all boils down to things like reading the stars, the clouds and qi. Making divinations from yarrow stalks and burning turtle shells are just a part of propaganda.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
People who were in power, and who really controlled military situations, never actually believed in such superstitious things. When on the march, you must move through uninhabited areas; the Enemy should be engaged in favourable terrain

Extract from the original text:
¡§Earth comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death."

Analysis:
Cao Cao wrote in his commentary: ¡§Here, Sun Tzu is speaking about the nine different kinds of terrain, and their favourableness in different seasons. For a discussion of this, refer to the chapter entitled The Nine Situations."
The Nine Situations is found near the end of Sun Tzu's The Art of War, and it contains a detailed analysis of the features and uses of nine distinct types of terrain.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Hence, the discussion of terrain in this part of the book is rather brief. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Whenever troops are to be used, it is valuable to first know the lay of the land. When you are familiar with the distances, you can use the stratagem of directness and indirectness." You can know whether to take a direct route or a meandering one. When you know how difficult or easy the terrain is to traverse, you know where foot soldiers and cavalry have unique advantages, and thus where to deploy them. ¡§When you know the locations of open ground and narrow passes, then you can gauge how many or how few soldiers you can use." You can know where to spread your troops out, and where a bottleneck can be defended by a single man. ¡§When you know the chances of death and life in various positions, then you can identify the positions that are amenable to fighting and to retreating." For example, if you deploy soldiers in a position where there is a high 'chance of death,' you know there will definitely be heavy fighting in this position.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Conversely, if you deploy them in a position with a high 'chance of life,' it will be easy to retreat and disperse. Of all the generals of the early People's Liberation Army, the most capable was Su Yu.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Among his admirers was Lin Biao, who said that Su was like a god of war, always descending upon his enemy from the sky. So, what were the bedrocks of Su's battle craft? Two things: maps and marching. Using maps, he would learn battlefield terrain by heart, and apparently would use maps so heavily that they were worn down into scraps of paper. Marching and moving one's troops is a crucial part of fighting battles - perhaps even more important than directly engaging the enemy.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: People often think that a battle has only really started once guns are being fired, but in reality, by the time that's happening the winner and loser have already been decided. And, crucially, they have been decided by troop movement: bringing soldiers into battle in the right place, at the right time, and with the right level of force. This is known as 'mobile warfare.' So, when people say that Su Yu was the most capable PLA commander, what they're really saying is that he was the most capable mover of troops. He invested more work and nuance than anyone else in studying and making use of terrain.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: During the Huaihai campaign of 1948-1949, Su Yu's troops were constantly moving around the war zone. They followed the principles of moving only through places where there were no other people, and engaging the enemy only when he enjoyed the advantages of favourable terrain and superior firepower. Fighting in this way, Su Yu was able to split a single army unit into ten mobile strike forces. He was like a master butcher, blades dancing everywhere, appearing and disappearing at will, like a ghost, and descending upon the enemy as if from the sky.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Along with troop movement, camping is also an important part of fighting wars. Campsites must be chosen on the basis of one's battle plan, and this is not only a matter of terrain but also of troop morale and battle effectiveness. Napoleon famously said that no matter how heavy the losses an army suffers in battle, it still does not have as negative an impact on the army as an unhygienic campsite. We can see now that most of the work that determines a battle's outcome has nothing to do with what we hear about in the epic stories and the songs.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The important parts happen well before the two sides engage - by then, all that's left to do is watch the pre-determined result unfold. Isn't it the same in our day-to-day lives, in the world of work? Be mindful of other people's interests, and make sure they know
 
Extract from the original text:
¡§The Commander stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness."

Analysis:
Here, Sun Tzu tells us the order of importance of different personality traits that 'The Commander' must possess. This is another case where his value system shows through - he put 'wisdom' in first place, whereas 'courage' is relegated to fourth.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Sun Tzu emphasizes wisdom because he wants to win before committing to battle, or even without fighting at all, rather than strong-arming the enemy's troops into submission by force. There is a Chinese four-character saying5 that translates as: 'A man who is both wise and courageous.' Yet, Sun Tzu has split these two virtues apart, and put 'sincerity' and 'benevolence' between them.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
What should we make of this? First of all, what exactly is 'wisdom?'
Du Mu wrote in his commentary: ¡§The Dao of the ancient kings was predicated above all else upon benevolence. Meanwhile, among military commanders it is prevalent to prioritize the use of wisdom." With wisdom, a commander can identify shifts in political currents and be agile enough to react effectively. Shen Baoxu, who was a senior official during the Warring States era (475-221 BCE), said: ¡§Without wisdom, one cannot have knowledge of the people's limits, and one is unable to gauge the number of people in the world." Wisdom underpins the ability to understand the limits of one's own strength, the balance of power and the overall situation in the world, as well as the ability to plan properly and to adapt to changing circumstances on the battlefield. That being said, it's not quite as simple as putting wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness in order.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: None of these virtues can exist independently of each other; if you have one, you must have them all. Now, let's look at what our commentators have to say about this passage. Only three of them wrote about it.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Gu said: ¡§With wisdom alone, man becomes treacherous; if a man showers benevolence on all without discrimination, he becomes weak; if a man is obstinately sincere, then he is a fool; if man knows only courage and force, then he becomes brutal; if a man is too strict when he gives commands, then he becomes cruel. The only way to become a worthy Commander is to possess all five of these qualities and to use each only when appropriate."
Mei Yaochen said: ¡§With wisdom, a man can formulate plans; with sincerity, a man can hand out both rewards and punishments; with benevolence, a man can maintain closeness with the people; with courage, a man can make decisions resolutely; with strictness, a man can establish his power."
Wang Xi said: ¡§The wise man looks first, and feels no doubts, but is able to reflect, plan, and fully understand changes in the currents of politics; the sincere man is consistent in what he says and in the orders he gives to subordinates; the benevolent man is devoted to compassion, and thus gains people's hearts; the brave man defends what is right and has no fear, and is decisive and resolute; the strict man uses his prestige to rectify the hearts of the masses. These five qualities all need each other; not a single one may be lacking."
Next, what is 'sincerity?'
Du Mu gives an accurate answer: ¡§Sincerity means making clear criteria for rewards and punishments so that everyone is extremely clear about what punishment they can expect for each kind of violation and what reward they can expect for each kind of meritorious deed."
For the kingdom of Qin, the first to rise above the other warring Chinese states and form an all-China empire, 'sincerity' was the key that unlocked the destruction of its six rival kingdoms.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The Qin leaders' sincerity was not directed toward its rivals, but toward the armies and common people of the Qin kingdom. Particularly noteworthy was the mechanism by which deserving subjects were granted titles within the nobility, which was completely tied to military merit. A good example is the old Chinese word shouji (­º?): shou means 'a person's head,' ji means 'grade/rank,' and together shouji means 'a severed head.' The word comes from the Qin convention of elevating a person by one grade within the hierarchy of nobility each time they cut off an enemy's head! This was a way of implanting the codes of reward and punishment into the very language people spoke - a person's head no longer just meant 'a person's head,' but 'one rank higher in the nobility.' The people of Qin were brave and eager to be at the front of the charge - who wouldn't be with such rewards waiting to be claimed?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When the pioneering Qin minister, Lord Shang Yang, instituted a series of reforms, the first thing he did was establish a reputation for sincerity. He did this by planting a wooden pole in the ground by the south gate of the capital city.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He stuck a notice on the pole, which said that whoever took the pole and carried it to the north gate would be awarded ten taels of gold. No one actually believed the notice. So, a new notice was written, raising the award to 50 taels of gold! This was enough for someone to give it a try, and sure enough, the man got his 50 taels of gold.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: From then on, the people believed whatever the government said. Sincerity - with it, the people's hearts and muscles are at your disposal; without it, the people's hearts and muscles are not yours to use. There is another type of sincerity beyond just clear criteria for rewards and punishments, and that is 'unspoken sincerity.' Only kings and the highest-ranking generals have total power to set rewards and punishments, but lower-ranked commanders still need to be able to lead troops into battle. Addressing this need, The United States Military Academy (also known as 'West Point,') makes a specific demand of its students, and it's about leadership skills: Always be mindful of other people's interests, and make sure they are aware that you are doing so. Sincerity is not just an administrative mechanism; more importantly, it is also a personal force that people can exert on others.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Fundamental to this side of sincerity is the ability to include other people in your considerations. Without doing this, you cannot hope to truly have sincerity. The second most fundamental thing is the ability to make other people aware that they are a factor in our thinking.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Otherwise, even if you are mindful of other people's interests, they won't know that and aren't likely to stick around at your side for long. Next on the list of five virtues is 'benevolence.'
Du Mu comments: ¡§The benevolent man loves the people and cherishes objects, and knows what it is to work diligently."
Both 'loving people' and 'cherishing objects' are fundamentally important. Valuing public property is part of being benevolent, and vice versa: if you don't place importance on resources, and instead use them wastefully, you cannot have 'benevolence.' For example, imagine you're working overtime at the office.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
You're the last to leave, but you don't turn off your computer or the air conditioning, and you even forget to hit the light switch on your way out - this behavior means that you don't have benevolence, because you don't 'cherish objects.'
In war, a benevolent general is one who loves his soldiers as though they were his own sons. In China, there is a famous story about the Warring States era (475-2221 BCE) general, Wu Qi.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's said that one of Wu Qi's men had a problem with his feet, which had become covered with festering wounds that oozed puss. When Wu Qi saw this, he got down on the ground, pressed his mouth to the soldier's feet and began to suck the puss out of his wounds. Later, the soldier's mother heard what had happened, and she was so distressed that she began to wail and cry.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Someone asked her why she was crying - after all, the great general had been so kind to her son. The mother replied, ¡§My husband was a soldier too, and he had the same problem with his feet. General Wu did the same thing for him as he did for my son, and my husband was so moved by the general that he ended up sacrificing himself in a battle. Now that it's happened again, I'm certain my son's going to give his life away, too!"
Next: 'courage.'
Du Mu comments: ¡§The brave general decisively orchestrates victory and forges ahead with momentum; he never hesitates, never yields an inch."
Chinese has a four-character phrase that translates directly as 'fond of planning but lacking resolve,' which military experts use to describe someone who is always plotting and planning, but can never quite come to a firm decision. Why do people have this problem?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It is because they have no courage! This behavior type is also common in the modern workplace: When you hear a colleague saying that a certain person can never seem to get things done, the basic problem with that person is a lack of courage, which causes them to be hesitant, slow and overly cautious. When someone behaves like this, it makes the people around them anxious.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Lack of courage in a general causes problems at two different stages of war. First, they're incapable of making a clear decision; and second, when they finally do settle on a decision, they don't have the resolve to execute it properly, and tend to flinch away from their work, ultimately backing themselves into a corner.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: No matter what you're setting out to achieve, it's important to embrace the spirit of self-sacrifice and to be willing to look death in the face and wrestle life from its jaws. It's worth mentioning here that although our stated aim in this book is to win first and fight later, there is no such thing as guaranteed success in this world.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
That's why you need courage to actually get things done. Finally, let's look at 'strictness.'
Du Mu comments: ¡§A strict general uses punishments and the prestige his name commands to maintain discipline among his forces."
Du Mu's commentary shows why, since ancient times, whenever a famous general first assembles troops ahead of launching a campaign, he always finds a reason to kill someone. It's a way to establish respect and fear.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The ideal candidate for this kind of execution would be someone with high social status, perhaps a person who is trusted by the Emperor, and who considers themselves 'untouchable' because they feel safe, sheltered in the shadow of the emperor. For example, Sun Tzu personally killed one of the King of Wu's favorite concubines, while the commander and author of one of the seven military classic, Sima Rangju, killed the Emperor's trusted aide, Zhuang Gu. The reason these people end up getting killed every time there's a war is that they didn't read the history books!

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: People who believed themselves safe in the shelter of their titanic protectors were the easiest victims whenever there was a new war or political reform, because their status meant they were highly visible in the public eye, and yet they had no practical value to the state. Killing them is a way to enhance your authority without incurring any real losses for the state.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: There's a life lesson here: no matter what you do, don't seek shelter between the legs of giants, because as soon as another giant so much as pats your protector on the back, you're liable to get squashed underfoot.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: You may think that you're as important as an extension of the Emperor's body, but you're not. As soon as the next political storm breaks, you'll be blown away like a speck of dust, or worse, your protector will be toppled and you'll be buried alive. This is one of the reasons why people of acumen follow the Confucian teaching of 'walking the middle path' - they rely not on a protector but on their own independent personhood, their own value.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
They know their own value. They take care of themselves, make their own way in the world, are self-disciplined, follow the law, and do not overstep any boundaries. Only small-minded people seek out a protector, and their lives can never amount to much. ~
We've now talked about 'wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness.' It's easy enough to talk about, but another matter entirely to put these virtues into practice.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: So, how is it done? In the waning years of China's last empire, a Qing dynasty scholar and politician named Zeng Guofan was tasked with leading an army. He was a bookish man, and every day he would page through Sun Tzu's The Art of War.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He measured himself against the standards of the five virtues, and it was clear that he didn't have any wisdom. After all, he'd never even fought in a battle before! He could, at a stretch, claim to have sincerity and benevolence. As for courage, although he wasn't especially scared of dying, a lifetime devoted to scholarship had left him physically weak. His wrists were so limp, he didn't even have the arm strength to wring a chicken's neck!

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
So, he could have had all the courage in the world, but he would never be warlike or fierce. The one virtue he really put into practice was 'strictness.' The world around him had been in a state of chaos for his whole life, and he had a decades-long list of people who deserved to die. As far as he was concerned, the greatest act of benevolence for the people would be to ¡§strew the country with evil men's corpses; then, benevolence and righteousness will once more return to the world." In the end, he became known as 'Zeng the scalp-shaver.'
So, how did Zeng compensate for his lack of wisdom and courage? As far as he could see, there was no getting around the fact that he was basically inadequate, and the officers under his command were even worse - they were just a motley bunch of peasants. His solution was to come up with two new virtues: 'incorruptibility' and 'clarity.'
Zeng's reasoning for increasing the five virtues to seven was this: Ordinary soldiers are not qualified to demand that their leaders be wise, resourceful battle commanders; however, every person alive has a keen sense of their own interests, and soldiers are very aware of whether their leaders are clean in the way they handle money and fair in who they select for promotions. As a commander, to earn the respect of your men you cannot be greedy with money.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Having 'incorruptibility' means that you are transparent and always above board in the way you manage the accounts, and this is essential to gaining your subordinates' trust. When corruption is rampant in an army, there's no way that army is going to be able to fight. If you want your subordinates to trust and follow you, you should be stingy with yourself, but at the same time make sure that you regularly give out small rewards of money to your men, so that everyone is getting a piece of the pie. Having 'clarity' means that you keep careful notes about each of your subordinates' performance.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: You need to know who is always at the front of the charge, who is always close behind and ready to assist, who is always willing to risk their life and stand their ground, and who is always trying to stay out of danger.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When you're not fighting, you should also closely watch who's hardworking and who's lazy. If you do this, you can give out the correct rewards and punishment, at the right time and in the right way. As a commander, the question of whether you should be at the head of the charge is actually not very important, because you will often need to be directing proceedings from the rear. It's not even of primary importance to come up with ingenious plans and command every detail of what's happening on the battlefield.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: What's really important is to fairly distribute resources and have a clear idea of who is making a good example of themselves through excellent service, so you can achieve the correct balance between rewards and punishments. If you can do this, your men will be relaxed.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When soldiers are relaxed, bravery comes easily, and they will be willing to lay down their lives for you. The lesson here is that, as a leader, you need to not just pay attention to events, but to people as well.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Don't make the mistake of thinking that if events are going in your favor, all is as it should be. Instead, you should make sure you know exactly what role each of your men is playing in the process of 'everything going well.' You also need to have the ability to hand out both rewards and punishments.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This is the only way to constantly improve your results. People say that during the Chinese civil war (1927-1950 CE), the difference between the Communist army and the Nationalist army was that in the Communist army, the generals would shout: 'Forward with me!' whereas the Nationalist generals would just shout: 'Forward! For your commander!' This is actually nothing more than a myth.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If you're the commander, and you're at the head of the charge, who will give the commands when you die? Who will be in charge of recognizing merit and giving rewards? Who will the soldiers follow? In the wars before the Han dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) was formed, there was a warlord called Xiang Yu the Conqueror who always was at the front of the charge and in the thick of the fighting. But, the man who ultimately emerged victorious and founded the Han dynasty, Liu Bang, concerned himself only with rewards, punishments and working out who was serving him well and whose conduct fell short.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It is far more important for a commander to have a clear picture of the conduct of his men than it is to fight alongside them. Zeng Guofan said that if you make 'incorruptibility' and 'clarity' your foundation, then 'wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness' naturally and gradually follow. But, if you don't have this foundation, you cannot win the trust of your men, you won't be able to properly distribute rewards and punishments, and so the other five virtues become meaningless.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The bulk of a general's work is setting military discipline

Extract from the original text:
¡§By method and discipline are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure. These five heads should be familiar to every general: he who knows them will be victorious; he who knows them not will fail."

Analysis:
'Method and Discipline' occupy last place in the line-up of the 'Five Factors' ('the Moral Law,' 'Heaven,' 'Earth,' 'The Commander' and 'Method and Discipline').

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: So, it is often not taken very seriously. Readers tend to think of it simply as meaning 'keeping discipline tight,' but in reality it's much more complex and technical. This is where the bulk of a general's work is to be done, rather than in actual battles, which are only a small blip on the timeline in comparison.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The original wording of this passage is quite arcane, but luckily Cao Cao elucidated the practical meaning in his commentary. 'The marshaling of the army' refers to the framework of an organization - its structure - and to the system through which commands are given and relayed.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: 'Graduations of rank' basically refers to 'human resources' systems. 'Method and Discipline' is another way of saying 'management,' and it encompasses a range of management solutions. Of course, in today's world, 'management' is a technical business term, but the modern concept of 'management studies' traces its earliest roots back to the military management of armies.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The topic of an army's organizational framework is a very complicated one. There are similarities with business - when a company grows at a faster rate than the management is able to keep up with, it's doomed to collapse.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When rapid business development happens, it's common for the organizational framework to become unclear and the structure confusing and strange. It's important to bring in organizational change at regular intervals; when this is done well, the company can unleash huge amounts of energy, but when it's done poorly, it can be brought to its knees. In modern China, the process of 'Reform and Opening Up' brought about many structural changes, as well as changes to 'the graduations of rank' among officials, and to infrastructure.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It also led to the creation of many small government organizations of all kinds, and so cross-departmental organizations were introduced to coordinate the new structures and ensure that new reforms could keep moving forward.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
In China, a common definition of a 'hero' is someone who is possessed of both great natural talent and great strategic abilities. The early 20th century general Zhang Xueliang, who inherited control of the northeast of China from his father after he was assassinated, said: ¡§My father had the natural talent, but not the strategic ability, and Chang Kai-Shek (the Nationalist leader who was defeated by the Communists) had the strategic ability, but not the natural talent."
Very well put! Zhang's father was one of the most talented men of his generation, but he lacked an advanced understanding of politics.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Meanwhile, Chiang Kai-Shek always had well-formulated plans, but didn't quite have the talent to execute them. Coming back to the 'Five Factors,' these two qualities of a well-rounded 'hero' can be divided like this: 'strategic abilities' fall under the domain of 'the Moral Law,' 'Heaven' and 'Earth,' while 'The Commander' and 'Method and Discipline' fall under 'natural talent.' A commander must have natural talent in order to effectively organize an army, mobilize troops, and provide guidance and driving force for an army in motion. In business, successful entrepreneurs are both naturally talented and adept at strategy.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: However, between these two qualities, natural talent is more important. That's because you can always ask other people's advice on strategy or hire consultants, but the talent to execute can only come from yourself. If you have talent, it's possible to become a successful entrepreneur even without strategic ability. If you have strategic ability but little natural talent, the obvious choice in ancient times would be to become an advisor.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In modern times, your best bet would be to start a consulting business. Throughout Chinese history, the forces that have founded new dynasties have always been a perfect alliance of talented leaders and strategically sharp advisors.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Some examples include Liu Bei (the founder of the Han kingdom of Shu, in modern-day Sichuan Province; Zhuge Liang; Zhu Yuanzhang, the first Emperor of the Ming dynasty; Liu Bowen; Liu Bang, the first Emperor of the Han dynasty; and Xiao He. The Dao is really just soft power

Extract from the original text:
¡§Therefore, in your deliberations, when seeking to determine the military conditions, let them be made the basis of a comparison, in this way: (1) Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao (Moral Law)?"

Analysis:
Sun Tzu took a seven-point approach to weighing the balance of the 'Five Factors' between opposing forces, and the first point is represented by the question: 'Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao?'
Earlier in this book, we saw that the Dao is defined as 'causing the people to be in complete accord with the ruler.' To achieve this, the ruler must widely share the fruits of victory, govern the people with appropriate policies, and not be stingy in handing out rewards and noble titles. Commentators from different eras used the same historical example to illustrate this line from Sun Tzu's The Art of War: The general Han Xin's choice during the wars following the collapse of the Qin dynasty to fight for Liu Bang (who went on to become the first Emperor of the Han dynasty) instead of his rival warlord, Xiang Yu.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Liu Bang apparently asked Han Xin: ¡§Why have you chosen to follow me now, and not Xiang Yu?"
Han Xin replied: ¡§Xiang Yu treats the people cruelly, and is always reluctant to reward those who serve him.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
He has a big official stamp, specially made to mark letters of ennoblement and reward, yet he is loath to use it and always hasty to snatch it back to his bosom. He keeps it close to him and caresses it so much that its corners have become worn and rounded. But you, my lord, are different - you govern the people with clear and simple rules, you reward your followers, and you set slaves free."
Being willing to spend money was an excellent choice by Liu Bang. After all, no matter how big the checks he wrote, it was always someone else who had to pay, because at that time he was a revolutionary in a crumbling empire that did not yet belong to him.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But, he also did not hesitate to use what money he had already secured in his purse. He bought the loyalty of his enemies' generals with the help of his advisor, Chen Ping, who did his dirty work for him.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He didn't seem to have a budget, and even after emerging victorious as Emperor of China, he continued to spend at will. When he first announced new policies as Emperor, he declared that whoever brought him Xiang Yu's head would be made a lord of 10,000 households and granted the title of Marquis. When Xiang Yu finally gave up at the River Wu, just before he slit his own throat, he was looking at the crowd of Liu Bang's soldiers surrounding him when he saw a man who used to fight for him, Lu Matong.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Xiang Yu cried out to Lu: ¡§Lu Matong, my old friend! My head is yours!" Then Xiang Yu drew his knife and cut his own throat. The other warriors didn't pay any attention to Xiang Yu's last words, and hurried to seize the warlord's body for themselves.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: After the body had been hacked to pieces, five different men ended up with Xiang Yu's body parts. They all went to Liu Bang, each seeking credit for bringing Xiang Yu to their lord. Liu Bang didn't ask any questions, and immediately settled the matter by making all five of the men Marquises. The Dao of Liu Bang was to orient himself downwards, towards the people; his Dao manifested in the rewards mechanisms he used and in his methods of governing his people. His approach to politics and governance was miles apart from Xiang Yu's.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For example, after Liu Bang delivered the finishing blow to the collapsing Qin dynasty, he didn't touch the fallen empire's treasure troves or the women. He didn't move into the imperial palace, and he immediately sealed the state treasury. He withdrew his troops, and established just three laws: anyone guilty of murder will be executed; anyone guilty of harming another person will be beaten; and anyone guilty of theft will be punished accordingly. He then abolished all of the harsh laws and draconian punishments that had been enforced under the old Qin legal code. Because of Liu Bang's actions, the people of Qin loved him devotedly.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They continued to whole-heartedly support him from behind the lines during the wars that followed. But after Xiang Yu declared himself Emperor and banished Liu Bang, he slaughtered the people of the old Qin capital, Xianyang, and killed the Qin king, Ziying, whose life had originally been spared by Liu Bang after he surrendered. Xiang Yu then loaded up wagons with Qin's riches and women and carted them away before setting fire to the Qin palaces and government buildings.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The fire burned for three months. So, why did Xiang Yu kill those people when peace had already been secured? He did it so that he could take their women and valuables. Xiang Yu's actions show that he didn't comprehend how to take possession of an empire; his desires went no further than riches and women. After Xiang Yu seized the women and wealth of Qin, he split the state in three, and in each of these three areas he installed one of his followers, giving them the title of 'king.' Because of this, people in the province of Shaanxi even today talk about 'the three Qin regions.' So who did Xiang Yu pick to be the three kings of Qin? In fact, they were all former generals of the Qin Empire who had surrendered: Zhang Han, Sima Xin and Dong Yi.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: What kind of background did these men have? Between them, they had been in command of 200,000 Qin troops when they surrendered to Xiang Yu. Accepting their surrender, Xiang Yu had all 200,000 of their men buried alive. Only the three generals were spared.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Because of this, the people of Qin hated their guts; these men had betrayed 200,000 of their own countrymen and had acquired vast riches and status for their deeds. These were the men who Xiang Yu later charged with the vital task of leading armies raised from among the people of Qin to block Liu Bang's advance at the strategic mountain pass town of Hanzhong.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But, given their past, how could they be expected to succeed? By asking the question, 'Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao,' we can see why Xiang Yu lost so badly against Liu Bang. Even further back in history, the first leader who really had the Dao was Lord Tang of the state of Shang, who became the first King of the Shang dynasty.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It is said that when he was digging foundations for a house, he unearthed some human remains that had been buried without any plaque identifying the deceased's name. Tang treated the remains respectfully, and gave them a proper burial. Word spread of this deed, and people said: ¡§Tang of Shang is so respectful to dead people; he must be even more respectful of living people!" Later, Tang saw peasants who had set up nets in the shape of a closed rectangle, to catch birds. He ordered them to take down the nets on all but one side, urging them not to kill wantonly, but to give the birds a chance. When word spread of this deed, people said: ¡§Tang of Shang treats animals so well; he must treat people even better!" 
Because of Tang's reputation, when he launched military campaigns to attack states in the east, people in states to the west complained: 'Why won't he attack us?' Likewise, when he attacked states to the east, people in the states to the west were offended.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The Way of the Hegemon requires control over a huge country and relies on the power brought by extensive territory and well-stocked armories. When a ruler follows The Way of the Hegemon, the extent of his kingdom is directly proportionate to his material power.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: By contrast, The Way of the King does not require a large state; it can be practiced just as well in a small state, and then used to expand the small state until it covers the entire known world. Lord Tang originally ruled over a very small state, and King Wen, the first King of the Zhou dynasty, only had a slightly larger state; both men were rulers of small fiefdoms, but both won the hearts of people all over China by practicing The Way of the King. Mencius' words offer great insight to those of us engaged in smaller-scale endeavors.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

But, beyond the fundamentals, Sun Tzu says that you should ¡§avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules." What he means by this is that you should adjust your plans to take advantage of opportunities. Du Mu comments: ¡§It is impossible to foresee what we call 'circumstances.' Circumstances may be favourable to the enemy and thus disadvantageous to me, or they may be disadvantageous to the enemy and thus favourable to me; when circumstances reveal themselves, then you can begin to create from them an advantage, and thus secure victory."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§As concerns 'circumstances,' they are about harnessing changes."
And so, this passage opens a discussion about how to gain advantage from the changing circumstances of a battle, while avoiding the dangers; how to turn disadvantages into advantages, respond to opportunities and seize the initiative, master the shifting contours of a battle in real-time, and create momentum. chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

Analysis:
In this rapid-fire passage, Sun Tzu reels off twelve deception-based strategies, most of which aim to trick the enemy into making an error of judgment. It's about using temptation to force a mistake.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But, what do you do when the enemy doesn't fall for your trick? What you do is wait. In this game, you need to out-wait the enemy, send agents to infiltrate their camp, and make all kinds of arrangements for different scenarios.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Essentially, you have to wait until the balance is broken and the odds of victory tip in your favor; only then can you engage in combat. Sun Tzu's basic principle is to win first and fight later. Or, if you can't win, you don't fight.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

If the odds aren't in your favor, you wait. This is precisely why it is a major character flaw to be incapable of waiting. People often think that real men, or heroes, have to fight. There is a passage in the ancient Tang dynasty military text, Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, in which the Emperor says: ¡§Through my readings of military books both ancient and new, I have discovered that there is but one crucial teaching - use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one's foe. That is, it is necessary to think of every possible way to entice the enemy into making a blunder; he makes one false move, and you expose his weaknesses." 
Duke Li of Wei, a prominent Tang dynasty general, replies in the text's dialogue: ¡§That is correct. War is like chess: one false move, and you lose control of the entire board.

Analysis:
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Seeming weak when in fact you are strong, seeming timid when in fact you are brave; this is how Li Mu defeated the Xiongnu, and how Sun Bin destroyed Pang Juan."
Li Mu, a general from the state of Zhao, was one of the four great generals of the Warring States period (475-221 BCE), the other three being Bai Qi, Lian Po and Wang Jian. Li Mu was in charge of the garrisons of the Dai and Yamen commanderies, tasked with fending off the Xiongnu, who were nomadic warriors from the steppes to the north of China.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Li Mu treated his soldiers exceptionally well, trained them rigorously and carried out frequent inspections. He insisted that his men obey just one order: Fighting the enemy is forbidden! He decapitated anyone who had the audacity to leave camp looking for a fight.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For years, Li Mu studiously avoided fighting. Because he had a strategy of 'fortifying the walls and evacuating the countryside,' which required all of the local people to retreat behind the fortified walls of his garrison camp, when Xiongnu raiders came prowling there was nothing for them to loot. Li Mu continued with this strategy for several years, never engaging in a fight.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This was distressing not only for the Xiongnu raiders, but also for his own men, and for his king. Believing Li to be a coward, the King of Zhao recalled him and sent a new general in his place. The new general scrapped Li Mu's strategy, and made regular trips out of the camp with his troops to attack the Xiongnu. This didn't go well; he lost more battles than he won, and suffered heavy losses in the process. The King of Zhao had no choice but to ask Li Mu to return to his old post, but Li Mu declined, pleading bad health. The King of Zhao, now out of options, promised Li that he would never again meddle in his military strategy. So, Li Mu returned to his post and reinstated his strategy of 'absolutely no fighting.' However, this did not mean he was idle during those years - in fact, he was even busier than if he'd been at war the whole time, personally running an intense training regime for his troops. After years of training in camp, Li Mu's border defense army was in excellent shape, morale was high, and his men were so eager for action that they would have been willing to go without pay or reward just for one proper fight against the Xiongnu. Meanwhile, the Xiongnu had grown complacent.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Finally, Li Mu decided the time was right for a decisive battle. He carefully selected his best troops and equipment - 1,300 war chariots, 13,000 war horses, 50,000 foot soldiers brave enough to charge the enemy lines head-on, as well as 100,000 archers - and he marched to war. Li employed the stratagem of 'luring the enemy in deep,' first sending a large number of nomadic herders with accompanying livestock out into the countryside. The Xiongnu sent a small force to intercept the nomads and steal their livestock, and Li Mu allowed them to 'win,' intentionally losing several thousand men to the Xiongnu. The Xiongnu were elated by their little victory, and their chieftain, Chanyu, decided to launch a full invasion with a much larger force. As the Xiongnu advanced, Li Mu spread his troops wide in an ambush formation, surrounding the invaders on two sides. With one stroke, Li eliminated 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. The Xiongnu chieftain fled into the wilderness, while the victorious Li Mu took full advantage of the momentum his victory gave him to attack and destroy two other nomadic tribal confederations, the Chanlan and the Dong Hu, while also subjugating the Lin Hu. For more than ten years after this battle, the Xiongnu didn't once come near the borders of Zhao.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Military thinkers put great store in the ability to win a war with a single, decisive battle. War should not be a back-and-forth process; instead, generals should save their energy and build their strength, waiting for the opportune moment to end the war in a single move. Some might consider a general to be 'great' if, during a ten-year command at a frontier fortress, he fought 100 battles and won all of them in spectacular fashion.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But, what if the price of this general's valor is 10,000 corpses on the battlefield? The general retires with a glittering record, yet not a single problem has been solved. Then, the next 'great' general is sent out to carry on doing the same thing: to keep on fighting.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Li Mu was an exception. He bided his time and didn't fight a single battle for ten years, and when the time finally came, he fought just one battle, and in doing so he actually solved a problem for his country.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: I hope I have now shown why the ability to win a war with a single battle makes a general truly great. What good are a hundred victories? All it means is that you've fought many, many times without solving the problem, and at the end of those 100 battles, you still have to keep on fighting! A general with a 100% record in 100 fights is actually incompetent, lacking even a basic understanding of the art of war. Anyway, the example of a hundred-victory general is hypothetical - have you ever heard of a general with that good a record?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Anyone who would make that claim isn't telling the whole story. The truth is that a certain number of losses are inevitable. The principle of this chapter can be applied to anything you do, and summarized as: 'When the time isn't right, don't do a thing.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When the time comes, use only a single move, and make sure it solves your problem.' The undoing of many a project comes from chronic over-activity, and the motivation behind chronic over-activity invariably boils down to some kind of anxiety complex. If you ask Li Mu what losses he incurred by refusing to fight, the answer would be 'none.' But, that didn't prevent the troops under his command, or the Xiongnu, or the King of Zhao from feeling anxious.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Anxiety is what caused the King of Zhao to act, recalling and replacing Li Mu, rather than any reasonable objection to Li's performance. After all, Li had done his job, which was to defend the border, flawlessly.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
