The meaning of this line is the same as the previous one ('When able to attack, we must seem unable'). Let's look at another classic case study: the battle of Baideng during the early years of the Han dynasty.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: After Liu Bang established the Han dynasty in 206 BCE, he launched a campaign against the Xiongnu, the same northern nomads who featured in the previous chapter. At first, Liu Bang, now known as Emperor Gaozu, won victory after victory. Pleased with his achievements, the Emperor was keen to launch an all-out assault on the Xiongnu and root them out once and for all. He sent over a dozen reconnaissance agents to the Xiongnu area, all of whom came back telling of depleted Xiongnu armies - no warriors and no horses. The time was ripe to attack, they said.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Emperor Gaozu sent another advisor, Lou Jing, to carry out further reconnaissance. Lou Jing returned from his mission and told the Emperor that he must not attack. When the Emperor asked why, Lou Jing replied that it is normal when two countries go to war for each side to show off their power. Yet, all that he saw in the Xiongnu lands was emaciated horses and listless soldiers; all the men seemed old, feeble, disabled or sick. Obviously, this was a Xiongnu trick to lure us in, a show that they were putting on for our benefit, he said.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But Emperor Gaozu had already made up his mind to go to war. As he listened to Lou Jing, he flew into a rage and had Lou thrown into a dungeon. He accused the man of distracting him from his battle plans, and threateningly told him he'd deal with him after he returned victorious from the war. Emperor Gaozu mobilized all the forces at his disposal and gave the order to march. He and his armies were camped on the Baideng plateau when they were ambushed by the Xiongnu chieftain. A force of 400,000 Xiongnu warriors completely surrounded Emperor Gaozu.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The enemy was not exactly 'depleted,' after all. They had plenty of horses, too - a mass of white horses hemmed in the Chinese forces from the east, black horses from the west, and red horses from the north. To put the two sides' cavalry resources in perspective, Emperor Gaozu couldn't muster up a handful of uniformly white horses to pull the chariots for his honor guard on the day he ascended his throne as Emperor of all China. The Han army was besieged for seven days and seven nights, despite several desperate attempts to break through the enemy encirclement.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

Chen went to the Xiongyu chieftain's queen, offering her a bribe and telling her: ¡§The Han Emperor is no ordinary mortal; he is favored by the gods.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

The queen asked Chen Ping: ¡§What ruin do you speak of?" Chen replied: ¡§You Xiongnu are not used to life in southern lands, so it will bring you nothing good if you seize our land. The only reason your people fight against us Han is because you want our women, our gold and our silk.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:

The queen was impressed by Chen Ping's reasoning, which seemed to her to get right to the heart of the matter. What good was it to her whether or not her husband became even greater than he already was?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: What mattered to her was that she could use her husband for her own benefit. So, one night in bed with the chieftain, she began to push the idea that Emperor Gaozu had the gods on his side, and she urged her husband not to do anything extreme. The Xiongnu chieftain felt ill at ease - not least because Emperor Gaozu had always had an aura of power about him - and he began to feel uncertain about what the next day might bring, not to mention the worrying failure of his two allies to arrive at the agreed time. What if they had turned against him and joined Emperor Gaozu?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The chances of this were not small. After all, his wife had already been turned against him. So, the chieftain decided to quit while he was ahead. He negotiated a treaty, took his money and allowed Emperor Gaozu to return home. Anyone can see how simple Sun Tzu's stratagems are.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Nobody actually needs thirty-six stratagems anyway; four or five are enough to cover any situation. The important part is the execution. When you put on a show for your enemy, you have to know how to scratch their metaphorical itch. chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
No certainties in victory and defeat - the leader must take responsibility for decisions

When Emperor Gaozu withdrew his army from Baideng, he freed from prison the advisor who had urged him not to go to war, Lou Jing, and gave him a noble title.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In this respect, he did a better job than Yuan Shao, a general of the late Han dynasty, and subsequently a warlord after the Han dynasty collapsed. Before the battle of Guandu, after which Cao Cao established dominance over north China, Yuan Shao's advisor, Tian Feng, told his lord that it would be better to hold his position than to attack. In response, Yuan Shao repeated Emperor Gaozu's words of several hundred years earlier, to the effect that Tian Feng's advice was distracting him from his planning. Yuan Shao threw Tian Feng in a dungeon and threatened to deal with him upon his victorious return.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But, Yuan Shao lost his battle. When news of the defeat spread, the jailer told Tian Feng: ¡§Looks like you'll be alright this time." But Feng Tian replied: ¡§You don't know our lord. If he'd won, he'd be in a fine mood and would forget about how I wronged him.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But if he really has lost, he'll feel humiliated by the very sight of me. Killing me will be his way out of having to face that humiliation." Sure enough, Yuan Shao accused Tian Feng of gloating over his lord's defeat and put him to death. While Emperor Gaozu cannot be directly compared with Yuan Shao, Gaozu did kill the advisors who told him the Xiongnu were open to attack, because of his own failure to take responsibility for his decisions, choosing to outsource it to them instead. Zeng Guofan dedicated part of his writings to the need for leaders to stand up and take responsibility for their decisions.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He felt compelled to do this because he knew there are no certainties in victory and defeat, and these things are not simply a matter of planning. Zeng included five different examples to illustrate his points, of which three address the same subject: various Emperors' attempts to weaken overly powerful feudal lords and bring them to heel.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The first example is from the Han dynasty. An advisor named Chao Cuo advised Emperor Jing to do something about the dangerously powerful feudal lords, and as a result, six regional 'kingdoms' rose up in rebellion, demanding that the Emperor 'cleanse himself of evil influences' by executing Chao Cuo. In a panic, Emperor Jing hastily complied, executing Chao Cuo.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But this didn't stop the King of Wu from continuing his insurrection. Eventually, Emperor Jing emerged victorious, and so the outcome in this case was that the Emperor successfully wrested power away from his feudal vassals. Much later, during the Ming dynasty, two advisors, named Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng, urged the Jianwen Emperor to do the same thing, with the result that the King of Yan rebelled and similarly demanded the execution of Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng. The Emperor did indeed kill them, but of course this did not persuade the King of Yan to stand down his troops, and in the end the Emperor was defeated.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In this case, the attempt was unsuccessful. Finally, a Qing dynasty advisor named Mi Sihan gave the same advice to the Kangxi Emperor. The general Wu Sangui, who had previously helped establish the Qing dynasty, rebelled. However, the Kangxi Emperor did not execute Mi Sihan, and eventually managed to put down Wu Sangui's revolt.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In this case, the outcome was a success. These three examples are similar in terms of circumstances and historical background, but differ in the way that the various Emperors dealt with them and in their outcomes. So, when dealing with momentous issues, or when making decisions in the face of uncertainty and doubt, it's important to think deeply about what is right and what is wrong.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's equally important not to cling to past successes or defeats. When faced with an intense situation, do not fold - situations are always temporary. And, be even more careful not to blame your advisors.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Now, let's move on to Zeng Guofan's two remaining examples:
In the twilight years of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Zhaozong had become very angry about his subjects' lack of respect for the Imperial house. Wanting to march in force against the warlord Li Maozhen, he asked his prime minister, Du Neng, to take charge of his army. Du Neng refused in no uncertain terms, telling the Emperor: ¡§If I go, all that will happen is that I'll end up executed just like Chao Cuo, and it will do nothing to stop disaster befalling the realm!" Emperor Zhaozong did not accept Du Neng's refusal, and Du was left with no choice but to go. In the end, the Tang imperial army was no match for the warlord Li Maozhen, who sent a formal petition to the Emperor, demanding that Du Neng be executed. When Du Neng heard about this, he said to Emperor Zhaozong: ¡§This is exactly what I said would happen!"
Emperor Zhaozong did not have the makings of a hero. In the pressure of the moment, all he could do was sob and snivel.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He told Li Maozhen that he would let Du Neng decide what to do about the situation. Then, he demoted Du Neng to the post of governor of Wuzhou, before 'allowing' him to commit suicide. In this case, Du Neng suffered an even more unjust fate than Chao Cuo, Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng. In his writings, Zeng Guofan had sharp words for Emperor Zhaozong, condemning him for forcing Du Neng to act against his will and then turning around and selling Du Neng out, having him killed. Such behavior, Zeng wrote, is that of a king who will not have a country to rule for much longer.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Zeng criticized himself too, writing: ¡§In my fighting days, sometimes I would make plans on the basis of some advisor's counsel, and subsequently suffer defeat. Perhaps I did not directly blame the advisor, but I'm sure that the next time I saw him, the ugly feelings I felt would have been plain to see on my face. I must attribute this to a lack of insight on my part; I was not thorough enough in my own training."
Zeng went on to reflect on the 'ugly feelings' on his face by writing about one more historical example:
The last Emperor of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Mo, was deeply worried, suspecting that a man named Shi Jingtang was plotting rebellion. The Emperor's advisors, Li Song and Lu Qi, told him that if Shi Jingtang really was considering rebellion, he would need support from the Khitans (a non-Chinese nomadic people from the far northeast).

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They advised that if the Emperor could establish good relations with the Khitans, Shi Jingtang would no longer have the opportunity to rebel. The Emperor decided to use their plan. Yet, a different advisor, Xue Wenyu, sowed seeds of doubt in his mind, questioning how the Emperor, the very Son of Heaven, could stoop so low as to treat barbarian savages as honored guests in his court. Xue mockingly quoted a poem about the female poet Zhaojun to drive his point home: ¡§The country relies on a clear-sighted sovereign; how can our safety be left to women?" Emperor Mo was persuaded to change his mind. He berated Li Song and Lu Qi, accusing them of trying to doom his daughter to an early grave.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The two advisors fell to their knees and apologized profusely, but apparently Lu Qi wasn't fast enough to kneel - he had a medical problem with his legs - and Emperor Mo accused him of arrogance. Lu Qi protested, pointing out that the Emperor was well aware of his bad legs, but Emperor Mo demoted him anyway. Just as the advisors predicted, Shi Jingtang ended up joining forces with the Khitans, and eventually destroyed the Tang imperial armies.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Emperor Mo knew then that he shouldn't have listened to Xue Wenyu, and he felt full of rage. He summoned Xue for a drubbing, shouting at the man: ¡§You horrid thing! The very sight of you makes me tremble with rage!" He almost pulled out a knife to stab Xue, there and then.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Emperor Mo was doomed; he ended up vanquished at the hands of Shi Jingtang. Summing up, Zeng Guofan wrote: ¡§In most cases, those who, suffering defeat, blame their chief advisors, are simply expressing their nature, which is that of a mediocre person."
So, there is no certainty in victory and defeat. The fact that there are success stories from the past does not mean that they can be replicated, but it also does not mean that they can't be replicated.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Leaders must take responsibility for their decisions. If things end up in a mess, blaming the person whose idea it was does nothing more than prove that you're a 'mediocre person.'

Ballplayers feint with every step, but do not confuse this with the real fundamentals of winning

Extract from the original text:
¡§When we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away."

Analysis:
What Sun Tzu is talking about here is 'strategic deception,' which at its core means making the enemy unprepared and unable to defend themselves. If the enemy is prepared and able to defend themselves, the odds are against you.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If the enemy is unprepared, and unable to defend themselves, you can bring all of your strength to bear on them, and they will buckle under the pressure. A famous example of this principle is the story of Han Xin crossing the River Wei using water pitchers. During the time when Liu Bang was fighting against Xiang Yu in the war between the new states of Chu and Han, following the collapse of the Qin Empire, Liu Bang was, for a while, in a precarious position, and his ally king Wei Bao decided to switch allegiance, going over to Xiang Yu's side.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: On the pretext that his mother was ill, Wei Bao asked Liu Bang to allow him to return home. Then, he about-faced and declared for Xiang Yu. Liu Bang immediately sent his general Han Xin to fight Wei Bao. The two armies arrived at Linjin, where they were separated from each other by a river.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Han Xin promptly assembled over 100 boats, and lined them up by the riverbank. Every day Han Xin put on a show, making it look like he was just about to lead his army across the river. On the opposite bank, Wei Bao kept his troops in battle formation, ready to fight. Meanwhile, Han Xin was secretly sending men to buy and make wooden and clay water pitchers - round at the bottom, with a narrow spout. Eventually, Han Xin moved a large force along the river to Xiayang, where he had his men lash the pitchers together into rafts. His army floated across the river, and attacked the town of Anyi on the far bank. Wei Bao was now outflanked, and ended up getting captured.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
When Wei Bao heard that Han Xin had crossed at Xiayang, he was shocked: ¡§There are no boats at Xiayang!" he cried. ¡§Where did he get boats?"
In this example, Wei Bao failed to grasp the concept of using 'substitution' as a problem-solving technique. Just because you don't have boats doesn't mean you don't have other tools for crossing a river.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Han Xin was using the stratagem of 'being near but making the enemy believe you're far away.' If you want to attack the enemy from afar, you have to put on a show for them nearby. Another example of this stratagem comes from the struggle for supremacy between the states of Wu and Yue during the final years of the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE).

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The Wu and Yue forces stood on either side of a river, so the Yue commander sent troops in both directions, up and down the river. Positioned a few miles apart, they waited for night and then began beating war drums and moving toward the Wu forces. The Wu commander was forced to split his army and send men in both directions to face the advancing Yue soldiers. However, the reason the Yue commander waited until night to stage his little show was that in fact the forces he had sent up- and down-river had more drums than fighting men. It was a bluff.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: With the Wu forces divided, the Yue commander crossed the river with his main force and attacked the Wu army head-on, routing their soldiers and dealing a massive blow to the kingdom of Wu. In this case, both sides understood the concept in play - the bluff - also known in Chinese as 'threatening from the east, striking from the west.' But, of course, bluffs are not always bluffs, and threatening from the east does not necessarily mean the strike will come from the west.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's entirely possible that the strike will come from the same direction as the threat. The analogy of the soccer penalty shot serves well here. The goalkeeper knows very well that the striker will use a feint, but also that the feint might not be a feint.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In other words, the striker might be feinting a feint. In this confusing tangle of deception and reality, who can win? The striker can win if they are steady, accurate, and powerful. But if the striker lofts the ball above the goal, it won't go in regardless of what the goalkeeper does. For the goalkeeper to win, he needs fast reactions and a bit of luck.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The goalkeeper also has the option of using a feint against the striker. But what does the daily training of both strikers and goalkeepers consist of? Do they spend all day practicing feints? No, of course not.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Their training has three main parts: physical fitness, skills and team tactics. These three things also happen to be the essence of warfare. If you believe the historians, you'd think that what made Han Xin a great general was his craftiness and his cunning tricks, but would be a mistake to say that this is what war is all about. Great generals are just like CEOs - the fundamentals of their work consist of operations management. Operations management is why Han Xin once said that, while Liu Bang could not lead more than 100,000 soldiers with any effectiveness, Han Xin himself would take all the soldiers he could lay his hands on.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: You could give him a million men, and he'd still be able to control them as if they were extensions of his own hands. If you want to know what Han Xin's true strength was, look no further than this. The Thirty-Six Stratagems is an entertaining story, but it doesn't represent the reality of war. Zeng Guofan actually said he was doubtful that the story of Han Xin crossing the river with water pitchers is really true.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: His reasoning was that it would be physically impossible to make rafts out of clay water pitchers that would be capable of ferrying a large army across a river. Zeng Guofan also debunked the other most famous story about Han Xin's exploits, in which Han Xin erected a makeshift dam using sacks of earth. According to the story, after the dam was built, the water downriver was shallow enough for the enemy army to cross, but when they'd only crossed halfway, Han Xin had the sacks of earth torn down, effectively bursting the dam and drowning the enemy army. Zeng Guofan pointed out that it would be impossible to dam a large river just with a group of men throwing sacks of dirt in the water, and it would be even more impossible to instantly tear down such a dam. Who exactly was supposed to have done the demolition job, and how?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The answer is that nobody did it, because it's impossible. Zeng wrote: ¡§After certain battles that I won with the Hunan army, I read some reports that writers were publishing about my victories that I found quite astonishing.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
I had no idea that this was how the battles had actually been fought! 'Strange,' I thought to myself, 'it can't have been me they were writing about!'"
In his conclusion, Zeng mused: ¡§I'm not yet one of history's dead generals, and yet these battle reports have morphed so beyond recognition in my own lifetime that I scarcely dare believe it. Well, Sima Qian (a great historian of the Han dynasty) was after all a writer, too - there can be no doubt that some sensational and embellished sources must have figured in his research into the stories of Han Xin."
There aren't many stratagems, and they're all well-worn tools of the trade, familiar to commanders on either side of any conflict, all of whom have read the same military books. Any time there is a battle, the same old stratagems are sure to be used.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
For example, you might (in your head) say to your adversary: 'Regardless of where I attack you, I must find a way to trick you into thinking it will be somewhere else. You know that I'm trying to trick you, and you know I might be trying to trick you into thinking I'm tricking you, when in fact I haven't tricked you, and I really am going to attack in the place where it looks like I'm going to attack.'
What does all this amount to? Ballplayers feint with every step, but do not confuse this with the fundamentals of winning.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Want great success? You'll have to give up three things. Number one: Greed

Extract from the original text:
¡§Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder. Then, crush him."

Analysis:
Li Quan comments: ¡§An enemy who is greedy for gain will inevitably become disordered. An enemy who is disordered can be crushed."
I'd like to re-use a previous chapter's historical example to illustrate this: the story of how Li Mu defeated the Xiongnu. Li Mu's strategy of fortifying his defenses and clearing the countryside, and then closing the gates for ten years without ever coming out to fight, left his own men as well as the enemy beside themselves with pent-up frustration.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Li Mu's men had their fill of good food and drink every day, and they were also receiving excellent training - their frustration came from a desire to serve their country on the battlefield, to repay the kindness they had enjoyed. The enemy, on the other hand, had been deprived by Li Mu's strategy of things to steal or loot.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: After ten years, they'd been reduced to miserable poverty. A decade into the standoff, the moment came when Li Mu decided the time was right to go out and fight. Though he was quite content to not fight at all, once he decided to move against the enemy, he did so with overwhelming force, mustering all his strength and aiming of settle the score with a single battle. This was his choice, and his enemy had no idea that he meant for this battle to be the only, and final, battle of the war. The first thing Li Mu did was to order a massive number of local nomads to release their livestock to graze on the plains - the countryside was instantly filled with herders. The Xiongnu responded by sending out a small mounted invasion force.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Li Mu intentionally lost the first engagement with the Xiongnu force, sacrificing a few thousand men to the enemy. The Xiongnu chieftain was delighted when he heard about this and, licking their lips at the thought of the loot waiting to be pillaged, the Xiongnu followed their leader in an invasion of the border country. Meanwhile, Li Mu had deployed his men in a pincer formation around the Xiongnu's flanks, catching them in an ambush and vanquishing over 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. Li Mu routed the Xiongnu chieftain, destroyed the Chanlan people, defeated the Dong Hu barbarians, and forced the Lin Hu barbarians into submission.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For the next ten years, the Xiongnu didn't once dare to set foot over the border into the state of Zhao. Greed is a huge weakness of human nature. During the Warring States period (475-221 BCE), Duke Mu of Qin once asked his advisor Jian Shu what he needed to do to claim dominion over the entire world. Jian Shu replied: ¡§Those who would rule over all the world must renounce three things: greed, anger and haste. Greed brings much loss, anger brings much difficulty, and haste brings many mistakes.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If one can thoroughly examine the scale of potential harms and benefits, and plan accordingly, what need is there for greed? If one can think from one's counterpart's position and weigh one's own position against theirs, what need is there for anger?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
If one can accurately measure the amount of time required for various things, slow or fast, and plan unhurriedly, what need is there for haste? My lord, if you can renounce these three things, dominion will not be far away."
Any time you need to make a judgment call or get something done, you need to have a good grasp on two concepts: go after things that benefit you, and stay away from things that put you in danger.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: These two concepts are equally important, but although people should in theory maintain a 50:50 balance between them, more often than not the ratio is somewhere between 70:30 and 90:10, in favor of going after benefit.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The reason for this is that things that are beneficial tend to be highly visible, and they're more exciting. Meanwhile, danger tends to lurk in the shadows, and because it seems so far away, people tend to think they can get away with leaving such things to chance.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
We often see people doing high-risk things even though the payoff is extremely small. This is because the payoff is immediate, while the danger, no matter how obvious, can be dismissed by the hopeless logic of 'Maybe it won't happen.'
If you're not greedy, you can't be tricked. All tricks basically boil down to greed.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When you're defrauded in some get-rich-quick scheme, the person who's tricked you is actually yourself. This is how people are. When they see profit, they're capable of going to extraordinary lengths to trick themselves, using self-talk like: 'Go for it!

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
You'll be fine!'
It's important to not let your desires sway your judgment when profit and danger are involved. If you can't win, you must be able to wait

Extract from the original text:
¡§If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him."

Analysis:
If the enemy is 'secure at all points,' meaning that they hold a strong military position, victory is out of reach.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
In that case, you have to employ the stratagem of waiting, and avoid making any rash moves. The Tang dynasty military strategist, Duke Li of Wei, put it like this: ¡§If you see that the enemy is exposed, then attack; if you see that the enemy is secure, then halt."
As for the line, 'If he is in superior strength, evade him,' Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§If my enemy has superior strength, I must stay clear of the sharp edge of his sword."
Du You comments: ¡§If the enemy's treasury is well supplied and his soldiers are filled with vigor, then you must retreat and wait for him to slacken; watch for changes and respond accordingly."
People often think that the only way to get opportunities is to take action first, but this is a mistake. That's because they forget to look at the other side of things, and there's always a price to be paid for any action.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
There's a common modern Chinese saying that expresses this quite well: 'If you go looking for ways to die, then you're going to die.'
We are reminded of the truth in this by the opening words of Sun Tzu's The Art of War: ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin." 
In war, every move is a matter of life or death, not just for the soldiers out fighting battles, but also for the state itself.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Above all else, be as careful as you possibly can. This is the first of three principles at the heart of this chapter. The second principle is the concept that the best thing you can do is to know ahead of time who is going to win; you can't just make victory happen. If you properly analyze your own situation and the enemy's, you can work out whether or not the odds of victory are on your side.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If they're not, you can march to war and fight as hard as you like, but victory will always slip away from you. It simply cannot be forced. If the enemy is as battle-hardened as you are, no amount of cheerleading or chest thumping will help you win, especially since the enemy will be thumping their own chests just as hard. The third principle is the idea of not trying to fight 100 battles and win 100 victories, but finishing the war with a single battle. Fighting a long war back and forth, without having something to show for your efforts, is a waste of blood, money and rations, particularly because once you're in that situation, you have to keep going.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Any general who gets stuck in the mud like this is committing a deadly sin. You need to get the timing right, move from a position of stability, and fight with overpowering strength when the time comes.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This is how to solve problems. So, the steps to be followed when the enemy has greater strength and holds a solid position are: 1) Be prepared and avoid fighting; 2) Be patient and keep yourself under control; 3) Use smooth diplomacy; 4) Wait for the enemy to let down their guard or make an unforced error, and then trick them into more mistakes (as Emperor Taizong said: ¡§Use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one's foe"); and 5) Get your timing right, and strike while the iron is hot. For a classic demonstration of these principles, let's turn to the War of the Three Kingdoms, which followed the collapse of the Han dynasty, and look at how the Wu general Lu Meng defeated the renowned Han loyalist general, Guan Yu.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: We begin with Guan Yu in the Yangzi River province of Jingzhou. He commanded a powerful army and could boast of 'a hundred victories in a hundred battles.' He had even received the surrender of one of the state of Wei's most feared generals, Yu Jin, and his name inspired popular rebellions that he directed from afar against his enemy, Cao Cao, in many parts of north China. The name of Guan Yu inspired awe throughout all of China, to the extent that Cao considered changing his capital city to put more distance between himself and the spearhead of Guan Yu's forces.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But Cao Cao's general, Sima Yi, had a plan. He claimed that there was no way the neighboring state of Eastern Wu would want to see Guan Yu become any more powerful, so Cao Cao should form an alliance and join forces with them to deal with Guan Yu together. That is exactly what happened.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Guan Yu actually only had control of Jingzhou because his commander-in-chief, Liu Bei, had borrowed the province from Eastern Wu's Emperor, Sun Quan. Of course, Liu Bei was reluctant to give it back, and following negotiations it was divided up.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Half went back to Eastern Wu and half remained in Liu Bei's hands. This situation was a sore point for Eastern Wu. At the same time, Guan Yu was becoming recklessly arrogant. When Yu Jin surrendered, 30,000 men and horses under his command were handed over to Guan Yu. Without enough provisions to feed these extra mouths, Guan Yu made a shocking move - he seized granaries controlled by Eastern Wu, adding insult to injury.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Emperor Sun Quan made up his mind to do something about it. Liu Bang and Sun Quan were allies, and Guan Yu's main aim in Jingzhou was to use it as a base to launch campaigns against the state of Wei. Guan Yu was obsessed with capturing the Wei fortress of Fancheng, but at the same time he was wary of the potential threat posed by Eastern Wu. He feared that if he made moves to attack Fancheng, he would make himself vulnerable to attack from behind by Eastern Wu general Lu Meng. Because of this, Guan Yu left a large reserve force behind to defend Jingzhou. As for Cao Cao, he could see that Guan Yu was too powerful to fight, and was keen to stay away from him. Likewise, Lu Meng could see that Guan Yu held a strong position, and so spent his time making preparations. For Lu Meng to stand a chance of taking Jingzhou, he would have to make Guan Yu pull out his defensive forces. In other words, Jingzhou would have to pivot from a 'secure' situation to an 'exposed' one. Guan Yu faced a dilemma: he needed to transfer some of his forces from Jingzhou to the front line in the north, because he didn't have enough manpower to take the fortress at Fancheng.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Yet, at the same time, he needed to leave enough troops in Jingzhou to guard against a possible attack from Lu Meng. This was the situation when Lu Meng came up with a plan: he would pretend to be sick. It actually wasn't hard for Lu Meng to convince people he was sick, because he really did get ill quite often, and this was already common knowledge. In fact, he did actually die of an illness after this part of the war was over. So, pleading sickness, Lu Meng returned to the capital city of Jianye and sent Lu Xun to command the garrison in Lukou in his place. At the time, Lu Xun was still a young man, and very much an unknown entity.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: When he arrived in Lukou, he wrote a letter to Guan Yu, waxing lyrical about how much he admired the great general. He essentially claimed to be Guan Yu's number one fan, and breathlessly told him how it was the honor of his life to be his neighbor, and that he hoped Guan Yu would be like an uncle to him, looking out for him while he was still young and inexperienced. Lu Xun also made it very clear that he would never dare make an enemy of the great Guan Yu.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Guan Yu was disarmed, and marched his Jingzhou garrison forces to the front line at Fancheng with peace of mind. Immediately, Lu Meng pounced from the sideline at the head of a large army, taking Jingzhou and cutting off Guan Yu's line of retreat. The war was soon over; Guan Yu was captured and promptly beheaded.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Guan Yu's defeat was the root of Liu Bei's ultimate failure. Jingzhou was the key to controlling the Central Plain of the Yellow River; once it was lost, Liu Bei was no longer a contender in the contest to unify all the lands of China. After losing Jingzhou, Liu Bei's brilliant general, Zhuge Liang, was forced to launch a doomed assault on the central plain by traversing the famously impassable Daba and Qinling mountain ranges from the Shu city of Hanzhong. Rugged terrain made transporting food supplies very difficult, even with Zhuge Liang's legendary invention, the wheelbarrow.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Tragically, Guan Yu's death led directly to the deaths of his sworn brothers, Zhang Fei and Liu Bei, about whom so many stories were written. Guan Yu is a classic example of the concept, 'A hundred fights and a hundred victories means that one defeat will spell ruin.' Sun Tzu's The Art of War tells us that ¡§good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage." This is precisely because good fighters don't fight many battles, and the battles they do fight are easy, uneventful and certainly not epic. They don't make for good stories.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Anyway, stories are only good for entertaining civilians. Guan Yu was the exact opposite of Sun Tzu's model general - his glory echoed all across the land, and he was immortalized by ordinary people everywhere for being a perfect combination of virtue, wisdom and strength. But professionals have a different take: Guan Yu was a leader who led his country to ruin.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Pay attention to this stratagem. Forgetting it is a common mistake

Extract from the original text:
¡§If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him."

Analysis:
Du Mu comments: ¡§A general who is of fierce, unyielding temperament may be provoked into a rage; then, he will pursue gratification and pay no mind to his best-laid plans."
Being able to trigger an enemy's rage is like casting a magic spell. They will forget all about what they were trying to achieve, and instead will instantly do whatever it takes to free themselves of their hate and anger.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In the end, they throw their life away, without ever relieving themselves of the emotions that doomed them. This stratagem is basically a trick designed to trip up proud and hot-headed generals. One of the seven ancient military classics, The Wei Liaozi, notes: ¡§A broad-minded man cannot be provoked into rage." When your enemy is a relaxed kind of person, it won't be easy to trick them by making them angry. A classic example of this stratagem is the defeat of Cao Jiu by Liu Bang's forces during the battle of Sishui River, before the establishment of the Han dynasty.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Xiang Yu held a position at Chenggao, and a face-off there against Liu Bang had sunk into a deadlock. Liu Bang's gambit was to hit Xiang Yu from behind. He sent his commanders, Lu Wan and Liu Jia, across the White Horse Ford at the head of over 20,000 men, to link up with Peng Yue, duke of Jiancheng. Their combined force attacked the region of Liang beyond Xiang Yu's forces, successfully taking around a dozen cities and cutting Xiang Yu's supply line.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Xiang Yu's hand was forced. He split up his army and personally led part of his forces to backtrack and attack Peng Yue, leaving General Cao Jiu in charge of holding Chenggao. Just before Xiang Yu left, he gave Cao Jiu detailed instructions: ¡§Make sure you hold Chenggao. If the Han army tries to attack, stay well clear of them; don't give battle, don't let them take the east. Within 15 days, I'll have Peng Yue's head and the Liang region will be under my control. Then I'll come back and resume command." 
After Xiang Yu left, Cao Jiu did what he'd been told, holding his position and refusing to come out.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: This is where our stratagem of the day makes its appearance. Liu Bang built a raised platform just outside Chenggao's walls, which he used as a launchpad for shouting a constant stream of verbal abuse at the enemy. He kept the insults coming for five or six days without stopping, until the enemy troops couldn't stand to listen for a single second longer.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Cao Jiu lost his temper. Forgetting all about Xiang Yu's plan, and what he was supposed to be doing, he became hell-bent on going out to teach this pack of rascals a lesson. Cao Jiu stormed out through the gate with his army behind him, wading across the Sishui River. Unsurprisingly, Liu Bang used the standard tactic of attacking when the enemy was still in the river. Cao Jiu was badly beaten, Chenggao was lost, and the tide of the war turned. Knowing his career was over, and too ashamed to face Xiang Yu, Cao Jiu slit his own throat by the riverbank. This stratagem was also attempted by Zhuge Liang against Sima Yi, but on that occasion he wasn't able to pull it off.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Because Guan Yu had lost the province of Jingzhou, the only way for Liu Bei's Han forces to move north. out of the area that is now Sichuan Province. and attack Cao Cao's state of Wei was to cross through the steep and inhospitable mountains between Han and Wei. Zhuge Liang attempted to do this many times, but the problem was that the terrain made it impossible to bring enough food supplies, which is the main reason each campaign ended with Zhuge Liang pulling up short before the finish line. The campaigns lasted roughly a month each time, which was the maximum period Zhuge Liang could stay in the field without being forced to head home without enough rations to get his men back over the mountains. So, Zhuge Liang had to fight fast, ideally only in pitched battles in open country. Cao Cao and his generals knew the score - all they had to do was hold firm for a month and hunger would force the enemy to go home. If they could avoid fighting, victory was theirs, but if they did fight things became a lot more uncertain.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Of course, not fighting quickly became the unquestioned strategy of all of Cao Cao's commanders. During Zhuge Liang's final drive north into Wei, his army came face-to-face with Sima Yi's forces on the Wuzhang Plain. As usual, there was no way Sima Yi was going to get involved in a fight, despite all kinds of provocations by Zhuge Liang, including insult of gifting Sima Yi with a set of women's clothing. Sima Yi wasn't falling for it; he was not going to get dragged into a fight.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Zhuge Liang was so exhausted by his efforts, physically and mentally, that he got sick and died while still in the field. His death marked the end of Liu Bei's northern expeditions. Sima Yi is a strong example of a player who has his head in the game.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
He never forgot what his goals were, and he stuck to the basic playbook. Forgetting our intentions is a mistake that we all make, and the reason isn't always anger. Any kind of distraction can pull us further and further away from what's important, without our even realizing it, and we end up chasing after unimportant details while losing sight of the essentials. This is why the Buddhist scriptures tell us: ¡§Never forget why you started; this is the only way to accomplish your mission."
Every day, we should evaluate everything we do against our original motivation, our plan. At the same time, we have to say 'no' to unhelpful urges, stay strong in the face of temptation, block out distractions, stick to our plan, and never forget why we started.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
No shame in showing weakness. Whatever you do, don't fight for the recognition of others, especially temporary recognition 

Extract from the original text:
¡§Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant."

Analysis:
The goal of 'pretending to be weak, that the enemy may grow arrogant' is to make your enemy underestimate you. If the enemy underestimates you, they won't prepare properly, and so they will be vulnerable to sudden attack.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
A classic example of this stratagem is the Xiongnu chieftain Modun's invasion of the Donghu barbarians. Modun came to power as chieftain of the Xiongnu Empire at the same time that the Qin dynasty was crumbling. The Donghu were very powerful at the time, and sent a messenger to ask the Xiongnu chieftain a favor: ¡§Your father, Touman, had a terrific horse," the messenger said, ¡§a very fast horse. How about you hand it over?"
Modun looked around at his advisors, and asked them: ¡§Well, should I give them the horse?" The advisors responded that this was terribly rude of the Donghu. Modun's father's horse was a treasure of the Xiongnu people; why should they give it up for no good reason?"
But Modun said, ¡§It's good to be kind to our neighbors, and after all, it's only a horse! I will gladly give it to them."
Not long after this incident, a Donghu messenger came again, and delivered this message to Modun from his chief: ¡§You have an awful lot of wives; why don't you give one of them to me?" Modun's advisors were furious, and shouted: ¡§You have gone too far, Donghu!

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
How dare you come to our chieftain asking for wives! We should send our warriors to punish you!"
But, once again, Modun said: ¡§It's good to be kind to our neighbors, and all they want is a girl; why be so stingy? Give them what they want!"
More time passed, and the Donghu messenger came again.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
This time, he said: ¡§You have thousands of miles of land that you're not using; why not give some of it to us?"
Modun asked his advisors what they thought. They hesitated. Since their lord had been willing to give up his own wife to these people, they weren't sure what they were supposed to say. In the end, they mumbled something non-committal, along the lines of, ¡§Well, we could give them the land, or we could not, either way..."
Modun went ballistic. ¡§The land is the very substance of our country," he raged.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: ¡§How could I give it away?" He immediately beheaded all of the advisors who'd said, 'give them the land,' and then he sent his warriors to attack the Donghu. The Donghu, unprepared because they hadn't taken Modun seriously, were wiped out.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Now that Modun was on the warpath, he didn't stop. He annexed in one fell swoop the Yuezhi nomads in the west, Loufan, Baiyang, the Great Bend of the Yellow River in the south, and Yan and Dai in the north. By the time Modun's rampage was finished, he'd reclaimed all of the Xiongnu territory that had been lost during their war against the Qin dynasty general, Meng Tian. It was also Modun who later surrounded Liu Bang (Emperor Gaozu) in the battle of Baideng, and signed a peace treaty with the Chinese Emperor granting him equal status as the Emperor's 'brother.'
When Emperor Gaozu died, Modun had ideas of invading Han dynasty China. Modun's queen had recently died, so he decided to send an envoy to Emperor Gaozu's widow, Empress Lu, with a highly improper message.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
It read: ¡§I am now a lonely lord... and I yearn to visit China. Your majesty, you too must be lonely now, living all alone. Since we two have both been saddened by unhappy circumstances, I express my wish for us to have once more what we have lost."
Modun was in effect asking the Chinese Empress if she'd like to marry him. Of course, Empress Lu was livid, as were the ministers in the Han court, and an old general named Fan Kuai even asked permission there and then to lead 100,000 crack troops to sweep the Xiongnu into oblivion.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But the General of the Household, Ji Bu, shouted: ¡§Fan Kuai, you should be executed for such a suggestion! Do you forget that our late lord the Emperor once led a host of over 400,000 men against the Xiongnu, and yet he was surrounded at Baideng?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
How, Lord Fan Kuai, do you propose to 'sweep the Xiongnu into oblivion' with only 100,000? To even suggest that you could do this is tantamount to lying to your Empress!"
Empress Lu had the final say.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: She decided not to go to war with Modun, but to continue with the old policy of appeasement. She sent a letter back to him, in which she wrote: ¡§My thanks to the great chieftain for thinking of us in these times.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: However, I fear that we have nothing here that is worth seeing, only endless mountains, treacherous passes and soldiers. If the great chieftain insists on visiting, I am afraid he will find that our poetry and books are rather dull, and the best thing to do would be to allow our fine soldiers to guide you on a hunting foray.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
As for me, I am old and frail, and my teeth and hair are falling out. But if it's hunting that interests the great chieftain, we will be delighted to accommodate him!"
Modun could see from the Empress' letter that she was fully in control, so he shrugged and let go of his invasion dreams.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
After all, he'd only been testing the waters to see if the Emperor's death might have opened an opportunity to add China to his collection of territories. Fighting tired

Extract from the original text:
¡§If he is taking his ease, give him no rest."

Analysis:
The idea is to be well rested while the enemy is exhausted.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If you find yourself facing an enemy who is 'taking his ease,' then harass him, causing him headaches however you can. Make him so tired that he doesn't have the energy to fight all-out on the battlefield.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: A classic historical example of this stratagem is the war between the states of Wu and Chu during the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE). When king Helu of Wu attacked Chu, he asked for advice from General Wu Zixu, who responded: ¡§You may divide your army between three commanders.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: First, order only one commander to attack. The enemy is sure to counter-attack with all the force at their disposal, and then our commander should order his men to retreat. Then, wait until the enemy has withdrawn their forces, and immediately launch a new attack led by the second of your three commanders. When the enemy marches out to fight, retreat once more.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Continue in this way, constantly forcing the enemy into action, employing a multitude of deceptions, until they are too exhausted to fight with conviction. Then, attack with all three commanders, and the enemy will fall at once."
King Helu did exactly as Wu Zixu advised, and over the course of the next year, the Chu general Zi Chong led his forces out to fight seven times, never successfully, and giving all that he had in the effort. Finally, the Wu army launched an all-out assault, and captured the Chu capital, the city of Ying.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Much later, in the beginning stages of the War of the Three Kingdoms, Cao Cao was locked in a struggle with a northern warlord named Yuan Shao. Just before the two sides clashed in the decisive Battle of Guandu, the strategist Feng Tian presented a war plan to Yuan Shao, but Yuan refused to listen. This was Feng Tian's plan:
¡§Cao Cao is a skilled military commander, and he will not easily be bested.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It would be best to settle in for a long conflict. You have a secure position because of the four provinces under your control, which affords you the protection of mountains and rivers. You should focus on the external and the internal at the same time.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Externally, seek alliances with strong generals; internally, focus on improving the state of both your fighting men and agricultural production. After honing your men's fighting skills, divide them into multiple stealth units, and send them south of the Yellow River to harass whichever regions are vulnerable. Then, if the enemy counter-attacks from the right, strike to the left, and if they counter-attack from the left, strike to the right.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In this way, the enemy will become too exhausted to fight effectively, and their people will be unable to go about their daily work in peace. You will wear the enemy down without any hard work on your part. Within three years, you can defeat them.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
This is the strategy I present to you today. But if you have already made up your mind to claim victory now, in a single battle, or else be vanquished in the attempt, there will be no use for regrets after it is done."
Chairman Mao Zedong expressed the same basic ideas as Feng Tian when he summarized the Red Army's strategy during the Chinese Civil War: ¡§The enemy advances, we retreat; the enemy camps, we harass; the enemy tires, we attack; the enemy retreats, we pursue." 
The art of war is actually very simple. What's difficult is making good judgment calls.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For example, when you see enemy forces approaching, how do you know if they're just planning to harass you a little bit and then leave, or if they're launching a full-on attack? In truth, there's no way of knowing. That's why Chairman Mao also said: ¡§On the battlefield, all strategy is forgotten." In the heat of battle, you constantly have to respond to emergency situations at a moment's notice, which leaves no time or mental capacity to think about things like strategy or the art of war. The way to deal with this problem is to stay away from the overall situation, and also to stay one step ahead of the enemy, so that they go where you want them to, rather than the other way round.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: In terms of your own position, you have to set yourself up in an impregnable position, protect yourself, and do not rashly commit to a fight if it means moving away from your position. Be like Li Mu, building up your defenses and sheltering your resources in the safety of your walls, closing your gates and not allowing yourself to be provoked into coming out until you're ready. If you're not ready after a year, keep preparing.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If you're not ready after ten years, still keep preparing. Then, the moment you are ready and an opportunity arrives, blow your enemy away in a single battle. In terms of dealing with the enemy, remember how Emperor Taizong summarized 'all the books on war, ancient and new.' He said it all boils down to: ¡§Using a multitude of diverse methods to fool one's foe." Do whatever it takes; use your imagination. All of the ancient generals read the same military texts.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: And they didn't just read them - they memorized these books by heart. So, why was there such a huge gap between their abilities to get results? The distinguishing factor is whether or not generals have good judgment. Without it, you can't effectively judge the situation in front of you.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: On the surface, the problem seems to be that you misjudged the enemy, but the real problem is misjudging yourself. As long as you can make accurate judgments about yourself, whatever the enemy does, you will naturally know how to deal with them.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Why do we let enemies turn us against our friends? Extract from the original text:
¡§If his forces are united, separate them."

Analysis:
Li Quan comments: ¡§Sabotage their diplomatic efforts, create schisms between king and minister, and thus transform them."
During the Warring States period, the states of Qin and Zhao fought against each other in a conflict called the Battle of Changping (262-260 BCE). A Zhao general named Lian Po found himself on the losing end of several battles, and decided to hole up in the safety of a fortress.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The Qin forces saw that Lian Po had no intention of coming out to fight, so they sent agents to Zhao to spread rumors that the Qin commanders didn't think Lian Po would be difficult to deal with, and that they were much more worried about another Zhao commander, named Zhao Kuo. The Zhao king fell for the Qin trickery and, ignoring the desperate pleas of Zhao Kuo's mother and his advisor Ling Xiangru not to do it, sent Zhao Kuo to take over Lian Po's command. In the end, this led to a terrible tragedy - the Battle of Changping ended in the brutal deaths of 400,000 Zhao troops. Why did the King of Zhao fall for the Qin trick?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Even before the Qin agents spread their rumors, the king was not at all pleased with Lian Po's losing record, nor his subsequent unwillingness to fight more battles. However, the king didn't have a good excuse to replace Lian Po. That is, not until the Qin agents did their dirty work. So, as far as the king was concerned, these rumors had been a great help; they even saved him the effort of working out which general to send out to replace Lian Po. Let's turn again to the wars between Liu Bang and Xiangyu following the collapse of the Qin dynasty. Liu Bang spent a year trapped by Xiang Yu in the city of Xinyang, cut off from outside help and supplies. Luckily, Liu Bang's advisor, Chen Ping, had a plan. He pointed out that Xiang Yu only had a handful of capable men giving him advice: Fan Zeng (whom Xiang Yu so respected that he called him his 'second father'), Zhong Limei, Long Qie and Zhou Yin. If a wedge could be driven between people in Xiang Yu's camp, these four men could be eliminated, and Xiang Yu would become much easier to deal with. Liu Bang gave Chen Ping 40,000 catties of gold, which he used to bribed a few of Xiang Yu's officers to spread rumors that Fan Zeng and Zhong Limei were dissatisfied that, despite doing more than anyone else for Xiang Yu, they hadn't got what they deserved: the title of 'king.' According to the rumor, Fan Zeng and Zhong Limei had already entered into a secret alliance with Liu Bang to destroy Xiang Yu, and that afterwards they would split Xiang Yu's kingdom between them. When the rumor reached Xiang Yu's ears, he became suspicious.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: He started to doubt Zhong Limei's loyalty, and stopped talking with him about important issues. He even suspected Fan Zeng of secretly communicating with Liu Bang, and began to treat him quite rudely. To put one more nail in Fan Zeng's coffin, Chen Ping contrived to put on a show. One day, when a messenger from Xiang Yu visited Liu Bang's camp, Chen Ping ordered servants to lay out an exquisite spread of fine meats and wines for the messenger. He then asked the man: ¡§What instructions from Lord Fan Zeng?" The messenger, perplexed, responded: ¡§I was sent by Xiang Yu, not Fan Zeng." Immediately, Chen Ping changed his tune. ¡§Oh! We thought you'd been sent by Fan Zeng!" he said, and ordered the servants to take away the fine meats and wines, and ushered the messenger into another, much less comfortable room, where he was served cheap tea and plain rice. Then, Chen Ping walked out, leaving the messenger to his own devices.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Of course, the messenger was outraged. He had not expected to be humiliated like this. When he returned to his own camp, and told Xiang Yu what had happened, Xiang Yu became fully convinced that Fan Zeng was in cahoots with Liu Bang. Fan Zeng kept on trying to give Xiang Yu advice - he suggested stepping up the siege efforts, but Xiang Yu blankly refused to listen. Fan Zeng knew why his lord was behaving so out-of-character: it was because of outside forces spreading rumors that he was in league with Liu Bang. He knew that Xiang Yu had been tricked, and so he asked for permission to return home.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Xiang Yu let him go without a second thought. Chen Ping's little show was far from subtle, so why did Xiang Yu fall for it? It was because Xiang Yu was already suspicious, and because the rumors were mostly true.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: For instance, it was true that Zeng Fan and Zhong Limei had made a bigger contribution than anyone else to Xiang Yu's rise, and it was true that they did not hold the title of 'king.' Xiang Yu had always been stingy, and reluctant to reward his men. As Han Xin said, Xiang Yu owned stamps specifically carved to grant people the titles of 'king' and 'duke,' and yet he could barely bring himself to let them out of his grasp.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: On the rare occasions that he did, he quickly snatched them back. This was a weakness in his psyche, and the rumor played to this weakness perfectly - he couldn't help but believe it. What about Fan Zeng?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Did he do anything wrong? Actually, yes. Before the war began, Xiang Yu once had a chance to kill Liu Bang at the Feast of Swan Goose Gate, but let him go despite Fan Zeng urging him to take advantage of the opportunity to eliminate his rival. After Liu Bang made his get-away, Fan Zeng was furious, and shouted abuse at Xiang Zhuang, the would-be assassin whose job it had been to kill Liu Bang while entertaining the banqueters with a 'sword dance.' ¡§Impudent boy! You don't even deserve my counsel!" Fan Zeng thundered.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Everyone there knew very well who Fan Zeng's words were really meant for - Xiang Yu himself. So, although Fan Zeng was a talented man, gifted with many kinds of wisdom, he lacked the wisdom to get along with Xiang Yu, which happened to be the most vital thing. It was the thing that he absolutely had to get right if he ever wanted to accomplish his ambitions on the world stage.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Why did events happen the way they did? It all comes down to a very human weakness: as close a relationship you may have with someone, there's naturally a corresponding build-up of resentment. Our relationships with enemies are very simple - it's about a clash of interests, to be solved either by fighting or by negotiating. But close relationships of any kind are more complex, because they're full of strong emotions, spanning a broad range from love to hate.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The relationship you have with your enemies is based on competition; this is a normal social mechanism. But, there is also internal competition between members of the same organization, because organizations are essentially mechanisms for competition and distribution of resources. The stratagem of dividing one's enemies is about external competitors crossing the boundaries of competition itself, and taking part in their enemy's internal competition.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The results can be magic. Castles always fall from the inside. If you don't want to fall prey to the stratagem of division, make sure your leader is broad-minded and of strong character. Stay alert, don't slack off
 
Extract from the original text:
¡§Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected."
 
Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Attack where they are lax, appear where they are exposed."
There is a phrase coined by the ancient strategist Wu Qi: ¡§When you step out of your door, act as though the enemy's in your yard." It means that you should always be vigilant. The Confucians also liked to talk about caution and fear: ¡§Be cautious of what you cannot see, and be fearful of what you do not know." Stay on the alert, and pay attention to things that you don't know, and things that you might not notice.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The ancient Classic of Poetry says: ¡§Tremble with fear, as though near the edge of an abyss, as though treading o'er thin ice."
When I was in elementary and middle school, the school buildings had big slogans painted on them: 'United - Alert - Earnest - Active.' But what does the word 'alert' really mean to school kids? In Chinese, the word used for 'alert' in this case is also the word for 'nervous,' so for us, we only knew this word as meaning the nervousness we felt when we were in the classroom.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The origins of this slogan come from the school motto that Mao Zedong gave to the Counter-Japanese Military and Political University in Yan'an during the war of resistance against Japan. Leaders must always be paying attention.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's important to keep your people in a state of alertness - if there is any sign that they're letting down their guard, you should immediately light a fire under them, because slacking off is a sure way to lose. This is especially true on the battlefield, where your enemy is constantly racking their brains, studying you to work out where you might be less than watertight.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Beware of thinking that you can relax in a certain area just because there don't seem to be any problems there - your enemy is probably already on to you. Now, let's look at an example of this stratagem in action. Cao Cao was preparing to launch a campaign against the nomadic Wuhuan people who lived in the far north, and his invasion strategy was drawn up by an advisor named Guo Jia. This was his advice: ¡§The barbarians rely too much on the fact that they are far away, and I am certain they are not well prepared for an invasion. Because they will be unprepared, you should attack them suddenly and swiftly; this is how you can destroy them."
When Cao Cao's army had made it north of Yi, Guo Jia gave his lord another round of advice: ¡§In war, speed is paramount; we have many miles to travel before we can reach within striking distance of our enemy; our supply carts are many and burdensome, and so it is difficult to put ourselves in a favourable position. It would be better to send out our light forces, and to travel by shortcuts so as to stay hidden and undetected by the enemy."
Cao Cao took Guo Jia's advice, and rode for Lulong Pass at the head of his light forces.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Bearing directly down on the Wuhuan chieftain's court, they took the Wuhuan by surprise and totally destroyed them. Another example of an effective surprise attack is the conquest of the city of Chengdu, in the final stages of the War of the Three Kingdoms, by General Deng Ai of the state of Wei. The two greatest generals of Wei, Deng Ai and Zhong Hui, together launched an attack on the kingdom of Shu (modern-day Sichuan).

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: However, their progress was blocked at Sword Gate Pass, site of a Shu fortress guarded by General Jiang Wei. The invading Wei generals settled in to a lengthy siege, but they seemed unable to breach the fortress's defenses. So, Deng Ai came up with a different plan, which he explained to his comrade, Zhong Hui: ¡§I know of a path that heads out of Yinping and around Sword Gate Pass. It is devilishly perilous, but I can use it to head west toward Chengdu and take the enemy unawares, striking them directly in the heart.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Then, if the forces at Sword Gate Pass backtrack towards Fu County, you will be able to breach the fortress. And if they decide to stay in their fortress, there will be fewer of their forces to guard Fu County, and I will be able to swiftly capture the whole region."
It was the tenth month of the lunar calendar - winter - when Deng Ai set out on a journey of over 200 miles through uninhabited mountains. As they slowly moved through the treacherous terrain, they had to chisel paths out of sheer rock faces and build bridges across rivers.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The mountains in that region are steep, and the valleys deep, and the men soon ran out of food. They were in grave danger. At one point, Deng Ai had to wrap himself in a roll of felt and roll down a mountain, and at other times he and his men had to march single-file, climbing trees and scaling cliffs. When they emerged from the mountains, it was as if they'd fallen from the sky, coming out of nowhere and smashing through Shu's weak reserve forces all the way to Chengdu's city walls.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Jiang Wei, along with the main Shu army, had stayed put in Sword Gate Pass, and so the Lord of Shu, Liu Chan, quickly surrendered. Play your cards close to your chest and success will follow; talk carelessly and watch yourself fail

Extract from the original text:
 ¡§These military devices, leading to victory, must not be divulged beforehand."

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Divulging information is the same as giving away your plans."
We have just talked about many different stratagems of deception, but one thing is essential if you want to successfully use any one of them: you cannot let anyone know about your plans.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If your enemy finds out your plan, it becomes totally useless. But it's not just your enemy you need to keep in the dark. You can't let your own people know what you're planning either, because the more people know a secret, the more likely it becomes that it will leak. The Warring States period philosophical text, the Han Feizi, says: ¡§Success comes from watertight actions, failure comes from loose words." In any bitter struggle, secret-keeping is of paramount importance. If you had to pick the most exceptional example of secret-keeping from Chinese history, there'd be no better choice than Modun, the Xiongnu chieftain discussed in an earlier chapter, who we last saw soliciting the widowed Empress Wu for her hand in marriage. What was his secret?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: As a young man, he plotted to commit treason against his own father, who he indeed ended up killing, installing himself as the new chieftain. Although Modun was the crown prince, his father, Touman, fell in love with a concubine and fathered another son, and decided to pass the throne to his beloved concubine's son instead of to Modun. Then, Touman formed an alliance with the Yuezhi people and gave them Modun as a hostage. Not long after, Touman attacked the Yuezhi, hoping that the Yuezhi would kill Modun, doing his dirty work for him. But in a twist of events, Modun managed to steal a horse and escape back home. His bravery was apparently enough to win back his father's affections, and Touman forgot all about his plans to kill him.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But Modun didn't forget. He knew all about his father's plot, and set his mind on killing his father, the concubine and his young half-brother. Conspiring against the state is serious business; it's not something that one person can pull off alone.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: It's vital to work with partners, and naturally this involves talking things through with other people. This stage is when the risk of failure is at its highest, because once you've told someone what you're planning, there's no way out for them, and no way of staying uninvolved.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They have two choices: either stake their life on fighting alongside you, to the death, or immediately sell you out. For example, the Hundred Day Reform movement that attempted to modernize Qing dynasty China at the end of the 19th century failed partly because one of the reformers, Tan Sitong, forced the powerful warlord Yuan Shikai's hand. Yuan then joined the other side - the anti-reform Empress Dowager Cixi.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: But there are always exceptions. Modun became the only person in the history of China to accomplish a coup all alone, without telling a soul what he was planning. The way Modun did it was by training his men to give conditioned responses, just like Pavlov's dog.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: First, Modun personally made a special kind of arrow that whistles loudly as it flies through the air. Then, he conditioned his men to immediately shoot whenever he fired his whistling arrow, and to aim in whichever direction the whistling arrow was flying. Any man who hesitated or delayed for even a second was immediately beheaded. After training his men for a while, one day Modun suddenly shot his whistling arrow towards his favorite horse. Some of his men hesitated, unsure if Modun had really meant to order them to kill his horse. Too slow - all of these men were beheaded, and everyone else was left in no doubt that Modun was not joking around. Another day, Modun suddenly fired towards his most beloved concubine.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Again, some of his men hesitated, and were immediately hauled away and beheaded. On the third occasion, Modun fired towards his father's horse. This time, his men immediately fired a single volley at the horse.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: None of them had thought twice. Modun knew that his conditioning work was finished; he was ready to make his move. The time came when Modun was out hunting with his father. He suddenly shot his whistling arrow towards his father, and his men, without time to think about what they were doing, immediately became accomplices in their chieftain's murder. Modun's plan had worked, and he went on to become the first truly powerful chieftain in the history of the Xiongnu Empire.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: His military might was the reason why the Han dynasty Emperors avoided confrontation, instead managing the Xiongnu threat with a policy of marrying Chinese princesses to Xiongnu chieftains. There's nothing difficult about The Thirty-Six Stratagems, yet people get very excited about it.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Meanwhile, the Five Factors and Seven Considerations are highly complex, but the mere mention of them sends people to sleep! Extract from the original text:
¡§Now the general who wins a battle makes many calculations in his temple ere the battle is fought.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
The general who loses a battle makes but few calculations beforehand. Thus do many calculations lead to victory, and few calculations to defeat: how much more no calculation at all! It is by attention to this point that I can foresee who is likely to win or lose."

Analysis:
Li Quan comments: ¡§The divine commander shuns donning armor in favor of making calculations; 'Many calculations' refers to sixty calculations or more, while 'few calculations' refers to less than sixty calculations."
