If you make more calculations than the enemy, victory is yours, and vice versa. This is why, if you properly carry out calculations in the temple before going to war, the outcome is easy to predict.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The side that makes more calculations will win. If you have made more calculations, you can go out and fight, but if you've made less, you need to exercise caution, think things through thoroughly, and spend more time preparing.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If the odds are totally against you, don't even think about going out to fight. And with that, we have reached the end of the first chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War - 'Calculations.' As we have seen, the bulk of its content is divided between two themes: the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations,' and the 'Twelve Ways of Deception.' The former is the foundation; it represents strategy and the real balance of power. To recap, the 'Five Factors' are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; and (5) Method and Discipline.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They're about comparing yourself and the enemy in terms of each of these, which is done by calculating the answers to the questions posed in 'the Seven Considerations.' These are: (1) Which of the two kings is imbued with the Moral Law?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: (2) Which of the two generals has the most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: (7) In which army is there the greater consistency both in reward and punishment? This is what the art of war is all about; calculating the outcome using the tools provided by the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations.' You only fight after you've already won, which means that if the odds aren't firmly in your favor, don't fight. Instead, bide your time, build your strength, and keep on preparing. When I say 'preparing,' I mean preparing in a way that boosts your score in the calculations of the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations,' because, again, these are the foundations of the art of war. Win first, fight later.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Win while you're still in the temple doing your calculations, summon your generals and mobilize your armies. March to the battlefield and watch the result reveal itself. Once you are on the battlefield, the dictum that 'The art of war is the way of deception' becomes true. At this point, it becomes more about unleashing the 'Twelve ways of deception,' and 'using a multitude of diverse methods to fool one's foe.' When able, seem unable; when using your forces, seem inactive; when near, make the enemy believe you are far away; when far away, make him believe you are near. Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Then, crush him. If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him. If your opponent is quick to anger, irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If he is taking his ease, give him no rest. If his forces are united, separate them. Attack him where he is unprepared, and appear where you are not expected. These 'Twelve Ways of Deception' are pretty much the same as the Thirty-Six Stratagems. They're cunning tricks and fancy maneuvers that prove drool-inducing for so many people who like to fantasize about using them to achieve lightning-fast gains.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: They're irresistible to those who expect to make something out of nothing. But, the fundamentals are never about flashy tricks, no matter what you're trying to achieve. It may be true that Liu Bang used many cunning ruses to bamboozle his way to victory over Xiang Yu, but the overarching structure of his success was still built on the foundation of the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations.' We see this throughout his career, from his merciful sparing of the people of Qin, to the simple new law code that he instituted. It was Liu Bang's political actions that really propelled him miles ahead of Xiang Yu. China's all-time most famous practitioner of ingenious tricks was Zhuge Liang, and the stories about him have become part of the fabric of Chinese culture.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
Yet, he ultimately didn't win. The reason was that the odds of victory and the arithmetic of the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations' were never really on his side. That's why I fully agree with his rival, Sima Yi, who condemned him as ¡§Trying to force his way against the currents of Heaven." Here, 'Heaven' is a stand-in for the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations.'
It's the same in business management. Don't waste your time thinking about fancy maneuvers.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Instead, get the basics right: products and service. The truth is that the 'Ways of Deception' are not at all difficult - there aren't many of them, and the main skill in using them is putting on a convincing show.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content:
'The Five Factors and Seven Considerations,' by contrast, are extremely complex, demanding strength of character, wisdom, sweat, time and accumulation. Their relative difficulty explains why people love to hear about the Thirty-Six Stratagems, but not so much about the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations.'



Sun Tzu said: ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Hence, it is a subject of inquiry that can on no account be neglected. The art of war, then, is governed by five constant factors, to be taken into account in one's deliberations, when seeking to determine the conditions in the field. These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; and (5) Method and Discipline.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: The Moral Law causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger. Heaven signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Earth comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death. The Commander stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerely, benevolence, courage and strictness.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: By method and discipline are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: These five heads should be familiar to every general: he who knows them will be victorious; he who knows them not will fail. Therefore, in your deliberations, when seeking to determine the military conditions, let them be made the basis of a comparison, in this way: (1) Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Moral law? (2) Which of the two generals has most ability?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained? (7) In which army is there the greater constancy both in reward and punishment?

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: By means of these seven considerations I can forecast victory or defeat. The general that hearkens to my counsel, and acts upon it, will conquer: let such a one be retained in command! The general that hearkens not to my counsel, nor acts upon it, will suffer defeat: let such a one be dismissed! While heeding the profit of my counsel, avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Accordingly, as circumstances are favourable, one should modify one's plans. All warfare is based on deception. Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable; when using our forces, we must seem inactive; when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away; when far away, we must make him believe we are near. Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Then, crush him. If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him. If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: If he is taking his ease, give him no rest. If his forces are united, separate them. Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected. These military devices, leading to victory, must not be divulged beforehand.

chapter: Chapter One of Sun Tzu's The Art of war: Calculations
content: Now, the general who wins a battle makes many calculations in his temple ere the battle is fought. The general who loses a battle makes but few calculations beforehand. Thus do many calculations lead to victory, and few calculations to defeat: how much more no calculation at all! It is by attention to this point that I can foresee who is likely to win or lose."

Waging War

War is about money and grain, not soldiers and horses

Extract from the original text:
¡§In the operations of war, where there are in the field a thousand swift chariots, as many heavy chariots, and a hundred thousand sets of armor, with provisions enough to carry them a thousand li, the expenditure at home and at the front, including entertainment of guests, small items such as glue and paint, and sums spent on chariots and armor, will reach the total of a thousand gold pieces per day. Such is the cost of raising an army of 100,000 men."

Analysis:
To start off the new chapter, Waging War, here's some commentary from Cao Cao: ¡§If one desires to wage war, one must first calculate the expense, and determine whether grain can be seized from one's enemy."
Another comment, by Zhang Yu, addresses the logical order of steps to be taken: ¡§The calculations being in order, prepare for war: calculate, in the following order, the costs of readying chariots and horses, procuring good equipment, and transporting grain and fodder." You need to have a budget. The 'swift chariots' Sun Tzu refers to were war chariots, each pulled by four horses.

When Sun Tzu was alive, stirrups had not yet been invented, making it too precarious for men on horseback to fight at close quarters. This meant there were no horseback soldiers, only war chariots. Each war chariot would carry three armored soldiers, and was backed up by 72 foot soldiers following closely behind, according to The Methods of Sima. Ancient Chinese war chariots were used in more or less the same way as tanks in modern warfare. One war chariot represents 75 soldiers. In Chinese history books, a common phrase is 'a country of a thousand chariots,' which is actually a practical measure of a country's military might. In meant that the country in question possesses 1,000 war chariots, equaling 75,000 soldiers in total. Meanwhile, 'heavy chariots' refers to supply carts, which would be loaded with everything from food rations and cooking equipment to weapons, armor, clothes, etc. Each heavy chariot would carry 25 men: ten cooks, five attendants, five horse grooms, and five laborers whose job it was to chop wood and fetch water. With 1,000 heavy chariots, the number of extra men adds up to 25,000. Together with the men assigned to light chariots, this adds up to army of 100,000 men, also explaining the arithmetic behind 'a hundred thousand sets of armor.'
This is definitely a lot of men to account for, but then you have to wrap your head around somehow procuring 'provisions enough to carry them a thousand li!' Transporting food was a seriously important part of warfare in ancient China. For example, suppose you're planning an expedition to attack the Xiongnu.

With ten carts of grain, you'll only have two left to feed your army once they reach the front line. Why? Because four carts worth will have been eaten on the way, and you'll need to save another four for the journey back. Each leg of a journey into Xiongnu territory might take several long months, and without enough food, your army will starve to death by the roadside. The figure I gave is actually on the high side. In Li Quan's commentary, he calculated that transporting an army's grain a distance of 1,000 li would require the labor of twenty extra men just to feed one soldier. That means twenty more sets of rations!

Then there are the other costs: hosting and entertaining messengers and emissaries, repairing and maintaining chariots, armor, weapons and other equipment, acquiring materials to make glue and paint, etc.

And, logistically, the supplies get sent out before the troops. The money adds up very quickly indeed - for an army of 100,000, the daily operational costs would amount to 1,000 gold pieces. The second chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War moves on from the questions of calculating balances of power, odds of victory and risk factors discussed in the first chapter, and sets its sights on costs, budgeting and safeguarding resources.

The principles are exactly the same as in modern-day business operations. The great Han Wudi: Hero of a generation, undone by military spending

Extract from the original text:
¡§When you engage in actual fighting, if victory is long in coming, then men's weapons will grow dull and their ardor will be damped. If you lay siege to a town, you will exhaust your strength.

Again, if the campaign is protracted, the resources of the State will not be equal to the strain."

Analysis:
Let's look at some commentary by Jia Lin: ¡§Though you may defeat your enemy, there is no benefit to victory which is long in coming. What is important in war is total victory. If your men's weapons grow dull and their ardor dampened, and if your troops are wounded and your horses exhausted, then you will be subjugated."
The aim of fighting wars is to gain some kind of benefit, but if the fighting takes too long, you'll burn through too many resources and whatever gains you make won't balance your losses. In Sun Tzu's words, ¡§If the campaign is protracted, the resources of the State will not be equal to the strain." In short, long wars can really bring a country to its knees.

In the story of the Great Emperor Wu of Han (Han Wudi), there is a profound lesson to be learned. In modern-day China, Han Wudi (141-87 BCE) figures large in history textbooks, movies and TV shows. His image is one of imposing power.

Yet, in reality, he not only bankrupted the imperial government, he also impoverished the entire population of the country he ruled. Such was his appetite for war that even a country as enormous as China could be pushed to the brink of ruin under his governance. But, Han Wudi's example also reveals the greatness of Sun Tzu - he didn't try to leverage his status as a military expert to falsely convince the lords to whom he offered his services to fight more wars, even though doing so would have boosted his own career. He did the opposite, going to great lengths to convince the men he advised not to fight, because he was both truly wise and truly benevolent.

Sun Tzu was a man with a strong sense of responsibility, if ever there was one. Humans, by nature, love the idea of achieving great things. This is a weakness, one that is by no means reserved for Emperors and rulers.

Ordinary people are broken down into cannon fodder by the thousands, and even as people's kin are killed and their families torn apart, still they hero-worship the rulers who are so infatuated with their own greatness. In China, the reign of Han Wudi is described using the euphemistic phrase, 'A time of flourishing,' whereas the reign of his father, Emperor Wenjing, was written up in the history books as 'An age of peace.' All periods of history that we might call 'the good times' are described as one or the other: 'time of flourishing,' or 'age of peace.' However, people only really get excited about the 'times of flourishing,' apparently unaware that the only time people could enjoy life in what could accurately be called a 'paradise on earth' was during times of peace. Meanwhile, if you live through a 'time of flourishing,' you are likely to lose friends and family members, or maybe even be fed to the cannons yourself, to become part of the songs of nostalgic poets in some later era.

What exactly is an 'age of peace?' Basically, they were periods of recovery and regeneration. Also, taxes were very low, often in the realm of 3%. There were no tariffs on trade, or tolls for highways and bridges.

People were free to invest in private business, and almost all businesses were on top of their debts. Business freedom extended to traditional monopoly industries: manufacturing salt by boiling seawater, mining, smelting iron, and even manufacturing copper money.

The overall situation was the same as in modern, economically liberal countries, including the freedom for private banks to issue currency. It was this kind of golden age that Emperor Wenjing ruled over, as well as Emperor Taizong of Tang during his Zhenguan reign period. In simple terms, these were times of freedom, when society governed itself, when government was small and didn't interfere in the people's economic and cultural life.

You could do anything, as long as it wasn't illegal. In any case, very few things were illegal; there were perhaps just a few more laws than the three that Liu Bang famously made into his entire legal framework.

These were times of regeneration, when people's energy and dynamism were released in unprecedented ways, and society's wealth exploded. By the time Han Wudi inherited the throne from his father, Wenjing, at the end of the golden age, the state treasury and granaries were full to bursting. The historical annals tell how the string traditionally used to tie up stacks of money was worn and frayed, and that the government struggled to find enough things to spend money on. ¡§Make it clear to any who would commit crime against the great Han court, that no matter how far they flee, they will always be caught, and executed." This pronouncement, first spoken by a Han dynasty general, is being used in our current era by passionate, nationalistic young people.

It inspires passion and fervor. But what these modern young people don't know is that there is another story lurking behind this warning. It's a tale of how a country's government and people fell into an abyss of bankruptcy.

Han Wudi sent his armies out to fight year after year, constantly expanding the empire's borders into new lands. Before long, the treasury was nearly empty, so he started up what was effectively a state-owned enterprise, based on the so-called 'salt and iron theory.' What was the rationale?

Salt was a daily necessity for every family in the empire, so production should be reserved exclusively for the central government. No private salt businesses were allowed. Likewise, every rural family needed metal tools - scythes, hoes and the like.

So, the same principle would be applied to the business of mining and smelting iron. As such, the Chinese people's livelihood was now monopolized by the state, marking the rise of the 'secondary-industry taxation system,' which was first devised hundreds of years prior by a politician named Guanzi in the Warring States period state of Qi. To this very day in China, food-grade salt is still monopolized by the government.

Even with the extra revenue from the monopolies, Han Wudi soon found himself without enough money for his projects. He began to increase tax rates at random, and once the tax increases became truly unsustainable, he began taxing people's accumulated wealth, demanding that everyone of middle-class background or higher must declare their wealth and assets to the government. Of course, no one wanted to do this, so a lot of people either didn't file a declaration or under-reported.

Han Wudi responded by ordering people to report their tax-dodging neighbors and friends to the government, and he threw in a big incentive: the informer would get half of their victim's wealth! Pandora's box was now well and truly open.

People falsely reported one another, officials ran extortion rackets, and innocent people were accused of giving false reports. Ultimately, the moneyed classes of China were bankrupted. By the end of Han Wudi's reign, the country couldn't take much more. Under unprecedented political pressure, the Emperor wrote a self-criticism addressed to the entire nation:
¡§Since the time when I ascended the throne, I have engaged in many wanton acts, and have caused distress to all under heaven.

It is now too late for regret. Starting from today, there will be a halt to all activities being detrimental to the common folk and squandering the resources of all under heaven."
This was the first written record in China's history of a monarch blaming himself for anything. 'Haste is stupid' - prepare slowly, act quickly 

Extract from the original text:
¡§Now, when your weapons are dulled, your ardor damped, your strength exhausted and your treasure spent, other chieftains will spring up to take advantage of your extremity.

Then no man, however wise, will be able to avert the consequences that must ensue. Thus, though we have heard of stupid haste in war, cleverness has never been seen associated with long delays."

Analysis:
When war is dragged out too long, there are bound to be problems both in the rear and with your alliances. When your troops are tired and morale is low, when the bank is nearly empty, that is the time when your underlings - the feudal lords - will take advantage of your crisis and attack.

When that time comes, no amount of wisdom or craftiness will save you; your hands will be tied. That's why you only hear about solid, well-prepared armies winning wars quickly, and also why you never see effective stratagems resulting in drawn-out conflicts. We have a classic historical lesson to chew on, courtesy of Emperor Yang of the Sui dynasty, a man who had a very similar temperament to Han Wudi.

He was highly competent, extremely intelligent, and equally in his element governing the state and leading war campaigns. As if fulfilling the Chinese idiom, 'The abler one is, the more one should do,' he decreed his reign title would be 'Great Undertaking.' He had big plans. It was Emperor Yang who dug the Grand Canal - at 1,776 km, the longest artificial river in the world - benefitting countless generations. If the only thing he did was to create the Grand Canal, eternal glory and a glittering place in the history books would have been his.

But human life is hard and short, and he was intent on using all his strength to achieve as many great deeds as possible. So, he moved the capital to Luoyang, building it into a new 'Eastern Capital,' personally led an invasion of the nomadic Tuyuhun people's territories, and invaded the Korean state of Goguryeo not once, but three times. All of this left the treasury empty and the people of China impoverished, and heralded a time of universal misery.

He also ordered the building of ships, which he wanted completed so quickly that the shipbuilders apparently developed festering sores on their feet because they spent so much time standing in water. Soon, rebellious champions of the people rose up, like Yang Xiangan and Li Mi, and China fell once again into chaos.

It wasn't long before Emperor Yang lost his head. This chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War was originally written for King Helu of the state of Wu, and yet, ironically, Helu became an anti-example during the 'Mulberry Leaf War' between Wu and its old enemy, the state of Chu. I named the war myself - it started near the border between Chu and Wu, with two girls who both wanted to pick the leaves from a certain mulberry tree.

They started arguing, and maybe even hit each other. Then, the parents got involved. Apparently, everyone was a little short-tempered, and began fighting each other. People were killed, and the border defense forces of both states mobilized.

In the end, the situation spiraled into a full-blown war. By the end of the war, the Wu army occupied the Chu capital, the city of Ying, and King Zhao of Chu fled into exile. This was the first time in the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE) that the capital city of a feudal vassal state had been occupied by external forces.

How exciting for the victorious King Helu! He stayed in Ying for a long time, terrorizing the people and enriching himself. As time passed, the King of Yue realized that the Wu army was still in Chu, and had left Wu unguarded. The Yue King seized his chance and launched an attack on Wu. At the same time, the self-exiled King Zhao of Chu returned from Qin at the head of an army. King Helu weakened himself fighting the Qin army, and his younger brother, Fugai, decided that the time was now right for him to make his own move. He secretly returned home to Wu and installed himself as the new king. Helu rushed home to Wu to deal with his brother's rebellion, which he eventually succeeded in, for better or for worse. The defeated Fugai led his men to Chu, where he surrendered and turned himself over to King Zhao. Helu, despite having already won a victory of an unprecedented scale when he first invaded Chu, did not know how to quit while he was ahead.

Instead, he ended up seriously weakened, and nearly destroyed, all for no benefit to himself. If there was nothing in it for him, then why did he want to fight a war in the first place? The reason is simply that people always seem to forget why they're doing things once they're in the middle of doing them.

¡§Though we have heard of stupid haste in war, cleverness has never been seen associated with long delays." Clever things are fleeting; they never last long. It's like fashion: fashionable clothes can only be worn for a season, and the most exquisite pieces of high fashion can only be worn once, and yet a normal shirt can be worn for years.

Zeng Guofan had his own understanding of 'stupid haste.' He saw it as 'Hurrying when there is no rush.' In terms of both strategy and the paths we walk through life, if you do things properly, practice steady accumulation, and move forward little by little, day by day, after 20 years you will be in all likelihood ahead of the pack. The real work gets done in daily life; it's about fundamentals.

When it comes to fighting wars, avoiding 'stupid haste' is about preparing slowly and acting quickly. This is the essence of Communist Party General Lin Biao's famous strategy of 'Four swifts, one slow.'
 The 'four swifts' are:
1) Swiftly advance on the enemy. When attacking, you must be skilled at doing what the enemy does not expect; launch long-range attacks over great distances, and you will hold the enemy firmly in your grip.

2) Swiftly carry out preparations before attacking. Once the enemy is within your grip, evaluate the terrain and select a point of attack where you can break through the enemy line. Position your troops and guns, and carry out construction and engineering works.

Readying troops for battle, and all other preparations and arrangements, must be swiftly carried out. 3) Swiftly expand on any gains you make. After breaking through the enemy line, resolutely expand the 'breakthrough point.' This will render enemy forces unable to restore their defenses. 4) Swiftly pursue and strike when the enemy retreats. After enemy forces collapse and retreat, you must be ferocious; pursue them until your task is complete.

This will render the enemy unable to escape, regroup, or continue to resist you. Lin Biao's 'one slow' is the idea of carrying out your general offensive slowly. It's about first gaining a clear picture of the enemy's position and the terrain, selecting a point of attack, and effectively positioning your troops and guns.

Prepare thoroughly, and only then launch your offensive. Lin Biao's formula, 'The four swifts and the one slow,' is the best possible commentary and clarification of Sun Tzu's idea that 'haste is stupid.'

The benefit-danger connection: First consider how to avoid danger, then consider how to obtain benefit

Extract from the original text:
¡§There is no instance of a country having benefited from prolonged warfare. It is only one who is thoroughly acquainted with the dangers of war that can thoroughly understand the beneficial way of carrying it on."

Analysis:
Gu Lin offers this comment: ¡§Prolonged war accomplishes nothing, except to give ideas to local power-holders."
Du You comments: ¡§When war is prolonged and sharp weapons remain drawn, things change.

Consider, for example, when Zhi Bo surrounded Zhao. For years he did not relent, and in the end his soldiers were captured by Xiangzi; Wei Po was killed, and his country divided."
Zhi Bo was a member of the Zhi clan, one of the four great families of the state of Jin during the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE). He also held an official post in the Jin government.

The other three families were the Han, Zhao and Wei families, but the Zhi family was the strongest. Zhi Bo approached the Han and Wei families and demanded land from them. Both families responded strategically, happily handed over their land and acting submissively so as to make the enemy overly confident. They knew that if they refused to give Zhi Bo their land, they'd be dragged into a fight that they couldn't win. They also knew that if they gave him their land, he would keep making demands of other people, and the number of his enemies would increase. Zhi Bo was pleased that he'd gotten what he wanted, and he soon demanded more land from Zhao Xiangzi. But he didn't want just any land - he was asking the Zhao family to hand over its best parcel, and more to the point, this piece of land included the Zhao family ancestral temple.

There was no way the Zhao family would give it up. It was at this moment that war broke out. Zhi Bo coerced the Han and Wei families to fight on his side, promising that once the Zhao family had been wiped out, he would give them part of the newly conquered land. The war lasted for three years, after which the Zhao family could no longer support its war effort. They sent messengers to the Han and Wei families, with this proposition: ¡§We all know what kind of man Zhi Bo is; there is no chance he will give you any land. He will attack each of us until we are all ruined.

The best thing for us to do would be to join hands and destroy the Zhi family. Then, we can split their land between us."
This was the moment the Han and Wei families had been waiting for. They sent a messenger to tell the Zhao family that they'd been on the same page all along, and were prepared to fall into step. Not long after, though, they turned their troops around and attacked Zhi Bo, taking him by surprise and killing him in the fight.

After the war, the three victorious families not only shared the Zhi family's land between them, they also deposed the Duke of Jin. They split the state of Jin into three new states - Han, Zhao and Wei - which became three out of the seven states that remained contenders at the start of the Warring States period. Zhi Bo was very talented, both as a military commander and a man of learning.

When you also consider that he was an official in the Jin government, his political and economic strength was far superior to that of the three other great families. If only he had waited for the right moment before attacking Zhao. If he'd prepared properly and launched a swift, well-coordinated attack, he may well have succeeded. He might have vanquished the three other families, and the state of Jin might have become the state of Zhi rather than the states of Han, Wei and Zhao.

But, long wars only bring trouble, and so, instead, Zhi Bo met with an ignoble end. His skull was painted and turned into a wine cup by Zhao Xiangzi, who apparently hated Zhi Bo so deeply that the only way he could process his hate was by drinking wine from Zhi Bo's skull on a daily basis. ¡§It is only one who is thoroughly acquainted with the dangers of war that can thoroughly understand the beneficial way of carrying it on."

Li Quan comments: ¡§Benefit and danger are entwined within each other.

When you know the dangers of doing something, then you also know the benefits."
So, anyone who doesn't fully understand the dangerous side of war also cannot understand its beneficial side. In the words of billionaire Hong Kong businessman Li Ka-shing, ¡§Before you do anything, first think about failing."
Running a business is the same as fighting a war; they are both games of fine margins, with dangers pressing in on all sides. Actually, the chances of success in business are generally about ten times lower than in war, because in war there are only two sides - if one side loses, the other side wins.

Meanwhile, in business, you don't know who you're fighting against and anything could happen. There's no use acting innocent and asking, 'How could this happen?' People shouldn't think that when they're successful it's all because of their own greatness, and when they fail it's because of 'shifting circumstances.' Circumstances are under no obligation to wait for you; you have to prioritize avoiding danger, and only then can you obtain benefits. This way, even if you can't obtain the benefit you want today, you'll still be able to try again tomorrow.

But, if you don't avoid danger, you lose your capital and end up forced out of the contest. This is why avoiding danger is so much more important than obtaining benefits. So why, then, are we a hundred times more conscious of obtaining benefits than we are of avoiding danger? Mainly, it's because we tend to trust in our own luck enough that we're willing to gamble.

People often repeat the idea that, at worst, you can always try again. But not everyone is destined to be a successful entrepreneur. Once you're out of the game you might not have the chance to get back into it, because the other players will never give their cards away for nothing.

If you have no cards in your hand, how will you get back in the game? Lower your war expenses, increase your odds of victory

Extract from the original text:
¡§Those skilled in war do not raise a second levy, neither are their supply-wagons loaded three times. Bring war material with you from home, but procure your food from the enemy.

Thus, the army will have provisions enough for its needs. A state, and its common people, can be impoverished by a commander who transports supplies over great distances. On the other hand, the proximity of an army causes prices to go up, and high prices cause the people's substance to be drained away. When their substance is drained away, the peasantry will be afflicted by heavy exactions."

Analysis:
'Not raising a second levy' means that a commander should raise enough troops to solve whatever problem his war is supposed to solve, without running out of soldiers halfway through and having to return home to enlist more men. But, the more difficult part is 'not loading the supply-wagons three times,' or, in other words, loading them only twice.

This means taking one load of rations with you on the way to battle, and having a second load sent to you for your army to eat on the road back home. And what about the time in between? What should the army eat when they're not on the march?

This is the part where you 'procure your food from the enemy.' If you can defeat the enemy and seize their cities, you can take their stored supplies and avoid having to transport food from your own country. At the start of the wars between Liu Bang and Xiang Yu, Liu Bang had already gotten hold of the state granaries left behind by the defunct Qin dynasty. While Xiang Yu's men groaned with hunger, Liu Bang's troops never once had to worry about having food to eat and clothes to keep them warm. When you set out to do something, do it right the first time; the most efficient way to do a job is to not do it twice.

This is a principle that seems to apply to everything people do, not just war. ¡§A state, and its common people, can be impoverished by a commander who transports supplies over great distances."

Du Mu comments that food is heavy; to transport food, you need people as well as oxen to pull the carts. If the farmers' plow-oxen are all taken away from the farms, the farmers won't be able to plow their fields, and the common people will be forced into poverty. The Warring States period politician, Guanzi, said: ¡§When grain is transported a distance of three hundred li, the country will be deprived of a year's worth of grain stores.

If the distance is four hundred li, the country will be deprived of two years' worth of grain stores. If the distance is four hundred li, then the people will suffer famine." So, each time Zhuge Liang set out on one of his expeditions to the north, he would first have to save up three years' worth of grain. His enemy, the state of Wei, was well aware of his food situation, so they were able to predict the timing of his next invasion.

Each time he attacked, they stayed safely behind the high walls of their fortresses and waited until he ran out of food and was forced to head back home. Whatever clever stratagems Zhuge Liang had in store, his enemies had already used methods of calculation to figure him out.

During Zhuge Liang's final attempt, at the Wuzhang Plain, he sent women's clothing to humiliate Sima Yi, but Sima Yi refused to be drawn into a fight, and ultimately Zhuge Liang tired himself to death. ¡§The proximity of an army causes prices to go up; and high prices cause the people's substance to be drained away."

When an army sets up camp, the sudden influx of large numbers of soldiers can cause prices to soar in the surrounding area, especially in the case of a siege.

During the time of the Qing dynasty Taiping Heavenly Kingdom rebellion, the Qing imperial army set up two large camps around the rebellious city of Nanjing - one camp north of the Yangtze River, the other one south of the river - in a siege that lasted for several long years.

There was a great boom in business for the nearby teahouses, taverns and brothels, and in general, prices skyrocketed. This hit the local people hard because, although the prices had increased, the amount of money in their pockets had not. ¡§When their substance is drained away, the peasantry will be afflicted by heavy exactions."

'Exactions' refers to the military conscription system invented by Duke Cheng of Lu during the Spring and Autumn period, known as the qiuyi system. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§If the country's needs are urgent, then procure from each qiu the contribution ordinarily made by each dian." What this means is that taxes would effectively be quadrupled!

Let's break down the numbers:
 From the most ancient times, military conscription in Chinese states had been based on calculations of land area and numbers of people living there. The Methods of the Sima contains details about the units used to measure land and the numbers of people living on that land: ¡§Six chi equal one bu; a hundred bu equal one mu; a hundred mu equal one fu; three fu equal one wu; three wu equal one jing; four jing equal one yi; four yi equal one qiu; four qiu equal one dian."
The basic unit of land used for calculating military conscription was the dian. Every dian had to contribute a war chariot as well as four war horses, three armored soldiers, 72 ordinary foot soldiers and 16 oxen.

Thanks to this system, we can calculate a country's overall strength by the size of its army. For example, I already mentioned the concept of 'a country of a thousand mounts,' which means that the country in question has 1,000 war chariots and 75,000 soldiers. Using the qiujia system, we can calculate that this country's territory spans 1,000 dian, meaning that it has roughly 1,000 towns. So, what did Duke Cheng of Lu do to change the old system?

As soon as he came to power, he introduced his new qiuyi system. The numbers stayed the same: one war chariot, four war horses, three armored soldiers, 72 ordinary foot soldiers and 16 oxen. But previously, there had been one important difference: the required contribution by each dian, but now each qiu had to make the same contribution.

There are four qiu in a dian, so this move meant that the requirement had quadrupled. This is why Duke Cheng has been roundly accused of recklessness, and even of being hell-bent on ruining his country. Expense accounting is a topic that The Art of War repeatedly comes back to, because Sun Tzu wanted to emphasize just how expensive all the working parts of war are - men, horses, oxen and grain all carry a high price tag. When war's operating costs are so high, it can easily become unaffordable.

But, what if we think about it from the opposite perspective? If there was a way of drastically shrinking just one of the main costs, wouldn't that make you unstoppable? One constant in war, as in business, is that the side with lower costs always beats the side with higher costs. One person who realized this revolutionary idea was Napoleon Bonaparte, and he used it to usher in a new era in military history - the age of the 'People's War.' The main cost-saver of the People's War was in reducing the price of a human life. Because of this, Napoleon didn't have to worry about suffering casualties, nor about the commandment to not 'raise a second levy.' Not only could he raise an unlimited number of regular soldiers, he also had other resources to throw into the fray: units of child soldiers and women.

Napoleon once proudly stated: ¡§Now human life is even cheaper than dust!" He also boasted that he could afford to sacrifice 30,000 people per month. Meanwhile, the monarchs of other European countries still relied on the aristocracy to lead their armies and paid professional soldiers.

The price gap between them and Napoleon's People's Army was enormous. Another advantage of People's War is that it reduces the cost of resources, by pouring a country's entire resources into the war effort. One leader took the ideas of both Sun Tzu and Napoleon to their pinnacle.

That leader was Mao Zedong. If you've never run a household, you can't understand the value of the daily necessities7; If you don't know the value of daily necessities, you can't run a household

Extract from the original text:
¡§With this loss of substance and exhaustion of strength, the homes of the people will be stripped bare, and seven-tenths of their income will be dissipated; while government expenses for broken chariots, worn-out horses, breastplates and helmets, bows and arrows, spears and shields, protective mantles, draught-oxen and heavy wagons will amount to six-tenths of its total revenue.

Hence, a wise general makes a point of obtaining food from the enemy. One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own, and likewise a single picul of his fodder is equivalent to twenty from one's own store."

Analysis:
A war that drags incessantly on saps both strength and finances. Long wars bankrupt everyone, from the government to the common people.

The people who live on the plains have to give food for the soldiers and transport it themselves, so both their wealth and their labor is conscripted for the war effort, leaving their houses stripped of seven-tenths of what they own.

Just the weapons and goods mentioned in the passage above cost six-tenths of the government's revenue, and this is before food has been accounted for. That's why a wise general will always think of a way to eat from the enemy's plate - ¡§One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own."
The words 'zhong' and 'picul' are both ancient Chinese units of measurement. One picul equals ten dou, and since Zhang Yu explains in his commentary that one picul is also equal to 120 jin (a commonly used unit in China today, about 0.5 kilograms), we can see that one dou equals 12 jin. One zhong, according to Du Mu, is equal to six piculs and four dou, or 778 jin. Let's calculate the basis of Sun Tzu's statement: ¡§One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own." Basically, you have to use 20 zhong of food in the process of having people transport one zhong of food to the front line. You need oxen and wagons to transport food over long distances, but oxen walk much more slowly than humans.

You also need human labor in the form of workers, and an armed escort to protect the wagons. If you send out a grain convoy with 21,000 zhong of grain, 13,000 zhong gets eaten on the road by the transport team. Once the convoy reaches the front line, only 1,000 zhong is handed over to the army, with the remaining 7,000 being the minimum amount needed to feed the transport team on their way back without them starving to death.

And there's your answer! Everyone has to eat - and not just people, but horses and oxen too. The animals that pull the grain wagons also have to pull enough fodder for themselves to eat on both legs of their journey. Here, 'fodder' includes soybean stalks, which are famously featured in the Seven Steps Verse, a poem written by Cao Cao's son, Cao Zhi: ¡§People burn the beanstalk to boil beans." 'Fodder' also includes straw from cereal crops. The same principle of 'One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own' also applies to animal fodder.

When the Qin dynasty generals invaded the Xiongnu territories and ordered people all over China to send food, the efficiency of food transport was much worse. A wagon setting out from Shandong with 30 zhong of food would only be carrying one picul by the time it reached the front lines, equivalent to just one two-hundredths of its original load! Clearly, relying on human laborers and beasts of burden to transport food takes a long time, and it's very inefficient. There was similarly low efficiency in grain delivery when Han Wudi launched his conquest of the southwestern Yi people. He conscripted tens of thousands of people to run the transport convoys, and each picul of food delivered came at a cost of over a dozen zhong, an efficiency rate hovering near 1%. So, Sun Tzu's figure of 'one in twenty' was favourable in comparison.

The reason Sun Tzu's figure was relatively low was because it was based on his experience in wars between Chinese states during the Spring and Autumn period, which took place over relatively flat land in areas that were already developed. However, later expeditions against the Xiongnu and the Southwest Yi had to cross large mountain ranges and tracts of barren land, so naturally the cost of transport was higher.

When Japan invaded China in the 20th century, they first captured China's northeast, closely followed by Zhejiang Province (the area around Shanghai.) This gave the Japanese supply bases in China. If the Japanese army had been forced to transport all of their food from Japan, they wouldn't have been able to support their invasion.

This is why China's determination not to surrender, as well as its success in stalling the Japanese, qualifies China to be recognized as one of the four major victors of World War II. Genghis Khan conquered the world, and part of his success was that he was unmatched in his ability to drive down food costs.

His people were nomads, herding sheep and cows across the grasslands. Every day, their animals gave them fresh milk, as well as meat, and the fact that sheep and cows can give birth while on the move gave Genghis Khan's armies independence. They could set out on campaigns, accompanied by livestock, without having to rely on supplies sent from home.

Once they reached the front lines, they could take more food from their enemies each time they captured a city. These are the crucial elements behind Genghis Khan's ability to reach across such vast distances. He put into practice Sun Tzu's commandment: ¡§Those skilled in war do not raise a second levy, neither are their supply-wagons loaded three times."

Fury and bounty: Turn your soldiers into willing desperados

Extract from the original text:
¡§Now in order to kill the enemy, our men must be roused to anger; that there may be advantage from defeating the enemy, they must have their rewards."

Analysis:
When you send an army to war, you have to give the soldiers a reason to kill the enemy. You have to turn each and every one of them into a wrathful killer, a willing desperado.

This is about using people's emotions. There are two kinds of emotion that can make people forget about mortal danger: (1) Anger. When anger fills a person, they don't care about anything; and (2) Greed.

People are willing to die for money. Let's start with anger. Du Mu comments: ¡§Ten thousand men cannot feel fury as if with one heart, unless I use circumstances to anger them."
A classic historical example of this is when the state of Yan attacked the state of Qi, besieging the Qi city of Jimo, which was under the command of Qi general Tian Dan. During the siege, the Yan army had captured some Qi prisoners, and it was decided that all of the captives' noses should be cut off.

This infuriated the people of Qi, and only stiffened their resolve to defend their city. Tian Dan saw an opportunity. He wanted to fan the flames of his people's rage, and turn their grief into a power strong enough to crush the Yan army. Tian Dan sent an agent into the Yan camp, where he spread a rumor that what the people of Qi dreaded above anything else was that the Yan soldiers might dig up their ancestral graves, which were outside of the city walls. According to the rumor, the people of Qi would feel so humiliated by the desecration of their ancestors that they would completely collapse.

If this happened, they'd be sure to surrender and beg the Yan army to relent. The Yan army fell for it. They not only dug up the Qi ancestral graves, but even burned the bodies. The people of Qi saw everything from where they stood on the ramparts.

Now, the flames of fury were truly blazing in their eyes and Tian Dan could see that his men were ready to be used. He led his men out of the city to fight, and the men of Qi went berserk with killing.

The Yan army was crushed. Now, let's look at 'bounty.'
Cao Cao comments: ¡§If there's no money to be made in the army, don't expect new recruits; if an army gives no rewards, don't expect your men to go where you command."
Du Mu comments: ¡§Wealth and goods can be used to lure soldiers, to make them willing to defeat the enemy. The wealth and goods obtained by defeating the enemy must be distributed as rewards; ensure that everyone desires these things, and each one of your men will fight.

When men know that defeating the enemy will bring them rich reward, this is all the enticement needed to make them joyfully advance through an onslaught of arrows, stones and bared blades."
It's quite common in military discussions to talk about this or that army having 'good discipline' or 'bad discipline.' The truth is that the only factor that decides whether an army's discipline is good or bad is the commander's strategic objective. If an army has good discipline, and refrains from bullying local civilians, it's because the commander has a political objective.

If an army has poor discipline and marauds through civilian settlements, burning, raping and pillaging, it's because this is being intentionally used as an incentive mechanism. In many prolonged sieges, when the people of the city stubbornly refuse to surrender, it became no longer necessary for the besieging army to treat the enemy civilian population well. In these cases, the besieging army's commander would often incentivize his men to stick out a long siege by telling them that after the city fell, they'd be allowed to ransack and pillage the place for three days, or even seven days, and that they could keep for themselves anything that they took from the city, including girls and women. This kind of incentive was enough to drive soldiers into a frenzy.

When Zeng Guofan's Hunan army took the city of Nanjing from the Taiping rebels, his army didn't exercise a shred of discipline. They burned, murdered, robbed and raped, and once they'd plundered every last item of value, they destroyed the evidence by burning down the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom's palace. Later, the Hunan army commanders reported to the Qing Empress Dowager that Nanjing 'contained nothing of any value.'
¡§As it turns out," they claimed, ¡§that Taiping fellow8 really was a model of purity and thrift!"
But Zeng Guofan was one of the great Confucianists of his age - how could an army under his command have behaved like this? Clearly, he had made a promise to his men.

He would have told them something like, ¡§The imperial court hasn't any money to give us, and yet we Hunanese have willingly come to fight for the court. Well, when we win, we know that the cities and the land that we conquer will go to the Empress Dowager.

Since that is the case, my brothers, the money and other valuables will be ours." This was basically an unwritten rule. And what did the Empress Dowager Cixi make of this? As far as she was concerned, if they said there was no money in Nanjing, there was no money in Nanjing. She never asked any questions about the missing money and valuables, but instead chose to look the other way, even though she knew very well that the riches of Nanjing had been taken back to Hunan. Sometimes, the Emperor himself will publicly announce as a policy that his men are expected to act in this way.

For example, when Emperor Taizu of the Song dynasty was about to attack Shu (modern-day Sichuan Province), he issued this order: ¡§All provinces and counties that my army conquers are to be my property, while all granaries, warehouses, and the goods stored within are to be divided in their entirety among the soldiers as their reward." Apparently, all that the state desires is land, land and more land. Famous generals of all eras have one thing in common: a willingness to share money among all their men.

The classic way of doing this was to give any and all valuables or money seized from the enemy or from civilians directly to the soldiers. The commander would not keep a single penny for himself, and instead would only accept rewards given by the Emperor.

Because the general didn't take a share of the bounty, any of his men who were unsatisfied with their own share had no grounds to complain or even mention the word 'unfair.' When generals do this, their men are willing to fight alongside them, so they win more battles and rise more quickly up through the ranks. Watch who is the first to climb the city walls

Extract from the original text:
¡§Therefore, in chariot fighting, when ten or more chariots have been taken, those should be rewarded who took the first.

Our own flags should be substituted for those of the enemy, and the chariots mingled and used in conjunction with ours. The captured soldiers should be kindly treated and kept. This is called using the conquered foe to augment one's own strength.

In war, then, let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns. Thus, it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter of the people's fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril."

Analysis:
¡§In chariot fighting, when ten or more chariots have been taken, those should be rewarded who took the first." But why? You have to think about the numbers of people involved when you capture ten chariots.

We know that each chariot comes with a unit of 75 men. Chariots were deployed in units of five, known as a dui, and also in units of ten, known as a guan. Each dui would be led by five officers (pushe) and each guan also came with ten additional officers (zuzhang). So, ten chariots come with a total of 770 men.

To capture this many men, you'd need at least 1,000 of your own men to do the job. Yet, if you tried to give rewards to every one of these thousand men, the incentive mechanism would break, and anyway the state treasury couldn't even afford such generosity. That's one of the reasons why only the first man to capture a chariot is to be rewarded. It's also because he is usually the one at the head of the charge; when his comrades see him running ahead, they charge after him, becoming a single mass of charging soldiers.

It's the same in a siege. The first man to set foot on the enemy's walls has to be richly rewarded, because this is the only way to ensure all of your men will be able to summon the courage to throw themselves ahead of the pack and into the thick of the fighting. For the commander standing at the back and directing the battle from afar, it's just as important to clearly see who the first man on the walls is as it is to command the course of the battle, because if you can't quite make out which man needs to be rewarded, when the next battle comes none of your men will have much interest in being at the front of the line. When that happens, you can hand out whatever commands you like, but nothing will work.

Fighting battles is in itself all about two armies trying to snatch each other's weapons and other resources - basically, trying to profit from the enemy. In the Chinese TV drama, Drawing Sword, the character Li Yunlong has a quirky habit: every time he wins a battle, he joyfully announces: ¡§I'm rich!" That explains it pretty well. On the ancient Chinese battlefield, it went without saying that your charioteers would try to pilfer the enemy's chariots, your cavalry would try to pilfer the enemy's cavalry, and your infantry would try to pilfer the enemy's infantry. When General Wu Qi did battle against a Qin army, he told his three armies: ¡§Though we may destroy the enemy, any victory we might gain would be meritless unless our chariots take from their chariots, our cavalry take from their cavalry, and our infantry take from their infantry!" This is one of the criteria for success in war; it's not enough just to kill the enemy and win the day. Your charioteers absolutely must come back in possession of the enemy's chariots, your cavalry need to wrangle the enemy's horses and equipment, and it's imperative that your infantrymen take the enemy's weapons.

Only if your men successfully do this should you tell them they've done a good job, and hand out rewards. When you capture an enemy chariot, you should immediately take down the battle flag from its banner pole and put your own flag up there. Then, squeeze the chariot into one of your own chariot units and send it out to fight for you.

What about when you take enemy soldiers prisoner? Sun Tzu said, ¡§Captured soldiers should be kindly treated and kept." Explain clearly to them what your policies are, and try to win them over so they'll join your army and be of service to you. Sun Tzu's thinking on this point was remarkable for the times he lived in.

In ancient Chinese wars, killing enemy soldiers who'd surrendered was a widespread practice. This was because when you suddenly find yourself in charge of several hundred thousand prisoners of war, it's very difficult to control so many men, let alone feed and water them.

You don't dare trust them, so generals often solved the problem by digging a huge pit and filling it with bodies. A classic example of this is Lord Changping of Qin, who buried alive 400,000 soldiers from the state of Zhao, en masse. Xiang Yu took it even further, leaving mass graves behind him everywhere he went. He is known to have buried alive 200,000 Qin soldiers at once, cementing the hatred showered upon him by the people of Qin. The most classic example of the opposite approach - treating captive soldiers well and putting them to use - comes to us courtesy of Emperor Guangwu of the Han dynasty (Han Guangwu). When Han Guangwu defeated the rebel Tong Mazei at Nanyang, he captured over 100,000 men, all of whom he integrated into his own army.

But, the captured men still felt uneasy, because their original commander, Tong Mazei, had already surrendered once before, to rebel a second time, and he ultimately surrendered again. The rebel commanders were sure that Emperor Guangwu wouldn't dare trust them. Emperor Guangwu was well aware what the captured men were thinking, so he told them to return to their various camps and that he would come and visit them there. True to his word, he visited each of the rebel camps with an entourage of only a dozen or so cavalrymen.

This was his way of showing the rebels that he trusted them enough to put his own life at their mercy. The rebel commanders were moved to tears by Guangwu's gesture, and said: ¡§My king, you put your beating heart between the teeth of others. Your sincerity is astounding!" There is a Chinese idiom still in use today that comes from this story, meaning 'To trust somebody completely.' Guangwu instantly became much more powerful now that he had the rebel forces under his command.

This is what it means to grow stronger in victory. If you kill 1,000 of the enemy's men, but lose 800 of your own, that is not a victory - both sides lose. The only difference is that the enemy's loss is heavier. This is why Sun Tzu promotes the idea of 'having it all.' The first priority is keeping your own forces whole, and then winning a complete victory, ideally while keeping the enemy forces intact. Sun Tzu's entire system of military thinking is: not fighting; fighting cautiously; and fighting swiftly. ¡§War is not a plaything." 

Right at the outset of Sun Tzu' s The Art of War, he declares that war is a matter of survival for both state and people.

War is incomparably dangerous, and it must be carried out cautiously. First, make careful calculations in the temple - this is the 'The Five Factors and Seven Considerations.' If you don't have good odds of victory, check yourself. Don't start a war that you might not win.

If the odds are with you, go to war with the aim of settling it in a single battle. ¡§In war, then, let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns."

Cao Cao comments on this line: ¡§Long campaigns are not beneficial, for war is like fire; without restraint, one may easily set fire to oneself." Cao Cao literally proved his own point when his fleet was set ablaze by Liu Bei's unmanned 'fire ships' at the Battle of Red Cliffs. ¡§Thus it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter of the people's fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril."

In the original Chinese text, 'arbiter' is actually a constellation of stars, one that's supposed to be in charge of people's births, deaths and lifespans.

That's the power and responsibility a general has over the lives of the people. The star who watched over the people of Zhao during the first part of the Battle of Changping was General Lian Po, and because of him the people of Zhao stayed alive. But when Lian Po's star was lowered from the sky and replaced with Zhao Kuo, the result was death for 400,000 men and a country left hanging over the edge of the abyss.

Likewise, in the 20th century, it was the generals who must be blamed for the countless young lives cut short in the meat grinder that was the First World War. In our daily lives, we all face 'the road either to safety or to ruin.' For example, it's often said that from journalists' pens flow great riches, that they wield power over human lives and have the ability to make or destroy reputations, and even to determine right and wrong, and truth itself.

Whatever tool you hold in your hands, whether a gun, a pen or the steering wheel of a car, your next move affects the lives and financial wellbeing of other people. Sun Tzu knew this, and that's why he has taught us responsibility and reverent wariness. Sun Tzu said: ¡§In the operations of war, where there are in the field a thousand swift chariots, as many heavy chariots, and a hundred thousand sets of armor, with provisions enough to carry them a thousand li, the expenditure at home and at the front, including entertainment of guests, small items such as glue and paint, and sums spent on chariots and armor, will reach the total of a thousand gold pieces per day. Such is the cost of raising an army of 100,000 men.

When you engage in actual fighting, if victory is long in coming, then men's weapons will grow dull and their ardor will be dampened. If you lay siege to a town, you will exhaust your strength. Again, if the campaign is protracted, the resources of the State will not be equal to the strain. Now, when your weapons are dulled, your ardor damped, your strength exhausted and your treasure spent, other chieftains will spring up to take advantage of your extremity.

Then no man, however wise, will be able to avert the consequences that must ensue. Thus, though we have heard of stupid haste in war, cleverness has never been seen associated with long delays. ¡§There is no instance of a country having benefited from prolonged warfare.

It is only one who is thoroughly acquainted with the dangers of war that can thoroughly understand the beneficial way of carrying it on. Those skilled in war do not raise a second levy, and their supply-wagons are not loaded three times. Bring war material with you from home, but procure your food from the enemy.

Thus, the army will have provisions enough for its needs. A State, and its common people, can be impoverished by a commander who transports supplies over great distances. On the other hand, the proximity of an army causes prices to go up, and high prices cause the people's substance to be drained away. When their substance is drained away, the peasantry will be afflicted by heavy exactions.

With this loss of substance and exhaustion of strength, the homes of the people will be stripped bare, and seven-tenths of their income will be dissipated. Meanwhile, government expenses for broken chariots, worn-out horses, breast-plates and helmets, bows and arrows, spears and shields, protective mantles, draught-oxen and heavy wagons, will amount to six-tenths of its total revenue. Hence, a wise general makes a point of obtaining food from the enemy.

One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own, and likewise, a single picul of his fodder is equivalent to twenty from one's own store. ¡§Now, in order to kill the enemy, our men must be roused to anger; that there may be advantage from defeating the enemy, they must have their rewards.

Therefore, in chariot fighting, when ten or more chariots have been taken, those should be rewarded who took the first. Our own flags should be substituted for those of the enemy, and the chariots mingled and used in conjunction with ours.

The captured soldiers should be kindly treated and kept. This is called using the conquered foe to augment one's own strength. In war, then, let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns. Thus, it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter of the people's fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril."

Planning Assaults

The best way to plan an attack is not attacking; Win without attacking

Extract from the original text:
¡§In the practical art of war, the best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it is second best. So, too, it is better to recapture an army entirely than to destroy it; to capture a battalion, a company or a squad entirely than to destroy them. Hence, to fight and conquer in all your battles is not supreme excellence; supreme excellence consists in breaking the enemy's resistance without fighting."

Analysis:
The first chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War is about calculations, the second is about fighting pitched battles in the field, and the third takes us into the topic of attacking cities. There is an order to this, and a clue as to why this chapter follows the one about pitched battles comes in the form of a comment written by Li Quan: ¡§When two armies meet, this is known as 'battle.' When a city is surrounded, this is known as an 'assault.'" This brief comment shows why this chapter comes after the one about 'battles.'
Cao Cao simply comments: ¡§If you want to carry out an assault against your enemy, you must first plan."
What needs to be planned?

A comment by Wang Xi explains: ¡§Plan the benefits and dangers of assaulting the enemy, develop a comprehensive plan to defeat them, and do not be hasty to send out your troops or assault the city."
Once again, it comes back to the benefit-danger dynamic - avoiding danger and following benefit.

You don't fight wars just to kill your enemies, because when you kill your enemies, there is always a price to be paid; perhaps you kill 100,000 of your enemies, but lose 800 of your own in the process.

The best outcome is to defeat the enemy army without a battle. Make sure the enemy knows the balance of dangers and benefits. Make the enemy surrender, and the whole city, with all of its people, goods and money, will be yours to keep. This is the basic idea behind Sun Tzu's philosophy of 'having it all.'

¡§The best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it second best."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Mobilize your generals, drive your army deep into enemy territory, keep your distance from their city walls, cut off connections between their city and the hinterland, and cause the enemy to surrender his country to you; this is the best way. Destroying the city with your soldiers and gaining it only after defeating the enemy is not as good."
Surround the enemy, fill him with despair, and make sure he clearly sees the situation he is in, and then he will surrender.

This is the absolute best way to win, the pinnacle. But, if he does decide to make like a cornered animal and fight to the bitter end, you will have to assault his city and defeat him in battle. There will be a price to pay, and what you'll get at the end won't be an intact city, but one that lies in ruins.

Not to mention that anything can happen on the battlefield; there's no such thing as a guaranteed victory. Before Cao Cao's unfortunate run-in with the fire ships, he had successfully marched his armies south of the Yangzi River, where he accepted the surrender of General Liu Cong, and even got his hands on naval forces formerly under the command of Cai Mao and Zhang Yun. This is a good example of Sun Tzu's dictum: ¡§The best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole." But, Cao Cao's winning streak came to an end when Sun Quan, Emperor of Eastern Wu, refused to surrender. The Battle of Red Cliffs happened not long after, dealing Cao Cao a catastrophic defeat.

His forces never again set foot in Eastern Wu. During the wars between Liu Bang and Xiang Yu, Liu Bang once entrusted a mission to his advisor Li Yiji: to go to the state of Qi and convince its king, Tian Guang, to surrender. The mission was a success, and another example of Sun Tzu's dictum. Li Yiji stayed in the Qi capital as a voluntary hostage, and told the king that if Liu Bei's Han armies ever invaded Qi, the king could throw him in the soup pot and boil him alive. Every day, the king and Li Yiji drank and ate together, and eventually the king did as Li Yiji said, dissolving the Qi garrison. Unfortunately, one of Liu Bei's generals, Han Xin, felt a little bothered by Li Yiji's success, using his powers of persuasion to talk the mighty state of Qi into surrendering. Han Xin's thinking was probably something along the lines of: 'Why should a bookish weakling like Li Yiji get more credit than me?' So, Han Xin secretly plotted to make a move of his own - a sudden attack on the Qi army, which was stationed in Lixia. The state of Qi was caught with its defenses down, and Han Xin's army rolled over it like a wave.

The Qi king was sure that he had been betrayed by Li Yiji, and sure enough, threw the man in a soup pot and boiled him alive. As for the king, he got caught up in the fighting and was killed. One might wonder if Han Xin didn't grasp the concept that 'The best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole.' Of course he understood the concept. He had put it into practice himself against the kingdom of Yan.

He cowed the Yan king into submission with the fearsome reputation he had made for himself by capturing Xia Shuo and King Bao of Wei, and by executing the Lord of Cheng'an. All it took for Yan to surrender was one messenger and a single letter.

Just like Yan, Qi had surrendered. But the difference was that it wasn't he, Han Xin, who had made them surrender, but one of his colleagues. So, Han Xin decided to go for the next-best thing: 'A broken country.' He destroyed Qi and killed its soldiers and war horses, even though they were already Liu Bang's property. When he'd finished, he went straight back to Liu Bang and tried to twist his arm into granting him the title of 'King of Qi.' In reality, Han Xin was sowing the seeds of not just his own downfall, but the destruction of his entire family line. The Ming dynasty writer Wang Fuzhi said there was nothing unjust about Han Xin's death, because in his heart he was not truly loyal to Liu Bang. For Han Xin, his relationship with Liu Bang was about trying to extract as much as possible from his lord; it was about benefitting himself. Wang Fuzhi put it like this: ¡§He poisoned the whole world, and then succumbed to his own poison; he was nothing more than a man greedy for credit!

Sir Li persuaded Qi to surrender, and Qi was prepared to accept this counsel. With this achieved, there was no longer cause for worry in the Northeast, and Xiang Yu's right-hand line of support was severed. Consider Jing Bu - he was a criminal, and yet having once turned away from Xiang Yu and come to Liu Bei's side, it was out of the question that he would ever rebel against Liu Bei. How much more could the Qi king Tian Guang be trusted?

He is an upright man, and there is no doubt that he would not have been the cause of any concern for Liu Bei. Yet, Han Xin hankered after success, and so followed after the example of Kuai Che, frenziedly attacking Qi, though Qi had already relented. As a result, Sir Li was hurled into a boiling vessel, and the Qi army was slaughtered at Li Xia, so that rivulets of blood flowed o'er the open country. King Tian Guang and his entire family were exterminated.

The tragedy of it! The stirrings of greed originated in ethereal darkness, and ended with soldiers' shields floating away on currents of blood." 
Wang Fuzhi explained why there was nothing unjust about Han Xin's death, and pointed out that if anyone died unjustly, it was King Tiang Guang and Li Yiji. ¡§It is better to recapture an army entirely than to destroy it, to capture a battalion, a company or a squad entirely than to destroy them."
This line delves into the organizational divisions within an army.

Here, an 'army' refers to 12,500 men; a battalion is 500 men; a company is 100 men; and a squad, the smallest unit, is five men. The basic message is that no matter what scale or level you're working at, from a whole country down to a single squad, you should always strive to keep everything whole and intact, and remember that winning without fighting is the perfect way to do this.

This is why there's nothing particularly great about fighting and winning a hundred battles. In the words of the Warring States period polymath, Li Kui, when he was advising Marquess Wen of Wei: ¡§With many victories comes certain ruin." This is because in every battle fought, something is used up and depleted; there is always a price to be paid. After a hundred battles, the people are exhausted; after a hundred victories, the ruler becomes arrogant.

When the people are exhausted and the ruler is arrogant, the enemy is likely to find a long-repressed reserve of strength, and when the next battle comes, suddenly the tables will turn. And that's not to mention that if you're still fighting after a hundred victories, clearly the 'victories' you've been winning aren't exactly of the highest quality, because you still haven't solved your problem. This is why causing your enemy to submit without fighting him is 'supreme excellence.' It's possible to finish your business just by writing a letter; the pen has the power to bring peace to the realm. If that doesn't work out, the next best thing is to solve your problems in a single battle.

When you find yourself having won a hundred battles, that in itself is a problem. The supreme strategy is to attack and sabotage the enemy's plans

Extract from the original text:
¡§Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans; the next best is to attack the enemy's alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy's army in the field."

Analysis:
¡§The highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans." You don't have to use stratagems to fight a war. What Sun Tzu is telling us here is that you should disrupt the enemy's stratagems.

In war, both sides finalize their stratagems before making their first move, so if you can destroy your enemy's stratagem, they won't be going anywhere. The all-time classic historical example would be when Kou Xun attacked Gao Jun during the Eastern Han dynasty (23-221 CE).

Gao Jun sent an agent, Huang Puwen, to visit Kou Xun. Without the slightest hesitation, Kou Xun had the agent killed. Then, he sent a letter back to Gao Jun, saying: ¡§Your general was very rude, so I took his head.

If you're going to surrender, be quick about it. If not, you'd better dig in tight!" The same day that Gao Jun received the letter, he opened his gates and surrendered. The generals didn't understand, and asked Kou Xun: ¡§These are two states that have always settled things in battle, not by decapitating emissaries. Why did he fall over backward to surrender to you just because you executed his envoy? You weren't even at war at that point!"
Kou Xun explained: That 'envoy,' Huang Puwen, was Gao Jun's chief general, the man he relied on more than anyone. The reason Gao Jun sent him to me was to see what my strengths and weaknesses are, so that he could go back with the information and get down to planning.

If I'd spared him, he would have given Gao Jun a stratagem, but as it happened, I killed him, and Gao Jun lost his nerve."
Killing Huang Puwen ensured that Gao Jun was left with no ideas, and no guts, either. This is exactly what it means to say 'The highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans.'
