Kou Xun's story is an extreme case, in which he took the most direct route possible: killing the enemy's planner-in-chief.

Under normal circumstances, this kind of opportunity doesn't just present itself. Instead, you have to focus on analysis and clarity of judgment as a way to sabotage the enemy's plans. This chapter's second example is about the origins of a Chinese idiom that basically means, 'To win by diplomacy.' The literal translation is 'Block the enemy's charge with vessels of wine.' The wording of 'block the charge' comes from the name of a type of ancient Chinese war chariot, the zhechongqi, which was designed to sever an enemy charge in a similar way to snapping a knife blade. The basic idea is to pluck victory from negotiations at the banquet table, rather than resorting to violence.

The idiom is based on the story of Yan Ying, a famous statesman from Qi who lived during the Spring and Autumn period. Duke Ping of Jin had designs on attacking Qi, so he sent Fan Zhao as an envoy to gather information.

When Fan Zhao arrived, Duke Jing of Qi held a banquet to welcome him. The wine was half drunk, and Fan Zhao suddenly said to Duke Jing: ¡§Would it be permissible for me to request a drink of wine from your cup?" Duke Jing replied: ¡§I see no reason why not, since you are my guest! Come, a servant will pour my wine into your cup!"
Fan Zhao downed Duke Jing's wine in one gulp, and just as a servant was about to pour more wine for both of them, Yan Yin shouted: ¡§Wait a moment! Bring a new cup for our lord!"
Fan Zhao was none too pleased by this.

He got up and, pretending to be drunk, began dancing and shouted over to the Grand Preceptor, a high-ranking official: ¡§I want to have a dance! Can you play some music from Chengzhou?" The Grand Preceptor's reply was icy: ¡§Nobody present is capable of playing the music you speak of." This seemed to irk Fan Zhao, and he soon took his leave. As the banquet drew to a close, Duke Jing said to his advisers: ¡§What got in to you today?

That man is the envoy of a powerful state, who came here to observe our ways of governance, and you've all annoyed him. What good does that do us? Won't this just bring us more trouble?"
Yan Ying replied: ¡§He came to observe our ways of governance, and that's exactly what we showed him. You see, my lord, it's not that this Zhao Fan fellow doesn't understand proper etiquette; he was intentionally behaving in a belligerent manner. There is a clear difference of rank between rulers and ministers - demanding the wine from a duke's goblet is a provocation.

He was testing us. That's why I had your cup changed, my lord, so as not to throw the proper hierarchy into disorder by drinking from the same vessel as him."
The Grand Preceptor had his own piece to say: ¡§The music of Chengzhou is sacred music. It belongs to the Son of Heaven (the Zhou king), and it is not for ministers or anyone else to dance along to.

So, of course I couldn't play it for him."
Fan Zhao returned to Jin, and made his report to Duke Ping: ¡§Do not invade Qi. I tried to humiliate their duke, but Yan Ying saw through me. Then, I tried to dishonor their ceremonial rites, but this time the Grand Preceptor called me out. Qi is a state with capable, virtuous ministers!"
Confucius himself once praised the ministers of Qi, exclaiming: ¡§Without taking the matter beyond wine vessels, Yan Ying blocked his enemy's attack from a thousand li distant." 
This is a man who, amid raised glasses and courteous smiles, destroyed the Jin plan to assault Qi, and beat the enemy back 1,000 li. This is the epitome of 'attacking the enemy's plans.'
Our third example comes from the Qin invasion of Jin, also during the Spring and Autumn period.

The man in charge of the Jin army sent to stop the Qin was named Zhao Dun, but the Jin prime minister and overall military leader, Yu Pian, had his own idea: ¡§The Qin army has travelled a long way, so they won't be able to stay long. We should build our walls higher and dig our moats deeper.

All we need to do is wait around for the Qin soldiers to give up and go home."
The plan was put into action, and the Qin army was stuck. There was no fighting to be had, but they couldn't retreat with nothing to show for it.

Duke Mu of Qin asked his adviser Shi Hui what could be done. Shi Hui said: ¡§I'm absolutely positive that this is Yu Pian's idea. But there's another general in the Jin army, a young man named Zhao Chuan.

He's Zhao Dun's nephew, and also the son-in-law of the Jin duke. He has no understanding whatsoever of military affairs, he's been spoiled to the point of arrogance, and he has a romantic love of bravery that renders him reckless.

Importantly, he is not at all keen on Yu Pian being given the position of prime minister. If we can provoke Zhao Chuan's men, he's sure to come out and fight."
The Qin army did just that - they harassed Zhao Chuan. Sure enough, Zhao Chuan led his men out in pursuit of his tormenters, but he couldn't catch them.

Furious, he went back and fumed: ¡§What are we doing here? Here we are, wearing armor and with food provisions ready, precisely so that we can kill our enemies. And yet we're not fighting! Why?" One of his men told him that they were waiting for the right opportunity, but Zhao Chuan didn't listen. ¡§I don't care if they have some clever stratagem. If the others won't fight, I'll fight on my own!" he retorted, and promptly led his men out to fight. When Zhao Dun heard what his nephew had done, he was frustrated, but he didn't have a choice. He had to save Zhao Chuan, so he led out the entire Jin army and fought a terrible, daylong battle with the Qin army.

At the end, it was unclear who had won and who had lost. Each of the above three cases is different - Kou Xun killed his enemy's planner-in-chief, Yan Ying nipped his enemy's plan in the bud, and Shi Hui sabotaged his enemy's plan when it was already in motion. But, each of them is a classic example of 'attacking the enemy's plans.'

Don't act like a dunce just because your teammate is a dunce

Extract from the original text:
¡§Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans; the next best is to attack the enemy's alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy's army in the field."

Analysis:
In the previous chapter, we established that 'attacking the enemy's plans' is about attacking the enemy's thoughts and rooting out their ideas.

This forces them to realize: a) They're unprepared; b) Their odds are lousy; c) Attacking you would be very risky; and d) They should give up on their plan. In this chapter, we move on to look at 'attacking the enemy's alliances.' This is the practice of diplomacy (and counter-diplomacy) as a part of war. Historians of ancient China often talk about the 'Vertical and Horizontal Alliances of the Roaming Diplomats,' during the Warring States period.

There were two main ideas: that the various states lying on the east-west (horizontal) axis should form an alliance on the one hand, and on the other hand, that a north-south array of states should join together. The most famous diplomats behind them were, respectively, Zhang Yi and Su Qin. Su Qin's 'vertical alliance' idea aimed to unite six states to jointly resist Qin, which had become a formidable power. The 'horizontal alliance' idea came later, and Zhang Yi toured each of the six states in the vertical alliance, lobbying their rulers to ally with Qin. He pushed the line that cosying up to Qin would at least give them some respite from the constant fighting.

Zhang's real aim was to dismantle the vertical alliance and isolate the six states. Then, Qin would destroy them, one by one. This historical era still echoes in the Chinese language today - 'vertical-horizontal' is a commonly used Chinese word with a range of applications. It often means 'interconnected.'
A classic story from this period, and one that nicely demonstrates Sun Tzu's principles, is the tale of how Zhang Yi attacked the alliance between the state of Qi and King Huai of Chu.

First, Zhang Yi visited Chu, where he tried to tempt King Huai by offering him 600 li of land in Shangyu if he cut off his alliance with Qi and formed a new one with Qin. King Huai was delighted by this offer, and wasted no time accepting. He cut his ties with Qi, and sent a general to Qin to take possession of the land that had been promised him. But, Zhang Yi would not grant an audience to the visiting Chu general, claiming he was ill. King Huai began to ask himself questions.

¡§Zhang Yi probably doesn't believe that I've already called off my alliance with Qi," he thought. So, he devised a way of showing his loyalty to Qin: he sent a warrior to Qi with instructions to insult and humiliate the Qi king. The Qi king was stunned by this sudden reversal, and stung by the humiliation, and flew into a rage.

He retaliated by announcing that he was personally ending his alliance with Chu, and not only that, he also immediately allied himself with Qin. Zhang Yi picked this moment to finally talk with the visiting Chu general, and fulfill his promise.

That is, he partially fulfilled it. Of the 600 li of land he originally offered, he handed over only 6. Two zeros had gone missing
King Huai of Chu was outraged when he heard this, and immediately launched an attack on Qin.

But, without the helping hand of their former ally, Qi, Chu was much too weak to beat Qin. Chu's defeat was catastrophic, and marked the beginning of the end - Chu quickly fell into terminal decline. The lessons to be learned from this story don't just come at the expense of King Huai of Chu, but also from the reaction of Qi. When Qin attacked Chu's alliance with Qi, shouldn't it have been obvious that this also represented an attack against Qi; an attack on its own alliance with Chu? If your teammate acts like a fool, that doesn't mean that you should also act like a fool. When Chu attacked Qin, Qi could have come to their former ally's aid. Then, the Chu ruler would have felt both ashamed and grateful, and as a result the Chu-Qi alliance would be stronger than ever. Meanwhile, the real enemy, Qin, would have been thwarted, their plan a bust.

As it happened, King Huai was not the only fool in this story; the King of Qi was just as foolish. In the last chapter, we saw an example of a brutally direct way of 'attacking the enemy's plans' - killing their chief planner.

Similar to 'attacking the enemy's alliances,' there are a surprising number of cases where a state has defeated the enemy by killing their diplomats. During the wars between Liu Bang and Xiang Yu, both had sent envoys to try to persuade the rebel leader Ying Bu, who was sitting on the fence, to join their side.

Ying Bu seemed to be leaning toward joining Liu Bei, but he was hesitant to commit. Meanwhile, he was still meeting and chatting with Xiang Yu's messenger, in the inn where Xiang Yu's man was staying. During one of these conversations, Xiang Yu's messenger chose his moment, and began pressing Ying Bu to send troops to help Xiang Yu. Liu Bei's messenger, Sui He, knew what was happening, and made a quick decision. He burst into the room where the two men were talking, sat down in his counterpart's seat, and shouted: ¡§The King of Huainan has already declared for Liu Bei. What are you talking about - 'send troops?'" Xiang Yu's envoy was startled, and made to leave the inn.

Ying Bu seemed frozen to his seat. ¡§We can't let him go. Kill him!" Sui He shouted. Ying Bu found himself forced into a corner. He had to make a decision now, even if he didn't want to. In fact, he did as Sui He said.

He killed Xiang Yu's envoy, and led his soldiers to Liu Bei's in Han. There's another famous example of destroying an alliance by killing a diplomat: the story of an Eastern Han dynasty general and diplomat named Ban Chao. This last option is saved for when you've tried the first two, but they haven't worked.

The first Zhou King's advisor, Jiang Ziya, said: ¡§A leader who seeks victory by the blade of his sword, does not a good general make."
 

You don't win just by beating the enemy. The real test is: have you grown stronger, or weaker?

¡§Besieging walled cities is an option chosen only when nothing else is successful. The preparation of mantlets, armored wagons, and various implements of war will take up three whole months; and the piling up of mounds over against the walls will take three months more.

Analysis:
'Mantlets' are a kind of large shield, which can cover a soldier's entire body, while 'armored wagons' were leather-covered, four-wheeled troop-carriers, especially designed for sieges. Basically, they were the ancient Chinese equivalent of an armored personnel carrier.

One wagon could carry several dozen men directly to the base of the enemy's city wall. Other siege equipment - like siege towers and ladders, shelters made of wooden planks and catapults - would take at least three months to build and prepare for battle. It would also take three months to finish various siege-related engineering projects, like shifting earth to make tuyin, a kind of mound used to give your soldiers access to the top of the enemy's walls, digging tunnels, and dealing with moats either by building bridges or filling them with earth. Besieging a city is a slow grind, but it also requires attention to detail.

If the besieging army's general is impatient, he might opt for the 'swarming ants' tactic and end up losing a third of his men while still not capturing the city - a disastrous scenario. It's not hard to imagine what a tactic named 'swarming ants' entails. Basically, you cluster your soldiers into a dense mass and swarm up the city walls like ants. Of course, they'll be greeted on the way with arrows, rocks, boiling water, sizzling oil and fire.

'swarming ants' is also known as 'fluttering moth.' Perhaps this captures the image better. This is why assaulting a city is a pretty desperate option, reserved only for when your original backup plan's backup plan has already fallen through.

Sun Tzu's philosophy has a consistent thread: put aside all thoughts of winning and not winning, and instead concern yourself with making sure you don't lose. What really matters is whether you've grown stronger or weaker.

Don't put yourself in a position where your losses outweigh your gains, and don't throw away human lives. Life has value. A classic example is the non-Chinese Tuoba Emperor Taiwu, of Northern Wei's attack on the Liu Song dynasty in Xuyi. This went on for a month, and in the end, Tuoba bodies were piled as high as the city walls. Over half of Emperor Taiwu's men lay dead, he'd killed his own vanguard leader, Gao Liangwang, and he still hadn't captured the city.

Finally, seeing his camp full of wounded and diseased soldiers, and fearing that his escape route might be cut off, he lifted the siege and beat a retreat, taking his grudge with him. There was a general during the Republic of China period (1912-1949 CE) named Fu Zuoyi, who became famous for peacefully liberating the city of Beijing. No one was better than him at holding a city during a siege. During the war between the Zhili and Fengtian warlord cliques, although Fu Zuoyi's enemies, the Fengtian clique, had just won, he led a small, isolated force, determined to hold Zhuozhou against the enemy. He was besieged by a Fengtian army of 50,000 men, while he had only several thousand. The siege went on for two months, with indiscriminate firebombing. The Fengtian commander, Zhang Xueliang, was hell-bent on leveling the city, and yet Fu Zuoyi kept on fighting. Eventually, the Fengtian commander-in-chief, Zhang Zuolin, let his anger at being denied victory make his decisions for him - never a good idea! But Zhang didn't try the 'swarming ants' tactic. Instead, he wanted to put Fu Zuoyi in his place by using some high-tech weaponry: poison gas canisters, 500 of them, hurled into the city. After the noxious haze cleared, the Fengtian attacked one more time, but Fu Zuoyi was still there, and managed to push the Fengtian forces back again!

Zhang Zuolin gave up. ¡§This kid's not going to surrender," he told Zhang Xueliang. ¡§No more trying to fight him. We'll starve him instead! Keep the city surrounded!"
At that point, the Zhili clique leader, Yan Xishan, decided there wasn't much need to keep on fighting, so he instructed Fu Zuoyi to sue for peace. Only then did Fu Zuoyi finally sign a treaty and accept the Fengtian forces' terms. A couple of decades later, when Communist Party General Lin Biao was besieging the city of Changchun, he used the same tactic that Zhang Zuolin eventually settled for: he surrounded the city and waited.

Extract from the original text:
¡§Therefore the skillful leader subdues the enemy's troops without any fighting; he captures their cities without laying siege to them; he overthrows their kingdom without lengthy operations in the field.

With his forces intact he will dispute the mastery of the Empire, and thus, without losing a man, his triumph will be complete. This is the method of attacking by stratagem."

Analysis:
This is Sun Tzu's summary of 'Planning Assaults.' He shows that, at its root, it is about planning to maintain 'wholeness.' This not only ensures that you don't suffer any losses, but you also avoid damaging the enemy's assets, and fully benefit from taking them for yourself. To achieve this, you have to follow the three no's: no fighting, no assaulting and no prolonging.

Again, the idea is to subdue the enemy's troops without fighting, take his city without assaulting it, and destroy his country without a long war. In Sun Tzu's philosophy, there is a checklist with three things that you must do before embarking on any undertaking: (1) Think through the risks; (2) Think through the price you'll have to pay; (3) Think through how your undertaking will benefit you. Two things above all else drive people into making mistakes: one is temptation, and the other is anxiety.

There is a Chinese four-character idiom that describes this aspect of human psychology -it translates as, 'Forgetting principle at the sight of profit.' But, this doesn't tell the whole story. A more universal version of the idiom would be: 'Forgetting danger at the sight of profit.' For many people, it's hard to resist the tantalizing attraction of financial reward, even if it means risking their life. Some people even die for pennies.

Then there's anxiety. The reason it forces mistakes is that when people are in an anxious state, they feel a need to do something, anything. When people are in this frame of mind, how can you expect them to wait patiently, and not fight or attack the enemy's city?

The battlefield is a place that teeters between the worlds of life and death. It is no place for a perennially anxious commander, because when anxiety distorts your every thought, mistakes crop up with alarming ease.

What can you do to avoid making mistakes? The answer is to adopt failure as the premise behind your every thought. Normally, we tend to do the opposite, predicating all our thoughts on the idea of success, because when we do something, the aim is to do it successfully.

So, isn't it natural to put success at the center of our thinking, planning, policy-making, critical analysis and judgment calls? If your strategy teacher doesn't teach you about success, is it really 'the art of war' that they're teaching?

Well, The Art of War doesn't take this approach, and instead relates everything back to failure. For everything Sun Tzu wrote about achieving, he first hypothesized that the outcome would actually end in failure. His analysis, planning, policy-making and assessments all revolve around avoiding failure, and decreasing any losses you may have to incur. The way things should be done, according to Sun Tzu, is to first set yourself up in a position where you can't be defeated, carry out your plan, wait for an opportunity and, finally, resolve the conflict with a single move. It's the same in the business world, and it's why a person who has the ability to focus, be consistent, and stay under the radar - while steadily perfecting their particular craft over the course of years - can make it as a leading figure in their industry.

Then there are people who are always looking around for something new to do, regularly hopping from one thing to another, and riding the turbulent waves of life as an entrepreneur. The difference between these two types of people is essentially about their ways of thinking.

The former is not necessarily particularly wise; they're just people who think a lot about failure, and make it the premise of their planning. They're the kind of person who, whenever you tell them about some new idea, tells you that your idea is risky.

They first think about new things in terms of how they might fail, and only continue pursuing things they've already experienced some success with. And so, eventually, their work culminates in massive success. On the other hand, the latter type of person - the type who thinks a lot about success - only has ears for opportunity.

They believe that big opportunities absolutely cannot be missed, and so they spend their whole lives starting new businesses. The Hong Kong business magnate Li Ka-shing once said: ¡§Whenever you set out to do something, first reflect on failure." This is the fundamental wisdom of 'the art of war.' When we talk about 'masters,' what makes one a master is that they know they're the same as everyone else. Thy recognize that at least half of the projects that present themselves will end in failure if attempted, so they're extremely cautious.

If someone boasts that there's nothing they can't do, you know they're not a master. The only 'greatness' they're setting themselves up for is great disappointment. The last of Sun Tzu's three is 'no prolonging.' Basically, this means you should make as few moves as possible, and then, at the crucial moment, play your hand. The worst thing you could do is spend every day trying new things, making new moves, and repeating things you've already done.

The more you do, the more mistakes you make. Concentrate a superior force and aim to annihilate the enemy

It involved leveraging a large amount of space where battles could potentially happen in order to buy himself time, which he used to maneuver his troops into position and surround the enemy. Mao's strategy was one of using absolute advantage to fight quick, decisive battles. He summarized his approach as: ¡§Evading the enemy's main force, luring the enemy deep into the country, concentrating our own forces in advantageous positions, and destroying the enemy's fragmented forces, one piece at a time."

¡§If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy."

And then, later, use your reserves to secure your victory in a surprise attack.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§You must surprise him from the front and harass him from the rear; feint east and strike west. If you do not possess a five-to-one advantage, you will be unable to divide as many of his troops."

If your army is twice as numerous, divide the (enemy's) army into two."

If you only have twice the troop numbers of the enemy, you don't have a big enough advantage, and you need to come up with a way to make the enemy divide his army. In Du Mu's commentary, he clarified that Sun Tzu meant that it is the enemy's army that should be divided, and not your own.

(As noted earlier, the original text in Chinese is so condensed that it could be interpreted either way). Du Mu advises that you should use your army to attack either the enemy's weakest point, or attack him where you know he will be unable to resist immediately coming to the rescue. In this way, you can decrease the number of troops available to him, and consolidate your initial two-to-one advantage.

Then, it'll be much easier to defeat him. Cao Cao's commentary is simpler: ¡§If attacking one with two, then use one part as your mainstay, and the other part as the auxiliary force." Cao Cao's interpretation of Sun Tzu is different; he reads it as an imperative to divide your own army. Du Mu argues that the decision to split your army into a main force and an auxiliary force has nothing to do with the relative number of troops commanded by you and your enemy.

He says that it's an essential part of all wars. As a case in point, when Xiang Yu fought his last battle by the Wu River, he only had 28 cavalry left, but he still split his men into a main force and an auxiliary force. During that battle, his two forces took turns trying to save each other.

Du Mu was right - the meaning of the original text is that you should divide the enemy's army. However, to achieve this, first you have to divide your own army. So, Cao Cao was right too. Cao Cao went into more detail as well, spelling out how many troops should be allocated for different functions. This topic actually constitutes a whole branch of the art of war, known as 'the art of division.' A book by Ming dynasty strategist Liu Bowen, Extraordinary Strategies of a Hundred Battles, contains a chapter devoted to the art of division. Here's an excerpt:
¡§When fighting your enemy, if my forces are numerous and the enemy's few, then I ought to select an open expanse as the site where I will defeat him.

If my forces are five times more numerous than the enemy's, then I ought to allocate three fifths of my soldiers to be the main force, with the remaining two fifths as an auxiliary force. If my forces are three times more numerous than the enemy's, then I ought to allocate two thirds of my soldiers to be the main force, with the remaining one third as an auxiliary force. This can be called 'blocking him in the front with one half of my forces, while attacking his rear with the other half.' The past master10 says: 'if you do not divide when you ought to divide, you are tying your own hands.'"
Cao Cao's ¡§If attacking one with two, then use one part as your main force, and the other part as the auxiliary force" could just as well be added to the text above. In fact, it comes from perhaps the most famous line (in China) of Sun Tzu's The Art of War: ¡§Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him." Here, 'irregular' doesn't refer to anything strange or odd, despite the fact that the Chinese character used in the original text usually means 'extraordinary,' or even 'queer.' It simply means 'forces kept in reserve.' While the main forces get the fight started, the commander watches from his command center, waiting for the crucial moment. Then, he orders his reserves to spring into action, sealing his victory.

This topic will be discussed in more detail in Chapter Five: Force. For now, we will put it to one side, closing with a quotation from Jiang Ziya: ¡§It is no good talking about the use of auxiliary forces with a general who does not understand the art of dividing troops."

It's the story of Fu Jian's catastrophic defeat in the Battle of Fei River, in 383 CE. His fatal mistake was that he didn't divide his troops when he should have. He had a ten-to-one advantage - 800,000 troops against the opposing Eastern Jin army of 80,000 - but he kept his whole army grouped together in a single mass.

When the Eastern Jin forces attacked, his army fell into confusion and crumbled. The example of how it should be done comes from a general of the Liang Dynasty, Wang Sengbian, who used the tactics of troop division to defeat rebel forces commanded by Hou Jing at a battle at Zhanggongzhou. Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail. Strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head." Then, he said: ¡§The rebel scum is walking into his own death; he wants this fight. We are many and they are few, so we should divide his forces." Wang Sengbian agreed.

From the front, he held the enemy back using his crossbowmen, while attacking it from behind with his more mobile forces. Then, the bulk of his army separated into three groups, and charged straight at Hou Jing's forces from three different angles, causing them to collapse.

¡§If equally matched, we can offer battle." If your forces are evenly matched with the enemy's, it's important that you have the ability to fight. Cao Cao comments: ¡§If the number of one's force are equivalent to the enemy's, then the skillful general lays an ambush with his irregular troops, and in this way secures victory." So, once again it comes back to a division of duties between 'regular and irregular troops.' The regular troops challenge the enemy head-on, while the irregular troops prepare an ambush. Though Cao Cao doesn't spell out here what proportion of troops should be allocated for 'regular' and 'irregular' roles, history tells us that in most cases when generals used this 'lure and ambush' tactic, the main force was actually smaller than the auxiliary force. ¡§If slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy."

If you have fewer troops than the enemy, don't leave your defensive position.

Dig deep defensive trenches and put up high walls. Alternatively, conceal yourself so that the enemy doesn't know how weak you are, and when you get the chance, run away! ¡§If quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him."

In Du Mu's commentary, he explains that if you are weaker than the enemy both in terms of your military strength and the level of support you receive from your allies, you need to escape without delay and flee as far away as possible. If the enemy gets too close to your weak point, it will be too late to run.

Sun Tzu was a conservative, deeply cautious man. He always wanted to win before fighting, and he refused to fight if victory did not seem almost certain. He certainly would never fight if he had fewer men than the enemy.

On this point, Sun Tzu doesn't conform to certain mainstream values. We love to see an underdog beat a larger opponent, and history seems to be on our side on this, because the books are full of stories of famous underdog victories.

So, why exactly shouldn't you fight just because the enemy has more men than you? There's a concept from management studies called 'proof is silent.' Cases where one side has held a truly absolute majority, where there has been an absolute probability, tend to happen in silence.

Nobody talks about them, so nobody knows about them. On the other hand, people tend to make a lot of noise about low-probability events, where the underdog somehow defeats their more powerful foe. With such loud fanfare, these events are still remembered 1,000 years after they happen.

So, as stories of these events have piled up over the course of 3,000 years of Chinese history, they appear much more common than they actually were. They have in fact become a mainstream cultural narrative. So, what is 'silent evidence?' First of all, generals who run away because they didn't have as many men as their opponent tend to keep quiet about it.

It's not something people like to publicize. Perhaps it shouldn't come as a surprise that none of the 11 great commentators on Sun Tzu's The Art of War offered a single historical example of these lines.

In fact, they really wrote nothing about it; not even so much as a brief explanation! Zhang Yu did write a short addendum: ¡§When the opponent is numerous and I am few, I ought to flee from him." But - and there is an important 'but' - Zhang Yu also said: ¡§If the enemy is in chaos and I am well ordered, if the enemy is lax and I am vigorous, then even though the enemy may be more numerous than my forces, I can still contend with him in battle." Zhang Yu offered two historical examples: ¡§Since Wu Qi destroyed a Qin army with 500 men against 500,000, and Xie Xuan defeated Fu Jian with 8,000 men against a million, what need was there for them to flee?"
Zhang Yu's claim here is equivalent to listening to Sun Tzu tell you that you shouldn't try to break a stone with an egg (which he did actually say), and then responding with two examples of someone doing exactly that. Zhang Yu is advocating a 'yes, but...' approach here.

But, what about you? Could you replicate the things he talked about, defeating a force of 500,000 with only 500 men? A good number of people tend to think that they can be the exception to the rule. After all, every time someone has defied the rule, their story has literally gone down in history.

But, propping up each of these success stories is an intricate structure of countless random circumstances. If you're missing just one piece, things won't go your way. Today, we can add two more historical examples to illustrate the principles of, 'If slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him.' One of them involves 'silent evidence,' and the other is heavy on the fanfare. The one about silent evidence is the story of Shi Dakai, a general of the Taiping Rebellion during the Qing dynasty.

His expeditionary force was hemmed in by the pursuing Qing imperial army, and within a year and a half he fought in three different provinces: Sichuan, Guizhou and Yunnan. After that, he returned to Sichuan and broke through the Qing defensive line at the Yangzi River.

In the end, though, he couldn't quite get away. He died, and his story ceased to be told. This is the silent evidence: his story does not prove that Zhang Yu's words were correct. The other story, the loud one, is common knowledge.

The reason it remains known is that the army involved, once it started running, kept running for 8,000 miles. They got away from their enemies, and at the end of the war they emerged victorious. This is the story of the Red Army's Long March (1934-1935 CE). What would have happened if the Red Army didn't start running at that crucial juncture in Jiangxi Province? ¡§Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force."

A classic historical example of this is provided by the Han dynasty General Li Ling. General Li was ordered by Han Wudi to deliver a shipment of grain and fodder, but his pride wouldn't allow him to act as a lowly deliveryman.

So, he asked permission to lead 5,000 infantry in a direct assault against the Xiongnu royal court. He ended up surrounded by 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry, and surrendered. Han Wudi punished Li's failure by executing his entire family, and even Li's main cheerleader, court historian Sima Qian, was punished with castration. Wanting to win is part of being human, but reality reminds us that there's always a good chance of losing.

So, it's important to be able to admit defeat. According to Stan Shih, the founder of Taiwan's tech giant Acer Inc, ¡§You can only be a winner if you know how to concede defeat." There's a lot to this idea. You could also say that only by losing can life keep on going.

When we admit that we've lost, we can keep hold of our wins and eventually expand upon them. Even the renowned Ming dynasty thinker and statesman Wang Yangming - who during his lifetime built a monumentally important body of scholarship and went down in history as one of the four great masters of Confucianism - admitted defeat and stoically withstood the scheming of the palace secret police ('the embroidered uniform guard') as they attempted to frame and provoke him with all kinds of outrageous ploys that also harmed the common folk. He understood that in the dark society of his times, anyone who attempted to extend justice, or even just a helping hand, to the common folk would immediately be pounced upon and destroyed.

He acknowledged that this would not do anyone any good. He knew that all he could do was hold back until the secret police saw that they couldn't prevail. So, Wang Yangming accepted defeat for the time being, and waited.

He saw that if he waited until he was no longer in a losing position, then by default he would become a winner! It's the emperor's prerogative to not understand military Issues, but it's imperative for generals to understand politics
