On the first level, 'complete' means 'possessing both wisdom and talent, and having well-rounded abilities,' while 'defective' means 'having gaps in one's abilities.' On the second level, 'complete' means that 'the general's military arrangements are integrated and watertight, while 'defective' means 'the general's arrangements are full of holes.' On the third level, 'complete' means 'the general's plans are complete and carefully kept secret,' and safe from leaks, while 'defective' means 'the general's plans are transparent and obvious,' allowing the enemy to see and capitalize on your strengths and weaknesses.

We should follow the same principles in our daily activities: we should be fully equipped, keep our plans tight and allow no leaks in our calculations. If you leave any base uncovered - if there's just one issue that you haven't given adequate consideration to - what you have is a leak, and when it comes down to it, this leak will sink you. If this happens, there'll be no point crying out at the injustice: 'Who knew this would happen?'
There is an ancient Chinese phrase: 'Not knowing is not a sin." Totally incorrect!

The phrase has it backward - not knowing is the biggest sin of all! If you don't know about something, how can you deal with it responsibly? From here, Sun Tzu outlines the 'three not knowings' that every state leader must avoid. His message is: 'Yes, you're the boss, but you're ignoring a few things, because you don't know about them.'
The first 'not knowing' is not knowing that your army is not in a position to advance, and as a result, you force the issue and order them to advance anyway.

By the same token, you will be unaware of when your army isn't in a position to retreat, and so you force them to retreat when you shouldn't. Case in point: During the Tang dynasty's massive An Lushan Rebellion, General Geshu Han intended to hold Tongguan Pass against the rebel army. However, because Emperor Xuanzong didn't know that Geshu's army was in no position to fight a pitched battle, Xuanzong insisted that Geshu do exactly that.

What happened? Geshu's army was overwhelmed and Tongguan Pass was lost. As a result, the capital city, Chang'an, fell to the rebels and Emperor Xuanzong was forced to flee south to Sichuan. Another example: During the Battle of Fei River in 383 CE, General Xie Xuan of Jin told his adversary, Fu Jian of Former Qin, ¡§Move your army back a little bit; I'll cross the river, and then we can fight it out." Fu Jian was apparently unaware that he absolutely should not retreat, and he did indeed move his troops back. Fu Jian's rear units didn't know why the forward units seemed to be retreating; all they knew was that they could hear the enemy troops shouting: ¡§The Qin are defeated!" They thought that their own comrades at the front really had been defeated, so they turned and ran, and that's how a false defeat turned into a real one. Situations like these are what happen when the leader doesn't know that life and death hang in the balance with every move his army makes, whether forward or backward.

It is about knowing when to stop. The second 'not knowing' is not knowing anything about military issues, yet still wanting to have a role in the management of your army. The Methods of the Sima says: ¡§Military affairs cannot be allowed to permeate the state, and state affairs cannot be allowed to permeate the military." Ruling a country and commanding an army are two very different games, with very different rules. The military text Bing Jing says: ¡§In state affairs, use words; in military affairs, use deception."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Benevolence and a principled approach can be used to rule a state, but not to command an army; an adaptable approach can be used to command an army, but not to rule a state."
Fu Jian, the losing Former Qin commander and Emperor, had bright prospects once upon a time. He was a brilliant and celebrated leader, and the military strength he commanded was unprecedented in his times.

But, he was also the kind of person who indulges others, a personality trait that set the tone for the way he acted in his dealings with his enemy, General Xie Xuan. In their relationship, Fu Jian saw himself as the Emperor, and Xie Xuan as his subject. Perhaps he took inspiration from Zhuge Liang, who apparently captured, and then released, his enemy Meng Huo no less than seven times. Fu Jian let Xie Xuan take the initiative, and then, when he captured him, he tried to win him over with persuasion.

During Fu Jian's erstwhile efforts, he forgot that ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin; Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected." Carelessness must not be tolerated.

Because of one lapse of attention, Fu Jian's army crumbled, his country collapsed, and he lost his own life. In Du Mu's commentary, he expresses his opinion that armies have distinct systems of etiquette and command, and can only be handled using military methods and rules. If you try to command an army using the ordinary methods of administrating a state, the soldiers won't know what you want them to do. To illustrate his point, Du Mu cites the example set by Han dynasty general Zhou Yafu. When Zhou was stationed in Xiliu, the Emperor, Han Wendi, made an inspection tour of his forces, intending to show his appreciation to the soldiers. At every camp the Emperor visited, the gate guards let him pass as soon as they saw him, and the commanding officers rushed out to greet him. But Zhou Yafu's camp was different. When Han Wendi arrived, he was stopped by the guards and told to wait while someone went to inform Zhou Yajun that he'd arrived. The guards told the Emperor that they took orders from no one except their general, not even from the Son of Heaven. The Emperor waited for a good while before he was allowed in. Zhou Yafu didn't come out to greet him, but just gave a simple message for his men to relay to Han Wendi: ¡§Please enter." Zhou even told the emperor that his carriage was not permitted to move too quickly while inside the camp, per military rules. When the Emperor's carriage pulled up outside Zhou's tent, Zhou stood in the doorway and offered a simple salutation, clasping his hands in front of him and bowing. He told the Emperor that he couldn't kneel, because he was wearing armor.

Han Wendi leaned up against the railing of his carriage, and nodded his head admiringly toward Zhou Yafu. From then on, he marked out Zhou Yafu as a general he could rely upon, and on his deathbed, he told his successor, Han Jingdi, that Zhou Yafu should be made use of in the event of any military problems. Han Jingdi took his predecessor's advice, and Zhou Yafu went on to successfully put down the major Rebellion of the Seven States. However, though the example Du Mu chose is a classic, it's not entirely apt.

This is because, on that day at the Xiliu army camp, there were two important factors in play: Han Wendi's moral character, and Zhou Yafu's temperament. Zhou Yafu was very self-assured, cocky even, and he didn't only behave this way in his own camp.

He didn't adopt a more deferential manner even when he was called to the imperial palace. Eventually, his behavior made Emperor Jingdi uncomfortable, and because of his lack of judgment he ended up accused of plotting treason. He was an old man by then, but he couldn't stand being accused of such a crime, so he chose to go on hunger strike in protest, a choice that proved to be fatal.

The third 'not knowing' is not understanding that in the army, you need to adapt your leadership style to deal with changing circumstances, while still being involved in giving orders. There's no getting around the fact that, if the wrong person is in charge, you're going to lose.

The most classic example of this is from the famous Battle of Changping (262-260 BCE), between the states of Qin and Zhao. The Zhao commander, Zhao Kuo, had no battlefield ability - he was an armchair strategist at best.

Zhao's fellow general, Lian Po, knew this, the Zhao statesman Ling Xiangru knew, and Zhao Kuo's mother knew. Even his dead father knew. Only two people didn't know: Zhao Kuo himself, and the King of Zhao.

And, in brief, that is how 400,000 Zhao soldiers lost their lives. Each of the 'three not knowings' comes down this: ¡§A general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign.' They are about the dangers of a ruler trying to directly control their armies. The Zhou dynasty strategist Jiang Ziya said: ¡§The state cannot be governed from outside, and an army cannot be commanded from the palace." If a ruler constantly tries to control his armies from afar, ¡§The armies will be driven into a state of confusion and doubt, and the feudal lords will be subjected to great difficulties." When this happens to a state, its enemies are able to exploit the confusion and slip in through the cracks. When you throw your own army into disorder, you're inviting the enemy in and giving victory away.

¡§A general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign."

These words were meant for the ears of rulers, but an erstwhile advisor can never assume that the ruler will actually listen. The best they can do is try to open the ruler's eyes to the truth of these words.

If he refuses to accept that truth, they still have to obey his orders. A general who doesn't obey his ruler doesn't tend to stay alive for long, and if he can't protect his own life, how can he protect his country?

Then, what's the use in being considered a hero? A good example is the famous and highly celebrated Song dynasty martyr, General Yue Fei, who died because he refused to accept that the Emperor wouldn't listen to him. To this day, he is a Chinese national hero.

People lionize him, and in the same breath they demonize Qin Hui, who is characterized as a treacherous courtier who betrayed Yue Fei. And yet, this doesn't change the fact that the Song dynasty was destroyed.

Yue Fei's decisions compromised his duty to care for his country. A counter-example would be the Qin General Wang Jian. The Qin king entrusted him with an enormous, 100,000¡Vstrong army, which he used to eliminate six states in a row and unify all of China. He knew he had to reassure the King that he didn't have royal ambitions of his own, so he would frequently send messengers to the royal court asking for small favors.

For example, one day he would ask for a few fields, and the next day he'd ask for a simple house. In contrast, Yue Fei had a habit of doing and saying things that the Emperor found threatening, such as his ambition to rescue the two former Song Emperors who had been captured by their northern Jurchen enemies. How could he have expected Emperor Gaozong to tolerate this?

What did he expect Gaozong to do if he came back with two other Emperors? How would Gaozong know that Yue Fei wouldn't pledge allegiance to one of them over him? So, while it's acceptable for an Emperor to not understand military issues, it absolutely is not acceptable for a general to not understand politics.

The words 'a general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign' are meant as advice for rulers, but it can never be assumed that an Emperor or King will understand the importance of this rule.

The understanding has to come from the ruler; all an advisor can do is guide them to realize it. Nothing is more difficult than getting judgment calls right

Extract from the original text:
¡§Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (1) He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight."

Analysis:
Here, Sun Tzu is talking about ways of knowing victory, not acquiring victory. This is another demonstration of the idea that you can know ahead of time who's going to win, but you can't just make victory happen.

It's about not going to the battlefield in the hope that fortune will favor you and bring victory. It's about fighting a single, decisive battle when you already know that victory is assured. So, the first of these five factors is about knowing when you can fight and when you cannot - before you make any moves, you need to know whether or not you can win. This is a lot to ask of a general's ability to make sound judgment calls.

How do you know when victory is a sure thing? If you always think you're going to win, and if you do indeed win time after time, wouldn't that make you a demigod? My own experience in the world of work is this: it's impossible to know whether you're definitely going to win, but it is possible to know when you're definitely going to lose.

For example, if you're tasked with drawing up a project plan, your most important skill is not creativity. Rather, it's an ability to make good judgment calls, as well as a clear grasp of where you are at any given point in the project, and knowing whether or not you're on track to successful completion. Being able to make good judgment calls is a prerequisite to creativity, and it's important to true creativity.

Without this ability, creativity disengages from reality and floats off into an undefined, nebulous zone. How do you deal with this kind of creativity? The Han dynasty Grand Historian, Sima Qian, had this answer: ¡§When a madman speaks, the sage seriously considers his words." In other words, call in someone else to make a judgment for you. There are some things that people believe only because they hope they're true - wishful thinking is a human weakness.

Let's suppose that wishful thinking accounts for 30% of any given judgment call. Having said that, whenever you feel a high degree of certainty about something, first subtract 30% of that certainty, and reevaluate. If you feel 100% sure of something, you get a revised certainty of 70% after subtracting the 'wishful thinking' factor. Assuming that our judgment is accurate, there's a 50% probability of winning - very good prospects indeed.

Success happens occasionally, but failure is always there, all but inevitable. It's important to understand this, and to not act rashly. Knowing victory and defeat is just another way of saying evaluating the situation before 'going to battle.' And the results will just automatically happen the way you've called them, right?

Actually, no. Wars end in victory or defeat, but that's not the case in business! Often, you don't know what the result is even after the 'fight' has been 'fought.' Sometimes, the results seem to show that you've won, when in fact you've just suffered a massive loss.

Why? The reason is that losses are often concealed; they can lie low for a long time, before finally reemerging and dealing you a crippling blow. It works like this: when someone starts a business, success and failure seem very obvious in the way they present themselves. Wins present as goals that have been achieved, while failures present as projects that end up costing you money. But, once a business is up and running, it's perfectly possible that you could make a crucial error, and yet your revenues keep on growing.

By the time your market share starts to come down, you might not think that you've done anything wrong, perhaps blaming it on your product having exhausted its life cycle. Nothing is more difficult that making judgment calls and getting them right. How many troops you can command depends on how strong your management skills are

Extract from the original text: 
¡§Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (2) He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces."

Analysis:
Every line of Sun Tzu's The Art of War is densely packed with information, and this one is no exception. The idea here, in the second of the 'Five factors for knowing victory,' is that if you understand the different uses of both large and small numbers of troops, you have the ability to be a leader of men and armies.

Broadly speaking, to unpack the meaning of this line we need to look at it from three different perspectives:
1) Do you know how many soldiers you need? Example: King Zheng of Qin (the man who eventually became the First Emperor of all China) was intent on destroying the state of Chu, so he called a court meeting of all his ministers, and asked them how many men and horses would be needed to take Chu.

One minister, Wang Jian, said: ¡§Without 600,000 men, it cannot be done." Li Xin disagreed: ¡§A force of 200,000 is all that will be needed to defeat Chu." King Zheng naturally preferred Li Xin's answer, and dismissed Wang Jian as an addled old man, no longer fit for use. The King named Li Xin and another general, Meng Tian, commanders of a 200,000-strong army, and sent them south to attack Chu.

They lost, badly. Seven high-ranking Qin officers were killed, and the debacle stands out in history as one of the few major defeats suffered by Qin. The first thing the Qin King did was apologize to Wang Jian, and then he invited him to lead a new army and fight Qin's enemies.

Wang agreed, on the condition that he would be given 600,000 men. Wang led his army into the state of Chu, set up camp and stayed put. He showed no interest in starting any fights, and instead spent his time running athletic competitions for his men. The Chu army was outnumbered, and they knew they were in position to attack, but after a year passed with no sign of action, the Chu forces became restless and began moving around much more often.

Gaps soon opened in their defenses, and Wang Jian wasted no time - he pounced, and in no time at all the state of Chu came undone. When the Xiongnu leader, Modun, wrote that highly improper letter to Empress Lu, the first thought that came into the furious Empress' mind was to send out troops to punish the chieftain for his impertinence. In the imperial court, General Fan Kuai got quite carried away by the excitement of the occasion and, eager to answer the Empress' call, dramatically proclaimed: ¡§Give me 100,000 men and horses, and I will wipe the Xiongnu from the maps!" He wasn't the only one; everyone seemed to be jumping on the war wagon. But then, Li Bu shouted over all the other voices: ¡§Fan Kuai, you should be executed for such a suggestion! Do you forget that our late lord the Emperor once led a host of over 400,000 men against the Xiongnu, and yet he was surrounded at Baideng?

It was only by the grace of Chen Ping's silver tongue that the enemy allowed Emperor Gaozu safe passage home. But you - do you consider yourself superior to Gaozu?" 

Empress Lu soon recovered her cool, and decided the best response was to write back to Modun instead of fighting him. Her letter, which we detailed earlier, was well balanced - neither submissive nor overbearing - which allowed her to maintain a friendly, peaceful relationship with her powerful Xiongnu neighbors.

2) How many soldiers are you capable of leading? This is a skill that touches on management, organization and mobilization abilities. How many men can you lead? A squad? A company? A platoon? Perhaps an entire army? Liu Bang once gathered his most trusted followers and held a discussion about how many troops each of them was capable of leading. He asked Han Xin how many he thought that he, Liu Bang, could command. Han Xin replied that he thought Liu Bang's limit was 100,000 men - any more than that and he wouldn't be able to get the job done. Then Liu Bang asked: ¡§Han Xin, what about you?

How many troops could you lead?" Han Xin replied: ¡§Well, since it's me you're talking about, the more the merrier! I can take as many as you can give me."

Organizational and managerial skills are, as a topic of conversation, somewhat dull.

They're not the kind of thing people relish talking about, unlike certain other personal attributes associated with war. For instance, everyone likes stories about leaders who had a knack for stratagems, or great courage.

This is compelling stuff, and so, naturally, it is these stories that spread wide and far. But which of these things made Han Xin so talented in the art of war? Why did he rise above his peers? Of course, he was certainly a very cunning strategist, but he was not courageous - this is considered his weakness.

He also had a superpower. Look no further than his words to Liu Bang: ¡§The more the merrier!" What if you asked yourself, what's the biggest team I could lead? Managing a company of 20 people and managing a company of 200 are very different things.

It's a different thing again to lead 2,000, 20,000 or 200,000. Some organizations might even manage a million people, like Foxconn. Unfortunately, the electronics manufacturer's management methods drove their employees mad, even to the point of suicide. On the other hand, we have the example of the Qin general Wang Jian, who managed to run a military camp of 600,000 men for a whole year with no battles to keep them busy, only daily athletic competitions. Yet, at the crucial moment, he was able to deliver a killing blow to the enemy.

The fact that he was able to avoid any major disasters, while managing 600,000 young men living in close quarters without much to occupy them, is a testament to his incredible talent for management. 3) How do you lead soldiers?

How do you use them? Here, we can borrow a principle from Chapter Five: ¡§The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men." This is what Han Xin was talking about: you could give him 100 men to lead, or a 100,000, and he would be equally at ease in both situations. He could do this is because he had a whole organizational framework and various management systems he could call upon.

This is a topic that is discussed in later chapters (Chapter Four: Tactical Dispositions; Chapter Five: Energy; and Chapter Six: Weak Points and Strong). Organizational framework is about designing different types of fighting units, from the smallest to the largest.

As we've noted, the smallest unit used in ancient Chinese warfare consisted of five men. By the Ming dynasty, General Qi Jiguang, who was famous for defeating the infamous wokou pirates, designed a 'Mandarin Duck Unit' consisting of 20 men.

In the 20th century, Communist Party General Lin Biao invented an organizational formula: 'One point, two sides, three threes.' Lin Biao was a masterful commander, directing his men as if they were an extension of his own arm, from the smallest units of three men to huge armies of over a million soldiers. This is what Sun Tzu meant when he wrote: ¡§The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men."

Employees who can't see things from where their boss is standing have no future; a boss who doesn't think like an employee will never make it big

Extract from the original text: 
¡§Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (3) He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks."

Analysis:
Now we move on to the third of the 'five factors for knowing victory.'
If you asked commanders if they understood what it means that 'He will win whose army is animated by the same spirit throughout all its ranks,' they would all say 'yes.' But, if you think about it in terms of Ming dynasty philosopher Wang Yangming's theory of the unity of knowledge and action, you can't really know what it means unless you've actually done it. By these standards, almost nobody really knows what it means.

Unsurprisingly, when people try to put it into action, they start with their own desires and demand that other people conform. In general, you see people in higher positions trying to force their desires upon people in lower positions.

Very rarely do people understand that the right thing to do conforms to the desires of others. The Neo-Confucianists spoke of 'preserving the patterns of heaven, and destroying the desires of mankind,' while Wang Yangming said: ¡§The patterns of heaven are the desires of mankind." But these are two different types of desire. The former is personal desire, and 'destroying' it simply means 'controlling' it.

The latter is communal desire, and Wang Yangming was saying that people should conform to this communal desire. There is a passage from an ancient narrative history text, The Zuo Commentary, that reads: ¡§It is admissible to follow men by using a desire, but if men are used to follow a desire, then success is a rare thing." This means that you can achieve success by aligning your aspirations with those of a larger group of people, but if you make a group of people follow your own, personal desire, success will be hard to come by. In fact, we might edit the original text, from ¡§He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks," to 'He will win who aligns himself with the desires of others.'

This takes us back to a truism: benefitting others is the same as benefitting yourself.

If you're an employee and you want to make quick progress, you should always analyze any problem you face from your boss's perspective. In any business relationship, you should always try to put yourself in the shoes of the other party's boss. Sincerity works magic; it's the key to business stability. If you're a boss, you need to be able to think like an employee.

You need to see everything from their perspective, take an active interest in them, and put yourself at their service. If you can do that, you will find people willing to work with you. If you're a business, you need to see things through the eyes of consumers.

Rather than trying to make money by exploiting an imbalance in information access, focus on building a solid product and service structure on behalf of consumers. Do what others won't, and you'll have a brand that can last a hundred years.

¡§He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks."

So, how is that done? First, you need to admit that the upper and lower ranks do not share the same desires.

Only when you've done this will you be able to think of a way to unify them. If your starting point is a belief that everyone else should conform to you, and that there's nothing you need to do, it won't work.

People will never truly conform to your way. The Warring States period Legalist philosopher, Han Feizi, touched upon this in his writings, but he used a different wording from Sun Tzu: ¡§Rulers and minsters cherishing divergent interests."
During the Three Kingdoms period, when Cao Cao attacked the state of Eastern Wu, the Eastern Wu King, Sun Quan, called a meeting with his minsters. He asked then: ¡§Should we fight, or surrender?" The ministers' response was unanimous: ¡§We cannot beat Cao Cao.

Even General Liu Cong surrendered to him, and he was well prepared. But us? Forget about it. We should surrender, and then focus on negotiating terms."
But one Eastern Wu statesman, Lu Su, had other ideas. When Sun Quan left the courtroom for a moment to answer nature's call, Lu Su seized his chance to make a pitch to the King: ¡§My lord, it does not matter for us ministers if we surrender, but you cannot." Sun Quan asked him why, and he replied: ¡§We're advisors - even if there's a new lord, we'll still carry on as before, working in our official posts. If you surrender, then our assets and salaries will be safe, but what about you?

What official post would you be eligible for?"
Now, Sun Quan understood. He had to fight. This is what it means for rulers and ministers to have different interests. So, what's the solution? And what's the solution for divided desires between 'the upper and the lower ranks?'
According to Han Feizi's logic, the answer is to develop a transactional relationship between a ruler and his ministers. In other words, build incentive mechanisms, which should be fair and transparent.

Then, there's no need for rulers to be inherently benevolent, or for ministers to be loyal, because the incentives will automatically steer rulers toward benevolent kindness and ministers toward courageous loyalty. In ruler-minister relations, there's no room for acting on emotion, whether love, respect, kindness or any of a long list of similar sentiments.

What's crucial is that everyone must be loyal to the responsibility they hold within their individual role. They must be loyal to their job and to the rules of the game. With well-designed incentives, even if everyone who works for you is essentially a bad person, it won't matter, because their impulse to follow their own interests will only cause them to do good. In terms of building your advisors' moral fiber, you just need to promote the idea that everyone should act the way good people act, and give credit to people who demonstrate especially good behavior.

If you do this, you will be able to unite the desires of the upper and lower ranks as one, and you will win. Properly understand the meaning of 'Just in case...'

Extract from the original text:
¡§Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (4) He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared."

Analysis:
Now let's take a look at the fourth of the 'five factors for knowing victory.'
The word in the original Chinese text corresponding to 'prepare' is a rarely used, archaic character, which means 'to make defensive preparations in advance.' It features in a modern Chinese four-character idiom, which means 'two people deceive one another,' with the root meaning being: 'two people make preparations against one another.'
The ancient text, The Zuo Commentary, says: ¡§He who makes no preparations in advance must not command soldiers." Likewise, a passage from Chapter Eight of Sun Tzu's The Art of War reads: ¡§The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemy's not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable." 
At one time during the Spring and Autumn period, the states of Wu and Chu were at war against one another. The two armies were positioned thirty li apart, but a rainstorm came that lasted ten days and ten nights.

At night, there was total darkness, with no stars to light the sky. The Chu commander, Yi Xiang, held a meeting with Chu General Zi Qi. ¡§With such terrible weather," the commander said, ¡§the Wu army no doubt believes that we have not made the proper defensive preparations.

They will attempt a surprise attack, I am sure of it. The best course of action for us would be to prepare accordingly."
Sure enough, a Wu surprise attack didn't take long to materialize. But, when the Wu forces saw the Chu army arrayed in full defensive formation, they realized they held no advantage and quickly retreated. The Chu army didn't pursue them, because Yi Xiang knew that the Wu forces would have been prepared for that eventuality. Instead, he waited until the Wu army had retreated back to their camp, and then he made his move. ¡§They have now marched a total of 60 li on their way here and back to their camp, so they will be tired and hungry. Their general will want to rest, and the soldiers will want to eat, so their defenses will be loose. If we quietly march our forces the 30 li to their camp, I am sure we can defeat them with a single, sharp blow," Yi Xiang reasoned. And he was right - his plan worked perfectly, and the Wu army suffered a massive defeat.

But theoretically, what would Yi Xiang have done if the Wu army didn't try their surprise attack? It was raining heavily, and his army was set up in a defensive formation. Wouldn't his effort have been wasted?

It's normal to hear people say words to the effect of. 'I wasted my time; all my preparation was for nothing.'" This is exactly the kind of thinking that the idea of 'the art of war' aims to dispel. The classic military text, One Hundred Sayings on the Art of War, puts it like this: ¡§It is preferable to make preparations that are unused, rather than to not make preparations with the result that the enemy profits thereby." 
These advance preparations go 'unused' in the vast majority of cases, because they are, by nature, made for 'just in case' scenarios. They're a back-up, not the main plan.

This means that for every example of such preparations working out with good effect, there are 9,999 cases of preparations going 'unused.' The Chu commander, Yi Xiang, was by no means blessed with supernatural powers of foresight - he had no way of knowing that the Wu army would come; he was just following standard operating procedure. That's why he prepared the way he did.

If the Wu army hadn't showed up, the Chu soldiers would have grumbled for a while, and then things would have moved on. That day certainly wouldn't have found its way into the history books, and we wouldn't even know what happened. But the Wu army did attack, and that's why Yi Xiang's name has lived on for over 2,000 years.

The very fact that this story has lasted so long goes to show how rarely things like this actually happen. A friend of mine who works for the French petroleum company, Total, once told me that in any company meeting, there's always a safety officer present, and the meeting always starts with a half-hour safety presentation. It covers things like where the fire escapes are, emergency exits, the overall layout of whatever hotel the meeting is taking place in, locations of fire extinguishers, step-by-step instructions for evacuating the building, how to save yourself in different situations, how to help colleagues, first aid information, and so on.

From the perspective of pragmatic, mainstream values - which put progress first, quality second, and safety third - these tedious safety briefings are a colossal waste of time, especially because everyone there has likely heard it hundreds of times before!

But, this is where you need to really understand what 'just in case' means. In Chinese, 'just in case' is literally 'one in ten thousand,' and that's what we're talking about here - being prepared for a one-in-10,000 outcome! How many parents who drive cars don't bother with a child seat for their babies, because they don't think anything will go wrong?

Clearly, they haven't considered the fact that if a one-in-10,000 event happens, their child will be gone. That's why whenever I travel with my child, I always take a child seat with me. Another way to understand the idea of, 'He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared,' is to put it like this: 'Opportunity belongs to he who is prepared.' Life is constantly setting the scene for new situations. If you embrace the idea of this passage, you will be ready for opportunity when it arrives.

War is fleeting, and 99% of our work is preparation. There's deep meaning in this. Yet, it's so easy for people to see only the benefits or losses that war might bring them. That's why more time and resources are allocated to gathering the fruits of war than to preparing for war.

But, you should be thinking about sowing seeds, not getting ahead of yourself and focusing on the harvest. I have observed certain entrepreneurs delegating 'harvesting' work to their managerial staff, because today's harvest is the product of seeds that they sowed three years earlier.

Meanwhile, the entrepreneur focuses all his attention and energy on the next round of sowing; he's preparing for the future. The boss should let go of his judgments, where appropriate; employees should let the boss cross workplace boundaries

Extract from the original text:
¡§Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (5) He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign. These five factors are the way to know who will win." 

Analysis:
We have now reached the last of the 'five factors for knowing victory.' The Methods of the Sima says: ¡§Advancing and retreating are decisions to be made according to the situation, not by dictate of the ruler." 
When the forces of Cao Cao's general, Sima Yi, were lined up against Zhuge Liang on the Wuzhang Plain, Sima Yi refused to fight. Day after day, Zhuge Liang launched tirades of insults against Sima Yi, including, as we've noted, allegedly sending him a 'gift' of women's clothing.

Sima Yi's men were outraged by this humiliation, and began to suspect that Sima Yi was a coward. In one soldier after another, the desire to fight grew stronger. Sima Yi responded by telling them: ¡§Alright, I will immediately request authorization from the Emperor to attack." 
Sima YI sent a letter to Cao Cao's court, but when they received it, they knew exactly what his real intentions were: he was just putting on a show, and he needed Cao Cao to play along. Cao Cao obliged, sending an imperial envoy named Xin Pi to Sima Yi's camp. Xin Pi stood at the camp's gate and announced an imperial decree to the soldiers: ¡§Any man who presumes to inquire about attacking the enemy shall be executed!"
When Zhuge Liang got wind of this, he said: ¡§If Sima Yi was really capable of handling me, would he have written to his Emperor asking permission to fight? He's just pretending that the Emperor won't let him fight, because he's worthless as a leader!"
By saying this, Zhuge Liang was referring directly to this chapter's passage from Sun Tzu's The Art of War: ¡§He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign." If Sima Yi wanted his ruler to interfere, that meant he didn't have any 'military capacity.'
However, Sima Yi's request for interference was a ploy - he was play-acting. Zhuge Liang knew this, and he never did succeed in starting the fight he wanted so badly at Wuzhang Plain.

Instead, he fell ill and died while still in camp. In ancient China, there was a ceremony by which the ruler would bestow his authority on his commander-in-chief. It centered on a ceremonial axe, which represented power over the lives and deaths of all subordinates, and the power to punish the ruler's enemies. The axe itself was not designed for battle, but for executions - specifically, by beheading and by cutting people in half at the waist. In the ceremony, the ruler would hold the axe by the blade and, holding the handle out toward the general, say the following words: ¡§Everything reaching from here up into the highest heavens shall be given into the general's power." Then, the ruler would take the axe by the handle, hold out the blade toward the general, and decree: ¡§Everything reaching from here down into the deepest recesses of the earth shall be given into the general's power." This is how the Emperor passes his all-encompassing power over everything, from the heavens down to the earth, to the general. ¡§He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign," and the general shall not be dictated to from afar by the ruler.

When people are lectured about the art of war, they naturally believe that this passage is correct. But in reality, it's describing an idealized state of affairs, which rarely crosses the boundary into objective reality.

Things generally did not go well for generals who stubbornly insisted on this ideal - many of them ended up dying horrific deaths. From a general's position, they have to manage every detail of army life, and they also have to deal with the overwhelming minutiae and variables of battlefield situations as they develop in real-time. It's not surprising, then, that there's no way they could ask the ruler's permission for every move they make.

But, it's not easier for the ruler either. Compared with his generals, the pressure a ruler has to deal with is significantly heavier. Rulers have to manage the ins and outs of politics, internal policy, diplomacy, hostile foreign states, armed rebels and other insider political foes. On top of that, the ruler has to hand over all his chips to his general.

If a ruler can resist the temptation to send a supervisor to watch over his generals, he's already doing quite well, given the pressure he's under. If you want a ruler to not manage his generals in any way, and referain from asking them any questions, he'd collapse into an anxiety-wracked mess. ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State.

It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected."

When a ruler is walking the line between life and death, you can't ask them not to speak their mind or interfere in military campaigns. This is because, with every passing moment, the ruler is constantly making judgment-calls.

Rulers should learn when it's appropriate to let go of their judgment; they should be able to exercise self-control. For example, during the Tang dynasty's An Lushan Rebellion, Tang general Geshu Han was holding a strong defensive position at Tongguan Pass, and his situation appeared to be improving after half a year of refusing to be drawn out of his fortress and into a pitched battle. Despite this, Emperor Xuanzong forced Geshu Han to go out and fight.

Why did Xuanzong make this judgment call? Why did he think it was a good idea to fight out in the open? One reason was his pride. He could not accept the fact that An Lushan had rebelled against him, let alone the possibility that the rebel general could defeat him. That's why Xuanzong executed his two best generals, Feng Changqing and Gao Xianzhi, who had lost battles against the rebels. Xuanzong's behavior was an act of self-sabotage. Now that he could see the tide was turning in his favor at Tongguan Pass, Xuanzong was anxious to destroy An Lushan as soon as possible, like waving away an unpleasant smell. Another reason was that Emperor Xuanzong's advisor, Yang Guozhong, was fanning the flames.

He was a sworn enemy of Geshu Han - whatever Geshu Han wanted to do, Yang would tell the Emperor to do the exact opposite. Emperor Xuanzong was not capable of making clear, critical judgment calls. He mostly acted on his emotions.

He couldn't accept the idea of failure or being humiliated, so he felt an urgent need to remove the possibility of these outcomes every materializing, and to do so as quickly as possible. Yang Guozhong slandered Geshu Han: ¡§Since Geshu Han is taking such pains to convince us that he cannot fight, then even if we listen to him, what good will it do to wait for another half year? Would that really make a difference?" Yang whispered in the Emperor's ear, and his cajoling worked.

Xuanzong became ever more assured that he was making the right decision. Of course, the result of all this was that when Geshu Han obligingly led his troops out of the fortress, his entire army was decimated, the Tang capital was lost, and Xuanzong fled to Sichuan. Yang Guozhong was killed by outraged soldiers, along with his cousin Yang Guifei, an imperial courtesan with whom Xuanzong had been besotted. Geshu Han's greatest 'inability' in all of this was his failure to make Xuanzong trust him. Because of this, he had no claim to having 'military capacity.' At the root of his failure was his vicious feud with Yang Guozhong.

Yang may have been a contemptible kind of person, but sometimes 'men of distinction' nonetheless have to put that aside and maintain friendly relations with such people. At the very least, you have to be aware of this idea, even if you can't bring yourself to actually be friends with people you despise. Many talented minsters and advisors achieved great things by relying on good relations with otherwise unpleasant palace eunuchs - for example, Ming dynasty reformer Zhang Juzheng.

Rulers need to consider this chapter's passage carefully. Then, they will realize that being overly eager to kill or be killed could quickly lead to irreversible defeat, and that there's no harm in letting go of some of the executive decision-making and trusting the generals to take care of business themselves. If you're a general, you should resist the temptation to swat away the ruler's hand whenever he tries to get involved.

Instead, allow him access whenever he wants. Make sure he sees you as someone who is totally transparent, who would never try to keep him at a distance. If you do this, you'll be able to reason with the ruler more persuasively when that crucial moment comes and you absolutely have to take full control of the situation.

Know yourself and know your enemy. Problems usually arise from not knowing yourself, rather than not knowing your enemy

Extract from the original text:
¡§Hence, the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle."

Analysis:
If you know yourself and your enemy, you can set yourself up in a position where failure is impossible. Knowing yourself and your enemy means that you clearly understand your own situation, and the enemy's, in terms of each of the 'Five factors for knowing victory.' And, you will understand exactly how your situation compares with the enemy's. But, if you only understand yourself and not your enemy, your odds of victory immediately plummet to 50%.

Worst of all, if you don't understand yourself or your enemy, your odds are zero. For an example of someone who knew themselves but not their enemy, look no further than Li Quan's commentary. He offers the case of the former Qin Emperor Fu Jian, and the Battle of Fei River. When the former Qin statesman, Wang Meng, lay on his deathbed, he gave Fu Jian some advice: ¡§Although the Jin court is located in the remote lands south of the Yangzi River, their bloodline is pure. The Jin generals Xian An and Huan Chong are powerful men, and we should not attack them.

Our true enemies are here, in our midst - the Xianbei and the Qiang, all wretched northern barbarians. They will ultimately be our undoing, unless we do what is good for the country and expel them from among us."
But Fu Jian didn't listen, and after Wang Meng died, he led an army to invade Jin. Even with the wheels already in motion, people tried to talk Fu Jian out of it: ¡§We're not the only ones with talented generals," his advisors argued.

¡§They have Xie An and Huan Chong, both brilliant commanders. We mustn't underestimate them!"
Fu Jian remained adamant: ¡§I command the multitudes of eight provinces, and have in my possession a million men and horses. My armies are large enough to hold back the Yangzi River!

What difficulty exists that I cannot overcome?"
In fact, he was marching into a catastrophic defeat at the Battle of Fei River. Afterward, the Xianbei and Qiang people did indeed revolt, and Fu Jian was murdered by the Qiang chief, Yao Chang.

In retrospect, was Li Quan right? Was Fu Jian's fatal error knowing himself, but not knowing his enemy? Not at all. His problem wasn't that he didn't know the enemy, but that there were internal dynamics in his own camp that he didn't understand.

He didn't realize that he was effectively bunking with his mortal enemies. Some doubt remains about the accuracy of the historical records I quoted above about Wang Meng's advice to Fu Jian. It doesn't ring entirely true that Wang would have said that the reason the Jin shouldn't be attacked was that they had a 'pure bloodline.' Fu Jian was himself not purely Han Chinese, and it's unlikely that people of ethnic minority background would believe it was dangerous to attack someone just because they were 'pure' Han Chinese. Remember, though, that Chinese history is written by Han Chinese historians of 'pure bloodlines,' and it's very likely this line is an editorial intervention.

Anyway, the important part was Wang Meng's second line, where he said that the non-Chinese Xianbei and Qiang peoples were the real enemies, and that they should be destroyed. But Fu Jian had one, massive character flaw: he was too kind, and his kindness lacked principle.

Anyone else, having conquered another state, would make sure they finished the job, pulling up the enemy by the roots. Not Fu Jian. As far as he was concerned, as long as the enemy surrenders, their former Emperor would be welcome to fight under his flag as a general. He was indiscriminately open-hearted. This flaw explains why Fu Jian had already failed one of the 'Five factors for knowing victory' - ¡§He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks." His vast ranks comprised a million men, but they were divided in spirit. Vanquished Emperors and Generals of defeated states who served under Fu Jian still harbored dreams of restoring their fallen kingdoms, and they certainly had no intention of helping Fu Jian in his bid to conquer all of China and found a new empire.

That's why, when Fu Jian's men heard the enemy shouting that their comrades were retreating, they all turned tail and fled. Among the states conquered by Fu Jian was Former Yan. The Former Yan prince, a Xianbei boy named Murong Chong, was taken to Fu Jian's palace along with his older sister, who was fourteen at the time. His sister became a favorite concubine of Fu Jian, and Murong himself became a male concubine, so brother and sister both were moved into the imperial harem. Later in life, Murong Chong yearned to reestablish his old kingdom, but he ended up serving in Fu Jian's army. When Fu Jian saw him one day at the front, the old Emperor was overcome with emotion, and had a servant take a brocaded gown over to Murong Chong. This was just one more humiliation for a man who had once been a prince, who had lost his country and his family at the hands of this man, and who together with his sister had been bundled off into the enemy's harem.

Yet, Fu Jian never thought there was anything but love between them! He was convinced that he was the undisputed lord of the whole world; that's what made him absurd. He had no idea that other people might also fancy themselves Emperor. Let's critique Fu Jian in terms of each of the 'five factors for knowing victory.' 
¡§He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight." Wang Meng specifically warned Fu Jian that his real problems were internal, and that it would not be a good idea to start a war with the Jin rulers. Fu Jian didn't get it.

¡§He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces." On this point, Fu Jian was just sloppy. He didn't bother dividing his huge army into different units, but massed them together in one huge heap. That's why Fu Jian's order to retreat triggered his army's total collapse. ¡§He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks." We've already addressed this point: many of the generals who supposedly served him were actually just waiting for a chance to restore their own nations and declare themselves Emperor. ¡§He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared." Xie Xuan carefully designed a trap for Fu Jian, who believed he didn't have anything to fear, regardless of what traps his enemies might have set.

So, he didn't prepare. That's how he found himself on the back foot and getting punched in the mouth. ¡§He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign." In this case, Fu Jian was both the Emperor and the general in the field. He led a million men, but they could be more accurately described as a mob than an army, each with their own subversive motives.

Fu Jian didn't meet the standards of any of the five factors. So, he started out with a 100% chance of failure, rather than the 50% odds that he would have enjoyed if he knew himself but not the enemy.

We often focus on knowing our enemies, because we take it as a given that we know ourselves. But reality often says otherwise. Our problems generally come from the fact that we don't know ourselves. In practice, if you can't quite work out your enemies, how are you supposed to understand other peoples' situations? The Tang Emperor Taizong specifically commented on this point with reference to Fu Jian: ¡§Though the generals and advisors of today may not be capable of knowing their enemies, but what of Fu Jian? If he had been able to know himself, how could he have fallen into such an unfavourable position?"
I believe that if you know yourself, but not the enemy, your odds of victory aren't just 50%, but 80%.

You should definitely make sure you put in the hard yards when it comes to knowing yourself. My attitude is: 'I don't care what your situation is, because that's out of my control. I only care about what my situation is, because then I'll be prepared for you regardless. More than that, I'll be able to twist you around my little finger.' In my readings of Zeng Guofan's Complete Works, I've found very few journal entries containing specific details about his enemies. Instead, he mostly wrote technical reflections on his own work as he built up and managed his army.

You only find out the truth about the enemy's situation after you've already fought them. There's another question you have to think about when you apply Sun Tzu's The Art of War to modern business management: Who is the 'enemy' in 'know yourself and know your enemy?' 
It's not your competitors! In fact, your 'enemy' is your clients.

If you know yourself and you know your clients, you are guaranteed to win every battle you fight. Business management problems normally happen when you haven't properly done the work you need to on yourself, and on top of that you don't understand your clients. If what you take from the art of war is that you should spend every day studying your so-called enemy, you're just wasting your time and your effort.

Sun Tzu said: ¡§In the practical art of war, the best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it is second best. So, too, it is better to recapture an army entirely than to destroy it, to capture a battalion, a company or a squad entire, than to destroy them.

Hence, to fight and conquer in all your battles is not supreme excellence; supreme excellence consists in breaking the enemy's resistance without fighting. Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans; the next best is to attack the enemy's alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy's army in the field.

Besieging walled cities is an option chosen only when nothing else is successful. The preparation of mantlets, armored wagons, and various implements of war, will take up three whole months; and the piling up of mounds over against the walls will take three months more. The general, unable to control his irritation, will launch his men to the assault like swarming ants, with the result that one-third of his men are slain while the city still remains untaken.

Such are the disastrous effects of a siege. Therefore, the skillful leader subdues the enemy's troops without any fighting; he captures their cities without laying siege to them; he overthrows their kingdom without lengthy operations in the field. With his forces intact, he will dispute the mastery of the Empire, and thus, without losing a man, his triumph will be complete.

This is the method of attacking by stratagem. It is the rule in war: if our forces are ten to the enemy's one, to surround him; if five to one, to attack him; if twice as numerous, to divide the army11 into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force. If our forces are ten to the enemy's one, surround him; if five to one, attack him; if twice as numerous, divide the army into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him.

Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force. Now, the general is the bulwark of the State; if the bulwark is complete at all points; the State will be strong; if the bulwark is defective, the State will be weak. There are three ways in which a ruler can bring misfortune upon his army: (1) By commanding the army to advance or to retreat, being ignorant of the fact that it cannot obey.

This is called hobbling the army. (2) By attempting to govern an army in the same way as he administers a kingdom, being ignorant of the conditions that obtain in an army. This causes restlessness in the soldiers' minds.

(3) By employing the officers of his army without discrimination, through ignorance of the military principle of adaptation to circumstances. This shakes the confidence of the soldiers. But when the army is restless and distrustful, trouble is sure to come from the other feudal princes.

This is simply bringing anarchy into the army, and flinging victory away. Thus we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (1) He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight. (2) He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces. (3) He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks. (4) He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared. (5) He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign. These five factors are the way to know who will win.

Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle."

Formations

Win first, fight later

Extract from the original text:
¡§The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.

Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy. Hence the saying: One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it."

Analysis:
There is a connection between Chapter Four of Sun Tzu's The Art of War (Formation) and Chapter Five (Force). These two words, 'formation' - of which the root meaning in Chinese is simply 'shape' - and 'force' combine in modern Chinese to form a word with a range of meanings.

They range from 'terrain' to 'power' to 'situation.' It is a word that traces its origins directly to The Art of War. So, what is the meaning of 'formation' here? Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is the shape of an army; I move, the enemy reacts. It is two enemies analyzing each other's situation."
Formation is something that can be observed.

It's about making moves and watching how the enemy responds; it's about probing and observing one another. It's similar to a widely known concept in modern Chinese known as 'reconnaissance by fire.' The idea is to take a couple of shots at the enemy, and see what shape or formation it exposes. Zhang Yu also takes a shot at explaining the idea of 'formation.' He said the following: ¡§It is the shape of two armies, one attacking and the other defending. When it is hidden within, then the enemy cannot determine what it is; when it is visible from outside, then the enemy can infiltrate through the cracks." 
Both sides do all that they can to not allow the enemy to probe their formation.

Once battle commences, one side becomes the attacker and the other the defender, and then the two armies' formations are exposed to each other. So, 'formation' is a stage before a battle starts, while 'energy' is a topic for when battles have already gone live. The Han dynasty scholar-official Xun Yue wrote about 'formation' and 'energy' in the same passage:
¡§There are three essentials in the art of establishing policies and obtaining victory: 1) Formation; 2) Force; 3) Circumstances. In general, formation is about calculations of what may be gained and what may be lost.

Force is about that which is appropriate in the moment-to-moment situation of a battle, and it is about opportunities for advancing and retreating. Circumstances are about whether or not, in truth, one's will is within the realm of possibility. Thus, the fact that results differ even when policies and events are the same is because of differences in the use of these three arts."
So, 'formation' is about calculating gains and losses, and your odds of victory can be calculated. You should act only once you are clear about the calculations; if you're not clear, don't move.

Before you do anything, take a good look at the formations and work out if you're in a viable situation. Xun Yue also said that once the wheels are in motion, you need to rely on force. This isn't wrong, but Sun Tzu discusses the topic in much more detail in Chapter five. Finally, Xun Yue also mentioned 'circumstances.' When he talks about 'one's will,' he's referring to the commander-in-chief's willpower, but also to his men's morale, and whether or not it's 'in the realm of possibility.' In The Art of War, 'circumstances' are categorized as part of 'force,' so Xun Yue's 'three essentials' are actually only two: 'formation' and 'force.'
Once you've got your head around these two topics, the whole process of fighting and winning battles boils down to the two processes of 'winning formation' and 'winning force.' Now, let's start reading through Chapter Four: Formation, which is all about winning through the use of 'formations.'

¡§The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.

Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy. Hence the saying: One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it."

Ancient generals who were truly skilled in fighting wars would start with themselves, first making thorough plans so as to put themselves in a position where they can't be beaten. Then, they would wait for the right time and opportunity to defeat their enemy. Being unbeatable is down to you; being able to beat your enemy is down to whether or not the enemy gives you the opportunity to win. By this logic, generals skillful in the art of war had the ability to make themselves undefeatable, but not to guarantee certain victory over their enemy.

Victory can be foreseen, but it can't be forced if the conditions aren't right. There is a parallel between, ¡§The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy," and a passage from the previous chapter: ¡§If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles." Making your own plans such that your enemy can't defeat you is the same as 'knowing yourself,' and waiting until the enemy can be defeated is the same as 'knowing your enemy.'

¡§To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself. Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy."

In short, you can control yourself, but not others.

First, get your affairs in order, and then observe others. If the enemy has no weak point for us to attack, there's nothing we can do to secure victory. ¡§One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it."

We can, through critical evaluation, determine that we are capable of winning, but if we don't have winning formation and force, we can't make it happen. What are you supposed to do if you can't win, given that victory can't be forced?

The first thing to do is not do anything. So many people lose because they don't know that it's possible to leave situations unresolved. There's a Chinese saying that sums this up quite aptly: 'If you go looking for ways to die, you're going to die.' If there's something you can't do, don't try to force it. That's because, as another Chinese saying reminds us, 'As long as the green hills last, there'll always be wood for your stove.' In other words, if you insist on forcing a resolution, you'll end up losing all of your leverage.

If victory is beyond reach, don't fight. Reel it back, focus on yourself, and focus on training. Sun Tzu's philosophy is to secure victory first and go to battle later, and we haven't seen the last of this idea. It comes up again later in the text, where I rephrased it as, 'Win first, fight later.' If you haven't won yet, don't fight.

Many people can't accept this idea. In their eyes, it means negligence; they have to always be doing something, because that's the only way they can feel at peace. This mentality is a kind of 'strategy-based anxiety,' and you see it when people forget that there's always another side to any action - there's always a trade-off, there's always risk, and there's always something lost. In reality, not making a move doesn't mean that you're being negligent.

Rather, it means that you're building yourself up and waiting for the opportune moment. In the War of the Three Kingdoms, Zhuge Liang was constantly doing things. It could fairly be said that he kept making moves even when the odds of victory were absolutely 'zero,' and in the end he wore himself out so badly that he died of exhaustion.

He should have waited for opportunities, and he should have worked out and kept his body healthy. There are two good reasons for doing this: 1) He would have lived longer; 2) He could have governed better, made his nation rich and powerful, and taught his son the lessons he needed to be well-prepared to carry on his legacy. But, like so many others, Zhuge Liang thought he couldn't afford to wait.

And what happens when you can't wait? Sima Yi lived longer than any of the other major players: he outlived Zhuge Liang, he outlived Cao Cao, and he even outlived Cao Cao's son and successor, Cao Pi. With no one left to stand in his way, Sima Yi's state of Jin took control of all three kingdoms.

That's why the second strategy is 'waiting.' It's the best choice in many situations, and yet far too few people understand this. What you're waiting for is a change in circumstances - specifically, for advantageous changes in formation and force. A 'winning formation' is something that gradually builds up while you wait. It's about making it impossible for the enemy to defeat you, and gradually growing stronger.

'Winning force' is about seizing the opportunity for victory when it presents itself, and thoroughly defeating your enemy with a single blow. No one was better at waiting than Japan's Tokugawa Ieyasu, who emerged victorious from Japan's war-torn Sengoku period (1467-1615 CE).

There's an amusing story about the three major heroes of the Sengoku period: The three - Tokugawa Ieyasu, Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi - were in a park with their pet bird, but the bird wouldn't sing.

They tried to work out what to do about this. Oda Nobunaga said: ¡§If it keeps on not singing, we should just kill it and get another bird."
Toyotomi Hideyoshi said: ¡§No need to kill it - we should give it a reward if its sings, and punish it if it doesn't. It'll sing, one way or another."
Then the two men asked Tokugawa Ieyasu what he thought, and he said: ¡§There's no need to do anything.

Just wait! It's a bird, after all, and sooner or later it'll sing."
Tokugawa Ieyasu was the only one of the three who had the ability to wait, and he was also the longest-lived, so he ended up as Shogun of all Japan. His dynasty ruled Japan for the next 300 years.

Again, what are you supposed to wait for? 'Winning formation,' meaning that you're waiting for yourself to built up to a certain point? Or, 'winning force,' meaning waiting for your enemy to make a mistake?

As soon as the enemy slips up, an opportunity for victory presents itself. If the enemy doesn't slip up, there's either nothing we can do to win, or the tradeoff involved in winning would be unacceptably costly. In both cases, you're better off waiting and calculating.

And this is why we have the third strategy - can we lure the enemy into making a mistake? First, take care of your own forces. Don't kill 1,000 of the enemy's troops if it means sacrificing 800 of your own. Second, try your best not to damage the enemy's forces and assets. Don't defeat the enemy only to watch him destroy bridges, roads, cities and other infrastructure, and burn his granaries and other resources as he retreats. You need to make sure none of these things get damaged, so that they can serve you later.

Ideally, you also wouldn't kill any of the enemy's men. You can take away their will to fight if you're able to descend from the sky like lightning. They'll lay down their weapons and surrender, and they can join your army, making your forces all the more robust.

Please do not think that defending means being conservative or not trying to make progress. Defending is, in essence, a way of accumulating the means to victory. In fact, it's a way of accelerating the process!

In terms of business management, a simple analogy for these principles would be specialization versus diversification. Every time you enter a new field, you're on the attack. Conversely, any time you do a deep dive into a certain field, you're in 'protection mode.' Early in the career of Chinese businessman Wang Shi, he sold off all of his companies except for his real estate business, which he protected and ultimately nurtured into China's biggest real estate enterprise, China Vanke. On a personal level, the ability to master anything you turn your hand to comes from concentration and persistence.

Any person can become an expert in any field within five years, as long as they focus entirely on that one field. Within ten years, they can become a respected authority in the field, and within 15 they can be the best in the world.

In business, if you lock down on one thing and grow your operation into a world-class organization, you can live beyond the limits of other people's imaginations. So, 'defending' is about moving from quantitative change to qualitative change. It's a technology that can destroy your enemies without being directly connected to them in any way. Being in the 'topmost heights of heaven' means that you and your enemy are not on the same level; you're operating from a different platform.

You're not even really fighting on the same battlefield. In today's business world, every online company has to use mobile internet technology - it's the price of admission. But there's no ticket office where you can buy admission; you have to create your own version of an entrance ticket.

Every company's logic is different, and everyone is working from a different platform, on their own issues. This being so, is there any meaning in talking about 'competition?' 
So, what is competition? In essence, it's about making sure that your enemies can't compete with you.

What it's not about is trying to compete against others. This is what Sun Tzu meant when he wrote: ¡§Those who are skilled in war first make themselves undefeatable." It's also what this passage from the Tao Te Ching means: ¡§Nobody in the world can compete against one who does not engage in competition." If you reach the point where you are considering competing against someone, you have already lost. Someone whose launch-point is in the 'topmost heavens' doesn't even see themselves as competing against anyone.

The way they would see it, wherever they move, they trail a strong wind in their wake, and 'competitors' are just people who are blown over by that wind. Of course, the 'competitors' do see it as competition, and are left believing that their possessions have been snatched away.

When you are deep in the 'recesses of the earth,' you need to endure long, lonely periods of silence, and you have to be able to watch other people who attract more attention and seem better-off than you without losing your cool.

Modern examples of this include technology company Huawei's decision early on to not enter the real estate sector, and online commerce giant Alibaba's decision to hone its core capabilities instead of jumping straight into gaming. If you bide your time and gradually build and grow, when you suddenly burst onto the scene, as far as everyone else is concerned, you'll be like Sun Tzu 'flashing forth from the topmost heights of heaven.' People will want to learn from your success, and to do that they'll need to hop in a time machine and go back ten years, or even further back, to when you were in kindergarten. Basically, it'll be impossible for people to 'learn' from you.

When they look at you from outside, what they see won't be the reasons for your success, because you're already living beyond the limits of other people's imaginations. What makes a general truly wise? Normally, only the general himself knows the answer
