If the commander moves even slightly, or if his flag falls, his army's morale will evaporate and his men will run for their lives.

Of course, there are some situations where running away is necessary. ¡§First, send out a mobile battle unit to set the edges." This means that when organizing and deploying your battle units, you need to deploy one to clearly demarcate where each of the others is to be deployed. The mobile unit does this by taking each unit's unique flag and planting it in the right position.

Then, the personnel of each unit assemble by their unit's flag. ¡§Four parts constitute the main, four parts the auxiliary." This line is a reference to the legendary 'stone sentinel maze.' Contrary to popular belief, the stone sentinel maze wasn't invented by Zhuge Liang, but was in fact much earlier - 4,500 years ago, by the Yellow Emperor and his general, Feng Hou. It is also known as Feng Hou's Eight Formation Diagram.

Similarly, Writings on Grasping the Irregular is also known as Feng Hou's Writings on Grasping the Irregular. Sun Tzu's philosophy and insights represent a continuation of Feng Hou's work, as do Zhuge Liang's version of the stone sentinel maze.

Even the Tang dynasty Emperor Taizong's ambitious work of drama, Music of Prince Qin Breaking through the Enemy Array, was based on Feng Hou's Eight Formation Diagram. ¡§Disorder comes from order, fear comes from courage; weakness comes from strength."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§These forms all convey destruction, but conceal the true situation." So, disorder, fear and weakness are all just a pretense, a show put on for the enemy's benefit, and a way of hiding the real condition of your army. Show the enemy disorder where in reality there is order; show fear where there is courage, and weakness where there is strength. The reason why 'disorder comes from order' is that you must manage your army with both transparency and tight discipline if you're going to have any chance of effectively producing an illusion of chaos on the surface while still maintaining perfect order. The reason why 'fear comes from courage' is that it takes extraordinary courage to act scared enough to suck the enemy in. Finally, the reason why 'weakness comes from strength' is that you need your army to be exceptionally strong before you can feel confident enough to make a show of weakness and lure the enemy into launching an all-out attack on you.

The above forms the logic for the next passage: ¡§Order or disorder? This is a question of subdivision. Courage or fearfulness? This is a question of latent energy. Strength or weakness? This is a question of tactical dispositions."
We've already talked about the idea of 'subdivision,' which appeared in the first line of Energy: ¡§The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers." The idea is that an organization's structure is built by properly dividing human resources into well-ordered units. What determines whether your men feel scared or brave?

Basically, the answer is energy. It's about knowing how to draw a group of people around you and inspire them to fight. But, if you take a group of people to war who haven't gone through military training, how do you make them brave? Bravery comes when you put them in a place of deadly peril - a place where, if they don't fight, they'll die.

When people are put in this situation, they instantly turn into death-defying berserkers. That's exactly what Han Xin did when he put his troops in a position where they had to fight with their backs to a river. So, bravery or lack of bravery really isn't about people's personalities; it's about the broader idea of 'energy.'
Strength and weakness are about how you present yourself. When Liu Bang sent an envoy to the Xiongnu Chieftain, the shrewd Modun made sure the envoy only saw the old and weak of his camp, the sick and disabled, men and horses both.

Liu Bang fell for Modun's trick, and as a result his 300,000-strong expeditionary force was surrounded at Baideng, and Liu Bang very nearly didn't make it back home. The passage's final couple of lines give a summary: ¡§Thus one who is skillful at keeping the enemy on the move maintains deceitful appearances, according to which the enemy will act.

He sacrifices something that the enemy may snatch at it. By holding out baits, he moves him where he wills; then with a body of picked men he lies in wait for him."
So, commanders who are skilled at manipulating their foes are able to move them exactly where they want them, no matter what impression of their own forces they engineer and present to the enemy. If they give the enemy a little incentive, the enemy is bound to come after it.

Then, once the enemy has been lured in, they unleash their true military strength and meet the enemy with force. To appoint the right people, use three energies: Qi (Air) energy, Earth energy and Adaptive energy

Extract from the original text:
¡§The clever combatant looks to the effect of energy, and does not require too much from individuals. Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize energy.

When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill; but if round-shaped, to go rolling down. Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height.

This is energy."

Analysis:
¡§The clever combatant looks to the effect of combined energy, and does not require too much from individuals. Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize combined energy."
According to a common saying, the energy of a situation is a much stronger force than individual people.

The balance between victory and defeat lies in how energy is created. This is a question for commanders-in-chief to ponder, not something that can be passed off to subordinates. If something isn't done right, you can't just blame the people below you, or claim that the problem is that they didn't carry out the plan as they were supposed to. You can't pressure subordinates to get things done by themselves, because the real problem is that you didn't do a good enough job laying the groundwork.

Even if the people working for you aren't up to scratch, that's still your problem, because you didn't choose the right people. This is why exceptional leaders focus on energy, and don't blame the people working for them.

They have the ability to create the right energy, and to choose the right personnel. Du Mu comments: ¡§Skilled commanders first weigh the energy of their army, then weigh the ability of their men and assign appointments according to their strengths and weaknesses. They do not flagellate subordinates by attacking their personal lack of worthiness."
It's essentially about using the right people in the right places.

If the wrong people are used in the wrong places, the only person at fault is the leader. A good example of these principles is the story of Cao Cao's 'stratagem in a sealed envelope.'
When Cao Cao led an army to Hanzhong to fight against Zhang Yu, he left three commanders - Zhang Liao, Li Dian and Le Jin - behind to guard the city of Hefei with a garrison force of a little over 7,000 men. Just before Cao Cao left, he gave a sealed letter to Military Protector Xue Ti, with instructions to open it in the event of an enemy attack.

Not long after Cao Cao's departure, the Eastern Wu Emperor, Sun Quan, marched toward Hefei at the head of a 100,000-strong invasion force. Cao Cao's four generals took out the letter and tore it open. It read: ¡§If Sun Quan comes, Generals Zhang and Li are to lead men out into the field to fight him. General Le is to remain in Hefei and guard the city, and the Military Protector also must not go out to fight." Three of the generals were perplexed, but Zhang Liao understood what Cao Cao meant, and explained: ¡§Prime Minister Cao is away fighting. If we wait for him to come to our aid, our city will lie in ruins long before he arrives.

Prime Minister Cao is telling us to take advantage of the fact that Sun Quan's military energy is not yet fully established. We must make a quick, brief strike so as to cut away his aura of power. Then, we shall be able to successfully defend the city.

If we get this right, everything will go well. But if we don't, the only outcome for us will be defeat."
There was no delay. Li Dian and Zhang Liao, both of whom were ferocious warriors, attacked Sun Quan before his forces had a chance to get settled. Sure enough, they inflicted a shocking defeat on the Wu Emperor.

The Wu army had been banking on its aura of power, but now that was gone. When Zhang and Li returned to the city, the garrison was in high spirits and feeling very secure in their position. Sun Quan had been slapped in the face, and although he re-gathered his forces and attacked the city, after ten days he still hadn't made any gains.

So, he decided to withdraw. The historian Sun Sheng commented: ¡§War is 'The Way of Deception.' Hefei was successfully defended by a stranded army, with no reinforcements coming to their aid. If the city had been left in the hands of lion-hearted warriors, their fondness for fighting would have led to disaster.

On the other hand, if the defense had been left entirely to cowards, then their fear would have made it difficult to stand firm. But because the enemy's soldiers were far more numerous than the defenders', the enemy was bound to be vulnerable to apathy. So, fearless commanders were sent out to strike the ill-prepared enemy, and their powerful energy ensured that they would win.

First winning a victory and then returning to the defensive is a sure way to stand strong against attack! Hence, the reason why Cao Cao chose commanders with diverse temperaments - because this enabled his forces to respond to a changing situation, and ultimately everything proceeded as he had so presciently calculated."
During the reign of the Tang dynasty Emperor Taizong, his advisor and high-ranking general, Duke Li, stated that armies have three energies: qi (air) energy; earth energy; and adaptive energy. Qi energy is, above all, about personal inner power.

When you have it, other people will believe that you are powerful. Duke Li said: ¡§The general pours scorn upon the enemy, the troops delight in fighting, one's aspirations tower up into the sky, and one's qi becomes as powerful as a whirlwind; this is what is meant by qi energy." Duke Li is saying that you should strategically show contempt for your enemy, while still taking him very seriously in terms of planning the details of battle tactics. If you do this, he asserts, you will create a powerful aura, and this aura will turn into true power, as real as a raging mountain river.

We have all experienced, whether in our work or in negotiations, the crucial importance of qi energy. It is the essence of authority. If a person immediately backs away three yards when they first see you, you have a three-yard advantage before you've even started.

We sometimes see celebrities leveraging their star status to get away with acting in outrageous ways, and people let them get away with it because they feel they have to submit to celebrities' qi energy.

Mark Twain's short story, The Million Pound Bank Note, is about how possessing a million-pound note enables you to eat, drink and live for free. This, too, is qi energy at work. Qi energy isn't all empty air.

It's very real, and that's because it's actually the product of accumulated strength. You can't effectively pretend to be strong when you're not. For example, the reason Twain's million-pound bank note had such power was because it was real.

It could never have had the same effect if it was fake. Every successful figure has a sense of how their own qi energy changes as their success grows. It truly isn't an empty notion - the more social recognition you get, the stronger your qi energy grows; everything starts to go your way, and you become virtually invincible. Qi power requires a solid foundation of actual, real strength.

This is vital. Next, it requires other people to be convinced that you have it; they have to be overwhelmed by your qi power. Otherwise, you'll have to fight them head-to-head. Moving on, what is 'earth energy?' Duke Li writes: ¡§A small path through a narrow mountain pass, so narrow that a single soldier could hold it against a thousand, stopping them from passing. This is 'earth energy.'" Hence the Chinese saying used to describe the most ideal circumstances possible: 'When the Heavenly timing is good, when the land is favourable, and when the people are in harmony.' In that way, 'earth energy' is about controlling all of the best terrain - having this advantage is like holding all the aces in a game of cards. No matter how talented your opponent is, they just won't be able to compete with you.

So, how do you make sure the aces end up in your hand? You have to take them before anyone else realizes how valuable they are. The land, or 'earth,' that you want has always been there, waiting, just like the aces have always been waiting in the deck of cards. They belong to whoever claims them.

The key is to know which cards are the aces. A good example is when Zhuge Liang lost control of the Jieting region. Jieting was an ace card; it embodied 'earth energy.' Whoever held Jieting also possessed earth energy. Without it, their earth energy dissipates.

Once Zhuge Liang lost his earth energy, no amount of fighting would do him any good. Retreat was his only option. The third type of energy is 'adaptive energy.' This is about adapting to the enemy's situation and energy, and taking advantage of the situation in front of you. Duke Li writes: ¡§Adaptive energy is when the enemy is lax, when his soldiers are hungry and thirsty, his vanguard forces have not yet made camp, and when his rear forces are halfway through a river crossing." We've already talked about the story of Cao Cao's 'stratagem in a sealed envelope.' This plan worked because he knew that Sun Quan commanded massive numerical superiority, and that there was a potential advantage for him in this. When a large army on the march reaches its destination, the natural thing for its commander to do is to wait until all of his troops are fully assembled and settled before launching an attack.

This is exactly the situation Sun Quan was in: his 'vanguard forces had not yet made camp' and 'his rear forces were halfway through a river crossing.' Cao Cao knew how to take advantage of the situation.

His forces delivered a stinging blow straight to Sun Quan's face, immediately puncturing his opponent's momentum, deflating his aura of power, and at the same time strengthening their own aura. So, adaptive energy is about being fluid and finding gaps to exploit; it's about opening and closing, manipulating the enemy, and being prepared to strike hard whenever the enemy's changing situation allows.

¡§When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill, but if round-shaped, to go rolling down."

Cao Cao comments that 'utilizing energy' is about 'utilizing natural energy' - moving with the natural flow. To do this, you first have to shape and design the 'natural conditions.' This means putting the right people in the right places.

If you can do that, everything will go your way, organically and naturally. Think of people as logs and stones: heir shapes and natures are unchanging, so if you put them in a place of safety, they will be safe.

If you put them in a place of danger, they will be in danger and unable to get out of danger's way, because they are inert and cannot move under their own power. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Logs and stones are heavy objects, but though it is difficult to shift them with force, it is easy to move them with energy." If you try to move a tree trunk or a boulder just using brute force, you'll find you can't make them budge even an inch. However, if you place them on top of a mountain, then by using the mountain's energy rather than muscle-power, a light nudge can send them crashing down with incredible power.

What about armies? ¡§No matter how large an army is, it can fight through the use of energy, but it cannot be maneuvered using brute force. This is The Way of Nature."
When Han Xin led his force of 10,000 against an enemy army numbering 200,000, every single one of his troops fought like untethered wild men. They did so because Han Xin exploited energy rather than putting responsibility on his men's shoulders.

That energy came from the fact that the only way out of fighting was to jump into a watery grave at the bottom of a river. The troops' only option was to fight for their lives. In the Battle of Fei River, Fu Jian commanded a truly colossal army against his enemy's 80,000. Yet, despite having a policy of executing runaways, he was powerless to stop his troops from fleeing the battlefield.

This is because the circumstantial energy was different: his men had an escape route available to them, and they took it. As for the officers, who were supposed to be executing the runaways, they had their hands full dealing with the onslaught of enemy troops. There's a reason why when generals surround a city in a siege, they often leave one side open so that the enemy troops have somewhere to run. It's about managing the energy, and making sure that you don't put the enemy in a position where they have to fight for their lives.

It's much easier to annihilate an enemy army if you can force them to run for their lives and attack them as they flee. This way, you can also avoid fighting a costly battle in which you might lose 800 of your own men for every 1,000 enemy soldiers you kill.

To really put the cherry on the cake, you can position an irregular force somewhere along the enemy's escape route, ready to ambush them as they flee. ¡§Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height. This is energy."

Sun Tzu finishes off his fifth chapter, Energy, with a short conclusion. He summarizes the meaning of energy: when a round stone is rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height, who can stand in its way?

'Potential energy' is a term we've all come across in physics class. It's expressed in the formula mgh (mass x acceleration due to gravity x height). The potential energy of a round stone on top of a mountain is equivalent to its weight multiplied by the height of the mountain. When the stone begins to roll down the mountainside, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy, which is calculated with the formula 1/2mv2 (the square of mass x speed/2). The higher the mountain, the faster the speed of the stone.

Nobody can stop it once it's rolling. Du Mu comments: ¡§A stone rolling down a high mountain cannot be stopped; this is not because of the stone, but because of the mountain. When soldiers have the courage to win a hundred battles, the question of whether they are strong or weak is not decided by themselves, but by energy." Basically, it's all about where you position things. In Wang Xi's commentary, he writes that stones are incapable of rolling by themselves; what makes them unstoppable is the energy of the mountain.

Similarly, in war you can't force victory, because military energy is not something that can be strong-armed into existence. So, what makes a skillful leader is their ability to exploit energy, not people.

Once they've exploited energy, then they appoint the right people to the right positions. Su Tzu said: ¡§The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers.

Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals. To ensure that your whole host may withstand the brunt of the enemy's attack and remain unshaken - this is affected by maneuvers regular and irregular. That the impact of your army may be like a grindstone dashed against an egg - this is effected by the science of weak points and strong. In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory.

Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more.

There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard. There are not more than five primary colors, yet in combination they produce more hues than can ever been seen.

There are not more than five cardinal tastes, yet combinations of them yield more flavors than can ever be tasted. In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers.

The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle - you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination? The onset of troops is like the rush of a torrent, which will even roll stones along in its course.

The quality of decision is like the well-timed swoop of a falcon, which enables it to strike and destroy its victim. Therefore the good fighter will be terrible in his onset, and prompt in his decision. Energy may be likened to the bending of a crossbow; decision, to the releasing of a trigger. Amid the turbulence and tumult of battle, there may be seeming disorder and yet no real disorder at all; amid confusion and chaos, your soldiers move in circles, yet they cannot be defeated.

Disorder comes from order, fear comes from courage; weakness comes from strength. Order or disorder? This is a question of subdivision; Courage or fearfulness? This is a question of latent energy; Strength or weakness?

This is a question of tactical dispositions. Thus one who is skillful at keeping the enemy on the move maintains deceitful appearances, according to which the enemy will act. He sacrifices something that the enemy may snatch at it.

By holding out baits, he moves him where he wills; then with a body of picked men he lies in wait for him. The clever combatant looks to the effect of energy, and does not require too much from individuals.

Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize energy. When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill, but if round-shaped, to go rolling down. Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height.
This is energy."

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The enemy has weak and strong points, and so do you

Don't try to 'fix' your weak points. Instead, learn how to fight as you are - weaknesses, strengths and all. Learn to not try to fix all of your problems, but to keep moving forward, even in the midst of those problems. When you learn how to do this, you will have mastered the essence of 'weak points and strong.'

Extract from the original text:
¡§Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted."

Analysis:
Let's start by talking about what 'weak points and strong' are. Du Mu comments: ¡§In war, generals invariably seek to avoid the enemy's strong points and strike his weak points.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The first thing a general must do is to decipher the weak and strong points, both of the enemy and of their own forces."
No matter how thoroughly you prepare your defenses, there will always be a weakness somewhere, and it will be exposed. But, this also means that the enemy has weak points, and you can find ways to expose them as well.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: You can even find ways to engineer new weaknesses in the enemy forces. Then, you can attack the enemy's weak points while steering clear of their strong points. The last two chapters, and this one, are all about how wars are fought, and they follow a logical progression: In Formation, Sun Tzu talks about winning first and fighting later; in Energy, he talks about how armies are to be deployed and split into main and auxiliary forces, with the main force used to start battles and the auxiliary force used to win them. Now, in Weak Points and Strong, he talks about avoiding the enemy's strong points and striking where they're weak.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The point to keep in mind in this chapter is that both you and your enemy have weak and strong points. Is it possible to make yourself strong in every area; to cover all your bases and have not a single weakness?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: No, that would be impossible. If you try to make yourself as strong as possible in every area, then inevitably every part of your defenses will be flawed, because there are limits to resources, and similarly there are limits to people's energy and concentration. There's a line later on in Weak Points and Strong that reads: ¡§Should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak." It's impossible to have all the good things fall into your lap, and yet people are willing to believe that that they can indeed have all the good things, because this is a highly appealing idea.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: So, we often entertain wishful thinking. A useful anecdote on this point is the Wooden Bucket Theory: the amount of water a wooden bucket can hold is determined by the length of the bucket's shortest stave. If we want our bucket to hold more water, we have to lengthen the shortest stave.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: It would be completely useless to try to lengthen the longest stave, because no matter how long it may be, the water will only go as high as the shortest stave before spilling on the ground. To put it in Sun Tzu's language, your longest stave is your 'strong point,' and your shortest stave is your 'weak point.' Where does success come from - lengthening your longest stave? No.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: To be successful, you have to lengthen your shortest stave. There's no getting around your weak points; you have to acknowledge them, and you have to acknowledge that you are not a god, but human, and that you are prone to all the traits that come as part of being human.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Then there's all the nonsense that we learn from a young age, ideas that would have us deny that we are actually human. In Chinese, there's a phrase that's a good example of this: 'Have what other's don't; when others can do something, do it better than them; when others are better than you at something, do it faster than them; when others are faster than you, then transform.' How is this supposed to be possible? This whole idea assumes that you're not human but a god, while the 'others' are mere mortals.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: And if it were actually possible to put this idea into practice, then the art of war would be irrelevant. You wouldn't need to learn about 'avoiding the enemy's strong points and striking him where he's weak.' You could just attack whichever part of the enemy's' forces you feel like, using whichever part of your own forces you feel like, because whatever you chose to do, it would be like hitting an egg with a rock. The enemy would shatter on impact.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The idea that you can just be better than everyone else by sheer force of will is madness. In the real world of actual military strategy, there is a fundamental principle: 'I have what the enemy doesn't, and what the enemy has, I don't.'
When we were looking at the idea of 'If you know the enemy and you know yourself, then you can fight a hundred battles without fear of losing,' we talked about how the main problem we have is that we don't know ourselves, and not that we don't know the enemy. It's quite easy to focus more on other people while forgetting to be mindful of ourselves.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: We think, 'Of course I know myself,' but in fact the person we know least tends to be ourselves. Similarly with 'weak points and strong,' we can't just focus on other people's weaknesses and strengths while assuming that we've effectively strengthened ourselves on every front. We'd be wrong to think that; no matter what you do, you will always have both strengths and weaknesses, and it's impossible to patch up all your weaknesses. If you think you've patched up all your weaknesses, every one of those patches is in fact a weakness.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Don't try to 'fix' your weak points. Instead, learn how to fight as you are... weaknesses, strengths and all. Learn not to try to fix all of your problems, but to keep moving forward, even while surrounded by difficulties. When you learn how to do this, you will have mastered the essence of 'weak points and strong.'
Sun Tzu said: ¡§Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will arrive exhausted."
When you arrive at the battlefield before the enemy, your troops and horses will be well rested and full of energy. Not only that, you'll also have the pick of the best terrain, meaning that you can wait for the enemy to arrive knowing that you've already secured advantageous 'earth energy.' 
But when you arrive after the enemy, the best terrain will already be occupied by your foe.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: And, you'll likely get no rest after your long, tiring journey, but be forced to fight immediately. You're making your job much harder for yourself when you arrive after the enemy. To rephrase this idea in a more relatable context, it's like going on a business trip to meet a client, and then having to sit through a two-hour meeting.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: For the client sitting in their office waiting for you to arrive, all they need to do is set aside two hours from their day. Meanwhile, you have to catch a flight to the client's city, and check in and out of a hotel, and by the time you get back home, the whole process has taken two full days of your time. Our historical example for this passage comes from the war between the Later Zhou dynasty and the Northern Qi.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The Later Zhou army moved to attack, but the Northern Qi commander, Duan Shao, held a defensive position inside his city walls. There had been heavy snowfall that day, and snow lay deep on the ground. The Later Zhou commander had sent a vanguard infantry force toward the city, moving in from the west. Northern Qi scouts informed their commander and his generals that the enemy army was now within two li of the city. All of the generals were eager to march out and fight in the open, but Commander Duan Shao reasoned against this: ¡§Infantry troops have limited energy reserves, and it's extremely tiring to trudge through snow as deep as there is today. If we charge out now, the snow will make it hard for us, too.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The better option is to deploy our soldiers in battle formation and wait for the enemy; thus, the enemy will be exhausted but we will be fresh. Victory will surely be ours." Sure enough, the Northern Qi forces crushed the Later Zhou army that day, wiping out their vanguard infantry forces and routing their rear forces. Creating a home field advantage

Extract from the original text:
¡§Therefore the clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy's will to be imposed on him."

Analysis:
'Imposing one's will on the enemy' is about making the enemy come to you.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: 'Allowing the enemy's will to be imposed' on oneself means that the enemy has caused you to come to them. 'The clever combatant' has the ability to manipulate the enemy, while not allowing the enemy to manipulate them.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: During the Eastern Han dynasty, a general named Fei Yi, who was in the service of the rebel commander Zhang Bu, sent his younger brother, Fei Gan, to hold a defensive position in the city of Juli. A commander of the Han imperial army, Geng Yan, moved in close to Juli and made ready to attack the city. He cut down a large number of trees, and let it be known that he planned to use them to fill in the city's moat, after which he would attack. Several days later, Geng Yan's forces captured a rebel soldier, who informed them that Fei Yi had heard Geng Yan was planning to attack Juli, and was preparing to come to his younger brother's rescue. When Geng Yan heard this, he loudly ordered his troops to ready their weapons and prepare for battle in three days' time. Then, he had his guards 'accidentally' let the enemy prisoner escape.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The prisoner made his way to Fei Yi's camp, and told him about Geng Yan's plans. Sure enough, Fei Yi ordered his forces to move out; he was coming to rescue his brother. But Geng Yan was ready; he left 3,000 troops to keep Juli surrounded, while with the bulk of his forces he personally orchestrated an ambush against Fei Yi. Geng Yan won a crushing victory that day, and executed Fei Yi. This is a classic strategy: besieging a city in order to manipulate the enemy into sending a relief force, and then ambushing that relief force while it's still on the road.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When I manipulate my enemy and cause him to come to me and fight, then he will always be in a position of weakness; if I do not travel to attack the enemy, then I will always be in position of strength. This is the art of using the strength and weakness of the enemy and of myself." It's about putting yourself in a position of strength, and the enemy in a position of weakness.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Du You comments: ¡§When two armies are far away from one another, they are equal in weak points and strong. The enemy may come to me and thus imperil himself, but I may not imperil myself by going to him."
Zeng Guofan also wrote his own, brief explanation of the idea of 'imposing one's will on the enemy and not allowing the enemy's will to be imposed' on oneself. ¡§It is delightful to be the host, but not at all delightful to be the visitor." This is the concept of the home field advantage, exactly the same as in soccer matches.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The visitors start with a 30% handicap. So, it's important to come up with a way to position yourself in a 'home field' position, and make sure your enemy is forced to play the role of the 'visiting team.'

Don't get carried away by your emotions; the art of war can be used to do all kinds of things, but the moment you get carried away, it all goes out the window

Don't be greedy. Greediness in a person makes them easy to trick.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Don't believe that some things are too important to ever let go of, because this makes you liable to being baited by your enemy. Except for your own life, everything is expendable. Extract from the original text:
¡§By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord; or, by inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out; if quietly encamped, he can force him to move."

Analysis:
What is this chapter, Weak Points and Strong, about? According to Cao Cao, it's about ¡§the ability to navigate the strengths and weaknesses of both yourself and your enemy." In other words, it tells us that both sides in a conflict have strengths and weaknesses, and that it's important in war to use your strong points to strike the enemy's weak points.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
To do this, you need to manipulate the enemy into moving where you want him, turning his strong points into weak points. ¡§The clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy's will to be imposed on him."

Make the enemy come to you.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Make them play the role of the 'visiting team,' while you enjoy the advantage of playing in your 'home field.' How do you go about doing this? You do it by 'holding out advantages to him' - in other words, by finding a way to tempt him.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: When General Li Mu of the state of Zhao took up his border garrison command, the first thing he did was build up his fortifications and evacuate the surrounding countryside. He closed his gates and refused to come out and fight for ten years, forcing the Xiongnu chieftain to hold his breath and wait. Finally, Li Mu chose a day to emerge from behind his walls and lay out bait for the enemy, in the form of several thousand troops sent out to 'fight a battle' against the Xiongnu. When Li Mu's suicide force was defeated, their oxen and sheep were scattered across the countryside, and this temptation proved too much for the Xiongnu chieftain, who had been starved of plunder for ten years. Swept up in uncontrollable excitement, he forgot all about the art of war, and led his entire army out to pluck up Li Mu's lost livestock.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Meanwhile, Li Mu had set an ambush. On that day, Li Mu wiped out 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. The Xiongnu were so badly beaten that they didn't dare show their faces again for years afterward. This is an example of 'holding out advantages.' But why did the Xiongnu chieftain fall for such a simple trick? He must have just been too excited.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: After all, he'd been waiting for a chance like this for ten whole years! Ten years without stealing so much as a single sheep, and without fighting a single battle! After all that time, the chieftain would have been on the verge of losing his mind.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
We know that people are prepared to die for a chance to get rich, just as birds are prepared to die in pursuit of their next meal. He couldn't help himself; he saw a prize waiting for him to grab, and he lost control of himself. ¡§By inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near."

If you don't want to make your enemy come to you, or if you want to move him away from the battlefield, you'll need to attack something that he is bound to want to protect, and inflict damage where it's bound to make him anxious.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If you do this, the enemy's anxiety will cause him to lose all concern for himself, and focus entirely on protecting whatever it is he considers so precious. A classic example of this principle from Chinese military history is a Warring States period story of how the Zhao city of Handan, under siege by a Wei army, was saved by an allied Qi army. When the Wei commander Pang Juan attacked the state of Zhao, the state of Qi sent Commander Sun Bin with an army to the rescue.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But, instead of rushing to join the fray at the besieged Zhao city, Sun Bin headed directly toward the Wei capital city, Daliang, and put the city under seige. With Daliang under attack, the Wei army couldn't hang around at Handan; they had to pull back and relieve their capital city.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: And so, suddenly, the siege of Handan was broken. Sun Bin's next move was a textbook example of the strategy of 'setting up a siege to destroy the relief force.' He devised an ambush for the returning Wei army, positioning himself in a home field advantage and forcing the Wei army into the role of the 'visiting team.' He successfully made himself strong and the enemy weak, himself fresh and the enemy exhausted, and in the battle that followed the Wei army was battered.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Commander Pang Juan died in the fight. ¡§If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him."

The point is to be in a situation where you're fresh and well rested, but the enemy is exhausted. If, at the starting point, both you and your enemy are well rested, you need to come up with a way to exhaust him; you need to keep him so busy that he doesn't have time to think. During the Spring and Autumn period conflict between the states of Wu and Chu, the Wu general Wu Zixu put together three separate forces, with the express intention of using them for 'harassment missions.' With much fanfare, he marched out to attack Chu at the head of one of those forces, but once the entire Chu army had been mobilized to fend him off, he retreated back home to Wu. Then, he waited until the Chu army had been disbanded and sent home, and immediately moved again to attack Chu, this time at the head of the second of his forces.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He kept using this tactic to harass Chu, to the point that their leaders were unable to think straight, and he managed to do this without fighting a single battle. Then, with deadly speed, he mobilized all three of his forces, and this time he attacked for real, sacking the Chu capital city. This was the first time in the Spring and Autumn period that a state had successfully attacked the capital city of another state.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: This same tactic was used by the Sui dynasty to defeat the rival state of Chen. Every time that the crops were just ready for harvest in the Chen territory, the Sui dynasty leaders deployed their armies and pretended they were about to attack. Then, they waited until the state of Chen had finished frantically mobilizing its forces to face the Sui threat, before standing down.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
They repeated this over and over, until the people of Chen were physically and mentally spent. ¡§If well supplied with food, he can starve him out."

This is about finding a way to use hunger against your enemy. We just spoke about how the Sui dynasty harassed its rival, the state of Chen, and in fact, hunger was also a part of the Sui strategy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The state of Chen was located south of the Yangzi River, where the climate is warm and damp, and where most of the houses are made of thatch. Food was hung up inside these houses for storage, rather than kept in the relative safety of underground cellars.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: So, the Sui leaders dispatched several raiding squads to roam the Chen territories and set fire to settlements, using the prevailing winds to their advantage. The people of Chen would build new houses, but then their Sui tormenters would come again and burn them down once more.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: This left the people with nothing - starving and utterly destitute. Years later, in the final days of the Sui dynasty, General Yuwen Huaji, who had just engineered a coup, led his army to attack another Sui general named Li Mi. But, Li Mi knew that Yuwen Huaji didn't have much grain, so he pretended to sue for peace, claiming that he was no match for his adversary.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Yuwen Huaji was delighted, and was content to wait while preparations were made for a peace treaty to be signed. In reality, Li Mi was just playing for time, waiting for Yuwen Huaji's army to run out of food. Yuwen Huaji didn't bother rationing his supplies, because he believed he'd soon be able to feed his men from Li Mi's granaries. Once his food was gone, though, he found that Li Mi suddenly wasn't quite as peaceful as he'd seemed.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Soldiers need to eat, and Yuwen Huaji's men soon went over to Li Mi's side, and so he lost. ¡§If quietly encamped, he can force him to move."

Cao Cao says: ¡§Attack whatever the enemy will be compelled to protect, appear where he will compelled to meet you; this is how to force the enemy to launch a relief action."
When one of Cao Cao's generals, Sima Yi, led an expedition to Liaodong to attack a rebellious general named Gong Sunxiao, Gong Sunxiao deployed his forces along the Liao River, blocking Sima's way forward. Sima Yi had no intention of fighting Gong by the river, and he told his generals in a meeting: ¡§Our foe's encampment is strong and well fortified, and it is his intention to tire us out.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
If we attack him here, we will be doing just as he has planned. We must attack him elsewhere, somewhere that he will be compelled to protect, so that we can force his men to leave their camp."
Sima Yi made a big show of strength close to the enemy, while secretly sending part of his army around the enemy's defenses and behind their lines to besiege Gong Sunxiao's base, the city of Xiangping. Gong Sunxiao was left with no choice but to leave his front-line camp and fight out in the open.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Sima Yi crushed his army, executed him and restored stability to the Liaodong region. But, if you look at this situation in terms of the results - Gong Sunxiao was executed - there wasn't actually any need for him to rescue Pingxiang.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Liaodong is a land of brutally cold winters. If Gong Sunxiao had hunkered down in his fortified camp, and pulled grain and people from the surrounding countryside inside his gate, it wouldn't have mattered if all his cities had been burned to the ground.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He could have stayed safe, far away from the cities, wait for winter to come and for Sima Yi to run out of food and pull his forces back. And then, Gong Sunxiao could have attacked him as he retreated.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If he'd done this, he would have had a chance of holding on to power in Liaodong. In fact, this is exactly how the people of Korea were able to survive for thousands of years as an independent nation without being annexed, even though it sits right at the edge of China.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: So, in conclusion, don't get carried away. The art of war can be used to do all kinds of things, but the moment you get carried away, it all goes out of the window. Don't be greedy. Greediness in a person makes them easy to trick. Don't believe that some things are too important to ever let go of, because this makes you liable to being baited by your enemy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Except for your own life, everything is expendable. Don't do things your own way without caring what people think; Do things your own way, but do it in a way that people don't expect; Don't let people know what you're doing

Extract from the original text:
¡§Appear at points which the enemy will not be quick enough to defend; march swiftly to places where you are not expected. An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended. You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked."

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Compel the enemy to mount a relief effort."
We often talk about how people should walk their own paths, and not worry about what other people say. But, from the perspective of Sun Tzu's The Art of War, this is not best way to do things.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Instead, he suggests, walk your own path in a way that other people would never expect, and don't let others know what you're doing. ¡§An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not."

There are two classic examples from Chinese military history that shed light on this passage, and both come from armies that conquered the kingdom of Shu, in modern-day Sichuan Province. One of these examples is well known in China, because a fictionalized version of it forms part of the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: It comes from the story of how Zhong Hui and Deng Ai conquered Shu. Deng Ai, taking advantage of the fact that the Shu commander Jiang Wei was boxed in at Sword Gate Pass by Zhong Hui, led a force east from Yinping along the Jinggu Path. He cut south through the mountains and emerging in Shu territory, over 200 li away from Sword Gate Pass.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He'd led his troops on a perilous journey through difficult terrain, building bridges and walkways along sheer cliffs as he went. For over 700 li, his forces moved in single file through uninhabited wilderness, a dangerous land of soaring peaks and deep canyons. Throughout Deng's journey, he had no access to food resupplies, and he often found himself in seriously dangerous situations. At one point, having arrived at a place called Horse Pavilion Mountain, he discovered that the way ahead was impassable.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: For a moment, it seemed he was stuck, unable to move forward or backward, but he eventually came up with a solution. He wrapped himself in felt and rolled down the mountain slope, ahead of his men. Finally, Deng Ai led his troops out into the Sichuan Basin, taking the enemy by surprise and making straight for the city of Jiangyou. Once there, he forced the garrison commander, Ma Miao, to surrender. Then, Deng Ai cut a bloody path all the way to the Shu capital city of Chengdu, at which point the Shu Emperor, Liu Chan, surrendered. Our second example comes from the Northern and Southern Dynasties period (420-589 CE). The Prince of Wuling, Xiao Ji, had gained control of Sichuan (Shu), installed himself in the city of Chengdu, and declared himself Emperor. The ambitious Xiao Ji had designs to attack Emperor Yuan of Liang and seize control of the Liang territories.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Meanwhile, the Northern Wei dynasty leaders saw an opportunity. The head of the Northern Wei military, Yu Wentai, thought that the time was ripe to gain control of both Shu and Liang. But, the other Northern Wei generals couldn't come to an agreement. So, Yu Wentai entrusted one of them, Yuchi Jiong, to take control of the mission. When Yu asked Yuchi what his plan was, he replied: ¡§The lands of Shu have been isolated from the central Chinese territories for over a hundred years.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: They are surrounded by dangerous mountains and rivers, so the Shu leaders will not expect me to attack. The best plan is to attack with an elite armored cavalry force, moving quickly and at night. We will travel at double speed in places where the road is easy, and when we encounter dangerous roads, we will slow our pace and advance more gradually.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Thus, we will take the enemy by surprise and strike straight to his heart. He will surely be unable to defend against us if we attack in this way."
And that is exactly what happened. Yuchi Qiong entered Shu through Sanguan Pass, besieged Chengdu, and took the city within 50 days, enabling him to take full control of the Shu territories. ¡§You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended."

There's a mantra that people often repeat: 'Fight when there is no possible outcome other than victory; attack where there is no possible outcome other than overwhelming the enemy's defenses.' But this is impossible, because it's not just your slogan; your enemy will have it posted all over his walls, too.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The only situation in which these words can become a reality is if the enemy hasn't made defensive preparations. Using soccer as an example again, it's no easy thing to score a goal when there are defenders in front of you, even if you're as talented as Argentine superstar Diego Maradona.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: To score, you first have to maneuver back and forth, wait until your opponent takes the foot off the gas, and then shoot. Our next military example comes once again from Geng Yan's campaign to put down Zhang Bu's rebellion during the Eastern Han dynasty.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Zhang Bu had ordered his younger brother, Zhang Lan, to hold a defensive position in the city of Xi'an, and he sent another of his generals to defend the city of Linzi. Meanwhile, Geng Yan marched his army towards Xi'an, and set up camp 40 li outside of the city. Studying the city's defenses, Geng saw that although Xi'an's walls were small, they were sturdy, and manned by experienced troops under the command of Zhang Lan. Linzi, on the other hand, though protected by high city walls, would be a much easier target to attack. So, Geng Yan made up his mind to attack Linzi instead. To do this, he had to convince the enemy that he was planning to attack Xi'an, so he used the same trick he'd used to such good effect before.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He ordered his men to build siege weapons, and let it be widely known that he was planning to attack Xi'an. Then, he 'accidentally' let some captive enemy soldiers escape, so that they would go back to their commanders with news of his fake plans. When Zhang Lan heard, he began intensive preparations to ward off Geng Yan's coming attack. At midnight the day before Geng Yan had said he would attack Xi'an, he called his officers from their beds to eat with him, and announced that they would be marching straight for Linzi. The officers didn't come around immediately, and argued that they should attack Xi'an instead. But Geng Yan reasoned with them that Xi'an had strong walls, elite soldiers and watertight defenses, whereas Linzi was undefended. Geng Yan told them that the enemy would never expect them to suddenly show up at Linzi's city walls; with their enemies shell-shocked, they could take the city within a single day. Then, once Linzi had fallen, Xi'an would be within their reach.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
So, they'd be killing two birds with one stone. Geng Yan put his plan in motion, and the events that followed happened exactly as he'd said they would. ¡§You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked."

If you want to guarantee that you'll be able to hold your ground against enemy attacks, you need to prepare solid defenses even in places where the enemy is not attacking. When the enemy attacks you in the east, it's possible that he's just bluffing, and that his real attack will come from the west.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: So, what happens if you haven't set up proper defenses in your western positions? Well, something like what happened in the example above. Geng Yan wanted to capture Xi'an, so Zhang Bu didn't bother properly defending Linzi, which led to Linzi falling into Geng Yan's hands. Earlier on, during the Western Han dynasty (206 BCE-9 CE), there was a major uprising called the Rebellion of the Seven States.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The commander of the Han imperial forces, Zhou Yafu, was holding a defensive position in the city of Changyi. The rebel army attacked swiftly, heading straight for the southeastern section of the city walls, but Zhou Yafu made sure to position a large part of his troops near the northwestern section of the walls. Before long, the rebel army did indeed send its best troops to attack from the northwest. However, because Zhou Yafu had set up strong defenses, the rebels couldn't break through.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
With the rebels forced to abandon their attack, Zhou Yafu pursued them as they retreated and inflicted a massive defeat on them. At its most refined, 'Weak points and strong' is about appearing and disappearing like a ghost, Holding your destiny and your enemy's destiny in the palm of your hand

Extract from the original text:
¡§Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy's fate in our hands."

Analysis:
¡§Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack."
Being good at attacking means making your enemy unsure where to defend, and being good at defending means making your enemy unsure where to attack. Cao Cao gives us a very simple comment on this point: ¡§It is about not leaking intelligence." In other words, don't let the enemy know what your army is doing.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
When attacking, if the enemy has no idea where you're going to attack, he won't know how to defend. He'll expend a lot of effort working out what you're doing, and then he'll set up defenses, only for you to feint left and strike right. In Chinese, this stratagem is known as 'luring the tiger out of its mountain lair.'
When defending, if the enemy can't work out where your weak and strong points are positioned, he will be unable to come up with an effective attack plan.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He'll put a lot of effort into working out where the gaps in your armor are, only to fall into your ambush when he tries to attack. This is the principle (the Dao) of 'weak points and strong.' If you want to win, you need to avoid the enemy's strong points and strike his weak points. You need to make sure the enemy can't find your weak points, so that each time he thinks he's figured you out, and attacks, he runs straight into your strongest point, like hitting a brick wall.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Meanwhile, when you attack, you need to always manipulate the enemy into exposing the gaps in his fortifications. Once you've done this, burst through as quickly as possible and liquefy his entire position.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
If you can do all this, you will have almost supernatural abilities. ¡§Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy's fate in our hands."

The Dao of 'weak points and strong' truly is extraordinary. It empowers you to attack like a lightning bolt from a cloudless sky, and to defend like a mole hiding deep underground.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: With 'weak points and strong,' you can appear and disappear at will, wrap your enemy around your finger, and put him entirely at your mercy. This is how to take control of your enemy's fate. In the original Chinese text, in the sentence translated as ¡§And hence we can hold the enemy's fate in our hands," Sun Tzu says that you will be like the underworld god in charge of people's fates. In Waging War, the second chapter of The Art of War, he also says: ¡§Thus it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter (god in charge) of the people's fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril." The general who knows his men is like a god to the people of his country, and he holds their fates in his hand; what he does will decide whether they live or die. Here, in Chapter Six, Sun Tzu takes it a step further by talking about how to become the arbiter of your enemy's fate, and taking control of whether your enemy lives or dies.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He Shi comments: ¡§Sun Tzu is here discussing the art of weak points and strong. It is divine in its subtlety, and it has the ultimate efficacy in achieving success. With it, I can make my strong points seem weak to my enemy, and my weak points seem strong.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Where the enemy is strong, I can manipulate and move him, so that he becomes weak. Where the enemy is weak, I can perceive his lack of strength. In summary, my enemy cannot see my weak and strong points, but I can see everything about his weak and strong points in a single glance. ¡§When I am preparing to attack the enemy, I know where his defenses are strong and where they are inadequate and weak, so I can avoid his strong points and attack him where he is fragile. When the enemy wants to attack me, I know that when he makes a great deal of noise and fuss about attacking a certain position, that position will certainly not be his main focus; rather, the place I actually should fortify with additional troops is wherever he has not yet attacked. ¡§I show the enemy my weak points, but attack him with my strong points.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If he makes a show of attacking from the east, then I should prepare to defend against him in the west. So, when I want to attack him, he doesn't know where to defend; when I want to defend against him, he cannot find a good opening to attack.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: ¡§The variables involved in attacking and defending stem from the art of using weak points and strong. I am either defending, in which case I am like a mole hiding deep underground, or I am attacking, in which case I am like a lightning bolt striking from a cloudless sky.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: I erase my tracks and thus I cannot be seen; I muffle my voice, and thus I cannot be heard. I delve into the ground and spring forth from thin air; I emerge suddenly and disappear into the space between things; I shine like the stars and move like a ghost; I enter into realms of nothingness and circle the void in the underworld. This is the subtlety of all subtleties, the divine of all divinity; the sharpest eyes in the universe cannot perceive the nuance of its forms, and the most acute ear in the universe cannot hear its divine sound.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
It has form yet it is as though without form; it makes sound yet it is as though soundless. It is not that it has no form, but that the enemy cannot see it; it is not that it makes no sound, but that the enemy cannot hear it. This is the immaculate intricacy of the variations in between weak points and strong."
This lengthy bit of commentary by He Shi basically covers all there is to say about the wondrous essence of 'weak points and strong.' But is it really so 'divine?' Actually, it really is! So, how is that you can avoid falling for the enemy's bluffs, while making the enemy fall for yours and take control of his movements into your hands?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: This is basically a question of experience and intuition. To put it in a philosophical frame, it's a question of uniting your knowledge and your actions as one, which was a major theme in the School of Mind, a movement identified with the major Neo-Confucian philosopher Wang Yangming. In ancient Chinese military circles, everyone was very familiar with Sun Tzu's The Art of War and Thirty-Six Stratagems, and even a six-year-old can understand the concept of the bluff.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But, once you're on the battlefield and your enemy is charging from the east like a thunderstorm, with dead bodies piling up before him, how do you know if he's actually planning to attack from the west?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: And what if he knows you know that he's bluffing? Won't he then just follow through on his bluff and continue his main point of attack in the east, or even change direction entirely and attack from the north and south? Here's another example question: do you know that sugar is sweet?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Of course, everyone knows that. But, if someone has never eaten sugar, how do you describe to them what sweetness is? So, though every commander in ancient China would have read The Art of War, and may even have it memorized word-for-word, how much actual knowledge you have of it is a different matter entirely.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: When people read books, they can only learn from those books to a certain extent, determined by their own limitations. If you can't map the knowledge from the books onto your own life, you don't really know what you've read.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Not only that, you don't know that you don't know what you've read, and you have the illusion that you know everything about it. General Zhao Kuo is a classic example. He was an armchair strategist, and not only did he not know what he was doing, he also didn't know that he didn't know.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Worse than that, he thought he knew everything, and this is exactly how he brought ruin on his country. So, can we know if our enemy is bluffing - feinting to the east, only to strike from the west? No!

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: That's because knowing about the concept of the bluff doesn't count as having real knowledge of it. Actual understanding only happens on real battlefields. Whether he's bluffing in the east or in the west, it doesn't really matter; it's about being able to instantly see where the enemy's weak and strong points are, and understanding where you need to position yourself. This is the meaning of unifying knowledge and action as one.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If you want to learn how to unify knowledge and action, you first have to know that you don't know. There's a Confucian saying that sages know things precisely because they don't know them, whereas small-minded people don't know things precisely because they know them. Sages know that they don't know things, which makes them cautious, alert and wary. They are good at observing, studying and asking questions, and so they are able to gain knowledge about things.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But small-minded people don't know that they don't know, and because they think they know things, they have no ability to observe, study and ask questions. This is why they don't know things. Just because we've studied the art of war doesn't mean we'll be able to win real-life battles. The act of reading books and studying is a kind of self-reflection; we mould the way we study around our real-life work, and then continue to refine this knowledge and gain more understanding of it as we apply it to our real lives and seek to improve ourselves.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
For the last part of our discussion on this passage, I'm going to talk about a story from my own personal experiences. Once, over dinner, I introduced a work partner to a good friend of mine. After we finished our dinner, my friend told me, very bluntly, that this person I'd been working with wasn't up to scratch. He told me, ¡§I can tell you exactly how much firepower this guy's working with - I can literally put a number on it." 
I was taken aback, and asked: ¡§How can you tell?" 
¡§Whenever someone has less money than me, I can tell how much money they have the moment I meet them, because I know how people act in each of the different levels of wealth. I can't tell when a person has more money than me, but I can always tell when someone has less."
This happened many years ago, but it had such an impact on me that I've always remembered it.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: As I reflected on what my friend had said, and on my own experiences, I realized that I had a similar knack. Whenever I talk business with someone who has less money than me, I always have a clear idea of how much they have, and I can actually tell quite easily when they're telling the truth and when they're faking it. This is because whatever they're talking about, I have a memory-bank of similar experiences from my own life to compare it with, and I know whether what the other person's talking about is the real thing.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Similarly, if the person I'm talking with has more experience than me, and has seen more of the world, there's no way for me to know. This is the meaning of unifying knowledge and action. It really is a mysterious thing.

Under Cao Cao's expert direction, his forces delivered a crushing defeat to Liu Biao's and Zhang Xiu's two armies, and then rapidly withdrew. Everything went exactly as Cao Cao had planned, except for one thing: he hadn't accounted for a certain, extremely talented adviser who was working for Zhang Xiu, a man named Jia Xu. chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Only then did they realize that the camp was deserted - the Song forces had retreated several days earlier. Pursuing a retreating enemy is also an important part of military tactics. It formed the core of Communist Party General Lin Biao's approach to war. His military principles included 'One point, two sides,' 'Three three's,' 'Four swifts and one slow,' and 'Three ferocities,' among others. Earlier in the book, when we were looking at 'dividing numbers,' we took a first look at Lin Biao's 'Three three's' organizational system. In his 'One point, two sides' principle, 'one point' is about shattering the enemy by concentrating your firepower on a single point, and attacking that point with maximum ferocity.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The 'two sides' are about surrounding the enemy on two sides, or more, so as to not allow him to escape. Then, you can wipe out his forces, or leave one open direction for him to run, and wipe him out while he retreats. To understand the 'Four swifts and one slow,' we should first look at the 'one slow.' It is about moving slowly as you launch your general offensive, and not making any moves unless you're fully ready. If you believe you're not ready, but you've received orders from above to hurry up the attack, you can disobey those orders.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Now let's look at the 'Four swifts': 1) When advancing on the enemy position, move swiftly; 2) Once the enemy is between your teeth, swiftly carry out necessary preparation work - surveying the terrain, building and engineering works, packing gunpowder, distributing your firepower, etc.; 3) Once you've made a breakthrough, swiftly expand your battle advantage; 4) Once you've broken the enemy and his forces are retreating, pursue them swiftly. The 'Three ferocities' are: fighting with ferocity, charging with ferocity, and pursuing with ferocity.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Concentrate on a single point, gather your strengths and attack the enemy where he is weak, and then charge and fight with ferocity. content: At this stage of battle, don't wait for orders, and don't bother making any other preparations. chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

When troop numbers are stretched thin and their battle capability weakened, it's because they're put in a passive position, forced to plan and account for their enemies. When troop numbers are kept high and battle capability strong, it's because the commander has been able to force the enemy to plan and account for them.

Therefore, he will divide his soldiers so as to guard all possible points of attack. ¡§For should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. This is the most fundamental principle, and it also applies to everything we do in our own lives.

Analysis:
¡§Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight."
If you are capable of predicting where and when a fight's going to happen, you'll be able to take the fight to the enemy, even if you've just marched 1,000 li. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Use measurements and knowledge of space to find out on what day battle will take place."
Meng Shi comments: ¡§Using measurements and knowledge of space, you can know the terrain of the battle location, as well as the time when you will encounter your enemy there.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
