If, on the other hand, the enemy arrives before you, and takes control of the best terrain, you can choose not to go, leaving the enemy with nothing to show for their efforts. Earlier on, we looked at how Wang Yangming destroyed the Prince of Ning.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: When the prince launched his uprising, he'd surrounded the city of Anqing with a large army. The reality on the ground was that, if he took Anqing, he'd be able to move unobstructed down the Yangzi River, and Nanjing would be his for the taking. As soon as he entered Nanjing, he'd have the political clout to rally more people behind him. From Wang Yangming's position, in order to put down the rebellion, he'd first have to work out where and on what day his forces would engage the Prince of Ning's army. He only had a small, hastily thrown-together army to achieve his aims, so where should the fight take place?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Well, since the prince was at that moment carrying out a ferocious assault on the city of Anqing, of course, he should save Anqing. However, if he did choose to go to Anqing, there was no guarantee that he'd be able to save the city. The Prince of Ning might actually be preparing for him to march to Anqing - it might even be his plan to use the siege as a way to lure Wang Yangming, and beat him on the road. Wang Yangming decided to gamble, but on what? His gamble was to attack the Prince of Ning's base, Nanchang, betting that the prince would abandon Anqing and rush back to save Nanchang. If Wang's gamble was right and the Prince of Ning did rush back, he'd have the chance to plan the battle location from afar. So, where should it be?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Not at Nanchang. Wang planned to catch the prince near Poyang Lake, while he was still traveling, and fight a decisive battle there. This is what it means to 'know the place and time of the coming battle.'
Was this a stroke of brilliance by Wang Yangming? Actually, he was just gambling, and it was the only thing he could do.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: There was also a potentially fatal problem with his plan: what was Wang supposed to do if the Prince of Ning didn't come back to Nanchang? If he did decide to give up Nanchang, and just continued his siege of Anqing, the city would be at serious risk of falling. If Anqing fell, Nanjing would be as good as lost, too, and the rebellious prince could march into Nanjing and proclaim himself Emperor. But, Wang Yangming bet that the Prince of Ning didn't have the wisdom or the boldness to pursue this course of action. As it happened, Wang won that bet. As soon as Wang entered Nanchang, the prince immediately called off his siege of Anqing, even though he had the place on the brink of collapse, and pulled his armies back to Nanchang.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: His bet paid off - after a fierce battle at Poyang Lake, the Prince of Ning became his prisoner. In our second historical example, Zhou Yafu, a Han dynasty Imperial general, put down a rebellion led by the Liu Pi, Prince of Wu. The prince was looking to attack the capital city, Luoyang, from the east.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: On the road west, he would have to move through the state of Liang, which had been given to Emperor Jing's younger brother, Liu Wu, the Prince of Liang. The rebel armies, from Wu and Chu, inflicted a heavy defeat on the Liang army at Jibi, in the south of Liang.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The Liang authorities sounded the alarm bells and requested imperial backup. However, Zhou Yafu was firmly ensconced in his camp, safe behind high walls and a deep moat. Every day, messengers from the Prince of Liang arrived in Zhou Yafu's camp, but Zhou Yafu obstinately refused to come to Liang's rescue. So, the Prince of Liang wrote a petition to Emperor Jing, who then sent an envoy to Zhou Yafu's camp, with orders to come to Liang's aid. But Zhou Yafu still didn't move.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He took the prerogative of the general in the field who does not always listen to his sovereign's commands. While Zhou Yafu let the Prince of Liang and the Wu armies fight a bitter war between themselves, he quietly sent a unit of light cavalry to cut the Wu and Chu supply lines. The Wu army soon was short on grain, and facing the reality of starvation.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Liu Pi knew that Zhou Yafu was behind this, so he moved to attack Zhou's camp. But Zhou stayed put behind his fortifications; he still had no intention of getting involved in a fight. As the Wu soldiers struggled to stave off starvation, their fighting capability began to weaken, and so Liu Pi decided to withdraw. Bearing in mind the tenet of 'knowing the place and the time of the coming battle,' Zhou Yafu's time had now come, and he'd chosen the location: an area of level ground in Huaibei. Because the bulk of the Wu army was infantry, fighting on level ground limited the danger for Zhou Yafu's imperial Han army, which had a higher proportion of cavalry, while also giving them an advantage - level ground is the absolute best terrain for fighting running battles. With Zhou Yafu in command, the Han army ran the rebel troops off the field and crushed the Wu forces.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: It took no longer than three months to put down the Wu and Chu uprisings, which is incredibly fast. Zhou Yafu gained widespread respect and admiration for his vision and his impeccable planning, from the Emperor to the court ministers and imperial generals.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But, there was one person who felt nothing but a deep hatred for Zhou Yafu: the Prince of Liang, Liu Wu. The prince was outraged that Zhou Yafu had essentially served him to the enemy on a plate, and left him to fight the entire war on his own, almost losing his fiefdom and his life in the process.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
From his perspective, all that Zhou Yafu did was to wait until the enemy was almost dead from starvation, and then gave them a little shove. The enemy collapsed, and the victory was chalked up entirely to Zhou Yafu's 'impeccable planning.'

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
¡§Though according to my estimate the soldiers of Yue exceed our own in number, that shall advantage them nothing in the matter of victory. I say then that victory can be achieved."

Sun Tzu's wrote The Art of War for Helu, King of Wu. The states of Wu and Yue had long been enemies, which is why Sun Tzu used Yue as the antagonist in this passage.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The story of the war between Goujian of Yue and Fuchai of Wu is a well-known cultural reference point for Chinese people - Fuchai was Helu's son. ¡§Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting."

So, victory can be engineered even if the enemy has more troops, because it's possible to put the enemy in a position where he can't fight. In Chapter Four, Formations, Sun Tzu says: ¡§One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it," which can also be interpreted as 'victory may be known, but not engineered.' And yet, here he's saying that 'victory can be achieved (engineered).' Is he contradicting himself? Actually, no, because the context is different.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He's talking about different situations in these two cases. For example, in the case of Wang Yangming's conflict with the Prince of Ning, if Wang had had enough resources, or enough time, it would have been a situation where 'victory can be known, but not engineered,' and Wang's best choice would be to fight slow and steady. But when the Prince of Ning rebelled, the imperial government was caught unprepared, and Wang was left without the backup of the imperial army.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He had to deal with the rebellious prince immediately, with only the resources already at his disposal. Wang couldn't let the prince get to Nanjing. In this situation, the only option is to make victory happen - ¡§Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting." In the end, Wang Yangming's gamble paid off. Though the Prince of Ning commanded a powerful force, Wang was able to stop him from attacking Anqing and gaining entry to Nanjing, and managed to summon him to Poyang Lake.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death. Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient."

Analysis:
¡§If you know yourself and you know your enemy, you can fight a hundred battles unscathed." The idea of 'knowing' before fighting a battle is about the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations' referred to in Chapter One, Calculations. The five factors are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: 'The seven considerations' are: (1) Which of the two kings is imbued with the Moral Law? (2) Which of the two generals has the most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained? (7) In which army is there the greater consistency both in reward and punishment? The five factors and seven considerations deal in terms of politics, resources, strength and strategy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
But how do you go about knowing the enemy in terms of tactics, once you're already on the battlefield? That's exactly what we're going to talk about next. ¡§Scheme so as to discover his plans and the likelihood of their success."

Meng Shi comments: ¡§Scheme and measure the enemy's situation, and observe his work; thus, you will know the likelihood of success."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§I already know, through my calculation and scheming, the likelihood of the enemy either succeeding or failing."
In sum, it's basically about analyzing the plans of both yourself and your enemy, and deducing who will win and who will lose. ¡§Rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity."

'Rousing' the enemy is about prodding him, irritating him so that he does something unnecessary, and then watching where he moves and where he stays still.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Then, you will know where his weak and strong points are. This is also similar to 'reconnaissance by fire,' which we have mentioned before. Duke Wu of Wei once asked his advisor, Wu Qi: ¡§What is to be done if, when my army meets with that of the enemy, I do not know how great or how limited my opponent's leadership skills are?"
Wu Qi replied: ¡§Send a small detachment of brave soldiers to launch a stinging attack on him, but order them to feign defeat and retreat as soon as they engage, and then observe how the enemy acts. If his forces pursue your men, but pretend to be unable to keep up, and pretend not to see the weapons, flags and other valuable objects discarded by your fleeing troops, then he is a general of great wisdom.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

But if they pursue with their entire army in a confused mass of motion and flags, and if they are greedy for spoils and loot, then your opponent's leadership skills are second-rate, and you may prepare to launch a general offensive against him directly. ¡§Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death."

One way of forcing the enemy to reveal himself is to 'rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity.'

¡§Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Here, 'comparing' refers to measuring."
Du Mu comments: ¡§Here, 'comparing' refers to making measurements. I use my areas of abundance to measure the enemy's areas of abundance; I use my areas of inadequacy to measure the enemy's areas of inadequacy."
In the ancient philosophical text, The Guanzi, it is written: ¡§Thus, those who are skilled at attacking learn the enemy's numbers by attacking them, learn the enemy's food stores by attacking his food stores, and learn the enemy's level of preparation by attacking his preparations.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
If the enemy possesses numerical superiority, do not attack; if he possesses superiority in food stores, do not attack; if he is well prepared, do not attack. Stay away from areas of strength, and attack weak points; stay away from places where the enemy is sturdy, and attack where he is weak; stay away from areas of difficulty, and attack where it is easy."
For our historical example for this passage, let's look back once more at Sima Yi's campaign to put down the rebellion in Liaodong. We've already talked about this example twice, and the principle of appraising the enemy's plans is yet another point that relates to Sima Yi's experience.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
During that campaign in Liaodong, Sima Yi had 40,000 troops compared to Gong Sunxiao's 200,000. As mentioned earlier, Gong Sunxiao sent a vanguard force of a few tens of thousands of troops to guard the River Liao. He personally commanded the main force, which was to act as a relief force for the vanguard, thus blocking Sima Yi's forward progress from a distance of several dozen li. Sima Yi used part of his army to pin down the enemy, and then quietly led an elite force around the enemy lines, across the River Liao, and directly to Gong Sunxiao's powerbase, the city of Rangping, which he then besieged. This is the stratagem of 'Forcing him to move by attacking a place where he is bound to come to the rescue; to leave him with no option but to fight, despite having strong defensive fortifications.' Gong Sunxiao was forced to move, to protect Rangping, and while on the road, he was defeated three times by Sima Yi's forces. He eventually retreated behind Rangping's city walls, where he took up a defensive position. This is what it means to 'surround an enemy position in order to destroy his relief force; know on what day and in what location the battle will be fought.'
When Sima Yi arrived in Liaodong, it was the seventh month of the year - the beginning of the wet season. Once the rains started, they didn't stop for a whole month, so Sima Yi hunkered down with his army and didn't move.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: He was in no rush. One of his officers, Chen Gui, asked him: ¡§Back when Meng Da rebelled, we marched against him with eight armies, day and night for eight days. We moved 1,200 li, took Meng Da's fortress, and executed him.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Today, we have come a great distance to Liaodong, yet we are sitting here, taking our ease, and drawing up plans at a leisurely pace. It must be because of my stupidity, but to tell the truth, I cannot understand this."
Sima Yi replied: ¡§What we are doing is measuring the enemy's numbers and the amount of his food stores. Meng Da did not have many men, and his food stores were enough to feed his army for a year.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Our army had four times the numbers of Meng Da's, and our food stores were only enough to last for a month. When you have a month's store of food, and your enemy has a year's, you naturally need to act quickly. That's why we had to beat Meng Da, without worrying too much about our own casualties. In truth, it was not Meng Da whom we were fighting against; we were racing against time to finish the war before our food stores ran out. If we failed to do that, our men would have starved to death.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: As for this campaign, though it is true we have travelled a great distance, we have brought ample food stores, whereas our enemy will soon run out of food. The enemy has more troops than us, so while he starves, we will be well fed.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
So, the situation now is precisely the opposite of when we fought against Meng Da. This rain does not make for good fighting weather, which is perfect for us - we are all using up our food supplies, so what need is there to hurry?"
After thirty days, the rain stopped and Sima Yi finally began his attack. In Pingrang, the food shortage was so severe that people had taken to cannibalism.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Many enemy officers surrendered, Sima Yi successfully took Pingrang. He executed Gong Sunxiao and restored stability to Liaodong. If you learn from me, you'll survive; If you imitate me, you're dead

Surface-level things - the things that people see and talk about - are never the things that are truly important.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: There are essentially two threads that contain what is really crucial. The first is the current situation, conditions and pre-planning, and the second is the skill that you, as an individual, have accumulated over many years. Typically, people who learn from other people don't have any grasp on the second of these threads, and don't even know about the first thread.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Their way of studying is to follow the crowd, so naturally their studies amount to nothing. Extract from the original text:
¡§In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form; when your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be. All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved. Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances."

Analysis:
¡§In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form."
'Making tactical dispositions' actually means showing the enemy a certain shape or form in the way your army is deployed. It's also about making false movements, which are meant as feints, but might also turn into a real move at any moment. This uncertainty is intentional - it's about selling the enemy a deceptive impression, just like Emperor Taizong meant when he said: ¡§Use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one's foe." The point is to come up with a way, any way, to trick the enemy into slipping up and making an error of judgment. So, 'In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain,' and the absolute best way to show the enemy your form is to make your form infinitely variable, to the point that your army becomes 'without form.' Then, the enemy is either completely unable to evaluate your situation, or he accepts a pre-made 'evaluation' that you give to him. ¡§When your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Here, Sun Tzu says that there is no more perfect way to use armed force than to employ formlessness. When you are formless, then though agents may come deep within my ranks to spy on me, they will be unable to perceive my weak and strong points.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Because there is no leaked information about my strengths and weaknesses, even wise and capable men will be unable to devise schemes against me."

¡§With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be."

'Showing one's form' is a way of misleading the enemy; 'formlessness' is about the dimensions within which you use your army. 'Varying formation' is about changing your formation and choosing the right approach in response to the enemy's situation and unfolding events.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: In the original Chinese text, it's not entirely clear how readers should interpret 'although it is placed before the people, they do not understand how it came to be.' Li Quan provides a clear explanation in his commentary.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: In the story of Sima Yi's expedition to Liaodong, in the previous subchapter, none of Sima Yi's subordinates understood what exactly his plan was, right up until he crushed Gong Sunxiao's army and executed the rebel leader.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
That's why we saw Chen Gui asking Sima Yi to explain what was going on. ¡§All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved. Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances."

It's clear for anyone to see what formation I use, and how I deploy my troops, yet nobody can tell how I responded to the enemy's formation so effectively that I won the battle. In the next battle I fight, the enemy's situation will be different.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: And so, because it's about responding to the situation in front of me, I won't use the same approach, and indeed I never use the same approach twice. There's an infinite number of possible variations, which are all based on the situation at hand. Let's look at the meaning of this subchapter's heading: 'If you learn from me, you'll survive; if you imitate me, you're dead.' If you watch how someone else wins a battle, and then try to copy them exactly, you'll end up in a terrible mess. Why?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Because you haven't understood how the person you're trying to learn from actually won. He did things a certain way based on the current situation and circumstances. When you try to copy their approach, the situation and circumstances that you're facing are completely different. Also, when you saw the general you're trying to copy using a certain approach, that approach was not something that just happened in isolation. There was also a wider context of conditions and factors at play before the battle happened, all of which the successful general has to take into account. But you didn't do any of this.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: You just made a crude copy of what you saw, with the mindset that if it worked for other people, then it should work for you, too. And that's why it's all going to go pear-shaped for you. Let's take another quick look at Han Xin's battle by the river, where he put his army of 10,000 men in a place of mortal danger, with their backs to the deep river, and yet he survived. It worked because his men had no escape route - they had to fight and win, or else die.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: That's how they defeated 200,000 enemy troops that day. But is that really what happened? If the fighting had lasted a little longer, Han Xin's 10,000 troops would have been wiped out. Or, if the enemy commander had ordered his troops to lower their weapons and stand down, some of Han Xin's men would have surrendered there and then. But, Han Xin also had a force of 2,000 cavalry, which he used to attack the Zhao camp, tear down the Zhao banners, and replace them with their own Han banners. When the Zhao troops saw that they'd lost their base camp, they panicked and began to run. That was the moment when the tide turned for Han Xin, when the conditions were right for him to pounce on his enemy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The crucial factor in that battle was the unit of 2,000 cavalry. We're now all familiar with how Han Xin won the battle, even with his back to the river, and the idea of winning with your back to the river has become an idiom in the modern Chinese language. But would you have the courage to intentionally fight a battle with your back to a river?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Han Xin himself only did this once - he changed his approach in the very next battle he fought. Another important point is that, to study the art of war, you need to also look at it through the lens of a devil's advocate.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: You should spend a lot of time thinking about worst-case scenarios, instead of assuming that things will go well. The first aspect of this is to not study how to make calculations about other people, but how to make other people unable to make calculations about you. Also, don't think that you can win by using the formula: 'I am formless, I show the enemy a form, I deceive the enemy, and then I attain victory.' As pleasing as this approach might seem, don't allow yourself to be too delighted by it, or when you're actually on a battlefield you'll find that the fun won't last for long. You need to play devil's advocate - turn the formula upside down, and as you read each line, imagine yourself as the person who is being 'shown forms' by the enemy. Don't allow yourself to be misled, don't act without thinking things through, prioritize protecting yourself, and only then allow your thoughts to turn to working out the enemy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: This is the true way of the art of war. We read books and study as a way of projecting what we learn onto ourselves. We take it for granted that we should put ourselves in the role of the winner, and we internalize the emotions and mindset of the winner, because it's human nature to do so. But, it's important to remember to look at the reverse side of things: to imagine yourself in the role of the loser, and to spend time thinking about how to avoid defeat.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: This is what you have to do if you want to learn more. When studying the art of war, first study how not to lose, and only then move on to how to win. Indeed, the starting point of the whole of the art of war is the question of not losing.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
The art of war does not begin with victory. Victory and defeat are not equal; Victory brings nothing more than a few spoils, but defeat means you might lose your life

¡§Military forms are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows; the soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing. Therefore, just as water retains no constant shape, so in warfare there are no constant conditions. Analysis:
This is the final subchapter of Chapter Six, and it shall be used as a summary of Weak Points and Strong.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
¡§Military forms are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak."

The way wars are fought is like water. When water moves, it always follows the same pattern: flowing from high places to low places.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
Similarly, the pattern to follow in war is to stay away from places where the enemy is strong, and strike him where he is weak. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Water flows smoothly when it is moving downhill, and battles unfold advantageously when striking the enemy's weak points."

¡§Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows; the soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing."

The above passage is quite self-explanatory. ¡§Therefore, just as water retains no constant shape, so in warfare there are no constant conditions.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
He who can modify his tactics in relation to his opponent, and thereby succeed in winning, may be called a heaven-born captain."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Energy comes from responding to the enemy." As the enemy changes, I change in response. That's why 'in warfare there are no constant conditions,' just as water never stays in any one form.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: When water comes upon a square-shaped space, it becomes a square, and when it enters a circular space, it becomes a circle. If you can find a way to victory based on how the enemy's situation changes, you have practically become a god of war.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
¡§The five elements (water, fire, wood, metal, earth) are not always equally predominant; the four seasons make way for each other in turn. There are short days and long; the moon has its periods of waning and waxing."

Each of the five elements - metal, wood, water, fire and earth - subdues one of the other elements, but none of them is able to permanently overpower all of the others. The four seasons - spring, summer, fall and winter - constantly replace one another, and none of them can last for a whole year.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: The days grow long and then short, and the moon waxes and then wanes. In this passage, Sun Tzu uses all of these natural phenomena as an analogy. He's telling us that since all of these things experience periods of growth and decline, how could anyone ever set in stone the constantly fluctuating forms of war?

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: We have now reached the end of Chapter Six, Weak Points and Strong. To sum up the chapter's essential message, we can look at a comment by Cao Cao: ¡§It is about being able to use weak points and strong, both your own and the enemy's." As you move your forces this way and that, the objective is to put yourself in a position of strength, and the enemy in a position of weakness - this is how you can become like a god of war. However, as we learn to fight like a god of war, the most important thing to understand is that you are not a god.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: It's therefore impossible for your troop movements to always put you in a position of strength and the enemy in a position of weakness. More likely, you'll find yourself in a position of weakness and your enemy in a position of strength. So, if you can double down on being cautious, you could at least say that your studies of the art of war have not been for nothing. Victory and defeat are a question of wisdom, of strength, and also of probability.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But, in terms of results, victory and defeat are usually not of equal value. All that you get from victory is some spoils of war, but if you're defeated, you're liable to lose your life. In Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, there's a whole chapter dedicated to weak and strong points, in which Emperor Taizong says: ¡§I have read all of the military treatises, and none surpasses Sun Tzu's. Within Sun Tzu's The Art of War, the best of the best is the chapter on Weak Points and Strong. If, as a commander of soldiers, one can distinguish between weak points and strong, then one will sweep to victory wherever one goes.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Every general is prone to say that they avoid their enemies' strong points while attacking their weak points, yet once they are upon the battlefield, they cannot perceive their enemy's weak and strong points.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content:
As a result, it is not they who move the enemy where they will, but the enemy who moves them. What do you make of this problem?"
Duke Li of Wei replied: ¡§To perceive weak points and strong, one must first understand 'the main and the auxiliary.' Most military leaders do not know how to use a main force as an auxiliary force and vice versa, so how could they properly identify when a strong point is a weak point, and a weak point is a strong point? The main and the auxiliary are used to manipulate the enemy's weak and strong points - where the enemy is strong, I must use my main force; where the enemy is weak, I must use my auxiliary force. Without an understanding of the usages of the main and the auxiliary, then even if one is able to perceive the enemy's weak and strong points, one will still be unable to attack them."
Then, Emperor Taizong said: ¡§When I use my auxiliary force as my main force, my enemy thinks that I am using my auxiliary force, when in fact it is my main force with which I am striking him. Or, the enemy thinks I am using my main force, when in fact it is my auxiliary force with which I am striking him. Thus, the enemy is in a constant position of weakness, while I am in a constant position of strength."
This passage ends with a summary by Duke Li of Wei: ¡§Countless words have been written on this subject, but essentially, the message never ventures beyond this idea: 'Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.'"
The duke's summary forms a pair with the principle of winning by responding to your enemy's situation. When the idea of manipulating your foe while avoiding being manipulated yourself is taken to an extreme, it becomes: 'I don't care what your deal is; I only care what my deal is.' Above all else, it's about not being manipulated by your enemy, not giving him any opportunities and forcing him to endure a long wait.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: In fact, it's totally viable to not even fight at all, because the one thing that you absolutely must do is to win first and fight later. Winning by responding to the enemy's situation is about basing decisions about where you should deploy your troops based on the enemy's troop movements.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: But, when you use this approach, it's easy to end up being manipulated and having your movements dictated by the enemy. This is because it's possible that the changes you can see in your enemy's situation and formation have been intentionally designed to trick you. Perhaps where you see a weak point, the reality is that it's the enemy's strong point.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: There's a great deal of danger in this strategy, and it's not something that just anyone is capable of pulling off. So, to truly be an all-conquering general, you must be able to 'manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated,' have a high tolerance for isolation, and be extremely patient.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: To reach an even higher level - to fight like a god - you need to be able to pluck victory from the changes in your enemy's situation. In all honesty, Emperor Taizong was practically a god. When we try to learn from him, the most important thing is to remember that, unlike him, we are not gods.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Sun Tzu said: ¡§Whoever is first in the field, and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted. Therefore the clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy's will to be imposed on him.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord; or, by inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near. If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out; if quietly encamped, he can force him to move. Appear at points which the enemy will not be quick enough to defend; march swiftly to places where you are not expected.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not. You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended. You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked. Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy's fate in our hands. You may advance and be absolutely irresistible, if you make for the enemy's weak points; you may retire and be safe from pursuit if your movements are more rapid than those of the enemy.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If we wish to fight, the enemy can be forced to an engagement even though he be sheltered behind a high rampart and a deep ditch. All we need do is attack some other place that he will be obliged to relieve.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: If we do not wish to fight, we can prevent the enemy from engaging us even though the lines of our encampment be merely traced out on the ground. All we need do is to throw something odd and unaccountable in his way.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight. But if neither time nor place be known, then the left wing will be impotent to succor the right, the right equally impotent to succor the left, the van unable to relieve the rear, or the rear to support the van. How much more so if the furthest portions of the army are anything under a hundred li apart, and even the nearest are separated by several li!

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Though according to my estimate the soldiers of Yue exceed our own in number, that shall advantage them nothing in the matter of victory. I say then that victory can be achieved. Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting. Scheme so as to discover his plans and the likelihood of their success.

chapter: Chapter Six: Weak points and strong
content: Rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity. Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death. Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient. In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form; when your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains. With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be.
