content: There are short days and long; the moon has its periods of waning and waxing."

Armed struggle

When you make projections based on the art of war, it all seems so perfect, yet once you're on the battlefield, you forget all about the art of war

Extract from the original text:
¡§In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign.

Having collected an army and concentrated his forces, he must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp. After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult."

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Armed struggle is about two armies vying for victory." Once the weak and strong points have been established, then you can maneuver yourself into a tactical advantage." This is why this chapter is positioned immediately after Weak Points and Strong. ¡§Having collected an army and concentrated his forces..."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Assembling the people of the country, forming fighting units, selecting officers, establishing camps - hence battle formations are drawn."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Assembling people from across the country is how armies are built; gathering the soldiers together is how battle formations are drawn."
So, what we're talking about here is a nationwide mobilization: recruiting soldiers, and then forming armies and sending your forces into the field.

¡§He must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp."

When you come face to face with the enemy, set up camp. Cao Cao comments: ¡§The gate of an army camp is called the 'gate of harmony.' Gates to the left and the right are called the 'banner gates.' The gate of a camp made of chariots bound together is called the 'axel gate.' The gate of a camp made by men is called the 'human gate.' When the two armies face one another, the different elements of the army are blended and harmonized."
There's a famous story in China about a warrior named Lu Bu, who managed to avert a battle with a wager that he could shoot a very difficult target - the blade of a halberd, a battle-axe topped with a spike - with an arrow. In the story, Lu Bu is standing by the axel gate.

From Cao Cao's comment, we know that the name 'axel gate' was used specifically for a gate made of chariot axel rods, while the main gate in an army camp was known as the 'gate of harmony.' He Shi comments: ¡§Facing the enemy at the gate of harmony, the general assembles his forces for battle and prepares to vie with the enemy for tactical advantage. This is a difficult task which military commanders face."

¡§After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§From the time when the general is first appointed, to the moment battle is joined, struggling for advantage is constantly difficult." 
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Nothing is more difficult, from being appointed as general, all the way to this juncture."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Standing opposite the enemy and vying with him for advantage is among the most difficult things in the world."
To put it simply, this is incredibly hard!

Earlier on, in Calculations, it was all about generals making their plans in the safety of their tents, far away from any real danger. Later on, in Waging War and Planning Assaults, we talked about scenarios where food supplies are plentiful and armies even got the chance to eat the enemy's food, and where generals were free to fight if they thought they could win, or to run away, which they'd definitely do if they weren't sure of winning. Then, in Formations and Energy, we talked about various situations involving formations and energy, and about organizing armies, deploying troops, and how to come to decisions. In Weak Points and Strong, we talked about probing the enemy to find out his weak and strong points, how to manipulate him and move him wherever you want, and how to stay clear of his strong points while hitting him where he's weak.

It's really quite joyful when you talk about it like that - you get to beat your enemy without fighting him. He just surrenders without you having to make a single move. And, even if you do fight, you get to set yourself up in a position where you can't be beaten, and you still get to win before you fight. You can cycle your troop organization between main and auxiliary formations, keeping the enemy constantly guessing and never able to work you out. Then, exploiting the space in between weak and strong points, you manipulate your enemy until he's more obedient than your own kids.

And finally, once you've put him a weak position and yourself in a strong one, you crack him like an egg. However, you have to remember that if you understand all this, other people understand it, too.

If you can do it, others can as well. If you're actually doing it, other people are also doing it. Not only that, other people might be doing it better than you. That's why you have to 'struggle,' and pit your courage and your wisdom against the enemy's.

You have to fight to stay one step ahead. And so, the most difficult thing in the world is to find yourself on the battlefield, facing the enemy's army, knowing that the fighting's about to start. Mao Zedong once said: ¡§As soon as you're on the battlefield, you forget all about the art of war."
So, how are you supposed to fight? What are the principles?

What do you need to remember? These questions are what Armed Struggle is all about. Sometimes it takes longer than you think it should to do something, but that's just life; In the same way, spending money on things you don't want to spend money on is part and parcel of spending money

When the right thing to do is admit defeat, admit defeat; when the right thing to do is swallow your objections, swallow your objections.

Don't fight just for the sake of being right, and don't try to right the boat when it's already sunk, especially if it means throwing away your capital in the effort. Extract from the original text:
¡§The difficulty of tactical maneuvering consists in turning the circuitous into the direct, and misfortune into gain. Thus, to take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, to contrive to reach the goal before him, shows knowledge of the artifice of the circuitous and of the direct."

Analysis:
¡§Turn the circuitous into the direct."
The quickest way of getting between point A and point B isn't to move in a straight line. A route that, on the surface, seems full of twists and turns is actually the easiest, most direct path.

There are two reasons for this: terrain, and the enemy's formations. Because of these two factors, if you try to move in a straight line, you'll find your way forward blocked. So, when faced with complex terrain and an enemy who is constantly shifting formation, which route is fastest? This is where you 'turn the circuitous into the direct.' The quickest road is actually the one full of twists and turns.

In soccer, it would be impossible to attack in a straight line from deep in your own half all the way to the opposition's goal posts. So, every time a player runs with the ball or passes it, they are 'turning the circuitous into the direct.' Even for the 'King of Soccer,' Pele, dribbling the ball in a straight line, right into the opposition goal, meant 'turning the circuitous into the direct' every time his foot touched the ball. It's about turning adversity into advantage.

¡§Thus, take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, contrive to reach the goal before him."

This is about intentionally choosing a long, winding route so as to give the enemy the impression that you're not actually planning to go to your destination. Then, you make some false moves and hold out some small enticement to gain control over your enemy, before making a sudden move straight to your destination.

This is how you arrive before your enemy, even if you set out after him. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Taking a long and circuitous route is about showing the enemy that you are far away. To arrive before the enemy, even though you depart after him, you must have a clear grasp of measurements, numbers and distances."
If you make your enemy think that you're far away, they'll let down their guard.

To arrive before the enemy, you need to work out the terrain ahead of time, including the distances of various routes and where you can cut quickly and suddenly to your destination. Our historical example for this subchapter comes from Warring States period: how Zhao She defeated a Qin army.

The name Zhao She might sound familiar. That's because he was the father of Zhao Kuo, the armchair strategist we talked about earlier. However, unlike his son, Zhao She was a true and renowned general. When Qin attacked Han, they sent an army to besiege Yuyu. The Zhao king, Huiwen, decided to go to Yuyu's aid, so he asked his general, Lian Po, for advice. Lian Po told him that it would be a difficult mission, because the road to Yuyu was long and narrow, and crossed through dangerous, rugged terrain. King Huiwen asked Le Cheng what he thought, and Le Cheng gave the same answer as Lian Po.

Then, King Huiwen asked Zhao She, who said: ¡§When enemies meet on a narrow road, victory goes to he who is bravest. Leave it to me."
When the Qin government found out that Zhao had dispatched an army, they sent a unit to set up a camp to the west of the city of Wu'an.

This, together with their position at Yuyu, put them in a strong position to attack any enemy force from two sides at once. Zhao She's war had just gotten harder. Zhao She, freshly appointed, gathered an army, marched out of the Handan city gate, and proceeded to set up camp after walking only 30 li.

He apparently had no intention of moving any further. He let it be known around the camp, by way of a formal decree: ¡§Anyone who speaks out of turn about military arrangements shall be decapitated!"
Meanwhile, the Qin army was riding a powerful wave of energy and momentum. From their camp outside the city walls of Wu'an, they beat the war drums to energize the troops, and the noise was so loud that it made the roof tiles inside the city shake.

But, one officer in the Zhao army camp had concerns about the commander-in-chief's orders not to move - concerns that were too strong not to express. So, he approached Zhao She, knowing that he was risking his life, and begged him to go to war to save Wu'an. Zhao She knew that this officer was a good man, but this was exactly what he'd been waiting for: a good man to come to him and offer his head on a platter. This was part of his plan to 'turn the circuitous into the direct.' So, he immediately ordered that the officer be taken outside and beheaded. Zhao She kept his army in that camp for 28 days, kept on building up the camp's fortifications, and showed no intention whatsoever of moving out to fight.

The Qin army sent a spy, and Zhao She put on a show for the agent. He convinced the spy that there was absolutely no chance that the Zhao army would move out, come hell or high water. When the spy brought this news back to the Qin commander, he was delighted.

It seemed to him that the Zhao army didn't have the will or the courage to fight him. It was likely that the only reason the force had been sent out in the first place was to make a show of honoring the state of Han's plea for help. Meanwhile, the moment Zhao She had seen off the Qin spy, he ordered his army to pack up their armor, along with a few, light pieces of equipment and supplies, and he set off. Moving quickly, they arrived safely at Yuyu after two days and one night's march, without running into a single ambush or even the slightest whiff of resistance. Zhao She didn't head straight for Yuyu, but stopped about 50 li shy of the city, and set up camp in a location he'd selected specially for its good terrain. At this point, another of his officers, a man named Xu Li, stepped forward and put his neck on the line by suggesting to Zhao She: ¡§Victory will surely belong to whoever holds the northern mountains." Zhao She immediately agreed with the man, and sent 10,000 troops to set up a position at the highest point in the northern mountains. Xu Li, who'd suggested the mountain defense, said: ¡§I have said my piece, and I am prepared to accept my death."
¡§And why should you be put to death?" Zhao She asked.

¡§Because... your decree! 'Anyone who speaks out of turn about military arrangements shall be decapitated,'" Xu Li replied. ¡§We shall discuss this matter further upon our return to Handan," Zhao She said, ending the discussion. (When the army eventually returned to Handan, Xu Li was promoted and given an official title: Defender in Chief.)
The Qin commander, hearing that the Zhao army had reached Yuyu, broke out in a cold sweat. He immediately pulled his army back from Wu'an and rushed to protect the Qin position at Yuyu.

But Zhao She already held the best terrain, so he won a major victory over the Qin army, resulting in the end of the Qin siege of Yuyu. The story of this battle is a particularly gripping one. Traveling unarmored, and with only light supplies, is a very dangerous move. After a forced march lasting two days and a night, without any supply wagons, the Zhao army had moved far away from its rear support system, and the soldiers would have been exhausted. If Zhao She had rushed straight into a confrontation with the Qin army under Yuyu's city walls, without pausing for a rest, he likely would have ended up as a Qin prisoner. Zhao She's stroke of genius lay in the fact that he camped 50 li outside of Yuyu, set up a proper defensive line and fortifications, and dug in, waiting for the Qin army to come to him. In doing this, he was putting into practice a key lesson from Weak Points and Strong: ¡§Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted." If one of the two sides was exhausted, it was definitely the Zhao troops - they would have been utterly spent after their forced march. But instead of heading straight for Yuyu, they pulled up 50 li short, meaning that the Qin soldiers basically had to run a marathon to get to them, wearing themselves out in the process. This turned the tables - the Zhao troops rested up while they waited for their enemies to tire themselves out on the road to the battlefield. Also in the chapter on Weak Points and Strong, we read how Duke Li of Wei said that in all the thousands of pages written about the art of war, there is nothing that isn't essentially saying: 'Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.' At first, the Qin army had everything planned out. They thought they were manipulating Zhao She, because they'd set up strong, mutually reinforcing positions at Wu'an and Yuyu, and planned to use the stratagem of besieging a city with the main purpose of drawing in an enemy relief force, under Zhao She's command, and destroying it on the road.

But as it turned out, the Qin forces weren't able to catch Zhao She, because he successfully 'turned the circuitous into the direct,' materializing as if by magic outside Yuyu with his army. Once Zhao She had put the finishing touches to the location he'd chosen for a battlefield, the roles had reversed: Zhao She was to be the gracious host, and the Qin army was to be his guests.

They had to go exactly where Zhao She wanted them. Another passage from Weak Points and Strong says: ¡§Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight." Again, Zhao She did it by the book, choosing both the time and the location of the battle. However, there's one question that must be asked: What it the Qin army didn't show up?

This was actually an option for the Qin commander - once he found out that Zhao She had used the stratagem of 'turning the circuitous into the direct,' and made his way to Yuyu, he could have thought things through more thoroughly. He might have realized that, since it was now a fact that the Zhao army was here, he could just work out how many days the isolated enemy force could realistically last without grain and supply wagons.

He could have waited and watched, and postponed making any firm decisions. But he didn't. He panicked, because something had happened that he wasn't expecting, and because he didn't know what other moves Zhao She might have up his sleeve. So, he allowed himself to be swept up in his panic, and hurried off to fight. He returned from the battle that followed as a badly beaten general. A different commander might not have fallen into Zhao She's trap.

That would have been a real problem. In the story we looked at earlier of Wang Yangming putting down the Prince of Ning's rebellion, Wang Yangming really only had one card in his hand: attacking the city of Nanchang and waiting for the Prince of Ning to come to its rescue. This strategy was also an example of 'turning the circuitous into the direct.' But what if the Prince of Ning didn't come to save Nanchang? His advisors all tried to tell him that losing Nanchang wasn't a big deal, because if he only managed to take Nanjing he'd become the Emperor of all China, and he'd be able to take back control of Nanchang by just sending a letter!

But the prince panicked. He went back to Nanchang, not knowing that he was marching to his death. In both cases, the panicked commander was like a rabbit in the headlights, choosing an escape route on blind impulse.

It's important to not panic, and to be able to admit defeat. Once you admit defeat, and acknowledge that the circumstances have changed, you can work out what to do about it. What you mustn't do is keep thinking about how to turn back time and re-create the old situation. Also, don't throw your capital away in an attempt to claw back your advantage.

If you do that, you'll lose everything. Finally - and this is a bit of a tangent - when you use the stratagem of 'turning the circuitous into the direct,' you're still going after 'the direct.' However, in life and personal growth, the road is inherently full of twists and turns, of forward movement and backward steps. Nothing ever goes entirely smoothly, and you can never move in a perfectly straight line.

So, you have to understand this at a basic level. A winding road is a road, too, and money you don't want to spend is just the same as any other money. If you refuse to take the winding road, you'll find yourself without any road at all, and if you refuse to spend money that you don't want to spend, you won't spend money when it's the right thing to do. Marching is part of war, and so is camping

If you take this logic a step further, you'll find that training troops is also a part of war.

In fact, it's an even more important element of war than fighting battles. Actually, fighting is the least important part; all the variables solidify and take their final form well before the battle happens.

Yet, when people talk about war, they always talk about battle stories. It's very rare to hear stories about camping, and you almost never hear stories about training, because 'training' and 'stories' don't go together.

So, the real work of wars all happens away from the limelight of storytelling. That's exactly what Sun Tzu meant when he said: ¡§Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage." True heroes don't make it into the storybooks. Extract from the original text:
¡§Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous.

If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores. Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination. If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal.

If you march thirty li with the same objective, two thirds of your army will arrive. We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost."

Analysis:
¡§Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§For a skilled general, it is advantageous; for an unskilled general, it is dangerous."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When a wise general engages in armed struggle, he does so to his advantage; when a mediocre general engages in armed struggle, he endangers himself. The wise general understands the circuitous and the direct; the foolish general is ignorant of the workings of the circuitous and the direct."
To put it plainly, nothing's difficult if you know how to do it.

If you know how to snatch an advantage from your enemy's hands, you'll do well; if you don't, you'll end up putting yourself in danger. For example, in the previous subchapter, Zhao She was able to successfully gain the advantage by marching light and fast for two days and a night, because he understood the stratagem of 'turning the circuitous into the direct.' So, he was able to manipulate his enemy while avoiding being manipulated himself, and he was able to foretell the time and location of the battle. Zhao She put into practice the principle that 'armed struggle can be advantageous' by marching 100 li to fight.

But, if he'd done exactly the same thing without first committing to do all the groundwork and showmanship that went into fooling the Qin general, he would have played straight into his enemy's plan, which was to besiege the cities of Wu'an and Yuyu with a primary objective of luring in and destroying a relief force. If Zhao She had been lured in and crushed, he would have been proving the other side of the equation: 'armed struggle can be dangerous.'
This is why, so often when we see someone else smartly pulling off a certain strategy, we fail spectacularly when we try to do the same thing.

This is because people aren't the same, and there are different levels of preparation that go into making these things either work or backfire. ¡§If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores."

A 'fully equipped army' means that, along with the soldiers and horses, you're marching with full armor, weapons and other equipment, grain and heavy supply wagons. This makes for slow travel, hence the phrase, 'you will be too late.' So, when the crucial moment arrives, you have to leave your heavy supply wagons behind and move quickly, with just a light cavalry force. This is the meaning of 'abandoning the army to snatch the advantage.' Similarly, 'the sacrifice of its baggage and stores' means giving your supplies to someone else. Who exactly you give them to is impossible to know, but you're essentially throwing them away.

¡§Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination."

'Rolling up the armor' is about packing just the essential armor and riding light. In this situation, your unit marches all through the day and all through the night, without rest.

If you make a forced march with three separate units over a distance of 100 li in a bid to seize the advantage, your three commanders will all be taken prisoner by the enemy. Why? The men who are in the best physical condition will be able to make it to the destination without any rest, but the weaker ones will straggle behind. So, only one tenth of the units' troops will arrive on schedule, and your unit will have drastically shrunk in size, to the point that it doesn't matter much where they are, because the enemy will be able to swallow them up. Also, the enemy will be fresh and well rested, while your men wear themselves out on their journey.

All the enemy has to do is wait for your men to walk, in scattered groups, right into their open jaws. In the Battle of Fei River, which we looked at earlier in the book, I wrote that Xie Xuan had an army of 80,000 men, and that he defeated Fu Jian's much larger army of 800,000. But actually, although Fu Jian's army did indeed number 800,000 troops in total, not all of them arrived in time. Many of his soldiers were still on the road when the battle started, and it's unclear in the historical records exactly how many made it to the battlefield on time. Xie Xuan had inside information, thanks to his secret ally, Zhu Xu, so he knew that Fu Jian hadn't yet assembled his whole army. That's the only reason Xie Xuan decided to launch a lightning-speed attack. In ancient Chinese warfare, armies would normally march 30 li, on average, per day. On forced marches, this speed would double, to 60 li per day.

If marching 'without halting day or night,' another 40 li could be covered, adding up to a total of 100 li over the course of a whole day and a whole night. So, since we know Zhao She marched for two days and one night, he probably covered a distance of 160 li.

According to The Art of War, he should have been captured by his enemy. What was his solution? To camp and set up defensive lines a full 50 li before reaching the enemy, partly to give the stragglers time to catch up, as well as to eat and rest.

And, he did so to force the enemy to march the remaining 50 li, tiring out the enemy troops while he waited at his leisure. ¡§If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal."

Zhao She implemented this passage to the letter: 50 li was the distance he left for the Qin army to march on their way to meet him. The Qin forces underwent a forced march to cover those 50 li as quickly as possible, with the result that only half of their force initially arrived, while the other half, including high-ranking officers, was still on the road. This would have made life quite difficult for the soldiers that arrived first.

¡§If you march thirty li with the same objective, two thirds of your army will arrive."

Even marching at a normal speed - 30 li per day - the army will still become separated, with two thirds of the troops reaching the destination before the remaining third. ¡§We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost."

Here, the 'baggage-train' includes battle equipment, grain, clothing and other consumable supplies.

'Bases of supply' means roughly the same thing: goods, valuables and other commodities. So, an army that marches quickly like this is, in reality, extremely vulnerable. Without their baggage-train, they're dead; without supplies and equipment, they're dead. Think about conditions during the Korean War - soldiers without winter clothing and blankets were doomed.

Whole regiments and whole army camps froze to death on the front lines. This passage from The Art of War contains three truths. The first truth is that accomplishing something isn't difficult if you have the right abilities, but it's impossible if you don't.

Challenges can bring huge benefits for wise leaders, but death and disaster for foolish leaders. If you see someone doing something, but don't understand how they do it, don't make the mistake of thinking that if someone else can do it, you can too.

The second truth is that marching is a part of war, and is in fact an even more important element than fighting in battles. The Art of War also states that camping is a part of war. Questions like where and when to set up camp can be even more pivotal in determining who will win or lose a conflict than the actual process of fighting.

By the time the fighting starts, who will win and who will lose is a foregone conclusion; what makes the difference is the commanders' decisions about marching and camping. These factors are exactly what decided Zhao She's victory over the Qin forces.

There's a famous quotation from Napoleon: ¡§Marching is war, and war is marching. Ability in conducting wars is one and the same as the ability to move effectively." Napoleon specifically researched different marching speeds. Traditionally, an army was supposed to be able to march 70 paces per minute, but Napoleon upped this speed to 120 paces per minute. So, Napoleon's main battle weapon wasn't his soldiers' guns, but their legs.

Another leader who was especially skilled at marching was General Su Yu, of China's People's Liberation Army. He understood the stratagem of 'turning the circuitous into the direct' better than anyone, and he was able to memorize maps of entire war zones in full detail.

This talent enabled him to cut across the terrain with incredible speed, and to appear out of nowhere, where his enemies least expected. If we take the logic of marching and camping being integral parts of warfare to the next step, we realize that training is also an integral part of warfare, and that it too is even more important than actual fighting. A bit of extra work and sweat in peacetime saves a lot of blood in times of war. If you take this logic yet an additional step further, you'll find that training troops is also a part of war, and in fact, it's an even more important part of war than fighting battles. Actually, fighting is the least important part; all the variables solidify and take their final form well before the battle happens.

Still, when people talk about war, they always recount battle stories. As we've said, it's rare to hear stories about camping, and you almost never hear stories about training, because 'training' and 'stories' don't go together.

The real work of wars all happens away from the limelight of storytelling. That's exactly what Sun Tzu meant when he said: ¡§Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage." True heroes don't make it into the storybooks. The third truth is that armies are extremely vulnerable and fragile.

If you stop paying attention for even a moment, you're dead. The strongest thing in the world is also the weakest and most delicate. In the times when we feel strong and powerful, we need to be even more careful than usual.

Observe yourself - are you really so powerful, or are you actually very weak? Behind the simple words, 'Know the terrain,' there are countless details, and countless people's sweat, wisdom and lives

Extract from the original text:
¡§We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides."

Analysis:
¡§We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Without knowing the enemy's situation and details of their plans, one cannot form alliances with them." If you don't know the politics and motives of neighboring powers, you don't have the ability to decide your own diplomatic policy, and you can't count on other people helping you. A passage from earlier in Sun Tzu's The Art of War tells us: ¡§Thus the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans; the next best is to attack the enemy's alliances." If you want to engage in diplomacy and get it right, you need a clear idea of what the various parties' interests and motives are.

This is an idea from game theory, the study of mathematical models of strategic interaction between decision-makers. So, The Art of War isn't just a work of military strategy, it's also hailed by game theory scholars as the earliest game theory text. Any behavior that contains elements of competition or antagonism can be called 'game theory behavior.' Within this category of behavior, every side involved, or every competitor, has different goals or interests.

The different sides, in order to achieve their various goals, have to contemplate all of their adversaries' possible moves or action plans, and also do whatever it takes to choose the right action plan for themselves.

They need to pursue a course of action that's as rational as possible, or maximizes benefits for them. In game theory strategy, one very important principle is that you mustn't look at the game just from your own perspective and your opponent's perspective, or just in terms of your and your opponent's interests, and the demands under which you and your opponent are operating. Instead, you need to expand your understanding of the number of participants in the game, or even to completely remodel the game, adding in more people and interests which might at first glance seem irrelevant to the game, while also increasing the number of chips you have in the game.

War, too, isn't just a game between two sides. By expanding your understanding of the number of participants in the game of war, by bringing more states and various other factors into the picture, you stand to gain support from unlikely or hidden sources, and increase your chances of winning.

For example, if you connect the dots between the 'Crimea Issue' between Russia and Ukraine, on the one hand, and the Diaoyu (Senkaku in Japanese) Islands issue between China and Japan, a regional game becomes a global one. ¡§We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps."

Cao Cao breaks down this passage in his commentary: 'mountains' refers to places of commanding height; 'forests' refers to places containing many trees; 'pitfalls' refers to moats and other deep holes in the earth; and 'obstructions' refers to vertically uneven terrain. 'Marshes' refers to damp, boggy places, full of water and grasses; and 'swamps' refers to places where water from many sources converges and becomes stagnant (i.e., lakes and ponds).

In short, you need to be extremely clear about the terrain before leading an army out on the march. ¡§We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides."

If you don't take seriously the need to use local guides, you won't be able to gain control of the best terrain. Studying and researching terrain from a strategic perspective is extremely intensive and detail-heavy work.

It's common knowledge that before the Normandy landings in World War II, the Allies took their reconnaissance of the terrain they'd be navigating in France to an extremely high level of detail. They sent spies during the night to dive in Normandy's coastal waters, where they took samples of beach sand and mud. They then evaluated all sorts of metrics, such as the thickness of the sand layer, the amount of mud, its relative hardness or softness, whether or not tanks could be driven onto the beaches, and so on.

In the end, the Ally researchers concluded that the sand was too soft, and that tanks would get stuck. What was their solution? The plan was to send a single tank ahead of the rest, the front part of which would be loaded with a 'carpet' made of canvas and wooden boards, which it would lay down on the beach so that the rest of the tanks would have a good surface to drive on. And how did the Allies deal with anti-tank obstacles?

Again, they sent a single tank ahead of the rest, which welded a bomb onto the anti-tank obstacle and blew it up. At that point, soldiers jumped out of the tank, wrapped cables around the obstacle - now reduced to a heap of scrap iron - and dragged it out of the way. Moving further up the beach, the next barrier to overcome would be rows of landmines. For this, the Allies designed a special mine-clearing tank, a great monstrous machine mounted with a horizontal bar on two arms at the front. From these arms hung a cluster of steel wrecking balls.

As it drove forward, the wrecking balls hit the ground in front of the tank, detonating any landmines and clearing a way for troops behind to move forward. If it weren't for this extremely intensive and detailed reconnaissance work, as well as the subsequent, highly-targeted design and engineering work, many, many more people would have died on those Norman beaches.

So, when we talk about 'knowing the terrain,' it seems simple - it's just three words. Yet, behind these words there are countless details, as well as the sweat, wisdom and lives of countless people. The idea that 'War is built on deception' plays the same role as feints in soccer; It's not actually a fundamental part of The Art of War, and it certainly is not representative of its value system

Extract from the original text:
¡§In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand, move with advantage, and change by dividing and consolidating."

Analysis:
The first part - ¡§In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand" - is a little misleading. Some readers consider these words the philosophical heart of The Art of War.

To them, it seems perfectly clear: Sun Tzu is telling us to 'make deception the foundation,' so it seems only natural that deception should also serve as a broader theoretical foundation. However, in the context of The Art of War as a whole, 'The Five Factors and Seven Considerations' don't come from deceit, and neither does 'Win first, fight later.' 
So, it's important, when you're reading a book or listening to someone speak, to make links between the different parts of the book or speech. Experts in the field of linguistics tell us that any given text can only communicate a small fraction of the writer's thoughts.

To get a complete picture of what the person behind the text is thinking, you need to integrate the language of the text with the wider context. We can't just lift a single sentence that someone's said out of its context, thinking we can explain what it means in isolation.

Likewise, we can't presume to magnify it by inserting it into a completely different context. If you do that, we'll veer way off course from the author's original idea. When Sun Tzu wrote the line, ¡§Make deception the foundation upon which to stand," he was writing in the context of this chapter, Armed Struggle. Here, he's beginning to talk about deception now that we've reached the stage where the two sides' armies fight it out for victory.

That comes only after going through the steps of making calculations in the temple, planning your assault, and thinking about formation and energy. What is deception? The simplest way to explain it is with a concept from soccer: false movement, also known as the 'feint.' You could say that every time your foot is about to touch the ball, there's always the potential for a feint - a deceptively faked move. Deceit is a way of concealing your intentions; of fooling your enemy and making them go where you want them to go.

Like Emperor Taizong said, it's about finding some way to lure your enemy into making a mistake. In the context of football, 'deceit' takes the form of feints. But, when you're training a soccer team, you can't just practice feints. In war, you make deceit your foundation, but if you also turn deceit into your entire value system, and believe that only deceitful people can get things done, you'll end up tricking not just your enemy, but also yourself.

You'll start to believe your own lies. ¡§Move with advantage."

This bit of text also has multiple possible meanings. What's your understanding of the word 'advantage?' Does it just mean 'Anything that might benefit you?' But if you're prepared to move at the first sight of benefit, aren't you liable to be tricked into moving if your enemy uses the illusion of benefit to fool you? So, 'advantage' means 'Something that is actually beneficial to you.' You should only move when doing so benefits you along the road to victory. You might think, 'Well, that's pretty obvious!

Of course you should only move when it's of benefit to you. It goes without saying, doesn't it?'
Actually, it does need to be said. That's because our failure to put into practice the principle of only moving when it gives you an advantage is our biggest weakness. So often, we move not because we stand to gain any real advantage, but because we feel anxious or under pressure, or because of greed or anger. The 'advantage principle' is the most important tenet to put into practice whenever we're trying to get something done. Don't preoccupy yourself with the past - no matter what might have happened before, the only thing you need to get a firm grip on is how to take your next step in a way that gives you an advantage.

'Moving with advantage' doesn't mean moving at the first sight of an advantage. It's about only moving if doing so actually gives you an advantage. It's just a few words, and yet the vast majority of people will never, in their whole life, successfully put them into practice.

Otherwise, what business would these words have being part of Sun Tzu's The Art of War? ¡§Change by dividing and consolidating."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Each act of division and each consolidation is a change undertaken in light of the enemy's situation."
Changing an army by 'division and consolidation' is exactly the same thing as allocating main and auxiliary forces. In the vocabulary of The Art of War, this is also known as 'the art of division,' and the overarching term for this strategy is 'dividing and consolidating the main and auxiliary.' Duke Li of Wei said: ¡§If your troops are scattered, consolidate them into an auxiliary force; if your troops are consolidated, divide them into an auxiliary force.

Thus, repeatedly ordering your forces to consolidate and divide, you return into the main."
¡§In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand." This plays a role similar to the feint in soccer.

It's not actually the foundation of the art of war, and it's definitely not part of the art of war's core value system. 'Moving with advantage' doesn't mean moving at the first sight of a possible benefit; it's about only moving when doing so brings you some kind of advantage. Wind, Forest, Fire, Mountain ¡V Takeda Shingen's version of Sun Tzu's The Art of War

Extract from the original text:
¡§Let your rapidity be that of the wind, your compactness that of the forest. In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire; in immovability, like a mountain."

Analysis:
These four lines have had a bigger impact in Japan than any other part of Sun Tzu's The Art of War. I say this because, during Japan's Sengoku period of prolonged war between feudal states (1467-1615 CE), a feudal lord named Takeda Shingen had these lines written in gold lettering upon a piece of cyan cloth, and he made this his battle flag.

It was known as the 'Flag of Sun Tzu.'
Let's start by looking at what these lines mean. ¡§Let your rapidity be that of the wind."

Li Quan comments: ¡§This is about advancing and retreating. When you advance, leave no trace of yourself; when you retreat, move with the utmost speed."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is about striking at emptiness."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Advance with explosive speed, and you will sweep away all in your path."
So, 'let your rapidity be that of the wind' has two parts: attacking and retreating. When you attack, be as fast as the wind, and when you retreat, leave no trace. Cao Cao adds on an extra meaning, which is that you should 'strike at emptiness.' This means that you need to be able to judge the enemy's weak and strong points, to do what they least expect - to attack them where they're unprepared, and to avoid their strong points while striking their weak points. If you do all this, you will sweep away all in your path, and you will be as fast as the wind.

¡§Let your compactness be that of the forest."

This line is talking about battle lines drawn up as neatly and tidily as the trees in a forest. If you move slowly and deliberately, there will be no gaps in your lines for your enemy to exploit.

Li Quan comments: ¡§Making your battle lines orderly, and then moving." You can imagine it like this: an entire army in battle formation, moving as a single unit, like a forest full of trees swaying. The army advances slowly and quietly, embodying a powerful sense of constriction, like being inside a huge forest. Du Mu comments: ¡§'Compactness' is about being slow and steady. When ordering the army to move slowly and steadily, the ranks and columns must be like trees in a forest, in case the enemy may attempt a surprise attack."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is for times when there is no advantage to see." This echoes the line from the previous passage about 'moving with advantage.' If you haven't yet been able to identify the enemy's weak and strong points, and if you haven't seen any opportunity to attack that would give you the advantage, you should move slowly and cautiously. Du You comments: ¡§Do not move forward if you see no advantage.

Be like a forest when the wind blows through it, making some small movements, but no big ones."

¡§In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire."

When moving in for the attack, be like a raging fire. Li Quan comments: ¡§Be like a blazing inferno burning across a prairie; leave not a single blade of grass unburned." His addition of 'leave not a single blade of grass' is telling us that the enemy should be left with nowhere to run and no way to resist.

Not a single enemy soldier should be allowed to escape. Lin Biao's 'three ferocities' - fight ferociously, charge ferociously and pursue ferociously - are a modern equivalent to this line from Sun Tzu. Cao Cao's comment repeats what he said earlier: ¡§It is about being fast."

¡§In immovability, be like a mountain."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about holding a defensive position." When your army is not in motion, it should be like a mountain: unshakeable. A text by the ancient philosopher Xunzi, entitled A Debate about Warfare, says this: ¡§When holding a position, form strong lines on all sides, and you will become like a massive boulder; whatever beast may charge you, its horns shall shatter upon impact."
The metaphor of 'wind, forest, fire and mountain' is about using speed, as well as caution. The ancient military text, the Wei Liaozi, says: ¡§In heaviness, be like the mountains and the forests; in lightness, be like fire and cannon smoke." So, when attacking and withdrawing, be like wind and fire, and when you're not moving, be like the mountains and forests. How should we understand 'wind, forest, fire and mountain' from the perspective of Takeda Shingen?

For him, there were two levels to being as swift as the wind. The first level was about how he used cavalry. He had the best cavalry in all of Japan, and he typically began his battles with a cavalry charge. The second level was about strategy and infrastructure, which had two main parts.

The first part was beacon towers used for communicating signals. Takeda Shingen built a dense network of signal towers radiating out in all directions from his base in Kai Province. If anything unusual happened in his border territories, smoke of various colors would be used to report to Takeda Shingen, enabling him to react, and possibly mobilize troops, at the fastest possible speed. The second part was his famous road system, known as the Shingen Bomichi roads. Kai Province is located in mountainous terrain, so Shingen Takeda built nine extremely straight roads that allowed his armies could move more effectively. All nine roads led directly to major war zones.

So, with the support of information and transport infrastructure, Shingen Takeda's armies were able to move as swiftly as the wind. What about the second part, 'Letting your compactness be that of the forest?' Again, there were two levels.

First, this relates to Takeda Shingens' rifle units. Each soldier in these units carried a long gun, between four and six meters in length. When these rifles were held upright, the unit would have looked just like a forest.

These units would move slowly, and they were a potent weapon against enemy cavalry forces. The second level is about the army as a whole - when ordering his men to move out, they did so in perfect order, moving fluidly and serenely, as a single unit. Moving on to the next line - 'In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire' - for Takeda Shingen, this was first about charging the enemy with irresistible force, like a blazing wildfire surging over grasslands. Secondly, it was about his system for organizing his army and communicating commands.

The idea was to be able to command his forces so seamlessly that it was as if they were an extension of his own arm, moving wherever he pointed his finger. Next, we have 'In immovability, be like a mountain.' First of all, for Takeda Shingen, this was about how he conducted himself as an individual. No matter how intense the situation around him might be, he would be able to rise above the flames of battle and continue directing his army.

It was about being untouched by the commotion around him. Even if enemy soldiers advanced right up to where he sat, he wouldn't so much as stand up - he would let his bodyguards kill the attackers. This is about the commander being immoveable and the army's battle flag remaining untouched.

This is the way to keep your soldiers' hearts steady, and to fill them with the courage to kill the enemy. The next part of 'immovability' is about the discipline of Takeda Shingen's army, and the way he managed his battle lines. Every member of his army would be positioned according to his own, specific role, and if anyone showed the slightest sign of non-compliance, they were dealt with by martial law. This meant that no matter what kind of attack Takeda Shingen's enemies might try, his troops never wavered, never left their position in the army's battle lines, and never allowed the enemy to affect them. So, from Takeda Shingen himself, down the hierarchy to every single member of his army, the whole organization was as immovable as a mountain. Next, it's time to look at how this passage relates to Takeda Shingen's strategy. He never acted without thinking through the possible consequences, and he never allowed the enemy's attempts to probe him provoke him into action.

He moved in step with his own rhythm - slowly and steadily, like the trees in a forest, and immovable like a mountain. Yet, as soon as an opportunity presented itself, he would strike with the speed of the wind and the raging intensity of fire. Wind, forest, fire and mountain - through these elements, Takeda Shingen brought Sun Tzu's The Art of War into the real word in a very big way. Takeda Shingen practically worshipped Sun Tzu. In a television drama series filmed by Japanese public broadcaster NHK, entitled Takeda Shingen, there is an episode in which a Chinese Buddhist monk visits Kai Province, Takeda Shingen's stronghold. Takeda Shingen invites the monk into his home, and recites these passages of The Art of War to him, in Japanese:
¡§sono?haya kikoto?kaze nokotoku,? sono?shizu kanarukoto?hayashinokotoku,?

shingyaku surukoto?hi nokotoku,? ugo kazarukotono yamano."
Then, Takeda Shingen made a request of the Chinese monk:
¡§Would you recite for me the words in Chinese, so that I may know how they sound?" 
The monk courteously accepted, and began to recite the words in a soft voice:
¡§qi ji ru feng,
qi xu ru lin,
qinlue ru huo,
bu dong ru shan."
Takeda Shingen closed his eyes, immersed deeply in his enjoyment of these heaven-sent sounds. The military practice of looting: An army's 'unofficial welfare benefit'

Any organization is always going to need some kind of benefits.

But, the problem with official benefits is that people feel that they're entitled to them. And then, as soon as they begin taking them for granted, the benefits' incentive mechanism breaks down or even goes into reverse, encouraging laziness.

So, you're always going to need a few unofficial sources of benefits - an occasional, pleasant surprise to incentivize your people and crank up their enthusiasm. Extract from the original text:
¡§Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt.

When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men; when you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men. Ponder and deliberate before you make a move.

He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct. Such is the art of armed struggle."

Analysis:
¡§Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night." Be like dark clouds covering up the sky, so that the sun, moon and stars become invisible, and their movements impossible to measure. ¡§When you move, fall like a thunderbolt."

Lord Jiang Ziya said: ¡§Be like thunder that comes so quickly that there is no time to cover your ears; be like the lightning that strikes before you can blink your eyes."
Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about attacking as if striking from the empty sky above, so that the enemy does not know how to evade you."

¡§Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt." 

When the sky is filled with dark clouds, nobody can see the sun, moon or stars, and your enemy cannot tell which cloud harbors thunder and lightning behind it. Behind the cloud layer, the hunter's eyes look down from on high, unseen yet seeing all.

When a lightning bolt suddenly cleaves the sky, there is nowhere to hide, and no time to react. ¡§When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men."

To put this line simply, it's about sharing the wealth, so that everyone gets a piece of the pie. 'Plundering a countryside' means robbing local landowners, but also the common people of your enemy's country. Once your army arrives in the enemy's lands, you move through the villages, plundering as you go.

What kinds of things do you take? You might take grain and other food, other useful items or tools, livestock such as chickens, ducks, pigs, sheep, cows and horses, and you might also take children, women, silk and gold. Food and other resources are things that every army needs, and indeed, Sun Tzu writes about this specifically in Waging War: ¡§Hence a wise general makes a point of obtaining food from the enemy. One zhong of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own, and likewise a single picul of his fodder is equivalent to twenty from one's own store." As for captured children, women, gold and silk, these are to be divided among the officers and troops, with everyone getting a share of the wealth, slaves and women. ¡§Let the spoil be divided amongst your men."

This just means that everything should be shared, so that every man in the army has the chance to get his hands on something.

There's no risk involved in plundering villages, and it can bring in lucrative profits. This cushy job shouldn't be given to just one unit; it's important that every man in your army gets the chance to join in.

Everyone can get rich together! Plundering was an unwritten convention of ancient warfare. It's certainly one of the uglier parts of army life, but it was an important incentive mechanism. Whenever you hear about disciplined, well-behaved armies that leave the common people alone, this is because there's some higher political ambition driving them.

They already consider the common folk of the enemy's country to be their own compatriots; they need to be looked after, and made ready to become future subjects of their new lord. But when a war is a simple conflict between two states, with the only aim being to extract some benefit from the enemy, there's no need to treat the enemy's people nicely, and they become just another part of the spoils of war, to be divided up between the officers and common soldiers. It's similar to the Chinese Communist Party's early 'mass struggle movements' against landlords in the 1950s.

If you were a landlord, you essentially had a big label on your face saying 'class enemy,' and that meant you'd be swept away as if you were dust, with absolutely no mercy. Then, all the villagers, having just overthrown the local landlords, would take part in claiming the 'spoils of war.' Every family got to take home part of the wealth.

One effect of this was that, even if you only took an old iron cooking pot, you'd become a part of the Communist revolution. For over 2,000 years, China and the Xiongnu people from the north fought each other.

When the northerners ventured down into China for a new round of war, plundering was their only goal. From the perspective of a Xiongnu leader, the warriors riding with you are following you because they want plunder, and you need to make sure that opportunities to plunder, as well as the actual spoils of war, are distributed in fair and rational way. Otherwise, your band of warriors will start fighting one another, and your army will collapse in on itself.

Generation after generation of successful generals who lived through times of war had one thing in common: they were all extremely fair in the way they divided up the spoils of war. But, how do you actually put fairness into practice?

It's not at all easy, because people are prone to believe that they haven't been treated fairly, even if it's not true. If everyone thinks they're getting shortchanged, then, essentially, 'fairness' doesn't even exist.

One general had a solution - he would not take a single bit of the spoils of war for himself. He decided he would only take what the Emperor saw fit to give him, and leave everything that came from the battlefield to be divided up among the soldiers.

That way, nobody could complain to him. War can be divided into two different types. The first can be called 'invasions,' which are characterized by plundering. The second can be called 'campaigns,' examples of which include the Chinese Nationalists' Northern Expedition (1926-1928 CE), and Zhuge Liang's nine campaigns into China's Central Plain region. The goal behind 'invasions' is to gain some kind of benefit, like plunder and territory.

Invasions aren't meant to bring down and replace the enemy state; they're simply about plundering and seizing some advantage, or perhaps beating the enemy into submission so that they have to sue for peace. That naturally involves them paying you, in the form of ritualized tribute offerings.

'Campaigns' are quite different. They're built around political objectives. In Chinese, the word for 'campaign' - which can also be a verb meaning 'to campaign against somebody' - has a root meaning of 'to chop down trees.' During a military campaign, you chop down the trees outside the enemy's temples, ancestral shrines and graveyards. Once all the trees are down, you level the buildings, overthrow the enemy state and take your place as ruler of all the land.

So, 'campaigns' are about cutting down the enemy's power, their culture and their symbols. Then, you build up your own power system, and your own symbols. During China's Cultural Revolution (1966-1976 CE), the Confucian temples were destroyed.

Even if you've already gained power, you still have to keep on cutting down the old powers. As the cycle of warfare and chaos came full circle, time and again throughout history, bandits and thieves roamed the land, and feudal lords fought each other for supremacy.

The way to identify a leader who has grander ambitions - for instance, someone who dreams of ruling the entire known world - is to watch out for armies that don't plunder, and that leave the common people undisturbed. One example would be Li Zicheng, a rebel leader who launched his bid for supremacy during the final years of the Ming dynasty, and who called himself 'The Roaming King.' He was known for his slogan: 'The Roaming King isn't here to take your grain!' He successfully captured Beijing, but then he fell back into his old ways - he forgot that he was in Beijing on a military campaign, and not as an invader.

He took the local children, women and valuables, and shared them with his soldiers. This paved the way for Wu Sangui, the general who helped establish the Qing dynasty, to lead Manchu soldiers through the mountains and toward Beijing from the northeast. Let's talk some more about 'plundering the countryside, and dividing the spoils amongst the men.' Cao Cao wrote a comment on this line, but it's quite vague: ¡§Find a way to victory based on the enemy's situation." Cao Cao isn't really saying anything here.

Bearing in mind that he was a leader of soldiers and also a prime minister, it's likely that he didn't want people to hear him talking about these things. By contrast, Du You's comment is very specific: ¡§If the enemy's villages and towns are undefended and their livestock and wealth easily available to plunder, then this plunder must be divided in an orderly manner, so that every member of your forces obtains some part of it. You must not allocate everything to one recipient.

Thus, everyone, from the young to the old, the weak to the strong, will want to participate in war and gain some advantage for themselves." It's important to make sure that everyone gets opportunities, and that no single army unit keeps all of the loot.

If you can do this, everyone will be enthusiastic. When Zeng Guofan spoke about the art of being a good general, he emphasized that it's important for generals to be incorruptible. Ordinary soldiers might not understand the finer points of military strategy, but they can all understand where the money is.

If the general is greedy for money, or if he's cutting his men out of the spoils and keeping them all for himself, his soldiers will never willingly give up their lives for him. But, if you're uncorrupt and clean, and make sure you have something nice to give your troops every now and then, every one of your men will gladly follow you and kill your enemies. We're now getting to the part about 'unofficial welfare benefits.' Any organization is always going to need some kind of benefits.

The problem with official benefits is that people feel they're entitled to them, and as soon as they begin taking them for granted, the benefits' incentive mechanism breaks down or even goes into reverse, encouraging laziness.

So, you're always going to need a few unofficial sources of benefits - an occasional, pleasant surprise to incentivize your people and crank up their enthusiasm, as well as to keep things interesting for them. ¡§When you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men."

The meaning of this line is basically the same as: ¡§When you plunder a countryside, let the spoils be divided amongst your men." The difference is that the 'spoils of war' are for sharing with the common soldiers, while new territory is to be divided up among the senior generals, especially those who've made a big contribution to the war effort.

It's essentially about giving out land and noble titles. Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about sharing benefits gained from the enemy."

¡§Ponder and deliberate before you make a move."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about gauging the enemy's situation before engaging in plunder."
The Wei Liaozi said this: ¡§Ponder the enemy and evaluate your generals before taking action."
In the original Chinese text, the idea of 'ponder' is expressed with the image of hanging up a steelyard weight, part of an ancient scale used for weighing objects. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Weigh the enemy so that you know how light or heavy he is, evaluate your generals' ability or lack thereof, and then determine to take action."

¡§He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct.

Such is the art of armed struggle."

After you've worked out whether the enemy is a heavyweight or a lightweight, and where his weak and strong points are, consider the terrain and then plan out how to apply the stratagem of 'turning the circuitous into the direct.' Within this is another principle: in armed struggle, strive to position yourself ahead of your enemy. The command system makes the army

It doesn't matter how many soldiers you have in your army - if you don't have a command system, it's not an army.

It's just a swirling mass of blind men. That's why the saying goes, 'A general in the field might not hear all of his king's orders,' and not 'A general in the field might not obey all of his commander's battle orders.' Any army officer who defied orders from his superiors would soon find his body separated from his head. Extract from the original text:
¡§The Book of Army Management says: On the field of battle, the spoken word does not carry far enough: hence the institution of gongs and drums.

Nor can ordinary objects be seen clearly enough: hence the institution of banners and flags. Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point. The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone.

This is the art of handling large masses of men. In night-fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army."

Analysis:
The Book of Army Management was an ancient Chinese military text, but it is now lost to history. Part of what is known about it today, from instances where it was quoted in other writings, is a passage that reads: ¡§At times it is not possible to hear one another's voices.

That is why we have drums and gongs. At times it is not possible to see one another; that is why we have flags and banners." 
Gongs and drums serve as an alternative command system. Ancient gongs were made of bronze, which produced a resonant, percussive sound like 'DANG,' powerful enough to send vibrations through people's bodies. Ancient war drums were made from cowhide, and emitted an energizing, blood-pumping 'DONG' sound. In their simplest usage, drumbeats were the signal to attack, while the gong was used to signal retreat.

But, there were also many other signals, and many other instruments, such as bugles and horns, each used to send different kinds of information. In situations where soldiers and officers couldn't see one another, flags were used to relay commands. Many different colors and patterns were used, each with a different role in communicating. There was also a whole system of 'flag language,' with different movements and gestures used to convey various kinds of information about battle commands or the enemy's situation. Flags were a visual communication tool; a way of using signals to give commands. ¡§Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point.

The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone. This is the art of handling large masses of men."

If you have gongs, drums and signal flags, you can make your entire army see and hear the same thing at the same time, and move as a single, coordinated unit. The bravest among your warriors can't charge the enemy on their own if you haven't ordered them to, and the less brave among your men can't retreat unless you give the order.

This is how to command a large army in battle. Under strict military discipline, 'Any man who, upon being ordered to advance, does not advance, or who, upon being ordered to retreat, does not retreat, shall be executed.' There is a story relating to this from the ancient commander Wuzi's war against the state of Qin. As the two armies stood facing one another, before the fighting had begun, one soldier couldn't contain his fighting spirit, and charged the enemy on his own.

He killed two enemy soldiers, cut off their heads, and took them back to his comrades. Wuzi executed that man. One of Wuzi's officers had his own opinion about this, which he expressed to the commander: ¡§That man clearly is a person of considerable ability! Why not give him a chance to make up for his crime?" But Wuzi replied: ¡§Military discipline is not concerned with distinctions between men of ability and men without ability."
A general in the field might not hear all of his king's orders, but it is absolutely unacceptable for anyone to ignore commands given on the battlefield. That is how serious battle commands are.

So, suppose you're an officer leading a battle unit in a pursuit movement. Judging from the situation in front of you, you're only moments away from catching the enemy, but then you hear the sound of gongs from behind. In this moment, you absolutely have to retreat, even if it means letting the enemy get away.

This is because it's not your job to give commands - you don't know what the overall situation is across all parts of the battlefield. ¡§In night-fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army."

There's a story from the Spring and Autumn period that's well known by Chinese readers. It involves Cao Gui, a general from the state of Lu who is famous for his theoretical approach during the battle of Changshao, a conflict between the neighboring states of Lu and Qi.

After a round of fighting between the two armies, the Qi army was second best, and began to retreat. Duke Zhuang of Lu wanted to pursue the fleeing enemy, but Cao Gui urged him to wait. Cao clambered up onto a chariot and spent some time surveying the scene.

Eventually, he said that now was a good time to pursue, and so that's exactly what the Lu troops did. They chased the enemy for 30 li, killing as they went. After it was all over, Duke Zhuang asked Cao Gui what his reasoning had been. Cao Gui said that although the enemy seemed to be defeated and retreating, he was concerned that they might have laid an ambush. But, then he saw that the enemy chariots were moving chaotically, and that the enemy flags had fallen on the ground.

That was how he knew it was safe to start chasing them. What does it mean if the enemy battle flags have fallen? It means that they no longer have a command system, and that their soldiers are all fleeing for their lives.

It's become an 'every man for himself' scenario. At this point, you could say that the enemy army is no longer an army; it's turned into a torrent of blind men. So, it's safe to give chase. Of course, it's also possible to be tricked even when the enemy's flags are in a mess.

You might think that their command system has broken down, but it's possible that they're using gongs and drums to send secret signals, and that abandoning their flags was all part of their plan to trick you. In Du Mu's comment on this passage, he talks about how fires and drums were used in army camps during nighttime: ¡§When the army has halted, they are used to set camp; when the army is marching, they are used to set formation." The logic behind setting up camp in the evening is more or less the same as that behind marching during the day. When marching, within the formation of the army as a whole, you need to organize men in smaller units of ranks and columns.

Likewise, a large army camp is made up of many smaller 'sub-camps.' The different parts of the army - forward, rear, left and right - set their tents in concentric circles. The commander-in-chief's encampment is located in the dead center of the camp, encircled by the other camps, which together formed an interlocking and symmetrical pattern, a bit like star constellations in the night sky. Each of the small camps would be positioned between 50 and 100 paces apart, with pathways connecting them.

The space between these camps would be large enough for the army to easily exit the camp and form up in battle formation. The camps were also close enough to each other that if one camp was attacked, soldiers in the neighboring camp could help their comrades by shooting at the enemy from behind their camp's fortifications. In each place where two pathways intersect, a raised earthwork would be built - with firewood laid on top and trenches dug underneath - where soldiers would be stationed to keep watch. If the enemy tried to raid the camp during the night, the watchmen would wait for them to enter the camp, and then sound the drums.

Soldiers from each of the camps would respond at the same time, lighting all the prepared firewood and turning the night as light as day. Soldiers were not allowed to run about on their own, but had to line up in battle formation, forming walls blocking the enemy's exit.

That way, it would be clear that any men left running around in a disorderly fashion were enemy soldiers. Then, archers would climb up to high positions and shoot the enemy soldiers until there were none left standing.

Any invader venturing inside the camp would never leave alive. This is exactly how Zhuge Liang planned his camps: they were like nets set out to trap the enemy. When he finally retreated, abandoning his camp, Sima Yi went to see what he could learn from his enemy's camp design, and apparently sighed: ¡§Genius! This truly is a wonder of the world."

¡§A whole army may be robbed of its spirit; a commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind."

Analysis:
¡§A whole army may be robbed of its spirit." This is about attacking the morale of the enemy troops, so that all their energy and momentum turns into sluggish dejection.

When an army loses morale, it also loses its strength, and so its battle capability goes out the window, too. The American psychologist David Myers put forward a 'fatigue motivation theory' that can be used to explain issues about the connection between troop morale and battle capability. According to his theory, the human body's energy store is a constant, but people allocate themselves different amounts of energy each day, based on their needs and their level of motivation.

If their motivation is strong, they allocate more energy. Conversely, if they have a low level of motivation, they allocate a smaller amount of energy. The most famous historical example of an army being robbed of its 'spirit' is one we just mentioned, in which Cao Gui explained his methods to his lord at the battle of Changshao, fought between the states of Lu and Qi. As the two armies faced off, the Qi drums began beating, and Duke Zhuang of Lu immediately became eager to get the fighting started.

But Cao Gui raised his voice: ¡§Not yet!" He held the army's battle lines in an iron grip, and let it be known that anyone who broke formation would be executed. The Qi army charged the Lu battle lines, but when they were unable to break through, they retreated, re-gathered their flags and drums, and then came again.

But still, the Lu army wouldn't charge. After three rounds of drumming by the Qi drummers, the Lu army finally began beating their own drums, and charged the enemy, thoroughly beating them. Later, when Duke Lu asked Cao Gui to explain his reasoning, Cao Gui said: ¡§Any kind of fighting always involves courage. The first round of drumming builds up soldiers' energy; in the second round, the enemy begins to deflate; and in the third round, the soldiers enter a state of rest. I make sure that when the enemy is resting, my energy is in full flow; that is why I can defeat my enemy." 
After one round of drumming, the Qi soldiers were pumped up and ready to go, but the Lu army ignored them and refused to engage. After three rounds of drumming, the Qi soldiers couldn't keep their excitement going - they lost their energy. Meanwhile, the Lu soldiers had conserved their energy, and now they were ready to unleash it.

This is how you engineer a situation where the enemy is resting, while you're overflowing with energy. There's another, similar historical example, from the final years of the Three Kingdoms period, involving Sima Yi's son, Sima Shi.

A Wei general named Wen Xin had rebelled against the state, so Sima Shi took an army to deal with him. Wen Xin put his son, Wen Yang, in charge of his whole army, even though Wen Yang was just 18 years old.

Wen Yang told his father: ¡§The enemy army has to travel a very long way to come here. I'm going to hit them as soon as they arrive, before they have the chance to get settled. That's how we can beat them." The boy's father didn't say anything, so when the two armies were lined up facing one another, Wen Yang got the drums beating. Amid deafening noise, the men shouted, ¡§Let's kill the enemy!" But three rounds of drumming went by, and still Wen Xin didn't give the order. Wen Yang was forced to retreat east, along with his father.

When Sima Shi saw the enemy retreating, he said: ¡§Wen Xin's going to run! Quick, chase him!" But his officers replied: ¡§Wen Yang's a fierce commander - if he's running away before the fight's even begun, it might mean he's laid an ambush for us." But Sima Shi had the last say: ¡§After the first round of drumming, the energy peaks, after the second round it begins to diminish, and after the third round it is depleted. Wen Yang beat his drum three times, but Wen Xin didn't respond.

Wen Yang's men will now have no energy left, so what are we waiting for?"
The Wei army gave chase, and dealt a major defeat to Wen Xin. When a leader has inner power, their team's energy and momentum are unstoppable
