¡§A commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind."

Analysis:
Du Mu comments: ¡§The heart - it is upon the general's heart that the entire army relies." It might not matter much if one soldier in an army is a coward, but a general's cowardice can infect the whole army.

'Robbing a general's presence of mind' means probing at and undermining the enemy general's resolve, because if he loses his resolve his army will fall apart. Our historical example for this subchapter is one we discussed in Chapter Three, about attacking and sabotaging the enemy's plans.

It's the story of Kou Xun's campaign against Kui Xiao, during the time of the Eastern Han dynasty. One of Kui Xiao's senior generals, Gao Jun, who was in charge of holding a certain city, sent one of his officers, Huang Puwen, to visit Kou Xun as an emissary. However, when Huang Puwen refused to submit to Kou Xun or to pay his respects, Kou Xun immediately had him executed, and then sent Huang Puwen's deputy back to Gao Jun to tell him to surrender. The next day, Gao Jun opened the gates of his city and surrendered.

Kou Xun's officers asked him to explain how this had happened. Kou Xun replied: ¡§Huang Puwen was the brains of Gao Jun's whole operation; it was he who did Gao Jun's planning and strategizing. When he came here, he was unyielding and defiant - it was clear that he could not be convinced to surrender.

If I had let him go back to Gao Jun, his planning abilities would have been put to work for Gao Jun. But, by killing him, I could rob Gao Jun of his courage and make him surrender."
So, by executing a single man, Huang Puwen, Kou Xun was attacking Gao Jun's planning capabilities. A commander can be robbed of his presence of mind - in this case, killing the one man Gao Jun relied on was enough to rob him of his presence of mind.

For our second historical example, we turn to the Uprising of the Five Barbarian Peoples during the Sixteen Kingdoms period (304-439 CE). Specifically, let's look at the war between Tuoba Gui of Northern Wei and Murong Bao of the Later Yan.

As their two armies faced one another across a river, Tuoba Gui received intelligence that Murong Bao's father, Emperor Murong Chui, had fallen ill at around the time that Murong Bao had deployed his forces. So, Tuoba Gui cut off the Later Yan army's communication lines, so they would be unable to receive news from home. Later, Tuoba Gui's forces captured a Former Yan messenger, and forced him to shout across the river to Murong Bao: ¡§Your father is dead. You need to go home, now!" When Murong Bao heard this, he was overcome with worry and snuck out with his forces under the cover of night, heading homeward.

Tuoba Gui chased him, and defeated the Later Yan army at the Battle of Canhe Slope. Sima Fa wrote: ¡§The mind is set in an original state, but it can be defeated after an influx of new energy."
Duke Li of Wei wrote: ¡§In attack, one must not only attack the enemy's fortifications and battle lines; it is essential to possess the skill to attack his mind."
If you want to rob someone of his presence of mind, there's a precondition" you need to have inner mental power. For a leader to be able to build up his team's energy, he must have the ability to strengthen his own mind.

When the leader's mind is strong, his team becomes truly powerful, like a force of nature. Force makes for a long war; Energy brings victory

Force can't last for long, which is why it's impossible to have a constantly overflowing supply of energy. It's important to be constantly aware of your energy and how to tend to it, and to know how to tend to your team's energy.

As for whether it's possible to influence other people's energy... since we're not in a war, it's best to focus on ourselves. There's no point to occupying your thoughts with other people when you haven't yet taken care of yourself. Extract from the original text:
¡§Now a soldier's spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp.

A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return. This is the art of studying moods."

Analysis:
¡§Now a soldier's spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp."
In simple terms, morning is the best time to get things done. Morning is the time when mental energy is at its fullest; by noon, it begins to decline, and by evening all you're thinking about is heading home for the day. There's a passage in The Methods of Sima that reads: ¡§New energy defeats old energy."
Chen Hao comments: ¡§When new energy first arrives, it is full and sharp; do not fight someone in this state." When the enemy is flush with new energy, stay out of his way, and don't try to fight him. Let him stew for a while. Meng Shi comments: ¡§Morning energy is the energy of beginnings; noon energy is the energy of continuing work; evening energy is the energy of decline." The meaning is the same as ¡§The first round of drumming builds up the energy, with the second round of drumming the energy begins to deflate, and with the third round, the energy is depleted."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Morning - here he speaks of beginnings; noon - here he speaks of the midpoint; evening - here he speaks of endings. He says that one's energy is sharp in the beginning, but after a while one's energy declines and one's thoughts turn to returning home.

This is the time when one may attack." The reason why it's important to pursue the enemy when they are withdrawing is because the enemy soldiers are all thinking about going home. This means that they don't have the will to fight, and the time is ripe to wipe them out.

So, in fact, the ideas of 'morning, noon and evening' used here don't correspond directly with the specific times of day that they seem to refer to, but represent a progression of three stages. ¡§A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return.

This is the art of studying moods."

Skilled generals stay well out of the enemy's way while they're still in the first flush of sharp, hard-edged energy, and wait for them to lose their edge, and for their thoughts to turn to home. That's when the skilled general attacks.

This is the way to manipulate energy. In the aftermath of the collapse of the Sui dynasty (581-618 CE), among three main contenders vying for the throne, it was Li Shimin who would eventually triumph and become the first Emperor of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Taizong. During his struggle for supremacy, he went on the warpath against another contender, Wang Shichong.

This was a worrying development for the other contender, a general named Dou Jiande, because if Wang Shichong fell, the delicate equilibrium between the three of them would break down. So, Dou Jiande moved out with a large army to help Wang Shichong fight Li Shimin. He lined his soldiers up along the eastern bank of the Si River, and his army was so large that it stretched for miles.

A powerful energy hummed through the ranks. From a nearby mountainside, Li Shimin looked down at the enemy. Turning to his officers, he said: ¡§The traitor army is poised and dangerous, but they have no government giving them instructions.

We will keep our lines close to the city walls - this will put my heart at ease. We will hold our position, and we will not go out to meet the enemy, but wait for enough time to pass that their soldiers grow tired and hungry.

Then, they are sure to withdraw. As soon as they withdraw, we will move out and pursue them, and then we shall be able to defeat them in a single battle."
Dou Jiande kept his troops in formation from six o'clock in the morning until noon. They became tired and hungry, and some of them sat down on the ground, while others took breaks to drink water. Li Shimin saw this, and shouted: ¡§Now is the time to strike!" The two sides fought a battle, and by the end, Dou Jiande was Li Shimin's prisoner. In chains, Dou Jiande was brought before Li Shimin.

The victorious Li asked his prisoner: ¡§Originally, I set out to fight Wang Shichong. There was no need for you to be involved - it had nothing to do with you - so why did you travel so far to be here today?"
¡§I thought I'd deliver myself right to your door, and save you the trouble of making a long trip just to come get me." As soon as these words came out of Dou Jiande's mouth, any residual angry energy disappeared. ¡§Force makes for a long war; energy brings victory." Force can't be kept up for long, which means it's impossible for your energy stores to always be full.

Properly managing your energy - maintaining the sharp, powerful energy of the morning - is the key, for both individual people and for teams. We need to keep observing our teammates and ourselves. When we first set out on a new endeavor, we don't let our standards slip, and each of us puts our full energy into our work. This is the meaning of 'morning energy' or 'sharp energy.'
After working like this for 10-20 years, we have no more financial pressure to deal with, or at least, much less. We have a family, and now it's time to enjoy life.

Once you reach this point, it's possible that you might not have the awareness or the ability to take the next step upward. If you can't find new value for yourself, and a new way of expressing that value, you won't be able to transition upward to the next stage, and you'll find yourself confronted with sluggish, lazy energy. If this lazy energy keeps growing, it will turn into 'evening energy,' and you break down as a person until you effectively become waste for the trash heap. We need to keep reflecting on ourselves, keep our energy sharp at all times, hold on to our true, individual nature and fulfill our life duties.

Once we reach the point where we have less energy than we did in our youth, we have to focus our 'sharp energy,' stay committed to our position on the front line, and stay connected to the earth's energy. We must also begin to transition upward to the next stage, moving from working on our own self-realization to helping other people become who they are meant to be.

It's necessary to have a constant awareness of managing energy - not only your own, personal energy, but also the energy of your team. As for whether it's possible to influence other people's energy, since we're not in a war, it's best to focus on ourselves.

There's no point occupying your thoughts with other people when you haven't yet taken care of yourself. Managing your own mind - The root of everything

¡§Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy: this is the art of retaining self-possession. To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well fed while the enemy is famished: this is the art of husbanding one's strength. To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array: this is the art of managing changes."

Analysis:
¡§Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy: this is the art of retaining self-possession."
Use your discipline and orderliness to wait for the enemy to fall into chaos. Use your calm to wait for the enemy to become agitated and loud.

This is how to manage your mind. Du Mu comments: ¡§Sima Fa Said, 'The mind is set in an original state.' Understanding the enemy is the way to win. Although your mind may be already set in a certain state, you can make adjustments and manage it, making yourself calm, sturdy and immune to annoyances and temptations. Wait for the enemy to descend into disorder and confusion, and then send out troops to strike him."
What exactly does Du Mu mean by the words 'disorder' and 'confusion?' Chen Hao comments: ¡§Disorder is when the government gives contradictory commands and there is no clarity in the system of rewards and punishments. Confusion is when the flags are jumbled and troops make much noise and act recklessly while on the march.

If you detect these things in your enemy, then it is time to move your forces and strike."
He Shi comments: ¡§Every general stands alone, in body and in mind, and alone, must take a great, confused array of things deep into his mind: uniting hundreds of thousands of troops, standing against ferocious, pitiless enemies; making sense of a tangle of dangers and potential advantages, untying victory from defeat, keeping track of the many, minute variations in power and knowledge.

He must take these things inside himself without becoming lost within their vast spaces; he must allow no trace of disorder into his heart. How can he make himself endlessly adaptable to changing situations?

How can he not get lost in details while dealing with all manner of things? How can he maintain composure when suddenly faced with a great disaster? How can he maintain a clear mind while dealing with everything?

Self-management is all that is needed to deal with confusion. Even if a million enemy soldiers are arrayed before you, if you see them properly, then it will be no different to facing a small raiding force.

When Yafu encountered a raiding party, he obstinately refused to get up from bed; When Luan Cuan was about to go to battle, he used orderliness and leisure to good effect. If we are to evaluate these two cases, what stratagems did they use?

They are refined in the way that they conceal their wisdom, and they nurture their minds with the result that they have an abundance of wisdom."
This is brilliant commentary by He Shi. As a general, every move you make has an impact on huge amounts of wealth, human lives, perceptions of truth, ethics and the moral fiber of many people.

A leader's emotions have an impact on the morale of the entire organization, and they can interfere with the leader's decision-making and execution of plans. So many decisions are made because of pressure and anxiety.

This kind of decision, which often is rash and ill advised, is an attempt to find some relief from the pressure and anxiety. Either that, or it's a result of the leader's inability to 'maintain composure when suddenly faced with a great disaster.' When confronted with challenging and dangerous circumstances, they panic and lose all sense of the right way forward, and instead gallop off in the worst possible direction, towards certain doom. ¡§When Yafu encountered a raiding party, he obstinately refused to get up from bed." One night, while Zhou Yafu was dealing with the Rebellion of the Seven States, there was a sudden commotion in his camp, and he could hear chaos outside his tent - soldiers shouting and screaming.

So, what did he do about it? He stayed in bed, and went back to sleep. Eventually, the soldiers calmed down. There are four key points to grasp if you want to keep your team's battle capability at a high level: managing energy, managing minds, managing strength and managing changes. And, at the root of all of this is managing your own mind. ¡§To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well-fed while the enemy is famished: this is the art of husbanding one's strength."

Be the first to arrive at the battlefield, and wait while the enemy makes a long slog from afar to reach your location. While you relax and wait, taking your ease, the enemy wears himself out marching at speed towards you.

And, keep your belly full while the enemy goes hungry. These are all ways to 'manage strength' and to maintain battle capability. The reason Li Shimin held his troops in position and waited all morning, while Dou Jiande's troops stood in formation, ready for battle, was to force the enemy to lose its orderliness, freshness and calm, and fall into chaos, noise and exhaustion. At the beginning of the morning their bellies were full and they were not thirsty, but by the end of the morning their bellies were hungry and their throats were parched, and they'd used up the strength that they needed to be properly prepared for battle.

Duke Li of Wei stated that all of the thousands of pages written about The Art of War boil down to a single idea: 'Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.' In other words, seize the initiative and keep it firmly in your grasp. ¡§To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array: this is the art of managing changes."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The meaning of 'in calm and confident array' is that the enemy's army is very large."
Here, 'intercepting' means 'attacking.'
If the enemy's flags are neat and well ordered, and if their battle lines are powerful and imposing, then don't attack. Do some evasive maneuvering, and let the enemy use up some of their energy.

Wait until their 'sharp morning energy' has run out; wait until they're hungry, thirsty and have lost their excitement, and become full of 'lazy midday energy' and 'time-to-go-home evening energy.' Then it is time for you to attack. Once, while Cao Cao was besieging the city of Yecheng, a general named Yuan Shang made an attempt to break the siege from outside.

Cao Cao said: ¡§If he comes here along the main road, we should evade him. But if he comes from around the mountains to the west, he will soon be our prisoner." What was Cao Cao's reasoning? Basically, if Yuan Shang advanced along the main road, his army would be able to move 'in perfect order' and in 'calm and confident array.' They would be fearless, and it would not be possible for Cao Cao to beat them. There would have to be some significant change in circumstances in order for Cao Cao to prevail. But, if Yuan Shang chose the difficult path along the base of the mountains, his men would have to walk carefully, with eyes glued to the ground. They'd have a feeling of being unsure, and they wouldn't have much physical strength to call upon.

They would be easy targets. As it turned out, Yuan Shang did choose to advance around the western mountains, so Cao Cao wheeled his forces around, attacked him on the road and heavily defeated him. 'Managing changes' is a skill that's used to respond flexibly and effectively to developments in the enemy's circumstances. Even though Cao Cao was an extremely formidable general, he didn't take the threat posed by Yuan Shang lightly.

If Yuan Shang had arrived in 'perfect order,' Cao Cao was prepared to run and stay well clear of his enemy's claws. The Book of Army Management contains a passage that reads: ¡§Advance when you see that it is possible to do so, retreat when you become aware of difficulty, and avoid the enemy when he is strong."

You need policies, strategies, tactics and a toolbox of elementary battle tactics

Extract from the original text:
¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
In my opinion, the most accurate way to break down the topic of military strategy is to use the six-level approach created by 19th century Swiss military strategist Antoine-Henri Jomini. His framework can be neatly applied to any strategic endeavor, no matter what it might be, and used to bring a high degree of clarity into your planning.

The first thing to think about is policy. Jomini put policy ahead of strategy, and he believed he was the first military strategist to propose that policy should be put above strategy. What this means in a military context is that the first thing you need to get busy with is foreign policy and diplomacy.

Only after this step do you move on to decisions about whether or not to fight, who to build alliances with, and who to fight against. In a business operations context, the first thing to do is formulate policies governing how we interact with society and with consumers.

Only when this is taken care of should we move on to thinking about what we need to do in terms of strategy. What the word 'policy' means is: 1) Who am I? 2) Whose interests do I represent? 3) What basic policy direction do I have to inform my actions?

Sun Tzu talks about policy, too. What he calls 'The Way' (one of the 'Five Factors and Seven Considerations') is just another way of saying 'policy.'
What exactly is the difference between 'policy' and 'strategy?' Strategy is about yourself; it's your personal scheme. Policy is about other people; it comprises the practices you use with other people.

Putting policy before strategy means that you think about other people, and then you think about yourself. First, think about the interests of all interested parties, and the systems and setups of the various players in the game.

After policy, we move on to item two: strategy. Strategy is about: 1) Where you are now; 2) Where you want to go: 2) How you get there. Strategy is your roadmap to victory. Sun Tzu's approach to strategy is to win first and fight later, or to force the enemy's army into submission without fighting.

This is what strategy is made of. The third level in Jomini's framework is 'overarching tactics.' This is about using one trademark move, something that only you can do, and capitalizing on it in any kind of situation. This is a common trait of every successful person - they all have their own, personal, special skill.

This is what 'overarching tactics' is all about. In Sun Tzu's The Art of War, the primary battle tactic is to use your main force to start a battle, and an auxiliary force to win it. This is applied to any and every battle situation; no matter how you fight, it's always some variation of the art of division.

Main and auxiliary forces repeatedly switch roles, with infinite variability. The fourth of Jomini's six levels is 'military logistics.' This is a key topic in Chapter Two of The Art of War - Waging War - and it includes all kinds of details. They include things like how to 'field a thousand swift chariots, as many heavy chariots, and a hundred thousand sets of armor, with provisions enough to carry them a thousand li.' No matter how strong or massive an army may be, without guaranteed logistical support it will be extremely vulnerable, fragile and likely to shatter upon first impact. The fifth of Jomini's six levels is the art of engineering, which is about how to attack and defend fortified strongholds.

Finally, the sixth level is basic tactics, which is all about how to fight in various situations. In other words, it's a tactical toolbox, a term commonly used in Chinese and one that's often cited in employee training programs. In this chapter of The Art of War - Armed Struggle - Sun Tzu writes: ¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen.

Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard."
Here, we are entering the realm of basic tactical principles.

The art of war can't account for all possible situations - That's what makes it so deadly! Extract from the original text:
¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
¡§... not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill."
When the enemy holds the high ground, you can't attack.

If the enemy is coming down from a mountain or a hill, you can't counterattack. If you do choose to attack an enemy who is uphill from you, the terrain is against you. It will be hard for you to leverage your strength, and it'll be easy for the enemy to launch missiles, such as logs and boulders, down at you. If the enemy holds the high ground and charges downhill at you, the terrain is working to his advantage.

He doesn't have to worry about covering his rear, and it's so easy for him to build momentum as he moves from high ground to low that his strength is effectively doubled. Don't try to counterattack. Instead, try to draw him onto level ground, and fight him there. Our historical example for this subchapter is another one that we looked at earlier in the book: Zhao She's war against the Qin forces.

Zhao She set up camp fifty li short of the city he was aiming to save. One of his men, Xu Li, advised him to take up a position on the mountains to the north, because, as he said: ¡§Victory will belong to whoever holds the northern mountains." So, that's what the Zhao army did: they turned the terrain to their advantage. When the Qin forces arrived, they struggled to scale the mountain but were unable to reach the top.

Then, the Zhao army hit the Qin soldiers with their full force, inflicting a heavy defeat on them. Zhuge Liang once said: ¡§When fighting in steep country, do not attack a position that is higher than your own.

If the enemy comes towards you from a higher position, do not try to fight them, for the momentum will be against you. Instead, draw the enemy onto level ground, and only then engage."
However, there's always another side to things. Zhuge Liang famously had to execute his disgraced ally, Ma Su, after the Battle of Jieting.

Ma Su had occupied the high ground and set up camp on top of a mountain, where he could await the enemy Wei army. He positioned himself ¡§looking down at the enemy," the story goes, ¡§with the intention to cut through the enemy like an axe through bamboo, to put himself in death's way and yet prevail."

It must be noted that while the semi-fictional classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, holds that Zhuge Liang executed Ma Su, official historical records say Ma Su died in prison. There's also a theory that Ma Su never reported back after his defeat, and escaped into obscurity with his life.

Ma Su's deputy general, Wang Ping, had tried to persuade Ma Su not to set up camp on the mountain, reasoning that there was no water source up there and no resupply route. If the enemy surrounded the mountain, he'd be stuck up there and unable to get out alive.

Why was Ma Su unable to understand the logic of what Wang Ping was trying to tell him? The truth is that he did understand, but his whole plan was to put himself in a dangerous position and yet find a way to survive.

He wanted to occupy the high ground and slam down into the Wei army with overwhelming force. He'd never planned to stay on the mountain for any length of time, so as far as he was concerned, issues like water sources and resupply routes were completely irrelevant.

However, Ma Su forgot one thing. Back when Han Xin had put himself in a similarly dangerous situation, with his back to a river, and yet found a way to survive, he didn't put all of his men by the river. He kept 2,000 cavalry aside, and it was this cavalry force that captured the Zhao camp and activated the 'main force/auxiliary force' synergy. If Han Xin hadn't used the art of division and separated his army into main and auxiliary forces, and instead positioned his entire army by the river, things would have been very different.

He and his men would have ended up in a watery grave. But, Ma Su didn't use the art of division. Instead, he placed all of his soldiers and horses in death's doorway. Wang Ping was unable to talk Ma Su around. All he got for his efforts was a tongue-lashing from Ma Su, who called him an 'unlettered general' who had 'no understanding of the art of war.' Wang Ping was in fact illiterate - he knew no more than ten Chinese characters - while Ma Su was a talented literary man. So, naturally, Ma Su had nothing but contempt for his deputy.

Wang Ping decided to try a different approach. He suggested that Ma Su set up camp on the mountaintop, but give some of his men to him, so he could set up another camp on level ground and divide their forces into two prongs. And then, if either of them got into trouble, the other could come to the rescue.

Ma Su agreed to this. So, in the end, the army did use the art of division: Ma Su led the main force, and Wang Ping led the auxiliary force. When the Wei commander, Zhang He, arrived, he saw that Ma Su was encamped on the mountaintop, so the first thing that he did was surround the mountain.

The second thing he did was cut off the water source and resupply routes. Ma Su had expected this to happen - he wasn't Zhuge Liang's favorite student for nothing. But, he didn't expect the third thing that Zhang He did, because it's not written about in Sun Tzu's The Art of War.

Zhang He set fire to the mountain. What makes The Art of War so dangerous is that it can't cover every base; it can't account for every possible real-world situation. As soon as the fire started to climb up the mountain, the words 'Do not advance uphill against the enemy' no longer applied.

Ma Su's men, already unbearably hungry and thirsty, fell into chaos as the smoke and heat of the fire began to torment them. In that state, there was no way they could charge down toward the enemy below them.

Zhang He launched an attack, and Ma Su was badly beaten. After losing Jieting, Zhuge Liang's whole war plan was completely derailed. But what about Wang Ping's auxiliary force? Wang Ping just stood and watched. There's a biography of Wang Ping, in the historical text Records of the Three Kingdoms, that contains the following passage: ¡§Ma Su turned away from the water source and went up the mountain, a disastrous decision. Wang Ping repeatedly tried to reason with Ma Su, but Ma Su did not take his advice, and suffered a heavy defeat at Jieting.

Ma Su's soldiers scattered, but Wang Ping, at the head of a thousand men, sounded his drums, and Zhang He did not press him, for he suspected an ambush." 
Wang Ping's fortunes began to improve after the Battle of Jieting, and he went on to become a highly respected general in the Shu army. Use yourself as bait; this is the only way to snare your enemy

Extract from the original text:
¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
¡§Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight." Another line - ¡§Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy" - also has this meaning: when the enemy uses bait, don't bite on his hook. Send a small force uphill to attack the enemy, and then have them pretend to retreat.

The idea is to draw the enemy's entire army toward you, and then hit him with your auxiliary force, crushing him in one fell swoop. This is a standard tactic - it's nothing new for anyone who wasn't born yesterday.

And yet, once you're actually on a battlefield and the enemy's retreating, it's impossible to judge with any certainty whether it's a real retreat or a fake. You see the bait, but you can't tell if there's a hook hidden within. It's precisely because of this kind of conundrum that we have the expression 'armchair strategist' to describe someone who seem to know everything, and yet never manages to make the right judgment calls.

The truth is, these people don't really know what they're talking about. So, does the fact that we've read Sun Tzu's The Art of War mean that we know the concepts of 'Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight' and 'Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy?' The answer is: no, we don't know. But, if we know that we don't know, reading The Art of War hasn't been totally in vain.

These two tactics - simulating flight and offering bait - were the key to Han Xin's defeat of the Zhao army at that famous battle in which he began with his back to the river. Han Xin's first move was to deploy 10,000 troops in a battle line by the riverbank, and then he sent out a detachment of soldiers as bait, to get the fight started.

And who played the role of the bait? Han Xin himself. That's why the Zhao army couldn't help but bite! How could they not, when they saw Han Xin dangling right in front of them, there for the taking? They certainly weren't going to go for any other target. Because it's nearly impossible to turn down such tempting bait, there are many more examples throughout history of using commanders-in-chief, and even Emperors, as bait. When the prize is so great, the enemy is sure to bite, even if he knows you're baiting him.

And, once the enemy gets excited, it's even more of a done deal - he's definitely not going to hold back and think about whether or not he's being baited. However, this is the kind of tactic that only gets put on the planning table if the commander himself puts it forward as an idea.

Advisors would never normally dare to suggest that their boss should use himself as bait. When Han Xin marched forth at the head of his unit of bait soldiers with drums pounding and his personal banner streaming in the wind, excitement crackled through the Zhao ranks. They all knew that a big battle was coming, and that whichever one of them cut off Han Xin's head would instantly become a great hero.

Today was going to be their day! Han Xin's men and the Zhao troops smashed together in combat, and after a while, Han Xin started his 'simulated flight.' But, in fact, it wasn't an entirely false retreat. He didn't have much choice but to withdraw, because the Zhao forces had a huge numbers advantage over him, and he could never have beaten them if the fight kept on going the way it had started.

So, the genius of his mock retreat was the fact that it was actually very real. He couldn't win, and that made his fake withdrawal all the more convincing. As Han Xin retreated, he started to lay out his baited hooks: his personal banner, his ceremonial weapons, his war drums, and so on. All of these items would be highly valuable to the Zhao troops; whoever got hold of Han Xin's personal banner would be sure to receive rich rewards. And so, the entire Zhao army poured out of the gates of their camp, falling over themselves in their rush to grab the treasure and bite on Han Xin's hook. The Zhao army broke two of Sun Tzu's rules: 'Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight' and 'Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy.' Meanwhile, in front of the massed Zhao soldiers, Han Xin's unit retreated to the riverbank, joined forces with the 10,000 men he'd stationed there earlier, and then charged back towards the Zhao army. From behind the Zhao lines, Han Xin's 2,000-strong auxiliary cavalry force rode into the Zhao camp and captured it, leaving the Zhao army facing a powerful enemy to their front, and suddenly without a base to retreat to.

That was the moment when they crumbled. There's a common Chinese saying: 'You can't expect to catch the wolf if you're not prepared to risk the life of your child.' From Han Xin's story, we learn that if you really want to catch the wolf, you also have to be prepared to use yourself as bait. Analysis of the battle of Changping: In our own lives, we often play the roles of Zhao Kuo and the King of Zhao

Extract from the original text:
¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
In the most horrific conflict of the entire Warring States period, the Battle of Changping, 400,000 Zhao soldiers were buried alive.

Why? Because the famous armchair strategist Zhao Kuo broke two important rules: ¡§Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight" and ¡§Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy." Two other rules also played a part: ¡§Do not advance uphill against the enemy and do not oppose him when he comes downhill."
As for the Qin commander, Bai Qi, he also broke three rules: ¡§Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard." If the enemy is forced into a corner, he's likely to fight with everything he has, so don't press too close. But, Bai Qi didn't pay any mind to these principles.

He completely surrounded the Zhao forces and annihilated them. Let's look at how the battle unfolded. The Qin army sent out a detachment of troops to act as bait, and then pretended to withdraw in defeat. Zhao Kuo immediately chased after them with his entire army. The Qin men drew Zhao Kuo to the main Qin force's position at a place called Changbi, where they Qin army was waiting for them. The Qin commander was using principles from The Art of War: ¡§Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted," as well as ¡§Knowing the time and place of the battle" and ¡§By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord." The Qin generals knew that the outcome of the battle would be decided at Changbi, so that's where they set themselves up to lure Zhao Kuo to them. Zhao Kuo was completely in the dark about this. ¡§The Regular May Be Used for Joining Battle, but The irregular Will Be Needed in Order to Secure Victory."

The Qin army started the battle by using its 'bait troops' as their main (regular) force, while the main army stationed at Changbi served as the auxiliary (irregular) force. When Zhao Kuo arrived at Changbi, the Qin bait troops merged with the bulk of the Qin army, forming a new main force.

Now it was time for the Qin general to dispatch his second auxiliary force. Zhao Kuo found his way forward blocked at Changbi, and the fighting wasn't going his way. He was getting ready to retreat when 25,000 Qin auxiliary troops struck out of nowhere. They had been waiting in ambush on each flank of the Zhao army, and now they cut their way behind the Zhao troops and took up a strong position on a raised barrier to the west.

From there, they blocked the Zhao army's escape route and cut off Zhao Kuo's communications with his main camp. The Zhao army had now been split in two. Next, General Bai Qi sent 5,000 elite cavalry soldiers to the Zhao camp, to pin down the small Zhao force that had been left behind to guard it. Now, all of the Zhao food resupply routes were cut off, and the Zhao army was completely immobilized. Surrounded, Zhao Kuo's only option was to build defensive fortifications and wait to be rescued.

Bai Qi didn't give him a moment's rest, sending out a constant stream of light cavalry to attack and harass him. Bai Qi was putting one of Sun Tzu's principles into action: ¡§If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out."
When King Zhaoxiang of Qin received reports that Bai Qi had control of the situation, he immediately set out to the front lines, where he enlisted all local boys and men over the age of 15 into the Qin army. He then poured the new recruits onto the battlefield, completely surrounding the Zhao army and cutting it off from its resupply routes and from any would-be rescuers.

After 46 days without food supplies, the Zhao troops had become so desperate that they'd started murdering and eating each other. All that Zhao Kuo could do was make one, desperate roll of the dice: he tried to break out of the Qin encirclement.

He was killed in the attempt. His army surrendered, and then the Qin forces buried them alive - all 400,000 of them. The first question is: Why did Zhao Kuo make such a basic error? After all, he was quite familiar with all of the writings about the art of war.

The answer is that he was too self-confident. Newborn calves aren't scared of tigers, but that doesn't mean a tiger won't eat them. Zhao Kuo's thinking would have gone something like this: 'Lian Po (the previous Zhao commander-in-chief) is an old man, and now it's my turn to be my country's star general.

Lian Po spent three whole years right next to the Qin army at Changping, and all he did was twiddle his thumbs and waste the country's resources. He's nearly bankrupted the state of Zhao, and now it's up to me to solve the problems he's created.'
Since Zhao Kuo was so self-confident, it was inevitable that he would underestimate the enemy.

In his first taste of battle with the Qin, his self-confidence was immediately validated when the enemy turned and fled. This proved to him that he was right, and that he was strong, so he immediately gave chase.

While we might say the enemy was 'simulating flight,' he would have argued that he was pressing his advantage and 'attacking the enemy when they are sluggish and inclined to return home.' But, once he was committed to the chase, there was no turning back. The second question is: How did Zhao Kuo's father, Zhao She, know that his son wasn't up to the task, and yet was unable to trip him up or stump him in debates about the art of war?

Zhao She once said to Zhao Kuo's mother: ¡§War is a matter of life and death, and yet Kuo speaks of it so easily and lightly. If the king does not make Kuo a general, nothing will come of it, but if he is made a general, he is sure to be the ruin of the Zhao army.""
Some say that Zhao Kuo was an example of someone who was deeply familiar with the scholarship on the art of war, but was unable to bring his knowledge into the real world. However, this misses the point.

The essence of Zhao Kuo's problem was that just because someone has read all of the books on the art of war and is deeply familiar with them, that isn't the same as actually understanding the art of war. There's a saying in Chinese: 'Even if you've never eaten pork, you've seen a pig running, haven't you?' This means that even if you've never tasted their flesh, you still have some observational knowledge of pigs.

But this is completely untrue! Seeing a pig running isn't the same as knowing about pigs. To really know what pigs are like, you have to have personally experienced eating pork. This is even truer in the case of Zhao Kuo.

He'd only ever seen pigs running through the pages of a book, and had never seen a real-life pig running in the real world! So, when we read about principles, we only can say we know the principles; we can't say we can actually use them.

To gain true knowledge, it's essential to actually use principles, and to practice using them. As for how well you can know something, that's a different matter. There's no end to knowledge. Confucius wrote: ¡§Is it not a delight to learn something and have the time to practice it?" When we 'learn' something, we haven't actually gained true knowledge of it. For that, we have to use this knowledge, practice it, and learn from experience.

This is the only way to gain true knowledge, and it truly is a delightful thing! Have you ever been taught something, yet failed to really learn it? Maybe you understood what your teacher was telling you, but when you actually tried to put it into practice, you found that you were unable to.

That means you never really understood in the first place. You can only say you've made some small steps in learning something once you're able to act on what you have learned. Zhao Kuo's mother also knew that her son wasn't fit for the task he'd been given.

We know this partly because her husband, Zhao She, had told her as much, and partly because she tried to talk the King of Zhao out of appointing Zhao Kuo as commander. She said to the King: ¡§You once appointed Kuo's father, She, as general. From the day that She received his orders, he never gave any attention to our personal family problems, and whatever gold or silks he acquired, he shared all of it between his officers and soldiers.

Now, you have appointed Kuo as commander. You have given him rewards and noble titles, and he has kept all of this wealth in our family; he is storing it away, and he has told all of our family members to hurry and buy up the best land and houses. He does not behave in the way a leader should."
The third question is: Why didn't the King of Zhao listen?

Why was he so hell-bent on replacing Commander Lian Po, and why did he want Zhao Kuo to take over? Did he really fall for the Qin trick - 'the stratagem of sowing discord?' Qin spies had spread a rumor that the reason Lian Po wasn't attacking the Qin was because he planned to surrender, and that the Qin generals were much more afraid of Zhao Kuo than of Lian Po. So, did the King of Zhao fall for it?

Not in the slightest! The reason why the King of Zhao made such a bad decision was because of anxiety and pressure. He was anxious and despondent, and he felt under such great pressure that he simply had to change something.

Even if he was going to die, he had to at least go out fighting! But why? Let's take a look at how this war started. It began when the state of Qin attacked the state of Han. The Qin army was too strong for the Han forces to deal with, so they sued for peace, and offered some land to the Qin if they would call off their attack. That land was the Commandery of Shangdang. But the Han official in command of Shangdang Commandery, Feng Ting, wasn't willing to take orders from the Qin authorities, so he decided to make his own offer. He announced that he was bequeathing Shangdang Commandery to the King of Zhao. The King of Zhao, being greedy by nature, was delighted, and immediately sent soldiers to occupy Shangdang. You could describe this move as 'stealing food from the tiger's mouth.'
There was no way the King of Qin would sit idly by after the King of Zhao had stolen his new land from under his nose, and he turned the Qin war machine toward Shangdang. Of course, the small detachment of Zhao soldiers sent to take possession of Shangdang was no match for the Qin army.

They retreated to Changping. The King of Zhao then sent a large army to Changping, with Lian Po in command. The two armies faced each other from across the River Dan. Lian Po knew that he couldn't beat the Qin army, so he established a defensive position in favourable terrain, and dug in. He had no intention to get into a fight, and this situation lasted for three years.

Over the course of those three years, more than a million Qin and Zhao soldiers twiddled their thumbs at Changping, using up their countries' resources until both states were on their knees, their economies close to collapse. What started with the King of Zhao salivating over the prospect of getting his hands on some new territory ended up with his whole kingdom sliding towards collapse, before he'd even had the chance to so much as sit down in Shangdang Commandery.

There was absolutely no way he could leave his kingdom in this downward spiral. In Chinese there's a saying: 'Trying to steal a chicken only to lose the rice you were using as bait.' But in this case, the state of Zhao was losing the entire contents of all of its granaries! But would things work out if the King of Zhao tried to put an end to this descent into ruin?

In the end, he wasn't equal to the task. The King of Zhao's frustration with Lian Po had reached boiling point - he absolutely had to change something, anything! What he didn't realize was that making changes isn't the same thing as solving a problem, or that making the wrong change can even make the situation worse. As far as the King of Zhao was concerned, if Lian Po couldn't fight, it went without saying that none of the other old generals would be able to, either. The only option was to choose a younger commander.

He realized that many believed Zhao Kuo wasn't the right man for the job, but also that nobody else could do what had to be done. Zhao Kuo hadn't yet been tested in battle, so why not take a chance and bet on him? In our own lives, we go about most of our decision-making in more or less the same way that the King of Zhao did.

We always feel a strong desire to solve problems, but we don't have the insight or attention span to realize that the action we choose to solve the problem is actually creating new problems, and might even bring a catastrophe down on our heads.

Imagine if we were sent back in time 2,000 years - if we were in the King of Zhao's position, what would be the right thing to do? A 'fierce general' is one who hides when the enemy is fierce. They wait until the enemy has used up their strength, and then they unleash their ferocity

¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
¡§Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen."
The word 'keen' means the same thing as 'sharp,' as in 'sharp morning energy.' You need to stay out of the way of the enemy when their energy is keen, and strike when their energy is lazy, and they're preoccupied with thoughts of returning home. When the enemy is full of energy and at the height of his powers, stay well out of his way.

Let him stew for a while, and wait until his energy and excitement pass and he becomes hungry, thirsty and tired. Then, it's time to strike. Once again, it's all about managing energy. The management of energy was a strong suit of Li Shimin, who became Taizong, second Emperor of the Tang dynasty. We've already learned about how Li Shimin beat Dou Jiande: during that war, he used the principles of 'Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen' and 'Attack when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.' Now, we're going to look at two more historical examples in which Li Shimin plays the leading role. In the first example - Li Shimin's fight against Liu Wuzhou - he used the same two principles.

Originally, Liu Wuzhou was a general in the imperial army of the Sui dynasty. When the Sui dynasty collapsed and the country descended into chaos, he raised his own army in rebellion against the Sui court, declared himself Emperor and went on the warpath.

After securing support from non-Chinese Turkic forces, he seemed unstoppable. He fought several battles against the Tang forces, winning each time. He shredded Tang Prince Li Yuanji's forces, which fled in tatters, abandoning the city of Jinyang (Taiyuan) to the enemy. At this point, Li Xiao (first Emperor of Tang) and his group of allies lost their base to enemy forces; all the land east of the Yellow River was now under the control of Liu Wuzhou.

Li Xiao was running scared. He told his advisors: ¡§It is impossible to contend with these bandits when their energy is like this. We should abandon the lands east of the Yellow River to him, and concentrate on guarding the lands west of the pass." Li Shimin replied: ¡§Taiyuan is the foundation of the King's entire cause; it is the very route of the country. The lands to the east of the Yellow River are rich, and it is from these lands that the capital derives its resources.

Your humble advisor would hate for us to abandon these lands." Then, Li Shimin asked for permission to personally lead 30,000 elite troops to deal with Liu Wuzhou and regain control of Taiyuan. These were the events that led to the Battle of Baibi. Li Shimin, taking advantage of thick ice on the Yellow River, crossed the river at the head of an army and arrived at Baibi. There, he confronted a detachment of Liu Wuzhou's army, under the command of General Song Jingang.

Li Shimin and Li Daozong climbed up to a vantage point and looked down at the two armies. Li Shimin asked Li Daozong: ¡§The enemy has so many soldiers - what do you think will happen if they accept our challenge and come at us in force?"
Li Daozong replied: ¡§The bandits command an unstoppable force. It will be easy to make them submit using calculated strategy, but impossible to best them in a contest of strength."
¡§My thoughts exactly," Li Shimin said.

¡§Song Jingang's army is seriously isolated; he has elite troops and ferocious generals under his command, and they are all gathered here. Liu Wuzhou is relying upon Song Jingang to hold us back so that he can retain control of Taiyuan, but Song's army lacks provisions. They rely on plundering to obtain the supplies they need, which means that it is to their advantage to finish this war quickly.

I will close the gates of our camp and build up our energy until it is sharp enough to force back the enemy. Then, I will divide our army and send one part to strike the enemy in their belly. By that time, they will have used up their food supplies and exhausted their planning capabilities, and so they will naturally flee from our assault. This is the opportunity we should wait for; it would not be to our advantage to fight this war quickly."
¡§Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen." At that moment, Song Jingang's energy had reached its pinnacle - it was as sharp as it would ever be. So, Li Shimin left him to stew.

He waited for five long months, never venturing outside the walls of his camp, except to send small detachments to harass the enemy and disrupt their resupply routes. Eventually, Song Jingang ran out of food and lost the sharp energy that had made him so dangerous before.

All he could do was withdraw. As soon as Song Jingang withdrew, Li Shimin sprung into action, 'attacking when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.' In ferocious pursuit, he and his army covered 200 li in a single day and night, fighting eight separate running battles as they went. After three days in which the Tang troops never once ate or took off their armor, the Tang generals finally called off the pursuit, announcing, ¡§That will do." They let their troops rest for a while, and once everyone had been fed and re-gathered, they set off once more in pursuit. Li Shimin said: ¡§I planned this all out long ago: we will keep chasing and keep fighting, and by the time it's over, we'll have crippled the enemy for good!" The Tang forces kept up their pursuit, eventually pinning down Song Jingang's main force and annihilating them in a single fight. Liu Wuzhou, seeing that the tide had turned against him, abandoned Taiyuan and fled toward the lands of his Turkic allies.

Before long, the Turks murdered him. And that is how Liu Zhouwu lost his power. It was the same story when Li Shimin led a campaign against another rebellious warlord, Xue Rengao. Xue Rengao had over 100,000 troops in his service, and they were full of energy, sharp and dangerous. Li Shimin used the same move he'd used before, once again following the principle of 'Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen.' After Li's generals begged him to allow them to attack the enemy, Li gave them a formal order: ¡§Any man who dares speak of attacking shall be executed!" The two armies faced off for over 60 days, at which point Xue Rengao ran out of food. With no food, some of his men surrendered.

It was clear to them that the other side's men got three square meals a day, while their own side had nothing left to eat. When Li Shimin saw that the enemy had lost its sharp energy, and had come adrift from its purpose, he announced: ¡§Now is the time to attack."
First, he sent out a small detachment to act as bait. Having lured out the few remaining enemy soldiers who still had the will to fight, his next move was to pour cold water over what was left of their sharp energy.

Li Shimin allocated part of his army to travel to Qianshuiyuan and set up camp there, under the command of General Liang Shi. Two months passed in which, try as they might, Xue Rengao's forces could not pull Li Shimin into a battle. One of Xue Rengao's generals, Zong Luohou, who was known to be a ferocious warrior, arrogant and always spoiling for a fight, couldn't take it anymore. He'd reached breaking point.

Zong moved out with his toughest soldiers and launched a blistering attack on Liang Shi. But, Liang Shi stayed safely behind his walls, content to let Zong wear himself out. Zong's response to Liang's refusal to engage was to redouble the intensity of his attack. Li Shimin waited until Zong Luohou's energy was dulled and his stamina exhausted, and then personally led the bulk of his army onto the battlefield, delivering a crushing defeat to Zong. As Zong Luohou began to retreat, Li Shimin pursued him mercilessly, all the way to the foot of Xue Rengao's walls. Once there, he re-gathered his forces and surrounded Xue's position. Xue Rengaao, his nerves badly rattled, opened his gates and surrendered.

Li Shimin took him prisoner and had him sent under armed guard to the capital city, Chang'an, where he was executed. The final years of the Sui dynasty were marked by the appearance of many heroic warriors, such as Li Mi, Dou Jiande and Liu Wuzhou. Each of them was a giant among men, but they were unfortunately up against a truly once-in-a-millennium fighter, a general so powerful that he was considered almost superhuman.

That general was Li Shimin, and he wiped the floor with them. What made Li Shimin such a great fighter was chiefly his ability to know when it was the wrong time to fight. His greatest power was knowing when to stay out of the way and hide.

Then, once the enemy was drained of energy, he would unleash his power. He never had to fight more than one battle in a campaign - he sealed the deal in the first round, and he always did a clean job.

Everyone who fought against him was out-calculated, and wiped out. Why do so many people gain nothing from their education? It's because what they're doing isn't studying, it's 'correcting mistakes'

Where people go wrong in their studies is by focusing on winning.

If you want to make real gains from your studies, the key is to have a correct understanding of what studying actually is. Extract from the original text:
¡§It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.

Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
¡§Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy."
When the enemy lays out bait for you, don't bite. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Fish die when they are greedy for bait; armies are defeated when they are hungry for bait. If the enemy uses soldiers to hook me, I must not follow them."
Our historical example for this subchapter is the story of how Cao Cao baited Liu Bei and Wen Chou. Cao Cao was fighting a war against Yuan Shao.

After executing Yan Liang and breaking the Siege of Baima, he and several hundred cavalry troops were escorting heavy grain wagons as they withdrew from the front line. He was still on the road when he ran into several thousand enemy soldiers led by Liu Bei and Wen Chou, who had been chasing him. Cao Cao's generals were shaken and scared.

The way they saw it, the enemy had too many soldiers for them to fight, and their best option was to run back to the safety of their camp. Cao Cao's advisor, Xun You, said: ¡§This is a situation in which we should bait the enemy. What should we do to drive them away?" They decided to abandon the heavy grain carts, while also unsaddling the horses and setting them free. This was a trick; a way of tempting Yuan Shao's troops.

The plan worked - Liu Bei and Wen Chou both went straight for the grain carts, and Yuan Shao's troops busied themselves stealing whatever they could. Fighting was the last thing on their minds. Then, Cao Cao and his men mounted their war horses, charged their distracted enemies and killed Wen Chou.

Du Mu provides a completely different commentary. According to him, the words 'Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy' should be understood literally. In his interpretation, it means that you shouldn't eat any food that the enemy leaves behind because it might be poisoned. ¡§If the enemy, being in a rush, leaves food behind after leaving a place, the food must first be tested and not eaten directly, for concern that it may have been poisoned."
Du Mu follows these words with a historical example. During the reign of Emperor Wen of the Later Wei period (Cao Cao's second son), the imperial lands were raided frequently by the nomadic Kumo Xi people from the north.

Emperor Wen ordered the King of Jiyin, Tuoba Xincheng, to take an army and deal with the Kumo Xi raiders. Tuoba Xincheng had his men collect a large number of wine jugs, which he filled with poisoned wine and deposited around his camp.

When the enemy attacked, he pretended to think he was no match for them, and fled from his camp. When the enemy troops entered Tuoba Xincheng's deserted camp, they were delighted to find so much wine, and drank without restraint, happy for the chance to let their hair down. As the poison started to take effect, Tuoba Xincheng appeared out of nowhere, and this time it was he who was on the offensive.

With no effort at all, he defeated the enemy, taking thousands of prisoners. Was Du Mu's assertion about poisoning correct? Of course not. There's no way that Sun Tzu's original intention for this line was to remind us not to eat candy from strangers. But, it doesn't really matter that Du Mu's comment is incorrect relative to Sun Tzu's original intent, because there is still some value to it.

From him, we have learned that there are real historical cases of poisoned wine being used to win a war. There's one exceedingly common mistake we make when we're studying or talking through problems: we're focused exclusively on winning.

Instead of concentrating on what we can learn, or on new experiences we can have, we think only about beating other people. When you're debating with someone, they might have made a very eloquent and strong point, and yet you rack your brains to come up with a counterpoint, because you want to beat them. Or, approaching from a different angle, you might be looking for a way to put your fellow debater off balance - that way, you can show off your own skill, or at least show other people that you know more.

In classroom situations, when we ask the teacher a question, it's not always because we really have a question. Sometimes it's just a way of displaying our 'wisdom.' When class is dismissed, or when we finish reading some famous book, we exchange our ideas about what we've learned with other people, but this isn't necessarily about having an intellectual exchange. Perhaps it's really about saying things like, 'Well, I think what they said there is obviously wrong.'
Wanting only to win is a very serious problem that can derail a person's studies. It makes you aggressive towards your fellow students in discussions, it makes you want to challenge your teachers, and when you read ancient texts, it even makes you want to 'beat' the ancient writers themselves!

As soon as you become obsessed with winning, you can no longer study with any sincerity. Instead, you hold on tight to the pleasure you gain from correcting mistakes. What you're doing isn't studying at all; it's correcting mistakes. I felt and saw this very clearly while I was reading Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu's Art of War, because this text is the product of 11 different people writing in different historical time periods, Each one built on the foundation left by those came before him.

The first commentator was Cao Cao, so he became a target for the others. Mainly, it was Du Mu who attacked him - he shot so many arrows at Cao Cao's commentary that it ended up like a porcupine. Many of Du Mu's comments begin with the line. ¡§What Cao Cao wrote is mistaken." Cao Cao was long dead by the time Du Mu was writing, and he couldn't rise from his grave to argue back, so these textual 'debates' were, naturally, entirely one-sided. Du Mu always won.

But why was Du Mu always saying that Cao Cao was wrong? It's because it gave him a huge amount of pleasure to feel he had beaten Cao Cao. Du Mu was a literary man - a poet - meaning that he took special joy in being original and unconventional. It seems to me that Du Mu probably wasn't thinking much about what practical use The Art of War might have in his own life when he was writing his commentary.

Instead, he was likely much more preoccupied with his own writings. If his commentary was too similar to those written by previous commentators, he may have felt, it would be meaningless. Confucius once said: ¡§He who is respectful to others will not be treated with insolence." The other side of this is: If you are disrespectful to others, you will be treated with insolence. Du Mu had a habit of claiming that other people were wrong, and so, naturally, other people came after him and said he was the one who was wrong.

That's why, each time the line, ¡§What Cao Cao wrote is mistaken," appears in Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu's Art of War, it's immediately followed by ¡§What Du Mu wrote is wrong." Mei Yaochen, in particular, made it his business to set the record straight. Mei Yaochen lived during the Song dynasty, and like Du Mu, he was also a poet.

Du Mu had been dead for 200 years by the time Mei Yaochen was writing, so he obviously couldn't argue back. In the final analysis, who do we think is right? First of all, we're not really concerned with who was right. Our main interest is what we can learn, and what use the text has in our own lives. Reading and studying is about projecting what we learn onto ourselves and our own experiences.

It's about applying what we learn to real-life situations and using it to figure things out. That's what real studying is about. It's a terrible mistake to chase after being 'original,' and doing things just so that you can push your own theories.

Second, just because something's wrong does not mean it has no value. We're able to learn a great deal of unusual things from Du Mu's commentary. Isn't that a good thing? Also, he put a huge amount of work into writing his observations, and that's why he became the greatest and most influential of the 11 commentators.

There's no need for us to correct his mistakes; it's enough to take what we can from his work. The Prussian military theorist, Carl von Clausewitz, once said: ¡§No matter how absurd a mistaken opinion may be, it at the very least enables us to learn other people's way of seeing things." There is value in this. Sometimes, when someone tries to explain their theory to you, it seems so ridiculous that you can't even deal with it.

At times like this, you should try to find something positive - this person is teaching you that there are people out there who see things in this way! Third, who's really right? This question is, quite naturally, something we pay a lot of attention to. After all, there is such a thing as right and wrong.

So, who's right? I pretty much always assume that Cao Cao's comments set the standard. Why? Because Cao Cao's the only one who's actually 'eaten the pork!' The others haven't so much as seen a pig running. Apart from Cao Cao's commentary, there's one other book that has been an authoritative mainstay for me: A Translation and Commentary of Sun Tzu's Art of War, by Guo Huaruo.

Guo Huaruo was a Lieutenant General in the People's Liberation Army of China, a graduate of the Whampoa Military Academy, and he taught for many years in the Counter-Japanese Military and Political University.

His commentary is fit to be used as a standard go-to for any questions readers might have about The Art of War. I often find myself in discussions with other people about Sun Tzu's The Art of War, and two questions often come up.

The first is whether Sun Tzu and Sun Bin were the same person. Nothing much can be said about this, other than that it's a boring question. There's no way they could have been the same person, because Sun Tzu worked with the King of Wu during the Spring and Autumn period, and much of the contents of The Art of War specifically talk about the state of Yue. Sun Bin lived in the state of Qi during the Warring States period, and by the time he was born, the state of Wu had long since fallen into history's dustbin. More than 100 years passed between Sun Tzu's death and Sun Bin's birth.

The only reason there's debate about this is that some people want something to talk about, to show that they're cultured and knowledgeable. These people's theories aren't worth taking seriously - they're only interested in empty talk, not in real learning. The second point that's regularly questioned in discussions is the line: ¡§Though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force." When you look at this line in the context of the text that comes before and after, its meaning is as clear as day. ¡§It is the rule in war, if our forces are ten to the enemy's one, to surround him; if five to one, to attack him; if twice as numerous, to divide the army12 into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force."
If you can win, go ahead and fight. If you can't win, then run. If you only have a 'small force,' but you insist on being 'obstinate'- meaning that you refuse to run away - you're going to be captured by the enemy. Or, at least, that's what everyone thinks it means.

One prominent Chinese expert who studies Sun Tzu's The Art of War who has a different interpretation of the original text. According to him, the real meaning of this line is: 'If the weaker side is able to hold out obstinately, they're guaranteed to be able to capture their more powerful opponent, without killing him.' If that's really what Sun Tzu meant, there was no point in him saying the lines that came immediately before. There is another interpretation, also from a highly regarded expert, that really takes the cake.

So vast is his learning that he came up with a unique way of expressing his ideas. After all, if his writing were no different from other people's, his breathtaking scholarship would have no chance to shine. According to him, the word translated as 'obstinate' actually means 'the enemy's financial assets and equipment.' He argues that the line means: if you can beat the enemy, all his treasure and gear goes straight to you, regardless of how carefully he's locked it up and hidden it away! He then quotes a passage from the classic Daoist text, Zhuangzi, to prove his point: ¡§Zhuangzi said: 'If one would like to ensure that thieves come groping into your bags and rifling through your cupboards, and you want to make the right preparations, then you must lock up your things as tightly and securely as you can.'"
As soon as the distinguished professor's audience hears the Zhuangzi quotation, they're blown away: 'Wow!

You know everything!'
As we contemplate the ills of education and academic pursuit, we might listen to what Wang Yangming wrote about it: ¡§When there is already a fully adequate explanation for something, do not persist in constructing alternative theories to defeat the original one." This isn't real learning.

It's empty, and it's motivated only by a vain desire for victory. When learning, just ask yourself what you're getting from it, and if it's useful to you. Don't pedantically quibble over words and manufacture farfetched connections, all in the belief that what you're doing is 'scholarship.'
This is why, during my studies of The Art of War, I try to understand it on another level - I insert myself into what I read, and imagine what I would do if it was me. When we study, just like when we watch films, we naturally imagine ourselves on the winning side.

We need to turn it around and imagine ourselves as the losing side, and think: 'If it were me, what would I do about this situation?'
Put yourself into the books you read, and then put the books you read into your own life and work. What has been revealed to me in my actual work, and what real-life situations have I been in that mirror scenarios and echo principles from Sun Tzu's The Art of War?

True learning comes when you diligently hone and polish what you have learned. Managing energy is about weighing one's willpower and matching it against your opponent's

Extract from the original text:
¡§Do not hem in an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.

Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Analysis:
The three instructions in the passages are about managing energy, and they all boil down to the principle of 'not attacking soldiers whose temper is keen.'

¡§Do not hem in an army that is returning home."

When soldiers are on the homeward road, their minds are focused sharply on the fact that they're going home. If you get in their way, they'll fight you with everything they have.

But, weren't we just talking about how you should attack the enemy when their energy is sluggish? So, why aren't we supposed to 'interfere with an army that is returning home?' This is a question of directions. If the enemy troops want to go home, and you're chasing them from behind - and if they want nothing more than to get home as quickly as possible, and have no desire to fight you - you're in a strong position to take advantage, in terms of energy. However, if you're in front of the enemy, blocking their way home, they'll fight with everything they have.

In that situation, their energy is stronger than yours. Our historical example for this subchapter comes from Cao Cao's campaign against Zhang Xiu. The campaign wasn't going well for Cao Cao, and he decided to retreat.

But Zhang Xiu's ally, Liu Biao, sent reinforcements and blocked Cao Cao's way home. Pressed in by enemies, in front and behind, Cao Cao set a trap. During the night, he stealthily moved out his heavy supply wagons and deployed troops in an ambush formation. Then, he waited for Zhang Xiu to come after him.

The next day, Zhang Xiu came in hot pursuit and got caught in Cao Cao's ambush. With infantry and cavalry soldiers clamping him in a pincer from either side, Zhang Xiu suffered a major defeat. When the battle was over, Cao Cao said to an advisor, Xun Yu: ¡§The bandits hemmed us in while we were returning home and gave me a situation of life and death; that is when I knew that victory was ours."
Du You comments: ¡§If the enemy is wavering and is marching a great distance towards home, because of the perilous circumstances in which they march, each enemy soldier thinks only of returning home, and so the enemy army has the ability and the courage to fight even unto death. Be slow and watch for opportunities presented by the enemy; do not move great distances in order to intercept him."

¡§When you surround an army, leave an outlet free."

When you surround an enemy, you have to leave a gap for him, so that he has a way out if he wants to run for his life.

There is a passage in The Methods of Sima that reads: ¡§Surround him on three sides, leaving one side as an outlet. This is to show him a path to survival."
The intention here is to not corner the enemy in a deathtrap, which he has to fight his way out of alive, because in this scenario everyone dies fighting.

The intention is to make him run away, and once he's running, to hit him with ambushes. Ideally, you would have troops lying in ambush at different points along the route that he'll take as he runs homeward. You let him run for a while, and take a bite out of him as he runs into the first ambush.

Then, he runs some more, and runs straight into the next ambush - and you take another bite. A few more bites like this, and you will have eaten and thoroughly digested every last part of him. Turning back to Cao Cao's fight against Zhang Xiu, what is it that Zhang Xiu and Liu Biao should have done with their armies? First of all, they shouldn't have completely surrounded Cao Cao, because they didn't have the ability to eat him. With no way out, and staring down death, every man in Cao Cao's armies fought for their lives - they were unstoppable. Zhang and Liu should have let Cao Cao go, with Zhang Xiu chasing after him from behind, and Liu Biao waiting in ambush further down the road.

But what Liu Biao actually did was attempt to hold a very dangerous position and block Cao Cao's way home. Sun Tzu's The Art of War tells us that we should surround our enemies if we have ten times his numbers. Liu Biao never had anything close to that kind of superiority.

If we recall, we've already looked at this historical example, but from a different viewpoint. Just as Zhang Xiu was moving out to chase Cao Cao, one of his advisors, Jia Xu, told him that he mustn't chase Cao Cao unless he wanted certain defeat, because Cao Cao was bound to have set an ambush. Zhang Xiu didn't listen, ran straight into an ambush, and lost the battle. Upon his return, he asked Jia Xu: ¡§Well, clearly you somehow know when I'm bound to lose a battle, but can your abilities tell you when I'm bound to win?

It's not much use to me if you only know about losing. If I'm going to win my battles, I need to know the results beforehand!" Jia Xu replied: ¡§The time is now! Quick, go and give chase - you are sure to win!" Zhang Xiu turned straight around, jumped on his horse and chased after Cao Cao once more. Just as Jia Xu had said, the next time he came back, he'd just won a battle.

But why was that the case? The first time that Zhang Xiu gave chase, he was 'hemming in an army that is returning home.'
But, the second time, he was 'attacking when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.'
The types of energy involved in these two scenarios are very different. The two sides' levels of determination had changed, and this in turn resulted in a major change to the fighting capacities of each side.

Managing energy is about weighing up both sides' level of determination, and matching yours against theirs. ¡§Do not press a desperate foe too hard."

Nothing fights harder than a cornered animal. If your enemy is already in a desperate situation, don't be too eager to get close to him.

Don't press him so hard that he has nowhere left to run, because then he'll turn and fight to the death. Somehow, at some point, the words 'do not press a desperate foe too hard' morphed into 'do not pursue a desperate foe.' But Sun Tzu never said that. 'Do not press' and 'do not chase' are two completely different things.
