Of course you should chase them. Why wouldn't you? Mao Zedong once said: ¡§The general should ride the momentum of his courage and pursue the enemy when they are under pressure; the general should not vainly flatter himself and take after the example of past tyrants."



Sun Tzu said: ¡§In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign. Having collected an army and concentrated his forces, he must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp.

After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult. The difficulty of tactical maneuvering consists in turning the circuitous into the direct, and misfortune into gain. Thus, to take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, to contrive to reach the goal before him, shows knowledge of the artifice of the circuitous and of the direct. Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous.

If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores. Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination. If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal. If you march thirty li with the same object, two thirds of your army will arrive. We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost.

We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps.

We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides. In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand, move with advantage, and change by dividing and consolidating. Let your rapidity be that of the wind, your compactness that of the forest.

In attacking and ravaging the enemy be like fire, in immovability like a mountain. Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt. When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men; when you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men. Ponder and deliberate before you make a move.

He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct. Such is the art of armed struggle. The Book of Army Management says: On the field of battle, the spoken word does not carry far enough: hence the institution of gongs and drums. Nor can ordinary objects be seen clearly enough: hence the institution of banners and flags. Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point. The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone.

This is the art of handling large masses of men. In night fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army. A whole army may be robbed of its spirit; a commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind.

Now a soldier's spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp. A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return.

This is the art of studying moods. Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy - this is the art of retaining self-possession. To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well fed while the enemy is famished - this is the art of husbanding one's strength. To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array - this is the art of managing changes.

It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy.
Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare."

Variation in Tactics

Making progress means constantly discovering what you can't do

What does it mean to know how to do something? It's impossible to say. Only people who know how to do the thing in question know what it means to 'know how to do it.' Not only that, as time passes they find again and again that they can't do it anymore.

They have to progress some more, and they have to keep growing their skill. Extract from the original text:
¡§In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign, collects his army and concentrates his forces.

When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem.

In a desperate position, you must fight. There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must not be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed.

The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account."

Analysis:
Variation in Tactics is the shortest chapter in Sun Tzu's The Art of War, at only just over 200 Chinese characters in the original text. However, the subject matter is complex - it overlaps with content from other chapters, and the ordering and layout is a little chaotic.

In particular, there's a part where Sun Tzu says, as a kind of summary, that if you don't know about the variations of tactics, no amount of knowledge about the terrain will enable you to actually take advantage of favourable terrain. This has prompted some researchers to say that this section should have been put at the end of Chapter Ten (Terrain).

The suggestion is that once the reader is finished learning about terrain, they can be reminded that they have to know how to adapt to the situation at hand. There are also some related technical terms that only appear, with accompanying definitions, in Chapter Ten.

Anyway, while noting that some people might have something to say about this, let's stick to the order of the original text. 'Variation' refers here to being able to adapt to changing circumstances, and being able to deal with a situation without relying on conventional principles. In the original text, the title of this chapter is actually Nine Variations. The Chinese tend to use numbers in a more general sense, so here, 'nine' just means 'many.' As such, Nine Variations could be translated as Several Types of Situations in which to Be Mindful of Adaptability. However, Cao Cao clearly states that there are nine relevant situations in his commentary: ¡§By considering the main variations, we derive nine principles to be used." 
This is awkward.

We are presented with a circle to be squared. No matter which way you count it, there just aren't nine principles:
1. When in difficult country, do not encamp. 2. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. 3.

Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. 4. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. 5. In a desperate position, you must fight. 6. There are roads that must not be followed. 7. There are armies that must be not attacked. 8. There are towns that must not be besieged. 9.

There are positions that must not be contested. 10. There are commands of the sovereign that must not be obeyed. And the grand total is... ten principles! Which brings us to an explanation offered by certain scholars, which is that there are 'nine variations and one summary.' According to them, the tenth and final principle is actually just a summary of what has come before. There's a vast number of studies and research about The Art of War, full of stuff like this.

I generally don't use, or even discuss, this kind of material. It's not particularly relevant for our study of Sun Tzu's thinking whether there are nine principles or ten, and once you start getting into this kind of highly detail-oriented research, it can easily consume your whole academic career. This kind of work is the specialty of scholars and experts, and it's outside the scope of our studies.

Even if we studied it, it wouldn't improve our critical thinking. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§'Variation' refers to being unconfined to ordinary methods; it is about adapting to situations as they arise. It is about resourcing our actions from that which must be done.

Whenever one is competing for advantage with another person, one must know the nine variations. That is why this chapter follows after Armed Struggle."
If you don't understand the art of war, you can't fight battles. If you go about your tasks using the principles of the art of war, but you still lose, that's because you don't understand Variations in Tactics.

This is why it's impossible to say what it means to know how to do something. As we said, only people who know how to do the thing in question know what it means to 'know how to do it.' And as time goes by, they can't do it anymore. They have to exercise and advance their skill.

Making progress means constantly discovering what you can't do. It's better to go looking for death than to wait for It to come to you; when you find yourself facing death, fight with steely determination

Extract from the original text:
¡§When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies.

Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight."

Analysis:
Cao Cao, in his commentary, defines 'difficult country' as 'places in which nothing can be relied upon; places of water and ruin.' What he's talking about is places dominated by water: wetlands, lakes, marshes and any other locale where the sodden terrain makes travel difficult. Don't camp in places like this.

When there's water everywhere, not only is it difficult to actually set up camp, but if the enemy shows up, you'll have a hard time building defenses and you won't have much ability to quickly move around the camp. ¡§In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies."

'Country where high roads intersect' refers to wide-open terrain, where it's possible to move in any direction. The original word used in the Chinese text - qu, a rarely used term meaning 'thoroughfare' - appears in the name of a city in Zhejiang Province.

The city is called Quzhou, and it was given this name because it's easy to travel from Quzhou to four different provinces: Zhejiang, Fujian, Anhui and Jiangxi. This is the kind of place that military strategists fight over.

In ancient China, places where there is open country made it easy to travel between different feudal states. In these places, you need to 'join hands with your allies.' In other words, make sure you get your foreign relations right.

If you get that right, you'll get help from your allies. At the very least, make sure your neighbors don't see you as an enemy, and make sure they don't fall into enemy hands. ¡§Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions."

Li Quan gives his definition of 'dangerously isolated positions' in his commentary: ¡§Dangerously isolated places are those in which there are no wells or natural water sources, no animals or livestock, and no firewood. One must not linger in such places." 
Jia Lin comments: ¡§River canyons with dangerous waters and no through road - this is what is called a dangerously isolated place; one should leave with haste, and must not linger." If you find yourself in a dead end with dangerous terrain, get out of there quickly.

Don't get boxed in by the enemy. ¡§In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem."

We can find a definition of 'hemmed-in situations' in Jia Lin's commentary: ¡§When surrounded by danger on four sides, this is called a 'hemmed-in situation.' The enemy is free to come and go, but I am unable to leave as I will. In this kind of situation, you may plan cunning stratagems to make the enemy unable to harm you; then, you can find salvation."
You face danger on all four sides, and the road ahead is narrow, while the road behind is tortuous and winding.

It is easy for the enemy to travel here if he wants to, but it is difficult for me to come and go. Terrain like this is a 'hemmed-in situation.' It's important to come up with a clever plan that makes it impossible for the enemy to hurt you.

That's the only way to escape. A good example of this is when Han Xin was about to deliver the final blow in the war against the state of Zhao. Before that, he had to get past Jingxing, a place with dangerous terrain, where it's easy to be hemmed in.

With Jingxing, the clue is in the name. Jing means 'well'- as in 'stuck at the bottom of a well' - and xing means 'an area deep within a mountain range.' Han Xin took an extremely cautious approach, not daring to move his troops into Jingxing. Instead, he sent out spies, which gave him a clear picture of the situation.

Only once he was sure there was no ambush did he swagger his way through the area, cross through the mountain pass and begin staging his famous show - 'Han Xin fights with his back to the river.'

 ¡§In a desperate position, you must fight."

After passing through terrain where he could easily have been hemmed in, Han Xin deployed his troops by the river - a deathtrap - and yet he came out alive. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§When obstacles impede you in front and behind, the time has come to settle the battle in a death struggle."
He Shi comments: ¡§He who quickly seeks battle will survive; he who dallies and does not fight will exhaust his energy, and meanwhile his grain supply lines are severed.

Why wait for death?"
When you're in a deathtrap, it really is true that it's better to go looking for death than to wait for it to come to you. When faced with death, greet it with a steely resolve, and fight. The psychology of strategic decision-making: The decision-maker's 'personal needs' are always in the background

These 'needs' might be someone's personal ambitions, their financial interests or those of their company.

They might be emotional - some kind of unresolved complex or anxiety, or some sort of shadow cast by their psyche. These are all possibilities. To analyze a person's decision-making, it's important to consider one's own, personal viewpoint. When it's time for you to make decisions, you need to have awareness of 'no self.' This means stripping away emotional and other personal factors from your decision-making.

This is how you make the right choices. Extract from the original text:
¡§There are roads which must not be followed."

Analysis:
There are some roads that, though possible to travel along, should not be taken. The opposite is also true: some roads are impossible to use, and yet there's a chance you might take them.

This is where 'variation' comes in to play. Li Quan comments: ¡§Some roads are narrow and dangerous, and may not be travelled lest one walk into an ambush."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§One should not follow roads which pass through dangerously narrow places; if there is no choice but to follow this road, then this is the result of variation."
We have already looked at the case study of Han Xin defeating the state of Zhao several times now. The story involves a road that should not have been used as a military route: Jingxing Pass.

Han Xin only made the decision to pass through this place after he'd received intelligence from his spies that the Zhao commander, Chen Yu, had opted not to use Li Zuoche's idea of sending part of the Zhao army to set an ambush at Jingxing Pass. If there had been an ambush, as Han Xin said to Li Zuoche after capturing him, ¡§If Chen Yu had employed your stratagem, our respective situations would be reversed - it is I who would be your prisoner."
'The General who Calms the Waves,' Ma Yuan of the Han dynasty, lost the final battle in his campaign to put down a rebellion of five non-Chinese ethnic groups precisely because he took the wrong road. When Ma Yuan and his vice general, Geng Shu, first mobilized their troops, they won some early victories that forced the barbarian armies to hide in the mountain forests.

Ma Yuan was ready to close in on the enemies' base, but first he had to choose which of two roads to take. The route through Chong County had good roads, but was very long, while the route from Hutou was short, but also dangerous, because it would involve water travel. Ma Yuan decided that it would waste too much grain to take the long, land route through Chong County, and that the better option was to take the water route. Anyway, he thought, if he could take the enemy base directly, Chong County would be his, too, and without any extra fighting.

However, Geng Shu strongly disagreed. He said that the land road might be long, but it was safer. Even if they were unable to break into the enemy Miao territory, they'd have an easy route to retreat. He argued that the water route was too dangerous, unless they could somehow reach the enemy base undetected.

Otherwise, the enemy could easily take up positions above them, on the high ground to either side of the water. Unless by some miracle they could grow wings, they'd be stuck in deep water and wedged between high hills, doomed to a watery grave. But Ma Yuan wouldn't change his mind.

He argued that the land route wasn't so safe, anyway - there could be an ambush anywhere. Neither man could convince the other, so they sent a message detailing their positions to the imperial court. In the end, Emperor Guangwu supported Ma Yuan's opinion. So, the Han army embarked on boats and travelled upriver into Hutou. It went exactly as Geng Shu predicted: the Miao fighters quickly found out what the Han army was up to, and took up a strong position on high ground above the narrow river. This was the Yuan River, whose fast-flowing waters made it difficult for boats to move against the current, and their slow progress, combined with the sticky summer heat, caused sickness among the troops.

Whole chunks of the army died, including Ma Yuan himself. Why did Ma Yuan make this mistake? First of all, the land route wasn't necessarily the right choice, either. We judge choices as being 'right' or 'wrong' in hindsight, by looking at the result.

But, in reality, what we call 'right' isn't necessarily right, and what we call 'wrong' isn't necessarily wrong. Having said that, there's no doubt that the water route was dangerous, and the more risky choice overall. By choosing it, Ma Yuan was gambling with his life.

Why did he do that? If you look at Ma Yuan's psychology and his emotional landscape before the campaign, you can see that the writing was already on the wall. When the campaign started, Ma Yuan was already sixty-two years old. When the 'barbarian' forces raided Jun County, Emperor Guangwu sent 'the General of Martial Power,' Liu Shang, to deal with them. Liu was defeated and his army destroyed at a battle by the Yuan River. The next year, a respected senior general, Li Song, and Ma Cheng, governor of Zhongshan, were sent out into the field, but still the Han army couldn't make positive gains. Ma Yuan then asked for permission to lead an army out, but Emperor Guangwu refused, out of concern that Ma Yuan was too old. But Ma Yuan protested: ¡§Your servant is still capable of donning armor and mounting a horse." So, Emperor Guangwu ordered him to do a test ride on a horse. Ma Yuan jumped into the saddle, and turned to look at the Emperor, eager to show he still had what it takes. The Emperor laughed, and said: ¡§I declare this fellow hearty and hale!" He ordered Ma Yuan to lead Geng Shu, Commander of the Palace Guard Ma Wu, Liu Kuang, Sun Yong and various other generals - along with a force of over 40,000 soldiers - to put down the barbarian rebellion. As they set out, Ma Yuan bade a nighttime farewell to various people who had come to see him off on his expedition.

To his friend Du Yin, he said: ¡§I am an old man now. I have often worried that I would not have the opportunity to die for my country, but today, my wish has been granted. Now I can die at peace."
Ma Yuan was determined to be a martyr. In fact, he's the original source for a well-known idiom in Chinese that refers to dying on the battlefield: 'corpse wrapped in horse hide.' He apparently said: ¡§A man ought to die in the wilderness, his body wrapped in horse hide to be carried home for burial. How could I just lay in bed and let myself be possessed by evil spirits, in the hands of my children?" All he wanted was to die on the battlefield, and not at home in bed.

Ma Yuan was an old man when he set out to put down the Miao rebellion, and he no longer cared whether he died. For him, this was the last chance to win glory in service of his country. Of course he knew the dangers of the water route - how could he not, after spending his whole life fighting? But this particular war against the Miao had already dragged on for two years, and three Han commanders-in-chief had already been recalled and replaced.

The only thing to be said for the land road was that it made for an easy retreat. It was good for self-preservation, but not necessarily good for winning. ¡§This will be my last war - if I don't establish my legacy now, there will be no more chances." Ma Yuan had decided to gamble with his life. But why were the young people in his army willing to follow this old man and gamble on their own lives?

Stranded in a river valley, unable to move forward or backward, disease was spreading rampantly through the ranks of the Han army, and men were dying in droves every day. Geng Shu was beside himself with anxiety.

But he was a young man, and a young man's words carry no weight. The Emperor would never listen to him, so there was nothing he could do. He wrote a letter to his elder brother, Geng Yan, telling of the situation and asking him to go and talk with the Emperor.

Geng Yan could tell the situation was serious, and he immediately requested an audience with the Emperor. His words carried more weight than his younger brother's, and the military situation really was dire, so Emperor Guangwu sent Liang Song to ask Ma Yuan some hard questions, and to supervise the army's operations. By the time Liang Song arrived at the army's locations, Ma Yuan was already dead.

In the end, the Han forces didn't win their war. Instead, they came up with a plan that resulted in the Miao forces murdering their leader and surrendering. The rebellion was over. Ma Yuan gambled with his life, and in return his name became immortal thanks to the idiom 'corpse wrapped in horse hide.' But he wasn't the only one. Because of him, many thousands of Han soldiers and officers also went home wrapped in horsehide.

It's possible that this psychological analysis of Ma Yuan's decision-making is just my own, subjective judgment. But... Whenever a strategic decision is being made, the decision-maker's 'personal needs' are always lurking in the background. 'No self' is an objective rock to stand on.

Make a decision with 'no self,' and it's guaranteed. Not fighting: An important element of war

Extract from the original text:
¡§There are armies which must not be attacked."

Analysis:
Sometimes, though it may be possible to attack the enemy army, you don't do it. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Though an army may be attacked, if the terrain be adverse and difficult to travel, then lingering there will cause you to lose formerly held advantages, and taking it will give you only a meager advantage. If the enemy army is small and beleaguered, it will certainly fight unto death."
If you find a small, down-on-its-luck enemy force holed up in the kind of terrain that can easily turn into a deathtrap, there's not much to gain by wiping them out. In fact, doing so would mean paying a big price, possibly even holding up your entire war plan.

If that's the case, don't fight. Du Mu, in his commentary, writes that this line refers back to earlier lines: ¡§Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen; do not interfere with an army that is returning home; do not press a desperate foe too hard; do not attack terrain where death abounds." These all refer to armies that shouldn't be attacked. Du Mu also raises one other situation where an army shouldn't be attacked.

Namely, if your army is stronger than the enemy's, and the enemy vanguard arrives before the rest of their forces, don't attack them straight away and cause them to run. Wait until the rest of the enemy troops show up, and then take down their whole army in one fell swoop. Jia Lin comments: ¡§Causing your enemy to submit without fighting him is supreme excellence." If you can cause your enemy to surrender, there is no need to attack. He also saw that if the enemy forces, though hard-pressed, are holding a position in dangerous terrain, such that attacking them will result in ¡§a fight unto death," don't attack.

Wait patiently for the enemy's situation to change, and wait for them to become sloppy, and then take them. Zhang Yu adds: ¡§There is no harm in indulging the enemy, and nothing to gain by defeating them." This is another kind of situation where you shouldn't attack. Don't be greedy for small gains.

When all that's on offer is a few tasteless scraps, you don't lose anything by not eating. On the contrary, if you see some small gain dangling in front of you, and immediately want to take it, you're delaying your real business and potentially sabotaging your grand plan. We've already talked about how marching is a part of war, one that might even be more important than actually fighting.

We've also talked about how camping is a part of war. Now, we're beginning to see that not fighting is also an element of war. This is about weighing pros and cons, and it's about being able to see the overall picture.

If you weigh up the pros and cons, it's not worth killing 1,000 enemy troops if it means losing 800 of your own. In terms of the bigger picture, a low-level gain might end up having a negative effect on your overall position, perhaps because it delays the day of the battle that's going to win you the war. It seems like quite a simple sentence - 'There are armies which must not be attacked' - that you'd think you could understand it the moment you hear it.

Yet, we need to remember that when we read books and study, the aim is to bring what we learn into our own lives. If we apply this notion to our own lives, we find that there isn't a single day when we actually live up to these words.

We're unable to actually not do certain things: not get sucked in to certain social engagements, or not drink alcohol in certain situations. Don't let yourself think that you're a hardworking, honorable caricature of a person, or that you're some brave, mythical warrior.

And don't let yourself feel guilty whenever you stop working for a moment to rest. If you keep yourself busy to the point of organ failure on a daily basis, if you're constantly grasping after every opportunity you get a sniff of, you'll end up losing what you already have because you're distracted by going after things you don't have. This mentality doesn't work; you'll never be able to really build anything.

It's better to just stop, do some proper planning, and work out what exactly it is that you want. The art of war for rebels: The name of the game is speed

Extract from the original text:
¡§There are towns which must not be besieged."

Analysis:
Some cities, though it may be possible to take them by force, should not be attacked. Cao Cao comments: ¡§If the city walls are small but solid, and if the grain supplies are ample, then one must not attack it.

This is why I laid aside thoughts of capturing the cities of Hua and Fei, and instead plunged deep into Xu Province, by which action I gained territory of forty counties."
Du Mu, in his commentary, says that if your enemy is positioned at a strategic point, and has dug deep moats and stored up vast amounts of grain, their intention is to hole up and delay your forces. If you attack him and manage pull him out by the roots, there's not much benefit for you.

Even worse is if you attack him but can't beat him - that'll really scupper your war plans. In this situation, don't attack. This line, 'There are towns which must not be besieged,' is more important for rebels than for anyone else. This is 'The Art of War for Rebels.' Or, at least, you could call it that. If you're ever thinking of starting a rebellion, the best plan you could choose is to take the capital city as quickly as physically possible, and get rid of the Emperor.

Then, you get to be Emperor. But if, for whatever reason, your progress gets held up, the whole country will mobilize to come to their Emperor's rescue, and before you know it you'll be faced with a massive army standing in your way.

At that point, your rebellion's a lost cause. We've already looked at how the Ming dynasty statesman Wang Yangming defeated the Prince of Ning's rebellion. If the Prince of Ning had focused all his strength on taking the city of Anqing, the capital, Nanjing, would be within his grasp. Once he entered Nanjing, he'd have the political capital to declare himself Emperor, and once he'd done that, all the government officials and court politicians would be forced to choose a side. The Zhengde Emperor, who was in power at the time, was laughably unsuited to be the 'Son of Heaven,' so the Prince of Ning wasn't lacking for opportunity. Wang Yangming, taking advantage of the fact that the Prince of Ning's stronghold city, Nanchang, was undefended, marched in and took it, gambling that the Prince of Ning would withdraw his army and attempt to take back Nanchang. The Prince's advisors tried to reason with him until they were red in the face: ¡§There are towns which must not be besieged!

We don't need Nanchang! Once we have Nanjing, the whole world will be ours - including Nanchang! If we get bogged down in Nanchang, we'll lose our chance. We'll be finished!¡§
But the Prince of Ning couldn't stand the thought of his home city being captured, so he abandoned his siege of Anqing, which had been about to fall, and pulled his armies back toward Nanchang. He never made it there - he was captured by Wang Yangming when he was only half-way back, at Poyang Lake. The Prince of Ning was inspired to launch his rebellion partly by the earlier success of Zhu Kang, who became Emperor Chengzu of the Ming dynasty. But Zhu Kang's strategy was precisely that 'there are towns which must not be besieged.' At the start of Zhu Kang's uprising, he spent a lot of time stuck in stalemate. He was mostly fighting in Hebei and Shandong Provinces, and although his army (the Yan army) won slightly more than they lost, he suffered heavy casualties, while the imperial army had a massive pool of manpower to call upon. If the imperial commanders could drag the conflict out, Zhu Kang would be unable to get the better of them. Later in the war, Zhu Kang got word from an imperial court eunuch in his service that Nanjing was poorly defended. So, he changed his whole strategy, drew up a large army, and personally led it directly to Nanjing. He fought his way to Yangzhou, at which point an imperial naval commander named Chen Xuan surrendered to Zhu Kang, handing him a fleet. He crossed the Yangzi River, made his way down to Zhenjiang, and then straight to Nanjing, where Zhu Hui, Prince of Gu, and Li Jinglong opened the Jinchuan gate and surrendered. Zhu Kang's rebellion had succeeded.

During the reign of Empress Wu Zetian of the Tang dynasty (665-690 CE), Xu Jingye attempted a rebellion. His advisors urged him to move directly on the city of Luoyang, which Empress Wu had turned into the new capital city.

If he did that, they'd suggested, he'd be cutting straight to the heart of the Empress' power, and he could neutralize the fact that she had far more followers than him. It might also bring more people to his cause, which was the only hope for his rebellion bid to succeed. But Xu Jingye chose not to move north toward Luoyang, and instead marched south with ambitions to capture the cities of Changzhou, Zhenjiang and the old imperial capital Nanjing, where he planned to finally achieve his dream of becoming an Emperor. But, this move sent a clear message to everyone: his ambition only went as far as separatism.

He was just interested in carving out a kingdom independent from the Tang dynasty, without actually replacing it. So, nobody followed him. Du Mu also wrote about another rebellion, that of a man named Shen Youzhi, who held de facto control of Jing Province. He'd attempted a rebellion against Emperor Shun (477-479 CE) of the Liu Song dynasty.

He was well funded: according to historical documents, he'd built up a force of 100,000 men and 2,000 armored horses, and had significant stockpiles of grain. When he made his move, the first target for his rebel army was the city of Ying.

A minister named Cang Yin of the Bureau of Merit once said that it is easy for shifts to occur in the balance of energy between attackers and defenders. In the case of the city of Ying, it was easy to defend and difficult to attack. It certainly couldn't be taken unless you committed 10-15 days to besieging it.

And, if you weren't able to capture it smoothly, your aura of strength would dissipate, along with the initial sharpness of your energy. The soldiers in rebel armies never have much say; they become rebels whether they like it or not.

So, at the first inkling that things aren't going well, the rebel army's entire mentality changes. What Shen Youzhi should have done was steer clear of Ying and instead move down the river and take the city of Jiankang (an older name for Nanjing). If he'd done that, he could have torn the Liu Song dynasty up by the roots, and Ying would have fallen into his hands by Shen Youzhi's imperial decree. Shen Youzhi didn't listen to his advisors, and even though he committed all of his best troops to attacking the city of Ying, he was denied victory by the Commandery Governor, Liu Shilong. The soldiers who had followed Shen could now see that even this, the very first battle, was far from an easy task.

They saw that their rebellion's chances of success were extremely slim, and so, unwilling to be convicted for a crime that would see them and their entire families executed, they deserted. Shen's rebel army fell apart. He realized that he'd lost control of the situation, and walked alone into a forest and hanged himself.

And that was the end of his life's work, his rebellion. It had been pure foolishness. In another, later era, military strategists in a certain western country developed a strategy that has been summarized as 'deep battle' or 'strategic paralysis.' It's about driving deep into the enemy country's heart and paralyzing their central nervous system. When you do this, the whole country surrenders.

Don't fuss around with setting up new camps and new defensive lines with every forward step you take; in fact, don't even wait for your supply line to catch up with you. The key is to be quick. This is none other than Hitler's and Guderian's blitzkrieg ('flash war') method of warfare. There's a price to pay for everything

In Chinese society, we have a culture of 'talking big.' For example, people love to talk about doing things 'no matter what the cost.' In reality, there's nothing in this world that is beyond calculations of 'cost.' There's a price to pay for everything.

Extract from the original text:
¡§There are positions which must not be contested."

Analysis:
There are some places that, although it might be possible to take them by force, you shouldn't fight over.

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Positions which can bring only small benefit are liable to cause loss as soon as they have been won; therefore, do not contest them." 
Du Mu comments: ¡§It is said that there is no harm in losing a position which, once gained, is difficult to defend. Wu Zixu once advised Fuchai thus: 'If today we attack Qi and take their land, that land will be alike to a field full of stones; it would be better to make haste and take action in Yue.'"
Wu Zixu wanted Fuchai, King of Wu, to try to seize the land of the state of Yue, and not of the state of Qi. His reasoning was this: both Wu and Yue were southerly kingdoms, so the land of Yue would be easy both to defend and to farm for the people of Wu.

But, the state of Qi was in the north, and its land wouldn't be much use to the Wu invaders; it would also be difficult to defend against invaders. However, Fuchai was already very happy with life at that time.

He was enjoying the pampering being showered on him by the King of Yue, Goujian. He spent his days in the arms of the renowned beauty, Xi Shi, who had been gifted to him by Goujian. He fundamentally didn't believe there was any need to wipe out the state of Yue.

Instead, his interests were much more focused on the Central Plain region to the north. He wanted to fight with the states of Qi and Jin in a bid to establish himself as undisputed ruler of the known world. So, Fuchai fell into Goujian's trap - the stratagem of sowing discord - and ordered Wu Zixu to be killed. Then, just as Fuchai had moved north at the head of an army, Goujian seized his chance. While the lands of Wu were unguarded, he launched a sudden attack, during which he killed the crown prince. Several years later, the state of Wu was obliterated by Yue, and Fuchai killed himself. As students of history, it's hard not to give a wistful sigh every now and then. Wu Zixu did such good work for his country, and he was so important to Wu - how could Fuchai kill him?

How could he be so self-destructive? The reason we might think this way is because of our position. We're observers. From Fuchai's point of view, the power and success of Wu was his own work, and he certainly would never give the credit to Wu Zixu. Du Mu also writes about another historical example.

It's the story of a general named Tao Kan. During the Eastern Jin dynasty (317-420 CE), Tao Kan was stationed in the Wuchang garrison. Across the Yangzi River, on the north bank, there was a city called Zhucheng.

The officers around Tao Kan were all trying to talk him into sending an army to take Zhucheng, but Tao Kan ignored them. The officers kept pushing the idea, so Tao Kan took them across the river on a hunting trip. During the trip, he went near Zhucheng, and told them: ¡§The reason why I foresee danger here and opt for a defensive posture is because of the danger presented by the Yangzi River. Zhucheng is on the north bank; it has no hinterland upon which to rely, and it is menaced by barbarians from outside. Lusting after the profit to be gained from Zhucheng will not only lead us into a place that is impossible to defend, but it will also incite barbarians to come. So, gaining Zhucheng will bring no benefit to our lands south of the river; on the contrary, it would invite disaster."
Years later, the Jin general Yu Liang attempted to hold Zhucheng, and sure enough, he suffered a crushing defeat. To gain territory, the highest price must be paid, and the people must suffer the greatest misery.

The so-called 'Emperor Wu the Great' of the Han dynasty once said: ¡§Any who dare use force against Han will surely be brought to the executioner, no matter how far away they may be." Because of these words, many people today think of Emperor Wu as a great hero, and he's hailed in history books as a great ruler and military leader. And yet, if you actually lived during the time of his reign, your fate would have been one of misery, and no escape.

You could go to the front lines and lose your life on a blood-soaked battlefield, or you could stay at home and suffer all kinds of hardships, because Emperor Wu bankrupted the entire country. In his later years, as the country tottered on the brink of collapse, and under enormous political pressure, he published his famous self-criticism, in which he called himself ¡§arrogant and unreasonable." On that count, he was right. Some 800 years later, the Tang dynasty poet Du Fu left behind one of the most famous Chinese poems of all, A Song of War Chariots, which speaks of the time when Emperor Wu was fighting his wars of expansion:
¡§Frontiers on which enough blood has flowed to make a sea,
Yet our Emperor still would expand his authority! Have you not heard how east of Huashan two hundred counties are nothing but weed-choked villages, desolate with thorns?

Extract from the original text:
¡§There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops.

The general who does not understand these, may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. So, the student of war who is unversed in the art of war of varying his plans, even though he be acquainted with the Five Advantages, will fail to make the best use of his men."

Analysis:
Sometimes, orders from the leader of the country should not be obeyed. For example, if a command doesn't take into account the actual situation on the front line, it should be rejected.

This line - ¡§There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed" - is one of the most famous passages in Sun Tzu's The Art of War. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Providing that it be expedient to handling affairs, one should not be constrained by the sovereign's commands." If it's good for your battle position, there's no need to stick to the letter of the sovereign's orders.

There's a passage in the Wei Liaozi that reads: ¡§War is a matter of deadly weapons; to fight in a war is to defy morality, and to be a general is to be a dead man. For him, there is no heaven above, no earth below, no enemy in front, and no lord behind."
This passage means that battle commanders work in the space between life and death, and nothing is off the table for them if it means surviving - there are no moral standards, no law and no heaven above.

The 'king' ceases to exist. But is that really true? If it were true, it would be impossible to command an army. Because generals sometimes don't obey commands from their rulers, so too there are junior officers who sometimes don't obey commands from the general. If everyone's making their own judgment calls, and ignoring the judgment of their senior commanders, how are you supposed to control an army?

This brings us to two concepts that are crucial to understanding this passage. First, this line is mainly intended to be read by kings and lords. Its message to them is that they should let the people who are actually within earshot of the cannons to do the decision-making, and rein in, as much as they can, their impulse to 'remote control' the army. Secondly, this is about one of the 'nine variations' - it's about staying open to change.

What this means is that this isn't a normal situation; this is for special circumstances. This line is saying that, although it's a crime to disobey the sovereign's commands, a crime that carries the death penalty, if you find yourself in exceptional circumstances, in which obeying orders would mean certain death, while disobeying them would be good for the country, you can 'adapt' and disobey. But, if you're a general, you absolutely shouldn't take the concept of 'There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed' at face value.

When this line was first written, the man who held the pen was a battle commander, and he was writing specifically for the eyes of kings and Emperors. His idea in writing this line was definitely not that it would be taken seriously only by generals and not by their kings. He wasn't trying to give generals the idea that nobody was above them on the decision-making ladder, and that they had the unique right to call the shots.

Let's take a look at the historical record, shall we? Was it actually true that sometimes the sovereign's orders could be ignored? The answer to that would be... no. During the chaos of the Tang dynasty's An Lushan Rebellion, Imperial Commander Geshu Han was committed to holding a defensive position at his fortress in Tongguan Pass, and to keeping his army safe behind its thick walls. However, Emperor Xuanzong was piling pressure on him to come out and engage the enemy in the open.

Geshu Han knew that fighting in the open would mean certain defeat. So, did the thought occur to him that 'There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed?' Yes, it did. But there were consequences for those who disobeyed the sovereign's orders - most notably, the death sentence. Geshu Han had already seen two prominent imperial generals meet this very fate at the hands of Emperor Xuanzong: Gao Xianzhi and Feng Changqing, both staunch pillars of the state. And so, Geshu Han came shaking and sobbing out of his fortress, leading the Tang army into battle. He lost, badly. Tongguan Pass fell to the enemy, Geshu Han was captured, and Emperor Xuanzong abandoned the capital city of Chang'an and fled toward Sichuan. Then there's the case of another toweringly famous Chinese general, Yue Fei.

He nearly pulled off a stunning success during his northern expedition, but fell at the final hurdle. As he mulled his defeat, he received a summons from Emperor Gaozong, calling him back from the front line. Was it an option for him to disobey the Emperor's orders?

If he'd chosen that path, he'd be dead - the Emperor would send a Military Supervisor armed with an Imperial edict, and he'd be executed it in his own camp. We can take another look here at a historical example from earlier on, to answer the question of whether or not a lower-ranking officer can disobey his general's orders.

It was covered in detail in an earlier chapter, but bears repeating. There was an episode during the war between the states of Qin and Zhao in which a massive Qin army surrounded the city of Yuyu. The Zhao commander, Zhao She, marched his army to the city in a bid to break the Qin encirclement. But, he halted his army with thirty li of road left before reaching the city of Handan, set up camp and fortified his position. Pretending he had no intention of moving any closer to the enemy, he circulated an order through his army: ¡§Any man who offers unsolicited suggestions regarding military matters shall be executed!"
Meanwhile, as the Qin army carried on its siege of Yuyu, a secondary force was formed to hold off the Zhao army and prevent it from reaching the city. This secondary force moved directly to Wu'an, splitting the Qin forces into two parts and positioning them in a pincer shape.

In the Zhao camp, a junior officer, distraught with worry, went to Zhao She with urgent counsel. The gist of the officer's advice was that the army should hurry over to Wu'an, otherwise this would happen and that would happen. As promised, Zhao She executed him on the spot. Zhao She waited just long enough for the Qin forces to let down their guard and start believing he'd only come to make it look like he was doing something to 'relieve the besieged city,' but didn't actually want to fight. Then, all of a sudden, Zhao She made his move. With a light force, he marched non-stop, day and night, straight towards Yuyu. When he'd reached within fifty li's distance of the city walls, he halted and set up camp.

One of his soldiers, a man named Xu Li, looked at the terrain around the camp and came to Zhao She with a suggestion: ¡§Victory will belong to whomever holds the mountain to the north. My lord, I hereby request that we set our camp atop the northern mountain, and that we draw defensive lines there." Zhao She agreed with the idea. Then, Xu Li said: ¡§I have said what I came to say.

My lord, please execute me now in accordance with your decree!" Zhao She only said: ¡§We will delay this matter until our return home."
Later, when the battle had been won and the Zhao army had returned home, Xu Li was promoted to the office of Defender in Chief. What can we see from this case study?

The first man, the one who was executed, could see part of what was going on, but not the full picture; he could see the outermost layer, but not the essence. So, his judgment fell short of his commanding officer's, yet he still tried to disobey his commander's orders, which led him straight to the executioner. His head was separated from his shoulders, and became a component in Zhao She's strategy. The second man who disobeyed his commander's orders, Xu Li, had the sense that he was walking into certain death.

According to his logic, his life belonged to the country, so if his words might be of use to the country, he would speak them and die with no regrets. The lesson is that if you want to actually disobey certain orders from your superiors, you need to be committed to sacrificing yourself. ¡§The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops.

The general who does not understand these, may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. So, the student of war who is unversed in the art of war of varying his plans, even though he be acquainted with the 'Five Advantages,' will fail to make the best use of his men."
 

This passage is a summary of the first part of this chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War. If a general has complete understanding of how to vary his tactics to adapt to the changes mentioned above, he understands how to use military force.

If he doesn't, even if he understands the terrain he's situated in, he won't be able to gain any advantage from it. If you try to command an army without understanding how to adapt your tactics, then even if you know about the 'Five Advantages,' you still won't be able to unleash the full potential of your army's battle capability. There's a concept that pops up here - 'The Five Advantages' - which actually means the same thing as 'The Nine Variations.' It refers to five different kinds of situations within the framework of the nine variations.

What are they? According to one interpretation, they are: 'There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed.' According to a different interpretation: 'When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies.

Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight.'
To conclude, all it means is that you need to understand how to adapt to change. The philosophy of risk and gain: You need to see risks within gains, and gains within risks

As you rush to make gains, don't forget to dodge risks.

Human psychology is wired for wishful thinking and trusting in luck. Even when people see a risk hiding inside a potential gain, they believe that there's only a low chance of the risk actually happening.

So, no need to worry! As for seeing gains within risks, people can see potential gains even when they're not really there, and they firmly believe that such gains will definitely pan out. Extract from the original text:
¡§Hence in the wise leader's plans, considerations of advantage and of disadvantage will be blended together.

If our expectation of advantage be tempered in this way, we may have confidence in accomplishing our tasks. If, on the other hand, in the midst of difficulties we are always ready to seize an advantage, we may extricate ourselves from misfortune."

Analysis:
¡§Hence in the wise leader's plans, considerations of advantage and of disadvantage will be blended together."
A wise leader has the ability to take into account gains and risks at the same time, and also has the ability to see when conditions are favourable, and when they're not. There is some similarity here to the modern SWOT analytical framework (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats).

'Gains' are the same as 'opportunities,' and 'risks' are the same as 'threats.' It's essential that you pay attention to both sides, and not focus entirely on either one of them. Cao Cao comments: ¡§When amidst advantage, consider the risks; when amidst risk, consider the advantages; when encountering difficulties, exercise authority."
When you see a potential gain, pause to think a moment longer about what hidden risks and dangers might be lurking under the surface. When you see a potential risk, think for a moment about whether there's a positive side to it, and whether or not it can be turned into a gain. When you find yourself in a difficult or unexpected situation, it's important to understand how to adapt.

This comment by Cao Cao is a deep one. What about ourselves? It's easy to think about what gains might be hidden inside a risk, but difficult to think about what risks might be hidden inside a potential gain. As we've said, this is because human psychology is wired for wishful thinking.

People are always greedy for gains and reluctant to get close to risks, and we're prone to trust in our own luck. When we're greedy for gains, that's real greed. When we try to stay away from risks, it's more of a psychological response, recoiling from the idea of risk. Instead of actually trying to avoid risk, we trust luck and don't bother taking actual steps to prevent risk.

When we see a potential gain, we know in our hearts that it involves some risk, but we believe that the danger won't actually happen. When we see a potential risk, we firmly believe there's something good hiding in the background, and we also believe that this good thing is definitely going to happen! We can see this from the way that people explain and deconstruct the Chinese word for 'crisis' - weiji. Wei means 'danger,' and ji can mean 'opportunity.' So: crisis = danger + opportunity. Therefore, the thinking goes, when there's a crisis, we need to turn danger into opportunity.

But this is incorrect. The ji in the Chinese word for 'crisis' actually has a different root meaning - 'trigger.' Don't pull the trigger. When your bills are due, pay them, and don't make a fuss about it.

Just accept that you're going to lose some money. This is the most positive way of dealing with the situation. Is there anyone alive who doesn't run up against at least some bad things in life? Don't always think about how to turn bad things into good things, and don't always look for a way to profit from them. You can only win if you're also able to admit defeat.

If you refuse to admit defeat - to pay your dues - and just keep plowing onward, not only will the dangers not turn into gains, they'll just keeping growing bigger. This is not the message that Sun Tzu's The Art of War is trying to teach us. Jia Lin comments: ¡§Dangers and benefits are mixed together; the wise leader is about to ponder both and deal cautiously with both, and thus derive the benefit."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§The wise leader's way of contemplating things is thus: though he be situated in a favourable position, he absolutely considers the risks inherent in this position. Likewise, though he be situated in a dangerous position, he absolutely considers the benefits inherent in this position.

This too is what we call 'adapting to change.'"

¡§If our expectation of advantage be tempered in this way, we may have confidence in accomplishing our tasks."

The words 'tempered in this way' mean that the advantages are considered along with the risks intertwined within. The non-beneficial side of the situation, as well as the potential for danger, are both part of the leader's calculations.

If you can address both sides of the situation, then we can have confidence in what we need to do, and we can make them into a reality. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Having calculated that the enemy is unable to harm me, and indeed lacks the position to do, I may have confidence in my tasks."
If you've taken into account all the areas where the enemy might be able to hurt you, and if you've found that, no matter how you add up the numbers, there's no way he can actually hurt you, your plan is workable. Du Mu comments: ¡§'Confidence' refers to 'reaching forth.' Sun Tzu's meaning is that if one desires to extract advantage from one's foe, it is not sufficient merely to perceive the advantage to be gained from the enemy; one must first add to one's calculations the ways in which the enemy may inflict harm. This being done, one can reach forth and execute one's tasks."
If you want to gain an advantage from someone, you can't only have eyes for the advantages.

You need to take into consideration the ways in which the enemy might be able to hurt you. This is a step you must take for the things you want to accomplish to actually succeed. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Add that which presents danger to that which presents advantages.

By doing this, one may reach forth and achieve one's objectives."
Zhang Yu also provides a case study. The ancient state of Zheng sent an army to attack the state of Cai. The Zheng army was victorious, and all the people of Zheng were happy, except for Zi Chan, who was deeply worried. ¡§There is no greater catastrophe than a small country which is bereft of moral civilization, and yet experiences military triumph," Zi Chan declared.

He was proved right: not longer afterward, the state of Chu raised an army and moved to attack Zheng. Chu had always seen the state of Cai as part of its sphere of influence, and so, for Chu, it was a case of: 'If you pick on my little brother, I'm going to beat you up!'

¡§If, on the other hand, in the midst of difficulties we are always ready to seize an advantage, we may extricate ourselves from misfortune."

Du Mu comments: ¡§If I wish to extricate myself from misfortunes caused by my foe, I must not only see the things that my enemy can do to harm me, I must also include in my calculations the advantages that I can extract from him. Having done this, I can then successfully extricate myself from misfortune.

For instance, supposing I have been surrounded by enemy forces: If I know only to attempt to break through the encirclement, my men's force of will is sure to be feeble, and we shall surely be harried and struck down. But if I rouse the soldiers' spirits and vigorously carry the fight to the enemy, then the prospect of victory and the advantages it brings shall enable us to break the encirclement."
Jia Lin comments: ¡§When in a position of danger, turn your mind to the advantages, and thereby you shall evade the danger. Thus, being confronted with death, one survives, and facing ruin, one persists.

This is what is meant by 'extricating ourselves from misfortune.'"
Zhang Yu gives another case study for this line of thinking: The Rebellion of the Eight Princes during the time of the Western Jin dynasty (266-317 CE). There was a general named Zhang Fang who, after taking the capital city, Luoyang, suffered a string of defeats.

He was advised by some to flee, but he said: ¡§It is entirely normal in armies for shifts to occur between potency and dullness, and the most precious victory comes from defeat." That night, his army sneaked right up under the enemy's noses and defeated them in combat. The second part of what Zhang Fang said gives readers much to chew on: that the most valuable victory comes straight out of failure.

In other words, you can fail over and over again, and still end up achieving your goal. This is exactly how it works with scientific inventions and experiments, and with entrepreneurs building new businesses.

In the final analysis, all success is a result of failure. If you keep moving with the flow, even as you rack up one failure after another, as long as you constantly review those failures, learn from them and apply what you've learned, you will ultimately succeed. 'The art of harm' teaches us not to let people harm us

This part of The Art of War teaches us how to hurt people. Take a quick look at this passage - that's all that's necessary.

The message is simple enough: Don't let anyone hurt you, and even more importantly, don't hurt other people. Extract from the original text:
¡§Subdue hostile barons by inflicting damage on them; encumber them with constant engagements; hold out specious allurements, and make them rush to any given point."

Analysis:
¡§Subdue hostile barons by inflicting damage on them."
Come up with a way of making them do things that aren't in their own interests, so that they're unable to unfurl their strength to its full extent. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Damage him in ways that he would consider pernicious." 
Li Quan comments: ¡§Damage him politically."
Jia Lin comments: ¡§Use harmful strategems - each one is different: perhaps one may entice the wise men and ministers in his court, so that he is deprived of advisors; or avail yourself of underhanded men, and through them sabotage his decrees and commands; or employ underhanded tricks to sow discord between the king and his advisors; or send ingenious craftsmen to him, and thus exhaust his people and empty his coffers; or use gifts of debauchery and pleasure to corrupt the social currents of his realm; or give him beautiful women to ensnare his mind.

Each of these stratagems, if conducted in total secrecy, is capable of harming people and causing them to submit."
All of this is about how to hurt people. As I've said, for us it's enough just to take a look and move on.

¡§Entice the wise men and ministers in his court, so that he is deprived of advisors." If you can draw capable people away from your enemy, he won't have anyone he can depend on. Lift up the unscrupulous men in his court, and his administration will rot from the inside; use trickery to create divisions between the enemy and his advisors.

There are many historical examples of this, including ones we've already examined in previous chapters. In the Battle of Changping, between the states of Qin and Zhao, Qin sent a spy to the Zhao city of Handan to spread rumors that the Zhao commander-in-chief, Lian Po, wasn't going to fight, and that he actually was planning to surrender to Qin. There was also another rumor - that the Qin generals weren't worried about the idea of facing Lian Po, but were scared stiff of a different Zhao general, Zhao Kuo.

The goal of these rumors was to make the Zhao authorities call Lian Po back from the front lines and send out Zhao Kuo instead. Zhao Kuo would march to his death. ¡§Send ingenious craftsmen to him, and thus exhaust his people and empty his coffers." The idea here is to make the enemy spend money on big projects, such as building grand summer palaces.

Then, he won't have any money left to spend on his army. During Japan's Warring States period, after the death of Tiyetomi Hideyoshi, Tokugawa Ieyasu used precisely this trick to destroy the rest of the Tiyetomi family. He contrived to cause Hideyoshi's wife, Yodo Dono, and his son, Hideyori, to launch a huge project building Buddhist temples, with the aim of making them use up all of their gold and leaving them unable to recruit new soldiers.

¡§Encumber them with constant engagements."

This is about finding things that will cause the enemy headaches, keep him busy and wear him out. Cao Cao comments: ¡§'Engagements' refers to 'problems.' Cause him to become weary and irritated.

When he advances, I retreat; when he retreats, I advance. That is what this is about."
Cause headaches for your enemy. For example, if he turns back, you should move out into the field. If he moves out, you should retreat. We have a good historical example of this from earlier in the book: the Spring and Autumn period state of Wu's campaign of harassment against the state of Chu. Recall that Wu Zixu split the Wu army into three forces, and then made as if to attack, taking only one of the three forces.

The state of Chu mobilized its full army in response, only for the Wu force to suddenly head back home. Once the Chu army had disbanded, the second Wu force would suddenly show up in Chu and start causing problems, causing the Chu authorities to once again mobilize their entire army. And, once again, the Wu army promptly turned around and went home.

Then, the third Wu force did the same thing. After several rounds of this, the state of Chu was exhausted and on the brink of a nervous breakdown. It was at this moment that Wu mobilized all three of its armies at once, captured the Chu capital, the city of Ying, and became the first Spring and Autumn period state to capture another state's capital city. During the Warring States period, the state of Han had a plan to exhaust its rival, the state of Qin.

It successfully enticed the Qin leaders into spending vast human and material resources on a huge irrigation project. They initiated this by sending a hydro engineer named Zheng Guo to the Qin court, where he pushed the massive, resource-intensive project forward. This left Qin without the energy to carry on its invasions against other states to the east. Zheng Guo designed a huge irrigation project for Qin, which would divert the Jing River a distance of over 300 li and into the city of Luoyang. But while the project was under construction, the Han king's plot was exposed. The Qin king wanted to kill Zheng Guo, but the engineer protested: ¡§It's true that, at first, the Han King wanted me to work as his agent, but this irrigation project won't do anything for Han apart from giving it a few years of grace. Meanwhile, this project is a great achievement of the state of Qin, one that will endure for generations." The Qin king's officials could see the sense in Zheng Guo's words, so he was allowed to continue overseeing the irrigation project. Once Zheng Guo's irrigation project was completed, it radically changed the agricultural productivity of the entire Guanzhong region.

Guanzhong had very little rainfall and poor soil quality, and yet it became one of the richest farming regions in all of China. So, the Han plan to 'encumber' and exhaust the state of Qin actually had the opposite effect: it helped Qin to accomplish an era-defining achievement.

Use the power of temptation to make the enemy go exactly where you want them. Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about making him come of his own accord."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Use the prospect of some small advantage to move him; make it inevitable that he will rush where you want him."

Stay safe but always be mindful of danger; Practice good governance but be mindful of potential chaos; This is the way to keep danger and chaos from becoming reality. Solve problems every day, and be ready for things to go wrong at any moment, because things inevitably do go wrong.

It would be impossible for nothing to ever go wrong. This is exactly what being a leader is about: solving problems and smoothing things out. Extract from the original text:
¡§The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemy's not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable."

Analysis:
Military principles tell us not to pin our hopes on the possibility that the enemy just won't turn up. Rather, we're supposed to depend on having made ample preparations and being ready to deal with them when they come.

Don't hold false hope that your enemy won't attack you; make sure you have the strength and the solutions that will stop the enemy from defeating you when they do attack. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Never be idle; let this be what you rely upon."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§When safe, do not forget danger. This is about constantly making preparations." Always be on your guard.

In the ancient strategist Wu Qi's writings about the art of being a general, he says: ¡§Whenever you go out of your house, act as though you had just seen your enemy before you." In other words, keep yourself in a state of heightened alertness. Then there's this line, from the ancient historical text, The Zuo Commentary: ¡§He who does not prepare or make predictions is not fit to serve as a general."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§In general, that which leads to victory in war can be called 'striking where the enemy is weak and attacking where they are sluggish.' The moment you show weakness or a lack of energy, you are immediately placing yourself in grave danger, because this is precisely what your enemy, lined up in neat battle formation, is waiting for. So, if you can consistently keep your battle lines in good order, the enemy will never come."
People often say that there's no point to making preparations if the enemy doesn't come; that it's a waste of time.

But, in reality, the enemy didn't come precisely because you made those preparations. If you hadn't done so, the enemy would be breathing down your neck in an instant. So, when something happens, you need to solve the problem.

If nothing's happened yet, you need to be prepared for something to happen at any moment. An anxiety-free life is just not possible for leaders - for them, each and every day is a journey through anxiety and highly-strung nerves. Wang Xi gives us several examples to think about:
¡§In ancient days, the people of Jin dug deep moats and erected high walls to defend against the military threat posed by Qin.

The people of Jin waited for the Qin armies to come, and the Qin commanders could not remain long in the lands of Jin. The Chu armies lined up in battle formations, so that when the Wu forces arrived to fight, they retreated upon seeing that their foe was well prepared.

Cheng Bushi was inflexible and rigid as a general. He instilled exacting order upon the ranks of his army, and he also instilled order while marching and setting camps; his men used their mess bowls as drums; he kept military documents in tight order; and no man violated his rules. When Zhu Ran became a general, he ordered his troops to beat the drums every day at dawn and dusk, even when all seemed at peace in the world.

When in camp, everybody stayed equipped and ready to march in formation at all times, which rendered enemies unable to calculate how to prepare. Thus, whenever he moved, he recorded new successes."
The parts about the conflicts between Jin and Qin, and Wu and Chu are self-explanatory. The next part, about Cheng Bushi, is especially interesting.

Cheng Bushi was a renowned general of the Han dynasty, and a contemporary of another famous general, Li Guang. These two men were both extreme in their own ways, and since they represent opposite ends of the spectrum, they're often compared against each other. But today, while stories of 'the flying general,' Li Guang, are family favorites across China, few know about Cheng Bushi. This is because of the sheer number of stories about Li Guang, and the total lack of stories about Cheng Bushi; it's possible that Cheng barely fought any battles at all.

But, why is that? It's because his enemies were too scared to attack him. He might not be able to score a victory against you, but one thing's for certain: he would never be defeated. Why is it that Cheng Bushi couldn't be beaten?

It was all down to his extreme strictness and caution. First, ¡§He instilled exacting order upon the ranks of his army," meaning that his chain of command was enforced with extremely tight discipline at every level. Next, ¡§He instilled order while marching and setting camps." He constructed his camps methodically and with a high level of detail, and when it was time for his army to move, it moved as a single unit.

Whenever he'd made camp, his enemies would never be able to dislodge him, no matter how hard they charged his lines. As for the mess bowls, these were the copper vessels used by soldiers at meal times, and they were also used as drums by sentries during their patrol rounds. There are some lines relating to this from a poem by the Tang poet Du Fu: ¡§Thoughts turning to men shouldering spears, who pass years guarding borders; Suddenly, at dusk someone beats their copper bowl, its noise jarring in all directions."
When Cheng Bushi was on the march, he sent scouts ahead of the main force, and a rear guard behind, and he stayed so alert that his camps were practically airtight. He was supremely well prepared, never leaving a base uncovered.

¡§He kept military documents in tight order." He did paperwork every evening, which kept him busy all through the night, until dawn the next day. This is how he never let the Xiongnu get the better of him.

Yet, he never won any impressive victories, and the soldiers who served under him never had a moment's rest. Life in his army was extremely tense, and extremely hard work. On the opposite end of the spectrum, we have General Li Guang.

He never had anything even slightly resembling a well-ordered chain of command. Instead, he formed close personal bonds with his junior officers; his army was a band of brothers. He didn't keep any particular order or structure when marching, and he was quite happy to set up camp any old place, as long as there was a water source. Troops were allowed to make their own arrangements, and generally do things in whatever way suited them, and Li Guang never used the mess-bowl sentry drum system. So, soldiers loved serving under Li Guang, and dreaded having to go with Cheng Bushi. The Xiongnu felt the same way about the two Chinese generals - they loved fighting against Li Guang, and they knew that picking a fight with Cheng Bushi would only bring them bad luck. That's why Cheng Bushi was never defeated.

He was so well prepared that even his enemies didn't want anything to do with him; the mere thought of him was depressing to them. With Li Guang, it was always either a massive victory or a massive defeat. He was once taken captive by his enemies, only to pull off a brilliant escape plan involving a fake illness and stealing horses.

He was later sentenced to death, bought a pardon and was reduced to the status of a commoner, but was eventually reinstated to the rank of general. In the end, after losing his way on the battlefield and finding himself powerless to achieve his objective, the shame was too much for him to bear, and he killed himself. The way Li Guang did things was not how armies are supposed to be run.

In fact, he didn't even manage his forces in any formal sense. This made him incapable of leading large armies, although he had the ability to lead a small band of brothers-at-arms. This is why the Emperor never trusted him with command of the main Imperial army, and instead tasked him with assistant roles, such as small-scale flanking strikes.

He won glory on the battlefield with great consistency, and became extremely famous, and yet he was never rewarded with any noble title. This even became a joke, immortalized in the lines of a Tang poem: ¡§How easy it is for Feng Lao to grow old, and how hard for Li Guang to win a noble title."
So, who should be our role model: Li Guang or Cheng Bushi? The most accurate assessment comes courtesy of Han dynasty general Ma Yuan, known as 'The general who calms the waves.' He said this: ¡§It is not possible to imitate Cheng Bushi, because trying to make oneself a careful, self-controlled person may end in the same way that attempting to carve a swan may produce something that looks much more like a duck. It is not possible to imitate Li Guang, because one will lower oneself to the station of a frivolous man - this is what is known as trying to draw a tiger and inadvertently drawing something that looks more like a dog."
Sima Guang also commented: ¡§If one imitates Bushi, one may not achieve great merit, yet one will not suffer defeat. If one imitates Li Guang, there are few who would not bring the whole empire crashing down as a result." 
The last person who Wang Xi uses as an example is General Zhu Ran, who served as a senior general under Sun Quan during the Three Kingdoms period.

Zhu Ran may not have been as famous as General Zhou Yu, but he was a man of high position. He ultimately reached the ranks of Left Grand Marshal and Right Military Advisor, which made him one of the highest-ranking decision-makers in the Eastern Wu military.

Over his lifetime, he built a glittering military record, and enjoyed what could be called a good death (at least by the standards of the chaotic era in which he lived), at the age of sixty-eight. Even when he wasn't at war, he still beat the drums and drilled his troops every day at dawn and dusk, and he was in the habit of wearing full armor at all times whenever he was in camp, so he'd be ready to move out at a moment's notice.

His enemies never knew what he was planning, so every move he made brought positive results.
