Leadership ability is, to a large extent, a personality type. But, this works both ways - the worst leadership failures generally happen because of some kind of character flaw.

As we'll cover below, there are five character flaws that are especially dangerous. Extract from the original text:
¡§There are five dangerous faults which may affect a general: (1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction; (2) Cowardice, which leads to capture; (3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults; (4) A delicacy of honor, which is sensitive to shame; (5) Over-solicitude for his men, which exposes him to worry and trouble. These are the five besetting sins of a general, ruinous to the conduct of war.

When an army is overthrown and its leader slain, the cause will surely be found among these five dangerous faults. Let them be a subject of meditation."

Analysis:
There are five character flaws that, for those in leadership positions, are especially dangerous:
1) Having no fear of death. If you blindly put yourself in situations where you have to fight to the death, you're going to die at the hands of your enemies.

2) Loving life too much, and being overly fearful of death. If you don't accept the fact of death, you'll end up an enemy prisoner-of-war. 3) Being prone to extreme anger. If you can't handle being provoked, your enemies will use plots to make you angry, so that you come out to fight when you shouldn't, and die in the process. 4) Being too precious, and too fond of your reputation. If you can't tolerate being bad-mouthed, you'll ignore serious risks if you think you're doing something to uphold your reputation and clean your name of the filth that your enemies have smeared it with. Because of this, you'll fall for your enemy's' tricks.

5) Being too protective of the common people. This is something your enemies will exploit, either by making you overwork yourself for the sake of protecting people, or by using ordinary people as human shields, so that you can't bring yourself to attack. For someone whose job it is to lead an army, all five of these character flaws are catastrophic. It is important to be alert to them - any time an army is destroyed or a general is killed, it's virtually always because of one of these five factors! A person's character is also their fate

¡§There are five dangerous faults which may affect a general: (1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction; (2) Cowardice, which leads to capture; (3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults; (4) A delicacy of honor, which is sensitive to shame; (5) Over-solicitude for the people, which exposes him to worry and trouble. These are the five besetting sins of a general, ruinous to the conduct of war.

When an army is overthrown and its leader slain, the cause will surely be found among these five dangerous faults. Let them be a subject of meditation."

Analysis:
¡§(1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction..."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Men possessed of courage but who lack contemplativeness are inevitably prone to desire fighting unto death; they cannot be made to bend or yield, but one traps them in ambushes."
If you ever come up against an enemy who's hell-bent on fighting a death match with you, don't face him head-on. Lure him toward you, set an ambush, and eat him for breakfast.

In The Methods of Sima, there is a line that reads: ¡§He who launches himself toward death cannot be victorious." In other words, a general is never going to win if he substitutes a willingness to lead the charge and duel with death for strategic thinking. Lord Huang Shi, the immortal who according to legend presented the Han dynasty's General Zhang Lang with a copy of Jiang Ziya's Art of War, once said: ¡§Brave men love to exercise their will, and foolish men care not if they die." Brave men like to do things their own way, and are typically unwilling to abandon their plans just because there might be some danger involved. If a man is both brave and foolish, he won't care about dying, which makes him blind to any danger that might threaten his life. Wu Qi once said that when ordinary people discuss what makes a general, they all agree that bravery comes before all else. But, in reality, bravery should only constitute a small part of a general's personality make-up.

This is because brave men can go to battle without giving it too much thought. Anyone who sends their troops into battle without first having a clear idea of what they need to do to advance their own interests doesn't have what it takes to be a general. When Sun Tzu writes about 'The Way of the General,' he lists the necessary personal qualities in the following order: wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness. But in the writings of the Prussian military theorist, Carl von Clausewitz, he emphasizes courage above everything else.

Meanwhile, Wu Qi bluntly said that bravery shouldn't represent more than one small part of a general's personality make-up. ¡§(2) Cowardice, which leads to capture..."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§One can see a potential gain, yet fails to advance because one is scared."
In the same passage of The Methods of Sima that contains the words, ¡§He who launches himself toward death cannot be victorious," there is also the line: ¡§He who clings to life is filled with many doubts." If you're scared of death, you're paranoid, you exaggerate dangers and you fear losing what you have. Lacking the will to fight is a disaster for any military commander.

During the time of the Eastern Jin dynasty (317-420 CE), General Huan Xuan usurped the Jin throne and declared himself Emperor. Another Jin general, Liu Yu, raised an army to put down Huan Xuan's uprising. Moving up the Yangzi River toward Huan Xuan's position, the two sides met at Zhengrong Island, in the middle of the river, and fought a battle there. Liu Yu only had a few thousand troops, while Huan Xuan commanded a much larger force of infantry and cavalry.

And yet, Huan Xuan was scared - scared of losing, and scared of dying. He kept a small rowboat tied to his warship so that he'd be ready to make his escape at any moment. His troops weren't blind; they could see he was frightened, and this completely deflated their willingness to fight. When the battle started, the wind was blowing in Liu Yu's favor, and he used it to set fire to the enemy fleet. Attacking fast and hard, he crushed Huan Xuan.

Meng Shi comments: ¡§Cowardice in a general inevitably gives rise to a desire to return home, and to an unwillingness to personally take part in fighting. This renders soldiers dull of spirit, and causes hesitation at all levels of the army.

When your army is in such a state, the enemy can attack swiftly and subdue your forces."
There's a lot of depth in these words. First, if you're cowardly, you'll be preoccupied with thoughts of going home, and in the back of your mind you'll always be thinking about how you absolutely must make it back alive.

There's no way you can fight a battle in this state of mind, because there's no such thing as a battle where you're guaranteed to come out alive. If you want to be certain that you'll survive, the only things you can do are run away or surrender.

Nor can you just let your subordinates go to their deaths on the front lines without being prepared to do the same yourself. This is because, as the leader, it was your idea to go to war in the first place. Everyone else in your army is just following your lead; they're there to lend you a hand, to help you solve your problems.

You can't send other people to do something for you if you're not prepared to do it yourself, because that means you're not needed. The same principle applies in the modern world: whatever project you're working on, you mustn't go absent from the front line. If you do, you become disconnected from the situation on the ground, which effects your ability to apply yourself mentally to the project.

Once you no longer have your nose to the ground, your ability to lead suffers and grows weaker. In terms of the dynamics of your organization, if you're not there by your soldiers' side, if you're not personally leading them, ¡§this renders soldiers dull of spirit, and causes hesitation at all levels of the army." When that happens, ¡§the enemy can attack swiftly and subdue your forces."

¡§(3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults..."
Du Mu comments: ¡§A 'hasty temper' refers to one who is unyielding and prone to anger; it refers to one who is often hurried, and whose character is not steadfast."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§In generals, the most precious characteristic is consistency and an even keel; with a hasty temper, one is susceptible to provocation."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Men who are of hasty temper can be provoked and angered, and in this way, they may be defeated."
To be a general, it is important to be naturally calm, steady and stable. If you're hotheaded, with a short temper, and blinkered in the way you think, these are character flaws that your enemies will exploit.

They'll poke you, press your buttons and insult you until you bite down hard on their baited hook. During the Uprising of the Five Barbarians, which took place during the Sixteen Kingdoms (304-439 CE) period, Yao Xiang of the Qiang ethnic group attacked Huangluo. Fu Sheng of the Former Qin dynasty sent Fu Huangmei and Deng Qiang to deal with the invasion.

Meanwhile, Yao Xiang had already built a solid defensive position, where he'd holed up and was refusing to come out and fight. Deng Qiang said to Huangmei: ¡§Yao Xiang is a hard man by nature, and fierce. It will be easy to make him angry.

If we make a lot of noise and fanfare, and press straight towards his ramparts, I am sure that he will not tolerate our noise. He'll be compelled to come out and show that he's stronger than us, and then, after just one battle, he'll be our prisoner." Huangmei went along with this plan, and sure enough, Yao Xiang couldn't take the provocation.

He came storming out to fight in a fury, and ended up getting executed by Huangmei. Another example would be the case of Li Shimin, who before he became the first Emperor of the Tang dynasty (Emperor Taizong) beheaded the Sui dynasty general Song Laosheng. Song Laosheng headed a force of 20,000 elite troops defending the city of Huoyicheng, and Li Yuan prepared to attack Song's position.

Li Shimin told Li Yuan that Song Laosheng was brave, but simple-minded - he could definitely be lured out to fight. So, Li Yuan set up an ambush outside the city walls, while Li Jiancheng and Li Shimin led a few dozen cavalry troops to the foot of the city walls, where they began hurling insults at Song Laosheng. As expected, Song Laosheng couldn't stand the verbal abuse, and came charging out of the gates at the head of his army. He ran straight into Li Yuan's ambush, by which point Li Shimin had already taken control of the city gates, leaving Song with nowhere to run.

He was cut down on the battlefield. ¡§(4) A delicacy of honor which is sensitive to shame..."
Here, 'a delicacy of honor' doesn't mean the kind of honor that's the opposite of corruption. Instead, it's the kind of honor that makes people believe in their own purity and perfection.

This is about people who have an extreme love for their own image and reputation, and who can't tolerate the slightest stain on their good name. This is the kind of person who, if you destroy his reputation, will jump in the Yellow River and still not feel clean. This means two things: 1) He'll fight you to the death; 2) He's willing to die to prove his purity.

He'll walk right into your trap, do exactly what you want him to, and he'll do this even if he knows perfectly well that you're tricking him. It's a massive character flaw to not be able to deal with being bad-mouthed.

At the same time, if you're always fishing for compliments and praise, and if you're motivated by shaping a glowing reputation for yourself, you have a serious problem. That's because the more your reputation sparkles and shines, the more you trigger a compulsive reflex in the people around you to throw dirt on your name.

Let's face it: it hurts the eyes to look at someone so impossibly pure and spotless. That's why, in ancient China, there was the concept of 'a gentleman belittles himself.' This essentially meant that by carefully applying some dirt to your image, you take the shine off and make it less painful for others to look at you. It's self-effacement as a self-defense mechanism.

¡§(5) Over-solicitude for the people, which exposes him to worry and trouble..."
The same principle works here as in kidnapping. In movies, when a hero's girlfriend is captured, no danger, no matter how deadly, can stop him from coming to her rescue.

If a general has great love for the people, the people can be used against him, as hostages. There's a well-known story that relates to this, in the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms. Before the Battle of Red Cliffs, Cao Cao was on the attack against Liu Bei. Liu Bei retreated, but he could only move very slowly because he'd taken civilians with him, and his focus and attention were drawn to protecting them.

So, Cao Cao caught up with him. However, this trick doesn't work on certain people. For example, during the Rebellion of the Seven States (154 BCE), when the rebel army attacked the kingdom of Liang, Liang was placed under enormous strain.

The situation was perilous. The King of Liang begged for imperial reinforcements, but Imperial Commander Zhou Yafu completely ignored him, and left him to struggle alone on the brink of the abyss. In fact, Zhou Yafu wanted to wear down the rebel army's morale and let them use up their grain rations, and in the end he swept in to the save the day, just when it appeared all was lost. Things had gone exactly according to his plan - the kingdom of Liang survived, the rebel army ran out of grain and retreated, and Zhou Yafu struck just as the enemy had become sluggish and had begun thinking of going home. In one fell swoop, the rebellion was over.

But the King of Liang was left with nothing but a deep hatred for Zhou Yafu. In the end, the Commander got all the credit for putting down the rebellion, but it was he who had weathered the ravages of war! Zhou Yafu didn't look out for the King of Liang, but Liu Bang was even more heartless - he didn't even take care of his own family.

His father, wife and children were all left out in the cold. Xiang Yu captured Liu Bang's wife, Lu Hi, as well as his father, who was stripped naked and trussed up on a giant wooden chopping board. Next to the chopping board, Xiang Yu installed a huge cooking pot, and told Liu Bang that if he refused to come out and fight, his father would be boiled alive and his wife would be slaughtered. Liu Bang, standing on his city walls, shouted his reply to Xiang Yu at full volume: ¡§You and I are sworn brothers - we made our oaths with King Huai as a witness - so my father is your father. If you intend to make our father into soup, then save a bowl for me.

As for my wife - kill her if you wish, it makes no difference to me." Xiang Yu, confronted with such appalling shamelessness, turned purple with fury. And yet, he never did harm Liu Bang's family members.

Another time, after being soundly defeated by Xiang Yu, Liu Bang was in a chariot fleeing the scene. Xiahou Ying was at the reigns, and also in the chariot were Liu Bang's young son and daughter, the future Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan. With enemy troops closing in from behind, Liu Bang decided that the chariot was moving too slowly because it was overloaded with too many people. So, using his feet, he shunted his son and daughter off the vehicle, planning to continue his getaway as the lone passenger.

But, Xiahou Ying immediately stopped the chariot, scooped up the children, and carried on. This happened three more times. Each time that Xiahou Ying plucked the terrified children from the ground, they clung tight to his neck. And Xiahou Ying took his time - he didn't lash the horses back up to high speed, but soothed the children until they'd calmed down a little, before finally speeding the horses on their way. Liu Bang was so furious that he wanted to kill Xiahou Ying there and then, but if he did that, there would be no one to drive the chariot.

In the end, everyone on board made it to safety. People like Liu Bang - who feel no compulsion either to cling to life or veer towards death, never rush things, don't have a sparkling reputation to keep shiny, and don't love the common people - may well be the most contemptible kind of people to walk the earth. Yet, because of this, they are also unstoppable as war leaders.

Sun Tzu said: ¡§In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign, collects his army and concentrates his forces. When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions.

There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must not be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account.  Chapter Nine
The Army on the March

Trusting to luck is the worst possible mindset for a decision-maker

Understanding the art of war doesn't necessarily mean that you know how to use it, because when the time comes, your state of mind might be different. Extract from the original text:
¡§We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy.

Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys. Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight. So much for mountain warfare. After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross.

Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move upstream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare."

Analysis:
Commenting on The Army on the March, Wang Xi writes: ¡§Armies on the move should occupy favourable terrain, and observe the enemy's situation." Here, 'armies on the move' includes the various stages of marching, camping and strategically arranging battle lines. Generals on the march should do two things: make good use of favourable terrain, and pay close attention to the enemy's situation. So, The Army on the March is about what to take note of in different types of terrain, and the secrets to accurately judging the enemy situation. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Choose that which brings advantage, and then march."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Understand the variations in the nine types of terrain; then, you can select for advantages and march. Hence, this chapter proceeds from Variations in Tactics."

¡§We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy."

The meaning of 'encamping the army' is self-explanatory. 'Observing signs of the enemy' is about watching for clues and signs from the enemy, and using these to shed light on certain questions. Wang Xi comments: ¡§Regarding encamping the enemy, there are four points to consider; regarding observing signs of the enemy, there are thirty-one points to consider." Wang Xi is talking about different methods for camping in four different types of terrain, and how to assess thirty-one different kinds of signals gleaned from observing the enemy. ¡§Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys.

Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight. So much for mountain warfare."

Here we have the most important things to know about the first terrain type: mountains. What is there in mountain valleys that's useful for an army? Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is advantageous to be close to water and grass." In mountain valleys, you can find water sources and grass for feeding livestock. Armies have horses, and horses need grass to eat.

Then there are the animals brought along by the army cooks - pigs and sheep. Li Quan comments: ¡§Whenever an army makes camp, it is essential to immediately assign soldiers to guard duty, set livestock out to graze, collect firewood and gather wild vegetables. Then, all will be calm in the camp."
During the Later Han dynasty (25-220 CE), there was an uprising of ethnic Qiang people in the Wudu Commandery. General Ma Yuan was sent to deal with the rebels.

When he arrived, the Qiang warriors were high up in the mountains, so he occupied a valley, setting up a strong defensive that gave him exclusive access to the area's water and grass. And then, he refused to come out to fight.

The Qiang warriors were in a dire situation - their water supply was cut off and their food stores dwindling - and so, they surrendered. ¡§Camp in high places, facing the sun."

'Facing the sun' also means 'facing south' in this context.

So, to 'Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys' means that, although you should stay close to the valleys, you mustn't camp in valley bottoms. Instead, camp somewhere high up, facing the sun.

In high places, your field of vision opens up, which makes it easier to defend your camp. If you camp in a valley, it's easy for the enemy to surround you, and to attack you from above. The reason we're told to specifically select campsites facing the sun is because they're drier, warmer and more comfortable. And, in these places, it's not so easy for disease to spread.

In shady, damp locations, it's easy for soldiers to catch colds, and due to the lack of medicine in ancient times, a rampant flu might lead to a large number of deaths. Napoleon once said that no war, no matter how brutal, has as negative an effect on an army's morale as an unhygienic camp. It's a much grimmer scenario to lose soldiers to an epidemic, away from the battlefield, than it is to lose them in combat.

That's because in a battle, at least the enemy is losing soldiers at the same time you are. But disease can decimate your army while completely ignoring the enemy. We just talked about how Ma Yuan's occupation of favourable terrain caused serious problems for the Qiang rebels, which ultimately led to their downfall.

But earlier in the book, we also learned about the final battle of Ma Yuan's career. He was leading a campaign in Hunan to put down a rebellion of the Miao people, and his risky decision to lead his army forward via a river led to him being stranded in a deep valley, hemmed in by high mountains and dense vegetation. His camp on the riverbank was damp and far removed from the sun.

Pinned down by enemy attacks from high above, and facing a disease outbreak, his own life came to an end when he fell prey to the contagion. Was Ma Yuan aware of the dangers when he made that fateful decision?

Of course he was - crystal clear. But he was also old, and he knew that this campaign would be his last chance to earn a glorious place in the history books. He didn't care about danger or whether he'd come out alive; he intended to take his chances.

This is a different kind of mentality, and it represents the first of the 'five dangerous faults which may effect a general' from the previous chapter. Namely, ¡§Recklessness, which leads to destruction." There's no doubt that he would have been able to recite this line from memory. The reason he disobeyed it was that he'd given himself over to the worst of all mindsets that a decision-maker can have: trusting to luck.

Trusting to luck is a mentality that effects all of us, and often. That's why it's important to check our state of mind before making decisions. Ask yourself, 'By making this decision, is there any part of me that's taking a chance?'

¡§Do not climb heights in order to fight."

Du Mu comments: ¡§If I occupy a lower position, then I may not move uphill to attack, and neither may I face an enemy attack if they come from above."
You'll always come off second best if you try to attack uphill. Don't even try it.

¡§So much for mountain warfare."

The lines above contain all the information needed to properly handle moving armies, camping and fighting in mountainous terrain. The art of war in marine combat is the same as fighting on land

Extract from the original text:
¡§After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream.

It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river that he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun.

Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare."

Analysis:
¡§When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river that he has to cross."
When an enemy army crosses a river on its way to attack you, before anything else, you need to choose a place far away from the river to set up your battle lines. Don't hover near the river, and don't stand in the river waiting for the enemy to come.

Instead, wait until only half of their forces have crossed, and then strike. So, Sun Tzu's methods for fighting marine battles are the same as his methods for fighting on dry land. The only difference is that if you fight all your battle on the water, you're leading a navy, and not an army. The reason you shouldn't deploy in battle formation directly on a riverbank is that although this enables you to stop the enemy from crossing the river, if they don't actually cross, you won't have a chance to beat them. So, abandon your position on the riverbank and draw the enemy across the river. Once they've begun crossing, don't wait in the middle of the river for them to attack - wait until half of their forces have crossed, and then strike. This way, the enemy army will only be able to commit half of its troops to the fight, and you also benefit from the fact that they're on low ground (the river bank), while you can charge down from higher ground.

This is all quite different from how we normally imagine launching and defending against amphibious attacks. For example, if during the Normandy landing on D-Day, the German army hadn't tried to hold a defensive position on the coast, but had instead waited for the Allied forces to be 'halfway landed' - and then launched an offensive - that day in history would have taken an unimaginably different course. That's why there's a pre-condition for this approach to fighting: it only applies 'If you are anxious to fight.' This is only for generals whose goal is annihilate their enemy in battle, and not for generals whose main objective is to defend. Duke Xiang of Song's attempt to model himself after Duke Huan was absurd, not 'Benevolent'

Extract from the original text:
¡§When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream.

It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun.

Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare."

Analysis:
In Du Mu's commentary on these lines, he writes about a historical episode from the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE). While General Guo Huai of the kingdom of Wei held a position in the city of Hanzhong, Liu Bei and his army were on the other side of the Han River, planning to cross and attack Guo Huai. Guo Huai's junior officers all considered Liu Bei a formidable warrior, and on top of that, he also had superior numbers. Therefore, they advised Guo Huai to set up battle lines along the riverbank, stopping Liu Bei from crossing. But Guo Huai disagreed: ¡§You are all wrong. By clinging to the riverbank we would be showing weakness, and Liu Bei would know immediately that we were scared to fight him. Knowing this, he would be emboldened to cross the river regardless.

It is better to deploy our forces at a distance from the river, thus enticing him to cross. Then, while only half of his forces have crossed, we will strike." And so, Guo Huai deployed his forces far from the river. On the far bank, Liu Bei saw what was happening, and knew exactly what trick Guo Huai was planning.

He knew better than to try to cross, and instead he withdrew his army. After the death of Duke Huan of Qi in 643 BCE, during the Spring and Autumn period, the lands of China no longer had a single, undisputed ruler. Duke Xiang of Song had ambitions to take up the late Duke Huan's mantle, but he lacked the power to do so.

So, he tried to fashion himself as a new Duke Huan, trumpeting his 'benevolence' in the hope that this would be enough to convince all the people of China to bend the knee to him. In the attempt, Duke Xiang left us with a big, historical joke - the battle of the River Hong. With his ambition to become undisputed ruler of the known world, Duke Xiang decided to start with the easiest target: he went on the warpath against the feeble kingdom of Zheng. Zheng requested help from the kingdom of Chu, which immediately sent out an army to attack the kingdom of Song. Duke Xiang, seeing that he had a serious situation on his hands, called his armies back and dug in at a defensive position by the River Hong, where the Chu and Song armies eventually clashed. The Chu forces had yet to cross the river, but meanwhile, on the far side, the Song army was already deployed in battle formation. The Song Minister of War, Gong Sungu, tried to give Duke Xiang some advice: ¡§The enemy's men are many, while we are few; we should strike when they are in the midst of crossing." But Duke Xiang didn't agree. Claiming that he was a 'benevolent' commander, he said: ¡§I shall not impel the enemy to a perilous position, and I shall not force them into distress."
So, the Chu army crossed the river safely and began to deploy in battle formation. Again, Gong Sungu pled with Duke Xiang to take advantage of the enemy's temporary disorderliness and attack, but Duke Xiang wouldn't allow it.

¡§They are not yet beating their drums, and they have not yet formed up in their ranks," he said. Only after the Chu soldiers had finished lining up did he finally give the order to attack. His whole army was annihilated, and he himself sustained a fatal injury.

And that was the end of Duke Xiang of Song's dreams of ruling the entire world. People often laugh at what they call 'Duke Xiang's pig-headed benevolence.' At the same time, they lament the loss of the 'traditional chivalry of war' that came after the time of the first three of China's dynasties, the Xia, Shang and Zhou. 'Benevolence is dead and buried,' people sigh, 'and skullduggery stands in its place.'
But, in reality, Duke Xiang wasn't the slightest bit 'benevolent.' He was just a classic nobleman, full of dreams of restoring his ancestors' glory. The rulers of Song were descended from the former royal house of Shang, confined to the land of Song after the new Zhou dynasty destroyed the final Shang ruler.

When Duke Huan of Qi died, Duke Xiang thought it should be his turn to rule the world. But he had lived his whole life deep inside palace chambers, in the hands of women. He'd never left the palace, and he had no idea what the world was like, let alone the intricacies of politics and war. He knew that he didn't have military power, but the way he saw it, 'benevolence' was what enabled Duke Huan of Qi to rule the world. And so, he felt, all he had to do was possess 'benevolence' and the world would raise him up and name him Undisputed Sovereign. Nobody else was buying it, especially not the leaders of Chu, who kidnapped Duke Xiang during a meeting he'd called in the hope of launching a new alliance.

It was only after the rulers of Lu spoke on his behalf that Chu let him go home. He'd been humiliated by Chu, yet he was too scared to take his revenge. And so, instead, he tried to vent his anger on Chu's 'little brother,' the state of Zheng. Chu then attacked him, and the whole absurd farce that was the Battle of the River Hong unfolded. There was nothing at all 'benevolent' about Duke Xiang of Song.

Even describing him as an idiot would be over-selling him - he was nothing less than absurd. The problem with studying The Art of War is that the enemy understands it, too; The problem with studying game theory is that the enemy doesn't understand it

The art of war is about winning.

But, if the enemy also understands the art of war, that makes it difficult to win. In game theory, everyone can win. This means that if you calculate the optimum outcome for both sides, but your enemy doesn't understand how it works, they'll end up dragging you down with them and you'll both suffer damage.

Extract from the original text:
¡§After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross.

Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare."

Analysis:
When Liu Bei saw that Guo Huai had lined up his army far away from the river, he didn't dare try to cross. A similar scenario played out in the early years of the Tang dynasty (618-907 CE), but there was an opposite outcome.

Generals Xue Wanjun and Luo Yi were defending Youyan when Dou Jiande attacked the area of Fanyang, at the head of an army of several hundred thousand men. Xue Wanjun said to Luo Yi: ¡§We are outnumbered - if we go out to fight, even if we fought a hundred different battles, we would be defeated each time.

Our only option is to subdue the enemy by trickery. We should send a detachment of our weakest soldiers to the river in front of the city to block Dou's passage. Thus, Dou will be enticed into crossing the river. Meanwhile, you will lay in ambush on the enemy's flank with several hundred elite warriors, and once half of the enemy forces have crossed, that is when you will strike."
Luo Yi went along with the plan, and sure enough, Dou Jiande crossed. Luo Yi attacked precisely when half of the enemy troops had crossed, and inflicted a massive defeat. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§If rebel soldiers move their forces across a waterway in order to join battle on the far side, you must not meet them at the water's edge. Wait until half of the enemy forces have crossed, and then move while their ranks are not yet settled and their head and tail detached; if you strike then, you are sure to be victorious."

¡§If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross."

If you're looking to engage the enemy in combat, don't deploy your forces at the water's edge and think they'll come to you; they won't. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§If I wish to be certain that battle will be joined, then I must not await the enemy near to the water, for fear that he will not cross. Conversely, if I do not wish to fight, then I must obstruct his passage across the water, so that it is impossible for him to cross."
However, given that both sides understand this principle, it's actually used in reverse, as in the historical examples above. Guo Huai didn't want a fight with Liu Bei, and he knew exactly what to do: according to the art of war, if you don't want to fight, you should deploy at the river's edge so as to block the enemy from crossing. But Guo Huai knew that Liu Bei was familiar with this tactic, meaning that if he followed the art of war and lined up by the river, Liu Bei would recognize this as a sign that Guo Huai was weak, reluctant to fight, and would then do the exact opposite of what Guo Huai wanted, crossing the river and attacking. Then, there would be no guarantee that Guo Huai's limited battle capabilities would be able to hold off the enemy. But, if Guo Huai chose to form up at a distance from the river, then according to the art of war, Liu Bei should take this as a sign that Guo Huai had a powerful enough army to feel confident, that he wanted to fight, and that if Liu Bei tried to cross, Guo Huai would attack before all his forces reached the far side. So, Liu Bei decided he couldn't take the risk of attacking.

In the end, Guo Huai's gamble paid off - he forced an error of judgment from Liu Bei. Zhang Yu also wrote about another interesting episode from Chinese military history, from the Spring and Autumn period. During a war between the states of Jin and Chu, the forces of Jin commander Yang Chufu and Chu commander Zi Shang came head-to-head at the River Zhi. Yang Chufu wanted to make the Chu army cross the river, so he could attack while only half their army had crossed. He pulled his army back some way from the river and set up camp. Meanwhile, Zi Shang had the same idea: wanting to lure the Jin army across the river, he also pulled his army back and set up camp away from the river. Both generals were thinking in exactly the same way, so neither was fooled by the other's plan.

Both sides kept retreating, further and further away, until it became clear that nothing was going to happen. At that point, both sides packed up and headed home. This is why the problem with studying the art of war is that the enemy understands it, too. By contrast, with game theory, problems happen when the enemy doesn't understand it. The art of war is about winning, but if the enemy also understands the art of war, that makes it difficult to win. In game theory, everyone can win.

This means that if your enemy doesn't understand game theory, even if you calculate the optimum outcome for both sides, if your enemy doesn't understand how it works, they'll end up dragging you down with them, and you'll both take damage. It's a common saying in Chinese that 'Circumstances are more powerful than mortal men.' So, if you're faced with circumstances where both you and your enemy are taking damage, why not team up instead? And yet, your opponent likely has a different assessment of the circumstances than you do.

If he thinks he can win, all you can do is walk with him down the road of defeat. ¡§Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun."

Earlier, we talked about how, in mountainous terrain, it's important to 'camp in high places, facing the sun,' and the same principle applies when you're near bodies of water. Cao Cao comments: ¡§On water also, one should position oneself up high; face the water, and keep your backs to the high terrain."
We've already talked about why you should choose a position facing the sun - these places are drier, more hygienic and less prone to outbreaks of disease. There are three good reasons to position yourself in high places.

First, you have a broader field of vision, which helps you monitor the enemy's situation. Second, the enemy won't be able to flood you out, and you'll be safe from flash floods if there's an overnight rainstorm.

Third, if the enemy tries a surprise attack, starting from a higher position will tilt the balance of power and energy in your favor. ¡§Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§For fear of being flooded." Here, Cao Cao is referring to being flooded out of one's camp by the enemy. The same meaning applies as in 'moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun.'
Jia Lin comments: ¡§In areas with flowing water, the enemy may flood my army, or he may release poisonous substances in the water." Poison is another potential danger. Zhuge Liang once said: ¡§In waterborne combat, one must not try to move counter to the current." Whichever side is moving with the current holds an advantage - a big advantage.

If you try to move upstream to attack an enemy, you're fighting against the current as well as against your enemies, leaving you with very poor odds of victory. This is why the cities of Xiangyang and Anqing were key strategic locations throughout history; any general who takes Xiangyang or Anqing would have free movement downriver, making it effectively impossible to stop them from taking Nanjing. ¡§So much for river warfare."

This concludes the section about applying the art of war to marine warfare.

The art of using military force in salt marshes and on open plains

Analysis:
Chen Hao comments: ¡§Salt marshes are areas of alkaline land, where both water and grass are of coarse quality, and they are so imbued with damp that they are not suitable places to position an army. In The Xin Xun, it is written that 'in areas of salt marshes and swamps, the five grains cannot grow.' This is true."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§Salt marshes are alkaline places, characterized by open, sunken land, and by a lack of secure places."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§On account of damp and humid vapor possessed by the earth in such places, and of the sparse and coarse water and grasses, one should make haste to pass through."
In these comments, we have four major threats posed by salt marshes:
1) 'The five grains' cannot grow, meaning there is no food and no opportunity to re-supply. 2) Water and local grass species are sparse and of poor quality, meaning these are challenging places in which to encamp.

3) The terrain is open and low, meaning there are no easily defendable places, and making it difficult to build defensive structures. 4) The air is damp and humid, making it easy for disease to spread. Hence, 'Your sole concern should be to get over them quickly, without any delay.' In these lines, we can find the source of the difficulties faced by the Communist Red Army while crossing grassy areas during the Long March. ¡§If forced to fight in a salt marsh or a swamp, you should have water and grass near you, and get your back to a clump of trees."

If you're going to be in a damp, marshy area, it's essential that you find somewhere with a fresh water source.

Without access to fresh drinking water, an army won't last long in a salt marsh. There are two benefits to positioning yourself up against trees: 1) Nobody will be able to come at you from behind, so at least it will be impossible for an enemy force to surround you on all four sides; 2) In marshland, it's impossible to know how shallow or deep the bog in front of you might be. With each step you take, you face the possibility that you'll sink irretrievably into a deep swamp, like hapless Red Army soldiers in war movies, swallowed whole as they walk across the marshlands.

The same thing can happen in deserts - in certain spots there are deep pits of loose sand that are impossible to climb out of once you fall in. All you can do is wait as you slowly sink deeper, and are eventually buried by the sand.

If you fall in, you're not the only person in danger; anyone who tries to pull you out risks being sucked in with you. Wherever there are trees, you know the ground is relatively solid, so you don't have to face this danger. Li Quan mentions this danger in his commentary: ¡§If it is impossible to cross quickly, and if one must fight, it is essential to find a position with water, and with trees with which to shield one's back. In any place with water and trees, there is no danger of becoming trapped and drowning." If it's not possible to quickly cross a marsh - for example, because it's too big to cross in a single day - it's necessary to find a place with water and trees to camp and prepare for the eventuality of engaging in battle. ¡§So much for operations in salt marshes."

This concludes the part about strategies for leading armies in salt marshes.

¡§In dry, level country, take up an easily accessible position."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Flat land - one must choose a place that is flat, level and provides easy access, and position one's army there. Thus, one's chariots and cavalry are able to move at speed."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is beneficial for chariots and cavalry."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Level, open wildernesses are places for chariots and cavalry; one must choose a position that is level, easily accessible, and devoid of pits and holes, and station one's army there.

This is beneficial to moving at high speed."
In ancient times, the Chinese didn't rely only on the Great Wall to stop the northern nomadic people from launching raids to the south. They also planted massive numbers of trees on the open plains, because the armies of the northern Xiongnu were built around cavalry, while Chinese armies mainly used infantry forces. The idea behind planting trees was to slow down the speed at which the Xiongnu could travel; otherwise, the pounding hooves of the northern cavalry would have been able to carry invading armies deep into China.

¡§... with rising ground to your right and on your rear, so that the danger may be in front, and safety lie behind."

While you should choose a flat place with easy access, that doesn't mean your base should be surrounded by flat ground on all sides. If all around you there's nothing but flat land, you would be exposed to the enemy on all sides.

In the ideal scenario, you would have high land to your right and to your rear, and flat land to your left. This gives you a protective barrier to shield your back, and flat terrain in front so that you can take the fight to the enemy. The meaning of 'danger in front, and safety behind' is that the battlefield, the place of death, should be out in front, and behind you there should be mountains - a place without danger, a place of life. This puts you in a good position to fight.

So, whichever side reaches the battlefield first, and claims the best terrain, gets a major boost to their odds of victory. Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is beneficial for fighting." In other words, setting yourself up like this makes things more convenient.

But why should the high land be on the right, and not on the left? Li Quan comments: ¡§In all things which a man might make use of, it is most convenient to use the right; hence, one should face away from the right." An estimated 90% of people worldwide are right-handed; they do everything with their right hand. For example, when holding a long gun, most use their left hand to hold the front and their right hand to hold the back.

Hence, the right side is, for the vast majority of people, the side of convenience. Jia Lin comments: ¡§Hillocks and mounds are here called 'life,' and battlefields are here called 'death.' With hillocks or mounds to your rear, your army occupies a stable position; with the battlefield positioned in front, one is conveniently positioned to deploy one's army; with high land to the right, it is expedient to turn around."
For example, if you shout an order, 'Turn to the right,' everyone will turn in the clockwise direction, but some might mistakenly turn to the left. If that happens, everyone will laugh and make fun of them.

Jiang Ziya once said: ¡§One's army must be positioned with rivers or swamps to the left, and hills to the right." This is the best of all possible worlds - you have everything you need, and the enemy only has one approach route, which makes the task of defending your position much easier. ¡§So much for campaigning in flat country."

This concludes the section on leading armies in flat terrain. ¡§These are the four useful branches of military knowledge which enabled the Yellow Emperor to vanquish the four sovereigns."

We've now reached the conclusion of this part on terrain, where Sun Tzu wraps up the sections on how to use military force in mountainous, watery, swampy and flat terrain. Zhuge Liang once said: ¡§When fighting in mountainous country, do not climb to fight the enemy at a higher elevation; when fighting upon water, do not move counter to the current; when fighting in marshland, do not wade into the depths; when fighting in flat country, do not leave yourself exposed at the rear."
These are the four principles the Yellow Emperor used to defeat the four feudal lords of China.

Who were these 'sovereigns? In the records of the most ancient reaches of Chinese history, there is mention of 'the Three Emperors and the Five Sovereigns,' but there's nothing written about 'the four sovereigns.' Cao Cao comments: ¡§When the Yellow Emperor first established himself, the sovereigns of the four regions all claimed the title of sovereign." So, 'sovereign' was just a generic word used for feudal lords at the time. Where did Sun Tzu learn the art of war?

Did it just fall from the sky? Did he come up with it entirely by himself? In fact, it was none of the above. He worked in the same way as Confucius, who said: ¡§I expound, rather than create." Sun Tzu just offered explanations of what he'd learned from the ancient thinkers who came before him; he didn't create anything new. Every version of The Art of War that exists traces its origins to the Yellow Emperor.

The Yellow Emperor's treatise was written about his top general, Feng Hou. We've already discussed the principle of 'Using the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.' This idea originally came from Writings on Grasping the Irregular, part of Feng Hou's writings on the art of war. It then passed from the Yellow Emperor down to Jiang Ziya, and from Jiang Ziya to Sun Tzu, who finally compiled the entirety of China's military wisdom in his book, The Art of War.

This book has, from ancient times until today, always kept its place at the cutting edge of each historical era's military strategy and thinking. The famous British strategist, BH Liddell Hart, once commented: ¡§There are only two books of military strategy in this world, which surpass all the strategies contained in all other books of military lore. Those two books are Sun Tzu's The Art of War and Clausewitz's On War, and the latter is outdated when compared with Sun Tzu's The Art of War."
On War came into the world more than 2,000 years after Sun Tzu's The Art of War, yet here Liddell Hart claims that On War is outdated, while The Art of War represents the forefront of military thinking. If you want to know the true value of Sun Tzu's masterwork, look no further.

¡§All armies prefer high ground to low and yang (sunny) places to yin (dark).
