When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the yang side, with the slope on your right rear.

Thus you will at once act for the benefit of your soldiers and utilize the natural advantages of the ground."

And with that, let's do one last summary. Whenever it comes time to find a campsite for your army, always choose high, dry terrain, and stay well clear of damp, low-lying ground. Orient yourself towards yang, and don't back yourself up against yin.

'Taking care of your men' means staying close to fresh water and grass. This makes it easy to graze the army's war horses, cattle and sheep, to find food for the pigs, to fetch water and firewood, and to maintain open supply lines. 'Placing yourself in a position of strength' means occupying the high ground, with mountains covering your back - this is a strong position. If you back up against empty space, leaving your rear unprotected, your position is weak.

If you 'take care of your men and place yourself in a position of strength' you are safeguarding your army's vital necessities. You have the security of a natural barrier protecting your rear, so you don't have to worry about being attacked from behind, and you keep one side open so that you can press the enemy. If you camp high up, facing the sun, taking care of your men and putting yourself in a strong position, disease won't spread easily through your army.

This is the only way to keep your army's battle capabilities sharp; this is how to guarantee victory. ¡§When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the sunny side, with the slope on your right rear."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Whenever encountering hills or banks, one should occupy the southeastern side."
So, selecting a military campsite is more or less the same as buying a house - if you want to be safe and comfortable, you have to carefully choose a place with the right orientation. Wang Xi comments: ¡§Positioned in yang, people are able to live in comfort and harmony; this is beneficial to nurturing health and talent."

Sun Tzu teaches a life-saving lesson to backpackers from The Art of War

Extract from the original text:
¡§When, in consequence of heavy rains up-country, a river which you wish to ford is swollen and flecked with foam, you must wait until it subsides."

Analysis:
If you're trying to cross a river and you see that the water is brown with mud and has bubbles on the surface, this means there's been a lot of rain upriver, and it's possible that the water level is about to surge upwards. If you see these signs and still try to cross, it's possible that the river will swell while you're still crossing.

If that happens, you might drown. Don't cross; wait for a while. When the river surface shows signs of calming down and the flow stabilizes, then you can cross. I regularly see news reports about water released from an upstream reservoir, resulting in death by drowning at points downstream.

The only effect of these reports is to rouse public fury, but nobody comes out with a technical solution for the problem. Why isn't it possible to release signals into the river before releasing reservoir water?

For example, you could start by releasing only a small amount of water, and at the same time put red floating balls into the stream to warn people downstream. These balls could be released in batches, every ten minutes, and after an hour the full water release would officially commence.

Wouldn't this give people downstream time to prepare? Otherwise, if you just continue the old policy of sending out notifications in downstream villages, there will always be people who don't get the news in time.

Then, when the deluge comes barreling down the river, lives are lost. For those of us who enjoy outdoor pursuits, this part of The Art of War is very useful. It's not unheard of for hikers to camp next to rivers, only for flash floods to come down from the mountains and drown them in the night.

This kind of tragic event has happened at the foot of Ali Mountain in Taiwan - tourists were fishing on a riverbank when a flash flood came down from upstream, causing the water level to surge. Search and rescue personnel made it to the scene, as well as television broadcasting trucks, but they were unable to save the stranded tourists, who ended up drowning on live television.

Make sure you remember this line from Sun Tzu's The Art of War: if you see river water turning muddy and starting to bubble, that means it's raining upstream, and the water level is liable to shoot up suddenly.

At least there's one difference between flood surges caused by rain and those caused by reservoirs dumping water into rivers - with natural floods, there's generally time to escape. Six dangerous types of terrain

Extract from the original text:
¡§Country in which there are precipitous cliffs with torrents running between, deep natural hollows, confined places, tangled thickets, quagmires and crevasses should be left with all possible speed and not approached.

While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear."

Analysis:
These are the six dangerous types of terrain, which we should never get too close to. Mei Yaochen comments about 'precipitous cliffs with torrents running between' that are 'dangerously steep all around, with water rushing about.'
Cao Cao comments: ¡§'Precipitous cliffs with torrents running between' refers to places of deep mountains and large waterways."
Basically, it's about places with deep ravines with large waterways flowing through, which are impassable. About 'deep natural hollows,' Mei Yaochen says that these are ¡§dangerously steep on four sides; places to which ravines and canyons lead."
Cao Cao identifies these places as having ¡§high walls in all directions, with a hollow below in the center."
Du Mu quotes from another ancient text, the Jun Shi: ¡§Terrain characterized by cavities, where large waterways flow; such places are called 'heavenly wells.'"
These places are deep holes with water at the bottom.

Basically, they're massive, natural wells. About 'confined places,' Mei Yaochen states that they are ¡§blocked on three sides; easy to enter, but difficult to exit.""
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Places which are passed through in deep mountain terrain; for those who are not diligent, they become 'natural prisons.'"
Du Mu comments: ¡§Oppressively narrow mountain ravines, which can stop people's forward progress; such places are called 'natural prisons.'"
Here, we have different explanations from three commentators. In Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu's Art of War, Mei Yaochen's explanation is considered the correct one.

In a 'confined place,' the way forward is blocked off on three sides, and although it's possible to enter on one side, once you're inside it's impossible to get back out. About 'tangled thickets,' Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Places where grasses and trees grow dense, such that neither spear nor arrow may be deployed."
This is about places where the vegetation is so thick and movement so difficult that there's no space to wave a sword or a spear, or even to fire an arrow.

It's just like in golf, when you're in a stand of trees and you don't have space to swing your club. About 'quagmires,' Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Muddy, low-lying terrain, impassable for chariots, carts and cavalry."
These places are 'natural traps.'
About 'crevasses,' Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Two mountains facing one another, forming a cave-like passage; narrow and loathsome."
This is the same geographical feature that is found in so many scenic sites in China, beloved by tourists and known in modern Chinese as 'a crack of sky.' But although these places make for fun tourist destinations, they're much less fun for armies on the march in wartime. It's bad luck to have to take an army through such places.

¡§... (such places) should be left with all possible speed and not approached."

If you encounter any of these six types of terrain, it's important to leave as quickly as possible. Better yet, don't even get close in the first place.

¡§While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear."

As we stay far away from these places, we can draw our enemies to them. If we engage our enemy near these types of terrain, the arrangement most favourable for us is for our army to be facing the dangerous terrain, while the enemy fights with their back to it. Cao Cao comments: ¡§In war, we always stay far away from the six dangers, while causing the enemy to draw close to them and to face away from them; thus, I benefit and the enemy is in danger."
Du Mu comments: ¡§This passage tells us that, when encountering these six dangerous types of terrain, I should stay far away while facing the dangerous terrain, allowing me the freedom to advance and to halt as I will; the enemy should be made to draw near to the dangerous terrain and to face away from it, thus creating a barrier to his movements. Thus, this is beneficial to me and dangerous to my enemy."
So, in war, the key is to seize control of the best terrain.

And, if you encounter any of the six dangerous types of terrain, keep your distance while still facing it, wait for the enemy to arrive, and then force him into the dangerous terrain. Thirty-two methods for monitoring the enemy's condition (part one)

Extract from the original text:
¡§If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking. When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position.

When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance. If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage. Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing.

The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious. The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade. Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth. When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing; when the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry.

When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood. A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping."

Analysis:
¡§If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§What is meant by 'steep' is terrain with abrupt transitions between high and low land; what is meant by 'obstructed' is terrain with large amounts of water; thick undergrowth can be used as a natural screen."
Next, we'll go through the various ways you can observe the enemy. The Art of War discusses a total of 32 such observational techniques:

1) ¡§When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position."

This is when the enemy is in close proximity to your army, but shows no signs of moving.

They have control of the best terrain, terrain that is dangerous for you to approach. So, they feel secure, without fear. Here, 'quiet' is used in the sense of 'motionless.' It doesn't necessarily mean that the enemy isn't making any noise. In a historical example from a previous chapter - the one about General Ma Yuan's expedition in Hunan against the rebellious Miao people - Ma Yuan became stranded on a riverbank.

The Miao fighters stood on the high cliffs above the river ravine and subjected Ma Yuan to a deafening racket, because they knew there was no way he could climb up to where they were. He was completely helpless.

2. ¡§When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance."

This is when the enemy stays far away from your army and sends a small force to lure you into a fight. Their aim is to tempt you into moving forward, towards them.

This is the exact opposite of the previous line. Rather than staying put, secure in the knowledge that their position is strong, here the enemy forces move over a great distance to pick a fight with you, as an attempt to provoke you into moving towards their main force. In the Wei Liaozi, there's a passage that reads: ¡§When the enemy has the distribution of dangerous terrain, do not commit your heart to battle. When the enemy challenges you to fight, do not commit your full energy to fighting." If the enemy takes control of dangerous terrain before you do, don't try to make a fight happen.

If the enemy is deployed far away from you, and sends soldiers to pick a fight, don't hit him with your full force. Leave some units in reserve, and watch how the battle unfolds. 3. ¡§If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage."

If the enemy has taken up a position in open country, he definitely has a terrain advantage, and he'll want to lure you towards him and finish you. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When the enemy spurns dangerous terrain and positions himself in easy terrain, it is certain that he has derived some advantage." This means the enemy isn't even slightly scared of you; he's just waiting for you to come to him so he can put you to the sword.

In this situation, you need to play it cautiously. The principle here is roughly the same as the passage, 'refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order; refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array,' which appears in Chapter Seven, Armed Struggle.

4. ¡§Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing."

If you see tree branches moving, that means the enemy is on their way towards you. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§It is vital, in an army, to send a man skilled in observation to climb high points and monitor the enemy. If he sees movement among trees, this means the enemy is cutting down trees to clear a path; he is coming.

It is also possible that they are not just clearing a path, but also preparing to craft weapons."

When a large army is on the move, it needs to cut down trees as it goes to clear its path forward, and it's also possible that they are using the wood of these trees to make weapons and build structures for their camp. To sum up, if you see trees swaying about, this is a sign that the enemy is coming.

5. ¡§The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§If the enemy makes bundles of grass to use as screens, he wishes to sow doubt in my mind."

If the enemy is setting up barriers in dense areas of grass, what he's doing is setting up a diversion. In fact, he might already have fled the area.

Du Mu comments: ¡§This passage tells us: either the enemy has not yet completed construction of defensive fortifications at his camp, or he has removed his army from the areas and has secretly departed, and, fearing that we may pursue him, he has deployed bundles of grass about the place as if there were people concealed behind, in order that we would feel misgivings and not dare to approach."

6. ¡§The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Where you see birds rising upwards, there are troops hiding in ambush below."

Zhang Yu's commentary gives a more vivid image: ¡§When you see birds flying horizontal to the ground, and then, having arrived at an enemy position, suddenly fly upwards, this shows there are enemy soldiers lying in ambush below."

7. ¡§Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth."

Chen Hao comments: ¡§What is meant by 'surging forth' is that the enemy is hidden in the woods, and will drive forth to attack you."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The enemy battle lines are vast and widely spread, and they are surging forth to attack."

'Surging forth' has two meanings. First, it means the enemy is hiding in the woods and is about to launch a surprise attack.

Second, it means that 'the enemy battle lines are vast and widely spread' - they have a lot of troops, and they will attack over a wide area. So, when you see wild animals running from the woods because they have nowhere left to hide among the trees, then you have a serious problem on your hands!

8. ¡§When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing..."

When you see dust rising high in the sky in a narrow column, that means enemy chariots are on their way. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Chariots and horses moving at high speed and in large numbers, when they move in formation and follow precisely in the tracks of those before them, then dust rises high and straight."

9. ¡§When the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry."

War chariots move in tight lines, each line following precisely the one in front, which is why the dust they produce forms narrow columns. Infantry soldiers, however, move in relatively broad lines, so they kick up wider dust clouds.

Also, dust from infantry units doesn't rise as high in the sky as dust produced by chariots. In ancient Chinese warfare, there were people who had the specific duty of observing dust clouds created by enemy armies. At one point during the Three Kingdoms period, Cao Cao was chasing Liu Bei, so Liu Bei's ally Zhang Fei sent a cavalry unit out to trick Cao Cao. Each of the unit's horses had a tree branch tied to its tail, which they dragged back and forth in an effort to send a huge amount of dust up into the sky. The question is, would Cao Cao have been able to tell that the dust was fake?

10. ¡§When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood."

When dust is spread out and forms long, narrow columns, this means the enemy soldiers are cutting firewood. Why does the dust do this?

First of all, the reason it's spread out is that soldiers on firewood-cutting duty fan out in all directions. Then, when they're finished chopping, they drag the wood along the ground back to camp, which is why the dust forms long columns. Li Quan comments: ¡§When the commanders of Jin set out to invade Qi, they ordered men to drag firewood behind their army. From the mountaintops, the men of Qi saw this and were terrified that this signified vast Jin armies.

They fled at night."

11. ¡§A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping."

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Whenever encamping, it is vital to dispatch light cavalry to travel out in the four directions and inspect the nearby terrain. This is in order to know where the terrain is dangerous or easy, and where it is open or narrow.

Hence, there is a small quantity of dust, and it moves here and there."

Thirty-two methods for monitoring the enemy's condition (part two)

Extract from the original text:
¡§Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance. Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat.

When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle. Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot. When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means that the critical moment has come.

When some are seen advancing and some retreating, it is a lure. When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food. If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst. If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are in chaos.

If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted. If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied. Clamor by night betokens nervousness. If there is disturbance in the camp, the general's authority is weak.

If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary."

We will now move on to the next 14 ways outlined in The Art of War for observing the enemy, and interpreting what you see:

 12. ¡§Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The enemy's messengers use humble rhetoric; when I send spies to observe the enemy, I learn the enemy is increasing his preparations."

The enemy is attempting to make us apathetic and arrogant; while we let down our guard, he's preparing to launch his offensive. In Du Mu's comment on this line, he writes about a historical case study we've already seen in previous chapters: Zhao She's war to save the city of Yuyu.

Zhao She set out with his army from the city of Handan, but after marching only thirty li, he set up camp and halted his troops' advance. When the enemy Qin forces sent a messenger to his camp, the man was treated well and given plenty of good food and drink. The Qin commander, it seems, believed that Zhao She didn't have the courage to attack. As soon as the Qin messenger left the Zhao camp, Zhao She moved out, marching double time until his forces reached the Qin army. He took the enemy unawares and unprepared, and utterly trounced them in battle.

Zhang Yu also writes about a historical case study, in which General Tian Dan defended the city of Jimo while being besieged by General Qi Jie of the state of Yan. As Tian Dan enlisted soldiers for his forces, he even enlisted his wives and concubines, and he personally joined the rank-and-file soldiers in readiness to fight for their city.

Once he'd finished his preparations, he sent a woman up onto the city walls to offer surrender to the enemy outside. Qi Jie received the news with delight. Tian Dan took 1,000 yi of gold from the people of the city and ordered Jimo's richest citizens to take the gold and present it to Qi Jie, and to deliver a message for him: ¡§The city is surrendering. I hope that your soldiers will not plunder the city or harm my wives and concubines." Hearing this, the Yan troops relaxed even more.

The next moment, Tian Dan was charging out of the gates with his army. He hit the Yan army hard, routing them in one fell swoop. Tricks and scams - the truth is that there are really only a handful of variations, and they're all well documented in books.

Yet, people still fall for them. All you can do is shake your head and sigh: 'There are too many idiots in this world. Frankly, there aren't enough scammers to go around!'

So, why do people fall for these scams? There's a proverb from the west: ¡§There are some things that people believe for the sole reason that they want so badly for it to be true."

When someone creates an illusion, if that illusion symbolizes a hope or desire you have, you'll believe in it totally.

You'll go all in, and you'll delightedly tell yourself: 'It's happening just the way I thought it would. I'm not surprised!'

In the case of the Qin general, he was thinking: ¡§Zhao She's just a boy; he'd never dare cross swords with the great Qin army! I always knew there was never any chance he'd come, and lo and behold, he's not coming!"

And, in the case of the Yan general, Qi Jie, he was thinking: ¡§How could Tian Dan ever be a match for me?

And I was right - he's no match for me! At least you can say this about him: he knows the score. Look, the local magnates are coming out to give me protection money."

13. ¡§Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat."

This is the opposite of 'humble words' signaling an imminent attack. If the enemy's messengers deliver fiery, aggressive speeches and give the impression that their forces are on the attack, this actually means they're about to run away.

The belligerent messengers are just sheep in wolves' clothing. Du Mu writes about a historical example of this principle: King Fuchai of Wu's northern expedition to tussle for supremacy with Duke Ding of Jin.

The two armies' paths collided at Huangchi, but before the fighting had even started, King Goujian of Yue invaded Wu, taking advantage of the Wu army's absence. Fuchai was spooked. He wanted to withdraw his armies and hurry back home to protect his kingdom, but he felt held back by two concerns. First, considering that his army was lined up opposite the Jin army, he was worried that retreating without a fight would cripple his troops' morale.

Second, he was worried the Jin forces would chase after him. He called a meeting with his advisors, and asked: ¡§Which course of action offers greater advantage - withdrawing without a fight, or fighting in a bid to secure supremacy?"

Advisor Wang Sunluo said: ¡§We must challenge the enemy to fight today, so as to invigorate the men's hearts. Only then can we withdraw."

So, the King of Wu took 30,000 armored troops and advanced to within one li of the Jin army, lined up in battle formation, and started up a deafening noise. Duke Ding of Jin sent his advisor Dong He to ask King Fuchai, ¡§What is the meaning of this?" Fuchai granted the messenger a personal audience, and answered his question with hard words: ¡§The time has come. If you want to orphan your children or if you want to save yourself trouble, either way, today is the day!"

Dong He went back to Duke Ding, and told him: ¡§When I was observing the King of Wu's complexion, it appeared that something of great magnitude is gnawing at his mind. If we engage in battle today, he will hold nothing back in the fight.

We cannot fight him." So, Duke Ding of Jin backed off, and agreed to make peace. Now Fuchai was on the front foot. He'd secured a peace agreement and he'd kept his dignity. He immediately moved his forces back to the home front.

14. ¡§When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Forming up battle lines means that the enemy desires battle."

The first to come out are the light chariots. This means the enemy is about to form up battle lines and engage.

The chariots are sent out to either flank to act as boundary markers for the army. Once they're in place, battle flags are planted in specific locations, and each unit assembles behind their flag. This is what happens when the enemy is setting up their battle lines and getting ready to fight.

15. ¡§Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot."

If the enemy says he wants peace but doesn't make any solid proposals, don't be fooled - he has a trick up his sleeve. We just talked about how Tian Dan 'sued for peace' with Qi Jie.

First, he sent a woman up on the city walls to make himself look weak and to ask for peace. Then, the richest residents of the city went out to offer protection money, and they did so as private citizens. At no point did Tian Dan himself offer specific surrender terms.

This proves beyond doubt that he was up to something. If he really wanted to surrender, wouldn't he have put some effort into negotiating a price for peace? The same thing happened when Ji Xin fooled Xiang Yu.

It happened like this: Liu Bang had been surrounded by Xiang Yu's forces at Xingyang, and his anxiety was at the boiling point. But his advisor Ji Xin had a clever plan. Since he looked very similar to Liu Bei, he could disguise himself as his lord and come out of the eastern gate to surrender, while the real Liu Bei could escape through the western gate. Liu Bei agreed to give the plan a try. He sent a document of surrender to Xiang Yu, in which he wrote: ¡§The King of Han shall this evening come to offer his surrender." Xiang Yu was delighted. At midnight, a large number of women poured out from the eastern gate, with multiple groups coming out in bursts.

The Chu army came forward to encircle the women, to watch and wait for Liu Bang to come out. By the time the last of the women had emerged, the sky was already growing light. Finally, a figure who appeared to be Ji Xin made his way slowly out of the gates, lying down in an imperial chariot. When the Chu troops saw that Liu Bang had come to surrender, they began to shout: ¡§Long Live King Xiang," the assembled troops cried. By the time Xiang Yu realized that this 'Liu Bang' was a fake, the real Liu Bang had already fled through the western gate.

He was long gone. Xiang Yu never stopped to wonder why Liu Bang would send a letter announcing he was going to surrender on the same day, without mentioning a single term or condition? It made no sense!

But Xiang Yu was a very arrogant man - the way he saw it, it was right and proper that Liu Bang should surrender to him unconditionally. There was another famous example of this from the reign of Emperor Dezong of the Tang dynasty: the treaty ambush at Pingliang.

A leader of the Tibetan Empire, Shang Gyaltsen, was invading Hequ when his army fell prey to a disease outbreak. Half of his men and horses died, and he became worried that he wouldn't be able to make it back home.

So, he sent a messenger to the camp of the Tang commander, Ma Sui, humbly and politely requesting a meeting to discuss not only signing a peace treaty, but forming an alliance. Ma Sui granted the request. The governor of Hezhong Prefecture sent his advisor, Hun Jian, to the imperial court with a message: ¡§If our nation's armies were pressing on the Tibetan border and we were planning to invade, then perhaps it might be believable that the Tibetans would request an alliance. But, in the current situation, the Tibetans need nothing from our nation, and yet they have made this bizarre request for an alliance. Without doubt, they are plotting something."
But Emperor Dezong didn't listen.

Hun Jian and Shang Gyaltsen arranged a meeting at Pingliang, and when Hun Jian arrived, he had 3,000 men at his back. Shang Gyaltsen had positioned cavalry troops in ambush formation at a location to the west of the Alliance Hall. When the time came, tens of thousands of Tibetan cavalry troops poured forth and captured the outlying Tang troops.

Hun Jian acted quickly; he leapt onto a nearby horse and fled across the Pingliang River. So, except for Hun Jian, who had been in charge of the alliance negotiations, all 60 or more Tang court officials sent to the meeting were captured by the Tibetans, including Vice Commissioner Cui Hanheng and a high-ranking court official, the eunuch Ju Wenzhen. In what went down in history as 'The treaty ambush at Pingliang,' 500 or more Tang soldiers were killed, and another 1,000 or more were captured. In Chen Hao's commentary, he writes that when commanders from two states go on the attack, if neither side is showing any weakness, and yet one of them requests a peace treaty for no apparent reason, that means one of two things: (1) The enemy leaders are worried about some internal problem at home and, out of carelessness, have decided on a policy of peace for the time being; (2) They knew that it might be possible to try something, and they're trying to make you believe in yourself beyond doubt, and asking for peace now, while planning to launch a surprise attack later. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§If the enemy requests peace for no reason, there is certainly some cunning plot in play." Once Liu Bang had already become Emperor Gaozu of the Han dynasty, he sent Li Yiji with a large cargo of treasures to visit with the Qin general Jia Shu and ask him to agree to peace terms. But they weren't even at war yet, so why would Gaozu send gifts and ask for peace?

And yet, Jia Shu believed the Han Emperor. Liu Bang then took advantage of his enemy's lack of preparedness and alertness, and destroyed the Qin army with a single strike. 16. ¡§When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means the enemy is in a state of anticipation."

In Du Mu's commentary, he writes that this line goes together with the previous one: ¡§When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle." Once the light chariots have staked out the flanks, then ¡§there is much running about and the soldiers fall into rank."

In an ancient text called The Rites of Zhou, it's written that: ¡§As chariots fly forth, foot soldiers follow, halting when they reach their mark." The 'marks' are flags set out by the chariot personnel, signs showing the infantry units where to take up positions as they run hectically after the fast chariots. As for the meaning of 'anticipation,' it's possible to interpret it as being directed at the enemy's own foot soldiers.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Marks are given where flags are planted, and as the general anticipates the people going forth, thus they run toward their marks."

17. ¡§When he is halfway in advance and halfway in retreat, it is a lure."

This means that there's a lack of coordination; some soldiers move forward while others fall back, advancing and retreating at different times.

The army seems like a chaotic mess, but this is engineered precisely to lure you into advancing. From the enemy's standpoint, he worries that if he advances, you'll run away, and if he retreats, you won't chase him.

So, he does both - advancing and retreating at the same time. 18. ¡§When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food."

Send spies to watch the enemy. If you can see enemy troops far in the distance hanging onto their spears to keep themselves upright, this proves that they're exhausted and famished.

They've run out of food."

19. ¡§If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst."

If you see the men on water-fetching duty glugging it down as quickly as they can, this proves that there's no water left in the enemy camp, and that the whole army is suffering badly from thirst. 20.

¡§If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted."

If the enemy can see you have a weakness they could exploit, and yet they don't do anything about it, this shows that their troops' energy and battle capabilities are badly depleted. 21.

¡§If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied."

In Zhang Yu's commentary, he writes that in a situation where the enemy army has stealthily retreated and left their tents behind to make it seem like they're still there, there's one sign you should look out for. If birds realize that nobody's at home in the camp, they'll congregate in the sky above.

It turned out that the Chu army had reached breaking point, too, and had already turned tail and run. There were birds perched on the city walls, so it was a sure bet that there was nobody guarding the city; they'd all run away. The Northern Qi general, Ban Shi, built fake tents using cypress branches, and then he created smoke by starting fires with ox and horse manure. The Qi army watched for two days before they realized the camp was empty.

By then, it was too late to catch up with the Northern Qi forces. 22. ¡§Clamor by night betokens nervousness."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§If the soldiers cry out at night, this means the general lacks courage." 

The general isn't brave, so he can't stay on top of his troops. The army has no backbone to keep it stable, making the men so jittery that every bush and tree looks like an enemy soldier. Panic in a camp doesn't stop at shouting and yelling.

It's hard to see at night, so in the madness it's possible that the men of the same army will start attacking and even killing one another, thinking that they're fighting the enemy. ¡§Now! Now, give chase!"

25. ¡§If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary."

Jia Lin comments: ¡§When people are tired, they become angrier." If officers become angry for no apparent reason, this proves that they're already exhausted. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When the generals' commands contradict one another, people become exhausted and thus the officers grow increasingly angry." Either the commander doesn't have a grip on the situation, and is giving commands that don't make sense, or he's inconsistent in handing out rewards and punishments. This makes people angry.

Then, the officers start taking out their anger on the regular troops, and they fly into a rage for no evident reason. When this happens in an army, the men lose their fighting spirit and even start hoping that their side will lose, as revenge against their commander. The classic historical example of this principle comes from the battle of the city of Bi, during the war between Jin and Chu, when the two states were vying for supremacy in China.

At the beginning of the conflict, neither side wanted to fight; they were on the verge of starting negotiations for a peace treaty. The Jin commander-in-chief, Xun Linfu, had set his heart on building an alliance with Chu, and he wasn't putting much energy into preparing for war. Two generals under his command, Wei Qi and Zhao Zhan, had once asked Xun Linfu for promotion to higher ranks, but had been refused. They'd borne a grudge ever since, and now they wanted to sabotage Xun Linfu's career.

So, they both in turn approached Xun Linfu and asked him to let them go to the Chu camp and provoke the enemy into fighting. Xun Linfu refused their request. So, they asked instead for permission to go to the Chu camp and propose an alliance. This time, Xun Linfu gave his permission. The two scoundrels made their way to the enemy camp, and instead of trying to build an alliance, they challenged the Chu leaders to fight. Nothing good would come of two disgruntled young men going to the enemy. Without proper preparations, the Jin army was bound to lose.

But, Xun Linfu didn't take the situation seriously. In the Chu army, there were two opposing factions: one wanted peace, the other wanted war. But when the King of Chu learned about the divisions among the Jin officers, he made up his mind - there was going to be war. The Chu commanders launched a major offensive, and what happened next will come as no surprise: the Jin forces were badly beaten.

What makes an army strong isn't filling it with as many troops as possible, but the ability to refrain from charging forward blindly, to bring its power to bear in specific places, and to accurately assess the enemy's situation.

This is all that's needed to make a strong army. And the key to being able to 'concentrate all our available strength, and anticipate the enemy's movements' is to pick the right people to work for you. ¡§Greater numbers of soldiers do not equate to advantage."

What do they mean by 'an even balance between the power of your army and the extent of your authority?' It's about being able to dominate your army. If your army reaches a size beyond your ability to control and dominate it, adding more troops isn't going to do you any good.

Han Xin once claimed that, as far his own leadership ability was concerned, there was no such thing as too many troops. Whether 100,000 or a million, he could dominate any army. ¡§Proper personnel selections are sufficient to concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy's movements."

Being able to 'concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy's movements' is all about choosing the right people to work for you. And where should you look for these talented individuals?

Cao Cao has the answer: 'personally cultivate' them. Don't bother with outside hiring - the people you need are already in your army. They're the next generation; you trained them yourself. So, how are you supposed to 'cultivate' your soldiers?

In the next part, we'll dive into how it's done. This is a major strategic and organizational concept. It's about relying on the internal strength of your organization, and picking talented people from inside, instead of relying on outside help. With armies, the important thing isn't to have as many troops as possible.

On top of that, your leadership ability needs to match the number of men under your command. You need to be able to unify your army - to hold the reins and stay in charge. That's why you shouldn't rely on people from outside.

This is a relevant passage from the Wei Liaozi: ¡§Any time that reinforcements are called upon in war, if it is claimed that 100,000 men will come, then in reality only a fraction of that number will materialize. Moreover, among those that come, every one of them remonstrates with their general: 'Let us not fight first on their behalf.'"
This is exactly what happened when the six remaining states at the end of the Warring States period were finally wiped from the map by the state of Qin. The Qin armies fought for their own kingdom, so when they won, the victory belonged to Qin.

The same was true when they lost. But, the other six states joined their armies together, meaning that nobody wanted to be the first to fight. That's because if they lost, they'd have to own it, and even if they won they might still come out the other end as a loser.

It's the same with development strategy for businesses. To develop, you need to rely on your own strength. If you want to get into a coalition with other businesses, so you can 'complement each other's competitive advantages,' it's because you're hoping the other companies will help you out with developing your business. You'd be better off letting go of such hopes!

The same principle applies on the level of individual people. People often say that 'Each friend you make opens up a new opportunity.' But, while it's true that friends can help you, you can't expect your friends to make things happen for you.

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Personally cultivating them will suffice." Use soldiers who you've raised yourself. This one word, 'cultivating,' is pregnant with meaning.

In the original text, the word translated here as 'cultivating' contains two characters. The first one, si, has a basic meaning of 'sticking close together.'
The words used to express the idea of 'cultivating personnel' in the original text could be interpreted as insulting, as if describing a dog someone was taming. But if the people being cultivated are like dogs, at least you know they'll be unfailingly loyal to their master.

If you turn things around and look at this potentially insulting language ('taming') from the master's perspective, then if you train your soldiers to be like your dogs ('unfailingly loyal'), isn't that a good thing, in terms of military command and control in times of war? So, it would seem that 'taming' people like this works out pretty well.

But, do we understand how to tame people? Have we ourselves at some point been tamed by someone? Turning the question around again, would we want to be tamed by someone else? Would we know how to be tamed? There's an expression in Chinese: 'A person who you look after, but who never really becomes part of the family.' No matter how well you treat this person, they don't understand you and never take after your way of thinking. So, you end up leaving this person.

If we turn this back on ourselves, could it be possible that there are people who would use this expression to describe us? I'm afraid that the answer is yes. There have been those who think this way about us, who've treated us so well that we took it for granted and thought it was normal. We lower the standards we hold ourselves to and end up hurting the very person who was looking after us.

This line of thought is profound. Under its surface, there lies a vast body of learning. 'Keeping and training' is the subject matter of a certain, highly influential work of world literature, one that's been called 'a fairytale for adults' - The Little Prince. The Little Prince, a short story by the poet and journalist Antoine de Saint-Exup?ry, is a famous work of French children's literature published in in 1943.

The main character is a little prince who comes from another planet, and the story's narrator is a pilot. He tells of how the prince set out on a journey from his planet towards earth, and about all the adventures he experienced on the way.

In one part of the story, the little prince meets a fox who demands that the prince take him in and look after him. The fox explains the essential qualities of the relationship between the person in charge and the creature who's being looked after: love and responsibility. The way a leader should keep, look after and train the people in their charge is all about love and responsibility.

Let's read a bit of the story. It's a long passage, but it's one that's absolutely worth reading, re-reading, and thinking about in detail

"Come and play with me," proposed the little prince. "I am so unhappy." "I cannot play with you," the fox said.

"I am not tamed." "Ah! Please excuse me," said the little prince. But, after some thought, he added: "What does that mean - 'tame?'" "You do not live here," said the fox. "They have guns, and they hunt. It is very disturbing. They also raise chickens. These are their only interests. Are you looking for chickens?" "No," said the little prince. "I am looking for friends.

And I have no need of you. And you, on your part, have no need of me. To you, I am nothing more than a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But if you tame me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique in all the world.

The fox seemed perplexed, and very curious. "On another planet?" "Yes." "Are there hunters on this planet?" "No." "Ah, that is interesting! Are there chickens?" "No." "Nothing is perfect," sighed the fox.

But he came back to his idea. "My life is very monotonous," the fox said. "I hunt chickens; men hunt me. All the chickens are just alike, and all the men are just alike. And, in consequence, I am a little bored.

But if you tame me, it will be as if the sun came to shine on my life. I shall know the sound of a step that will be different from all the others. Other steps send me hurrying back underneath the ground.

Yours will call me, like music, out of my burrow. And then look: you see the grain?fields down yonder? I do not eat bread. Wheat is of no use to me. The wheat fields have nothing to say to me. And that is sad.

But you have hair that is the color of gold. Think how wonderful that will be when you have tamed me! The grain, which is also golden, will bring me back the thought of you. And I shall love to listen to the wind in the wheat..." The fox gazed at the little prince, for a long time. "Please - tame me!" he said.

"I want to, very much," the little prince replied. "But I have not much time. I have friends to discover, and a great many things to understand." "One only understands the things that one tames," said the fox. "Men have no more time to understand anything.

They buy things all ready made at the shops. But there is no shop anywhere where one can buy friendship, and so men have no friends anymore. If you want a friend, tame me..." "What must I do, to tame you?" asked the little prince.

"You must be very patient," replied the fox. "First you will sit down at a little distance from me - like that - in the grass. I shall look at you out of the corner of my eye, and you will say nothing.

Words are the source of misunderstandings. But you will sit a little closer to me, every day..." The next day the little prince came back. "It would have been better to come back at the same hour," said the fox.

"If, for example, you come at four o'clock in the afternoon, then at three o'clock I shall begin to be happy. I shall feel happier and happier as the hour advances. At four o'clock, I shall already be worrying and jumping about.

I shall show you how happy I am! But if you come at just any time, I shall never know at what hour my heart is to be ready to greet you... One must observe the proper rites..." "What is a rite?" asked the little prince. "Those also are actions too often neglected," said the fox.

"They are what make one day different from other days, one hour from other hours. There is a rite, for example, among my hunters. Every Thursday they dance with the village girls. So Thursday is a wonderful day for me!

I can take a walk as far as the vineyards. But if the hunters danced at just any time, every day would be like every other day, and I should never have any vacation at all." So the little prince tamed the fox. And when the hour of his departure drew near - "Ah," said the fox, "I shall cry." "It is your own fault," said the little prince.

"I never wished you any sort of harm; but you wanted me to tame you..." "Yes, that is so," said the fox. "But now you are going to cry!" said the little prince. "Yes, that is so," said the fox. "Then it has done you no good at all!" "It has done me good," said the fox, "because of the color of the wheat fields." And then he added: "Go and look again at the roses. You will understand now that yours is unique in all the world.

Then come back to say goodbye to me, and I will make you a present of a secret." The little prince went away, to look again at the roses. "You are not at all like my rose," he said. "As yet you are nothing.

No one has tamed you, and you have tamed no one. You are like my fox when I first knew him. He was only a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But I have made him my friend, and now he is unique in all the world." And the roses were very much embarrassed.

"You are beautiful, but you are empty," he went on. "One could not die for you. To be sure, an ordinary passerby would think that my rose looked just like you - the rose that belongs to me. But in herself alone she is more important than all the hundreds of you other roses: because it is she that I have watered; because it is she that I have put under the glass globe; because it is she that I have sheltered behind the screen; because it is for her that I have killed the caterpillars (except the two or three that we saved to become butterflies); because it is she that I have listened to, when she grumbled, or boasted, or even sometimes when she said nothing.

Because she is my rose. The reason why The Little Prince has been described as a fairytale for adults is because it lays bare the deepest essence of how humans relate to one another. That essence is, in a phrase, 'taming' one another.

Bosses and their underlings tame one another; husbands and wives tame one another; businesses and consumers tame one another; governments and ordinary people tame one another. To tame someone is to establish a bond with them.

Once there's a bond between us, I know how you'll treat me, and how you'll behave at different times and in different circumstances. Also, I know how I should treat you. Taming someone is about love and responsibility, expectations and dependence. The relationships built by the act of taming are deep, and yet they also become increasingly fragile as they gain more depth - they cannot survive even the slightest betrayal.

In taming, there are no surprises; everything runs its course, steadily and dependably. For example, look at how circus troupes tame their animals. When they train a dolphin to bounce a ball on its head, it is absolutely certain that each time it bounces the ball, it will be fed a fish. There's no way the one-fish-for-one-bounce mechanism can fail.

If it does, even once, it will not be possible for the show to go on. Now, let's get back to The Art of War. ¡§Bear in your mind the interests of those under your command and be able to make them aware of it."
This is one of the regulations at The United States Military Academy. In relationships based on taming, it's important to be mindful of the other person; you can't just think about your own goals.

It's also essential that the other person knows you're being mindful of them, and that they trust you to think on their behalf. If you feel that the other person in this relationship is keeping distant from you, then, unfortunately, that's probably because you haven't factored them into your thinking enough.

Or, perhaps, you haven't been able to make them aware that you're thinking about them. Teams must understand the need for members to tame each other, and each of them must also enter into the spirit and ritual of taming one another.

You could spend a lifetime practicing this skill, and still have more to learn. That said, let's read another piece from Sun Tzu:

¡§If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless."

If you try to use punishment as a method for managing your soldiers before they've become personally attached to you, they won't accept that you're right. If they don't accept that you're right, it will be very difficult to put them to use. Du Mu comments: ¡§Without trust and kindness having first been established, it will not do to use punishment to bring your soldiers into line."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Use morality to make yourself supreme over them; use kindness to bring them close to you. Without applying morality and kindness, they will not accept your punishments but rather will grow resentful.

It will be difficult to use them."
First, you have to make your people respect and love you. Only then can they respect and fear you at the same time. If you want everyone to be scared of you from the very start, you won't make it as a leader. ¡§If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless."

This situation is the opposite - if everyone's already attached to you, but you're unable to enforce strict discipline, your army won't be any use in a battle. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Kindness and trust having been established, if you do not employ punishments, then the soldiers become arrogant, slothful, and useless."
If you have kindness but no authority, love but no punishments, your troops and officers will grow lazy and arrogant.

They'll be of no use to you. All of this is the territory of what could be called 'The Way of Taming.'

¡§Therefore, soldiers must be treated in the first instance with civil values, but kept under control by military values. This is a certain road to victory."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§'Civil values' means 'benevolence.' 'Military values' means 'law.'"
'Civil values' are about soothing and pacifying people - they're the carrot to the stick of 'military values,' which consist of martial discipline and law. You need both the carrot and the stick if you want to create an army that's guaranteed to win.

¡§A man capable of using civil values to build intimacy with the people, and military values to extend authority over his enemies." This is a recommendation for Sima Rangju, written by the ancient statesman Yan Ying. Wu Qi wrote: ¡§He who combines civil and military values may take command of an army; he who can be both hard and soft has the ability to fight wars."

¡§If, in training soldiers, commands are habitually enforced, the army will be well-disciplined; if not, its discipline will be poor. If a general shows confidence in his men but always insists on his orders being obeyed, the gain will be mutual."

Note the use of the word 'habitually'- it's important.

You don't wait until you're on the battlefield to start enforcing commands. Just imagine: 'Alright! The battle's about to start, so it's time to start enforcing some commands! We normally like to keep it nice and casual, but this time is different!' It's precisely during the 'normal' times that you need to strictly enforce your commands. This way, your troops will get in the habit of obeying them. If your normal way of doing things is very relaxed, and you don't instill good habits in your men, they won't obey you on the battlefield when you finally do start to insist on strict compliance with your commands. They simply won't be in the habit of doing so.

The only way to build well-oiled coordination between the ranks of an army is to train your troops to jump when you tell them to. Du Mu comments: ¡§When staying in a fixed position, on days when there is no other business to attend to, one must, as a priority, instill in one's men trust and fear towards you, an awareness of your kindness, and compliance with commands.

Then, when the time comes to face the enemy and you issue commands and call upon the laws, every one of your men will obey... Commands must be clearly stated in advance, so that people are not confused when they hear them; laws must be enforced, so that people abide by them and do not look upon them lightly. The 'three commands and five orders' must be demonstrated to people so as to avert confusion. Laws and commands should be simple and adequate, and any law that is introduced must be enforced. Then, it will be possible for the general and his men to understand one another."
There are two crucial elements when it comes to commands and rules: make clear what they are as early as possible, so that everyone knows exactly what they mean; and any law that you establish absolutely must be enforced, with no exceptions. 'The three commands and five orders' refers to the ancient Chinese system of military laws and rules. The first 'command' is: 'Keep watch over the enemy's plots, observe the state of the roads and other transport routes as regards ease of use, and be informed about where the places of life and the places of death are located.'
The second 'command' is: 'Keep your ears alert to the sound of gongs and drums and your eyes alert to flags and banners, so that your eyes and ears work in unison.'
The third 'command' is: 'Raise the axe high, to make known what are the punishments and what are the rewards.'
Now, for the 'five orders.'
The first 'order' is: 'Use rewards and punishments to make their hearts and minds as one.'
The second 'order' is: 'Observe the way they divide and come together, so as to make their movements as one.'
The third 'order' is: 'Draw battle lines using flags and banners.'
The fourth 'order' is: 'When fighting at night, listen for fire and drums.'
Finally, the fifth 'order' is: 'To any who does not reverently obey orders, look upon him with the axe.'
To make everyone in your organization feel secure and rooted, you need to make the 'three commands and five orders' totally clear. Make your rules and orders simple and appropriate, enforce all of your rules, and don't make any exceptions.

If you do this, your people's minds will be clear and unclouded. However, if the 'three commands and five orders' become nothing more than empty words - if you enforce the rules selectively, even though all of your men are guilty of violations - they'll get in the habit of trusting to their luck. At the same time, this situation makes men feel anxious and insecure. There's a passage from the Wei Liaozi that reads: ¡§If, in the rules which you employ to give orders, there are found some small errors, do not change the rules; if you find some minor issues involving lack of clarity, do not reformulate them. The reason for acting this way is that the senior officers will not doubt the commands they give, and the soldiers will not conjure up two interpretations of each command.

If you can act without hesitation or doubt, then the soldiers will not have second thoughts about their will to act. Thus, you will not face a situation where you cannot command confidence and trust in their minds, but will be able to harness their strength; having averted the possibility of not being able to harness their strength, you will be able to make them fight unto death."
This is about how to make rules. If you realize, after the fact, that there are some minor issues with your rules, as long as they're not serious, don't change them.

Just keep on enforcing them the way they are. If there are some minor parts of your rules that aren't easy to understand, don't try to re-write them. Rules are rules - once you've made them, just keep enforcing them.

It's important that rules be strict, authoritative and stable, more so than how practical they are. For example, when Zhuge Liang was enmeshed in fighting the Wei army, he started off outnumbered. Despite this, when the prescribed time came for a portion of his soldiers' military service to end, he was bound by his own rules to send them home.

¡§Trust cannot be lost," he said. He didn't keep them until the fighting was over and then send them home; he let them go on exactly the predetermined date. This in fact inspired them to stay with Zhuge Liang, and fight at least one more battle.

This trust between the general and his soldiers was like rocket fuel for his army's morale. Zhuge Liang ended that campaign by inflicting a massive defeat on the Wei army. This is how Zhuge Liang and his men 'tamed' one another.

Sun Tzu said: ¡§We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy. Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys. Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight.

So much for mountain warfare. After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross.

Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare. In crossing salt marshes and swamps, your sole concern should be to get over them quickly, without any delay. If forced to fight in a salt marsh or a swamp, you should have water and grass near you, and get your back to a clump of trees.

So much for operations in salt marshes. In dry, level country, take up an easily accessible position with rising ground to your right and on your rear, so that the danger may be in front, and safety lie behind.

So much for campaigning in flat country. These are the four useful branches of military knowledge that enabled the Yellow Emperor to vanquish four sovereigns. All armies prefer high ground to low and sunny places to dark.

If you are careful of your men, and camp on hard ground, the army will be free from disease of every kind, and this will spell victory. When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the sunny side, with the slope on your right rear.

Thus you will at once act for the benefit of your soldiers and utilize the natural advantages of the ground. When, in consequence of heavy rains up-country, a river that you wish to ford is swollen and flecked with foam, you must wait until it subsides. Country in which there are precipitous cliffs with torrents running between, deep natural hollows, confined places, tangled thickets, quagmires and crevasses, should be left with all possible speed and not approached. While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear. If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking. When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position.

When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance. If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage. Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing.

The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious. The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade. Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth. When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing; when the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry. When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood.

A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping. Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance. Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat. When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle.

Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot. When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means that the critical moment has come. When some are seen advancing and some retreating, it is a lure.

When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food. If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst. ¡§If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are in chaos.

If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted. If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied. Clamor by night betokens nervousness. If there is disturbance in the camp, the general's authority is weak.

If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary. When an army feeds its horses with grain and kills its cattle for food, and when the men do not hang their cooking pots over the camp fires, showing that they will not return to their tents, you may know that they are determined to fight to the death. The sight of men whispering earnestly without ceasing or speaking in subdued tones points to disaffection amongst the rank and file.

Too frequent rewards signify that the enemy is at the end of his resources; too many punishments betray a condition of dire distress. To begin by bluster, but afterwards to take fright at the enemy's numbers, shows a supreme lack of intelligence.

When envoys are sent with compliments in their mouths, it is a sign that the enemy desires repose. If the enemy's troops march up angrily and remain facing ours for a long time without either joining battle or taking themselves off again, the situation is one that demands great vigilance and circumspection.

Greater numbers of soldiers do not equate to advantage; do not advance relying solely upon military might. Proper personnel selections are sufficient to concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy's movements. He who exercises no forethought but makes light of his opponents is sure to be captured by them.

If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless. If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless. Therefore, soldiers must be treated in the first instance with civil values, but kept under control by military values. This is a certain road to victory.

If, in training soldiers, commands are habitually enforced, the army will be well disciplined; if not, its discipline will be poor. If a general shows confidence in his men but always insists on his orders being obeyed, the gain will be mutual."

Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part one): First, occupy the most favourable terrain

Extract from the original text:
¡§We may distinguish six kinds of terrain: (1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy. Ground which can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible.

With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies. Then you will be able to fight with advantage. Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling.

From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue."

Analysis:
Here is Cao Cao's commentary to begin the chapter on Terrain: ¡§If you wish to fight, assess the terrain. Use it as the foundation upon which to construct your victory."
Terrain is crucial to fighting battles.

That's why you must assess and familiarize yourself with the terrain before the fighting begins. This is the only way to 'construct victory.'
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Whenever an army goes on the march, first send out an advance party to search for enemy ambushes; order them to sweep all the land, mountains and rivers within a distance of fifty li. Then, the general shall personally inspect the terrain, and by his inspections, shall map the land so that he may know where it presents danger and where it may be easily traversed.

In this way, when an army marches into foreign territory, victory is constructed upon an assessment of the terrain. When this has been done, then soldiers may be dispatched."
Having this information allows you to choose a good location to engage in the fight. Every time Li Shimin went to war, he unfailingly inspected the terrain in person.

He even scouted out enemy camps, putting himself in danger many times in the process. He never palmed off this work to other people - it had to be him. The reason behind this principle is that, whatever question you might have, the answer will be found at the spot where the battle will take place.

These places are almost 'alive.' They talk to you. Once you arrive, you'll know where and how to send your troops into action; you'll be able to sketch out a mental outline for every step you take, so by the time the battle begins you'll already have a few cards up your sleeve. During the Three Kingdoms period, there was a high-ranking Wei general named Deng Ai, who was sent with an army to attack and attempt to destroy the kingdom of Shu Han. Deng Ai came from a poor family and had once worked as a junior official in charge of a few rice fields under Cao Cao's Tuntian system of state-organized farming.

He was a very intelligent, educated man, and he deeply enjoyed military life. Whenever he was on the move, every time his journey took him to a high mountain or a big river, he would scout the surrounding area and hold elaborate discussions about where would be a good spot to camp, where to set up an ambush, and what route the enemy would take if they were to attack.

The people around him made fun of him for this diligent intelligence gathering, analysis and planning, but he didn't care in the slightest. Just like landscape painters who liked to search out strangely shaped mountains and sketch every one they could find, Deng Ai was constantly formulating projections based on everything he saw, constantly practicing and mentally rehearsing battles in whatever type of terrain he came across. Twenty years passed without anything of much significance happening, until finally he was promoted and given a position as a 'Commandant of Agriculture.' He'd been put in charge of managing a few farms, which gave him the opportunity to travel to the capital city, Luoyang, where he was to deliver a report.

He was able to meet with General Sima Yi, and the conversation that ensued changed his life. He was brought into the palace, and he finally had his chance to do something great for his country. At this point, let's talk about 'the six types of terrain.'

¡§(1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy."

1) Accessible ground:

¡§Ground which can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Places where transport routes intersect and expedite travel."

Du You comments: ¡§All such places are in level expanses, expeditious for coming and going." These places are accessible to your forces and the enemy's alike; neither side can obstruct the other. ¡§With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies.

Then you will be able to fight with advantage."

What's the right way to fight on terrain where neither side is able to block their opponent's access? The first thing to do is to occupy the high ground, from where you'll have a clear view of the surrounding area.

Make sure your position faces the sun and that your grain re-supply carts can get in and out easily. This is how to create a more beneficial situation. Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is better to maneuver the enemy to come to you than to be maneuvered by the enemy."

Du Mu writes that 'accessible land' consists of places where a battle could happen anywhere - the enemy could come from any direction. He also emphasizes that you should occupy the high ground, facing into the sun, and not allow the enemy to get there first.

That's because it's not easy when you're in a flat landscape to find a piece of elevated ground big enough for a large army to camp. How are you supposed to 'benefit your line of supplies?' Build defensive structures or walls either side of the road in key 'crossroad' locations. This is how to protect your supply lines, and building walled-in roads between key grain depots is exactly what Liu Bang did during his war against Xiang Yu. He relied on these structures to secure his food supply.

Zhang Yu writes that you should position yourself at the battlefield and wait for the enemy to come to you - this is how to maneuver the enemy while avoiding being maneuvered. But what if you do this, and even though you hold the best terrain, the enemy never comes?

Meanwhile, you're burning through food supplies every day. That's why it's essential to secure your food supply and make sure your supply lines don't get cut. Reading Sun Tzu's The Art of War, we realize that much of the time, the best strategy is to wait for the enemy to come to you. It's essential to know how to wait, and to be able to put that ability into practice.

Some people can't wait; to them, waiting is the same as doing nothing. That's why such people are likely to act without thinking and are bound to make mistakes. Before we move on, I'll add a few words about how Liu Bang's war against Xiang Yu wrapped up. Liu Bang held the granaries, so he and his men had plenty to eat every day. Meanwhile, Xiang Yu's supply lines were cut by the Han armies, and his troops suffered unspeakable hunger.

Ultimately, this led Xiang Yu to accept peace terms, which fixed the borders between the kingdoms of Chu and Han. But, the moment that Xiang Yu had signed the peace treaty and pulled his troops back, Liu Bang immediately tore up the treaty and attacked while the enemy's spirit was 'sluggish and inclined to return.' Soon after, he fought the final battle of the war at Gaixia, where Xiang Yu slit his own throat on the bank of the River Wu. Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part two): True heroes understand the waiting game

Extract from the original text:
¡§Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling.

From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue.

When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground. In a position of this sort, even though the enemy should offer us an attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn; then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage."

Analysis:
2) Entangling ground:
¡§Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling."
When you're able to travel to a place, but unable to get out again, you've become entangled. Du Mu comments: ¡§That which is called 'entangling' is when one is drawn in and hung up."

¡§From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him.

But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue."

When you come across 'entangling ground,' you need to observe whether the enemy is prepared to hold off an attack.

If they're unprepared, you can send out your troops and beat him using a surprise attack. But, if they're prepared, you won't be able to get the upper hand in an attack, and you'll find yourself unable to move forward or backward without serious difficulty. Du Mu comments: ¡§Entangling ground is a place of danger and obstruction, both for oneself and for one's enemy. Presented with a jagged, uneven line between the two sides, any move might cause one to become entangled and obstructed.

Moving to attack the enemy, if the enemy be unprepared, then one's attack is certain to bring victory. Thus, although one is situated amidst danger and obstructions, the enemy is already defeated and will be unable to intercept my route of retreat. If, having moved to attack the enemy, the enemy is prepared, then victory will be impossible. Then, with the enemy holding a defensive position in a dangerous and obstructed location, they will block one's road of retreat, rendering it difficult to return."
If the enemy is unprepared and you launch a surprise attack, the enemy is already beaten. At that point, you don't care about the terrain.

But, if the enemy is prepared, you won't be able to dislodge them, and they'll cut off your escape route. Unfortunately for you, you're likely to get hung up to dry. What are you supposed to do if you find yourself in this unpleasant situation? ¡§If, despite one's efforts, one is trapped there, one must adopt a stratagem of holding one's own for a long duration; plunder grain from the enemy so that you may wait for an advantageous situation, upon which you must seize and strike the enemy." This advice comes from Chen Hao's commentary. Dear old Mister Chen is just trying to make you feel better.

In reality, he's putting you in even more danger! If you're all tangled up in treacherous terrain, with an enemy in front of you that you can't beat, and your way back cut off, what makes you think you'll be able to steal the enemy's food and hold out over the long haul? In this situation, you only have three choices: (1) Wait for reinforcements to come and save the day, in which case everything's coming up roses; (2) Stand and fight - go all out and hope you can beat the practically insurmountable odds. However, the result is likely to be the death of your entire army.

Otherwise, you're not really in 'entangling ground; (3) Admit defeat and surrender. The Art of War doesn't teach anything about surrendering, which is a serious problem. If you don't admit defeat when it's the right thing to do, all that's left for you is to give up your life.
