Why do I say that Chen Hao is putting people in danger? Here, Sun Tzu hasn't taught us what to do in this dire situation, because he doesn't have a solution. And yet, here we have a 'solution,' because Chen Hao has made one up.

You mustn't go into 'entangling ground' - if you do, there's no coming back 99% of the time. The moment your escape route is cut off, you're totally trapped. But, Chen Hao tells us that 'where there's a will, there' a way.' He tells us he has a solution, and when we hear this our ears perk up. Hope stirs in us that, with a bit of luck, we might just pull it off.

This na?ve hope, combined with a compulsion to do something, is what got you in this mess in the first place. Admittedly, it's true that this has sometimes worked. You can find the proof if you flick through the history books, and knowing this, your confidence swells some more. But the reality is that this kind of situation has played out 1,000 times through history, and 999 times, it's ended in death. There's no point writing something down that's happened so many times, but the one time when it worked and the protagonists came out alive - that's enough to convince you it'll work out the same way for you, or even better. And so, you venture into the 'entangling ground' anyway, and what happens?

You get hung up to dry. 3) Temporizing ground:
 ¡§When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground."
If you and the enemy are on either side of a narrow strip of crossable land, meaning that whoever moves first will be at a disadvantage, this is called 'temporizing ground.'
For example, suppose there's a narrow canyon separating two armies. Whoever attacks first will have to pass through the canyon, and while they're inside, they'll be vulnerable to ambush.

Or, suppose there's a river separating the two armies. If one side wants to attack, they'll have to cross the river, which gives their opponents the chance to attack before they've finished crossing. The upshot is that neither side is keen to make the first move. In this situation, even though the enemy may offer us attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn.

Then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage. Chen Hao writes in his commentary that if both sides send out troops in difficult terrain, it's vital that you not chase after the enemy if they try to bait you. You should pull your army back, and if the enemy doesn't chase after you, forget about it.

If they do chase after you, wait until they're halfway through the 'temporizing ground,' and then strike as quickly as possible. In an earlier case study, we learned about a standoff between Commander Yang Chufu of the state of Jin and Commander Zi Shang of the state of Chu. The two armies stood on either side of the River Zhi, and Commander Yang Chufu decided he wanted to make the enemy come across the river so he could attack before they'd finished crossing. He pulled his men back from the riverbank and set up camp.

Meanwhile, Commander Zi Shang had the same idea, and he also pulled his men back and set up camp some distance away from the river. Both men were thinking alike, and, each unable to fool the other, they both retreated further and further away from the river, until it became obvious that nothing was going to happen.

At that point, they both quit while they were ahead and marched back home. This is an example of 'temporizing ground.' All that means is that whoever moves first will be at a disadvantage. So, both sides try to lure the enemy into attacking first.

When they fail to bait each other, they give up the idea of fighting and just go home. Some might ask, 'What has this got to do with the art of war, if there's no fighting and nobody wins?'
As we've said again and again, the most important part of the art of war isn't fighting, but not fighting.

Why do we lose? Why do our troops die and why do our commanders' heads get separated from their bodies? It's because we decided to fight. If we don't fight, we can't lose. If we don't fight, there'll always be a chance to fight in the future. If we fight, lose and end up dead, we'll never have another chance. This is why Sun Tzu talks about winning first and fighting later.

If you haven't already won, don't fight. Obviously, this means there aren't many situations where you actually fight; most of the time, you should choose to not fight. If you do fight, finish the job with one battle. If you look closely at the major historical case studies - such as when Zhou Yafu put down the Rebellion of the Seven States - they can all be summed up as 'waiting instead of fighting, then settling the score in a single battle.'
A true hero is someone who's mastered the waiting game, and who understands how to hold off from fighting. Heroes who spend their whole time fighting belong in the movies; their only job is to put on a show.

True heroes understand one, simple truth: if you don't go looking for death, you won't get yourself killed. Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part three): Ability to judge when you're doomed to lose is more important than confidence that victory is yours

Extract from the original text:
¡§With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy. Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned.

With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up. If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away.

If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage. These six are the principles connected with Earth. The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them."

Analysis:
3) Narrow passes:

¡§With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Narrow passes are canyons giving passage between two mountains. Here, the enemy's force is powerless to harm me."

High mountains on either side, and a canyon in between - if I seize this position, there's only one road the enemy can take to get to me.

If I hold the entrance to the canyon, he's powerless to attack me. If you come across this kind of terrain, 'fill it up and await the advent of the enemy.' The notion of 'filling it up' is the same idea as filling a sink with water: deploy your men in a formation that uses up all the space in the pass. How do you do this?

Deploy troops on either side of the pass. Cao Cao writes: ¡§Square your forces with the entrance of the defile," meaning that your battle lines should precisely cover the entrance to the pass. Each pass has two entrances - one in the front, and one in the back - so you need to deploy troops on both sides.

This is how to make sure nobody can get in. ¡§Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned."

If the enemy seizes the pass before you and fills it up with his men, stay away. If he only deploys troops on one side of the pass, or if he doesn't secure it at all, you should attack, because without securing both sides of the pass, the terrain isn't giving him any advantage.

Who will win then comes down to the people in both armies, rather than the terrain. We've already learned about how General Han Xin defeated the state of Zhao. In that war, the Zhao army failed to secure Jingxing Pass, allowing Han Xin to saunter unopposed through the dangerous terrain. 4) Precipitous heights:

¡§With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up."

Places described as 'precipitous heights' are strategic locations, easy to defend and difficult to attack.

If you get there first, you can set up in high, sunny ground, and wait for the enemy to come to you. This is about the importance of seizing the high ground before your enemy can. ¡§If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Precipitous heights are places of steep mountains and deep ravines, against which human strength is impotent. It is essential to occupy the high, sunny ground, and there await the enemy.

If the enemy seizes the position first, then you must not contend with him, but should entice him to leave his position. Sunny ground is that which faces south. It is likely that the enemy will hold his position for a long time; if you position yourself on shady ground, then disease will spread through your ranks. Should you encounter the enemy in mountainous or watery terrain, then first move to occupy a position in the mountains to the north; thus, you will be facing into the sun and away from the shade.

Facing the sun, or holding a high position - between these two, one may sacrifice a sunny position for the sake of gaining a high position, but not the other way round. Sun Tzu wrote about this in general terms."

If the enemy occupies a strategic location, you can't beat him through force of arms alone.

If it's obvious that you can't win, don't fight. Pull your troops back and retreat. If the enemy chases after you, he's left his strategic location and lost his terrain advantage and you can set an ambush. If he doesn't chase after you, let him stay on his mountain.

Time to go home. Cao Cao comments: ¡§In dangerous and constricted terrain, it is particularly important not to be maneuvered by the enemy." It's essential not to attack in this kind of terrain. Duke Li of Wei wrote that the entirety of The Art of War boils down to just one sentence: ¡§Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated." In practice, this means that you have to set up the battlefield and wait for the enemy to bring the fight to you. Accordingly, it also means refusing to go to a battlefield if it was chosen by the enemy.

5) Great distances:

¡§If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage."

In terrain characterized by 'great distances,' your army and the enemy army are positioned far apart. If you're in this situation, and if your capabilities are evenly matched with the enemy, you shouldn't try to start a fight.

In Du Mu's commentary, he gives an example: If your army is 30 li distant from your enemy, and you march out to attack the enemy camp, your men will be exhausted by the time you get there, while the enemy is still fresh. But if you wait for them to come to you looking for a fight, you can stay fresh and just wait while they tire themselves out.

What if you absolutely have to fight? ¡§Those who are determined in their desire to fight should move closer to the enemy," Du Mu writes. Move your camp closer to the enemy. This solution comes straight from Du Mu's imagination, not from anything Sun Tzu wrote.

Sun Tzu only wrote about the characteristics of 'great distances' in terms of general principles. The only place to get a detailed, specific solution is the battlefield. No two places are the same, and no two battles are the same.

¡§These six are the principles connected with Earth. The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them."

These six terrain types, and the 'art of terrain,' are crucial considerations. For any general or leader, it's simply not an option to be ignorant about such an important subject.

It's a big responsibility. When we're at war, we're all more than willing to drum up confidence within ourselves that victory is the only outcome. But, for generals, it's more important to be a good judge of when you're 'doomed to fail' than to be confident of victory. If you know that you've lost the initiative and the terrain advantage, don't engage.

The biggest disaster is when you don't know that you're going to lose and walk blindly into a fight. Zhuge Liang had a Chinese Dream - to unify all of China. This is why, even though it was obvious that his kingdom was no match for the state of Wei, he kept hammering, launching one campaign after another into the Central Plain.

However, whenever he saw that victory was beyond his grasp, he would immediately pull his army back and head home. There's no such thing as a sure victory. Instead, we should aim to not lose. Six ways to lose (part one): You always lose to yourself; All responsibility belongs to the commander-in-chief

Extract from the original text:
¡§Now an army is exposed to six calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout.

Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former. When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness.

When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse. When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin. When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixed duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization. When a general, unable to estimate the enemy's strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout.

These are six ways of courting defeat, which must be carefully noted by the general who has attained a responsible post."

Analysis:
¡§Now an army is exposed to six several calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout."
This section is about the six 'calamities,' or the six failures:
1) Flight:

¡§Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The force has not been measured."

Li Quan comments: ¡§This is about not measuring force. One may use the stratagem of ambush by an auxiliary force, provided that you have obtained advantageous terrain."

If you try to fight a force ten times the size of your own, you haven't accurately assessed the balance of power.

Then, the only way you'll be in a position to fight is if you have a terrain advantage that allows a single one of your soldiers to hold back thousands of the enemy. 2) Looseness:

¡§When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness."

If the soldiers are tough but their officers are soft, to the point that officers' commands don't move them and discipline is limp, this is called 'looseness.'

During the Battle of Jifu, between the ancient states of Wu and Chu, the Chu forces teamed up with a few, small vassal states to form a seven-state allied army, which included in its ranks several minor lords. During the war, the Chu commander-in-chief, Yang Gai, fell ill and died.

¡§The Chu army has been spoiled, and there is no consistency in commands and decrees; the commanders are debased and incapable of organizing the army. Lacking authority sufficient to give orders, Chu is likely to lose." Thus spoke the Duke of Wu, Zi Guang.

And he was right - the conflict ended with a major defeat for Chu. During the reign of Tang dynasty Emperor Muzong (795-825 CE) there was a military uprising in Zhen Prefecture. The Imperial House appointed Tian Bu as Governor of Weibo, and ordered him to deal with the rebels. Tian Bu had spent his childhood in Weibo, and the local people looked down on him and didn't listen to him.

In his camp, many thousands of troops milled around aimlessly, and Tian Bu was unable to rein them in. After several months, it seemed like fighting was about to break out, but none of his soldiers were willing to go to battle.

Helpless, Tian Bu sent a note to the Emperor, telling him about the army's situation and that he was powerless to do anything about it. The only thing Tian Bu had to offer was his life, and so he killed himself. The lesson here is that if you want to put a person to work for you, not only must that person have the proper skills, he also must have authority and the ability to twist people's arms and make them do his bidding.

If the person you choose has the skill but not the authority, he's only fit to work as an assistant. 3) Collapse:

¡§When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Strong officers want to advance, but if the common soldiers are weak, collapse will ensue." This applies when soldiers don't follow behind their brave and strong commander. ¡§With me!" the general shouts, as he charges.

Behind him, though, his troops haven't followed. He plunges forward, alone, and into collapse. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§The general and officers are brave and desire to fight, but the common soldiery lack quality and training, rendering them unable to match their leaders' bravery or to fight zealously alongside them. If you use such men, you are certain to meet with collapse, death and defeat."

It's important to 'match bravery' between troops and officers, and for everyone to fight alongside each other with the same, elevated energy.

The general's duty is to train and lead soldiers, not to fight single-handed. If he can't properly train his men during peacetime, all his personal bravery and strength won't do any good on the battlefield.

He'll find himself trapped, and collapse will inevitably follow. 4) Ruin:

¡§When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§'Higher officers' are assistant generals. The senior general vents rage upon them, and so in their hearts they do not respect him.

Being already angry, when the time comes to attack the enemy, they do not measure the balance of power. Then, ruin is inevitable." After meeting the enemy, the senior officers don't wait for command, and lead their men into battle under their own authority. In an army where the commander can't control his officers, ruin is what happens. Chen Hao comments: ¡§This is when the commanding general behaves unreasonably and thus enrages the assistant generals.

They harbor disrespect in their hearts, and because they bear grudges, they commence battle as soon as the enemy is at hand, without considering whether they can win. Therefore, they are heavily defeated." When officers are disgruntled, they want to fight as soon as they catch sight of the enemy. They don't care whether they live or die, and they care even less about overall strategy.

Feeling bitter and having lost control of their emotions, they want to fight to vent their feelings. But, it might be even more serious - they might hope that their own side will lose just to humiliate their commander.

'I remember when it was you abusing me. Well, let's see how things go for you now!' they think to themselves."

We've already learned about the Battle for the City of Bi, which took place during the war between Jin and Chu, as both states vied to dominate China. The Jin and Chu armies were standing on opposite sides of the Yellow River.

It was clear that the next battle would be decisive, and within the Jin army everyone had different opinions about whether to fight or sue for peace. The commander-in-chief, Xun Linfu, wanted to hold their position, while the Military Adjutant, Xian Gu, wanted to take the fight to the enemy.

There was a fierce debate, but no conclusion. So, Xian Gu did exactly what Sun Tzu wrote about: he got angry, lost respect for his commanding officer, and because of his feelings, he started a fight on his own initiative, leading his household soldiers across the Yellow River. Xun Linfu was shocked when he heard the news.

Sima Hanjue suggested mobilizing the rest of the army to prevent Xian Gu's force from being wiped out. And that's how the entire Jin army was forced to start a fight. But, there were two other men in the Jin army who proved to be even worse than Xian Gu: Wei Qi and Zhao Zhan. At least Xian Gu thought he was trying to help his country, but these two wanted the Jin army to lose.

It was, as we discussed earlier, all because Xun Linfu had refused them when they'd asked for promotions. Now, they wanted to see Xun suffer. The two managed to get authorization from Lin to go to the Chu camp and negotiate a peace accord. But when they got there, they did the exact opposite.

Instead of negotiating for peace, they picked a fight. They intentionally left Xun Linfu unprepared for the Chu surprise attack that they'd provoked, which naturally inflicted a heavy defeat on the Jin army.

That was the moment when Jin was no longer a contender in the contest to dominate China. Xun Linfu's grandson, Xun Yan, also served as commander-in-chief of the Jin army, and while he was at the helm, he led a campaign against the state of Qin. When it was time to march out from Jin, he announced: ¡§We ride when the cock crows; you will follow me, and me alone." But this infuriated the man next to him, Lian Shu, who announced: ¡§There is no man of Jin living who can give me orders like this!" He was in effect saying, 'I'm pulling my men out, and I don't want to have anything more to do with you.'

Lian Shu was a powerful politician in Jin, and he was old enough to be Xun Yan's father. If this is how things were done in Jin, it's no wonder that the state eventually fractured, resulting in new states - Han, Zhao, and Wei, three of the seven major states during the Warring States period.

If Jin had stayed unified, there only would have been five states, and Qin might not have been able to ultimately unify all of China. Let's talk about another arrogant Jin general, Zhao Chuan. He was a through-and-through rich kid, completely reliant on his uncle Zhao Cui and his older brother, Zhao Dun.

Zhao Dun was the Jin commander-in-chief when Qin invaded. His trusted advisor, Military Adjutant Yu Pian, came up with a plan. He said that the Qin army lacked staying power, and proposed taking advantage of that.

¡§If we hold our position and don't come out to fight, they won't be able to last. Eventually, they'll pull back, and then we can hit them when they're 'sluggish and inclined to return.' It'll be a complete victory." Zhao Dun was completely sold on the plan, so he gave orders that nobody was allowed to go out and fight. When it became clear that the Jin forces weren't going to engage, Duke Kang of Qin grew anxious.

He turned to a Jin exile, Shi Hui, who had moved to Qin. The duke asked Shi Hui, ¡§What's going on?" 

¡§This is Yu Pian's idea, no doubt," Shi Hui replied. ¡§The Jin commander-in-chief's younger brother, Zhao Chuan, is extremely upset that his brother promoted Yu Pian. If we pick a fight with Zhao Chuan's men, he's bound to come out and fight."

The Qin commander did as Shu Hui said.

A force was dispatched to harass Zhao Chuan, and sure enough, Zhao Chuan came out to fight. At the time, Zhao Dun was holding a meeting. When he heard that Zhao Chuan was fighting, his only option was to mobilize the whole army and join the fray.

After all, his little brother's safety was at stake. Six ways to lose (part two): The art of choosing your vanguard

5) Disorganization:

¡§When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixes duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization."

When a general is timid, doesn't manage his men strictly enough, and doesn't give clear instructions, his soldiers are left without a consistent framework.

When it's time to line up for battle, the battle lines will be ragged and the troops will get in each other's way. This is what Sun Tzu means by 'disorganization.'

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§The general is weak and not strict; this is what it means to speak of 'a commander who lacks authority and moral force.' His instructions and communications are unclear; this is what it means to speak of 'a commander whose commands are not informed by the methods of old.' There is no consistency among the officers and the soldiers; this is what it means to speak of 'a commander who has no long-standing advisors.' When he lines up his soldiers, the lines are slovenly and uneven; this is what it means to speak of 'the soldiery lacking control.' When a general is like this, disorganization follows."

A general who 'is weak and not strict' has no authority or moral force. In a company where no one has been in the job for long - where everyone's new - frankly it would be strange if disorganization and chaos weren't the order of the day.

6) Rout:

¡§When a general, unable to estimate the enemy's strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout."

The key here is: 'place picked soldiers in the front rank.' This is imperative. Form a vanguard from a handpicked group of your best fighters.

They will be your spearhead; they'll be like a dagger to plunge into the enemy. You could say that without a spearhead, all you're left with is a bunch of soldiers with no sharp edges. King Wei of the state of Qi asked the strategist Sun Bin about battle theory: ¡§If the ground is level and the two armies' personnel are evenly matched when they come together, what causes one side to be routed?"

¡§Because they had battle lines but no spearhead," came Sun Bin's reply. Any army that makes this mistake is doomed to be defeated.

Also on this point, there's a passage from a chapter of the Wei Liaozi, entitled Authority in War, which reads: ¡§If one fails to hand-pick warriors, one's entire army will be weak."
This line is a reminder: where is your spearhead? As a military leader, it's absolutely essential to have one.

Du Mu mentions in his commentary that Duke Li of Wei wrote about having a vanguard unit as part of his writings on the art of war. We also have a detailed comment from He Shi: ¡§It is always unacceptable to treat soldiers as a single entity, when they comprise soldiers who are weak and soldiers who are full of courage.

Because the brave soldiers will receive no encouragement, and the weak soldiers will be able to hide themselves and thus will go into battle but not fight. Hence, defeat awaits. This is why it is written in Sun Tzu's The Art of War: 'Neglecting to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout.' 

¡§In times of old, the state of Qi derived strength from their 'strike specialists,' Wei derived vigor from their 'martial men,' and Qin built victory upon their 'sharp swords.' There were many alternative names for 'handpicked vanguard.' The Han military men had their 'three rivers, valiant swordsmen and prodigies,' the Wu generals called them 'problem-solvers,' the Qi generals called them 'fate-fixers,' and the Tang generals called them 'leapers and shakers.' Nothing comes before this in the use of military tactics. As for the talents the chosen men must possess, the senior general would order each camp to select its best fighting men, who must be unusually strong and fit in addition to being surpassingly skilled in the use of weapons.

These men should be 'organized into a separate unit' consisting of roughly one tenth of the army. The chosen men have few tasks; the crucial point is that they must be ready. They are the heart of the general's command system; they are the general's personal fighting force, and they also serve such tasks as fighting at the front line, setting ambushes, and so forth. Each of them must be deployed in accordance with an accurate assessment of their qualities."

If you treat all of your men as if they were the same, the best fighters won't get any recognition; if they think there's no honor to be gained, their will to fight will fade. As for the weaker men, they'll be able to hide their mediocrity by blending into the background and letting more capable men do the heavy lifting.

They'll be physically present on the battlefield, but they won't be fighting; they'll be hiding behind the stronger men. That's why The Art of War tells us that if you don't have an advance unit, you're going to lose. You can call this unit 'the big guns,' 'the death-defiers,' or simply 'the vanguard.' Whatever you call it, they'll be your cutting edge. All the dynasties throughout Chinese history have made it a priority to build up vanguard forces, and each dynasty had a different name for these special units. During the Spring and Autumn period, they were called 'forward marchers' by Jin tacticians, and 'sharp swords' or 'line-breakers' by Qin generals. They were known as 'strike specialists' or 'fate-fixers' by Qi commanders, during the Warring States period. The leaders of the state of Wei referred to them as 'martial men,' while Tang strategists called them 'fighting blades' and 'leapers and shakers.'

Judging by all these names, it's clear how much importance was attached to building these vanguard units. Above all else, using military force is about using these units.

They account for one in ten soldiers in an army - chosen from among the best men in every camp - and tasked with fighting at the front line, carrying out ambushes, serving as the general's personal guard, and other critically important duties.

They are absolutely crucial; they are the elite force that brings victory. The Ming dynasty writer Yu Qian observed: ¡§Of all the methods to prevent disgrace, none is better than training the soldiers, and the crucial part of training soldiers is to separate the strong from the weak. Thus it is written in Sun Tzu's The Art of War: 'Neglecting to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout,' and 'proper governance is what brings victory in war.' A million men who do not obey orders are worth less than ten thousand with the will to fight; ten thousand men who do not obey orders are worth less than a hundred imbued with powerful energy. That is, the most treasured resource in war is not numbers, but spirit; much better to have a handful of spirited men than many lackluster men."

During the time of the Eastern Jin dynasty (316-420 CE), the Eastern Jin commander Xie Xuan faced heavy military pressure from the Former Qin dynasty. Xie Xuan picked out the most fearless warriors from among the northern nomads and put a man named Liu Laozhi in command.

He proved to be an excellent leader, and he led the vanguard unit in dozens of battles, winning each and every one. His unit became known as the Northern Palace Detachment. They made their name at the Battle of Feishui after defeating Fu Jian's million-man army, and they were consistently the most powerful weapon in the Eastern Jin arsenal. It was from their ranks that the man who founded the Liu Song Empire, Liu Yu, first rose to power.

After taking the throne, the Northern Palace Detachment became the core of the Liu Song military apparatus. Sun Tzu's professional ethics: Don't seek fame when you advance; don't avoid blame when you retreat

Guo Ziyi represents the Chinese people's ultimate dream, a dream thousands of years old: honor, wealth and status; good health and long life; and many, many children and grandchildren. Extract from the original text:
¡§The natural formation of the country is the soldier's best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general.

He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles. He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated. If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler's bidding. The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom."

Analysis:
¡§The natural formation of the country is the soldier's best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general. He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles.

He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated."
In war, terrain is your natural helper. The best generals accurately judge their enemy's plans, study the terrain and identify where it presents danger and easy travel, calculate the distances to be travelled, and draw up a battle plan.

If you go into battle as a commander having understood these principles, victory is within your grasp. If you don't, you're going to lose. Terrain is of crucial importance. In Chinese, there's a saying that good terrain trumps timing. However, it's still just a helper; having the right personnel is better than having a terrain advantage. Your human resources are your foundation.

This doesn't mean that good terrain is worth less than having more people; it means that having people who understand the art of war is the only way you can evaluate the terrain, assess the enemy's situation and ultimately win the decisive battle. ¡§If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler's bidding."

Depending on the situation on the ground, if victory is already certain, you can fight even if the ruler orders you not to.

If it's clear that you're going to lose, you can choose not to fight even if the ruler orders you to fight. This is the same principal as before: 'The general in the field does not always obey the sovereign's orders.'

¡§The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom."

What makes this kind of person a national treasure? Zhang Yu comments: ¡§A loyal servant of the state is a man who advances or retreats without regard for his own life, who never acts out of personal interests, and who does everything to protect the people and bring benefit to the sovereign; such a man is the jewel of the kingdom." 
He Shi comments: ¡§How could it be acceptable to seek fame by advancing?

Look always for what is beneficial to the state and the people, and only advance when you have seen it. How could it be acceptable to avoid blame by retreating? Upon seeing a danger that might bring disaster to the state and the people, do not advance even if the sovereign commands you. Have no regrets, even if you are tainted by disgrace."
As He Shi has pointed out, Sun Tzu doesn't just suggest that everything you do should be for the people: ¡§Protect the people in everything you do; seek outcomes that align with the sovereign's interests."
Protecting your officers, soldiers and the common people is about staying alive. Don't throw lives away for no good reason, and remember that you need to bring home whatever helps your ruler's interests.

There's a difference between the interests of the people and the interests of the ruler. A 'jewel of the country' could be described as 'of superlative quality, honest and upright, kind, devoted and proud.'
Being of 'superlative quality' means having the ability to see the essence of things, to know whether the outcome of a conflict will be victory or defeat, and to know when to advance and when to retreat. Being 'honest and upright' means integrity is in your very bones; you're not just truthful and principled in certain things, but in everything you do.

No matter what decision you're faced with, nobody in your organization, from the lowest rank to the highest, questions your motives. This is the only kind of person who has the qualifications and the space to make unilateral decisions and to act alone. This kind person is someone who truly loves their people, their country and their subordinates, as well as their ruler.

Their love is sincere and without pretense; it is a love that every person can feel emanating from them. A 'devoted' person is someone who is truly loyal to their country, and to the interests of their people and their ruler.

It is not someone who is loyal only to instructions given by any one person. Because the ruler's instructions don't necessarily align with his interests, the ruler's judgment might be incorrect. A 'proud' person is someone who cares nothing about the fame that comes with being a 'winner.' That's worthless to them.

They have no use for yet another victory to prove their worth. When other people measure them by their victories, they just laugh. So, who lives up to these standards? Who can rightly be called a 'jewel of the country?'
How about Yue Fei?

Actually, no. The way Yue Fei moved his armies might have aligned with the interests of the state and the people, but not with those of the ruler, Emperor Zhao Gou. Yue Fei's actions could have resulted in two men both claiming to be Emperor - what was Zhao Gou supposed to do about that? In the fallout after the destruction of the Northern Song dynasty, Zhao Gou had the biggest stake in the game, because he'd become Emperor even though he wasn't technically 'qualified.' If there were a war, the enemy Khitan state wouldn't even need Yue Fei to fight. They might have just released Zhao Gou's older brother and sent him home, which would have plunged the Emperor into a deep political crisis.

There's not much use you can get out of a captive enemy ruler; the enemy will just choose a new ruler, and your prisoner will become worthless. During the Ming dynasty's Crisis of Tumu Fortress, the Mongolian commander Esen Taishi captured Emperor Yingzong. Immediately, the Ming court installed Yingzong's younger brother, Chengwang, as the new ruler, known as the Jingtai Emperor. Esen Taishi no longer had any use for the Emperor he'd captured, so for lack of better options, he sent him home, where he was put under house arrest in the Southern Palace by the Jingtai Emperor.

He stayed locked up for seven years, until the Jingtai Emperor fell ill. Then, Shi Heng and his co-conspirators launched the 'Duomen Coup' and restored Yingzong to the throne. So, when Yue Fei championed the idea of bringing back 'the second Emperor,' he was completely ignoring Emperor Gaozong's (Zhao Gou's) interests. Ultimately, Emperor Gaozong negotiated peace with the Khitans, who kept his older brother Qinzong in captivity but released his mother, Empress Xianren. Emperor Gaozong became the architect of the Southern Song restoration, and eventually died peacefully at the ripe old age of 81.

In the long run, the man who acted in his ruler's interests wasn't the folk hero Yue Fei, but the 'villain,' Qin Hui. They were two halves of a whole: Yue Fei embodied the principle of 'protecting the people in everything you do,' while Qin Hui embodied the idea of 'seeking outcomes that align with the sovereign's interests.'
There was one man who meets both requirements: protecting the people while bringing benefits to the ruler. That man was Guo Ziyi.

During the Tang dynasty's cataclysmic An Lushan Rebellion, Guo Ziyi was the governor of Shuofang Province. On the battlefield, he defeated Shi Siming in Hebei, and later joined forces with an ethnic Huihe army, retaking the two capital cities of Luoyang and Chang'an.

With a glowing record of service for his contribution to quelling the rebellion, he was promoted to Grand Councilor and granted the noble title of King of Fenyang. During the reign of Emperor Daizong, the traitorous general Pugu Huai'en convinced Tibetan and Huihe forces to invade the Guanzhong plain region. Guo Ziyi made the correct strategic decision: he allied with the Huihe troops and fought against the Tibetans, and successfully upheld the peace and protected his country. Guo Ziyi spent his whole life working as a military man, only leaving the arena for the final time at the age of 84.

He racked up many amazing achievements during his career, and because of him China enjoyed peace for over 20 consecutive years. He had all the power in the world, but didn't provoke the imperial court's hostility.

He was the most celebrated man of his generation, but he was never doubted by the Emperor. He enjoyed the highest esteem and prestige, throughout the land. Holding posts at the pinnacle of the governmental hierarchy, Guo Ziyi had immense power. And yet, he always had an easy way about him, and never put up any barriers between himself and the Emperor. Certain court ministers, the type naturally given to treachery, were jealous of him and told tales that he was plotting a rebellion. They insisted to the Emperor that he summon Guo Ziyi to see whether he would obey the summons. If he didn't come, that would prove he would soon rebel; if he did come, they figured, they'd have their chance to take him down. Guo Ziyi didn't delay for a second.

He went immediately before the Emperor, and he went alone, with no guards. He told the Emperor that his head had always been Imperial property, and it was the Emperor's to take if he wished. Guo Ziyi's son, Guo Ai, was given an Imperial princess as his wife, but the two used to quarrel.

¡§My father is the Emperor, how dare you treat me so rudely!" the Princess said. ¡§Who cares about the Emperor? My father doesn't want to be Emperor. Otherwise, the throne would be his already! Do you really think your father would have a chance?" Guo Ai shot back. The princess went to the Emperor in tears and told him what Guo Ai had said.

Under the rule of any of China's historical dynasties, his actions would have been enough to have him sentenced to death. Guo Ziyi heard about his son's ridiculous actions, and hurried to the palace to apologize for the young man's crime. ¡§The boy has been quarreling and saying all manner of nonsense.

What are we to do with him?" the Emperor said. In the end, Guo Ziyi personally gave his son a beating. And with that, it was done. Guo Ziyi had seven sons and eight sons-in-law, and all of them made it into high-ranking government posts. On his sixtieth birthday, all his sons and sons-in-law came to celebrate, and each carried from the Imperial court the tablets that government ministers used to record the Emperor's commands or comments.

These they placed on their father's bed. The bed was covered in the tablets, and the phrase 'a bed full of courtier's tablets' has entered the Chinese language as a reference to classical culture, meaning 'a family that has achieved extraordinary success.'
If you visit ancient Chinese villages, you will see tile sculptures above the doorways of old manor houses, and the story of Guo Ziyi is the most common theme of these sculptures. Guo Ziyi represents the Chinese people's ultimate, age-old dream: honor, wealth and status; good health and long life; and an abundance of children and grandchildren.

Love your troops like your own children; True love isn't easy; Not for generals, and even less so for the troops! Extract from the original text:
¡§Regard your soldiers as your children, and they will follow you into the deepest valleys; look upon them as your own beloved sons, and they will stand by you even unto death."

Analysis:
Treat your soldiers the same way you'd treat a baby you are raising. If you do that, you can command them to go with you into dangerous places, and they'll follow.

You can go face-to-face with death, and know that they will be with you at your side. During the Warring States period, the strategist Wu Qi served as a general. He shared food and clothing with even the lowest of the low among his troops.

He slept on the ground without a mat to pad his body, walked rather than ride a horse, and carried his own food on his back; he shared all the physical work and all the hardship that his men experienced. In a story we recounted earlier, one of his men had an ulcer on his leg, so Wu Zi put his mouth to the wound and sucked out the puss.

When the man's mother heard of this, she began weeping bitterly, as if in grief. ¡§The general has been so kind to your son, what are you crying for?" her neighbors asked her. ¡§Years ago, my son's father also had an ulcer on his leg, and general Wu sucked his wound clean. Very soon after that, my husband died in battle.

Now, General Wu has done the same thing for my son, and he too will fight and die for him," the woman replied. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Give them nurture and comfort, and they will stay close to you and never stray.

Love and help them, and they will trust you and never doubt. Thus, though they may die, they will offer you their death; though they may come into peril, they will do this for you."
That's why it's important to sincerely care for your troops. Don't think that Wu Qi's sucking of the ulcers was just a cheap trick.

If you do think that, why don't you try sucking on someone's ulcer! Without sincere, honest love for your men, and without leading them as though they were your own sons, you can never become an outstanding leader.

In He Shi's commentary, he writes that a benevolent approach to directing an army is what enabled General Duan Jiong to defeat the Qiang people. He personally attended to the wounded in his army, wrapping their bandages himself.

Over the dozen or more years he spent living on the frontiers of the Empire, he never gave himself the luxury of a bed or even proper bedding. Whatever hardship his troops went through, so did he. That's what made every one of his troops glad to fight and die for him. What about the idea that leaders should 'lead from the front?'
¡§Soldiers toil and labor; the general must go before them. In summer he should not protect himself from the sun with awnings, and in winter he should not wear heavy clothing.

When danger comes, he must take the first step. He must only drink after the soldiers' well is ready, he must only eat after the soldiers' meal is cooked, and he must only take shelter after the soldiers' quarters are built." This is a teaching from the art of war. This isn't about going through the motions a couple of times, or just for a day or two; you have to do this day after day, perhaps for decades.

It isn't something that can be faked, and if you do manage to 'fake it' for decades, you're not actually faking; you're really doing it. Can it be done? Few indeed really and truly have the ability. Also in He Shi's commentary, he tells the story of Wang Rui, a governor of Ba Commandery under the Western Jin dynasty. Wang Rui took up the post in Ba, part of modern Sichuan Province, after Liu Bei's Shu Han Kingdom was wiped out by Western Jin forces.

Ba Commandery bordered the kingdom of Wu, so Wang Rui was tasked with preparing for war. Soldiers and commoners were conscripted for forced labor, and the work was so grueling that many families killed or abandoned their newborn sons rather than raise them to join the workforce.

Abandoning boys is a phenomenon that happened again and again throughout Chinese history. This was because the poll tax was calculated by the number of males in each household, as was conscription for forced labor. During the reign of Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty (141-87 BCE), the Emperor's constant wars bankrupted the country:
A passage from the ancient text, History of the Former Han Dynasty, reads: ¡§Emperor Wu, to finance his campaigns against the various barbarians, imposed heavy taxation upon the people.

When a family produced a son, taxation was due upon the boy's third birthday. So burdensome was this that some killed their sons upon their birth. What tragedy!"
Readers know that the modern 'one-child policy' led to people killing or abandoning female babies, but many might not know that the same thing happened to male babies throughout China's historic succession of dynasties, all because of military conscription and taxes. There's a passage from a poem by the Tang dynasty poet Du Fu that reads: 
¡§We know now having boys is bad,
While having girls is for the best;
Our girls can still be married to the neighbors,
Our sons are merely buried amid the grass."
The true horror was even worse than the poem suggests. What did Wang Rui do about it when he found out this was going on?

First, he gave out harsh punishments to people who abandoned or killed babies. Next, he granted maternity and paternity leave to all new parents, along with exemptions from forced labor and tax breaks.

That was all it took to save thousands of baby boys! Nearly two decades passed like this, until Wang Rui raised an army and gave orders to invade the kingdom of Wu, by which point the baby boys had reached fighting age. The young men's mothers told them:
¡§It wasn't us, your mother and father, who brought you into this world; it was the lord up in the palace.

You must do all you can to help him, and do not hold back from giving your life!"
So, Wang Rui, by then over 70 years old, completed his great task of destroying the kingdom of Wu and uniting the Three Kingdoms under the rule of the Western Jin dynasty. There's more to fear from your high-ranking officers than from the enemy

Extract from the original text:
¡§If, however, you are indulgent, but unable to make your authority felt; kind-hearted, but unable to enforce your commands; and incapable, moreover, of quelling disorder: then your soldiers must be likened to spoiled children; they are useless for any practical purpose."

Analysis:
If you only know how to be soft with your men, and can't make them do what you want - if you constantly spoil them, and can't make them obey your orders - you won't be able to reel them in if they break the rules or if their discipline lapses.

Then, your men will become proud and unusable. In Du Mu's commentary, he quotes from Huang Shigong: ¡§One may go down to one's men, but one may not foster arrogance." You can make yourself approachable and get close to your men, and you can treat them politely. What you cannot do is give them free rein.

'Going down to one's men' is about using kindness to cultivate your troops and behaving modestly with them; 'Not fostering arrogance' is about using rules and law to control them. There's a passage in a classical text, the Yinfujing, which reads: ¡§Danger is born of kindness." When we treat a person too well, we generally end up hurting them as well as ourselves.

Why? Because you're always nothing but kind, nothing but loving, and you have no boundaries or rules. People get used to this, and they start to act spoiled and let themselves go. Once that happens, there's no way back, no matter how you try to adjust.

All you can do is give up on them. Then, they lose their chance to be a part of what you're doing, and you've wasted your time trying to make something of them. As soon as the kindness that these people have come to expect from you is gone, they become your enemy. On what grounds do they make an enemy of you? It's not that you've hurt them, just that you've withheld your kindness.

As far as you're concerned, all you've done is stop giving them something, but they feel that you're taking something of theirs, something precious, away from them. Kindness and resentment, debts of gratitude and desire for revenge; they all go together, and they are proportionate to each other.

Without kindness, and without a debt of gratitude, there's no drive for revenge. Wu Qi writes: ¡§Drums, both on horseback and on the ground, cymbals and bells all establish authority over the ears that behold them; flags, banners and insignias establish authority over the eyes that behold them; prohibitions, commands and punishments establish authority over the minds that behold them. Sounds are used to build authority via the ears, so they must not be unclear; images are used to build authority via the eyes, so they must not be dull; punishments are used to build authority via the minds, so they must not be lax.

If you do not establish these three, you inevitably shall suffer defeat at the hands of your enemy. Therefore, it is said that 'when a general gives signals with flags, all of his soldiers without exception follow the direction indicated; when a general points, all of his soldiers without exception advance towards death.'"
Regular training, drills and ceremonies are all important; they strengthen the authority of your command system and get your men used to obeying commands and not doing forbidden things. This is the only way to train troops who aren't scared to sacrifice themselves, and who will fight wherever you point them.

As soon as you point your signal flags and beat your drums, they'll charge without a second thought, because they know that not charging will bring dire consequences. Duke Li of Wei wrote: ¡§Those who fear me will not fear my enemies; those who fear my enemy will not fear me." As a general, it's essential to be scarier than your enemy.

You want your men to realize that they won't necessarily die if they charge the enemy battle lines, but there's no escape from the executioner if they don't charge when the bugle sounds. If that doesn't horrify you, a passage from later on in Duke Li's writings might: ¡§In ancient times, it was a requirement for generals to be able to kill three of every ten of their own soldiers; second-rate generals would kill one of every ten. Killing three of every ten, your authority will shake the enemy's country; killing one of every ten, you could effectively command an army."
In early antiquity, Chinese generals would kill some of their own men, not enemy hostages, before marching to war. Killing hostages - like the Kangxi Emperor's killing of rebel general Wu Sangui's son - isn't a way to establish authority, but to burn bridges. If you want to build military authority, establish military law and make sure your army obeys you, the only people you should kill are men under your command who don't listen to orders.

As for exactly what kind of people you should select for the executioner, the best targets are those who have some favor with the Emperor. They think that nobody would dare hurt them, and this makes them careless.

By killing people like this, you show your men that anyone can be killed. Execute first, tell the Emperor afterward. When you report to the Emperor when the deed's already done, he'll feel that you've acted appropriately.

There are countless stories along these lines. When Sun Tzu was discussing the art of war with the King of Wu, the king handed his concubines over to Sun Tzu and instructed him to train them as soldiers. If he could turn them into a squad of battle-ready warriors, the King of Wu said, Sun Tzu would win his trust. At first, the concubines giggled and ignored Sun Tzu's orders, so he immediately executed the leaders, two of the king's most beloved concubines.

After that, Sun Tzu was able to complete the women's training without delay. Another classic example of this principle is Tian Rangju's execution of Zhuang Jia. The states of Jin and Yan had both attacked the state of Qi, and Qi crumbled under their assault.

Duke Jing of Qi then appointed Tian Rangju as a senior general, on the recommendation of his advisor, Yan Ying. The new general had an idea, and went to tell Duke Jing: ¡§I am of humble birth, and now you have elevated me from a commoner to a great general. Nobody knows me, so nobody will obey me, and I shall be unable to hold together the battle lines. I ask you, my lord, please appoint one of your must trusted and senior advisors to serve as my overseer." Duke Jing chose to appoint a man named Zhuang Jia. Tian Rangju made arrangements with Zhuang Jia, and they agreed to set out at noon the next day.

At the hour of departure, the army was assembled and ready, but Zhuang Jia was still drinking with his fellow senior officials, who were giving him a send-off. It was sunset by the time he arrived at the place where the army was gathered. Tian Rangju summoned a military legal official, who confirmed the punishment for reporting late to an army preparing to march - execution by decapitation! The death sentence was served immediately. When Duke Jing received a report that Zhuang Jia was about to be beheaded, he dispatched an official to rush to the scene and save the condemned man. When the official arrived, Tian Rangju found him guilty of driving horses at excessive speed in a military camp, and sentenced him to death as well. However, he granted the man a reprieve on account of his status as a messenger for the Duke, and instead executed the charioteer and the left-side horse. These executions sent shockwaves through the enemy lands, and when the Jin leaders heard about this savage man in charge of the Qi armies, they didn't wait to see what it would be like to fight him.

They were so scared that they immediately pulled back their forces. With the Yan armies in flight, Tian Rangju pressed his advantage and gave chase, recovering all the territory that Qi had lost. When the Qi army returned in triumph, Duke Jing came out to greet them at the head of an escort of 100 officials.

He'd forgotten all about his advisor, Zhuang Jia! Tian Rangju was granted the title of Minister of War ('sima'), and that's how he became the famous General Sima Rangju. Sima Rangju's gambit has been imitated again and again throughout history, but many times by ignorant men who neglected to study, and who ended up losing their own heads as a result.

In the final years of the Qin dynasty (221-207 BCE), Chen Sheng and Wu Guang launched an insurrection, as did Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu. Both rebellions managed to seize a few commanderies, and left chaos in their wake.

Every wild, ambitious young man in the realm was itching to get involved, and a few - hangers-on of General Peng Yue - went to Peng. They told him they'd follow him if he rose up against the Emperor ¡§If Chen Sheng, Wu Guang, Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu can do it, we definitely can!" they said. But Peng Yue refused: ¡§Currently, there are two tigers in battle against each other, and it is completely unclear how the situation might develop. I don't want anything to do with it."
But, the young, would-be rebels wouldn't let the matter drop.

They gathered together 100 or so men, determined to conquer the world with their big brother Peng Yue leading the way. Peng Yue couldn't get them out of his hair, and finally he gave way: ¡§Alright, alright - since you all are insisting on doing this, we'll hold our first military meeting tomorrow at dawn. Since we're making an army, we'll need a code of military laws; anyone who is late to the meeting will be decapitated!"
The next day at noon, Peng Yue was still waiting. Finally, the last few young men began to trickle into the meeting place.

Over a dozen of them were late. ¡§According to military law, anyone who is late is to be decapitated, but since so many of you are late, I can't execute you all. So, I'll just execute whoever arrived last!"
The men laughed, and asked: ¡§Is that really necessary?

Now, we know it won't happen again."
Peng Yue said nothing. He stepped forward, drew his sword, and beheaded the man who'd arrived last. Everyone else was so scared they began shaking; they didn't dare look Peng in the eye.

Then, Peng built a simple, earthen altar and offered up the man's severed head as a sacrifice. Peng Yue became a powerful figure in the region, and after throwing his weight behind Liu Bang he was eventually made a senior official in the new Western Han regime. Today, when we talk of official corruption, there's this idea in China that 'unless we fight corruption, the country will fall; if we do fight corruption, the party will fall.' This is a talking point used by people who don't want to do anything to stop corruption.

Actually, not fighting corruption is what will bring down the party. It's not true that the party won't have any officials left to do its work if all the corrupt officials are rounded up. In fact, this will only bring the party more strength and vitality.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Neither kindness nor punishments may be used exclusively. If you show only kindness, then the soldiers will become arrogant and useless. If you show only punishments, then the soldiers will not be close to you, which will also render them useless. The kingly way to manage soldiers is to use both kindness and punishments, thus establishing grace and authority simultaneously."
There's also a passage from the Wei Liaozi that reads: ¡§If you do not use love to make their hearts willing, then they are useless to you. If you do not use authority to make their hearts fearful, then they cannot be commanded by you." 
For generals, the art of commanding men consists of love and fear - it's a matter of rewards and punishments.

What is the essence of fear? ¡§Those who fear me shall not fear my enemy; those who fear my enemy shall not fear me." If men are scared of their commanding officers, they won't be scared of their enemies, they won't be scared of death, and vice versa.

So, we have clear criteria for what constitutes 'fear'- as a general, you have to be scarier than your enemies. 'Knowing yourself and your enemy' according to Emperor Taizong: If you don't have the skill to understand others, make sure you know yourself

As long as you know yourself, you can't lose.

Where people go wrong isn't that they don't understand other people; it's that they don't know themselves. Extract from the original text:
¡§If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half.

If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half. Hence the experienced soldier, once in motion, is never bewildered; at his disposal is an endless array of possible actions. Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete. Analysis:
¡§If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half."
In this scenario, you understand yourself, but not your enemy. You know your army is ready to fight, but you don't know that the enemy is also very strong, and you won't necessarily be able to get the best of them. So, your odds of victory are fifty-fifty. ¡§If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half."

If you've identified a vulnerability in the enemy that you can strike, but you don't realize your men aren't up to the task, you won't necessarily be able to win. In this scenario, you understand your enemy, but not yourself.

Your odds of victory are still fifty-fifty. In both scenarios, there's no certainty of victory. Emperor Taizong wrote: ¡§Whenever I stand with serried ranks facing my enemy, I first evaluate the enemy's thoroughness and prudence, and mine also, and so I am able to know my enemy in this way. I observe the degree to which my enemy's energy has been cultivated, and mine also, and so I am able to understand myself. This is how I come to know both my enemy and myself; this is indispensable for any military leader. If the officials and advisors of today only know themselves, even without knowing the enemy this is still enough that they will not easily be defeated."
Emperor Taizong was able to see through his enemies, and he also had a clear understanding of himself. Even in midst of a dynamic, developing situation, he was able to grasp and manipulate both his army and his enemy's forces, including shifts in both armies' morale and mood.

By doing this, he could create opportunities for certain victory. But, he also says that if you don't have the ability to do all this, you don't have to completely understand your enemy. In other words, as long as you have a clear understanding of yourself, you can't lose. This is Emperor Taizong's view on 'knowing yourself and your enemy' - if you don't have the skill to understand other people, make sure you know yourself. I feel very much the same way.

Generally, when we try to learn about 'knowing yourself and your enemy,' we focus entirely on how to understand other people, thinking that of course we have a good understanding of ourselves. But, in reality, people usually go wrong because they don't correctly understand themselves, and not because they can't understand other people.

The same is true in business. Don't focus exclusively on learning about the so-called 'competition,' because it's not particularly useful to know what other people are doing. You need to know what your customers need and what you're capable of doing. ¡§If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half."

It's not enough to know yourself and your enemy; you also have to know the terrain. ¡§Hence the experienced soldier, once in motion, is never bewildered; at his disposal is an endless array of possible actions."

You've already seen and thoroughly considered all the factors in play before you take action, so you can't become confused.

You know yourself and your enemy, and you know where the advantage of terrain and timing are, so you can take any change in your stride and adapt without breaking step. You'll never find yourself without a plan.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§He does not move recklessly, and thus when he does move, he makes no mistake. He does not take action lightly, and thus when he does take action, he does not find himself in difficulties.

He learns the weaknesses and strengths of himself and the enemy, and he gains the advantage of expeditious terrain. Only then does he fight."

¡§Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete."

So, if you know yourself and your enemy, you can win without danger; if you understand the advantages of terrain and timing, victory is completely guaranteed. Sun Tzu said: ¡§We may distinguish six kinds of terrain: (1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy.

Ground that can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible. With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies.

Then you will be able to fight with advantage. Ground that can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue. Ground that can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him.

But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue. When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground. In a position of this sort, even though the enemy should offer us an attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn; then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage.

With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy. Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned. With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up.

If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away. If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage. These six are the principles connected with Earth.

The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them. Now an army is exposed to six calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout.

Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former. When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness.

When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse. When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin. When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixed duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization. When a general, unable to estimate the enemy's strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout. These are six ways of courting defeat, which must be carefully noted by the general who has attained a responsible post. The natural formation of the country is the soldier's best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general. He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles.

He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated. If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler's bidding. The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom. Regard your soldiers as your children, and they will follow you into the deepest valleys; look upon them as your own beloved sons, and they will stand by you even unto death.

If, however, you are indulgent, but unable to make your authority felt; kind-hearted, but unable to enforce your commands; and incapable, moreover, of quelling disorder: then your soldiers must be likened to spoiled children; they are useless for any practical purpose. If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half.

If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half. How to wage war in the 'Nine terrain types' (part one): Managing energy, selecting men for your vanguard, and the art of dividing your forces
