Cao Cao comments: ¡§There are nine types of terrain where battle may be desirable."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Among all the terrain types where war may be waged, there are nine attendant energies. Here, the subject matter is the energy pertaining to terrain; hence, this chapter follows after the chapter entitled Terrain."
This chapter is about the 'energy pertaining to terrain' - the various features of a battlefield. It mainly revolves around how deep one's army has entered into enemy territory; the state of relations with neighbors; your psychological condition and that of the enemy; the disparity in overall support available to yourself and your enemy; and what strategic action plans are used under different 'terrain energies.'

¡§The art of war recognizes nine varieties of ground: (1) Dispersive ground; (2) Facile ground; (3) Contentious ground; (4) Open ground; (5) Ground of intersecting highways; (6) Serious ground; (7) Difficult ground; (8) Hemmed-in ground; (9) Desperate ground."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§These are the names of the nine types of terrains."
According to the laws of warfare, there are nine terrain types that strongly impact on the strategy of the fighters:
1) Dispersive ground:

¡§When a chieftain is fighting in his own territory, it is dispersive ground... On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not."

Where does this term, 'dispersive ground' come from?

Why is it used to describe a situation where a leader is fighting on his own territory? Cao Cao comments: ¡§One's soldiers are attached to this ground; the roads are short and it is easy for one's army to disperse." When you fight close to home, your men will slip through your hands and go home if you don't keep control of them. It's easy for your men to lose focus, and if that happens your army can easily collapse. Li Quan comments: ¡§Soldiers long for their home ground and they miss their wives and children; if they become anxious then they will disperse. This is 'dispersive ground.'"

Du Mu comments: ¡§The soldiers being close to their homes, they will not be committed to death in their minds as they advance, and they will be mindful that a place of refuge awaits if they only retreat."

What are the principles for waging war on dispersive ground? Sun Tzu writes: ¡§On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not." Don't get into a fight lightly.

Jia Lin comments: ¡§One must not fight too many times." If you must fight, finish the job in a single move. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§Since it is inadvisable to fight on dispersive ground, one is compelled to hold fast in a defensive position, and to not come out. But what ought I do if my enemy attacks the small towns of my kingdom, if he plunders my fields and forests, if he prevents me from gathering firewood, if he blocks my roads, and if he waits for me to be weakened before launching a rapid strike?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§If the enemy enters deep into your territory, his fighting spirit is concentrated and he will easily engage in combat. Your soldiers are close to their homes, so your battle lines will lack solidity and you will not prevail in battle.

Instead, you should assemble your people and gather up your grain, protect your fortified cities and prepare to hold strategic locations with dangerous terrain; then, dispatch light forces to sever the enemy's supply lines. The enemy will be unable to provoke you into fighting, his supplies will not reach him, he will be unable to plunder the countryside, and his forces will suffer deprivations.

Thus, you may lure him after observing his condition, and you will have a chance to succeed. If you desire to fight in open country, you must base your designs upon the energy of terrain and set ambushes in locations with dangerous terrain. If there is no dangerous terrain, conceal yourself in the shadows and emerge when the enemy does not expect you and strike when he is sluggish."

Raiding parties manned by the peoples of the north repeatedly invaded China throughout the ages, and pretty much any time the marauders breached the Great Wall, the Chinese defenders used the strategy outlined above. The Chinese forces would shrink back and stay inside Beijing's city walls.

The invaders would plunder and loot the surrounding countryside for a while, without much to show for their efforts, until soldiers loyal to the Emperor would coalesce from around China and march towards Beijing. At that point, the invaders would retreat north.

Alternatively, if the Emperor couldn't stand his honor being tarnished, he would inevitably send an army out to fight. This approach typically ended in disaster. During the Ming dynasty's Crisis of Tumu Fortress, Emperor Yingzong personally led an enormous army of 200,000 troops into battle against the Mongol leader, Essen. His army was annihilated at Tumu Fortress, and he was captured alive.

An official named Yu Qian rose to face the crisis, and was given the authority to lead the imperial response. First, he ordered all government officials in Tongzhou to withdraw their salaries and empty all of the grain stores, so they wouldn't fall into Essen's hands. Meanwhile, Essen was scything a path towards Beijing, right up to the base of the city walls. Defending the city was a force of 220,00 men under the personal command of Yu Qian, who had taken up sword and shield to protect Beijing. He inflicted heavy defeats on Essen, first at Desheng Gate and then at Xizhi Gate, and Essen's younger brother was killed in the fighting.

Unable to breach Beijing's walls and with no loot within his reach, the Mongols' morale was low after successive defeats. At the same time, soldiers from all over China were now on their way to save Beijing.

Essen couldn't stay where he was - he was standing on hot coals. So, he broke camp and beat a retreat. Yu Qian came out and pursued him while he was 'sluggish and inclined to return,' hitting him with cannon fire. He roundly beat Essen two more times, once at Gu'an (famous now for the slogan 'Gu'an, 50 km due south from Tiananmen - I love Beijing!'), and once at Bazhou (the 'Hot Spring Town'), and captured eighteen high-ranking Mongol generals. 2) Facile ground:

¡§When he has penetrated into hostile territory, but to no great distance, it is facile ground...

On facile ground, halt not."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is easy for the soldiers to return home."

Li Quan comments: ¡§This is terrain which facilitates retreat."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Having entered no great distance into enemy territory, the road home is short and it is easy to return."

There's not much difference between dispersive ground and facile ground. On dispersive ground, you're practically standing in the doorway of your home; as soon as your men's fighting spirit slips, home is where they'll go.

Meanwhile, on facile ground you're standing in your enemy's doorway, but you're still not far from your own home. Here, the idea of pressing forward is scary; you don't know what dangers lie ahead. But, you know that pulling back is an easy option, and that you'll be safe once you're back in your own country. So, facile ground is also a terrain type where your men's fighting spirit will be weak.

What is there to do about it? ¡§On facile ground, halt not." Don't linger. Du Mu comments: ¡§That which is called 'facile ground' in The Art of War is terrain where one has entered not far past the enemy frontier, before the point where dangerous terrain may be pressing against you from behind; it is terrain where the soldiers' minds are preoccupied with thoughts of returning home, where it is difficult to advance and easy to retreat; it is a place where the most difficult thing is to move deeper in. One must select the best cavalry soldiers at one's disposal and dispatch them in secret to lay an ambush; when enemy soldiers arrive, strike without hesitation; if the enemy soldiers do not come, then quickly depart."

If enemy troops come to you, for them it is dispersive ground, and their fighting spirit will be even weaker than your own!

So, strike immediately. If they don't come, move through quickly - don't linger, and make sure your men drop their anxiety about leaving home as quickly as possible. Make them let go of any wishful thinking they might have about a quick return. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§What is to be done if the soldiers are preoccupied with thoughts of returning home, if it is difficult to advance but easy to retreat, if one does not yet have one's back up against dangerous terrain, and if the minds of one's men are filled with dread?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§When the army is situated on facile ground, the soldiers' minds are not concentrated. Your task is to advance; do not seek battle.

To this end, do not move close to major enemy cities; do not travel by their major transportation routes. Establish decoy units and feign confusion, and give the impression that you are on the verge of departing. Then select an elite group of cavalry soldiers, attack them where they are weak and seize their livestock; when the rest of your forces see this, they will no longer fear moving forward.

Split off some good soldiers from your army and secretly install them in an ambush position; if the enemy comes, strike without hesitation. If the enemy does not come, abandon the ambush position and move onward."

When you've only just crossed the enemy's border, your men haven't yet had a chance to get into a war mentality. This is an extremely frightening situation.

It's best not to fight if you can help it; don't bite off more than you can chew, don't attack any cities, and don't travel along major roads, because they will be guarded by enemy troops. Send out decoy troops to confuse the enemy, and then plunge ahead with elite vanguard units, find easy targets for them, and go looting around the countryside.

When the rest of your men see this, they'll think that you're winning the war! Their spirits will rise, and they won't be frightened anymore. At the same time, split off some of your men and use them to set ambushes.

If the enemy comes, move at once and hit them where it hurts. If they don't come, move onward as quickly as possible; don't wait around. When making plans and coming up with tactics for fighting on facile ground, put into practice three art of war philosophies that we've already learned about: 1) Manage energy; pay attention to your men's psychological state, and engineer a small victory to put some wind in their sails and lend them some courage. 2) Select troops to form a vanguard unit; rank-and-file troops will be scared, so choose some who aren't afraid to be your spearhead.

Give them the task of winning some victories, seizing some loot and drumming up your army's morale. 3) Use the art of division - 'Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.' While your main force rapidly makes its way forward, your vanguard wins some cheap victories by picking easy targets, while another auxiliary force sets an ambush in coordination with your other movements as defense against an enemy attack. How to fight battles in the 'Nine terrain types' (part two): The crucial thing about strength is willpower

What we see when we look at how the art of war applies to dispersive ground, facile ground and contentious ground is that everything revolves around the element of psychology.

It's all about the two sides' relative mental strength, and how each side manages energy. The crucial thing about strength is willpower. Extract from the original text:
¡§Ground the possession of which imports great advantage to either side, is contentious ground... On contentious ground, attack not."

Analysis:
3) Contentious ground:

'Contentious ground' is the kind of terrain that military strategists fight to control and which offers an advantage to whoever seizes possession of it first. As to why, Cao Cao has the answer: ¡§Here the few can defeat the many, and the weak can strike the strong." So, if your enemy gets hold of 'contentious ground,' don't insist on fighting him there.

Li Quan comments: ¡§This is about holding dangerous terrain such as narrow passes and defiles; victory belongs to whoever holds it first; such is 'contentious ground.'" 

Du Mu includes a historical case study in his comment. Before the Battle of Feishui, Fu Jian sent Lu Guang, one of his high-ranking generals, to invade the western regions.

Lu Guang subdued the armed opposition he met there, and returned east with a huge consignment of treasure and other goods. However, by that point Fu Jian had already suffered a catastrophic defeat at the Battle of Feishui.

After Fu Jian's fall, the regional generals of the Former Qin dynasty held total military power, and each one of them had his own ideas about what to do with it. When Lu Guang arrived at Yizhu (present-day Anxinan, in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region), the Former Qin governor of Liang Province, Liang Xi, wanted to seal off his region's roads, and refused to let Lu Guang in. The governor of Gaochang, a man named Yang Han, said to Liang Xi: ¡§Lu Guang is newly returned from his conquest of the western regions; his army is strong and he bears an acutely sharp energy. Now that he has heard of the chaos reigning in the Central Plain, he is sure to have his own designs.

He holds a vast expanse of land west of the river, and his army boasts 100,000 armored warriors; he is well placed to defend himself. And if he chooses to come out from the land of sands, his momentum will be hard to oppose.

There is a location at the entrance to the Gaowu River Valley, a place of narrow and dangerous terrain. We should hold it and thus deprive him of a water source, and thus he will become tired and thirsty, and we will be able to best him even without moving. If you consider the Gaowu Valley to be too far away, then we can also hold him off at Yiwu Pass.

This is a location that must be contended for, because it would offer Guang a great opportunity. If he passes through these two places, even though we have Zifang's stratagem, we will be unable to use it." 

But, Liang Xi refused to take Yang Han's advice. This is precisely the essence of 'contentious ground' - the mouth of the Gaowu River Valley and Yiwu Pass were the two places containing terrain where Lu Guang could have been stopped. When Lu Guang received reports from his spies telling of Yang Han's plan, he was deeply concerned.

But then, his advisor Du Jin told him: ¡§Liang Xi has talent in spades when it comes to the gentle arts, but he lacks pragmatism. He will not listen to Yang Han. For us, the advantage lies in advancing rapidly; we must not delay. I assure you, if Liang Xi does go along with Yang Han's plan, I will cut off my own head and present it to you as a gift."

Just as Du Jin predicted, Liang Xi decided that the Gaowu River Valley and Yiwu Pass were too far away. So, he sent 50,000 men to block the road at Jiuquan.

Meanwhile, Lu Guang's army was rapidly covering the great distance toward the eastern regions. Yang Han was the first regional leader to surrender, followed by the governors of Dunhuang and Jinchang. In the end, Lu Guang captured and beheaded Liang Xi and then established the Empire of Later Liang. We've seen that no army camp is short of wise advisors, but if the lord can't understand what they're telling him, there's nothing to be done. For example, in Han Xin's Battle of Jingxing, his opponent, Chu Yu, refused to listen when his advisor Lord Guangwu suggested blocking off Jingxing Pass.

So, Han Xin defeated the Zhao army, beheaded Chu Yu and took Lord Guangwu prisoner. Han Xin treated Lord Guangwu courteously and told him that if Chu Yu had used his plan, there was no way things would have worked out the way they did. So, Lord Guangwu switched sides and began to work for Han Xin. The same thing happened with Yang Han - when he saw that his superior wasn't going to listen to him or use his plan, he knew that it was over.

He was the first to surrender when Lu Guang's army arrived. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§What should be done if the enemy arrives first, occupies the advantageous terrain, drills his soldiers there, and is able to either come out or hold his position in order to prevent me from effectively using auxiliary forces?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§As regards the methods to be used in contentious ground, the advantage belongs to whoever seizes it first. If the enemy holds contentious ground, be cautious and do not attack.

Draw him out and feign retreat; plant flags and sound your drums, attract his attention using things that are precious to him, drag firewood about to raise up dust clouds, confuse his ears and eyes, and select your best soldiers and secretly set an ambush. The enemy is bound to come out; go to the places towards which he harbors desire and take that which he discards.

This is the art of contentious ground. If you arrive first and the enemy seeks to use this strategy against you, then select your best soldiers and form a light unit to pursue him; meanwhile, hold your original position and establish ambushes in locations with dangerous terrain.

Then, if the enemy returns to fight, your ambush unit will leap forth from the flanks. This is the way to total victory."

Here, Sun Tzu clearly explains how to deal with this situation, from the position of both the attacker and the defender. His principles of fighting on contentious ground were put into practice by Li Shimin - who eventually became Emperor Taizong of Tang - when he defeated Dou Jiande at the Battle of Hulao Pass.

Amidst the pandemonium of the final years of the Sui dynasty, strongmen all over China were running around chasing power. Wang Shichong had occupied the ancient capital of Luoyang and proclaimed himself Emperor of the state of Zheng. Meanwhile, north of the Yellow River, Dou Jiande had proclaimed himself Emperor of the state of Xia. Li Shimin, at the head of over 30,000 Tang troops, surrounded Wang Shichong's Luoyang, and the two sides engaged in vicious combat for eight months. Wang Shichong was relentless, and the conflict left both sides utterly exhausted. It was then that Dou Jiande began to march with a massive army of 100,000 men to rescue Wang Shichong. Dou Jiande was a capable and battle-hardened warrior - even if Li Shimin pulled back and tried to re-gather his forces for another attempt, nobody could blame him. On the other hand, if he left he'd be wasting all the hard work that had so nearly brought Luoyang within his grasp.

Also, if Zheng and Xia joined forces, they'd be able to take the fight deep inside his own territory. And yet, Li Shimin saw a chance to wipe out his two formidable opponents in one fell swoop. It would rely on using an area he'd identified as contentious ground: Hulao Pass. So, Li Shimin left Li Yuanji in command of the siege of Luoyang, while he led a tiny force of 3,500 cavalry on an all-day and all-night journey straight to Hulao Pass. He made it there just before Dou Jiande.

By the time he finished setting up his position, Dou Jiande's forces were only 30 li away. The next day, Li Shimin sprang a small-scale ambush on the Xia army and succeeded in blunting his enemy's momentum. He led 500 cavalry soldiers out of the pass and ordered two officers, Qin Shubao and Cheng Yaojin, to lay an ambush. Meanwhile, he and another officer, Yuchi Jingde, went with only four soldiers to the Xia camp to provoke them.

They lured several thousand enemy cavalry straight into an ambush, crushing the Xia force and capturing two of its senior generals. As we've already mentioned in the sections on 'dispersive' and 'facile' ground, even though on the face of it we're talking about terrain, it's actually all about psychological warfare, or 'managing energy.' You need to manage your own army's energy, but you also need to manage the enemy army's energy. Dou Jiande's army was massive - 100,000 men - and it was bearing down with the momentum of an avalanche.

By comparison, Li Shimin's 30,000-strong Tang army was tiny; it would be difficult for his men not to be deeply nervous about their chances of victory. But, Li Shimin didn't delay for a second. Before the enemy could establish themselves, he swiftly went to the front lines in person, and scored a victory. This boosted his men's morale while shaking that of his enemies.

And that's how Li Shimin held Dou Jiande off. Hulao Pass is a place that can be held by a single warrior against 10,000, and Li Shimin stalled his enemies there for over a month. Occasionally, he would send out a fast-moving force to pick off some of the enemy, and the Xia army was powerless to breach the pass.

Li Shimin's spies fanned out over the land, enabling him to seize opportunities. He also sent a 1,000-strong cavalry force to disrupt the Xia supply route, and in the process they stole all of the Xia grain wagons. Once that happened, the Xia army's situation took a sharp turn for the worse and their morale sank ever lower.

After tormenting his enemy for over a month, Li Shimin decided that he'd done his job. As a smokescreen, he let it be known that the Tang army was going to put its horses out to graze, meaning that his cavalry would be without the use of their mounts. Dou Jiande mobilized his entire army, hoping to use this opportunity to deal with Li Shimin once and for all. At dawn, the Xia army was lined up, but noon came and went and still there was no sign of a battle starting. The soldiers were hungry and tired.

Meanwhile, Li Shimin had re-gathered his war horses and launched a sudden, all-out strike. His 3,500 cavalry troops shattered the 100,000-strong Xia army's lines, and on that day he captured Dou Jiande himself. He put Dou Jiande in a cage on wheels and took him to the foot of the Luoyang city walls, where he shouted for Wang Shichong to come and look: ¡§Your reinforcements are here!" When Wang Shichong saw this, he suffered a total breakdown. He came out from behind his city walls and offered his surrender.

Li Shimin asked Dou Jiande: ¡§What business was it of yours that I was fighting with Wang Shichong? What made you come running from so far away just to skewer yourself on my sword?"

Dou Jiande tried to ingratiate himself: ¡§I just didn't want you to go to the bother of coming all the way to get me, so I delivered myself to you instead." Clearly, his energy was utterly depleted - how could a war hero, a man who called himself Emperor, speak in such a way? So, what we see when we look at how the art of war applies to dispersive ground, facile ground and contentious ground is that everything revolves around the element of psychology.

It's all about the two sides' relative mental strength, and how each side manages energy. The crucial thing about strength is willpower. How to wage war in the 'Nine terrain types' (part three): Ally with 'third parties'
