Analysis:
4) Open ground:

¡§Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is where roads intersect."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Rivers are wide and the ground is level, such that one may come or go at will; it provides adequate conditions to fight a battle."

Du You comments: ¡§Open ground is a place transected by multiple roads; it is impossible to block movement here."

He Shi comments: ¡§Open ground is a flat, navigable plain; one may travel great distances in all four cardinal directions, and it is impossible for movement to be blocked."

Open ground is an area of open space, with no dangerous terrain features and roads that stretch out in all directions. Even without roads, it's possible to travel freely and meet no resistance.

If this is a terrain type you can travel through easily, the same is true for your enemy; nobody can stand in anybody's way here. So, what is the principle of waging war on open ground? Sun Tzu tells us: ¡§On open ground, do not try to allow obstacles to movement."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§One's component parts must be joined to one another." Every part of your forces needs to stay joined up, with no gaps in between. If there are gaps, it's easy for the enemy to split up your forces and either cut off the head of your army or surround you and prevent you from reattaching your head to your body, as it were.

Du Mu comments: ¡§Rivers are wide and the ground is level; battle may be joined from any direction, and so one must combine chariots, cavalry and infantry into a single, connected unit so as to prevent the enemy from severing the parts of your forces and for fear that the enemy will take advantage."

Wang Xi comments: ¡§It is beneficial for grain supply routes. Ground which is expeditious for coming and going can also be referred to as 'easily navigable ground.' Occupy an elevated, sunny location, and await the enemy there.

You should ensure that your grain supply routes are not severed."

It is not a set-in-stone requirement that your army must not be separated. When Sun Tzu says 'on open ground, do not allow severance,' he means that you shouldn't allow your forces to be cut off. He's not saying that you absolutely must keep all parts of your army together, with no separation at all.

For example, to secure your grain supply routes, you will need to send some of your troops out to guard the roads. In order to occupy high, sunny ground, it might also be necessary to split off part of your army and set it up somewhere else, where the terrain enables you to coordinate the different parts of your army into a pincer formation. Taking the initiative to divide your army is not 'severance.' Rather, it requires you to pay attention and not allow gaps to open up between your various units while on the march.

You need to be able to use the different parts of your army as a coordinated whole, keep communication open, and don't give the enemy any openings to exploit. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§If I desire to sever the enemy's forces on open ground and render him unable to move, I must order my frontier cities to prepare their defenses, I must fully sever transportation routes, and I must fortify areas of narrow terrain. But what is to be done if my planning is not timely and the enemy is already prepared, and being prepared, he is able to come to me and I am unable to move, and if our forces are evenly matched in number?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§Since you are unable to move, and since the enemy is able to come, you can take a part of your army and conceal it.

Meanwhile, remain behind your defenses and take your ease, showing yourself to be incapable. When the enemy arrives, set a hidden ambush and spring it such that he is taken by surprise."

5) Ground of intersecting highways:

¡§Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways."

This terrain type is quite simple to understand. 'Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states' just means a place where the borders of three countries meet.

It's a place where, as a Chinese saying puts it, 'Roosters can be heard in three provinces.' The city of Quzhou, in Zhejiang Province, takes it one step further - four provinces share borders there: Fujian, Zhejiang, Jiangxi and Anhui. The city of Quzhou is a transportation and distribution hub for all four provinces, making it a 'super-intersection.' This is also the source of the city's name: the 'Qu' (Åü) in Quzhou means 'intersection.' It has been dubbed 'the four-province intersection and the source of the five roads.'

What is the reasoning behind the next part: ¡§He who occupies it first has the world at his command?" Here, 'the world' stands for the feudal states of ancient China. The parties involved aren't just limited to your country and your enemy's; there's also a third country.

Whoever arrives first can form an alliance with that third country and gain their assistance. Then, the war turns into two against one, increasing your odds of victory. This is why Sun Tzu writes: ¡§He who occupies it first has the world at his command." The strategy to use in this terrain type is to get your diplomacy right; build alliances with other countries. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Your forces being evenly matched with the enemy's, and being situated where neighboring countries converge on three sides, whoever arrives first will acquire the aid of the other country."

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§It being vital to arrive first at ground of intersecting highways, what is to be done if I am unable to arrive first due to the distance to be travelled, and despite driving my chariots and horses forward at high speed?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§States adjoin one another, and they are connected to one another in all directions. Your forces and those of your enemy being equivalent, and if there is another neighboring country, then he who is referred to as 'arriving first' must be he who first sends messengers with a heavy load of treasures to negotiate an accord with that neighboring country.

Having established close ties and favor, then the peoples of the two countries are already linked, even though your army shall arrive later. Thus, you have the support of many people, while the enemy has lost the chance for an alliance; two countries poised either side of the enemy, you then attack amidst a thundering of drums, reducing the enemy to shock and terror and utterly without recourse."

Arriving first doesn't always mean that your army reaches a certain location before the enemy; it's about making sure your envoys get there first. With a generous haul of gifts and all the proper courtesies, you can secure an alliance before your enemy has a chance.

Then, it doesn't matter if your army arrives after the enemy. You attack alongside your new ally, and your enemy is powerless to stop you. This is the true meaning of that line from Chapter Three, Planning Assaults: ¡§Thus the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy's plans; the next best is to attack the enemy's alliances..."

6) Serious ground:

Extract from the original text:

¡§When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground... On serious ground, gather in plunder."

Analysis:

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is terrain from which it is difficult to return." Serious ground is the opposite of facile ground; once you're deep inside serious ground, meaning deep within enemy territory, with a good number of enemy cities already behind you, it becomes very difficult to go back to your home country. Li Quan comments: ¡§These are places of firm resolve." When it's difficult to go back the way you came, you give up on the idea of going home and stop thinking about it altogether.

Your mind becomes focused, and your willpower grows steady and strong. Two examples of 'entering deep into serious ground' are Bai Qi's invasion of the state of Chu and Yue Yi's invasion of the state of Qi.

What should you do if you find yourself in serious ground? ¡§Gather in plunder." Steal what you can; seize grain and other supplies, because you're already beyond the reach of resupply missions from your own country. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§Suppose I have drawn my army deep into serious terrain and I have travelled through much enemy territory, and my grain supply routes have been severed. I desire to return to my country, but I am constrained by circumstances; what should I do that I may eat my enemy's food and maintain my army without suffering loss?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§Whenever you are situated in serious terrain, your soldiers are easily emboldened. If your transportation routes are impeded, then you can secure food supplies by plundering.

Soldiers who acquire grain and fine goods must deliver their plunder in its entirety to their superiors; those who render the largest quantity shall be rewarded, and thus your soldiers will have no thoughts of returning home. If you truly desire to return to your country, then make defensive preparations; dig deep trenches and erect high walls to show the enemy that you intend to stay for a long time.

Thus, the enemy will suspect that some other transportation route remains open to you, and so he will secretly remove his soldiers from the main roads. Then, order your light chariots to move swiftly and silently. Use your oxen and horses as bait, and if the enemy comes, sound your drums and pursue him.

Having concealed your soldiers in ambush, when the enemy triggers the ambush, attack from two sides at once. If you do this, the enemy's defeat is certain."

When you're deep inside 'serious' enemy terrain, the most important thing is that you take supplies from your enemy.

However, your enemy will also be aware of this principle and might burn everything rather than leave anything for you. When Napoleon fought his way into Moscow, if the city had been full of supplies and comfortable living quarters, he could have stayed there and waited for the Tsar to surrender. But, the Russians burned Moscow down with a single torch.

The French army tried to put out the fire, but they found that all of the city's fire-fighting equipment had been sabotaged. In the trajectory of Napoleon's fall, the Great Fire of Moscow was a major turning point. How to wage war in the 'Nine terrain types' (part four): Move rapidly through dangerous terrain

Extract from the original text:
¡§Mountain forests, rugged steeps, marshes and fens - all country that is hard to traverse: this is difficult ground.

(... in difficult ground, keep steadily on the march.)"

Analysis:
7) Difficult ground:

Jia Lin comments: ¡§Passing through terrain ravaged by water - this is called 'difficult ground.'"

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about places with few solid features."

He Shi comments: ¡§'Difficult ground' refers to places with few solid features, where it is not possible to build fortified walls or dig deep moats; one should make haste to leave such places behind."

What's the right thing to do in difficult ground? ¡§In difficult ground, keep steadily on the march." With nothing but water-logged ground beneath you, these are places where it's impossible to secure yourself, and impossible to build fortifications or any other construction works.

You can't camp there either; all you can do is make your way through this terrain as quickly as possible. Don't stop. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§Suppose I have entered difficult ground, where I am faced with mountains, rivers, and all manner of dangerous and obstructive terrain, such that the road is hard to follow, my soldiers are exhausted by long days of marching, the enemy is at once ahead of me, lying in ambush behind me, encamped to my left, holding another defensive position to my right, and blocking my narrow way forward with strong horses and fast chariots. What am I to do?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§First, move your light chariots ten li ahead of your army and order them to await the enemy there, and engage the enemy in battle in a place of dangerous and obstructive terrain.

At the rear, spread out your soldiers and move now to the left, now to the right; the general must keep watch in all directions and identify a weakness in the enemy position, following which all parts of the army must converge in a suitable location.

Once your soldiers become exhausted, then stop."

Once your men are exhausted, stop attacking, secure your position and re-gather your army. This is important, because moving over difficult ground is a painstaking task and it consumes a lot of energy.

It's necessary to conserve your men's strength. How to wage war in the 'Nine terrain types' (part five): To break out of an encirclement, rely on cunning

Extract from the original text:
¡§Ground which is reached through narrow gorges, and from which we can only retire by tortuous paths so that a small number of the enemy would suffice to crush a large body of our men: this is hemmed-in ground. (...

on-hemmed in ground, resort to stratagem.)"

Analysis:
8) Hemmed-in ground:

Here, we're talking about being 'hemmed in,' or surrounded, not by enemy forces but by terrain - narrow roadways and places where the only way back is to travel long, twisting routes. If you get stuck in this kind of terrain, the enemy can beat you even with a small number of troops. This is what we mean when we talk about 'hemmed-in ground.'

Li Quan comments: ¡§Here it is difficult to move."

Du Mu comments: ¡§It is difficult both to enter such places and to exit them."

It's not just that these places are hard to get into; once you're in you can't get out, nor can you spread out your forces to fight. So, what are you supposed to do?

Sun Tzu's advice is this: ¡§On hemmed-in ground, resort to stratagem." In other words, you have to work it out yourself! Clearly, there really isn't much you can do. Unless you come up with some clever plan, you'll never be able to get out. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§Suppose I have entered into hemmed-in ground; before me the enemy awaits in strength and behind me I am backed against dangerous terrain; the enemy has severed my grain supply routes, is enticing me to retreat, and is sounding war drums, yet without advancing, to watch what my response will be. What should I do?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§This is what should be done in hemmed-in ground: you must obstruct access to your location and make it seem as though you plan to stay there; then you ought to treat your army like your family, and make the hearts of your men of one accord. Then, cook food enough for several days; in the following days, the enemy will believe we are weak and in tumult, because they will see no smoke where are cooking fires should be.

Believing this, the enemy is sure to slacken their preparedness; then, fan the flames of your soldier's passions, rouse their fury, send forward a unit of your strongest men, and making use of the treacherous terrain to left and right, charge at the enemy to the beat of war drums.

If the enemy tries to stop you, attack with rapid fury and you will be sure to break through the encirclement. Then, while your forward troops give battle, their gains shall be expanded upon by your rear troops, with left and right units working in unison, pinching the enemy between them."

First, make sure the enemy can't attack your position, and make it look like you have no intention of trying to smash your way out. Show everyone, your enemy and your own men, that you're determined and that you won't back down.

This will make your troops 'feel at home,' as it were. It will encourage them to think of the army as their family, and to think with one mind. Then, you can guard against the enemy with peace of mind.

Cook all the food you'll need for several days in one go, and then don't cook for the next few days - this will make the enemy think you have nothing to eat. Make it look like you're in bad shape. As a reference point, look at this passage from Chapter Nine, in The Army on the March: ¡§When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food.

If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst... If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary. The sight of men whispering earnestly without ceasing or speaking in subdued tones points to disaffection amongst the rank and file..." You can act out all of these diversionary tactics and put on a nice show for the enemy scouts. The enemy will believe you're on your last legs, and that the fruits of victory will soon be theirs.

They'll relax and let down their guard. This is the moment for you to call your whole army before you and prepare them to fight a decisive battle. Whip them up into a state of excitement and fury, and send out your best soldiers to charge the enemy in a sudden burst, all the while making use of the tricky terrain.

If the enemy puts up a fight, move in hard and attack - they won't be able to stop you from breaking through. While your vanguard fights at the front lines, your rear units will capitalize on the vanguard's gains.

With your entire army mobilized and working in close coordination, you can quickly take down the enemy. The King of Wu had another question for Sun Tzu: ¡§If I have hemmed in my enemy and he conceals himself so as to plot and scheme; if he entices me and orders his flag bearers to wave them here and there in imitation of chaos, such that it is impossible to know in which direction he will move, what should I do?"

This is just the opposite of the first situation the king asked about. Sun Tzu said: ¡§Send forth a thousand men waving flags.

Meanwhile, block off the main transport route using a separate detachment of soldiers, and send a mobile unit towards the enemy to provoke him. Reserve the bulk of your army and maintain formation; do not engage them in fighting and keep them steady.

Do not retreat. This is the way to thwart the enemy's plans."

Keep your main force in position and steady. Don't charge after the enemy, and don't retreat. Keep doing this, and watch what the enemy is trying to do; then you can work out what his plan is. Staying alive in 'desperate ground' ¡V Nine times in ten, you're dead

What you need to learn is how to stay away from 'desperate ground.' Once you're in such a place, you can't chase after life; you have to chase after certain death. But, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into the jaws of death, and manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up to annihilation.

High stakes risk-taking is not something to draw lessons from. If you're forced into it, you'll find out how strong your life force really is. That's all. Extract from the original text:
¡§Ground on which we can only be saved from destruction by fighting without delay, is desperate ground.

(... on desperate ground, fight.)"

Analysis:
9) Desperate ground:

What's the difference between 'difficult ground' and 'desperate ground?' On 'difficult ground,' you can wait, but there's no waiting on 'desperate ground.' So, what can you do? ¡§On desperate ground, fight." Fight immediately, because if you fight quickly you may live, but if you're not quick you're going to die."

This is a vitally important point to make because, in most situations, waiting is in fact a viable option. But, if the leader thinks they can't wait, and that fighting at speed might save them - and not doing so will lead to death - they end up walking into their own death for no good reason. In reality, it's not guaranteed that fighting quickly when you're on desperate ground is a foolproof way to survive. If it was, it wouldn't be called 'desperate ground' in the first place; it'd be called 'be-quick-and-you'll-live ground.' In 'desperate ground' the outcome is practically guaranteed to be death. There's no hope of survival.

That's why you shouldn't chase after life. However, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into death, and if you manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up their lives! In other words, it's time to fight as though you're already dead.

When an army does this, they become possessed of a power terrible to behold. And what do our commentators have to say about 'desperate ground?'

Cao Cao comments: ¡§High mountains ahead, great bodies of water behind; the road ahead is fruitless, the road behind is obstructed."

Li Quan comments: ¡§Blocked by mountains, backing onto water, food has run out. In this situation, speed is beneficial, slowness is not."

Duke Li of Wei offers a more complete commentary: ¡§Perhaps one has advanced with one's forces and, lacking a guide, plunges into danger and defeat and becomes constrained by the enemy.

With a chasm to the left and cliffs to the right, one travels a road where horses must be led by hand and cart wheels hang into the void on one side; the way is blocked ahead and behind, rocks and cliffs over which one passes like a column of wild geese or fish on a line.

One's battle lines are disorganized; if the enemy comes at speed and in strength, there is no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon. One cannot fight even if one desires to, and there is no safety in guarding one's position.

The days will be long if one stays still, and if one moves, then the enemy will be waiting in any direction one may choose. In this wilderness there is no drinking water or grass, the army lacks grain and supplies, the horses are weary and the men exhausted, one's resourcefulness is depleted and one's strength has reached its limits. When one man guards a narrow defile, ten thousand men cannot pass through.

If the enemy has occupied such a location, then he possesses so great an advantage that one has already lost. Though one may have talented soldiers and sharp weapons, how can they be put to use? In 'desperate ground' such as this, one may survive by fighting quickly; if one fails to fight quickly, death awaits. One must unify the hearts and minds of the various ranks within one's army so that they become a single force, pull out one's intestines and splash one's blood, charge forward toward death, glory in defeat, and transform disaster into a great good fortune."

Duke Li's discourse on 'desperate ground' can be divided into commentaries about seven distinct situations:

1) ¡§Perhaps one has advanced with one's forces and, lacking a guide, plunges into danger and defeat and becomes constrained by the enemy."

You didn't bother finding a local person to guide you as you moved your army forward. You plunged blindly ahead, got lost, and found yourself in a deep hole, in danger and at the mercy of the enemy.

So, the main point to learn when studying 'desperate ground' isn't how to fight in this kind of terrain, but how to avoid being forced into such a desperate situation in the first place. The first point Duke Li makes is the vital importance of studying the maps and being totally clear about the lay of the land. Also, you absolutely must use a guide while on the march, because this is the only way to avoid trapping yourself in 'desperate ground.' Throughout Chinese history, renowned generals have always memorized maps inside out, and made a point of studying maps whenever they had a spare moment. When Liu Bang came through the mountain pass as a conqueror into the land of Qin, he didn't steal the beautiful women or the riches of Qin.

Instead, his strategist Xiao He headed straight for the Qin archive library and gathered up all the maps he found there. The People's Liberation Army commanders Lin Biao and Su Yu used to sit in daylong trances before tables-full of maps, whether or not they were at war at the time.

In their minds, great armies were constantly maneuvering back and forth across those maps. 2) ¡§With a chasm to the left and cliffs to the right, one travels a road where horses must be led by hand and cart wheels hang into the void on one side."

The enemy doesn't even need to attack at this point. All they have to do is crowd you, and your whole army will plunge into the void. 3) ¡§The way is blocked ahead and behind, rocks and cliffs over which one passes like a column of wild geese or fish on a line."

There's no road open to you either ahead or behind. All you can do is move single-file along the edge of steep cliffs. 4) ¡§One's battle lines are disorganized; if the enemy comes at speed and in strength, there is no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon."

You've only just arrived at the battlefield, you haven't had a chance to organize your battle lines, you haven't built any defensive structures, you haven't had time to form up your soldiers, and already the enemy is charging towards you. If you advance to meet them, your army will be uncoordinated and unable to muster any kind of striking force; if you retreat, there's nowhere for you to shelter, and your army will disintegrate.

What to do in this situation? This has already been covered in an earlier section of Sun Tzu's The Art of War: victory belongs to whoever arrives first. The key is to be there waiting for the enemy. In this situation, your enemy is well prepared, while you've showed up in total disarray and are completely unable to organize yourself. So, the battle is basically lost already, and there's nothing you can do except get ready for a messy scrap - find out what your men are made of, and see whether their training has equipped them to fight, kill, and somehow carve out the slenderest hope of survival from the chaos. If you get out alive, remember the next time to get to the battlefield first and be properly prepared.

If the enemy gets there before you, don't go. Set up camp 30-50 li away, form up your battle lines and coax the enemy to you. Then, the enemy will be the one whose 'battle lines are disorganized,' and they'll have 'no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon if the enemy comes at speed and in strength.' This is exactly how General Zhao She defeated the Qin army: he set up a defensive position 50 li away from the enemy camp and lured the enemy to him, compelling them to march the extra 50 li and tire themselves out. 5) ¡§One cannot fight even if one desires to, and there is no safety in guarding one's position.

The days will be long if one stays still, and if one moves then the enemy will be waiting in any direction one may choose."

Even if you try to make a fight happen, you won't be able to reach the enemy. And, if you try to stay put and defend, you'll find no terrain features to secure your position. If you hunker down, the days will drag past slowly and your situation won't get any better.

If you try to take action, you'll be hemmed in by the enemy in both directions, and you'll be completely unable to move. 6) ¡§In this wilderness there is no drinking water or grass, the army lacks grain and supplies, the horses are weary and the men exhausted, one's resourcefulness is depleted and one's strength has reached its limits."

Suppose you're in the Gobi Desert, and there's no water for your men and no grass for your horses. Your army has no food and everyone's exhausted, men and horses both.

Your men's strength is being pushed to its limits, there's no way out, and no actionable plan. 7) ¡§When one man guards a narrow defile, ten thousand men cannot pass through. If the enemy has occupied such a location, then he possesses so great an advantage that one has already lost. Though one may have talented soldiers and sharp weapons, how can they be put to use?"

If your enemy holds a position where one man could hold off 10,000, the rope is already around your neck. No matter how strong your men are or how sharp your weapons, you won't be able to put them to use.

In any of these seven situations, if you attack quickly, survival is a possibility. If you don't, you'll die. You need to make everyone in your army, officers and rank-and-file soldiers alike, into a single mind. They need to be ready and willing to spill their own blood and march to their death; they need to find glory in their predicament and find something good in a hopeless situation. The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: ¡§Suppose my army has departed the borders of my country and travelled into enemy lands.

The enemy has arrived in force and encircled me in many rings around. I wish to break through the encirclement, but I face an impregnable barrier in all directions. I desire to encourage my soldiers and rouse their spirits so that they are willing to forfeit their lives and break the enemy encirclement. How can I do this?"

Sun Tzu replied: ¡§Dig deep trenches and build high walls, creating the impression that you intend to take a defensive bearing. Remain calmly in place and do not move, thus concealing your capabilities.

Inform your soldiers that the situation is desperate, that there is but one option before you. Slaughter your oxen and burn your carts, so as to provide a feast for your men. Burn your grain, fill in your wells, level your cooking ranges, cut your hair and cast aside your hats, thus severing yourself from care about whether you live. The men will see that their general has no other plan, and so they will steel themselves to death.

Then, don armor and take up your swords and mould your army into a single force. Attack both of the enemy flanks amid the clamor and thunder of war drums; the enemy will be scared and will not know what they should do.

Divide your best soldiers among the ranks and launch a fierce attack to the enemy's rear. This is how to abandon morality and seek life. Thus, it is said, 'He who is in a desperate plight and yet does not make a plan is lost; he who is lost and yet does not fight is dead.'"

There are many rituals described here, all designed to unleash your men's inner fury and savagery. Once you've whipped your men up and mentally prepared them for certain death, then is the time to charge the enemy.

If you find yourself in 'desperate ground,' you're going to die nine times out of ten. When the odds of survival are so low, there's nothing to be learned from this situation. What you need to learn is how to stay away from 'desperate ground.' Once you're in 'desperate ground,' you can't chase after life; you have to chase after certain death.

But, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into death's door and if you manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up. In the South Korean film, The Battle of Myeongyang, the Korean troops and officers were terrified by the power of the invading Japanese army, and one after another they came before the commander-in-chief, Yi Sun-sin, and asked him what they were going to do. Li Sun-sin's reply was brief: ¡§Are you telling me you still want to live?

Tomorrow we shall all go to our deaths!" Surviving when you're in desperate ground isn't about learning how to survive; it's about learning how to accept death! High stakes risk-taking is not something to draw lessons from - if you're forced into it, you'll find out how strong your life force really is.

That's all. Don't, whatever you do, try to copy what Han Xin did, leading his men to the edge of a river and forming up for battle with their backs to the deep water. As you'll recall, that was only part of the story; he also had 2,000 men waiting behind, ready to help out.

He was never really in 'desperate ground,' he only made it look like he was. It was a fake. If those 10,000 men backed up against the river really had been his whole army - if he had no other forces to call upon, and yet those 10,000 somehow managed to survive - only then could you say that he had gone into desperate ground and come out on the other side alive! People are fond of exaggerating and adding flavor to details.

That's what gives stories their dramatic tension, and everyone likes a bit of drama, including those who write the official histories, which also contain a good amount of seasoning. But facts are as cold as ice. So, when we read history, we mustn't fall into the traps that our innate fondness for drama sets out for us; we must not think that you can reenact the battles we read about, move for move.

You'll find that if you try this, the script that reality plays from isn't what you imagined. This is the real script: everyone who goes into 'desperate ground' dies. That's why it's called 'desperate ground.'

The King of Wu asked Sun Tzu: ¡§If I have surrounded the enemy, what should I do?"
Sun Tzu replied: ¡§Where the cliffs are steep and the ravine is perilous, such that the terrain is impassible, then it may be said that the enemy is cornered. This is how to strike: conceal soldiers in ambush, open a way for the enemy to exit his confinement; show him a way out.

As he flees for his life, he will have no appetite for battle, and thus you can attack. Even if his soldiers are numerous, your victory is certain."
According to The Art of War: ¡§If the enemy is in desperate ground, his soldiers will be filled with courage. The way to attack such an enemy is to use smoothness, and not to pit strength against strength.

You may gain advantage by secretly establishing a secure position. Then, you must open a path for the enemy while blocking the road in various places with elite cavalry soldiers in various positions. Send fast soldiers to draw him out, form up as if to fight, but do not engage.

This is the way to scheme the enemy's defeat."
Don't keep the enemy totally surrounded. It's necessary to give him an escape route; you have to make him run. If the enemy's men think they might live, they won't want to die and their will to fight will weaken.

Their minds will be filled with thoughts of escaping death. Set up ambushes along the road, manned by your best troops, and each time the enemy triggers an ambush, you can eat away at his forces. Then, chase down the remainder.

This is not only a way to guarantee total victory, it also guarantees that your army won't suffer any losses. Suppose you have surrounded 1,000 enemy soldiers. If you keep up a watertight encirclement, you can be sure of killing every single enemy soldier, but at a cost of perhaps 800 of your own men, because the enemy will be fighting like cornered animals. But, if you give them an escape route and stage your attacks at various points along the road, although 20 enemy soldiers might get away, you can limit your own casualties to ten soldiers or less. The artistry of commanding an army as battle breaks Out ¡V First and foremost, harass the enemy

Extract from the original text:
¡§Those who were called skillful leaders of old knew how to drive a wedge between the enemy's front and rear; to prevent cooperation between his large and small divisions; to hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men. When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy's men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting.

When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still. If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will."

Analysis:
The most effective battle commanders of ancient China all kept these skills in their arsenal. They knew how to ¡§Drive a wedge between the enemy's front and rear..."
The best generals had the ability to separate the front and rear parts of the enemy army and stop them from helping each other or coordinating. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Establish an ambush, then charge and slaughter." Set up an auxiliary force in an ambush position and use them to charge the enemy, scattering their troops and breaking up the links between different parts of their army.

¡§Prevent cooperation between his large and small divisions..."
Prevent the enemy's main force and their smaller forces from backing each other up. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§This is about harassing the enemy."

¡§Hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men."
This is about stopping the enemy's officers and rank-and-file from helping each other; it's a way of sowing confusion in the ranks, spreading panic and breaking down the enemy's organizational structures. ¡§When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy's men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting."

Keep the enemy soldiers scattered.

If they are already gathered together, make it impossible for them to form up in an orderly formation. Du Mu comments: ¡§Employ varied and numerous deceits to harass the enemy; you may charge his front lines and slaughter his rear units, or launch a surprise attack in the east before striking from the west, or array your soldiers in a false formation, or unveil an irregular formation. If I join battle with my soldiers in shapeless formation, the enemy must make preparations to counter all possibilities, and so the great host of his army becomes divided.

I fill his thoughts with fear and disperse his forces; his officers and soldiers are panicked and harassed so that they are unable to unite in an orderly fashion. This is the way skillful generals conduct battles."
An army is only an army if it's organized. Without organizational structures, even if you have a million men, your army might as well be a massive flock of lambs awaiting slaughter. The artistry of directing the flow of a battle is all about disrupting the enemy's organization. Any time in history when a small army has defeated a large one, it's always been because the leaders of the larger army either lacked the ability to organize their men, or their chain of command broke down.

¡§When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still."

If you can manufacture a situation that favors your army, take action; if you can't, don't move. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Use violence to scatter them, use chaos to make them unable to organize themselves, then mobilize and engage."
Li Quan comments: ¡§Harass them until an opportunity becomes apparent, then take action. If they do not move, then be still."

¡§If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will."

The first item on the agenda when you're trying to control the course of a battle is to harass and disrupt the enemy.

But, if they keep their shape, and if they have more soldiers than you and begin advancing toward you in neat formation, what should you do? Seize something the enemy holds dear. Cao Cao comments: ¡§First, seize an advantage upon which he relies. If I arrive first upon favourable ground and occupy it, then I am sure to gain what I desire."

Cao Cao is saying that 'what the enemy holds dear' is the favourable conditions he's counting on to win. If you hold the best ground, you've seized the initiative.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§That which the enemy holds dear is territory and food; if I seize these things first, then circumstances will in no way proceed counter to my plans."
If you hold the territory and the food supplies, the enemy will dissolve in panic and chaos; they'll be completely unable to muster the courage and energy to take the fight to you. In the case of Li Shimin defeating Dou Jiande, which we learned about earlier, 3,500 men under Li Shimin took possession of Hulao Pass and successfully kept out Dou Jiande's 100,000-strong army.

Then, Li found a way to wipe out Dou Jiande's grain supply units and steal all his food. Once that had happened, it was only natural that Dou Jiande lost. It takes years to raise an army, but only a moment to use it

Extract from the original text:
¡§Rapidity is the essence of war: take advantage of the enemy's unreadiness, make your way by unexpected routes, and attack unguarded spots.

The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you.

Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food. Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans. Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight.

If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength. Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear. If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm.

If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard. Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted. Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts.

Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared. If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity.

On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks. But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Chu or a Gui."

Analysis:
¡§The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you."

Having penetrated into enemy territory, you are already deep in 'serious ground.' At this point, your soldiers won't even think about running away. Their minds will be focused, and they will fight with everything they have.

The reason why the enemy can't beat you is that while you're in 'serious ground,' and the enemy is in 'dispersive ground.' As we've already said, dispersive ground is no place to fight. So, the enemy's will to fight won't be as strong as yours.

Du Mu comments: ¡§This passage comments on the art of attacking in general. If you have entered deep within enemy lands, your soldiers will have the conviction to die and their minds will be focused. The defending enemy will be unable to defeat you."

¡§Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food."

This aligns with passages from earlier in the text: ¡§On serious ground, gather in plunder... procure your food from the enemy." If you do this, all your men and horses will stay well fed.

¡§Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans."

Make sure to keep your soldiers well rested and fit. Keep their energy sharp and their strength focused.

Use deception and schemes whenever you move your army, so that the enemy can't work out what you're doing. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Nurture your soldiers and keep your army's energy unified. When you move your army, plan it in such a way as to be inscrutable to the enemy."
Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about what to do when one plunges deep into enemy territory.

One must plunder the countryside to keep one's army sufficiently supplied with food. Then, enclose oneself behind walls and nurture one's army. Do not exhaust them with labor, but maintain their full strength and energy so that one may obtain victory immediately upon taking action. When one moves, use variety so that the enemy is unable to take one's measure."
When Wang Jian destroyed the state of Chu, he did it by using this exact approach. He set out with 600,000 Qin soldiers on a mission to annihilate Chu.

When he arrived, he set up camp, built fortifications and dug moats, and then concentrated on looking after his men and keeping them sharp. Day after day, all he did was organize athletic competitions, getting his troops to compete at games such as rock throwing. When the Chu forces tried to provoke Wang into fighting, he just stayed secure behind his defenses and refused to come out. The massive size of the Qin army scared the Chu leaders out of trying to attack them in their camp. Time went by, and eventually a year passed without any change in the situation.

The Chu soldiers were tired and stiff after a year of waiting and being constantly on alert. So, they began to roam the area to get some exercise, and as soon as they moved from their position, Wang Jian pounced, ending the war in a single, bloody battle. Afterwards, the state of Chu ceased to exist. ¡§Nurture your soldiers and keep your army's energy unified." There's actually a huge amount of information contained in this brief line of commentary by Cao Cao. When people look at wars, they always concentrate on the actual fighting.

And yet, the fighting is only one part of war, and as we've said again ad again, it's not the most important part. Sun Tzu said: ¡§Win first, fight later." By the time fighting starts, it's only happening because victory has already been sealed. It's a case of 'beating them and then fighting,' not 'beating them by fighting them.' The secret of warfare lies in what conditions you need to meet, and what conditions you need to identify in the enemy, that give you the signal to launch your attack. When Zeng Guofan was in charge of the Hunan army, he didn't have many clever stratagems or tricks.

What he did have was a steady, grounded attitude. This gave him staying power. He always consolidated his advantages. In his diary, the things he paid attention to during drawn-out stays in camp while besieging enemy towns were details like whether there was enough meat and whether there were any vegetables. Eventually, he decreed that every time his army set up a new camp, they must plant crops and breed pigs.

This way, he'd have fresh vegetables and meat; he'd be living right, and his men would have some physical work to keep them fit and their energy sharp. There's a saying: 'It takes years to raise an army, but only a moment to use it.' Normally, this phrase is used to remind soldiers that the state is looking after them, so when the time comes to take to the battlefield, they'd better repay their debt to the motherland.

But, this isn't what the phrase originally meant. It comes from the ancient text, The History of the Southern Dynasties, in a chapter entitled, A Biography of Chen Xuan: ¡§One may keep an army for a thousand days without using it, but one may not keep an army for a single day without being properly prepared."
There are three layers of meaning in these words. First, it's possible to keep an army for years.

If you carefully look after your men and don't work them too hard, you can build up their strength and mould their energy into a single force, and you can maintain it without ever using it. But, the moment you do use it, it evaporates.

Second, you use an army for only a very short period of time. So, it's important to wait until the crucial moment, when the enemy is unprepared, caught off-guard, and not expecting you. Then, fling your army from your hand and strike like lightning; only if you do this can you guarantee victory. It's like when two people are in a knife fight - before you lunge, while the knife is in your hand and ready for use, you still have all your energy at your disposal.

If you lunge, but your knife doesn't find your opponent's body, in the moment before you pull your knife back you've left the door wide open for your opponent. You have no energy to call upon and you're in a state of almost total defenselessness.

If your opponent seizes his chance, you're finished. The power of a knife comes from the moment before you lunge with it. If you do lunge, it's imperative that you get a result. If you don't, your enemy will, and in all likelihood you'll be dead.

The third layer of meaning has already been discussed in the previous section: you have to be constantly ready to defend. You can't let your guard down for a single second. If you do, the enemy will serve you up on a plate. ¡§Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight."

If you bring your men into a place where there's no way out, they'll naturally be mentally prepared to die in battle, and they won't run away. After all, there's nowhere to run anyway.

¡§If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The soldiers being willing to die, how could they fail to be victorious?"

¡§Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength." 

Facing death, they don't have any choice but to fight with all their strength. Cao Cao comments: ¡§In challenging terrain, their hearts are united." It's critically important for your men to pool their strength and make their thinking as one. There's a passage in the Wei Liaozi that reads: ¡§When a single brigand takes up a sword and takes to hacking all around him in a market, though there are ten thousand people there, every one of them will shrink away from him, and not a single one will have the courage to fight him alone, because all ten thousand people are unworthy.

One who has committed himself to death can never be compared to one who has committed himself to life."
The man with the sword is ready to die, but everyone else wants to live. He is a true terrorist, in the sense that everyone else is terrified of him.

¡§Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear."

When people find themselves in desperate peril, they accept that death is inevitable, and so they no longer fear the enemy. They are already dead, so what is there to be scared of?

There's nothing scarier than death, is there? ¡§If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm. If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§They are bound and trussed." They're trapped. There's a Chinese saying: 'Grasshoppers tied together on a length of string.' When an army comes to a dead end deep in enemy territory, it's as if they're bound together with rope - they must fight like cornered animals, and they must fight as a single unit. Du Mu comments: ¡§If there is no help, then the men will all suspect that they have already entered the land of death and that survival is impossible.

They will resolve to fight death with death. There being utterly no help available, each and every man will fight with all their strength."
'Fight death with death' - these four words are crucial. It's not about fighting desperately against death in the hope of living.

The moment the idea of survival occurs, it becomes much more difficult to fight against death, because you might surrender or try to run away. But, if survival isn't even a possibility in your mind, your mindset will be: 'I might as well take some enemy soldiers with me, since I'm going to die anyway.' This is the only way to truly keep the possibility of survival alive. ¡§Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted."

When you have an army like this, you don't need to keep them in line or order them around. The men will know without you telling them to stay vigilant.

Without the officers making any demands of them, they'll be able to fight with all their strength. Without any boundaries being set or any encouragement given, they'll be so intimate with each other that they'll form the most united of fronts.

When you have an army like this, you won't need to repeat your orders again and again, because they'll keep their discipline anyway. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Everyone is crammed together on the same boat."
This passage forms the root of a saying that has entered the Chinese language as a 'four-character idiom' - 'Wu and Yue on the same boat.' During the Spring and Autumn period, the states of Wu and Yue were bitter rivals; they had been fighting for generations. One day, a group of common folk from both countries were crossing a river on the same boat.

They sat there, shooting hostile looks at each other, when suddenly the weather turned bad just as the boat reached the middle of the river. Strong wind and heavy rain sprang up from nowhere, and it seemed as though the boat was about to capsize.

The only thing to do was to climb the mast and unfurl the sails. Suddenly, everyone on the boat, Wu and Yue alike, moved as quickly as they could. Working together, they managed to unfurl the sail, and the day was saved.

On stormy waters, everyone's in the same boat; enemies can turn into family. You don't need to preach the message that 'unity is strength,' because circumstances force people to put it into action. ¡§Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts.

Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared."

Forbid all superstitious activities and clear up your men's deluded doubts. Do this, and they will fight to the death and never run away. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Forbidding all talk of omens and sorcery is the stratagem for dispelling doubt."
Du Mu comments: ¡§Lord Huang Shi said: 'Forbid fortune-telling and wish-making in order that your officers and soldiers do not divine the fortunes, good or ill, of your army. Fear disturbs the mentality of soldiers.' Lord Huang meant that if one dispels doubt, then one's soldiers will fight unto death without being distracted by other thoughts." 
Of course, there are examples in which the opposite happened - when generals cast themselves in the role of gods or wizards and prophesied that the army would enjoy great good fortune, all in an effort to spur on their men to fight bravely.

That's exactly what General Tian Dan did while defending the city of Jimo. He had one of his men dress up as an immortal and then brought him out and treated him like a deity, with all the respect and ceremony that's proper when dealing with divine beings.

He waited hand and foot upon the man, and every time he gave an order, he would always say that it was the will of the immortal. ¡§If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity."

The reason 'our soldiers are not overburdened with money' is because they have to choose between money and their lives.

They don't fear death, either, but that's not because they don't want to live to 'a good old age.' Rather, it's because if they don't fight without fear of dying, they have no chance of surviving the war. Cao Cao comments: ¡§If they all burn their riches, it is not that they loathe being overburdened with them; they abandon their riches and draw close to death because there is no other choice."
Du Mu comments: ¡§If they have wealth, then sadly the soldiers will feel attached to it and the idea will occur to them that they ought to cling to life. They might not have the conviction to meet with death."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Wealth and long life are things that people hold dear. So, when people burn and discard riches and cut themselves free from the prospect of long life, it is not because these things are loathsome to them, but that they have no choice."

¡§On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks. But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Zhu or a Gui."

In war, it's generally true that when you give marching orders, there are men who will weep.

But, if you put them in a place where there's nowhere to go except forward, each and every one of them will become as brave as the legendary heroes Zhu Zhuan and Cao Gui. Just how brave was Zhu Zhuan?

When Duke Guang of Wu (who later became King Helu of Wu) ordered him to assassinate King Liao of Wu, he accepted the mission. Duke Guang invited King Liao to his house to eat with him. Zhu Zhuan brought dishes to the table, among which was a whole cooked fish with a dagger concealed in its belly. When Zhu Zhuan pulled out the dagger and leapt toward King Liao, he was immediately impaled from behind by a spear wielded by the king's bodyguard. And yet, with his last breath he managed to stab the king, and the blow was fatal.

What about Cao Gui? What made him brave? He was a senior official in the state of Lu, and in a previous chapter we discussed his role in the Battle of Changshao. It was he who came up with 'The strategy of three rounds of drumming.' Recall that the first round of drumming builds up soldiers' energy; in the second round, the enemy's energy begins to deflate; and in the third round, the enemy soldiers enter a state of rest. He was there with Duke Zhuang of Lu during his conference with Duke Huan of Qi at Dong'e, and it was he who pulled out a dagger and seized Duke Huan, putting him in a position to secure an alliance treaty that restored Lu's lost lands.

If you tie everyone to a war chariot, nobody can get off

Extract from the original text:
¡§The skillful tactician may be likened to the shuairan. Now, the shuairan is a snake that is found in the Chang Mountains.

Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail; strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head; strike at its middle, and you will be attacked by head and tail both. Asked if an army can be made to imitate the shuairan, I should answer, 'Yes.' For the men of Wu and the men of Yue are enemies; yet if they are crossing a river in the same boat and are caught by a storm, they will come to each other's assistance just as the left hand helps the right. Hence it is not enough to put one's trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground.

The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach. How to make the best of both strong and weak? That is a question involving the proper use of ground. Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand."

Analysis:
¡§Hence it is not enough to put one's trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground."
'Squaring of horses' means tethering them. Even if you tie up the horses and bury the chariot wheels in an attempt to stop your soldiers from running away, you can't trust them not to run anyway.

Cao Cao comments: ¡§'Squaring horses' means to tether them. Chariot wheels are buried to show your men that they are not to move. This passage tells that it is better to adapt intelligently than to rely exclusively on creating difficulties for the soldiers." It is more effective to be flexible with your troops than to force them into anything.

This way, you can create a situation where they have no choice but to fight to the death. Why does 'squaring' mean the same thing as 'tethering?' Du Mu comments: ¡§Horses are tethered in order to form battle lines that are even and square." So, the horses aren't tethered to posts.

Rather, they're tied up in their respective battle units - forward, rear, left and right - so they can't run away. ¡§The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Being unified and possessed of courage, the soldiers of an army become as one; this is a principle to be used by all in positions of governance."
Chen Hao comments: ¡§The style of governance and orders both being strict and clear, brave soldiers will not advance alone, and neither will cowards retreat alone; all the soldiers of the army will be as one."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Positioning them in a place of peril and causing them to keep each other alive, the masses of soldiers within the army will pool their strength and unify their courage as though they were one man. This is the proper way to govern armies."

¡§How to make the best of both strong and weak - that is a question involving the proper use of ground."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The strong and weak shall be of a single energy." The key to unlocking the potential of strong and weak soldiers alike is to use the terrain appropriately and set your army up in the best possible position.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Gaining the advantage of favourable terrain, even weak soldiers can defeat the enemy in battle, let alone the strongest among your soldiers. It is the energy provided by terrain that enables one to make full and simultaneous use of both weak and strong soldiers."
Your army is made up of both strong and weak soldiers, and you need to make full use of all of them. A good example of this is how Li Shimin used 3,500 soldiers to defeat Dou Jiande's army of 100,000.

How do you properly use 3,500 people? He kept 3,000 of them to guard Hulao Pass, a transport corridor so narrow that a single man could guard it against 10,000. There was no way the enemy would be able to fight their way in. Meanwhile, Li Shimin led the remaining 500 men out of the pass to pick a fight, luring Cheng Yaojin and Qin Shubao to chase after him with their troops, while he set an ambush at the side of the road. Later in that conflict, Li Shimin selected the six strongest men from the 500, who themselves were the strongest of his entire 3,500-strong force. They included two ubermensch warriors - Yuchi Jingde and himself - and went out again to pick another fight. Li Shimin said to Yuchi Jingde: ¡§With my bow, and your spear, not even a thousand armed men could touch us!" The two of them, along with their four handpicked cavalrymen, headed straight for Dou Jiande's main camp and lured several thousand enemy troops into the pre-assigned ambush location, where Li's forces won a great victory. Winning the first couple rounds of this conflict provided a huge morale boost to the 3,000 soldiers left guarding Hulao Pass.

This is how to use both the strong and weak soldiers in your army. ¡§Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand."

So, the best strategists have the ability to make their army work as a single unit, almost as a single body, because they are able to engineer circumstances in which their men have no choice but to go along with him. If each and every one of their men has no way out and no other choice but to do what they say, the commander has effectively tied them to his war chariot.

Li Quan comments: ¡§The patterns by which to govern a great multitude are the same as those used to govern a small number of men." This is the same principle that we've already seen in a passage from Chapter Five, Energy: ¡§The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men... Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one." People who have a firm grasp on the art of managing an army are just as unconstrained and at ease commanding any number of men as if they were only in charge of a single man.

They are able to advance and withdraw as one and unify their men's bodies and minds. As a leader, don't be frantically busy, be calm and collected; Your movements should be neither slow nor rushed

We think that becoming successful and catching hold of success always comes from motion - 'We have to move, because by moving we take hold of success.' And yet, so often we flail and grab at success but come up empty-handed. Can we calm down, do some serious thinking and steadily build success?

Can we let it come to us from a place of calmness, instead of spinning around in constant motion, grabbing at it? This is the thinking behind strategy, behind Buddhism, and behind managing military issues.

It's also a kind of wisdom that can be applied to life in general. Extract from the original text:
¡§It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order. He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance.

By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge. By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose. At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him. He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand.

He burns his boats and breaks his cooking-pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going. To muster his host and bring it into danger: this may be termed the business of the general."

Analysis:
¡§It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is what is called 'quiet' - serene, obscure and orderly."
Du Mu comments: ¡§'Quiet' is a simple and easy thing; obscurity is difficult to gauge; orderliness does not err. By using these, one is able to govern with total effectiveness."
As a leader, you don't want to be manic or overly busy.

It's best to stay calm and level-headed. Don't do things too slowly, but don't be too quick either. Take plenty of time to think things over, act in a systematic way, behave with moderation, and keep as a tight a grip on events as you can. We want to control other people, and we make up many rules and demands that we place on them, but we don't consider that if we want to straighten out other people we first have to straighten out ourselves.

Then, we have to use our own 'straightness' as a mould, and reproduce it throughout the ranks of our army. The Confucians have something to say about the idea that 'to straighten out other people we first have to straighten out ourselves.' They put it like this: 'Rectify your heart, make your thoughts honest, cultivate your moral self, bring order to your house, bring good governance to your country, and bring peace to the world.' The principle also applies to military leaders: cultivate your own moral fiber in order to bring order to your army. In Zeng Guofan's approach to the art of military leadership, he put special emphasis on the concept of 'incorruptibility.' Zeng said that ordinary soldiers don't understand the art of war, and they have no idea which generals are more talented than others.

Yet, when it comes to gold and silver, they have a very clear idea of what's happening. If a general is greedy and corrupt, there's no way his soldiers will truly submit to him. But, if a general is clean and honest in matters of money, his soldiers will accept him as their leader.

If, on top of that, the general has the ability to clearly lay out information about rewards and punishments, and also make sure all of his men get a share of whatever profit the army might come by, each and every one of his men will be ready and willing to fight alongside him. ¡§He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance."

This isn't about fooling people; it's about keeping secrets. You can't let your men know what your battle plans are.

Just make sure everyone knows what their individual task is, while remaining in the dark about the planning and intent of the war effort. It is what must be done to protect military secrets. Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is permissible for the people to come together with you in joy, but not to start out from worry." A leader's responsibility is to fill everyone with confidence and get them to work side by side; what a leader mustn't do is spread worry through his ranks about what on earth should be done. Confucius said something along the same lines: ¡§The people may be made to follow a path of action, but they may not be made to understand it." The soldiers should only know what their individual tasks are, while the general keeps a grip on the overall situation.

¡§By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge."

By making frequent use of variation in the way you carry out operations, and by constantly tweaking your stratagems, other parties won't be able to decode what you're up to.

Du Mu comments: ¡§In all that you do and in all that you plan, do not show the original thoughts that bring these things into being and do not make known the source from which they flow." Make sure people know what you're doing, but not how.

Then, nobody will be able to work out what your next step will be. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§All your former acts and all your old plans were varied and changed so that people could not know them." If you're constantly bringing variety and change into what you do, nobody can know what you'll do next. This is because the people who make up your army aren't just your brothers-at-arms; your ranks will always contain a certain number of enemy spies and even your own people who, without knowing it, leak secrets.

That's why you mustn't let anyone work out what your next move will be, and you have to make nonsense of any information that might enable people to identify a pattern. On the other hand, if you're in a constant state of instability, how can you make sure your men listen to you?

This calls for some more tricks. Zhang Yu wrote about the story of a famous Tang dynasty general named Pei Xingjian, who waited until just after his men had set up camp and then suddenly gave the order that the camp was to be moved up a nearby mountain. The men would have to break everything down and set up again.

The soldiers weren't happy. In fact, they felt extremely frustrated. But, when evening came, a heavy rainstorm appeared from nowhere and flooded the original campsite, where the water rose over ten feet deep. The soldiers were shocked, and asked Pei Xingjian, ¡§How did you know it was going to rain?" Pei replied: ¡§In the future, when I tell you to do something, you do it. Don't ask me what I know, and don't ask me how I know."
Pei Xingjian managed the situation expertly. If he'd told his men there was a possibility of rain, but then the rain failed to show up, they'd stop believing everything he said.

He didn't say anything, so if it hadn't rained that night, nobody would have made the connection between the weather and his command to move camp. And so, his authority wouldn't have been compromised.

In fact, it did rain - to an extent that everyone would have perished - and he gained a reputation for supernatural foresight. This boosted his authority even higher. ¡§By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose."

If you want your men to keep a secret, the best approach is to keep them from knowing the secret in the first place.

If you do that, the enemy can send as many spies as they want; it still won't do them any good. ¡§At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him."

When a commander assigns tasks to his men, it's like he sends them up a ladder to the floor above, and then pulls the ladder away so they have no choice to retreat. ¡§He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand.

He burns his boats and breaks his cooking pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going."

When a commander-in-chief leads his men deep into enemy territory, it's like firing an arrow - once you're there, there's no coming back. He burns his boats and smashes his cooking pots, because today will be the day of the battle that seals the war. The commander drives his troops before him like a herd of sheep, turning this way and that, nobody knowing where they're going, only that they are to follow their leader. Li Quan comments: ¡§The general, having burned all the ships, hardens the resolve of his men, who neither know what their commander's plan may be, nor harbor any thought of returning home. In this way, they are like herded sheep." The soldiers have no idea what their commander is thinking; all they can do is stake their lives on following him.

In this respect, they're no different from a herd of cattle or a flock of sheep being driven by their herder. ¡§To muster his host and bring it into danger - this may be termed the business of the general."

It is a general's duty to lead his men into peril and somehow find a way to victory. I'm suddenly reminded of the America general George Patton's famous words at the height of World War II: ¡§I want you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country.

He won it by making the other poor, dumb bastard die for his country."
Although it's a generals' business to take his men into danger, it's also your responsibility to bring them home alive. As Zeng Guofan put it, the young men you lead to war should, after the war is won and they return home to their parents and brothers and sisters, remain simple and honest young men, if perhaps more mature than when they left. You mustn't lead them astray and teach them the vices of gluttony, drinking, whoring, gambling and smoking.

This is the way of the benevolent, Confucian general. Success depends on making just a little bit of effort every day

Extract from the original text:
¡§The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied."

Analysis:
The ability to respond flexibly to each of the nine situations and to a developing situation, as well as mastery over the psychology and emotions of the many kinds of people in your army, are essential capabilities that every general should possess. This passage is a summary of the nine situations, and it also lays the ground for what comes next.

The reason there is special mention of 'the fundamental laws of human nature,' or just 'emotions,' is to highlight the role of managing energy. The only way to gain control over your army's morale is to master human psychology and emotions.

If you can do that, you be able to both boost your men's morale and take control of the enemy's. Confucian scholars talk about 'the Laws of Heaven,' 'the Laws of the Realm,' and, as with the art of war, they also talk about 'the laws of human nature.' We've already seen examples of how the art of war is applied to human nature or emotions - when we talk about managing energy, that basically means paying attention to your soldiers' psychological state. Psychology determines morale, and morale determines an army's fighting ability.

Zeng Guofan had two things to say about studying. First, stay committed and study every day, even if you only read one page or even one line in a day. Stay dedicated and you'll progress quickly enough - this is the idea of moving at speed without hurrying.

The worst scenario is to whip yourself into a frenzy and go all out for one, huge session, only to abandon your efforts as soon as you lose steam. If that's the way you do things, you'll have a hard time finishing anything.

The key to finishing a job and achieving a goal is to keep moving forward, one step every day. If the road to success were a chess game, becoming successful would depend on using pawns, not rooks, because you don't have as many rooks as pawns.

And yet, lots of people only want to use their rooks. If you try to talk to them about pawns, they simply don't listen. The second thing Zeng Guofan said about studying and reading is that you should finish reading the book in your hands before starting the next.

That's so you don't end up with a hulking pile of books, all of which you gave up on halfway through. I suppose this could be called 'the art of war for reading books.'

Once inside enemy territory, unite your army as one

Extract from the original text:
¡§When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion. When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground.
