Analysis:
¡§When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion."
When fighting as a 'visitor' in foreign lands, your soldiers' minds will become focused and their resolve will harden once you're deep in enemy territory. But, if you don't plunge deep into enemy territory, your men's fighting spirit will easily become diluted and weak. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Entering deeply brings focus and solidity; entering shallowly brings dispersion and a desire to return home." This is the difference between serious ground and facile ground on the one hand, which we've already talked about, and shallow ground. ¡§When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground.

When there are means of communication on all four sides, the ground is one of intersecting highways. When you penetrate deeply into a country, it is serious ground. When you penetrate but a little way, it is facile ground.

When you have the enemy's strongholds on your rear, and narrow passes in front, it is hemmed-in ground. When there is no place of refuge at all, it is desperate ground."

This passage introduces an additional piece: 'critical ground.' Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§This refers to a situation in which one cannot reach facile ground by moving forward, yet also cannot reach dispersive ground by retreating; critical ground is between these two other types of terrain." When you're a short distance inside enemy territory, you are no longer in dispersive ground, but you also have not yet reached facile ground. Areas with easy transportation links in all directions are 'ground of intersecting highways,' areas deep within enemy territory are 'serious ground,' and areas only a short distance inside enemy territory are 'shallow ground.' Terrain characterized by impregnable, dangerous terrain behind and narrow, obstructed passages in front is 'hemmed-in ground,' and areas where there is no way out is 'desperate ground.'
What's the right way to deal with each of these different terrain types? ¡§Therefore, on dispersive ground, I would inspire my men with unity of purpose."

Li Quan comments: ¡§Mind of a single soldier." Bring together an army and make them of one mind and one will.

Du Mu comments: ¡§When defending, the army's will is as one; when fighting a battle, it is easy to become dispersed." When you're holding a defensive position behind a fortified wall, everyone in your army will be unified in their intent to prevent the enemy from breaking in.

But, if you come out from behind the walls to fight, the idea will occur to some of your men that this is an opportunity to run away and go home. This is the logic behind the earlier passage: ¡§On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not." Hold your ground and don't go looking for a fight. ¡§On facile ground, I would see that there is close connection between all parts of my army."

When you enter facile ground, make sure the various campsites of the different units in your army are close to each other and connected. There are two reasons for this.

First, it's a way to defend against enemy attack, because it makes it easier for different units to support and rescue each other. Second, it's a way to defend against your own men running away. Ask yourself: 'What have I learned?' ¡V Don't get caught up in words and their meanings

When you study ancient treatises, or when you have an experience, ask yourself: 'What have I learned?" Try to understand the writer's thinking, not the meaning of the words. Extract from the original text:
¡§When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion.

When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground. When there are means of communication on all four sides, the ground is one of intersecting highways. When you penetrate deeply into a country, it is serious ground.

When you penetrate but a little way, it is facile ground. When you have the enemy's strongholds on your rear, and narrow passes in front, it is hemmed-in ground. When there is no place of refuge at all, it is desperate ground. Therefore, on dispersive ground, I would inspire my men with unity of purpose. On facile ground, I would see that there is close connection between all parts of my army.

On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear. On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses. On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances. On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies.

On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road. On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat. On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives."

Analysis:
¡§On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear."
This line causes some problems. All of our commentators have a different interpretation.

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Favourable ground lies ahead. One should order one's rear units to advance quickly." This is effectively a non-comment, because he's saying exactly the same thing as Sun Tzu. Cao Cao understands, but the others don't.

The issue is, what does 'rear' mean? Does it mean you should maneuver your army behind the enemy? Du Mu comments: ¡§On terrain which is vital to the point that it must be contended over, if I am behind then I must rush forward to contend for it; is this any less true if I do not start from behind?"
Chen Hao tells us that Du Mu's comment is incorrect. Chen Hao comments: ¡§Both statements are incorrect.

If the enemy occupies the favourable ground and I come from behind to contend for it, would this not be exhausting my army by coming to fight when the battleground is already held by the enemy? What is meant here about the vital importance of hurrying up the rear when on contentious ground is that if the favourable ground is in front, then one should first select one's best soldiers and send them to occupy it. Then, if the enemy comes to contend for it with the whole mass of his army, one should come with the main part of one's army and strike the enemy's rear; then it would be impossible not to overcome the enemy."
Chen Hao claims that the commentators who came before him were wrong, but his own logic doesn't stand up to scrutiny. In fact, Du Mu was saying that if the enemy has gotten ahead of you, you should chase after him, and try to get ahead, so you can be the first to arrive at the contentious ground. Du Mu was not saying that in this scenario the enemy has already occupied the contentious ground. Chen Hao's comment argues that if the favourable terrain is ahead of you, you should send a small unit of elite soldiers to occupy it. Then, if the enemy attacks their position in force, you can send your main army to attack them from behind.

Chen Hao seems once again to have put too much of his own thinking into his comment. With contentious ground, if you get hold of it, it's yours, and that's all. Sun Tzu probably wasn't saying that after you've taken the contentious ground you should come up behind the enemy and strike their rear. Du You comments: ¡§With favourable terrain ahead, one should enter into it from behind. On contentious ground, victory belongs to whoever occupies it first, and defeat falls to whoever fails to do so. Therefore, bring your rear units close after the remainder of your forces so that the different parts of your army remain connected." The first part of what Du You said was right - the nature of contentious ground is that whoever occupies it first will win, and the other side will lose. That's exactly why it's called 'contentious ground.' This makes what you do after you hold the contentious ground, or whether you should hit the enemy with a sneak attack from behind, a moot point. But, the second part of Du You's comment - ¡§Therefore, bring your rear units close after the remainder of your forces so that the different parts of your army are connected" - shows that he also didn't understand the original text. Does he want the rear units to catch up and link together with the forward units so that the army doesn't fall apart? Zhang Yu doubles down on Du You's view: ¡§In contentious ground speed is a commodity of the highest value; it is not acceptable for your forward units to move quickly ahead while your rear units fail to keep up. Therefore, you should quickly move your rear units forward so that the head and tail of your army arrive together." So, Zhang Yu is interpreting the 'rear' from Sun Tzu's original text to mean not the enemy's rear, but your own rear. He's saying you shouldn't get yourself in a situation where your forward units make it to the contentious ground, but your rear units can't keep up.

He's saying that your rear units have to move quickly, too. By my reckoning, this is much more complicated than what Sun Tzu was actually trying to say. Zhang Yu also provides an alternative explanation: ¡§'Hurrying up the rear' means that although you set out after the enemy, you arrive before him." So, according to this explanation, the 'rear' means that your enemy set out first and you came after - in other words, you followed after the enemy's rear. I think it's even less likely that Sun Tzu was saying this.

What would the point be? He didn't care whether you set out before or after the enemy. The point is that you need to get to the destination first. To sum up, we shouldn't over-think things and make them more complicated than necessary.

Keep things simple and direct. ¡§On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear." All this means is that when it comes to contentious ground, you need to get there as quickly as possible, find a way to get behind enemy lines, and arrive at the destination before the enemy. Whenever you study ancient texts, or have a real-life experience, ask yourself: 'What have I learned?' Try to understand the writer's thinking, not necessarily the literal meaning of the words.

You can find the writer's thinking in the context and by looking at the book as a whole. If you get it, you get it. But, if you get caught up in entanglements and debates and different interpretations of the meaning of a certain line, or even a handful of words, you're doing pointless mental labor. There's not much meaning to be found in this kind of work.

In particular, don't make it into a contest that you have to win - don't single-mindedly fixate on coming up with a new theory or an innovative angle to beat other people over the head with. ¡§On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses."

¡§Ground on which each side has liberty of movement" - this is 'open ground.' These are places where you need to carefully guard your fortifications and cut off the enemy's transportation routes. Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about diligently seeing to your fortifications." If the enemy can come at you from any direction, you need to build strong fortifications, dig deep moats and guard them vigilantly.

¡§On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances."

Make sure your enemies don't secure alliances with your neighbors before you do, and don't let them break up your alliances. Wang Xi comments: ¡§To solidify alliances, use moral virtue and courtesy, prestige and trust, and show them the 'benefit-and-harm gambit.'"
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Use riches and money to show them benefits, use oaths of alliance to secure the alliance, be firm and consistent; then, they are bound to help you."

¡§On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies."

The crucial thing about serious ground is to take care of your army. Basically, you need grain, animal fodder and other supplies.

That's because once you're deep in enemy territory, your rear units can't keep up, and you'll need to feed yourself from the enemies' resources. In other words, you need to find a local solution to the problem of keeping your army fed and supplied. Cao Cao comments: ¡§It is about plundering from the enemy."
When we talk about the Second World War, why do people say that China made an enormous sacrifice and contribution? It's because China consistently and firmly refused to surrender.

As a result, Japan couldn't secure all of China's resources for its war effort and instead had to spend a huge amount of its own resources fighting there. ¡§On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road."

When you're in difficult ground - terrain with mountains and forests, other obstructions, or dangerous terrain features, marshes and swamps - you need to quickly pass through the area. Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about passing quickly through and leaving."
Li Quan comments: ¡§It is not permissible to stay in such places."
In summary, make your way through these places quickly.

You mustn't delay. If you do, and your enemy strands you, you're in serious trouble. ¡§On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat."

If you find yourself in hemmed-in ground and surrounded by the enemy, you need to block whatever gap in the encirclement might offer escape. But why would you want to block your one chance for escape? The Art of War tells us: ¡§When you surround an army, leave an outlet free." When your enemy surrounds you, they leave a gap for you to escape through because they're worried that otherwise you'll fight like a cornered animal. If your men have a way out, they'll lose their will to fight to the death and instead head straight for the escape route that the enemy has intentionally left open.

As soon as your men run, the enemy will capitalize on their eagerness to make it home alive, cutting off groups of your soldiers, walling them in and attacking until there's nothing left of your army. That's why you should block up the hole yourself and tell your men that there's nowhere to run, and the only option is to fight like madmen. If you do that, you can turn the situation around and actually have a chance to hit the enemy so hard that their lines shatter. Also, the fact that the enemy intentionally left a gap for you means that it will be surrounded by enemy troops waiting to ambush you.

If you block it up, the enemy has no way to know from which direction you'll try to break through the encirclement. When Gao Huan, also known as Emperor Shenwu of Northern Qi, first raised his army in Hebei, he fought a battle at Yenan against the combined forces of Erzhu Zhao, Erzhu Tianguang, Erzhu Dulu and Erzhu Zhongyuan. At the time, the army of Erzhu, Erzhu and Erzhu was a formidable force known as the 'Great Army of 200,000.' It managed to surround Gao Huan's army of 2,000 cavalry and 30,000 infantry at Nanling Mountain. The Erzhus left a single way out for Gao Huan's army, so that his men would have an escape route, and then they got ready to annihilate him.

But that didn't happen. Instead, Gao Huan gathered his army's cattle and donkeys, tied them all together, and put them right in the way of the escape route, blocking it off. His men could see there was nowhere to run, so they fought for their lives, striking the enemy hard on all sides and ultimately inflicting a heavy defeat on the Erzhus. ¡§On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives."

When on desperate ground, you need to show your men that you've made up your mind to embrace death. Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about rousing the soldiers' spirits."
Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about making clear to the soldiers that death is inevitable; make them stoke their inner fire so that they may seek life."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Burn the heavy wagons, throw out the food, block the wells and demolish the cooking ranges so as to show the soldiers that there is no hope of survival and to incite them to fight unto death."
Shout something along the lines of, ¡§The wagons and the food are burned, the well is blocked, the cooking ranges are smashed; there's no life for us now. Now fight with me!"

The way of hegemons and kings: To strike iron, make yourself harder than iron

Extract from the original text:
¡§For it is the soldier's disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger.

We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides.

Analysis:
¡§For it is the soldier's disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger."
These are 'the fundamental laws of human natures' from the passage: ¡§The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied." You need to gain control over your men's psychological state, because psychology determines an army's will to fight, and the will to fight determines an army's battle capability. ¡§...

to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about resisting the enemy when in deadlock."
Du Mu comments: ¡§Keep strict discipline among the soldiers when in hemmed-in ground, and then all of the men will have the will to resist the enemy and find a road to victory; this is resisting the enemy when in deadlock. When in dire circumstances, make your army of a single mind and hold your position."
¡§...

to fight hard when he cannot help himself." 

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about scenarios in which the circumstances leave no choice."

¡§... to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§In situations of excessive danger, soldiers will obey and follow the plan."
Meng Shi comments: ¡§When sunk in peril, none of the soldiers will not obey." There's nothing they can do, except do exactly what you tell them to. Zhang Yu writes about a historical example of this principle: Ban Chao's diplomatic expedition, which we looked at earlier in the book.

Ban Chao was sent as an envoy to the Western Regions, to the kingdom of Shanshan. When he and a small contingent of men first arrived, they were treated with warm hospitality by the King of Shanshan. However, the sovereign suddenly turned cold. Ban Chao made some enquiries and found out that another foreign emissary had arrived in Shanshan, from the Xiongnu nomadic confederation. So, was Shanshan going to go with the Xiongnu, or with the Han Emperor? If Shanshan made an alliance with the Xiongnu, Ban Chao and his men likely would have been executed as a gift to the Xiongnu diplomat. Ban Chao had just 36 men with him, and they were definitely 'sunk in peril.'
Faced with this situation, Ban Chao assembled his men and told them his plan.

Frankly, it was startling. They would launch a direct attack on the Xiongnu diplomatic team and kill every last one of them. The King of Shanshan would never be able to explain to the Xiongnu leaders how their men ended up dead on his watch, so his only choice would be to ally with the Han Emperor. Hundreds of miles from home, in the capital city of a foreign country, Ban Chao was asking the handful of men under his command to do something truly audacious.

He was daring enough to do it, but what about his men? Ban Chao treated them to wine, and then explained clearly to them the danger they were in. He asked what they wanted to do: let the King of Shanshan hand them over to the Xiongnu, so that the jackals and wolves could gnaw on their bones, or do something truly great, which would make them rich in this life and immortal heroes in the history books. The men said: ¡§Today we are in the land of death.

We will follow you into battle, whether we are to live or die." They handed their lives over to Ban Chao. Under cover of night they launched a surprise attack, setting fire to the Xiongnu diplomat's campsite and killing the men inside.

The next day, they took the diplomat's head to the King of Shanshan. Terrified, the king decided to send his son as a hostage to the Han Emperor. He had accepted an alliance with the Han Empire. ¡§We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs.

We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides."

So, if you don't know what other countries are planning, or what they want, you can't design a foreign policy. In the story of Ban Chao, if he hadn't known about the King of Shanshan's situation, or the movements of the Xiongnu, he could never have acted so decisively. If you don't know the lay of the local mountains, forests, marshes, swamps and other dangerous terrain features, you can't move your army through the area.

If you don't employ a local guide, you won't be able to take advantage of the best terrain. Cao Cao comments: ¡§These three matters have already been expounded upon above. Here, they are repeated, so as to vigorously express that one must absolutely not take military action."
The reason these three principles are repeated is to emphasize their importance. ¡§To be ignorant of any one of the following four and five principles is inconsistent with the way that hegemons and kings use military force."

What exactly is meant by 'the following four or five principles?' Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about the benefits and dangers inherent in the nine terrain situations. An alternative formulation is: 'the four and five issues.'" Four plus five equals nine, so 'the four and five principles' means 'the nine terrain types.' Some people have a different interpretation, suggesting that it's not a reference specifically to 'the nine terrain types,' but a more general reference to the various principles introduced above.

In the original text, this passage could be interpreted either to mean 'hegemonic kings' or 'hegemons and kings.' The correct meaning is 'hegemons and kings.' A hegemon is a regional lord, while a king is someone who can claim to rule the known world.

So, hegemons and kings are different categories, with differing status and existing within different boundaries. A hegemon is someone who is feared, someone who everyone submits to and obeys. He's in charge, and his role is like that of the oldest brother in a clan.

Separately, a king is someone who the whole populace recognizes as their lord; he's like the father of his country. ¡§When a hegemon or a king attacks a powerful state, his generalship shows itself in preventing the concentration of the enemy's forces. He overawes his opponents, and their allies are prevented from joining against him."

By attacking a powerful country in the manner of a hegemon or a king, you cause the enemy's country to collapse from the inside, rendering them unable to assemble their army.

Make a show of force to psychologically dominate them, and they'll be unable to build friendly relations with other countries. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§When invading large countries, being able to divide the populace ensures you can command an abundance of authority and power, and then you can impose your authoritativeness upon the enemy, inspiring fear in neighboring countries and rendering it impossible for your enemy to seek allies." 
When you command military strength that is truly earthshaking, your enemy fears your power, and this fear handicaps their ability to raise an army. As word of your power reverberates through the land, nearby countries will be paralyzed and horrified at the thought of getting on your bad side.

So, nobody will be eager to hold out a hand of friendship to your enemy. For example, when the states of Jin and Chu went to war over control of the state of Zheng, if Jin won, Zheng would become a Jin vassal.

If Chu won, Zheng would turn its back on Jin and become a Chu vassal. This is how a big country practices The Way of the Hegemon - by winning wars and annexing smaller countries, thus becoming even stronger.

¡§Hence he does not strive to ally himself with all and sundry, nor does he foster the power of other states. He unfurls his own personal designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Thus he is able to capture their cities and overthrow their kingdoms."

Therefore, there's no need to spend time and effort building alliances with other countries, or to help build up another country's military strength. Just flex your muscles and let your intentions be known.

Exert your aura of power on your enemy, and then you can easily take their cities and reduce their country to rubble. Du Mu comments: ¡§The character 'xin' (which usually means 'trust') here means 'shen' ('unfurl')." This passage tells the general to not form ties with foreign forces, nor to use the stratagem of building power, but to flaunt the power of his army and exert the pressure that arises from it upon enemy countries. High importance is placed on carrying out one's personal desires; if you do this, the enemy's cities can be plucked from their hands and their country destroyed."
Jia Lin comments: ¡§The various feudal princes will fear you.

They will be unable to bring their people together and they will not dare to ally with other countries. You can call upon an abundance of authoritativeness and intelligent planning capabilities, and the various feudal princes will naturally align with you. What need is there to foster alliances?"
Chen Hao comments: ¡§Commanding ample wisdom and strength, authority rests in your hands. Foster only your own soldiers; this is how to make yourself invincible, and all the feudal princes in the world will have no authority to call upon.

Benevolence, righteousness and wisdom will be your personal assets, owned by nobody else, and you can use them to unite the people. Thus, it is said: 'Unfurling my personal designs, my authority shakes all under heaven, my moral virtue shines over the four seas, my grace blesses all things, and trust in me pervades all beings even unto pigs and fishes.

The hearts of the common people are mine and nobody even entertains the notion of not submitting to me. Thus, I will inevitably take the enemy's cities; when I invade, their country is bound to fall."
Chen Hao is talking about The Way of Kings, which applies to all living things in the world, not just to the people of one's own country. Even the birds and beasts are included.

An example of this, which we discussed earlier in the book, is the story of Shang Tang, the legendary founder of the ancient Shang dynasty (1600-1046 BCE), and how he 'left the net open on three sides.'
Shang Tang was outside of the city when he saw a hunter putting up nets to catch birds. The hunter was arranging the nets in a square shape, with no way out.

He muttered while he worked: ¡§Any bird that comes from the sky and any beast that comes from the earth; any creature coming from any direction; here they all come, straight into my net." From the tempo of the hunter's work, it seemed he was hell-bent on catching as many animals as he possibly could. Shang Tang approached him, and said: ¡§If you act this way, you will hunt the animals until there are none left! This is the evil influence of King Jie of Xia; if it were not for his example, who would behave in this way?" Shang Tang told the hunter to take down his nets on three sides, leaving only one side remaining. Then, he taught the hunter a new song.

Loosely translated into a more modern form, it reads like this:
¡§When a spider weaves its web,
It only weaves on one side! Let me be like the spider
To set my nets and catch the birds! When I go setting nets
And hunting birds!

Go left, if you like,
Or right, if you like,
Or up high, if you like,
Or down low, if you like. Three sides free to fly,
One side for my net. Fly into my net,
If you insist,
And if that is your lousy fate. I'll take the birds
Who throw their life away,
And to the rest I say,
Fly free and godspeed!"

News of Shang Tang's good deed spread, and when people in other countries heard about it, they exclaimed: ¡§Tang's virtue reaches even the birds and the beasts!" If Shang Tang's good deeds extended even to animals, imagine how kind he must be in his dealings with human beings! After that, 40 countries and states submitted to him.

The moral of the story is that, even if you set up nets on four sides, you won't necessarily catch any birds. Shang Tang removed the nets on three sides and managed to catch 40 countries in his one remaining net. He wasn't in the business of catching birds!

There's another story about Shang Tang. He was once building a house, and while digging the foundation his shovel unearthed a human skeleton. The workers made as if to dispose of it, but Shang Tang said: ¡§This is our countryman, you know!" Then, treating the nameless skeleton with the utmost dignity and respect, he gave it a proper burial. When this story spread, people all over the world exclaimed: ¡§If Tang's virtue reaches even the dead, then imagine how well he must treat the living!" 
Then, the common people gave their hearts to Shang Tang, and there was nobody who even considered not submitting to him.

And what was the result? When Shang Tang began launching military campaigns all over China, if he attacked countries in the east, people in the west would be unhappy: ¡§What's Tang doing fighting in the east? Why isn't he attacking us?

How we wish that he would come and be our ruler!" Then, after Shang Tang turned his armies west, the people in the east were most displeased: ¡§He hasn't finished the job over here yet! Why's he going west?"
And that is how Shang Tang unified all the lands of China.

The lesson is that if you're going to strike iron, the key is to make yourself harder than iron. This is The Way of Hegemons and Kings. Once your economy, culture, military and government administration are more advanced than your rivals', you can roll out The Way of Hegemons and Kings around the world. You won't need to bother with building alliances or calculating who to fight and who to seduce into a partnership - that's not what hegemons and kings do.

For example, at one time the United States had ambitions to win over the hearts and minds of the common people: The Way of Kings. When the US first invaded Iraq, I'd guess that many Libyans wished the American military was coming to their country.

In fact, America was unable to continue to bear the responsibility it had taken upon itself. US President Barack Obama didn't understand the one rule that is the bare minimum for anyone wishing to be a world leader. Being a world leader means sacrificing yourself for the sake of the world.

If you sacrifice nothing at all, what qualifies you to lead others? If you refuse to make any kind of blood sacrifice, and instead try to rule the world purely through diplomacy and building up other countries, you're doomed to be nothing more than a world-class laughingstock. To emerge victorious, you must lay aside all fear and doubt

This is about breaking with the ordinary rules and administration, and thus it is said: 'Act without regard to law or previous arrangements.'"
The prospect of massive reward brings daring men out of the woodwork.

That's why you have to offer rewards that seem to go beyond the remit of your laws and rules when you want to take a city. War is a time of extraordinary circumstances, so you have to command in an extraordinary manner; you have to go against the usual way of doing things. This is all for the sake of victory.

Don't tie yourself to the normal rules; make up whatever 'special' rules the circumstances demand. ¡§... and you will be able to handle a whole army as though you had to do with but a single man."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§The character 'fan' (which normally means 'violate') here means 'yong' ('use'). This passage says that one must make clear what the rewards are, and to use your army as though it were only a single man, even if it is of great size."
This is a principle we've come across many times already: to command a large number of men, lead them as though they're few in number. ¡§Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Use soldiers only to fight battles; do not tell them your plans."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§When information is leaked, plans go awry."
When you're trying to accomplish something, only tell your soldiers what to do.

Don't explain why. If more than a handful of people know why you're doing something, an intelligence leak becomes highly likely. If that happens, your enemy can work out what your next move will be. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Use them to fight battles, do not discuss matters of planning and authority. When people know your plan, they are prone to doubt."
This brings us to the second issue.

If you tell your men why you're making such-and-such a move, they'll start thinking and analyzing, and it will be impossible to stop them from doubting your plan. Once your men have doubts, they'll lose their determination to get on with their job. In an earlier example, we saw how General Pei Xingjian's men had just finished setting up camp when he ordered them to take down their tents and move to higher ground. He didn't give them any reason for this command, and his men were reluctant to obey.

They did, though, and that night a huge rainstorm came and flooded the campsite they'd abandoned. After that, everyone in the army had nothing but admiration for Pei Xingjian! Now, let's imagine that Pei Xingjian had explained his reasoning when he gave the order to move camp: ¡§It's possible there will be a big rainstorm tonight. That's why I'm telling you to hurry up and move to higher ground." Then the troops would have started talking among themselves.

Some of them would have argued that Pei was right and it was indeed going to rain; others would insist it wasn't going to rain. And, if it wasn't going to rain, they'd figure they should rest instead of making life hard for themselves...

and so on. Tongues would start wagging. If the rainstorm did materialize that evening, General Pei would come off as a wise man. If it didn't, getting his men to do as he said would become much more difficult the next time round.

By not telling them a reason, even if it didn't rain, they'd never make the connection between being ordered to move camp and whether or not it would rain that night. In the minds of the soldiers, their general would be an inscrutable leader, impossible to second guess and always acting for his own reasons.

Their role is to do as he says, and nothing more. As a general, you have to make your soldiers trust you completely; leave no room for doubt in their minds. There's a relation between trust and not doubting - trust is the reason, and soldiers who never doubt you is the objective. So, the best course of action is to not give your soldiers the choice between trusting and not trusting; go straight to making sure they never doubt you. Confucius made the same point when he said: ¡§The people may be made to follow a path of action, but they may not be made to understand it." Don't get everyone in your organization involved in analyzing decisions.

The more they analyze, the more ideas they have and the more they start to worry. Then, everything turns into an opaque muddle. ¡§When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Do not make them aware of danger."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§This is about worry, doubt and fear."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§It is the human disposition to advance upon seeing gain and to hide upon gaining knowledge of danger; thus, do not tell them about danger."
In the previous passage - ¡§Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design" - Sun Tzu advises us not to let the soldiers think, and not to let them make their own judgments or feel doubt. Get them to do their job with single-minded focus.

This passage - ¡§When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy" - instructs us only to tell our soldiers about things that they can get some gain from and not to tell them about danger. It's human nature to go after attractive things and stay well away from the bad.

You need to make your men see only gain, so that they put aside their attachment to life. You mustn't let them see danger, or they'll get scared and have doubts, and they won't have the courage to move forward.

Ideally, make sure your men feel no doubt and no fear. Walking out alive from a death trap: Who truly has what it takes? Extract from the original text:
¡§Place your army in deadly peril, and it will survive; plunge it into desperate straits, and it will come off in safety. For it is precisely when a force has fallen into harm's way that is capable of striking a blow for victory."

Analysis:
The only way to keep your army whole is to place it in a deathtrap, and the only way to survive is to put it in a desperate situation.

This is because the only way to seize the wheel of victory and failure is to plunge your troops into a place of certain death. Cao Cao comments: ¡§You must engage in life-and-death battles; you cannot be defeated when you are in a desperate situation. Sun Bin said: 'The most frightening proposition for an army is to not be plunged into desperate straits.' Without being in a place of danger and difficulty, the soldiers' minds will not be focused. Being in a situation of danger and difficulty, then victory and defeat are in the hands of your men."
Unless your men are in mortal peril, they'll never be able to focus their wills and their minds, transcend the questions of life and death, and fight as though their lives depends on it.

That's because unless they're in mortal peril, they'll always have other choices open to them. That is why you have to put them in a situation of certain death; it's the only way for them to break out from their own personal little worlds and defeat your enemies. Of course, if we're going to talk about historical examples of 'walking out alive from a death trap,' we have to once again mention Han Xin's gambit, fighting with his back to a deep river. However, although Han Xin plunged his soldiers into a situation of certain death, he also had other plans: 2,000 cavalry waiting elsewhere.

He was very clear that he'd left himself an out. But there was a general who really did plunge all of his own men, and all of the enemy's men, into mortal peril. That general is Chen Qingzhi, and it happened at the Battle of Guoyang. Chen Qingzhi was a famous general of the Liang dynasty, during the Dynasties period (386¡V589 CE). People called him 'The God of War,' and it's said that Mao Zedong revered him above any other ancient general.

Chen's wartime achievements are so dazzling that they beggar belief. As a result, there's an ongoing debate about whether what the history books say about him is true. Chen Qingzhi laid siege to the Northern Wei city of Guoyang, which today is the city of Mengcheng in Anhui Province. From spring to winter, the two armies fought dozens of battles, and eventually Chen's men grew dispirited, officers and soldiers alike tottering at the brink of total exhaustion.

Then, a Northern Wei relief force showed up and built a camp behind the Liang army's position. Chen's officers were horrified - facing the prospect of being hit in the belly and the back at the same time, they were all anxious to retreat.

Then, Chen Qingzhi spoke: ¡§Since we came here, we have spent a year fighting, at great expense of money and grain. And yet, you all have lost your appetite for fighting, and now you want to cower away.

The enemy has surrounded us. What could be better! As I see it, we are now in a situation of certain death, and so we will survive. Once they have us completely surrounded, then the soldier will be ready to fight to the death. That will be the moment of our victory!"
Throughout the history of war, generals all feared being 'wrapped up like a dumpling,' but Chen Qingzhi actually welcomed the idea, because he thought that it was the only way to unleash his soldiers' ferocity. Sure enough, the Northern Wei army built 13 camps in a tight circle around the Liang army. Chen Qingzhi led his men into action under the cover of night, knocked out four of the enemy camps, and secured the surrender of the Guoyang garrison commander, Wang Wei. Then, Chen picked out 13 enemy prisoners and released them to go back to the Northern Wei camps and spread the news of the Northern Wei defeat. At the same time, Chen and his army followed close on the heels of the surrendered enemy troops, taking advantage of their momentum to attack and destroy the remaining nine enemy camps.

The entire Northern Wei army was wiped out. Loyal advice: you might not want to hear it, but it's to your own advantage to act on It; Beware of advisors who scrape and bow, they have treachery in their hearts

Extract from the original text:
¡§Success in warfare is gained by carefully accommodating ourselves to the enemy's purpose.

By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning.

On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of all emissaries. Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation.

If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in. Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time. Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle. At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you."

Analysis:
¡§Success in warfare is gained by accommodating ourselves to the enemy's purpose."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§An alternative formulation is: 'If the enemy is poised to advance, set an ambush and retreat; if the enemy is poised to withdraw, open up and strike.'"
Basically, to get something you have to give something. Directing the course of a battle is about going along with the enemy's desires, giving them a sense of accomplishment, getting them to let their guard down, and then attacking.

Du Mu comments: ¡§Accommodate yourself to the enemy's purpose. That is why Sun Tzu says that if you want to strike the enemy but see no vulnerabilities, then you must hide your army and conceal all traces of yourself. Whatever the enemy might do, accommodate him and do nothing to startle him.

If he tries to overawe you with aggression, then you must make yourself seem cowardly and hide. Accommodate his aggression in order to make him arrogant. Wait until his vigilance slackens and then attack. If the enemy wants to withdraw whence he came, then open a gap in your encirclement so that he may depart.

Pursue and strike him as he retreats. The purpose in all of these actions is to accommodate the enemy."
If you want to inflict damage on the enemy, the principle is always the same: go along with what they want and let them be the makers of their own undoing. That's why, although it can be unpleasant to hear honest advice from a loyal advisor, evil advisors always fawn over you and go along with whatever you say.

¡§By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning."

¡§Massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy" is about throwing the full force of your entire army at a single point in the enemy lines. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall be able to capture their general even if we must first travel 1,000 li to reach him. This is what is called the ability to accomplish things through sheer cunning."
The knack of dictating how a battle unfolds is about pretending to go along with what the enemy wants, making him drop his guard, and then stealthily massing your forces and striking with speed and in a single direction, capturing and killing the enemy officers and soldiers.

This is how to use cunning to get things done. Our historical example for this section is one we've seen before: the story of how the Xiongnu chieftain Modun defeated the Donghu people. Modun had seized the throne after killing his father, Chanyu Touman.

While he was still new on the throne, the Donghu thought they could bully him. They sent an envoy with this message: ¡§Your father, Touman, had a terrific horse, a very fast horse. How about you hand it over?" Modun's advisors said that the Donghu had no manners, but Modun replied: ¡§It's just a horse, why shouldn't we give it as a gift to our friends?" So, he gave away the horse. Another Donghu envoy arrived and asked if Modun would give them one of his wives, since he had so many.

His advisors were furious and exclaimed that this was a terrible insult, and an army must be sent to punish the Donghu. But Modun said: ¡§It's just a woman, why not give one to our Donghu brothers?"
So, he gave away one of this wives. Now it wasn't just the Donghu who thought Modun was weak and an easy target; even Modun's own advisors gave up on him.

After a while, another Donghu envoy arrived. The envoy said that there was a 1,000-li stretch of deserted land between the Xiongnu and Donghu territories. This land had no owner, so would Modun be willing to draw a new border and recognize it as Donghu territory?

Modun called another meeting of his advisors. Some of them thought: since you didn't have any problems giving away your own wife, what's a piece of deserted land worth? You might as well give it away; why are you even asking us?

Modun flew into a rage:
¡§The land is the very substance of our country! How could I give it away?" He killed the advisors who'd suggested giving up the land, immediately raised an army, and launched a long-distance surprise attack on the Donghu, who were totally unprepared.

The Donghu king was killed, and their land, people and livestock became Modun's property. ¡§On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of enemy emissaries."

This is about the need to keep your secrets. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Having determined your plan, close the passes, every transmission of enemy travel, and do not allow passage to their emissaries."
Once you've decided to go to war, close the mountain passes, cancel and invalidate all travel documents, forbid all travel by civilians, and don't let any enemy agents into your territory. This is how to prevent leaks of military intelligence and stop the enemy from finding out anything about your situation.

¡§Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation."

When making major military decisions, do it in the temple, in conditions of strict secrecy. Du Mu comments: ¡§Hold discussions in the temple, control the whole process. Having already established what the outcome will be, mobilize your armies."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Major military issues must not be discussed lightly; they ought to be discussed in the temple, with the proper reverence and sternness. Control the situation; information about important plans must not be allowed to circulate outside the temple."
So, there are two levels of meaning here.

First, plan first and act later, or win first and fight later. Second, do your planning in seclusion and make absolutely sure to keep it secret. ¡§If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§If there is a vulnerability in the enemy lines, rush in."
However, this can also result in your own defeat.

The enemy's 'vulnerability' might be a trick designed to lure you in. ¡§Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time."

¡§Seizing what he holds dear" is about occupying whichever strategic location the enemy is most attached to. For example, when Li Shimin went to war against Dou Jiande, he occupied Hulao Pass and blocked Dou Jiande from entering his territory through the pass.

Cao Cao comments: ¡§This is about controlling the most advantageous and expedient factors."
Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about seizing whatever the enemy's war effort depends upon." This could be a strategic location, or it could also be food, fodder and supply wagons. The next part, ¡§do not fight on any fixed day or time," requires quite a lot of explaining.

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Setting out after the enemy but arriving before him." That's all well and good, but Cao Cao hasn't explained the meaning of the passage. Du Mu comments: ¡§Here, 'subtly,' a misinterpretation of the character wei (·L), refers to concealment. The character qi refers to a location to which the enemy is attached for the advantages it offers; the general must occupy this location, and so he must secretly travel there so as not to make the enemy aware."
Du Mu's interpretation of 'subtly,' as referring to concealment, makes perfect sense. There are several Chinese words and terms in which this character (wei) is used to mean 'in concealment.' However, his claim that qi means 'that which is desired' doesn't match up with the grammar of the sentence.

The subject of the verb qi is 'the general,' not the enemy. So, this interpretation doesn't fully make sense. Du Mu isn't the only commentator to interpret the passage this way. Chen Hao, Mei Yaochen and Wang Xi all agree with him, and all four of them were influenced by Cao Cao's comment. But, what connection is there between Cao Cao's comment - 'setting out after the enemy but arriving before him' - and 'subtly contrive?" The commentators argue that 'subtly' is about casually leaking information to the enemy. The reasoning is that if you occupy a location, but the enemy doesn't know you're there, he won't come.

And what are you supposed to do then? You have to subtly leak information to the enemy so that he'll come, and only then can you fight him. With all due respect, I think the four commentators overthought this one.

Their explanations, along with Du Mu's and Cao Cao's, left me unsatisfied. So, I went to the Academy of Military Science of the Chinese People's Liberation Army to look for the book, A Translation of Sun Tzu's Art of War with Annotations, by academy vice president General Guo Huaruo.

His comment on this passage was very simple: don't arrange with the enemy to set a date for the battle. After further investigation, I found that the words conventionally translated as 'subtly contrive' (wei yu) actually mean 'don't do it this way.' There's a well-known phrase in Chinese, 'Poor man come; here's food,' which means food that is donated with contempt." Originally, it comes from a passage of the ancient text, The Book of Rites, from the chapter entitled Tan Gong II. This is the relevant passage:
¡§During a great famine in Qi, Qian Ao had food prepared on the roads, to wait the approach of hungry people and give to them.

(One day), there came a famished man, looking as if he could hardly see, his face covered with his sleeve, and dragging his feet together. Qian Ao, carrying with his left hand some rice, and holding some drink with the other, said to him, 'Poor man! Come and eat.' The man, opening his eyes with a stare, and looking at him, said, 'It was because I would not eat (when told) 'Poor man come; here's food,' that I am come to this state.' Qian Ao immediately apologized for his words, but the man would not take the food and died. When Zengzi heard the circumstances, he said, 'Do not behave like this!

When the other expressed his pity as he did, the man could have gone away. When he apologized, the man could have taken the food.'"
When the starving man refused to eat the 'poor man, come' food that Zengzi had offered, Zengzi used the same phrase from the Sun Tzu passage (wei yu), followed by: ¡§You're within your rights to turn down the offer when a man calls you 'poor man,' but it also would have been perfectly acceptable to eat the food after he apologizes." A commentator on the text named Zheng Xuan wrote: ¡§Wei is used in the same way as the word 'don't.' The intent of the passage is to tell the starving man not to speak so imprudently." The scholar Kong Yingda commented: ¡§Wei means 'do not.' Yu is merely an auxiliary word. The passage means: 'Starving people should not behave in such a way!'"
So, wei yu means 'don't.' There are further examples of wei being used in this way, such as in Memorial to Yueyang Tower, by Fan Zhongyan. The relevant passage from Sun Tzu's The Art of War is typically translated as, ¡§Subtly contrive to time his arrival on the ground" actually means, 'War isn't a gentleman's duel; don't arrange with your enemy to set a time and place for the battle.' You need to be prepared to take the enemy by surprise at any moment, and to attack where he's unprepared.

This explanation is the only one that makes sense in the context of the rest of The Art of War. ¡§Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle."

¡§Tread the inked line and follow the enemy." This line raises more questions. The 'inked line' means 'convention' or 'customary rules.' When a carpenter needs to cut wood to make a piece of furniture, the first thing he does is draw an inked line on the wood, which he then cuts along. But, in the original Chinese, it's unclear whether 'tread' means that you should follow the rules or go against them.

You'd think that it would mean you should follow the rules. After all, that's the normal meaning of 'tread the line.' But in ancient Chinese, the word for tread is interchangeable with another word of the same pronunciation that means to cut or eliminate. So, it would also be correct to interpret it as meaning 'don't follow the rules.' 
Du Mu says that it means you should follow the customary rules: ¡§The word 'ink' here refers to 'customary rules.' The meaning is that you must always tread the line of the customary rules, staunchly follow the system of rules and follow enemy's situation closely; if there is any opportunity to exploit, advance and prepare to fight a decisive battle."
But, Jia Lin interprets it to mean that you shouldn't follow the rules: ¡§Here, the word 'tread' means 'to tread on.' The word 'ink' means 'rules.' Follow closely the enemy's plans in order to engage in a decisive battle and accomplish your task. Advantageous conditions are what bring victory; you must not base all of your actions upon conforming to the rules."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§When treading the inked line, do not always act the same way." He doesn't say whether 'treading the inked line' means 'obey the rules' or 'disobey the rules.' He's saying that when you do obey the rules, don't always stick to convention.

General Guo Huaruo comments: ¡§When implementing your war plans, you need to be flexible in following changes in the enemy's situation and correct your plans accordingly. This should inform your decisions about what course of military action to take." This is the correct explanation. ¡§At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§Make yourself seem weak like a maiden, then fly like a hare on the run."



Sun Tzu said: ¡§The art of war recognizes nine varieties of ground: (1) Dispersive ground; (2) Facile ground; (3) Contentious ground; (4) Open ground; (5) Ground of intersecting highways; (6) Serious ground; (7) Difficult ground; (8) Hemmed-in ground; (9) Desperate ground. When a chieftain is fighting in his own territory, it is dispersive ground.

When he has penetrated into hostile territory, but to no great distance, it is facile ground. Ground the possession of which imports great advantage to either side is contentious ground. Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground. Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways. When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground.

Mountain forests, rugged steeps, marshes and fens - all country that is hard to traverse - this is difficult ground. Ground which is reached through narrow gorges, and from which we can only retire by tortuous paths so that a small number of the enemy would suffice to crush a large body of our men: this is hemmed-in ground. Ground on which we can only be saved from destruction by fighting without delay is desperate ground.

On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not. On facile ground, halt not. On contentious ground, attack not. On open ground, do not try to block the enemy's way. On the ground of intersecting highways, join hands with your allies. On serious ground, gather in plunder.

In difficult ground, keep steadily on the march. On hemmed-in ground, resort to stratagem. On desperate ground, fight. Those who were called skillful leaders of old knew how to drive a wedge between the enemy's front and rear; to prevent co-operation between his large and small divisions; to hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men. When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy's men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting.

When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still. If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: 'Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will.' Rapidity is the essence of war: take advantage of the enemy's unreadiness, make your way by unexpected routes, and attack unguarded spots. The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you.

Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food. Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans. Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight.

If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength. Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear. If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm.

If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard. Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted. Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts.

Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared. If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity. On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks.

But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Chu or a Gui. The skillful tactician may be likened to the shuairan. Now, the shuairan is a snake that is found in the Chang Mountains.

Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail; strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head; strike at its middle, and you will be attacked by head and tail both. Asked if an army can be made to imitate the shuairan, I should answer, 'Yes.' For the men of Wu and the men of Yue are enemies; yet if they are crossing a river in the same boat and are caught by a storm, they will come to each other's assistance just as the left hand helps the right. Hence it is not enough to put one's trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground.

The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach. How to make the best of both strong and weak - that is a question involving the proper use of ground. Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand. It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order. He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance.

By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge. By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose. At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him. He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand.

He burns his boats and breaks his cooking pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going. To muster his host and bring it into danger: this may be termed the business of the general.

The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied.

On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear. On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses. On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances. On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies.

On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road. On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat. On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives. For it is the soldier's disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger.

We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country - its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides.

To be ignorant of any one of the following four and five principles is inconsistent with the way that hegemons and kings use military force. When a hegemon or a king attacks a powerful state, his generalship shows itself in preventing the concentration of the enemy's forces. He overawes his opponents, and their allies are prevented from joining against him.

Hence he does not strive to ally himself with all and sundry, nor does he foster the power of other states. He unfurls his own personal designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Thus he is able to capture their cities and overthrow their kingdoms. Bestow rewards without regard to rule, issue orders without regard to previous arrangements; and you will be able to handle a whole army as though you had to do with but a single man.

Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design. When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy. Place your army in deadly peril, and it will survive; plunge it into desperate straits, and it will come off in safety.

For it is precisely when a force has fallen into harm's way that is capable of striking a blow for victory. Success in warfare is gained by carefully accommodating ourselves to the enemy's purpose. By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning.

On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of all emissaries. Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation.

If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in. Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time. Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle. At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you."

Targets to attack with fire

Extract from the original text:
¡§There are five ways of attacking with fire. The first is to burn soldiers in their camp; the second is to burn stores; the third is to burn baggage trains; the fourth is to burn depots; the fifth is to hurl dropping fire amongst enemy units."

Analysis:
These five 'ways of attacking with fire' correspond to five types of target: personnel, supplies, supply wagons, weapon stores and 'armed units.'
Attacking personnel with fire means setting fire to enemy camps and burning enemy soldiers. After Guan Yu was killed during the Three Kingdoms period, his ally Liu Bei was hungry for revenge.

He mobilized his troops and invaded the kingdom of Wu, but his camps were set on fire by Lu Xun and he fled back home, defeated. Soon after, he vomited blood and died. This is an example of targeting enemy personnel with fire.

But, this method doesn't necessarily involve setting fire to enemy camps. During the chaotic final years of the Tang dynasty, Zhu Wen, who later became Emperor Taizu of the dynasty, found himself with an army in an untamed grassland wilderness, facing off against the combined armies of the military governor of Tianping Circuit, Zhu Xuan, and his brother, Zhu Jin. At first, wind was blowing from the southeast into the face of Zhu Wen's army, which frightened his men.

After a while, the wind suddenly changed direction; it was now blowing from the northwest. Immediately, Zhu Wen gave the order to start a fire, and soon flames and smoke were billowing into the sky and churning towards the enemy Tianping army.

Zhu Wen pressed his advantage, launching a blistering attack, decimating the Tianping army and killing Zhu Xuan. 'Burning stores' is about burning the enemy's equipment, food, fodder and whatever other supplies they might have.

During the Chu-Han Contention (206-202 BCE), Liu Bang and Xiang Yu once found themselves in a standoff at Chenggao. Liu Bang's Han army had seized a granary, and he wasn't worried about running out of food or water. Meanwhile, he sent General Liu Jia with 20,000 infantry and several hundred cavalry to cross White Horse Ford, drive into Chu territory and go about reaping destruction and burning Xiang Yu's grain stores.

The Chu army was left with even less to eat than before. During the early years of the Sui dynasty (581-617 CE), Gao Jiong presented a plan to Emperor Wen. Gao Jiong wanted to destroy the state of Chen, one of the Southern Dynasties, and his plan was to burn Chen's supplies. Gao Jiong pointed out that in the southern areas of China, people lived in thatched grass houses, and unlike northern storehouses, which tended to be built underground, southern storehouses were elevated above ground on wooden and bamboo stilts.

This was because the south's moist ground made it impossible to preserve supplies in underground cellars. These elevated, wooden storehouses were extremely vulnerable to fire. So, Gao Jiong dispatched special forces to go around the state of Chen starting storehouse fires. The southerners would rebuild the structures after they were burned down, but soon after they'd be burned down again.

This constant harassment left the people of Chen in a state of desperate poverty. A passage from earlier in The Art of War says: ¡§An army without bases of supplies is lost." 'Burning stores' is about leaving your enemy without any supplies. 'Burning baggage trains' and 'burning depots' are both about burning the same kind of things: supplies.

The only difference is that the former is about burning supplies while they're being transported, while the latter is about burning them while they're in storage. Du Mu comments: ¡§Weapons, equipment, supplies, money and clothes; when in transit on wagons, it is referred to as 'baggage trains.' When in storage inside cities or camps, it is referred to as 'depots.' In both cases, the items are the same."
In the Battle of Guandu (200 CE) Cao Cao defeated Yuan Shao by burning his depots. The most important items under the umbrella of 'baggage trains' and 'depots' aren't limited to weapons and foodstuffs; money and its equivalents are also important.

Cao Cao wrote: ¡§If the army has no funds, the soldiers won't come." If you're unable to give soldiers cash rewards, you'll have a hard time fighting battles. There are a few different explanations for 'burning armed units.'
Li Quan comments: ¡§Burning enemy units' weaponry."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Burning enemy units' weaponry in order to seize their implements of war."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Burning enemy units' weaponry in order to render them disunified and lacking implements of war. Hence it is said: 'Without sharp weapons, it is difficult to contend with the enemy.'"
If you burn their flags, they have no signal system for relaying commands; if you burn their weapons, they can't fight.

It's just like in the movies, when soldiers sneak into the enemy camp while everyone's asleep and steal all the guns. When they have no guns, all you have to do is send in a single soldier with a gun, and the enemy soldiers will all surrender.

Jia Lin and He Shi's comments are different from the others. In their interpretation, 'army unit' should actually be translated as 'passages,' meaning 'roads.' So, the meaning becomes 'burn the enemy's supply routes and destroy their transport links.'
Other commentators say that it's about burning the enemy's logistical units, including transport facilities. So, what did Sun Tzu actually mean?

I tend to think it's about burning enemy units' weaponry, but General Guo Huaruo thinks it's about burning enemy supply routes. Sun Tzu can't stand up and tell us what the right answer is, but I think that if you manage to set fire to any of the suggestions above, you're doing well.

If you succeed at burning something of the enemy's, you've done a good job. If you don't, knowing what the right answer is won't do you any good. When you attack with fire, you're basically giving your enemy moxibustion therapy

Extract from the original text:
¡§In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available. The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness.

There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration. The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind."

Analysis:
¡§In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§The 'means' are 'guileful people.'" You need to plant agents on the inside. Li Quan also thinks it's about having men on the inside: ¡§The 'means' refers to placing guileful people within enemy ranks."
Chen Hao comments: ¡§You must command factors that are beneficial to you, not only 'guileful people.'" The key is to have the various things needed for war, not necessarily just men on the inside.

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§In any assault involving attack by fire, dry weather is a requirement. If the enemy's shelters and structures are built of grass or bamboo, if their stores are concentrated or kept close to undergrowth and brush, then make use of the wind to set fire to them."
In the previous historical example, we talked about how Lu Xun defeated Liu Bei by burning down his camps. This happened because Lu Xun realized that the other army's structures were built of grass and bamboo, and his stores were concentrated and kept close to undergrowth and brush.

In other words, all the preconditions that Sun Tzu mentions were there. When Zhu Wen was preparing to fight Zhu Xuan and Zhu Jin, their armies were positioned in an overgrown grassland. As soon as the wind changed, and began blowing towards Zhu Xuan and Zhu Jin, Zhu Wen seized his chance and started a fire.

In both of the cases above there was no need to plant a 'guileful man' on the inside. So, when Sun Tzu writes that ¡§in order to carry out an attack, we must have means available," the main point is that you need to have the preconditions in order, and you don't necessarily need an agent behind enemy lines. Situations that call for planting an agent often revolve around attacking cities.

An agent inside an enemy city can start fires as a way to spread chaos, and use the pandemonium as cover to open the city gates and let your soldiers come rushing in from outside. So, if you're defending a city and a fire starts inside your walls, the first thing to do is not to rush to put it out.

Instead, secure the gates as your first priority, because that fire was likely started by an enemy agent who's trying to distract you. ¡§The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Materials such as mugwort, reeds and rushes, dry grass, and oil must be prepared in advance. Methods which can be used to fight in this way include rockets, fire sickles, 'fire apricots,' 'fire troops,' 'fire animals,' 'fire birds,' 'fire bandits,' and 'fire crossbows.'"
'Fire rockets' are made by attaching a small pouch of oil to an arrow.

When you hit an enemy building or boat with a fire rocket, the oil pouch bursts, spraying the oil all around. Then, you ignite it by shooting a fire arrow at the same spot. Once a fire has started, you can shoot more fire rockets at the same spot to feed the flames and burn the target to ashes. 'Fire sickles' are objects used to make sparks and start fires.

It's called a 'sickle' because of its shape, which is curved. When you strike it with a flint, it makes sparks. 'Fire apricots' were another device used in ancient Chinese warfare to hit the enemy with fire. When besieging a city, the attackers would stuff a bundle of mugwort grass inside an apricot pit, light it, tie it onto a bird's foot, and let the bird go. The bird takes shelter under the eaves of a building, by which point the apricot pit has completely burned up and the flames catch on the building. With enough fire apricots, you can start fires at many locations, all over an enemy city. The mugwort grass used in fire apricots is the same as the mugwort used today in moxibustion therapy, a traditional Chinese medical treatment. It burns slowly and steadily, and the fire doesn't go out until there's no mugwort left to burn.

If you want to use fire as a weapon, mugwort is an essential item. When you attack with fire, you're basically giving your enemy moxibustion therapy. 'Fire birds' are used in combination with fire apricots.

They're a way to carry a fire source (the fire apricot) and weaponize it. 'Fire animals' employ the same approach as fire birds, using mugwort grass as a fire source. The idea is to catch a wild pig, deer or something similar, light the mugwort, tie it to the animal's neck and drive it towards the enemy camp. There's a story from the Spring and Autumn period of making a whole battle line with 'fire oxen.' The state of Yan had invaded the state of Qi, and had already captured over 70 towns and cities.

A Qi general named Tian Dan, who led the defense of the city of Jimo, gathered over 1,000 oxen, tied knives onto their horns and oil-dipped reeds to their tails, dressed them in colorful dragon pattern coats, and lit the reeds. Maddened by terrible pain, the oxen charged toward the Yan camp, closely followed by 5,000 of the best Qi warriors.

That charge smashed the Yan army to splinters, and soon after the 70 lost cities were recovered. But, does this count as an example of 'fire animals?' Perhaps this could be written up as one especially innovative way to use fire animals, but not what Sun Tzu originally meant. 'Fire bandits' are agents sent behind enemy lines to start fires.

'Fire troops' are cavalry units tasked with starting fires. Equipped with flammable materials and fire starters, they move directly into the enemy camp and set things ablaze. During the Battle of Guandu, Cao Cao personally led 5,000 infantry and cavalry with a bundle of grass for every man. Using the enemy commander Yuan Shao's own flag signals to conceal their identity, they advanced quickly along back roads, under the cover of night, and launched a surprise attack on the town of Wuchao.

When they arrived there, they immediately surrounded the place and attacked with fire. This is a classic example of using 'fire troops.'
'Fire crossbows' are basically a means of launching fire arrows. At night, prime the crossbows, set the tips of the arrows on fire, shoot several hundred of them at once into the enemy camp, wait for your opponents' supplies to burn and for their forces to descend into chaos...

and then attack. ¡§There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Do not use this indiscriminately."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§You must not use this randomly, but should wait for the right time."
Being able to start a fire depends on the weather. You can't just use fire whenever you want.

It's important to make sure that all the preconditions are in order, and only then to attack with fire. ¡§The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind."

Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When the weather is dry, it is easy to start fires." The right time to start a fire is when both the weather and the materials to be burned are completely dry. When choosing a day, you need to choose one when the moon is in either 'The Winnowing Basket,' 'The Wall,' 'The Wings,' or 'The Chariot,' all of which are names of constellations.

In ancient Chinese astronomy, 28 constellations were used as reference points when observing the positions of various celestial bodies.
