All 28 are close to the equator, and are divided into four groups of seven: 1) In the east, the Azure Dragon, consisting of The Horn, The Neck, The Root, The Room, The Heart, The Tail and The Winnowing Basket; 2) In the north, the Black Tortoise, consisting of The Dipper, The Ox, The Girl, The Emptiness, The Rooftop, The Encampment and the Wall; 3) In the west, the White Tiger, consisting of The Legs, The Bond, The Stomach, The Hairy Head, The Net, The Turtle Beak and The Three Stars; 4) And in the West, the Vermilion Bird, consisting of The Well, The Ghost, The Willow, The Star, The Extended Net, The Wings and The Chariot.

It was believed in ancient China that windy weather came while the moon was passing through The Winnowing Basket, The Wall, The Wings and The Chariot. Together, they were known as 'the four windy constellations.' There are similar myths in western culture - for example, the ancient Babylonian name for The Chariot was 'The Wind Star.'

Attacking by fire: Five changes

Extract from the original text:
¡§In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments: (1) When fire breaks out inside to enemy's camp, respond at once with an attack from without; (2) If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy's soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack; (3) If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment; (4) When you start a fire, be to windward of it. Do not attack from the leeward; (5) A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls.

In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days. Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength. By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed."

Analysis:
¡§In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments..."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§As the fire develops, maneuver your forces in response."
Whenever you use fire as part of an attack, you need to coordinate your troop movements with the fire as it develops. The 'five developments' correspond to the five ways of attacking with fire that we looked at earlier: burning personnel, burning stores, burning baggage trains, burning depots and burning enemy units.

So, how do you coordinate troop movements with fire? Sun Tzu writes about each of the five in turn, so it makes sense to explain the 'five possible developments (of attacking by fire)' one by one:

1. ¡§When fire breaks out inside the enemy's camp, respond at once with an attack from without."

Du Mu comments: ¡§In all cases involving fire, spread panic and confusion among the enemy and, availing yourself of this, strike.

It is not for nothing that fire is said to be a way to defeat one's enemies. As soon as you hear that a fire has started, attack immediately. If the fire is extinguished and the enemy soldiers are calm when you attack, then there is no advantage for you. Hence it is said 'respond at once.'"

When you use fire, you're not necessarily pinning all your hopes on literally burning the enemy to death. Use it to panic the enemy and then take advantage of the confusion to attack. You should move in as soon as you hear a disturbance in the enemy camp.

If you wait until the fire has been put out and the enemy soldiers have calmed down, you might as well not have started a fire in the first place. That's why you have to 'respond at once.'

2. ¡§If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy's soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack."

If a fire starts in the enemy camp but the enemy soldiers remain remarkably calm and quiet, that shows that the opposing general has tight control over his army, that his men are highly trained, and that they were prepared for this scenario. In this case, don't attack.

Wait for a while and try to make the fire bigger. If you see an opportunity, attack. If you don't, you'd better forget about it. There is no situation where the only good choice is to attack. Don't feel that you're wasting your time. It's a stronger move to waste your time than to take a beating and limp home, let alone taking a beating and getting trapped, unable to make your way home. If you can attack, then attack.

If you can't, don't. It's necessary to know when to stop. A general who by his nature can't accept the idea of getting no return on his work - who won't stop until he's had a 'proper fight' - is just lining up for defeat.

3. ¡§If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment."

If you start a fire from the outside, you don't need to plant an inside man.

All you have to do is choose the right time to start the fire. Li Quan comments: ¡§Cao Cao used this stratagem at the Battle of Guandu, to set fire to over ten thousand wagons in Yuan Shao's baggage train and defeat him. This demonstrates the meaning of this passage."

Du Mu comments: ¡§The preceding text says that the five developments of attacking by fire must occur within.

But if the enemy camp is situated in a grassy wilderness area, or if the camp's stockades of walls can be burned, then you must start a fire immediately rather than wait for an agent behind enemy lines to act.

Otherwise, there is a risk that the enemy will take the initiative to burn down the grass around his camp, depriving you of the opportunity to start a fire."

If the enemy pre-emptively burns down the grass around his camp, any fire you start won't be able to reach their camp. When a Han dynasty general named Li Ling fought a campaign against the Xiongnu, the Xiongnu forces started a fire upwind of his position. Li Ling rushed to burn down the grass around the perimeter of his camp so that the enemy's fire couldn't reach him. This is a method to rescue yourself from grassland wildfires.

During the final years of the Eastern Han dynasty, General Huangfu Song finally did battle with Bo Cai, a leader of the Yellow Turban Rebellion. Huangfu Song had taken a defensive position in the city of Changshe (located to the northeast of present-day Changge County City, in Henan Province), and Bo Cai came to lay siege to Changshe at the head of a large army. There were precious few soldiers in the Changshe garrison, and facing attackers who massively outnumbered them fear spread through the ranks of the city's defenders.

Huangpu Song declared: ¡§All manner of strange developments occur in war, and not because of one army having more or less troops than the other. The bandits who oppose us are currently encamped in a grassy area where a fire could easily be started with some assistance from the wind.

If a fire is lit under cover of night, then the enemy army is sure to fall into panic and mayhem. At that time, I will send out our forces to attack and we can thus recreate the effect of Tian Dan's 'fire oxen.'"

The weather was on his side.

That night, a strong wind began to blow. Huangpu Song ordered his men to take unlit torches and assemble atop the city walls, and then sent a squad of elite troops out of the city to start a fire and wildly yell and shout. Then, the men on the city walls lit their torches and joined in the shouting. Huangpu Song rode the momentum his men had created, sounding the war drums and charging forth. The Yellow Turbans panicked and fled in disarray.

4. ¡§When you start a fire, be to windward of it. Do not attack from the leeward."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§To do so would not be convenient."

Du Mu comments: ¡§If the wind blows from the east, then set the fire eastward of the enemy position. Then, launch an attack following the wind and come from the east. If the fire comes from the east, but you attack from the west, then you will suffer the fire's depredations just as the enemy does."

Du Mu's comment explains why Cao Cao says: ¡§To do so would be inconvenient."

Actually, it would be more than just inconvenient. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When you burn the enemy, they are sure to flee before the fire.

If you attack from the direction toward which they're fleeing, a fight to the death will surely ensue." If you stand between the enemy and their escape route away from the flames, they'll fight for their lives and almost certainly defeat you.

Think about it: when an 80-storey building catches fire, people jump from the windows to their certain death rather than being roasted alive. So, of course men fleeing from a fire would be prepared to fight like animals against anyone standing in their way.

That's why you set a fire from upwind and don't attack from downwind. You can attack from the same direction the fire is moving, or you can attack from the left or the right. Wang Xi comments: ¡§One may also strike the enemy's left or right flank."

During the chaos that enveloped China during the final years of the Sui dynasty, one of the warriors who rose up was a man named Liu Yuanjin. Liu proclaimed himself Son of Heaven, destined to be Emperor, and he commanded a powerful army.

To deal with him, Emperor Yang of Sui dispatched his general, Wang Shichong, but Wang was unable to best Liu in battle. Liu Yuanjin was adept at attacking with fire, and every one of his soldiers was always equipped with a handful of reeds because, as Su Tzu wrote, ¡§If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment." He kept his army ready to start a fire at a moment's notice. The two sides fought a significant battle at Yanling, where Wang Shichong's men were so startled by the fire Liu Yuanjin started that they were about to abandon their camp and flee.

Suddenly, the wind changed and began driving the fire back towards Liu's own army. Liu's camp was burned down and Wang Shichong took advantage of this opportunity to take the fight to his enemy, inflicting a heavy defeat on Liu Yuanjin. Liu never recovered from this setback, suffered a string of defeats, and was eventually beheaded by Wang Shichong. When you use fire as a weapon, remember that the wind can change.

5. ¡§A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls."

This observation comes from experience. Cao Cao comments: ¡§One should be mindful of this."

There's a passage from Lao Tzu's Tao Te Ching that reads: ¡§High winds do not last all morning. Heavy rain does not last all day." It means that anything that moves with frenzied force will not last long.

¡§One should be mindful of this."

Wind and rain, an army's morale, a man's vigilance - all of these things are variable, and none of them are unlimited. The art of war is about studying, understanding, balancing and making use of the ebb and flow of these 'variables,' both in your own army and in the enemy's. ¡§In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days."

So, it's necessary to understand the five different changes that can occur when using fire, stay mindful of these changes and take a flexible approach to using fire. ¡§Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength.

By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed."

This is saying that it's better to attack with fire than with water. ¡§Those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence." Clearly, generals who use fire to aid their attack gain an easier path to victory. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§One can understand how to easily secure victory."
¡§Those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength." It is possible to strengthen your attacking position by using water as an aid. So, if you can use fire, you can understand how to win easily, while using water merely strengthens your attack.

Why? ¡§By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed." Water can be used to cut off an enemy army's movements, but it can't deprive them of their supply stores. But what exactly is the meaning of 'robbed' in this passage? According to all 11 of our commentators, it means 'robbed of their stores.'
Cao Cao comments: ¡§By using water as an aid, one can sever supply routes and separate enemy forces, but one cannot rob the enemy of their stores." Unlike fire, water cannot burn the enemy's grain and wagons. Personally, I think that the objects being 'robbed' also include the lives of enemy troops.

Fire's 
'killing power' is much greater than water's. Many people can swim, but I've never heard of anyone who can swim through fire. When Japan invaded China in the 1930s, Chiang Kai-shek blew up the levees on the Yellow River at Huayuankou, which only succeeded in slightly delaying the Japanese army and came at a massive cost in lives of the Chinese people. A lot of stories that involve attacking with water should be taken with a grain of salt.

For example, the story of Han Xin drowning Long Qie's army - which was cited earlier in the book - is very suspect. According to the tale, Han Xin ordered his soldiers to dam a river using over 10,000 sandbags. While Long Qie's army was crossing the depleted river downstream, Han Xin ordered his men to remove the sandbags, releasing the river and drowning Long Qie's men. Zeng Guofan researched this story and came to the conclusion that it was physically impossible.

If it were possible, Zeng would have very much liked to use the stratagem himself. As noted previously, how could it possible to build a dam capable of holding back enough water to drown a large army with sandbags, and then tear it down with just a few moments' work? In hydropower station construction, completing a dam capable of holding back the water is a major engineering project - how could something like that be accomplished with a group of men carrying sandbags? Even if it were possible to build a dam in this way, it would never have been possible to demolish it at a moment's notice.

Gunpowder, which could conceivably have been used to blast open a dam, hadn't yet been invented. It would, however, be possible to drown an enemy city if you could surround it and channel a river into the city. During the Spring and Autumn period, Zhi Bo of Jin once coerced the noble houses of Han and Wei into surrounding the house of Zhao, and channeled the Fen River in an attempt to submerge the city of Jincheng. However, Zhi Bo didn't get his way in the end.

The Zhao leaders persuaded the leaders of Han and Wei to unite, and together they destroyed Zhi Bo. Ultimately, the state of Jin was divided between the three noble houses and became the states of Han, Wei and Zhao, which were three of the seven contending states during the Warring States period. In conclusion, fire is fast and water is slow.

The key to winning a fight: Can you afford to win? Being able to afford victory is just as important as being able to afford to lose. If you win a battle but can't afford victory, you're in serious trouble. That's why generals who always win end up dead.

As we've said so often, the key is to settle the war with a single battle. Extract from the original text:
¡§Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation. Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources.

Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are.

Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by contentment. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life.

Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution. This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact."

Analysis:
¡§Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation."
Our 11 commentators seem to have agreed on how to interpret 'cultivating the spirit of enterprise' and 'waste and general stagnation.' They explain it as referring to a situation where, after a battle, the general doesn't hand out rewards quickly enough, which leaves the soldiers wondering what they're supposed to do. The army becomes stuck, unable to return home, and all the while the money dwindles and the troops grow old waiting.

Cao Cao was the first commentator, and his interpretation may have influenced the others' observations. Cao Cao comments: ¡§Just like water that flows away, it is impossible to return things to their previous state. It could also be expressed like this: the rewards are not dispensed in a timely manner; to make effective use of rewards, one cannot delay until the next day."
Cao Cao is saying that you have to give out rewards on the same day as the battle. Any delay will lead to waste and 'general stagnation.'
Comments by Li Quan, Jia Lin, Du Mu and Zhang Yu are almost the same as Cao Cao's, although with one or two minor differences.

Later scholars weren't satisfied with this interpretation, and neither am I. The 'spirit of enterprise' that must be cultivated isn't just about rewarding soldiers for their service; this is only one small part of it. What this passage is really about is consolidating gains after battle and clarifying the political situation.

It bodes poorly for any general to not consolidate his gains after winning a battle, or to fail to clarify the political situation. It will lead to disaster 'waste and general stagnation' - in other words, disaster.

After winning a battle, it's crucial to win the political battle. Otherwise, the 'victory' you just won on the battlefield will turn into a disaster. Active battlegrounds are quagmires, and when the fighting's done they become black holes, sucking up your money and your troops' stamina.

If you stay there, you're setting yourself up for catastrophe. A classic example of 'waste and general stagnation' is the Wu invasion of Chu during the Spring and Autumn period. Sun Tzu himself was involved in the war.

King Helu of Wu came to power by killing King Liao and seizing the throne. He was an enthusiastic reformer, and his army grew stronger. He went head to head with the state of Chu, aiming to become the dominant power among the various Chinese states.

In the third year of his reign, he invaded Chu together with the strategists Wu Zixu, Bo Pi and Sun Tzu. They won a great victory, and King Helu want to push on immediately and capture the city of Ying, capital of Chu.

But, Sun Tzu told him that the people were worn out, and the time was not right to attack Ying. They should wait for an opportunity. Only when Sun Tzu spoke out did King Helu let go of his burning desire to move on Ying immediately. Wu scored two more major victories over Chu, once in the fourth year of King Helu's reign and again during the sixth year. Between these campaigns, Wu also defeated the state of Yue during the fifth year of the king's reign.

By the ninth year of his reign, King Helu could no longer hold himself back. He went for advice to Wu Zixu and Sun Tzu: ¡§You both were against invading Ying all those years back. Well, what about now?" Wu Zixu and Sun Tzu were unanimous: if alliances with the states of Tang and Cai could be secured, an invasion of Ying could go ahead. The Wu army once again invaded Chu, and this time took the city of Ying in one fell swoop. The King of Chu fled his country, and this became the first example of a state capturing the capital city of another major state during the Spring and Autumn period. The war between Wu and Chu lasted nine years.

What was the prevailing state of affairs? Waste and general stagnation. Why? Because the sole focus was war; nobody was thinking about politics. Not only did King Helu fail to take any political action or 'cultivate the spirit of enterprise' after occupying Chu, he didn't even have a coherent approach to politics in his own country. While he wallowed in waste and stagnation in the city of Ying, the leaders of Yue saw their chance and invaded Wu.

Meanwhile, the remaining Chu forces requested assistance from the state of Qin, whose leaders sent their army to attack the Wu forces. Fighting a war on two fronts, the Wu forces were defeated in their battles against both the Qin and the Yue forces. Helu's younger brother, Fugai, saw how Helu was idling away his time in Ying, with no intention of returning to Wu, so he went back alone and proclaimed himself the new king. With the country in chaos, Helu rushed back from the city of Ying with his army to attack Fugai, which allowed the Chu forces to retake the now empty city of Ying. Fugai, coming under attack from his older brother, fled and surrendered to the Chu authorities. After years of war, Helu had nothing to show for it.

Despite that, he invaded Chu again the very next year and won another big victory. Helu's army was always a force to be reckoned with. Its power reverberated across the lands of China. However, nothing lasts forever. In the 19th year of King Helu's reign he suffered a serious injury while fighting against Yue forces, and later died of his wounds. He was succeeded by his son, Fuchai. When Helu was on his deathbed, he told Fuchai to never forget the man who killed his father - King Gou Jian of Yue. The story of Fuchai and Gou Jian is well known among Chinese people.

It ends with Fuchai and his country being destroyed by Gou Jian, making Wu one of the first major states during the Spring and Autumn period to be tossed into the dustbin of history. ¡§Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise." The most classic example of this is the state of Wu, from the same time period as Sun Tzu's life. In ancient China, there was the idea that 'He who wins many victories is doomed.' If you win 100 battles, you're going to die.

Isn't that a strange idea? This saying actually originated as a comment on the state of Wu. Marquess Wen of Wei once said to Li Ke: ¡§Why was the state of Wu destroyed?" Li Ke replied: ¡§Because Wu fought many battles and won many victories." Marquess Wen said: ¡§It is a blessing for a country to fight many battles and win many victories. So why was the state of Wu defeated?" Li Ke told him: ¡§Many battles make the people poor; many victories make the lord arrogant. The state of Wu was destroyed because an arrogant lord ruled over an impoverished people."
The strategist Wu Qi had a similar understanding:
¡§Attacking and winning is easy, maintaining one's victorious position is difficult. Hence it is said: 'Among all the warring states of the world, those who win five victories suffer great catastrophe, those who win four victories face many problems, those who win three victories become regional hegemons, those who win two victories become king, those who win one victory become Emperor.' Hence, rare are those states who conquer the world by winning many victories, yet many such states suffer destruction."
Xiang Yu fought and won dozens of battles, while his rival Liu Bang only won a single battle, at Gaixia. Attacking and winning is easy; maintaining one's victorious position is difficult.

This is the case today for the United States. Invading Iraq was as easy as cutting up a rotten tree, but holding onto victory is another story. The US has been unable to hold its position in Iraq, in Libya, and indeed anywhere else.

In Iraq, America fell into 'waste and general stagnation.' Obama was unwilling to stay mired in this state because it would only lead to more losses. But if you have a girlfriend, you can't just break off your relationship the moment you feel like it, and you certainly can't undo the invasion of a foreign country the moment you feel like it.

These conflicts started with chaotic invasions and ended with the United States running away. Victory isn't easy! ¡§Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources. Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are.

Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by content. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life. Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution. This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact."

So, a wise ruler thinks through these things very carefully, and exceptional generals are obligated to do their research thoroughly. If there's no benefit to be gained, don't take action.

Don't raise an army if you can't win, and don't fight unless the situation demands it. Rulers can't go on the warpath just because they're angry, nor can generals start a battle merely because they're enraged. Action should only be taken if there's some benefit to be gained for the country, and war should be stopped the moment it becomes unbeneficial for the country. Joy can be restored after an episode of anger, but a destroyed country cannot be revived, and the dead cannot be brought back to life.

A wise ruler has to be cautious and a good general has to stay vigilant. This is the only way to keep your country safe and your army intact! Sun Tzu said: ¡§There are five ways of attacking with fire. The first is to burn soldiers in their camp; the second is to burn stores; the third is to burn baggage trains; the fourth is to burn depots; the fifth is to hurl dropping fire amongst enemy units.

In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available. The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness. There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration. The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind. In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments: (1) When fire breaks out inside the enemy's camp, respond at once with an attack from without; (2) If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy's soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack; (3) If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment; (4) When you start a fire, be to windward of it - do not attack from the leeward; (5) A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls.

In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days. Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength.

By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed. Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation. Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources. Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are.

Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by contentment. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life. Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution.
This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact."

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Giving money to other people isn't the same as stating their value; It's stating your own value

Extract from the original text:
¡§Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor. Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy's condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory. Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits; it cannot be obtained inductively from experience, nor by any deductive calculation. Knowledge of the enemy's dispositions can only be obtained from other men."

Analysis:
Cao Cao's first comment is about 'the use of spies.' ¡§Those engaged in warfare," he wrote, ¡§must use spies in order to learn the actual situation of the enemy."

¡§Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor."

Cao Cao comments: ¡§In ancient times, eight households formed one lin. In each lin, one household would contribute soldiers for the army, and the remaining seven would work in supporting roles. This passage says than when an army of 100,000 soldiers is raised, 700,000 households will be left unable to farm their fields."
Why did one lin consist of eight households? Du Mu comments: ¡§In ancient times, the amount of land one man could farm was called one qing.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
In any area of nine qing, a well would be dug and dwellings erected in the center-most qing. Eight households would live and farm there, and this area was called a well field. This passage says that 700,000 households will suffer exhaustion on the roads while transporting supplies."
The well field that Du Mu mentions is not quite the same as the 'well field system' that Chinese middle school pupils learn about in history class. In history textbooks, the well field system is explained as being a way of dividing land into sets of nine squares, organized in a grid.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The size of each square was 100 mu, and the eight squares along the perimeter of the grid were privately owned and farmed by individual families - one per household. The central square was common land.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The eight families had to finish working the common land before they could start farming their own private squares. The harvest from the private squares was kept by the families, while the harvest from the common land went to the state.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But 'the state' back then wasn't the same as now. It didn't refer to the whole country, but to noble houses like those of Duke Mu of Qin and Duke Xiang of Song. But what's the difference between this and what Du Mu said? According to Du Mu, the center-most square wasn't common land, but comprised the village where the eight families had their houses, their well, and other communal facilities. There's no way to verify whether the well field system of the Zhou dynasty consisted of private fields surrounding one common field.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Personally, I have my doubts. For example, the idea of one common field where everyone works together is similar to the People's Communes of the collective agriculture era, beginning in the 1950s. In this system, it's difficult to monitor and control how much work and effort each person is contributing.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Also, why should the harvest from the central common field go to the state? What if there's a good harvest for the private fields, but a poor harvest for the common field? It's vastly better to just collect tax from each family. That's why I tend to think that the well field system wasn't just about drawing up a nine-square grid (in the shape of the character for 'well,' ¤«). I agree with Du Mu's description - farmland around the perimeter with a well and village in the middle.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Eight families in one well field; one family provides soldiers, the remaining seven provide labor and help transporting supplies. So, in total, an army of 100,000 soldiers actually requires the labor of 700,000 families.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is a massive expense. The expense of mounting a war was covered in great detail in Chapter Two, Waging War. Here, Sun Tzu emphasizes it once more, showing that his value system involves being extremely cautious in matters involving expenses of war and the cost of victory.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is quite different for some people today, who say 'no matter the cost' without thinking. Deng Xiaoping put it succinctly when he said: ¡§People say so many empty words." Everything has a cost. The most important calculation to make, whenever you want to do something, is to estimate the cost.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
If there's a potential profit, go ahead. If not, quit while you're ahead. ¡§Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy's condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity. One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory."

What a resource-intensive thing war is!

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Armies really do spend years lined up opposite one another, all for the sake of a single day, the day of victory! If you accept the massive expense of keeping an army in the field day after day, yet remain clueless about what's going on in the enemy camp just because you can't bring yourself to spend money on spies, you are a supremely irresponsible - and even inhumane - general. You're not a pillar of your country, and you're definitely not a 'master of victory.'
Sun Tzu put 'the height of inhumanity' at the top of the list of negative adjectives that describe such behavior, because a general who acts in this way shows disregard for the good of his country and his people. The core values in The Art of War are 'use benevolence' and 'take whatever action the situation calls for.' For any student, it's necessary to remember that benevolence and humanity come first, and 'taking whatever action the situation calls for' comes last.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Too often, people think that the art of war is essentially about doing whatever is necessary, including using underhanded tricks. If that's your interpretation, you'll never really understand the art of war. During the Chu-Han Contention, nobody was more willing to spend money than Liu Bang, and nobody was more reluctant to spend money than Xiang Yu. As the war reached its most intense phase, Xiang Yu trapped Liu Bang behind the walls of Xingyang city.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Liu Bang spent a year unable to free himself and totally cut off from reinforcement and supplies. But his advisor, Chen Ping, had a plan - he told Liu Bang to take 40,000 jin of gold from his reserves and bribe some of the Chu generals. The idea was to spread division among the Chu ranks and create distance between Xiang Yu and his general, Zhong Limei, while also removing General Fan Zeng from Xiang Yu's inner circle. In the end, by making these strategic expenditures, Liu Bang was able to break out from Xiang Yu's siege. Years later, when Liu Bang was surrounded by the Xiongyu chieftain Modun's forces at Baideng, Chen Ping once again came forward with a plan: to offer a large bribe to Modun's wife and have her persuade Modun to let Liu Bang go. Xiang Yu and Liu Bang were on opposite ends of the spectrum when it came to the value they attached to spending money.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Xiang Yu had the ability to truly love his people, as if they were his own children, but he had even greater love for the people's money. Han Xin gives us some particularly vivid musings about Xiang Yu: ¡§When King Xiang saw his people he bestowed compassion, respect and love; he spoke softly to them and whenever one of his people fell ill he would weep and sob and feed them with his own food.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
When a subject performed some good deed meriting reward of noble title, he would carve an official seal to mark the ennoblement, yet feel loathe to give it to his subject. This is what is known as 'the benevolence of a woman.'"
If you have a problem that can be dealt with by just spending money, that's always the lowest-cost solution.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
If you spend more money on spies than on anything else, it's also the most cost-saving investment you could make. Zhang Yu comments: ¡§When armies spend long periods of time facing one another in the field and 700,000 households exhaust their wealth and their strength, if the leader has no care for these expenses and yet begrudges the cost of dispensing rewards and noble titles to spies who uncover information about the enemy, then this is the height of inhumanity."
This idea seems simple, when you read it in a book. But, in reality, it's extremely difficult to apply it in your work process.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
In fact, it's the hardest part of all. What makes it so difficult? The problem is human nature. Specifically, four types of mentality get in the way:
Mentality type one: You've gotten used to spending large sums of money on certain expenses without thinking about it, but any additional small expenses that aren't in your budget make you feel extremely uneasy, to the point that you're completely unable to spend these small sums. For example, if you're spending money every day on 700,000 households, perhaps one piece of gold per household, that adds up to 700,000 pieces of gold per day.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: And yet, you don't mentally register this expense. It seems like a river - it's just there, and it just keeps flowing. But, if you're called upon to spend an extra 50,000 per day, you won't even consider doing it.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Mentality type two: You keep track of other people's money, but not your own. You don't keep track of your own expenses, and you don't even know how much money you're spending every day on the 700,000 men working for you.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But, you do keep a close eye on other people's money. When dealing with people you work with, you have thoughts like: 'So, you're really asking for this much money? Do you really have a good reason for asking me for this much?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Are you really worth that much to me? Does it match the value you've given me?' You don't take it well when people ask for money. You feel resentful and reluctant, and you'd rather make things harder for yourself than let others take advantage of you financially. Xiang Yu is a classic example of this mentality.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In his mind, his followers were freeloaders profiting from his military success, and he thought they had no right to want rewards from him. There's one cure for this mentality: understand that giving other people money doesn't mean you're making a statement about their value - it's actually a statement about your own value.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: You need to give people a lot of money not because they're extremely valuable, but because you're extremely valuable, and the things you're trying to accomplish are extremely valuable. It's like a large corporation that spends a billion dollars to acquire a start-up company, even if the acquisition target has only been running for a year or less and may not even be generating income.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Is the start-up really worth a billion dollars? The deal would instantly make the start-up founder richer than the CEO of the corporation that's acquiring it. However, if the corporation doesn't buy the start-up today, tomorrow it might become a competitor and completely overturn your whole market.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: From that perspective, a billion dollars suddenly seems like a bargain! Mentality type three: How do I know it's the right move to give that person the money? It's possible that I'll ultimately realize I gave away my money for something that has no value, or that I gave it to the wrong person entirely!

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: For example, imagine giving an enemy general a sum of money as a bribe, but after taking your payoff he still refuses to turn against his commander. In your attempt to sow division among the enemy, you've actually played into your opponent's hands and caused division in your own organization.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, hasn't the money you spent actually made your situation worse? This is an extremely common mentality. It seems to be rational, but in fact it's a dead end. You should have started off by considering the possibility that spending the money might lead you into a trap. If there were 100% certainty that you could solve your problem by spending money, it would be too easy! The world's not that simple.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Spending money is sometimes just a way of creating or eliminating certain possible outcomes. There's never a guaranteed outcome. Consider again the example of the big corporation acquiring the small start-up. There's every chance that if the corporation didn't acquire it, the new business would never take off and would never become a competitive threat. Or, a similar start-up might spring up the day after the first one had been acquired.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In both cases, there's nothing to be done about it, because the start-up is simply worth too much money. Mentality type four: I only want to spend my money where it really counts. There's an especially effective antidote for this mentality: to believe that the only way to 'spend money where it really counts' is to spend on things that you don't want to spend money on. The only way to increase the odds of spending money where it counts is to spread your spending over a wide enough area. If you succeed in spending just one percent of your money where it counts - on the cutting edge of your operations -it will yield a thousand-fold in return.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The principle is exactly the same as in investing. Putting long-term work into large-scale angel investing is an integral part of business intelligence-gathering operations. If you want to spend all of your money 'where it really counts,' you're deluding yourself.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
It will never happen. ¡§Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§The lord does not move recklessly. When he moves, he is certain of vanquishing the foe.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
The general does not act negligently in the pursuit of achievements, and so he is sure to achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men. What makes these things possible? Foreknowledge of the enemy's situation."
A famous general of the Northern Zhou dynasty (557-581 CE), Cavalry General-in-Chief Wei Xiaokuan, led the defence of Yubi Fortress. His greatest skill was keeping the people he worked with happy, and he also knew how to make good use of spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: All of the agents he sent to spy on the state of Northern Qi knew how to execute commands and complete tasks to the best of their ability. There were also subjects of Northern Qi who took his money and passed on information, which helped keep the Northern Zhou fully informed on the latest happenings in Northern Qi. Wei Xiaokuan sent one of his men, a high-ranking general named Xu Pen, to take command of the garrison in a key city. Wei Xiaokuan trusted this man completely, but to his surprise Xu Pen surrendered himself and the city he was responsible for to the Northern Qi authorities. Wei Xiaokuan was enraged, and sent an agent to assassinate Xu Pen. The assassin soon returned, carrying Xu Pen's head.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Clearly, Wei Xiaokuan had the ability to use spies to accomplish anything his heart desired. ¡§Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits..."

If you want to understand what's going on, you mustn't use divination or ask ghosts and spirits to help you.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
¡§... it cannot be obtained inductively from experience..."

You can't make assumptions by drawing on parallels between the current situation and your past experiences. Du Mu comments: ¡§This is about analogy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This passage says that you cannot seek to compare different situations using analogy." This is an important comment, with a lot of information to unpack. Throughout Chinese history, analogies have always been one of the favorite tools of political advisors and lobbyists, and the same is true today in commercial advertising. For example, in one toothpaste advertisement, an analogy is made between winter snow covering trees in a white coat and the ability of toothpaste to prevent tooth decay. But, what's the connection between these two things?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Actually, there's no connection at all. Can the analogy prove that this brand of toothpaste can prevent tooth decay? Not in the slightest. However, the connection seems reasonable on the surface, and the visual impact of the image makes a strong impression.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Sparkling, white teeth appear to be clean, healthy and strong. This is the influence analogies can have on people's thinking. So, when the time comes for us to make a major decision, it's necessary to cleanse yourself of the influence of analogy-based thinking. In meetings, speak with precision and discuss each agenda item only in terms of its own merits. Don't allow anyone to use analogies, because they can stealthily divert the conversation and make it about something else entirely.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
They can make people deceive themselves and pass the deception on to others. ¡§... nor by any deductive calculation."

This is another line that has been interpreted in different ways. Cao Cao comments: ¡§It cannot be gauged by reference to other things." You can't use the normal way of things, or patterns you have observed from your own experience, to make predictions about what will happen, because exceptions to any rule are always possible.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In fact, Cao Cao got this one wrong in his own career. During the Battle of Red Cliffs, he deployed his boats in a long, linked-up line. When his men reminded him to take precautions, in case the enemy attacked with fire, he gauged the situation 'with reference to other things' - he said that because it was winter the wind wouldn't blow from the southeast.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In the end, though, that's exactly what happened. Li Quan comments: ¡§Here, 'calculation' refers to counting and measuring. This passage could be referring to counting and measuring anything, including length, width, distance and size.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
People's emotions are fickle, and it is impossible to gain knowledge from counting and measuring."
The later commentators all said more or less the same thing, but none of them asked the most crucial question. Namely, what is 'counting and measuring?'
Later scholars offer an explanation, suggesting that 'counting and measuring' is about measuring the movements (positions) of the sun, moon and stars.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Their explanation for this line is that you can't use the positions of celestial bodies to learn about the enemy's situation. In the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, we often see Zhuge Liang spending his nights stargazing and trying to calculate whether the heavens are showing him omens fair or ill. But, Sun Tzu's The Art of War tells us, this is not reliable.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, the ancient leaders understood all of this, and none of them indulged in superstition. They recognized that 'Knowledge of the enemy's dispositions can only be obtained from other men.' In other words, the only way to gain this knowledge is to have eyes and ears on the ground.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: When you read and study, you need to ground yourself in the correct values. From the explanations we've seen about the meaning of 'deductive calculations,' we know there are various ways to understand it. There's making deductions based on 'the normal way of things,' counting and measuring data, and reading the stars.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But which one is right? It's actually not important which one is 'right.' Each provides a different perspective from which to look at problems, and each of these perspectives is extremely valuable - they lead us to think and reflect, and through them we can learn many new things.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Many people look for the answer to this question by analyzing, critiquing and cross-referencing other ancient texts. Yet, all such attempts can only unearth different usages for the word translated as 'deductive calculation,' which they then insert into this passage of The Art of War. You can't say that the old writers were wrong, and presume to come up with a new 'correct answer.' The Ming dynasty philosopher Wang Yangming addressed precisely this problem.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
He said that reading and studying are about what you can get out of them, not about trying to find the 'right answer' by digging through reams of ancient writings. Five ways to use spies (parts one, two, and three): All doubts ultimately are doubts you have about yourself

Extract from the original text:
¡§Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies. When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is called 'divine manipulation of the threads.' It is the sovereign's most precious faculty. Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district. Having inward spies means making use of the enemy's own officials.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Having converted spies means getting hold of the enemy's spies and using them for our own purposes. Having doomed spies refers to doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy. Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy's camp."

Analysis:
¡§Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system. This is called 'divine manipulation of the threads.' It is the sovereign's most precious faculty."
When you use these five types of spies simultaneously, the enemy is unable to work out how information is leaking out. ¡§Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district."

Our 11 commentators' remarks about 'inhabitants of a district' are simple.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
They don't go out of their way to explain what it means - it just means local people in the enemy's country. Du Mu comments: ¡§Village people of the enemy's country."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Avail yourself of the country's people and make use of them by providing them with benefits."
Jia Lin comments: ¡§Interpret 'local spies' as 'enemy villagers.'"
However, General Guo Huaruo has his own, differing explanation. He says that the word translated here as 'local' (xiang) had different meaning in the ancient Chinese language of the Spring and Autumn period.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: According to General Guo, it refers to the enemy's local government officials and noblemen. In the state of Qi, such people were referred to as xiang liangren, and in the state of Song they were called xiang zheng. According to a subchapter in The Rites of Zhou, entitled Xiang Dafu, those who held the official rank of 'xiang dafu' were positioned between the Minister of Education and the Rural Officer.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: General Guo's explanation makes an important contribution. He asserted that for a spy to be capable of producing valuable intelligence, they have to have a certain level of status and involvement in local affairs. A good example of someone who knew how to use local spies is Zu Ti, well known in China for his strong work ethic. Zu Ti came from a high-status northern family, but then the Uprising of the Five Barbarians turned the Chinese world upside down.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The Han Chinese people of northern China fled south, the Western Jin dynasty ended, and the Eastern Jin dynasty took its place. Zu Ti was possessed by a burning desire to retake the Central Plain from the barbarians.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He was optimistic by nature, much more interested in justice and righteousness than the details of finance. He was also a hard worker, devoted both to academic studies and military training, and an accomplished warrior and thinker. Zu TI was brave, wise and inspired trust in all around him. Zu Ti loved his men, and in return his men pledged their lives to him. There was no 'principal' he wasn't willing to set aside for the sake of his soldiers.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: His army was sizeable, and included no shortage of rogues and thieves. When famine broke out in Yang Prefecture, some soldiers went around robbing rich families, and when they were occasionally arrested by local authorities, Zu Ti used his local connections to secure their release. Not only did he not criticize them, he would even say things like: ¡§How about we go down to Nantang and do a heist together?" These actions ensured that every soldier in the land thought their lives would be complete if only they could serve under Zu Ti. Leaders like Zu Ti, who form close, even brotherly, bonds with their men and are able to make their soldiers absolutely committed to them, are only suited to being regional strongmen. They can never become Emperor, or even a major court minister or advisor.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: If an Emperor or a prime minister treated the men under their command as their own brothers, willing to cover for their illegal behavior and sloppy discipline - as long as they do whatever is asked of them and ask no questions - they're indulging in corruption in exchange for loyalty. They are in effect governing their country using corruption, and the country will fall.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: A good example of this is Emperor Wu of Liang. Zu Ti eventually became a target of the court's jealousy and suspicion, and later died in a cloud of anger and resentment. Is it any wonder that a lawless maverick like Zu Ti would attract the enmity of others? Looking back for a moment at how Zu Ti made use of 'local spies,' he treated them the same way as his own men, like they were his sworn brothers. His attitude was that, as long as you're with me, I'll protect you no matter what.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: While Zu Ti was serving as Governor of Yu Prefecture, he shared a border with Shi Le of the Later Zhao dynasty. China was experiencing a chaotic period at the time, and in the borderlands of the Jin and Zhao states (in modern-day Henan Province), the local strongmen were focused only on protecting their own necks. The border fort commanders all had sons living in Zhao captivity as hostages, so Zu Ti made exceptions for them and let them maintain good relations on both sides of the border. He treated them with special courtesy and got them to provide him with intelligence from contacts in Later Zhao. Occasionally, he would launch a pretend attack against one of the Jin forts to show the Later Zhao authorities that the garrisons had nothing to do with him. Because of this, the fort commanders felt extremely grateful to Zu Ti, so they kept him up to date on all the latest happenings across the border, in the lands of Later Zhao.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
This was a major factor in Zu Ti's success in retaking large swathes of land in the Henan area. ¡§Having inward spies means making use of the enemy's own officials."

Du Mu wrote about seven types of people, and the categories he came up with can be applied to 'inward spies.' Here are his descriptions of the types of officials who might be co-opted:
1. Among enemy officials, there are capable men who have lost their posts.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: 2. There are those who have made mistakes and been punished. 3. There are those who harbor proclivities or lust after wealth. 4. There are those who are wasting away in lowly positions. 5. There are those who are unable to secure appointments as envoys.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: 6. There are those who, having suffered defeat and loss, develop their talents and skills. There are deceptive turncoats who habitually act as double agents.7. Du Mu comments: ¡§You may secretly approach all of these types of officials and make enquiries.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Give them generous presents of gold and silks to form ties with them. In order to acquire intelligence from their country, and investigate any schemes they may be plotting against you, make repeated enquiries about their lord, and the ministers of their country, and spread disharmony in their country."
You can find all kinds of people among enemy officials: talented men who have made mistakes and whose career is in jeopardy as a result; people who've been punished and feel resentful; those whose father was punished and as a result of this face roadblocks in their own career. There will be those who are particularly fond of their wives or concubines, or who have some other 'special interest,' and who are also hungry for money.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Some will be unsatisfied with their station in life; some feel blocked from realizing their potential; others want their own side to lose because they think it's the only way they'll get opportunities.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
And, there are individuals who are constantly changing sides. All of these types of men can be turned into 'inward spies.'
However, if you decide to use 'inward spies,' understand that the enemy will try to put on shows for you. For example, when Zhou Yu attacked Huang Gai, he only did it so that Cao Cao would see him doing it.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It made Cao Cao think that Huang Gai would be filled with hate and willing to surrender to him; that his defenses would be lowered. In the end, this led to Cao Cao's ships being burned by Huang Gai at Red Cliffs. Sun Tzu himself once fell prey to enemies taking advantage of some of his officials' fondness for money and other interests to bribe them. Fuchai of Wu had surrounded Gou Jian of Yue and 5,000 exhausted Yue troops, remnants of a defeated army, at Huiji Mountain. Yue's destruction seemed imminent. At the time, there were three high-ranking advisors in King Fuchai's entourage: Wu Zixu, Sun Tzu and Bo Pi. Gou Jian sent a messenger to tell King Fuchai that he wanted to surrender, but Wu Zixu urged Fuchai not to give Gou Jian any chances. He advised destroying Yue outright. Meanwhile, Gou Jian sent a man named Wen Zhong to bribe Bo Pi with gold and beautiful women, and to tell him that, despite appearances suggesting that Yue was surrendering to King Fuchai, the real surrender was actually being offered to him, Bo Pi. Wen Zhong also told Bo Pi that, from then on, any time gold, silks or women were sent to the Wu king, Bo Pi would get the first pick. The wealth of Yue was to be at Bo Pi's disposal.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This convinced Bo Pi to throw all his strength into assisting Yue. There are certain skills that dishonest advisors have and loyal advisors don't. The King of Wu ignored Wu Zixu's and Sun Tzu's counsel on this matter.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He gave his ear exclusively to Bo Pi. Later, Bo Pi worked together with Gou Jian to murder Wu Zixu, despite the favor Wu Zixu had done Bo Pi by recommending him to the King of Wu when Bo Pi had fallen on hard times. The reason Gou Jian later had the nerve to deliver himself as a hostage to the Kingdom of Wu, in a bid to lull Fuchai into a false sense of security, was to a large extent because he had Bo Pi's protection. Again, it was Bo Pi who later persuaded Fuchai to release Gou Jian and give him safe passage back home to Yue. And, it was through Bo Pi that Gou Jian sent two famously beautiful women, Xi Shi and Zheng Dan, as gifts to Fuchai. It was also Bo Pi who caused Fuchai to squander his people's energy and his kingdom's riches by not only suggesting that he rebuild the Gusu Tower, but also arranging for the finest Yue timber to be made available for the job. Gou Jian made full use of spies, and he used almost the entire contents of The Art of War.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He embraced the notion that 'all warfare is based on deception' in Chapter One, Calculations, through to the concepts of 'make yourself weak to make the enemy arrogant... if he is taking his ease give him no rest...

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: and if his forces are united, separate them.' Sun Tzu was left with no moves to make; all he could do was watch wide-eyed as the kingdom of Wu was destroyed. Spies were also a factor in LI Shimin's defeat of Dou Jiande.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Li Shimin had surrounded Wang Shichong and Dou Jiande was on the move, intending to rescue Wang. Li Shimin seized the initiative by taking Hulao Pass, and Dou Jiande was unable to break through Li's position. Each time Dou attacked the pass, Li's soldiers came charging out to beat them back. Dou's forces suffered many casualties. Li Shimin weak spot was his fear that Dou Jiande would refuse to fight him at Hulao Pass and instead turn around and attack him from the rear. Doesn't The Art of War talk precisely about this?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Sun Tzu made it clear that when the enemy has control of 'contentious ground,' don't attack. Instead, you should lead your army away and attack places and things that are important to your opponent, which he's bound to defend.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Draw the enemy out and then ambush him on the road. So what if Li had control of Hulao Pass? Dou should have just left him to it. This is clearly a simple principle. There were undoubtedly people in Dou Jiande's camp who were aware of it. Indeed, an advisor named Ling Jing told Dou Jiande: ¡§We should cross the Yellow River with the entire army and move north, attack and seize Heyang in Huai Prefecture, and place a general in charge of defending the city. Then, you should lead the bulk of your forces and, with drums beating and battle flags raised, cross through the Taihang Mountains and move into Shangdang County.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
But this will be a ruse, and you will hide your true intention. You need not trouble yourself by actually fighting battles. Accelerate the pace of your army's march, make for Hukou Pass and, taking Pu Jin by surprise and harassing his forces, seize the land to the east of the river. This is the best strategy, and it offers three benefits: first, by pivoting your army to a position undefended by the enemy, your forces cannot lose; second, by expanding the territory under your control you can recruit more soldiers; and third, the enemy Tang army will then, of its own accord, lift its siege of Wang Shichong's position."
Ling Jing's plan was a textbook application of standard operating procedures for 'contentious ground,' and it also embodied the strategy of relieving a besieged ally by attacking the besiegers in a different location. There's nothing particularly cunning about this plan - it was straight from the playbook.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Dou Jiande thought this approach made sense, and he initially planned to use it. If he had, though, Li Shimin would have been in big trouble. But what happened next? Who gave Li Shimin a helping hand?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
It was Wang Shichong himself. Besieged and desperate, Wang Shichong saw Dou Jiande moving his army away, and the city of Luoyang fell. Wang's senior emissary, Sun Anshi, secretly sent gold, silver and pearls to various generals in Dou Jiande's army and asked them to persuade Dou not to leave. They said to Dou: ¡§Ling Jing is nothing but a student of books, how can you seriously consider his opinions about matters of war?"
Dou Jiande folded. How could the opinion of a 'student of books' hold up against so many senior generals?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, Dou changed his plan. This decision ultimately ruined him. He was run ragged at Hulao Pass by Li Shimin, captured and sent to Chang'an, where he was beheaded. Dou's generals had willingly served as agents for Wang Shichong, and they ended up hurting themselves, Dou Jiande and Wang Shichong.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is the pain of being a leader. Everyone has advice, but while some are loyal servants to their country, others conceal ulterior motives behind their words: desire for power and material gain. How are you supposed to tell the difference?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Even the people giving advice can't tell! In the case of Dou Jiande, Ling Jing had loyalty and patriotism in his heart, and he spoke plainly and objectively. Meanwhile, the senior generals were in the pockets of Wang Shichong. However, when they spoke to Dou Jiande on behalf of Wang Shichong, they spoke with conviction and strength; in their minds, they didn't say what they said only because of the money.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, what was the other reason? It's part of the human condition, and as universal now as it always has been - people fool themselves and then fool others. Once the generals believed what they had to say was right and fair, they assured themselves that reason was on their side. They argued that there was no reason to run away from LI Shimin's puny force of 3,500 men when Dou commanded an army of 100,000.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Yet, in their wisdom they failed to recognize just how brutal and dangerous war truly is. There are simply too many examples of the use of spies in war. You couldn't fit all of them into a single book, even if you wrote about nothing else. It's not at all true that all spies always intend to betray their country.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In many cases, they aren't aware of just how much harm their lies can do. They're simply jealous of other, more talented men, and they want to thwart them and ruin their chances of being credited for their national service. Or, they want to feel that their existence has meaning by expressing by their own unique way of seeing a situation.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In doing so, they're dragged down into murky depths by their country's enemies. People like to sigh over kings and lords who are led astray by the words of petty, immoral men. Yet, such men are not all bad people like Bo Pi was.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: More often than not, they're simply people operating without much understanding of the world. They might believe themselves to be highly loyal to their lord, and their lord also might believe them to be loyal. This is precisely the type of person who is most easily turned into a spy or an agent, because they remain unaware that they're serving as a spy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: They don't understand why the person grooming them to be a spy is giving them gifts, or what that person's goal is. These people who have limited vision and understanding, and who become spies, are even more destructive to their country than those who are truly bad!

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is because kings and lords don't put up any defenses against these kinds of people, in the belief that they don't have it in their hearts to do anything bad. During the infamous Feast at Hongmen, the key factor that allowed Liu Bang to escape was that he had bought off Xiang Yu's uncle, Xiang Bo. Did Xiang Bo believe he was doing anything to hurt Xiang Yu?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: No, he didn't. Did Xiang Bo know that, through his actions, he was serving as Liu Bang's agent? No. He was just a well-meaning fellow, and he certainly had no malice in him. It never would have occurred to Xiang Yu that he needed to protect himself against Xiang Bo.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: And yet, Xiang Bo had agreed to marry one of his family members to one of Liu Bang's family. As such, before the Feast at Hongmen, Xiang Bo was already kin with Liu Bang. This is why the state cannot use people who are supposedly of 'good morals,' but who lack talent.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Issues that effect an entire country can only be understood by people who have a certain amount of ability - they're the only ones who belong in high-level discussions of national importance. Anyway, true morality always comes as a package with talent and ability, because morality is the highest form of insight and understanding. There's no such thing as people who are virtuous but untalented.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Talent is a precondition for virtue; it's impossible for a person with no talent to have moral power. There's another common, and highly dangerous, situation: people who want others to fail so that they have a chance to 'prove themselves.' Initially, everyone on your team might be loyal, patriotic servants of their country, but the moment the king decides to use Advisor A's strategy, and not Advisor B's, what happens?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Will Advisor B want the plan to succeed, or will he want it to fail? In many cases, he'll want the plan to fail because then he'll have a chance to prove he was right. A certain percentage of advisors will end up serving as an enemy accomplice, precisely because of this.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Those who play turncoat and change sides often play both sides. When people regularly switch their allegiances, both sides want them for their own. However, neither side trusts them, and might cast them out at any moment. General Lu Bu, also known as 'the slave of three surnames,' is a classic example of this. Where did the 'three surnames' come from?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: His original surname was Lu, so that's one. Later, he showed his loyalty to the warlord Ding Yuan by ceremonially recognizing him as his father, making Ding his second surname. He was later bribed by Dong Zhuo, and killed Ding Yuan. He proclaimed that Dong Zhuo was his new father, and so Dong became his third surname. But, it didn't stop there.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He later killed Dong Zhuo on behalf of Diaochan. So, when Lu Bu offered his fealty to Cao Cao, Cao Cao didn't dare trust him. Instead, he sentenced him to death. It was the same story with Meng Da, another general of the Three Kingdoms period.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He started off as a general for the kingdom of Shu but later switched his allegiance to Wei, before finally going back to Shu after being lured back by Zhuge Liang. It was part of Zhuge Liang's plan - he leaked information that Meng Da was in contact with Shu leaders so that Wei general Sima Yi would find out, leaving Meng Da with no way back and no option except to work for Shu. Sima Yi knew what kind of man Meng Da was - he knew that he liked to play both sides - so he also wrote letters to him, tempting him to reconsider. Then, Sima Yi moved his army rapidly, and within eight days had arrived at Meng Da's city, where he defeated and executed him. Sima Yi managed to deal with the instability Meng Da had created and secure the city, all without taking any losses. Meanwhile, Zhuge Liang also made some small gains: he'd eliminated one of Wei's generals, and he'd also taken Sima Yi for a ride.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
And that's how Meng Da was cast aside. ¡§Having converted spies, getting hold of the enemy's spies and using them for our own purposes."

'Converting spies' is about enticing enemy spies into working for you. Du Mu tells us there are two ways of enticing enemy spies: ¡§If the enemy has spies sent to spy on me, you must know the situation beforehand.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
You can either entice them with lavish gifts or pretend you are unaware and furnish them with false information by way of contriving performances. Thus, the enemy's spies work for you."
Either lavish them with gifts to make them willing to work for you, or pretend you don't know what's going on, put on a show for them, and let them send back misleading information to their master. During the Chu-Han Contention, Liu Bang managed to catch Xiang Yu using the strategy of 'converting' enemy spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Liu Bang had the idea to eliminate one of Xiang Yu's key men, and his honorary 'father,' Fan Zeng. To achieve this, he first played the 'inward spies' card, using his man Chen Ping to pay 40,000 liang of gold to generals under Xiang Yu's command. These generals then spread rumors that Fan Zeng, Zhong Li and other advisors were disgruntled about their supposedly inadequate compensation, and that they were plotting to team up with Liu Bang to destroy King Xiang Yu. It was true that Xiang Yu wasn't particularly generous when it came to handing out rewards, so although he didn't fully believe the rumors, they still lodged inside his mind.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The groundwork was now laid. As we described earlier in the book, when an envoy sent by Xiang Yu arrived at the Han camp, Chen Ping initially greeted him like an honored guest, with all the trimmings, laying out good wine and plenty of meat. But, just as the envoy sat down and began to speak, Chen Ping put on a surprised expression and said: ¡§What? You're Xiang Yu's man? Why did I think it was Fan Zeng who sent you?" Immediately, he ordered a servant to clear away the meat and the wine, and began treating the envoy much less respectfully. When the messenger returned to his camp to report, Xiang Yu was furious.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He sent Fan Zeng away. This story seems ridiculous, as if Xiang Yu was a toddler distracted by an adult making silly noises. And yet, somehow Xiang Yu fell for it. Why? One reason is that Chen Ping laid thorough groundwork by spreading rumors and influencing public opinion in Xiang Yu's camp. The second reason also had to do with Xiang Yu - he wasn't generous enough to the people he worked with. This filled him with secret guilt; he felt uneasy and suspected that any of his men could betray him and go over to Liu Bang. Suspicion always comes down to self-doubt. Xiang Yu was by no means wrong to be suspicious. After all, his own uncle, Xiang Bo, had protected Liu Bang at the Feast of Hongmen.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He'd served as Liu Bang's 'inward spy,' and it was he who persuaded Xiang Yu not to kill Liu Bang's father when the man was in his grasp. When Liu Bang became Emperor of all China, he allowed Xiang Bo to change his surname to Liu as a gift, and granted him the title of Duke of Sheyang. Liu Bang also fell victim to the stratagem of 'converting spies' at the hands of that bitter foe: Modun, chieftain of the Xiongnu.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
