content: Later, General Han Wangxin launched a rebellion against the Han Empire, joining forces with the Xiongnu. Liu Bang, in an attempt to wipe out the Xiongnu with a single blow, sent a dozen or more groups of trusted men to gather intelligence about the enemy's strengths and weaknesses. Modun hid his strongest men and horses and made sure the Han envoys saw only the oldest, weakest and most decrepit of his forces. So, the Han scouting parties reported that the Xiongnu were feeble, and that the time to strike was now. Only the lone voice of Lou Jing spoke up to say that this was a trick - he saw that the Xiongnu were using the strategy of 'converting spies' as a misdirection tactic. But, Liu Bang was hell-bent on fighting and flush with confidence.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He cursed Lou Jing, saying that he was upsetting his men's focus, and locked him up with the threat that he'd deal with him upon his triumphant return. In the end, Liu Bang was surrounded by 400,000 of Modun's men on the Baideng plateau, and barely escaped with his life. The only reason he managed to get a peace treaty and safe passage home was that Chen Ping came up with a plan to bribe Modun's favorite wife. To Liu Bang's credit, he immediately freed Lou Jing, made him Duke of Guannei, and granted him income in perpetuity from the taxation of 2,000 families.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
As for the dozen or so others who'd said that it was safe to attack the Xiongnu, he executed them all. No matter how deeply you read into The Art of War, and try to apply its lessons in the real world, you can never guarantee you won't be fooled, because you're always dealing with different situations and all kinds of different possibilities. Five ways to use spies (parts four and five): 'Doomed spies' and 'Surviving spies'

Extract from the original text:
¡§Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy's camp. Analysis:
¡§Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy."
It doesn't get much worse than being a 'doomed spy.' When they're sent out on a mission, their own side has already sold them out. What defines a 'doomed spy?' They're envoys or agents to whom you hand false information and order to pass it on to the enemy. They're not told that the information is false because, first of all, this makes it impossible for the mission to be compromised by an intelligence leak.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Second, it makes them better able to win the enemy's trust. And third, of course, it means the thought never occurs to them that they should protect themselves. So, when the truth finally comes out for all to see, the unwitting spy is inevitably killed by the enemy. That's what makes him a 'doomed spy.'
Perhaps the most famous doomed spy was Li Shiqi. He worked for Liu Bang, and he was given the mission of going to the state of Qi and talking their leaders into surrendering.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Blessed with a silver tongue, he did actually manage to persuade the King of Qi to give up. Holding his hand over his heart, he assured the king that if anything he'd said was a lie, the king had his consent to boil him alive. The talks concluded with both the King of Qi and Li Shiqi enjoying a rowdy evening of drinking together.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Things took a turn when Han Xin, unwilling to let a civilian with a big mouth like Li Shiqi overshadow everything he achieved on the battlefield, turned the tables. Han sent a force to attack Qi, which was totally unprepared.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Now Li Shiqi was in a real pickle; he'd become a doomed spy. Just before Han Xin destroyed Qi entirely, the King of Qi filled a massive cauldron with hot water and boiled Li Shiqi alive. Another famous example of a doomed spy comes from the Spring and Autumn period.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Duke Wu of Zheng had designs on invading the state of Hu. So what did he do? First, he set up a marriage alliance with Hu, arranging for his son to be married to a Hu woman. Then, at a meeting of his court, he told his advisors and ministers that he desired to expand his kingdom, and asked which direction would be the best for him to set his sights on. A senior official named Guan Qisi said: ¡§The state of Hu is an appropriate target." It was a good judgment call, but tragically, he didn't know that the reason his lord had asked this question was that he wanted a 'doomed spy.' By being the first to put his hand up, Guan Qisi had unwittingly volunteered for the role. Duke Wu flew into a rage, and said: ¡§The people of Hu are our brothers, how dare you suggest we attack them?" He had Guan Qisi hauled from the court and executed.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Naturally, news of this episode soon reached the lord of Hu, and he felt full of gratitude! So, he let his guard down, and Duke Wu promptly raised an army and used it to utterly destroy Hu. In a later era, there was a war between Northern Song and Western Xia.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: An agent was disguised as a monk, made to swallow a wax pellet and sent into Western Xia territory. He was caught by the local authorities and, after being interrogated, confessed that he had a wax pellet in his stomach. The pellet was taken out, and found to contain a secret message for a senior Western Xia strategist. The strategist was executed, and of course, the 'monk' had to die, too.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
And so, yet another 'doomed spy' met his cruel fate. ¡§Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy's camp."

Doomed spies never come back from their missions. 'Surviving spies' are their opposite - they return from their missions alive, bearing information to report to their superiors. Li Quan comments: ¡§They are envoys who return."
According to Li Quan's interpretation, all diplomatic envoys and messengers are, in a broad sense, spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
They're spies who survive. Du Mu comments: ¡§They are messengers who return and deliver reports. When choosing men to be 'surviving spies,' you must select those who are inwardly intelligent but outwardly foolish. They must appear weak but be mentally strong; they must be athletic and brave, unmoved by base concerns, and able to endure hunger, cold, dirtiness and humiliation."
During the Northern and Southern Dynasties period (420-589 CE), there was a war between Eastern Wei and Western Wei. Yuwen Tai of Western Wei sent an agent named Daxi Wu to spy on an Eastern Wei military camp at Gaohuan.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He dressed in an enemy uniform and took three mounted soldiers with him. When evening fell, he was just a few hundred paces away from the enemy camp. He got down from his horse, listened, and learned the enemy's communication signals. Then, he got back on his horse and made his way around all of the nearby enemy camps, posing as a night sentry.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
He even whipped enemy soldiers who he found breaking the rules. And that's how Daxi Wu learned all the ins and outs of the enemy's situation, which he reported to Yuwen Tai upon his return home. What special skill does a person like Chen Ping have? The skill of 'Dividing up the pork'

The skill of 'dividing up the pork' is having the ability to weigh the interest of everyone involved, giving full play to each person's productivity, and coordinate the relationships between all involved.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Being able to divide up the pork is something that political leaders and chief ministers must be able to do. Extract from the original text:
¡§Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: None should be more liberally rewarded. In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved. Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity. They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports. Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used."

Analysis:
¡§Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§The soldiers of the army are all to be kept close and treated as intimates, but only spies are to be kept closest to your heart, and you shall be most intimate with spies."
Du Mu comments: ¡§They receive audiences and commands are issued to them in the inner chambers."
Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§They enter into your chambers to receive your words; they are your closest relations."
Du You comments: ¡§If you do not treat them with the utmost closeness and if you do not reward them handsomely, then they will become servants of the enemy and divulge information to them."
Any spy you send into the field has the potential to be groomed by the enemy as a 'converted spy.' If you don't bind them to you by treating them well, giving them generous rewards and bringing them under your personal leadership, they could be used by the enemy and reveal information about your army's situation. ¡§None should be more liberally rewarded."

Be willing to spend money.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Spending on spy operations, no matter how expensive, comes down to pennies when you realize what you're buying with that money. You're buying the world, and you're buying your own life. When you choose whether or not to spend that money, you're choosing between gaining control of the entire world and throwing away your life. For example, during the Chu-Han Contention, when Liu Bang was surrounded by Xiang Yu's forces, Chen Ping said to him: ¡§Are you willing to spend 40,000 gold pieces to buy spies in the chambers of the Chu council?" Liu Bang handed over the money immediately, without asking what the plan was, how the money would be spent, or why the price was 40,000 in gold, rather than 30,000 or 50,000. ¡§In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved."

There's no other area of operations where secrecy is more important than in spying.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
This work belongs underground, cloaked in strict secrecy. Du Mu comments: ¡§What comes out from the mouth enters directly into the ear."
Du You comments: ¡§If spy work is not conducted in secrecy, you will come to harm."
When Chen Ping was planning to pay some of Xiang Yu's men to spread rumors, if he hadn't kept tight secrecy, he definitely would have ended up dead. ¡§Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity."

Du Mu comments: ¡§First, gauge the character of the person to be employed as a spy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
They must be honest, resourceful and wise. Having assured yourself of this, only then take them into your service. They must appear innocent yet be hard to judge, and they must be willing to brave the dangers of wilderness travel. Anybody who is not a sage will fall short."
You can feel like you 'know' someone, and yet that knowledge might only be skin-deep. With spies, you have to know their minds, their abilities and intelligence, and you have to be capable of handling them.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
To manage a spy, you have to be extremely wise. Wang Xi comments: ¡§Being possessed of wisdom and sagacity, you have the ability to know people."
Chen Ping took charge of all spy work for his lord, Liu Bang, and many people cast doubts on his character. The most famous rumor about Chen Ping was that he had an affair with his sister-in-law, even though his older brother, her husband, had always treated him well.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There was no clear proof that this was true, but the rumor spread far and wide nonetheless. According to another rumor, he'd taken bribes from his subordinates while serving as an officer in Liu Bang's army. He even admitted it when Liu Bang accused him, but he had an explanation - he was new in the army, he had no money, and without money he couldn't get anything done. That's why he took a bribe, he said.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Plenty of people spoke against him, but Liu Bang trusted him and gave him control of the most important, confidential spy work. So, was Chen Ping a wise man? There are no historical records of his intelligence reports, of who he employed or how he did his business.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: However, the records do talk about something he did as a young man. In his hometown, the locals were willing to let Chen Ping be in charge of the annual offerings to the gods at the communal shrine; to act as the 'minister of sacrifices.' He directed the event, and was in charge of dividing up the pork among the villagers. The reason they were happy to let Chen Ping take charge was that he always cut the meat up in exactly equal portions. As such, it was common to hear the elders and other villagers saying: ¡§Bravo! Chen the scholar is our man, our minister of sacrifices!" Young Chen had already mastered the dividing up of the pork.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Chen Ping would get emotional and say: ¡§Oh my! If I were to be made prime minister of all China, I would set about my task in the same way as cutting up this meat!"
So, what is the main skill that people like Chen Ping have? It's the skill of 'dividing up the pork.' What this means is having the ability to weigh the interests of everyone involved, giving full play to everyone's productivity, and coordinating the relationships between everyone involved. Being able to divide up the pork is something that political leaders and chief ministers must be able to do.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Chen Ping didn't just provide Liu Bang with a constant supply of brilliant strategy, helping him take control of all China. He also managed to protect himself after the deaths of both Liu Bang and his wife, Empress Lu, deal with the threat posed by the dead Empress' various relatives, keep a steady hand on the Han court and maintain the country's stability as prime minister of the Han Empire. ¡§They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness."

How should we interpret the concepts of 'benevolence and straightforwardness?'
Chen Hao comments: ¡§Benevolent men touch other people with their grace; straightforward men manage affairs in the proper way.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Commanders-in-chief must be able to both bind men to them using benevolence and put them to use by using straightforwardness. Having achieved this, spies will conduct their work to the best of their abilities and serve you happily."
Wang Xi comments: ¡§Benevolence to bind their hearts to you; straightforwardness to awaken their moral integrity."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Benevolence means being not stingy when dispensing noble rank and rewards; straightforwardness means being resolute and free of doubt. One must both entice men using generous rewards and treat them with the utmost sincerity. Thus, spies will devote all their strength to their work."
So, benevolence and straightforwardness are leadership qualities ¡V they enable leaders to close any emotional distance between themselves and their men, and to not hold back when giving out rewards, while also making decisions and dealing with problems decisively, without hesitating. People bend to your will because they see your character, your openness, your generosity, your sense of justice and your powers of insight.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
This is the way to keep your people grounded, passionately committed to serving you and blissfully unoccupied by other thoughts. ¡§Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports."

Spy work goes so deep and takes place amid such terrible danger, and any spy can be bought over to the enemy's side or otherwise fall under enemy control. When you're in the business of handling spies, you have to give them your absolute confidence and form strong, emotional bonds with them, while at the same time remembering to trust no one.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The dynamic between these two opposing needs is extremely subtle. When a spy returns home to report, is he telling the truth? The only way to get the truth is to have spies who think and analyze at an extremely sophisticated level.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It's possible that a spy thinks he's telling the truth, but actually he's just regurgitating false information fed to him by the enemy. Among those who fell into this trap was Liu Bang, who was otherwise such a brilliant example of using spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: For instance, he fell into a trap set for him by Modun. As discussed earlier, he listened to the scouting parties who told him the Xiongnu were weak and vulnerable to attack, instead of listening to Lou Jing when he said the Xiongnu were only pretending to be weak as part of a strategy to draw them in. For all Liu Bang's wisdom, he somehow still decided to lock up Lou Jing and believe the men who told him to attack.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: As a result, Liu Bang almost didn't make it back from that war. As is always the case with trickery, Modun's ruse could have come from any textbook - you can find clear descriptions of what he did in any 'Complete Guide to Trickery and Deception.' It couldn't be any simpler; it's even clumsy in its simplicity. Anyone could come up with something similar, and it's so obvious that you'd see through it with a single glance.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: So, why did Liu Bang fall for it? Wasn't he too clever to make such a basic mistake? It was because the false information Modun fed him appealed to his desires and expectations: he was chomping at the bit to destroy the Xiongnu and win even more glory. If you have specific expectations, and if you're influenced by greed, you'll fall for people's tricks.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
People sometimes believe things only because they want them to be true. ¡§Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used."

Pay special attention to the low-status people who hang around major actors ¡V These are the people who can help you do big things

Extract from the original text:
¡§If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told. Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command. Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these."

Analysis:
¡§If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told."
The spy is put to death as punishment for leaking information, while the person who received the leaked information is put to death to keep him quiet. Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§The spy is killed as a response to his heinous act of divulging information; the person to whom he divulged the information is killed in order to prevent him from telling the information to others."
In any confidential work, it's necessary to keep tight discipline throughout your organization.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Don't say a word to anyone, not even your family members. The people who worked on China's projects to launch the country's first satellite and build its first atomic bomb were separated from their families for years. Their family members didn't even know where they'd gone or when they'd come back; they weren't even allowed to send letters to them.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is the nature of confidential work - if you want people to keep a secret, the best strategy is to make sure they don't know the secret in the first place. Sima Yi pretended to be sick twice in his life.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The second time he did it, he tricked Cao Shuang and seized control of the state of Wei. The first time, he'd been staying home and biding his time, hiding his strength. Cao Cao summoned him to return to work, but he didn't yet feel he had a clear enough understanding of the political landscape.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He didn't want to come out of the political wilderness, so what did he do? He pretended to be sick. Specifically, he said he had rheumatism, but Cao Cao didn't buy it and sent a man to his house in the middle of the night to investigate. What he observed was Sima Yi lying motionless inside, his body painfully contorted.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: After that, Cao Cao believed him. So, whether you're pretending to be sick or pretending to be crazy, it's important to put on a consistent show, including when you're 'backstage' and don't think anybody's watching. You can't afford to be careless, because an investigator could show up at any time and monitor you in secret.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: One day, Sima Yi was lying on his side indoors. Meanwhile, he'd had some of his books made of bamboo slips spread out in the courtyard, to dry in the sun. Suddenly, rain began to hammer down. Sima Yi forgot about his pretend illness the moment he realized his books were about to be ruined, and leapt up to bring them inside.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: After all, he was a man of learning and a lover of books. But, he'd been spotted by one of his own serving girls. She was so shocked that her mouth hung open. Sima Yi's wife, Zhang Chunhua, was in the house at the time, and she made an instant decision to kill the girl on the spot. She did it with her own hands.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Sima Yi wasn't the only wolf in his family; his wife was also quite the cold-blooded killer. ¡§Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these."

There's a lot of information to pick through here, and it explains a lot. The first thing mentioned in this passage is that you have to know who the enemy commander is.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is the easiest part to understand. When you fight a war, you're fighting against the enemy commander, and it is this man's competence that decides the fighting capabilities of his army. There's a saying that an individual soldier might fight like a lion, but when a powerful general is calling the shots, his army becomes a whole pride of lions. For example, Han Xin had the ability to gather a rag-tag band of sub-par soldiers and turn them into an elite fighting unit. Han Xin was the kind of man who could go into a market and come out again with an army at his back.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In other words, he knew how to round up a mob, build it into an army and lead them into a life-and-death battle. General Zhao Kuo, on the other hand, could be given a huge army of 400,000 fighters and somehow still manage to get slaughtered on the battlefield. That's why, during the time leading up to the Battle of Changping, the Qin commanders focused on coming up with a way to get the leaders of Zhao to recall General Lian Po from the front lines and replace him with Zhao Kuo. Meanwhile, the Qin leaders quietly put General Bai Qi in charge of their forces, under strict secrecy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It was decreed that anyone who leaked information that Bai Qi had been made commander would be beheaded. Just like that, the pieces on the chessboard were switched. The original matchup between Lian Po for Zhao, and Wang He for Qin, had become Zhao Kuo for Zhao and Bai Qi for Qin. This led directly to Zhao's defeat.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Liu Bang once sent Han Xin, Cao Can and Guan Ying to attack Wei Bao. Liu Bang asked: ¡§Who is the greatest general of Wei?" 
The answer he was given: ¡§Bo Zhi."
Liu Bang said: ¡§Bo Zhi? He's barely weaned from his mother's teat!

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
He's no match for Han Xin."
Then Liu Bang asked another question: ¡§Who is the commander of their cavalry forces?"
The answer he was given: ¡§Xiang Ta." 
Liu Bang said: ¡§He can't beat Cao Can. Clearly, I have nothing to worry about!"
So, as a commander-in-chief, you not only need to know everything about the people under your command, you must also have a thorough understanding of the personal background, military abilities, personality traits and even the hobbies and interests of each and every one of the enemy's generals. We've just talked about how a commander needs to understand the enemy commander, but why is it also necessary to understand his attendants, aides-de-camp, doorkeepers and sentries?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Zhang Yu elaborates on this by writing about an historical example, and once again it's about Liu Bang. Once, Liu Bang was defeated in battle and fled, taking refuge in Han Xin's camp. He went straight to Han Xin's sleeping quarters, took possession of Han Xin's official seal and seized command of his forces. If he hadn't done meticulous groundwork beforehand, he could never have marched straight into Han Xin's bedchambers without startling the man, regardless of his status as commander-in-chief. There's a similar historical example, except unlike Liu Bang bursting into the sleeping quarters of one of his own men, it involved someone bursting in on the enemy commander-in-chief while he was in bed. This story comes from the Spring and Autumn period, during a time when the states of Chu and Song were at war.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: The Chu army had been besieging the city of Handan for about a year, and the situation had deteriorated to the point that residents had begun eating one another. Despite that, the defenders of the city were hell-bent on to the death.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There would be no surrender. Meanwhile, the Chu soldiers outside the city walls were exhausted. The Song forces were attempting to outlast them - to wait until they'd burned through all their resources and would be forced to leave. So, the Chu forces began to build houses, plough fields and get ready to plant crops, to show that they were prepared to settle in for the long haul.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Their message was clear: they weren't going anywhere. Faced with this reality, the Song leader Hua Yuan snuck into the Chu camp at night, went straight to the bed of Zi Fan, the Chu commander-in-chief, and took him captive. There in Zi Fan's bed, the two men negotiated. The Chu forces would withdraw, and in return Hua Yuan would travel to Chu as a hostage and sign a peace treaty. If it weren't for the detailed spy work he did before he made this move - he'd acquainted himself closely with Zi Fan's attendants, aides-de-camp, doorkeepers and sentries, and even come to a silent agreement of sorts with them - how could Hua Yuan have made it to Zi Fan's bed?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There's one more example. During the Republic of China period (1912-1949 CE), there was a network of underground cells dedicated to resisting the Japanese occupation. As part of their operations, an agent named Dai Li planned to eliminate the Mayor of occupied Shanghai, Fu Xiao'an. Who did Dai Li go through to accomplish this mission?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He used a man who Fu Xiao'an trusted completely, who'd served him for decades and whose service spanned a regime change. He was a cook named Zhu Shengyuan. While Fu Xiao'an was fast asleep in his official residence in Hongkou, Zhu Shengyuan cut his head off with a kitchen knife. It was true that Zhu had been a loyal servant to his master, but his loyalty to his country outweighed that.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
That's why it's important to pay special attention to the low-status people who hang around major actors. These are the people who can help you accomplish big things. There are five types of spy, but 'Converted spies' are key

Extract from the original text:
¡§The enemy's spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies. It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy. Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions. The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy. Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality."

Analysis:
¡§The enemy's spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service."
This part emphasizes that, although there are five different types of spy, the most crucial of these is 'converted spies.'
The idea of 'comfortably housing' enemy spies is actually a form of house arrest. Once they're safely inside a house, then you can begin to tempt them, corrupt them and bring them over to your side.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Seek out enemy spies who have come to spy on you, and turn him into your agent by means of generous gifts, temptations and housing. In this case, the meaning of 'housing' is actually detainment. The longer he is kept there, the more he will talk, and thus you will gain intelligence about the enemy."
The Han dynasty court and the Xiongnu often sent envoys to each other's seat of power, and the vast majority of these envoys also were assigned spy duties.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
It was common practice for both sides to detain the other's envoys. One of them, a man named Su Wu, was held for nineteen years and never gave in to the enemy. The story of Su Wu and how he raised sheep on the plateau later became a famous legend. ¡§It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies."

Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§It becomes possible to make use of subjects and officials of the enemy state, and this is all because of knowledge acquired from converted spies."
Zhang Yu comments: ¡§Through converted spies, you learn which of the enemy's people are susceptible to greedy desires, and you learn which officials of the enemy court are at odds with one another.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Then, you can bring them into your service by means of enticements."
So, a converted spy is not necessarily someone who fully comes over to your side. It might be someone who you keep detained, who you keep wining and dining and chatting with, until eventually, inevitably, he lets something slip. As Zhang Yu writes: ¡§The longer he is kept there, the more he will talk, and thus you will gain intelligence about the enemy."

¡§It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy."

Through the information you learn from converted spies, you can find out exactly what kind of false information can undermine the enemy with the greatest effectiveness. Then, you can dispatch 'doomed spies' to deliver the message. ¡§Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions."

From information gained from converted spies, you can find out details about the enemy's troop density, and use this intelligence to arrange times for 'surviving spies' to return home and report on what they've learned. ¡§The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy. Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality."

In sum, converted spies are at the root of all spy work.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
You have to spend a lot of money on spy work, and the lion's share of that money needs to be spent on converted spies. The key to 'Winning first and fighting later' is: If you can't win, don't fight

Extract from the original text:
¡§Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia. Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move."

Analysis:
¡§Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia."
Cao Cao comments: ¡§Yi Zhi is the same person as Yi Yin."
Yi Zhi, also known as Yi Yin, is singled out by Sun Tzu as the first Chinese historical example of a spy. The details of Yi Yin's background are a little complicated.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It seems he was a chef, a private tutor, a royal teacher, a spy, a general, a prime minister and a sage. Yi Zhi's first role was as a chef, and he's considered as one of the fathers of Chinese cuisine. There's a concept in Chinese cooking that can be translated as 'heat control' (huohou).

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It's a way of talking about the strength of the cooking flame and the duration of cooking time in relation to one another. Heat control theory was Yi Zhi's invention, and he also came up with the idea that taste can be divided into five flavor categories. His approach to cooking had deep theoretical underpinnings.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Yi Zhi served as chef to the lord of the state of Shen, which existed during the Xia Dynasty (2070-1600 BCE), and he also served as a tutor to the children of noble families. He was devoted to the study of two fields of knowledge: crafting delicacies in the kitchen, and effective governance of large states. I have my suspicions that that a phrase coined by Lao Tzu - 'Governing a large state is like cooking tiny delicacies' - might have been inspired by Yi Zhi. This seems likely to me because Lao Tzu just wrote the words, whereas Yi Zhi could in all fairness be hailed as the father of Chinese cuisine and statecraft. He has been called 'the original sage of Shang.'
The founder of the Shang Dynasty (1600-1046 BCE), Shang Tang, was so intent on bringing Yi Zhi into his service that he married a daughter of the lord of Shen.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Yi Zhi was sent to Shang as part of the dowry. There's a passage in the ancient text, The Book of Mencius, that reads: ¡§Shang Tang learned from Yi Yin and later made a minister of him. Hence, he became king easily and without toil." Shang Tang honored Yi Zhi by appointing him royal teacher and taught him the ways of the legendary ancient Emperors Yao and Shun. Shang Tang also assigned Yi Zhi to five different diplomatic missions to visit the last King of Xia, Xia Jie, in the state of Jin. Yi Zhi's duties included befriending Xia Jie's favorite concubine, Mei Xi, and extracting large quantities of intelligence about the Xia dynasty.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
His work during these missions was pivotal to Shang Tang's success in finally crushing the Xia dynasty. ¡§Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin."

Here, Sun Tzu gives us another example of a historical spy. This time, it was Jiang Ziya, a man from Yin Shang who was pivotal to the rise of the Zhou Dynasty. Jiang Ziya once worked for King Zhou of Shang, and when he came into the service of King Wen of Zhou, he brought with him a huge amount of insider knowledge about the Shang royal court. Over the millennia since Sun Tzu's The Art of War was written, many scholars have struggled to understand why he cited these two men, Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya, as examples of spies. Some have even been downright disgruntled about it. This is because the majority of people who read, or write commentary about, The Art of War are bookish types, generally with a Confucianist bent. Within the Confucian tradition, both Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya are venerated as sages and models of Confucian values, and the fact that Sun Tzu describes them as spies doesn't sit well with those values. Spies might be important, but in the framework of Confucianism, a true gentleman of noble character would never consider doing the kind of things that are routine tasks in spy work. On top of that, both Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya played crucial roles in the founding of a new dynasty.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: How could their glorious contributions be chalked up as spy work? Mei Yaochen comments: ¡§Yi Yin and Lu Ya did not betray their countries. In the case of the former, the Xia dynasty was no longer fit to rule, and so the Shang dynasty rose up; in the case of the latter, the Shang dynasty was no longer fit to rule, and so the Zhou dynasty rose up. The great deeds that these men accomplished were done for the good of the people." They weren't treacherous spies, they were moral servants of the country who chose to serve the greater good and promote the betterment of the common people's lives. Zhang Yu wasn't happy about the choice of Zhi Yi and Jiang Ziya as examples of spies, either.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He writes: ¡§Yi Yin was a minister of Xia who later joined Shang; Lu Wang was a minister of Shang who later joined Zhou. Yi and Lu respectively assisted Tang and Wu to restore stability to the world through force of arms.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
This was in accordance with heaven and with the people of the earth. Their cases are not the same as when Bo Zhouli fled to Chu or when Miao Benhuang went over to Jin."
Bo Zhouli and Miao Benhuang are the two standard examples from Chinese history of men who betrayed their countries. Bo Zhouli was a nobleman from the state of Jin whose father, Bo Zong, was persecuted by 'the three Xis.' He fled his home and went to Chu, where he was appointed prime minister.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Miao Benhuang was a nobleman from the state of Chu. He had the surname Mi, and the clan name Dou. He was in the same clan as Ruo Aoshi, and was the son of Yin Doujiao, who held the official rank of guoling.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
During the ninth year of the reign of King Zhuang of Chu, Yin Doujia launched a rebellion that soon failed, after which King Zhuang set about exterminating all members of his clan. That was when Miao Benhuang fled to Jin, where the rulers appointed him Chief Strategist and he became one of the venerated 'eight good ministers of Jin.'
During the Battle of Yanling, between Jin and Chu, the two men were standing by their respective lords' sides, feeding them insider intelligence about the opposing army and making suggestions. Miao Benhaung was the most talented, and the Jin army prevailed. The Battle of Yanling is a classic example of a major Spring and Autumn period military campaign, and the history books contain vivid records about both of these treacherous officials:
In one such account, Bo Zhouli accompanied King Gong of Chu on an excursion to observe the Jin army camp. The King of Chu asked: ¡§The Jin soldiers are driving their chariots and moving all around at high speed.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
What are they doing?"
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They are assembling their officers."
The King of Chu said: ¡§Those people have gathered in the middle of the camp."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They are holding a meeting. They are discussing among themselves."
The King of Chu said: ¡§They have erected tents."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They are communing with the late king to divine whether the omens are good or bad."
The King of Chu said: ¡§Now they have taken down the tents."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They will soon issue commands."
The King of Chu said: ¡§How noisy it is, and there is dust flying around."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§That is because they are preparing to fill in their wells and smash their cooking ranges. They will soon form battle lines."
The King of Chu said: ¡§They have mounted their war chariots and the men to left and right have taken up weapons and lined up in formation."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They are listening to their commander's instructions and commands."
The King of Chu asked: ¡§Do they mean to start the battle?"
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§I do not know yet."
The King of Chu said: ¡§Now they have once more mounted their war chariots, and the people to left and right have come down."
Bo Zhouli said: ¡§They are now making their pre-battle prayers to the gods."
Reading this dialogue, we can see why spies are to be feared! Because of them, your enemy can see straight through every little move you make.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Bo Zhouli also told King Gong of Chu where Duke Li of Jin's personal unit was located. With this information, the Chu forces knew exactly where they could find the enemy leader. Of course, Miao Benhuang was providing the same services to the other side, so Chu and Jin were in much the same situation - the Jin forces also knew where the personal forces of King Gong of Chu were located. However, the information Miao Benhuang provided to his side wasn't as detailed or vividly expressed, or even as gossipy as Bo Zhouli's.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
But gossipy tidbits don't serve much practical use; unlike Bo Zhouli, Miao Benhuang's information cut straight to the most crucial details. One of his suggestions for Duke Li of Jin went like this: ¡§The Chu forces' elite unit is located in the middle of their army, and for the most part they consist of the Chu king's personal soldiers. If you allocate some of our elite soldiers to attack and pin down the Chu forces on both flanks of their army, and then focus our entire attacking power on an assault against the personal unit of the Chu king, then we will surely be able to inflict a heavy defeat upon them."
Duke Li of Jin did as Miao advised. The Chu army was defeated and withdrew.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: King Gong of Chu decided to fight again the next day. On the Jin side, Miao Benhuang informed the entire army that they must prepare to fight again the following day, and then he deliberately let the Chu prisoners of war get away so that they would rejoin their armies and report to their leaders that the Jin forces were preparing to fight. When King Gong found out that the Jin forces were already prepared, he immediately summoned Zi Fan for a consultation about how to respond.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But it was nighttime, and Zi Fan was drunk. He couldn't answer his lord's summons. With no other options, King Gong withdrew his army under the cover of darkness. And that's how the Battle of Yanling ended in victory for the Jin forces.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is why Sun Tzu emphasizes the importance of spies. If you talk about the most valuable personnel you could acquire, nobody's more valuable than people from within the enemy's organization. But, when you recruit enemy personnel, you have to make sure you get the right people.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
If you don't, you still won't be able to defeat your enemies. ¡§Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move."

Du Mu comments: ¡§Without information about the actual situation of the enemy, your army cannot move. There is no way to gain information about the enemy that does not require the use of spies. Hence it is said: 'On them depends an army's ability to move.'"
Li Quan comments: ¡§Sun Tzu's treatise about war begins with calculations and ends with spies, for attacking is not the most important thing. How could those who would be generals not reflect upon this with the utmost care?"
This comment from Li Quan serves well as a conclusion for this book. The essential core of Sun Tzu's way of thinking is expressed in just four words:
¡§Win first, fight later."
The purpose of making calculations is to win before fighting, and to only raise an army once you're sure of victory. Likewise, the purpose of spies is also to win before fighting.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Once you have information about the enemy's situation, and if you know both yourself and your enemy, it's time to go out and fight. And what is the key to winning first and fighting later? Don't fight if you can't win.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: If you can't see a clear path to victory, don't move. The art of war is mainly about learning how not to fight, not how to fight. You need to be able to stay out of fights and protect yourself, and you also need to be able to settle a conflict in a single engagement. If you can do that, you've fully understood the opening words from the first chapter of Sun Tzu's The Art of War: ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected."
Regardless of what we're trying to achieve, we need to adopt 'win first, fight later' as our way of thinking. Work everything out at the planning stage, and only then take action.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: If you don't do anything, that doesn't matter. In many situations, waiting is the best strategy. Among all the factors that effect developing events, there's one that plays the ultimate role in deciding outcomes. That factor is time.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: You need to understand how to wait; you need patience. You need the ability to observe and exploit the changes that time brings. You also need to exploit time itself, in order to manufacture changes. It was time that took Chairman Mao away and gave us Deng Xiaoping, the man who brought reform to China. If you try to resist the effects of time and impose yourself, you'll end up with nothing.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Don't always be itching to do something. Many so-called 'strategic measures' are just reflections of strategists' anxieties and nerves. You might feel that, unless you do something, you're being 'passive.' Or, you might worry that your commander will think you're useless, and your king might think you're negligent, so you end up beside yourself with anxiety.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
In that worried state, you may conclude that the only way you can get some relief from these intense emotions is to do something, anything! But, as soon as you move, you become another example of the saying: 'If you don't put yourself in death's way, you won't die.'



Sun Tzu said: ¡§Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor. Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy's condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory. Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge. Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits; it cannot be obtained inductively from experience, nor by any deductive calculation.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Knowledge of the enemy's dispositions can only be obtained from other men. ¡§Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system. This is called 'divine manipulation of the threads.' It is the sovereign's most precious faculty. Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Having inward spies means making use of officials of the enemy. Having converted spies, getting hold of the enemy's spies and using them for our own purposes. Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy. Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy's camp. ¡§Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: None should be more liberally rewarded. In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved. Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity. They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports. Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used. ¡§If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told. Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command. Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: ¡§The enemy's spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service. It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies. It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy. Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions. The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality. Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia. Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move."

Epilogue: The final conclusion ¡V The nine essential threads of the thinking behind Sun Tzu's The Art of War

By the time you finish reading through The Art of War, you will have realized that it's not as mysterious as it's made out to be. It's not some kind of secret scroll; it's a vessel for simple, ordinary principles, expressed in clear, sensible terms.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
As it turns out, simplicity has always been 'The Way of Sages.' The reason we can't become powerful, mighty beings is that we don't like the idea of ordinariness. We always make things so complicated, because we don't believe in simplicity. As my final summary of Sun Tzu's The Art of War, I have organized the core threads of his way of thinking into nine points:

1) The art of war is about strength trumping weakness, not weakness trumping strength. The first chapter is about 'calculations,' not to be confused with 'ingenious strategems,' which is another possible translation of the root Chinese character ji (?).

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It corresponds to the modern-day SWOT analytical framework: Strength, Weakness, Opportunity and Threat. The idea of 'carrying out calculations in the temple' is about weighing and comparing both sides' political, economic and military strengths, while you're still safely at home, before you decide to go to war. There's also the framework of 'The five factors and the seven considerations,' which is a system for assigning scores to the various items up for comparison.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Whichever side scores more points will win; whichever side scores fewer points will lose. Once you finish these evaluations, you'll know who's going to win. And then, once you know you can win, you can summon your officers, mobilize your army and go to war.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: If your calculations give you a score lower than your enemy's, don't fight. This is why Sun Tzu didn't believe in trying to beat strength with weakness -there's a low probability of a successful outcome. ¡§The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected." Sun Tzu would never have bet the fate of his country's people on a low probability outcome. 2) Even if you can win a war, you still need to calculate the cost of victory.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Every action comes with a price, and the price of war is enormous. Don't think only about winning; you need to keep count of the costs you'll rack up along the way and decide whether it's worth it. Li Ke said; ¡§For Marquis Wen of Wei, many victories will lead to his certain ruin." You can win a lot of battles, and yet all those victories can lead to your country's destruction. This is because constant fighting leaves the people exhausted, while frequent victories tend to make lords arrogant.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: An arrogant lord leading an exhausted populace is a recipe for a failed state. The great Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty was a true example of this, as represented by his immortal words: ¡§Any who dare use force against Han will surely be brought to the executioner, no matter how far away they may be." The arrogance is breathtaking! Emperor Wu spent his life hacking away at the borders of his empire and expanding his territory, and for his efforts he won himself a glittering military record.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But, what was the end result? Both the government and the people of China were bankrupt, he drove the country to the brink of destruction, and in his later years he was forced under heavy political pressure from his government, and made to kneel and confess his guilt. This is what he said during his self-criticism: ¡§Since the time when I ascended the throne, I have engaged in many wanton acts, and have caused distress to all under heaven.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
It is now too late for regret. Starting from today, there will be a halt to all activities being detrimental to the common folk and squandering the resources of all under heaven."

3) Win first, fight later. Sun Tzu's The Art of War is primarily about ways to strengthen yourself.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: First and foremost, you have to train and improve yourself instead of always thinking about other people and how to defeat them. Sun Tzu wrote: ¡§The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself." He also wrote: ¡§One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it," and ¡§Those who are skilled in war obtain victory first, and then fight." Don't look for victory on the battlefield; look for a battle after you've already won. Train and practice until you're strong.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Make yourself undefeatable, leave no chinks in your armor, and then wait until a chink appears in your enemy's armor. If the enemy isn't weaker than you, or if you're evenly matched - and if they don't make any mistakes, or leave any gaps in their defenses - you can't attack. ¡§The opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself." In other words, victory comes the moment the enemy makes a mistake. If the enemy doesn't make a mistake, there's no way you can win. So, it's possible to judge and know ahead of time whether the outcome will be victory or defeat, but you can't make victory happen. As soon as the opportunity for victory appears, grab it and fight. You can't turn this formula around - if you charge into a fight casually, and look for a path to victory once the battle has already started, you're putting yourself in danger. 4) You have to be able to wait; patience is a necessity. These days, people often repeat the saying, 'If you don't go looking for death, you won't die.' The Art of War talks about this more than anything else.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: In war, the profits and the costs are totally disproportionate to each other. If you kill 1,000 enemy soldiers, but lose 800 of your own, there isn't necessarily any significant benefit in it for you.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But if you lose, you face the prospect of your country's destruction, the death of your entire family and the loss of your own life. That's why it's crucial to be able to wait. You mustn't get twitchy and move around a lot just because you feel anxious.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: When Shuge Han was holding Tongguan Pass, he knew he was in no position to fight. But although he had the ability to wait, Emperor Xuanzong didn't - the anxious Emperor forced Shuge Han to leave the safety of the pass and start a fight, which led to the total destruction of his army. When Wang Jian of Qin invaded Chu, he had the ability wait, and he also had the ability to sooth the nerves of the first Emperor of Qin and prevent him from becoming anxious. This enabled Wang Jian to lead a massive army of 600,000 soldiers into Chu territory, set up camp, and while away the days holding contests for his soldiers until finally the people of Chu grew anxious and began to move about, which opened up gaps in their defenses. Then, Wang Jian pounced and destroyed the state of Chu in a single move.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Waiting is the best strategy in many different situations. And yet, people often believe that if you wait, you're being passive. They think waiting is unacceptable. This is what people need to understand: it's perfectly acceptable to be 'passive,' even for your entire lifetime, because the consequences of taking action might include your own death. Look at Japan's Tokugawa Ieyasu, for example.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: He perfected the waiting game. Nobody had greater patience than him, and nobody was better at compromising. When Oda Nobunaga was in power, Tokugawa was a young boy; when Toyotomi Hideyoshi came to power, Tokugawa had become a powerful regional lord. Did Tokugawa at any point try to force his ambitions, to make them a reality?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: No, he didn't. He could wait and he could compromise. While Toyotomi Hideyoshi was strong, Tokugawa was content to maintain his status as just another regional lord, for as long as it took. In the end, he outlived his rivals and his road to total power came unblocked. Even so, he bided his time for another 17 years after Toyotomi Hideyoshi's death before steadily taking control of all Japan. After him, his descendants ruled over Japan for more than 200 years.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: 5) Settle the score in a single move. If you win a battle without ending the war, your victory is meaningless. Victory is a tool, not an objective. The objective is stability. It's possible to win a war and yet not secure a stable outcome. If you win 100 battles, and yet still have to keep fighting, what's the point in the hundred victories?

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Even when you win, people still die. And even if it's only the enemy's men who die, it would still be better for them to have lived and come over to your side. That's how you defeat your enemy and make yourself stronger at the same time. Sun Tzu's way of thinking has a strong emphasis on preservation - self-preservation, preservation of the people, preservation of cities, preservation of wealth and, ideally, preservation of enemy subjects so that you can bring them over to work for you. Only by doing all these things can you create universal stability.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: During the Warring States period, the Zhao general Li Mu was assigned to command a border garrison, to defend against Xiongnu raids. His strategy was to close the gates and focus entirely on training his troops.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: For years he didn't venture out to fight the enemy, which didn't please the King of Zhao. And so, the king decided to replace Li Mu with a different general. Just over a year after the new general took up his post, there was 'a new normal.' The signal fires were constantly lit, there was fighting each and every day. The lives of the Chinese people living in the borderlands was so disrupted that they couldn't take proper care of their farms, the Xiongnu people couldn't take proper care of their herds, and both sides suffered terrible loss of life.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Resentment between the two sides spiraled, and soon there was no peace to be had. The King of Zhao ultimately reinstated Li Mu. Frankly, he had no other options. Back in his post, Li Mu went on with his old strategy of avoiding battle and cutting off all contact with the Xiongnu. Several uneventful years went by at the border.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content:
The Xiongnu, without anything to steal, gradually let down their guard. Suddenly, Li Mu launched a major attack and wiped out over 100,000 Xiongnu fighters in one fell swoop, stabilizing the frontier and securing peace for the next dozen or more years. 6) ¡§Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him."
 
This is one of the best-known lines in Sun Tzu's The Art of War.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Earlier in this book, we looked in detail at many examples of these words from Chinese military history. We talked about how the word 'irregular' is the correct translation of the root Chinese character, although it is often mistakenly interpreted to mean 'extraordinary.' It means 'irregular' in the mathematical sense of 'odd,' as in 'even numbers and odd numbers.' It's the part of the army that's left over or kept in reserve - the card you keep up your sleeve until the crucial moment, before finally pulling it out and securing victory. This is known as 'The art of dividing forces,' and it's one of the most fundamental principles of battle tactics.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: It's indispensable in any armed conflict, whether you have an army of a million troops or, like Xiang Yu during his last stand by the River Wu, you're down to your last 28 cavalry soldiers. In both scenarios, you have to divide up your army into two forces that can cover each other.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Don't mass all your men together in a single unit. When Han Xin fought that famous battle with his back to a deep river, he didn't put his entire army up against the river. If he had, he really would have ended up as fish food that day.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Before the action started, he split off an auxiliary force and used it to set up an ambush. Then, at the crucial moment - when the battle hung in the balance - he suddenly sprang them into action. That was how he secured his victory.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: People tend to believe that by using surprise attacks you can defeat a much larger force, but this is the mentality of people who trust in their own luck. They're always thinking about what kind of fancy maneuver they can pull out of the bag, but Sun Tzu is here to tell them that there is no luck in the art of war. Fancy maneuvers go wrong, and the only way to do things is by following the rules of combat and the lessons from the art of war. 7) The Way of Deception just isn't important. ¡§The art of war is the way of deception." These words are from Sun Tzu's The Art of War, and that misleads a lot of people. They might think that the art of war is about the same kind of thing as The Thirty-Six Stratagems - namely, the use of deception to win wars. But, if your opponent doesn't bite, you can use deception until you're blue in the face and it won't do you any good. The art of deception is not a major part of the. These days, lots of publishing houses combine Sun Tzu's The Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems into a single book, which makes it seem like the art of war is all about clever stratagems and tricks.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is a mistake. 8) Know yourself and know your enemy, but remember that the key is to know yourself. ¡§If you know the enemy and you know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles." When people repeat these words, they tend to think more about knowing their enemy, and that it goes without saying that they know themselves. 'How could I not know myself,' they think.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But in reality, the crucial part of this formula is knowing yourself. This is because being undefeatable is entirely up to you. If you're strong and don't make mistakes, nobody else can do anything to get to you.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Yet, even if you do everything you can to know your enemy, you still might fall prey to their tricks. Sun Tzu's The Art of War covers a lot of ground, but it all comes back to getting your fundamentals right. Manage your own affairs properly, make yourself strong and wait until an opportunity presents itself.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Wait until you have the strongest possible grasp of the situation, and then make your move. Win first, fight later. Settle the score in a single move. If you're not strong, don't pretend to be. 9) The art of war doesn't teach you how to win.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: More than anything, it teaches you how to admit defeat. Why do people thrill to the words, 'I'll never surrender!' It's because they don't like to hear bad news; they're not willing to hear the truth when it doesn't fit their interests. Then there's the phrase, 'Admitting defeat is the only way to win!' People can, at a stretch, just about accept this concept, because the end result is still a win.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: But, what if the end result wasn't a win? What if it was still a loss? Can you accept losing? Before you began to seriously study Sun Tzu's The Art of War, you might have thought of it as a profound book about how to win in war.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: This is true, of course. Information about how to win wars and deep profundity - it's all here in this book. However, if by studying the art of war you can learn how to accept failure, then and only then have you truly stepped through the gates of wisdom. 1 'The Daily Necessities' in Chinese refers to firewood, rice, oil and salt.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: 2 The commentators wrote in very formal language, and the translation into English reflects that. The idea of this book is to introduce the formal language in a way that is similar to how it appeared in its original context, and then to break it down and expand on it in simpler, everyday language.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies

The book is not as yet available English. 5 Four-character idioms are pieces of received wisdom that have been embedded in the Chinese language and are used often in spoken and written language. 6 Ji has a variety of meanings, including 'stratagem,' 'plan,' 'calculation' and 'counsel.' Ji is central to Sun Tzu's The Art of War, and its meaning is discussed in Chapter One, The Value System of Sun Tzu's Art of War. 7 'The Daily Necessities' in Chinese refer to 'firewood, rice, oil and salt.'
8 Hong Xiuquan was the leader of the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom rebellion.

chapter: Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies
content: Hong claimed to be the brother of Jesus Christ. 9 The original text is so condensed and brief that it's hard to tell whether 'the army' refers to one's own army, or the enemy's. The various commentators have interpreted it in different ways. 10 'The past master' refers to the Tang dynasty Emperor Taizong, whose words were recorded in Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei. 12 As noted previously, the original text is so condensed and brief that it's hard to tell whether 'the army' refers to one's own army, or the enemy's.

If you wish to mention the author's name along with the title of the book, as is done repeated in these pages, it must be --> Su Tzu's The Art of War.
